Nearly 70% of investors surveyed by FTSE Russell agreed something needed to be done to ensure minimum voting rights for companies in its indexes, but what exactly is unclear. This [BLANK] to both the fear institutional investors have that they would have to buy companies where they wouldn't have a say and to complexity in addressing the issue. There was a roughly even split among investors between excluding only non-voting securities, excluding both voting and nonvoting securities, and reducing weighting.

Tesla may need to build a battery "gigafactory" in China to lower costs of its cars' power source. Dependence on Japan, South Korea and its gigafactory in Nevada for batteries could [BLANK] the electric-auto maker's costs in China, offsetting the benefits of vehicle production in Shanghai. Sourcing batteries from within China would reduce import duties and cut material costs due to local supplies of graphite, cobalt and lithium. The battery makes up as much as half the cost of a battery-only electric vehicle.

The Trans-Pacific Partnership trade deal, agreed on Oct. 5, is partly designed to boost cross-border trade in goods and services on a multi-year basis. This should [BLANK] welcome support for Japan, a key signatory, which has faced a weak economy, evidenced by September's 114.5 billion yen ($955 million) trade deficit vs. consensus expectations for a 87 billion yen surplus. The trade figure miss should help bolster efforts by Prime Minister Shinzo Abe to secure the deal's passage into law.

Mixed equity performance is key to watch for asset managers given it's a direct driver of asset values and fees and influences flows. The MSCI ACWI Index [BLANK] 1.8% in October, after a 4.8% gain in 3Q, with mixed regional performance. The U.S. S&P 500 fell 1.9% vs. September, Europe's Stoxx 600 declined 1.2% and Japan's Nikkei rose 5.9%. The MSCI Emerging Market Index gained 0.2%, with Brazil 11.2% higher and China's Shanghai Composite up 3.2%. Average prices are 2.5% above October 2015 as measured by the MSCI ACWI.

House leaders have three options now that a transportation panel has approved a $325 billion road bill: identify a way to pay for it, approve the Senate bill or pass another short-term patch. The House hasn't [BLANK] the big obstacle holding up the long-term road legislation: the gap between revenue and spending. The committee that approved the bill Oct. 22 can only set spending and policy and doesn't make revenue decisions, which come from a separate panel that hasn't unveiled a plan.

Casual-dining chains have underutilized the "to-go" opportunity, focusing instead on filling seats. Busy hostess stands and a lack of dedicated resources to [BLANK] orders can cause an unpredictable to-go customer experience. While many restaurants offer the option, any serious focus to make it a viable additional revenue stream remains nascent. Making it available requires some technology investment to improve order timing and accuracy. Applebee's, Outback and Olive Garden offer online ordering.

A $180 a share bid for Tesaro would give it an enterprise value of $9.13 billion. The company isn't expected to [BLANK] earnings-positive until 2020, making a standard valuation analysis challenging. The easiest comparison would be with Pfizer's $14 billion acquisition of Medivation in 2016, valued at 6x 2021 sales. At $9.1 billion, Tesaro would be worth 5.5x 2021 estimated sales of $1.7 billion. For both companies there's a significant amount of risk associated with long-range forecasts.

A securities prospectus routinely points readers to underlying contracts and agreements for the legal rights of stakeholders and descriptions of contracts. In the unusual case of Clear Channel Outdoor's cash management arrangement [BLANK] 13 years ago, however, that underlying pact points parties right back to the prospectus. Outdoor has relied on the "unambiguous" terms of this arrangement to justify its acquiescence to iHeartCommunications' persistent sweep of Outdoor's cash. We review in this report the unusual construction of the cash management arrangement, the history of litigation spawned from it, and the two current lawsuits that may offer a different reading of the contract. iHeart's plan confirmation process offers a window to potentially settle these lawsuits in the context of a deal with Outdoor.

Bank Indonesia may leave its seven-day reverse repo rate unchanged at 4.75%. Last month, the central bank sounded more dovish, noting [BLANK] price pressures from "weak" domestic demand and contained food prices. It shifted focus earlier this year to inflation from growth, to anchor price expectations as inflation started to reflect a jump in global oil prices. More recently, headline inflation has retreated, falling below 4%. Core inflation has been slowing since February.

Demand for pharmacy benefits manager services in the 2016 selling season may be in-line with the past few years. Catamaran has lost two health plan clients for 2016, though may be able to recapture clients by [BLANK] up the market to larger employer groups. CVS Health may be positioned to retain clients and win new business given its strong finish to the 2015 selling season, with net new business totaling $3.6 billion. Express Scripts' client retention may improve to the 94% to 97% range in 2016.

Thailand's banking sector may see a recovery in loans and narrowed margins in 2017. The nation's slow economic recovery and rising exports should be [BLANK] in stronger loan growth of 3-5%. Margin recovery could flounder on tighter liquidity, raising funding costs. The pace of time-deposits decline is slowing, suggesting banks have either shed most of their expensive deposits, or may be preparing their funding base for an increase in lending demand. Asset quality may remain under pressure in the near term.

Merck's better-than-expected 3Q results, while clearly positive, still leave room for work if sales and margin growth are to materialize. EPS beat consensus on higher sales, which partly [BLANK] from timing of Japan shipments, and better operating margins. Gardasil also beat estimates, yet this was partly offset by Januvia's miss. Keytruda's sales fell slightly short, but first-line lung approval and label expansion will help speed up its growth, offsetting an expected sales decline for Zetia on patent loss.

Long-acting bronchodilator LABA-LAMA combinations and monoclonal antibodies are being developed as asthma and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease rates rise. Two antibodies for asthma are under FDA and EU review: GlaxoSmithKline's mepolizumab and Teva's reslizumab, with reslizumab [BLANK] an FDA advisory panel in December. Phase III data of antibodies by AstraZeneca and Roche are expected 1H16. Novartis expects FDA action on Ultibro (LABA-LAMA). Click the image to open the Asthma-COPD Calendar.

Lawsuits against the Renewable Fuel Standard's 2014-16 rule face an uphill battle in voiding the rule entirely, but could result in its delayed implementation. Challenges to prior annual volume obligations [BLANK], at least with respect to the ethanol mandates set by EPA. Circumstances haven't changed enough with respect to the 2016 obligations that would merit the court to change course. A stay would suspend the March 31, 2017, deadline to demonstrate compliance for the 2016 standard.

The CVS-Aetna and Cigna-Express Scripts deals represent an effort to consolidate power and leverage as the pharmaceutical supply chain finds itself in an increasingly hostile environment. Both Republicans and Democrats in Congress are shining a spotlight on drug-rebate practices, and FDA Commissioner Scott Gottlieb sharply criticized the sector's impact on [BLANK] out-of-pocket expenses for individual patients in a March 7 speech. At the same time, the recently announced Amazon-JPMorgan-Berkshire Hathaway venture underscores corporate America's dissatisfaction with the health-care system.

Kingfisher's same-store sales fell in France in-line with the industry, hurt by external factors. The potential boost from an [BLANK] housing sector has yet to materialize. B&Q's sales were strong during peak trading, even with cool weather in June and Homebase shifting to an everyday-low-price strategy after Wesfarmer's takeover. While sales remain solid at Screwfix, competition in the tradesmen sector is increasing, with the Bunnings entry looming and a potential post-referendum slowdown in U.K. housing.

A potential rally in coal prices during 4Q may look a bit different relative to the 25% to 35% jump seen in 2014, given the many factors in play. While Powder River Basin prices could be pulled higher on restocking activity, the pace of the move may be [BLANK] as transport capacity is slowly restored. Appalachian coal, boosted by spiking natural gas prices in 2013, may be challenged as a more mild winter tempers coal burn from the region.

As mining-equipment demand enters an unprecedented fifth year of contraction, there are mixed signs of stabilization. The Parker Bay Surface Mining Index [BLANK] 6.6% sequentially in 3Q. It had fallen about 10-30% in the past six quarters before plummeting 41% in 2Q. Mining trucks and dozers posted sequential improvement. Russia grew for a 4th quarter, though most other regions worsened. A near-term new-equipment rebound is unlikely, with consensus calling for a 7% drop in mining capex in 2017.

Post-2Q Earnings Outlook: Spark Therapeutics' gene therapy, Luxturna, is off to a slow-but-steady launch as the company makes progress with payers, but we think consensus is achievable at the current rate of growth. Government coverage for gene therapy this year [BLANK] a key hurdle. The focus remains on the company's pipeline products for hemophilia A and B, which we view favorably despite competition from BioMarin. The partnership with Pfizer, which is now running the Phase III trial for hemophilia B, offsets some of the risks and costs for Spark.

Chicago Bridge & Iron, Aecom and other engineering companies may get incremental bidding opportunities from a government fund that may total $14 billion after a judge denied BP's effort to reduce the fine it faces for the 2010 Gulf of Mexico oil spill. A federal judge's Feb. 19 decision to side with the government's maximum $4,300 per-barrel penalty rather than BP's $3,000 [BLANK] limit makes a reduction in the $14 billion estimate for a Gulf coast restoration project fund less likely.

While property and casualty pricing in the U.S. has risen after one of the worst years ever for hurricane losses, the increases have been modest, particularly for reinsurance. European prospects remain mixed, with price increases [BLANK] and volume constrained. In the U.K., where auto-insurance prices have retreated, the outlook rests on enactment of the Civil Liability Bill, the timing of which remains uncertain. New data protection laws in Europe promise to increase demand for cyber insurance, though risk aggregation is a concern. Changing technology is also creating threats and opportunities in established markets, pushing insurers to embrace new technology to better understand risk and cut costs. The largest insurers in BI's European P&C insurance peer group include Allianz, Zurich, Sampo, Talanx, Mapfre, RSA and PZU.

The home and personal care Bull Case focuses on income growth in the middle and upper income brackets of emerging market consumers. This reflects rising demand for globally [BLANK], innovative, trusted and time-efficient consumer goods. These products are spread across many categories, including laundry, cleaning, beauty and personal care. Growth in mature markets, albeit at a slower pace, is built around brand trust and reliability at the right price points.

Gilead's black-box warning on liver toxicity doesn't hinder use, though it does make use more complicated, given the required monitoring, according to Dr. John Byrd of Ohio State University. Colitis that [BLANK] after 12 months of therapy is more of a concern and may prompt use of Johnson & Johnson-Pharmacyclics' Imbruvica in some patients. Imbruvica can't be used concomitantly with anticoagulation, which would promote use of alternatives such as Zydelig, said Dr. Gary Schiller of the University of California, Los Angeles.

Calpine's 3Q adjusted Ebitda fell 20% from a year earlier due to weak pricing, even as its total power generation peaked. Across its three regional segments, earnings from California operations fell most due to lower [BLANK] prices and the expiration of contracts at its Pastoria plant. Earnings also fell significantly in Texas, as higher wind penetration pressured power prices in the state. Calpine lowered its forecast for 2016 adjusted Ebitda based on weak quarterly performance.

Signature's revenue gains have slowed in recent quarters from a previously above-average clip as rising interest rates drag on the bank's top line. Analysts [BLANK] revenue increases of 4-5% in 2018-19. Net-interest income, which makes up the vast majority of the bank's revenue, will be driven almost entirely by continued strong loan growth, offsetting anticipated net-interest-margin pressure from the bank's liability-sensitive balance sheet. Deposit growth and rates are key swing factors. Signature Bank's return on equity may rise to 12% this year from the 10% of 2017, which was dragged down by elevated provisioning. ROE is typically slightly above most peers due to its commercial-focused, relationship-based business model that helps produce a best-in-class efficiency ratio.

Yahoo's share-price movement may remain more dependent on Alibaba trends, even if Verizon can wring a discount in Yahoo's core-asset value in the wake of a disclosed e-mail breach. Yahoo's stock has [BLANK] Alibaba's very closely over the last two years and since the Verizon deal announcement on July 25. Alibaba accounts for a significant portion of Yahoo's market cap. Verizon is reconsidering the acquisition and its value, due to the breach of 500 million Yahoo e-mail accounts in 2014.

Gold's robust 2007-16 price momentum was driven by eight elements. These [BLANK] the use of gold exchange-traded funds as a refuge in times of global financial or geopolitical crisis, dollar weakness and inflation, and low or negative interest rates. Also on the list is increasing demand from China and India, weak confidence in financial markets, greater global gold consumption and higher net central-bank purchases. The metal peaked at $1,921 an ounce in 2011 when gold met all eight criteria.

Bristol-Myers Squibb's immuno-oncology lead with Opdivo and Yervoy has led consensus to estimate 2020 sales of $8.9 billion, with Opdivo alone at $6.8 billion. While Bristol-Myers's first-mover advantage can't be [BLANK], three others are gunning for its franchise, including Roche, the oncology behemoth. An analysis of clinical trials suggests that Roche and Merck & Co. are running as many, or more, trials than Bristol-Myers in lung cancer, while Roche's trials involve almost as many patients as Bristol-Myers.

The spirits industry is undergoing a regeneration with "authentic" craft brands, and delivering on consumers' desire to enjoy different drinks on specific occasions. Companies [BLANK] to understand the factors behind such decisions. Significantly, price is not one of them, as consumers seem prepared to pay up for experiences. This lets companies innovate within their portfolios by focusing on heritage and local taste preferences, particularly with new, younger consumers, again driving growth in spirits consumption.

European powers are diverging on global bank capital accords. France and Germany wrenched concessions on output floors as Basel III was [BLANK], while the U.K. must grapple with the implications of Brexit. Swiss regulators, meanwhile, are having to delay their "gold standard" approach as other jurisdictions vacillate.

Besides $1.5 billion in writedowns and two years' delay, the Kemper project has now created an SEC investigation for Southern Co. investors. Accounting and disclosure on the $6.7 billion project were [BLANK] as the SEC's subjects of review. The disclosure came with an 18.3 million share offering to finance the AGL acquisition, but the SEC began reviewing Kemper last summer. Southern sees "no material impact," but the SEC, Kemper startup and Mississippi rate-making for the huge project are all overhangs.

Loan-growth estimates for U.S. consumer lenders are consistent with 2016's 5-10% rates, though rising credit-loss provision expense is expected to slow sharply from 2016's surge and be closer to the pace of loan gains. Loss rates should [BLANK] to rise toward long-term averages. Wide lending margins will likely get a further boost in the early stages of Federal Reserve rate hikes. Pressure from rewards costs should continue, reducing net fee revenue and offsetting much of the gains in net interest income.

European low-cost airlines continued expansion in July, likely pressuring yields. Capacity rose 3.4%, though Ryanair and Norwegian [BLANK] expansion. EasyJet increased capacity most with an 8% gain as it boosted leisure flights from its U.K. bases to Spain, Italy and France. Ryanair added 6% more capacity, with large gains in eastern Europe and plans to increase 10% to 15% in the winter, driven by a 20% increase in Ireland. All made load-factor gains, with Norwegian improving by 560 bps to 94.

The large seasonal buildup of U.S. gasoline stockpiles will put pressure on crack spreads in the short term, but demand supports expansion. Narrowing crude oil differntials could weigh on U.S. refiners as Cushing continues to drain, but growing shale production should [BLANK] spreads close to transportation costs.

Relative North American spot-trucking demand increased 2.3% sequentially to 14.6 in the week ended Oct. 21, as measured by Truckstop.com's Market Demand Index. Capacity [BLANK] as truck availability was little changed from the prior week, while the number of available loads rose 2.3%. Even though the spot market remains strained by weak fundamentals, the index is up 60% from last year amid easier comparisons with significantly looser capacity in 4Q15. Holiday demand may nudge the index higher into November.

Citigroup, JPMorgan and 20 other primary dealers named in investor antitrust lawsuits alleging collusion in the U.S. Treasuries market will likely seek dismissal of the cases before agreeing to any settlement. The anticipated dismissal motions may not come until 2Q because lead plaintiffs must first be chosen and a consolidated complaint filed, which might not [BLANK] until 1Q. As a result, a settlement, which would require court approval, may still be more than a year away.

Barclays and banks facing Department of Justice-led RMBS probes may not see much relief once Donald Trump's nominee for U.S. attorney general, Sen. Jeff Sessions, takes over. While Sessions hasn't specifically [BLANK] RMBS, he prosecuted banks during the savings and loan crisis and has said companies aren't too big to fail or jail. He co-sponsored a bill in 2009 to hire more prosecutors and agents for financial fraud cases. Lower level prosecutors on the RMBS cases are expected to stay on, providing continuity.

Recent results from various tech companies suggest strong adoption of the public cloud, which is likely to accelerate in 2016. Such a scenario may lead to a faster sales [BLANK] for IT outsourcing companies. The infrastructure outsourcing industry has been under pressure for the past few years due to public cloud adoption, increased use of software in data centers, shifting tech budgets, greater competition from low-cost providers and unbundling of contracts.

Net interest income could become a more positive metric for the larger Italian banks if the first signs that asset spreads are improving are sustained. One of the most significant surprises of 1Q results was the positive contribution to NII growth from [BLANK] asset spreads after medium- and long-term loans were repriced at Intesa and UniCredit. The stabilizing Euribor rate could have helped, but it's unlikely that there will be much improvement for smaller banks as loan competition remains high.

If GM, rated Ba1 by Moody's and BB+ at S&P and Fitch, posts 2015 and 2016 results in-line with consensus, its Ebit margin may exceed Nissan's, rated two to four steps higher, and approach Honda's, rated five to seven notches higher. GM's asset turnover already [BLANK] several higher-rated peers. Consensus expects sales growth of 3% at GM in 2015 vs. 7% at Ford. That may reflect both the introduction of the updated Ford 150 as well as the anticipated effect of GM's recalls.

The legal fight against the Environmental Protection Agency's methane rule will likely begin in earnest in 3Q17 when briefs may be scheduled for filing by the rule's challengers. The court continues to consider what to do with the rule while the challenge is pending, but has yet to [BLANK] the merits of the case. Briefing should take about two months, with a hearing to be scheduled after. From the date of the hearing, the court can be expected to issue an opinion in about three months, which may be as soon as 1Q18.

Pershing Square founder and investor Bill Ackman reiterated his claim July 22 that Herbalife is a fraudulent company. The definition of a pyramid scheme is when income in a multilevel marketing plan is primarily [BLANK] from recruiting new members and not from selling retail products. Herbalife issued an economic analysis claiming 97% of its products are bought for end-use consumption. The Federal Trade Commission and FBI are also investigating.

The 10-year Treasury yield is off of its lows, though apartment REIT debt remains at low rates vs. historic levels. Apartment REITs appear more likely to issue unsecured unsecured debt than equity in 2015 to [BLANK] debt maturities and fund development, especially with swap futures and analysts expecting the 10-year yield will rise further by year-end. Coupons on new bond issues are below those of maturing debt, which could cut apartment REIT interest expense and raise FFO as debt is refinanced.

Exxon Mobil has launched a multifaceted defense against subpoenas focused on what and when the company knew with regard to climate change. The subpoenas were [BLANK] by the state attorneys general for New York and Massachusetts and broadly seek internal company documents going back as far as 40 years. The focus of the investigations leading to the subpoenas is whether Exxon Mobil misled investors and consumers in each state and should have to take writedowns for the impacts of climate change.

Performance is the product of asset managers, and Invesco's long-term track record may support organic growth. The percentage of actively managed assets [BLANK] in the top half of related peer groups in 1Q was 83% on a five-year basis, 69% for three years and 65% for one year. Fixed-income performance ranges from 62-100% of fund assets ranked in the top half of related categories over five years. Among equities categories, global, European/U.K. and Asia, and U.S. Value are 85-98% of top-half-ranked assets.

Pricing pressure rose for European carriers in June, with U.S.-booked trans-Atlantic airfares falling on a euro basis. Non-premium fares fell 6.5% and premium were down 2% in euro terms, [BLANK] with a 1.6% decline in non-premium and 3% increase in premium on dollar basis. Jet fuel prices will have little effect on profits as they rose 100 bps and only 20% to 30% of costs are comprised of fuel.

Brazil's weakening economy has weighed heavily on construction growth following the ramp-up from the 2014 World Cup. Trailing 12-month sales of construction materials [BLANK] 3.5% in July, its seventh consecutive month, as the Brazilian central bank continued monetary tightening. Slowing construction is challenging one of chemicals top end-markets and a driver of demand for coatings and vinyls. A $65 billion infrastructure package may be the only salve, which if passed, would go into effect in 2016.

Alaska Air is refreshing its fleet to improve efficiency and customer appeal and reduce costs. In 2016, 17 Boeing 737-900ERs will [BLANK] older and less-efficient 737-400s. In a marked change in strategy, Alaska ordered 30 regional Embraer E-175s with deliveries starting in 2017. Those will serve longer-distance though less popular routes, as Alaska seeks to add destinations and effectively compete with Delta out of the Northwest. The E175s will be flown by Horizon and replace some of the Q400 turboprop fleet.

The traditional winter season, an anchor for natural-gas fundamentals, has ended with demand or heating degree days near seasonal lows. Storage [BLANK] swollen with inventories 13% above the five-year average, but below last year as the demand lull of the off-peak season awaits. Sentiment has retreated and prices have faded almost 15% this year. While pipeline exports to Mexico and LNG flows have offered modest support, balances remain loose. Volume will likely move higher as capital spending accelerates.

Liberty Global has adopted a leveraged equity strategy that rests on debt-funded acquisitions to fuel growth. Taking on its total debt of about $41 billion would raise Vodafone's post-merger net leverage to about 3.1x in an all-share deal, [BLANK] it to the top of its telecom peers. While investors have tolerated high leverage for still strong cable growth prospects, this may not apply to a company that would generate 65% of its revenue from mobile operations.

A tax-accounting policy that eliminates interest expense could shift more than $175 billion on S&P 500 income statements, or about 14% of projected 2018 index earnings of $1.24 trillion. Total S&P 500 interest expense ([BLANK] the financials sector) was $151.1 billion in 2016, up 14% year-over-year and up an average of 9.8% annually for the last three years. As a share of Ebitda, interest expense was 9.6% last year and averaged 8.7% in 2014-16.

North American telecom carriers reduced capital spending beginning in 2H14, with AT&T proposing some of the biggest cuts. Leading equipment suppliers, [BLANK] Alcatel-Lucent, Cisco, Ericsson, Juniper and Nokia, said declines in service provider capital spending in North America have been a drag on their revenue growth. Capital spending should remain low as these carriers wind-down large network upgrade projects and focus instead on targeted capacity enhancements.

The Nexus Pipeline project is sitting idle in the regulatory process as FERC awaits a third commissioner before it can make the decision to grant a certificate for the project to proceed. The pipeline, extending from Ohio to Ontario by way of Michigan, is [BLANK] to deliver 1.5 Bcf of natural gas a day across about 250 miles of pipe, carrying Marcellus and Utica gas to Canada. DTE Energy and Spectra Energy Partners, the project's lead developers, continue to project a 2H in-service date despite regulatory delays.

Goldman Sachs led equity issuance in 2014, though its market share shrank. Morgan Stanley reclaimed second place, as JPMorgan [BLANK] back to third. Bank of America (No. 4) and Citigroup (No. 5) maintained their 2013 rankings. Deutsche Bank moved into sixth place ahead of UBS, while Credit Suisse and Barclays held steady. RBC returned to the top 10, while Wells Fargo fell out, below HSBC and Nomura.

Splunk is maintaining its lead in the $3 billion core machine-log analytics market. Demand for the company's products is [BLANK] by rising enterprise spending on big-data technologies. The use of Splunk's products across large markets such as operations management, security and fraud management will likely aid its momentum.

Jewelers will likely increase selections of affordable items in China to boost spending by younger shoppers at stores and online. The price gap between merchandise sold by luxury jewelers such as Chow Tai Fook and the fashion accessories by Pandora could [BLANK], resulting in more competition.

Two weeks before Christmas, store traffic remains weak relative to last year amid a shift to digital shopping and more gifting of experiences. North American traffic at apparel retailers [BLANK] 18.2% in the week ended Dec. 17, according to Prodco. Overall retail traffic dragged 16.4% and was 14.5% lighter at luxury stores. Declines are likely to be less pronounced the week before Christmas -- especially on Dec. 24 -- as shipments in time for the holiday aren't guaranteed, forcing shoppers into stores.

The global pulp market is being tested by weakening supply and demand fundamentals. Prices continue to [BLANK] across regions and grades. Although shipments ended 2015 on a strong note and producer inventories are at balanced levels, the industry is being challenged by excessive supply and the devaluation of China's renminbi. While recent list prices in North America and Europe are unchanged, the net price has fallen as discounts have increased. Rising production could limit a price recovery near term.

Farm-equipment sales may remain pressured by persistently low corn prices. Corn-ending stocks were 5% above consensus after the production estimate was [BLANK] to a record 15.2 billion bushels on record yields of 175.1 bushels per acre. While this prompts higher feed and residual usage, the forecast for so-called ending stocks was raised to 2.081 billion, the highest since 1987-88. The USDA's August WASDE report projected 2016-17 corn price of $3.15 is 25 cents below July's, and 40% less than 2014's prior peak.

If the recent rally in carbon and power prices holds, it's likely to keep improving the earnings outlooks and shares of most EU utilities (such as EDF), though some stocks still don't fully reflect fundamentals. Coal-fired generators ([BLANK] RWE and EPH) could be the net beneficiaries if the carbon-market rally reverses.

Copper traded on both the CME and LME set new futures open interest (OI) and net managed-money long-position records in November, indicating potential excessive optimism in the shorter term. This also indicates the multiyear copper lows reached in February may [BLANK] a longer-term bottom for prices. Up 41% in 2016 as of Nov. 28, combined CME and LME copper open interest was last exceeded on an annual basis by the 48% increase in the crisis recovery year of 2009, when CME copper futures gained 137%.

Exxon Mobil's defense against a lawsuit brought by New York state will likely be a drawn out affair, lasting years, though we expect the ultimate outcome won't have much financial impact on the company. The state alleges that Exxon misled investors in what proxy calculations were used to [BLANK] the impact of climate change.

Producing more DRAM on smaller transistors may cause wafer growth to contract through 2015, according to SEMI data. Making chips with smaller transistors is more complex and [BLANK] more assembly steps. Even though wafer output is lost, Micron, Samsung and Hynix still do it to benefit from higher sales and margins yielded from higher-gigabyte chips with smaller transistors. With supply and demand balanced, increased production time cuts wafer output yet boosts pricing.

Further investments and contracts in 2014 to export U.S. ethane to Europe and Asia have fueled concern on threats to the U.S. chemicals feedstock price advantage. U.S. companies suggest either that ethane supply will continue to exceed demand, or that ethane is not an economically viable feedstock once [BLANK] overseas. Yet buyers and exporters have continued committing to decade-long supply agreements, and building significant new assets to feed ethane to plants overseas.

Citigroup has fallen from the leading spot among U.S. equity underwriters in 2015, though maintains its recovery to top three in 2012-14, similar to 2002-08 ranks. JPMorgan [BLANK] the lead, and has improved longer-term from its pre-financial crisis rankings. Goldman Sachs has fallen from its top three positions in 2013-14. Credit Suisse and Deutsche Bank are higher than 2008, and UBS is lower. Bank of America has been in the top four, and Barclays and Wells Fargo have been in the top 10 since crisis acquisitions.

Building permits, a more reliable and leading indicator of residential construction, fell 8% from a year earlier (on a non-seasonally adjusted basis), due to a 23% drop in the multifamily segment. Conversely, builders [BLANK] 6% more permits for new single-family homes. On a regional basis, single-family permits rose 14% in the West, 6% in the South and 3% in the Midwest and fell 10% in the Northeast. In 2016, building permits slipped 1%, with the single-family segment up 7% and the multifamily segment down 13%.

Should Aetna and Humana choose to appeal a U.S. district court's Jan. 23 decision to block their proposed merger, they could do so until mid-March, though they would likely file their notice of appeal earlier than that. They have 60 days from the date of the court order to lodge an appeal, after which the appellate court would set up a schedule for the filings [BLANK] the basis of the appeal and rebuttals by the Department of Justice. Once the briefing is done, oral arguments would follow.

Tencent is likely to continue to increase sales of games and other value-added services by operating China's largest social-networking and entertainment platform. People seek fun and pay for game-related virtual items to convey status, foster social interaction and [BLANK] character advancement in games. Game sales still account for close to 50% of Tencent's total revenue. Mobile games, whose sales grew 113% in 2Q, were 56% of online game revenue, and will likely remain Tencent's main driver of revenue growth.

A bill eliminating Obamacare's tax on health insurers has little chance of enactment in 2015 or 2016 even with majority support in the House. Pressure to [BLANK] the tax could mount in 2017 as a new president takes office and insurers pass the cost on to consumers via higher premiums. In the near term, the need to find $145 billion over 10 years to offset the government's loss of the tax, and a probable veto from President Barack Obama, should prevent this bill from becoming law.

Shoe retailers' September preliminary sales finished 1.7% lower than a year earlier after rebounding from a 3.7% drop in the first half of the month. Store traffic increased, [BLANK] the decline through Sept. 25 to 2.7% from 4.2% at midmonth, according to SpendTrend point-of-sale data. The category's sales have fallen every month this year, potentially dragging down revenue at large fashion-focused shoe retailers such as DSW and Brown Shoe.

The North American packaged-food group's sharp outperformance of the S&P 500 through Oct. 31 has been boosted by a high number of deals, punctuated by the $55 billion acquisition of Kraft Foods in July. Rising interest in the group by private equity and activist investors is also [BLANK] group valuations. Industry profit growth in 2016 may be further pressured by weak packaged food demand, shifting preferences and adverse currency exchange. Low input costs may be a mitigating factor.

Hyperscale public cloud companies can outspend most IT departments as well as pure-play security companies to better protect their infrastructure against cyber attacks. Also, the homogenous nature of cloud architecture makes it less vulnerable to attacks compared with those that have a number of different products [BLANK] together. Greater data sovereignty and privacy requirements by governments across the globe are also a key differentiator for Microsoft and Amazon, which have data centers in most regions.

Merck & Co. led large pharma's earnings outperfomance in 2Q, driven by solid sales of Keytruda and Zepatier along with lower operating expenses, though costs will increase on R&D investment and efforts to remediate the cyberattack. AstraZeneca benefited from cost cuts, partly due to phasing, but its outperformance was eclipsed by the Mystic trial setback which [BLANK] an anticipated EPS rebound in 2018 and benefits Merck's Keytruda. Eli Lilly beat on robust sales across its drug portfolio.

Valuation ratios of western European utilities have declined to a median 7.6x consensus EV/Ebitda, representing the fifth-lowest industry in the region. This follows the long-term trend of declining ratings, [BLANK] from falling demand for conventional power generators since 2009. Repeated political intervention in market structures and customer tariffs have also weighed. Ebitda estimates continue to slide on fears that, after a four-year decline, power prices may fall further amid the rout in commodities.

Infosys will have to expand its arsenal of next-generation IT products to increase future sales, which have been spotty in the past few quarters. Industry-wide pricing pressure and investments in onshore delivery centers may [BLANK] long-term operating margin, currently one of the highest at about 25%.

Tariffs per megawatt-hour sold by coal-fired plants in China fell substantially in 1H with government cuts. The reduction may continue, [BLANK] the return on equity of Huadian, Huaneng, CR Power, Datang and other developers. Tariff pressure means the coal-power companies will resist higher coal prices. The government's gradual push to have more power sold on open markets, which have lower prices, further pressures developers' ROE.

Eli Lilly's revenue is at risk in lawsuits against Teva over proposed generic versions of its osteoporosis drug Forteo. Though the patents [BLANK] in 2019, the 30-month stay lifts in 2018. If Teva launches when the stay expires, Lilly could lose revenue in a year when analyst estimates place the drug's revenue near its record. Forteo brought in $1.3 billion in fiscal 2015, or 6.8% of Lilly's revenue, while consensus places peak revenue above $1.4 billion in 2017 and 2018.

ProSieben expects to gain from the impetus new entrants, such as Netflix, and ARD, are likely to inject into video-on-demand growth in Germany, as the company maintains its leading share (36%). Subscription-VoD revenue in Germany may [BLANK] more than 5x to 383 million euros ($512 million) by 2019, according to Gold Media. ProSieben will step up promotion of Maxdome in 2H, using reach on its core TV channels, and distributor platforms T-Entertain, Xbox One, and Google Chromecast.

Recent changes to Wal-Mart's online strategy could see the retailer play up its everyday price position, free two-day shipping and additional discounts for pickup-at-store items, as well as some special offers, as Amazon.com's annual Prime Day (July 11) approaches. "Dare to Compare" promotions on Walmart.com [BLANK] prices that are equal or below those at Amazon, Best Buy, Target and others on select items. Wal-Mart may also be able to leverage Jet.com to compete with some of Amazon's promotions on higher-end goods.

Philippines casino operators are luring foreign gamblers, especially from China, to expand gaming revenue given the limited gains from mass-oriented domestic gamblers. Yet more resorts in Metro Manila and Cebu are [BLANK] cannibalization risks with Entertainment City's cluster of integrated resorts. Other rising Asia gaming hubs pose as long-term competitive threats.

Aetna topped peers as its Medicare Advantage membership grew 21% in January, while CVS' Part D membership widened 11%. Industry MA enrollment [BLANK] 8% and UnitedHealth and Anthem grew faster than the market. Humana added 7% more members, which is slightly below its 7.4-8.2% outlook.

The settlement Reynolds American entered on May 26 with the FTC to acquire Lorillard won't be final until a 30-day public comment period has expired, but this is unlikely to be of consequence. The 30-day period is a standard FTC operating procedure and it is rare that settlement terms are [BLANK] before finalization. This deal is particularly unlikely to be affected, given that the primary settlement terms have been publicly known for some time and detractors have had ample time to express views to the FTC.

The number of complaints from Chinese consumers about online shopping reached 30% of the total this year, according to China state TV's annual expose on World Consumer Rights Day. Quality control at online shops is difficult because products and services are [BLANK] unexamined. It is particularly challenging for platform operators, such as Alibaba, which don't operate or own shops. JD.com and Vipshop should offer higher quality control because they have their own inventory procurement and delivery divisions.

Citizens expects fee income growth to accelerate in 2017, emphasizing strength in commercial-side capital markets and interest rate and foreign exchange risk management. It [BLANK] 5% fee income growth vs. 2016's adjusted 2% and consensus' 1%. The bank's 2017 net interest income growth may slow along with the boost in commercial lending from companies taking advantage of lower rates, though that borrowing remains strong. Citizens said higher GDP could make up the demand, but it's not seeing that yet.

A challenge to a European patent can at times highlight the strength of its U.S. counterpart, given patent laws are highly harmonized across jurisdictions. A European patent may be [BLANK] within nine months of issue by filing a request to the European Patent Office. Opposition requests can be filed by multiple parties, even anonymously. The EPO must decide whether to grant the request and generally holds an oral hearing before issuing a judgment. The judgment can be appealed to the EPO Appeal Board.

A decline in printing, and not the use of non-branded ink and toner, is the key reason for weak sales of supplies. HP Inc. has [BLANK] that price volatility from weaker currencies can drive customers to use ink refills and non-branded toner cartridges for its printers, but Gartner data shows less than 30% of supplies come from vendors other than the printer makers. Emerging markets and home consumers are still the main users of non-branded supplies. HP may be regaining share in ink and cartridges in these segments.

Earnings revisions following 1H bank results reflect a stark contrast between German financials Deutsche Bank and Commerzbank and CEE-focused Erste Bank. Upgrades of more than 6% at Erste and Credit Agricole contrast with further earnings cuts at Deutsche, Commerzbank and RBS, where capital concerns and a deteriorating outlook continue to [BLANK] the agenda. On average, 2016 EPS forecasts for large-cap EU banks have fallen 3% since results were released and 9% over three months.

Even after some energy efficiency measures (S.535) became law in 2015, both chambers have prioritized additional legislation. Measures in S.720 [BLANK] in a broader Senate energy bill and one or both may get votes in the fall. S.720 is uncontroversial, while the energy bill contains more contentious language such as expediting liquefied natural gas exports. The efficiency programs may have the best shot in the standalone bill which is less likely to attract divisive amendments.

The anticipated recovery in corporate loans from a raft of ECB measures is likely to be gradual after Mario Draghi rued the ``painfully slow'' lending to the real economy in recent years. Euro-zone net corporate lending fell 9% to 4.28 trillion euros ($5.4 billion) in August from the end of 2011, even after the ECB [BLANK] 1 trillion-euros in 2012. Draghi reitereated the need for structural reforms, including tax, to quicken new start-ups and credit applications.

Despite increasing political rhetoric over breaking up the largest banks, it's unlikely U.S. lawmakers will pass that type of legislation in 2017. Many Republicans would rather take a first stab at [BLANK] Dodd-Frank. If those efforts fail next year, Republicans may instead look to curtail large banks' activities in order to achieve regulatory reform for smaller banks -- something Democrats may support. If that's the case, it's unlikely that Congress will push for a formal separation of banking units.

Cement is the most energy-intensive manufacturing industry, according to the U.S. Energy Information Administration, with energy costs about a quarter of material expense. Boosting energy efficiency, as well as sourcing alternative fuels, such as biomass and solid waste, can [BLANK] operating costs. ACC reports the lowest energy use per ton of clinker, followed by Ambuja Cements and Taiheiyo Cement. CRH's 8.1% improvement leads peers reporting over five years, while Cemex trails with a 5.4% increase.

Lockheed's F-35, the only stealth fighter in production, is integral to the future of the U.S. and allied militaries. Over 3,000 are expected to be built, [BLANK] a diverse set of aircraft, including the fleet-leading F-16. Timeliness and costs have improved, and an approaching multiyear contract should bolster confidence in the $400 billion program, though technological and budgetary risks remain. An acceleration of a follow-on fighter, which appears to be 15-20 years away for now, could be a long-term threat.

Caterpillar's global dealer machinery sales, a bellwether for construction and mining equipment, were weak in April on tepid worldwide economic growth. Sales fell 11%, [BLANK] a two-year decline led by mining-equipment weakness. North America sales rose 5% after a 12% year-ago gain, as both construction and mining-equipment sales increased. Declines slowed to 9% in Europe, the Middle East and Africa after a 17% slump a month earlier. Latin America plunged 44%, adding to a 34% drop in March.

The number of year-round vacant housing units (total vacant units less seasonal vacancies) declined 1.1% in 3Q vs. the prior year to about 13.5 million, according to the U.S. Census Bureau's Housing Vacancy Survey. This [BLANK] there may be about 2.1 million excess vacant units, the number of vacancies above the historical norm of about 8.5% of the total housing stock. A higher level of vacancies is one factor contributing to a slower pace of new home construction.

Bipartisan support in Congress boosts prospects for a 2014 revival of the Section 179 tax benefit, which allows farmers and other machinery buyers to immediately deduct certain new and used capital purchases as an expense. In 4Q, Congress will likely reinstate the $500,000 annual expensing limit that was in place for three years before [BLANK] in 2013. The current limit is $25,000. Section 179 reinstatement could lift machinery sales for Deere, Agco and others.

Retailers' margins typically suffer when input prices as measured by the Producer Price Index (PPI) rise faster than selling prices. Consumer Price Index (CPI) data for food bought for at-home consumption shows inflation has [BLANK], with deflation a larger concern than too-high inflation. Retailers typically prefer food inflation in the 2-3% range. The PPI fell below CPI levels in early 2015, ending a trend extending from 2012 that created a sustained period of margin pressure for retailers.

Recent AB InBev innovations such as Bud Light Lime-a-Ritas have established a new beverage category and expanded its reach to include more women. The products also cater to millennial consumers [BLANK] a wider variety of choice and taste. While costs may rise, new volume may be serviced from the existing asset base. High pricing may encourage switching to other alcoholic beverages. Budweiser price increases trailed inflation before the InBev acquisition, a situation since corrected.

The success of cloud-based applications from Dropbox, Box and Slack has disrupted the $13 billion collaboration software, where sync-and-share is the fastest growing segment. This trend is likely to continue as the cloud segment of the market is expected to grow 16% a year through 2020, while the on-premise segment continues to [BLANK]. Among large vendors, Google continues to gain share while Microsoft is protecting its market dominance with increasing adoption of Office 365.

Biotech and pharma events include Phase III data on Synergy's plecanatide for irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) with constipation and Cosmo's CB-17-01 colon-cancer diagnostic agent. Phase II data are [BLANK] for Clovis' rucaparib pivotal ovarian cancer trial, Ablynx's respiratory syncytial virus drug and Synthetic's SYN-004 for Clostridium difficile. Galena's NeuVax Phase III breast cancer trial has an interim analysis. RedHill awaits RHB-102 pivotal trial data in acute gastroenteritis and gastritis.

Short interest for U.S. solar energy peers has fallen in the trailing 12 months on rising equipment demand ahead of Section 201 trade policy concerns. The implementation of cost-reduction plans is starting to [BLANK] margins, with First Solar and SunPower's shift from dropping projects into their joint yieldco to selling them to third parties boosting project values. Distributed-solar peers face lower competition as Tesla scaled back installations, with a focus on profitability over growth adding value.

Biotech and specialty pharmaceuticals companies concerned about Hillary Clinton's proposals should note that some of her ideas, such as allowing HHS to negotiate drug prices directly and imposing higher Medicare rebates, have been repeatedly put forth by President Barack Obama or congressional Democrats and ignored by the Republican-led Congress. Her proposals to [BLANK] corporate write-offs for drug advertisements and increase funding for the FDA's Office of Generic Drugs may receive more serious consideration.

Deutsche Bank, Societe Generale and Standard Chartered face U.S. probes for potential violations of Iran or other trade sanctions. Deutsche [BLANK] with the Fed and New York's Financial Services Department for $258 million yet still faces other agency investigations, including one related to about $10 billion in trades that may have breached sanctions against Russia. SocGen has disclosed talks with the U.S. over possible trade sanctions violations, as has StanChart, despite having paid almost $1 billion in fines.

Good governance principles dictate executives should use company money to buy shares at the same price as they would with their own. The process of steam-cracking natural gas liquids (such as ethane), or oil-based feedstocks (e.g. naphtha) into olefins, can produce varying amounts of co-products depending on the feedstock used. A steeper yield curve is positive for interest margins because banks tend to fund longer-term loans with short-term deposits. Citigroup is in the process of settling claims related to 68 mortgage-backed securities trusts for about $1.13 billion. Signs of a Brexit reconciliation may be the cure for an ailing pound, but they're an ironic weight around the neck of shares. British companies with international exposure are at most risk to [BLANK] cold in this scenario, with the health-care sector as the poster child.

On the Las Vegas Strip, Malaysia's Genting and Australia's Crown Resorts are developing resorts targeted to open 2018. While the focus for understanding the profitability of online grocery has been on picking and delivery charges, greater levels of competition mean that customer acquisition costs are becoming more important. Japan automakers' currency losses may surge in 2016 due to the yen's sudden strength in February. Wireless carriers around the world are poised to deploy 5G services starting in 2019. Dynegy may raise its $717 million forecast for total capacity earnings for 2016-17 and 2017-18 following PJM's incremental auctions scheduled for this month and next. As rival Western Digital acquires SanDisk to address a product gap amid rising sales of solid-state drives, Seagate continues to stress the necessity of hard drives and investments in tech advances for capacity, performance and areal density. Same-store sales rose above the total retail increase of 1.7% in four of 12 retail categories, according to First Data. Novartis' secukinumab faces an FDA panel on Oct. 20 for its use to treat psoriasis, following a 4Q13 biologic license application filing. Sanofi-Regeneron's dupilumab could have best-in-class efficacy in severe asthma, phase II data show, yet it's unlikely to launch before 2018. Luck could run out for casinos on the Louisiana Gulf Coast as Tropical Storm Harvey causes record rainfall. September supermarket sales in Brazil grew at the highest rate in five months, at 7.25% in nominal terms, according to ABRAS, Brazil's supermarket association, which tracks 130 retailers across 2,800 stores. Diesel demand, used mainly for industry and transportation, fell 6.1% in 1Q, even as China's industrial-output growth started to pick up this year. Drug pricing continues to be a key focal point of the pharmaceutical and biotech industry discussions, on the one hand inviting criticism -- particularly by politicians -- but on the other, as a source of driving revenue growth.
