If the use of these allowances is vetoed and bankers then quit London, anitpathy toward the EU may escalate.

The rise of Vanguard's low-cost model is transferring wealth away from financial middlemen and toward investors' accounts. For every $3 trillion in assets, hedge funds take in $54 billion in fee revenue, while active mutual funds [BLANK] $22 billion and ETFs $8 billion. Vanguard, by comparison, collects just under $4 billion. Though the current bull market is making up for the loss in fee revenue, it will end eventually, likely leading to industry consolidation.

Unplanned refinery shutdowns occur regularly, though it's unknown how much capacity will go offline. If average unplanned shutdowns for the Gulf Coast and Cushing regions are similar to those of the last 10 years, it's unlikely that either region will [BLANK] maximum storage capacity by summer. The wild card is the level of unplanned outages. Oil stockpiles are likely to be higher by midyear, pressuring oil prices. Sustained higher oil prices are unlikely without OPEC changing course or U.S. production slowing.

Weekly data compiled by the EIA offer insights into cyclical natural gas storage flows and fundamentals during cooling and heating seasons. Monitoring wellhead production data from PointLogic [BLANK] supply information. The data, supplemented by cyclical weather trends, structural shifts in demand from power generation and industrial demand, and pipeline and LNG exports, can help draw conclusions about U.S. natural gas supply-demand balances. These are key components of the natural gas pricing mosaic.

Consensus estimates imply that the median efficiency ratio among BI-tracked banks will tick down 1 bp in 2016 and 2017. Zions, Citizens and Regions, which are executing on profitability initiatives, may [BLANK] big improvements over the next two years. KeyCorp, BB&T and Huntington may also see relatively more improvement as they close on announced deals and extract cost synergies from them. Fifth Third's efficiency ratio may rise the most, driven by its elevated investments this year.

A proposed antitrust class-action by end buyers of generic ursodiol is in its infancy, yet could expose Lannett, Actavis and Epic Pharma to multimillions of dollars in damages. The drugmakers are [BLANK] of colluding to increase the drug price by 200% in 2Q14 and maintaining such pricing to present. The companies are the leading manufacturers of the drug, with combined 2014 sales of $370 million constituting 98.3% of the generic ursodiol market. The risk grows if direct purchasers join the litigation.

Class I rails' median 3Q EPS beat consensus by 4.4%, though expectations were low due to weak volume. Productivity gains aided most rails, while others, such as Union Pacific, also [BLANK] EPS declines by accelerating the pace of buybacks. Norfolk Southern beat estimates by the widest margin (11.1%), yet its EPS fell 12.3% vs. 3Q14, which was worst among all Class I rails. EPS jumped 19% on average for Canadian Pacific and Canadian National, fueled by improved network efficiencies and the weak Canadian dollar.

If the D.C. Circuit says the FCC's net-neutrality order violates the Communications Act, the case would be a serious candidate for U.S. Supreme Court review. Though the Supreme Court refuses to [BLANK] more than 95% of cases it's asked to take, the U.S. government has a much better record there. The court has granted almost 70% of the U.S.'s petitions since 2011. Chances of high court review of an FCC loss dip, however, if a Republican wins the White House or if the D.C. Circuit decides the case on a procedural issue.

The proportion of enhanced annuities, underwritten using health and lifestyle information, increased to 29% in 2Q from 25% a year earlier. The proportion of small pension pots used to purchase [BLANK] annuities rose as well as the proportion of external annuities that are enhanced. Twelve providers now offer enhanced annuity rates. Enhanced annuities may provide as much as 40% more income for life than a standard product.

Should Apple launch an Android app for Apple Music, as reported by USA Today, the company could more than double its total addressable market of smartphones and potential revenue from the service. In the U.S., Apple has an installed base of 114 million iPhones, [BLANK] 45.6% of the total installed base vs. Android's 50.7% share, according to IDC. By enabling Android users to access Apple Music, its U.S. total addressable market would expand to 240.8 million smartphones, 2.1x the iOS base.

Ratings companies have addressed low commodity prices by downgrading industry participants such as Chevron, which was reduced to AA- by S&P. While stressed fundamentals will continue to affect industry dynamics, Chevron says it can [BLANK] additional debt during this period without compromising its financial strength. Incremental debt capacity of almost $30 billion would raise its debt ratio to 30%. This additional financial flexibility could support dividends or inorganic growth.

Asset quality trends at Indian banks should continue to kindle investor focus. India's banking system gross nonperforming-loan ratio [BLANK] to 10.2% in September and may rise further in fiscal 2H18 ending March before it improves. A gradual shift toward recognizing stressed loans as impaired, and raising provisions against these, are steps forward in addressing the banks' asset-quality woes. New regulations and reviews are a step toward corrective action, but banks may face more pain before asset quality improves. Timely disclosure, provision and recovery for bad assets are key to restoring investor confidence.

Originated intermodal traffic rose 6.6% in the week ended Aug. 2 (week 31), compared with last year, AAR data show. Union Pacific led the week (14.2% higher) as it continues to take share from BNSF (down 4.4%), the only rail to decline, while it [BLANK] service issues. Canadian National (up 12.9%) followed, expanding its intermodal business through share gains at Prince Rupert Port. North American intermodal volumes are 5.9% higher this year.

Wells Fargo's exposure in a lawsuit brought by BlackRock, Pimco, Prudential Financial and other mortgage-bond investors is likely lower than the $32.2 billion in alleged trust losses. Wells Fargo, [BLANK] in its capacity as trustee, may reduce damages risk by getting derivative claims tossed, as trustees have done in similar cases. Based on a $69 million settlement of a similar case against Bank of America, this suit's potential high-end settlement value may be about $673 million.

BI's Asia-Pacific large-capitalization telecom peer group ended 2015 with an enterprise-value-to-Ebitda ratio of about 5.7x, trailing the MSCI Asia Index. Valuations of Chinese telcos [BLANK] Asia-Pacific peers. China Mobile's 3.8x EV/Ebitda was highest domestically, with its share price the most resilient during the stock market's slump, due to its dominance in the country. Valuation multiples of telcos in South Korea and Southeast Asia declined amid weaker share prices and earnings prospects.

Biotech IPO trends made a turnaround in 2017, finishing the year strong vs. a declining 2016, driven by a surge in 2H. There is already $500 million worth of planned IPOs in the pipeline for 2018, giving hope that the trend will [BLANK]. Venture capital funding improved in 2017, and 2018 is already off to a robust start.

Plans to introduce a financial transaction tax in 11 of 28 EU nations are moving slowly as a result of steadfast opposition from the 17 other states. Any EU country that wants to impose the tax later can, yet many, including the U.K. and other hedge-fund hubs like Ireland, Luxembourg and Malta, are [BLANK]. Talks are ongoing at the EU level, as lawmakers seek to fine-tune provisions on international reach and the treatment of derivatives. Plans are unlikely to be approved before the end of 2015.

Shares of North American railroad peers are up 11% in 2018 through Nov. 15, about 900 bps more than the S&P 500, fueled by volume growth and strong pricing power as a result of tight trucking capacity. Gains are led by CSX's 31% on precision [BLANK] railroad productivity improvements, while Kansas City Southern is the only peer to decline (down 4.5%).

Skilled-nursing REITs fell more than the health-care REIT average in October, with Omega Healthcare falling 10.2% and Care Capital Properties dropping 6.8%. In addition, [BLANK] peer HCP (down 9.8%) and Welltower (8.4% lower) were among the worst-performers in October as they worked toward reducing their skilled-nursing exposure. HCP executed its spinoff of Quality Care Properties on Oct. 31, and Welltower announced plans to sell $1.7 billion of its skilled-nursing properties in 4Q.

Men's and women's apparel sales continued to deteriorate in mid-August as store traffic weakened. Sales [BLANK] 2.5% during the first two weeks of the month, according to SpendTrend's non-cash point-of-sale data. A 30-bp increase in average amount spent failed to offset a 2.8% decline in transaction volume. Category sales have fallen every month this year, potentially hurting retailers with a larger men's and women's presence, such as Ralph Lauren and J. Crew.

A key reason for the creation of loan-loss provisioning standards, IFRS 9 (to be phased in, transitionally, from 2018), was the failure of existing accounting rules to drive appropriate, timely provisioning following the 2008 crisis. Germany, Greece and Italy have significant banking industries with no additional provisioning guidelines [BLANK] beyond the backward-looking IAS 39 approach. A binding, harmonized system will be tough to create but is essential to level the playing field for EU banks.

A majority of software vendors, including Microsoft, SAP and Oracle, are transitioning from a traditional license-based sales model to subscriptions. In this model, users pay a recurring fee rather than a large upfront payment and the software is generally [BLANK] via the cloud. This change increases insight into revenue but compresses margins in the short term. The deferral of revenue to future quarters and the cost of investing in cloud infrastructure are the main reasons for margin compression.

Exelon, Entergy and NRG have the most capacity imperiled -- more than 11,000 megawatts -- by four suits in the D.C. appeals court against the Nuclear Regulatory Commission (NRC). Three states and other non-government organizations are [BLANK] to require that costs of managing spent fuel be part of NRC licensing and re-licensing decisions. Adding waste storage costs to the cost-benefit analysis NRC uses to make licensing decisions could lead to licenses being denied. There are 16 licenses under NRC review.

The absence of objectors to Citigroup's $1.1 billion mortgage-backed securities accord with investors and MBS trustees makes it unlikely the settlement amount will increase. Unlike similar settlements by Bank of America and JPMorgan where some investors objected and sought a bigger deal, no investors [BLANK] objections to the Citigroup deal. Though the court must still approve the accord, it's even more likely to defer to the MBS trustees' decision to accept the settlement.

One of the most geographically diversified holding companies, Black Hills operates seven natural gas utilities and three electrics touching eight states in the upper Plains. The aggregate [BLANK] return on equity changes slowly, as the 10 different utilities complete rate cases over years. It can be hard for investors to follow all the companies in detail, but three big electric companies dominate the earnings, and all completed rate cases in the last two years.

Samsung faces several legal actions that could affect device margins, including a licensing dispute with Huawei over rates charged for patents on cellular interoperability standards, which we estimate could be worth $400 million in annual royalties to Huawei. A separate dispute with Xperi [BLANK] almost $100 million in damages on patents related to technologies in Samsung's semiconductors and flagship Galaxy and Note devices. Samsung continues to develop a patent-licensing business that offsets fees incurred under cross-licensing agreements with other companies. Samsung joined a royalty-free cross-licensing deal with Google, LG, HTC, Foxconn and others within the Android ecosystem in April 2017 to reduce patent disputes involving Android and Google applications.

Medicaid medical costs may have been controlled by payers in 2Q as Centene's medical loss ratio from existing businesses declined 10 bps yoy. Centene's overall loss ratio rose 10 bps, though the increase may be [BLANK] to the addition of higher premium membership. Demand for health-care services remained relatively flat during 2Q, according to Centene. Minimal increases to utilization could aid loss ratios at Medicaid payers Molina and WellCare.

The Trump administration almost certainly will encourage fossil-fuel production and seek to reverse Obama-era regulations targeting the coal industry. Scott Pruitt, the new EPA administrator, was [BLANK] by the Senate on Feb. 17. President Donald Trump's pick to lead the Interior Department, Ryan Zinke, was confirmed on March 1, and a Senate vote on Rick Perry as head of the Energy Department is expected soon. Former Exxon Mobil CEO Rex Tillerson was confirmed as secretary of state on Feb. 1.

Late-stage trials for CML are mostly testing already-approved therapies in earlier lines of treatment, such as Ariad's trials looking at Iclusig as a second-line agent in Gleevec failures and an early switch trial. Novartis is testing Tasigna in several studies that [BLANK] whether patients who achieve a certain molecular response can stay in remission after stopping therapy when given first-line or after Gleevec. Bristol-Myers Squibb is testing Spyrcel with its PDL-1 Opdivo in a Phase II trial.

Deutsche Bank's current plan includes about 9,000 employee cuts in 2015-18, or 9% of its 2015 year-end total. The group [BLANK] Oct. 6 an agreement for 4,000 cuts in Germany as part of this, including 3,000 already flagged in June, which were mainly in private and commercial banking. Later reductions include about 450 in infrastructure support, along with human resources, communications and corporate social-responsibility functions, asset management, trading, corporate finance and research.

European Industrials' 4Q results broadly met with negative share-price reactions despite expectations being achieved and positive economic fundamentals for 2018. Concern about valuations and the sustainability of the earnings recovery may [BLANK] the market's reaction, though some peers, such as Volvo and Atlas Copco, would appear to be better placed to sustain growth vs. others, such as Siemens and Konecranes.

The lone Turkey exchange-traded fund aced its recent stress test, providing some reassurance to those worried about ETFs' ability to handle financial calamities. Trading in the ETF has gone smoothly despite record-breaking volume and a surge in create-to-lend flows, even as the fund [BLANK] 25% during a two-day selloff.

When the euro appreciates vs. local currency, reduced revenue from foreign subsidiaries euro zone-based utilities can be offset by lower euro-denominated interest expenses on foreign-currency denominated debt. Such a strategy may not [BLANK] in countries with a smaller, less liquid corporate-bond market. Utilities try to match their foreign earnings with debt denominated in local currency, as a natural hedge against the currency moves. As a result, the impact on net profit may be neutral when translated into euros.

Alberta's plan to implement a C$20-a-ton carbon tax (about $15) in 2017 comes during a time of upheaval in Canada's oil patch. Numerous oil sands projects have been canceled in 2015, mostly because of falling oil prices, and a carbon tax may extend that trend by [BLANK] Canadian E&Ps at a cost disadvantage compared with competitors abroad. Canada's oil production has risen almost steadily in the past several decades. Looking ahead, a new set of policies from the province and the federal government may slow growth.

Historically, the spring season ushers in the two best months for auto sales in the U.S., along with warmer weather. March has [BLANK] 9.2% of annual volume since 1992. Tax refunds and tax season incentives propel May to 9.3% over the period. Automakers will likely shrug off the sluggish February, given that it typically is the third-weakest month, contributing just 7.6% of full-year U.S. new vehicle volume, and may fall further as automakers leverage the November (7.4% since 1992) shopping frenzy of Black Friday.

Anti-PD-L1s appear to be as effective as anti-PD-1s in second-line lung cancer, based on available data. While Merck's trial was [BLANK] to PD-L1 expressors, Bristol-Myers and Roche included all comers in their trials. Tecentriq's efficacy looked similar to Opdivo's. In POPLAR and OAK trials, Tecetriq achieved an overall response rate of 19.4% and 18% respectively in PD-L1 expressors, comparable to Keytruda's, albeit using different PD-L1 expression tests. Durvalumab and avelumab data were from early stage trials.

Suddenlink, the midsized U.S. cable company (1.1 million video subscribers) acquired by Altice in 2015 is the most profitable operator, with a 45% operating cash flow margin. Altice is [BLANK] for drastic cost-cutting, a strategy also being applied in its other U.S. acquisition of Cablevision (now Optimum). Cablevision has trailed in profitability, though its near-30% margin in 2Q was its best result in two years. Comcast and Cable One also logged margins above 40% with pro-forma Charter at 35.5%.

Swiss banks may experience outflows of client assets from local booking centers as a result of plans to tighten tax laws. Switzerland and the EU will automatically exchange information on the financial accounts of each other's residents starting in 2018, pursuant to an agreement [BLANK] by both in 2Q15. This will ultimately bring bank secrecy to an end. The Swiss Corporate Tax Reform Act III, designed to align elements of the Swiss tax regime with international standards, will also bring costly and uncertain change.

Standard Chartered's board shake-up means six of 18 directors will step down, including CEO Peter Sands and Chairman John Peace. Three of the departures are independent directors who have [BLANK] over 10 years, including Ruth Harland, remuneration committee chair. Two of the new arrivals, Gay Evans and Jasmine Whitbread, are women. This will take female board representation to 21%, still trailing peers. The lender was one of only three European banking peers with four or more directors serving over 10 years.

An unseasonable build in U.S. crude oil inventories in the week ended July 22 may further pressure WTI oil prices near term, as elevated petroleum imbalances persist. Despite marginal gasoline demand growth, U.S. refinery utilization fell to 92.4% as crude inputs [BLANK] to 16.6 million barrels a day, down 2% amid faltering margins. Gasoline stockpiles rose for a third consecutive week. Onshore rig counts have recovered from their May lows, as the steady 1H decline in U.S. crude output has stalled.

Engie, Gas Natural and Centrica are among the suppliers that may see a recovery in gas use by power plants in 2015. Gas-fired generators' margins are improving and those of coal-power generators are [BLANK] across Germany, the Netherlands, Spain and France. While gas-power margins in Italy fell to zero in 2015, generators' output was boosted by a dip in hydro reserves, favoring gas. Gas use may proliferate if oil-indexed gas contracts reflect lower crude prices and coal prices fall at a slower rate.

An Oklahoma plaintiff moved a step closer to putting the issue of whether there's a link between oil and gas activities and earthquakes before a judge to determine. The Oklahoma Supreme Court [BLANK] away a procedural hurdle on June 30, allowing the plaintiff in a lawsuit to move forward in a lower court against local drillers. The suit alleges damages from induced earthquakes. The case may address the link between earthquakes and injection wells as soon as 2016.

The ability to sell bonds at a very low cost of capital, and to issue stock far above book value, has allowed many utilities to pursue acquisitions that weren't previously possible. Pending deals such as Southern's takeover of AGL and Duke's Piedmont purchase are touted as [BLANK] a boost to future earnings, even at high premiums of about 35-40%. The ability to borrow at low rates has also cleared the way for offshore suitors, including Macquarie, Iberdrola, Emera and Fortis.

Long-term survivors are becoming clearer at the start of what appears to be a weeding-out process amid the cryptocurrency frenzy. As Bitcoin's status diminishes, Ethereum, Ripple and Cardano are standouts in the ebbing of a tide that's still quite [BLANK].

Asia short-haul travel demand growth was stronger than capacity additions in May, netting load-factor improvements for most airlines. South Asian carriers Garuda and its subsidiary Citilink; Cebu of the Philippines; and Thai Airways [BLANK] regional and domestic demand rise more than 20% as capacity grew at a slower rate for all but Cebu. Chinese airlines improved traffic in the mid-teens, in part due to May holidays. Qantas cut domestic capacity on the continued slowdown in the resources sector.

Vacationers who travel on cruise ships and visit casinos account for fewer travel bookings than non-gaming hotels and airlines. Yet operators of [BLANK] resorts and ships, like their hotel and airline counterparts, have developed strategies that enable them to distribute their inventory more efficiently in a travel industry dominated by online travel agents, or OTAs. MGM's customer-loyalty program offers room discounts and guest services that attract direct bookers and mitigate agent-commission costs.

Pier 1 Imports' (PIR -21%) three-year strategic plan, discontinued dividend and comparable-sales miss in its 4Q highlight increasing competitive pressure from mass merchants and online retailers, in particular Amazon.com and Wayfair. Pier 1's [BLANK] marketing and promotions may be necessary to increase sales in-store and online, but margins take a hit: though online sales penetration increased 25%, gross margin was 220 bps lower. In our view, the board should reallocate the $22 million of incremental cash flow in fiscal 2019 that it's gaining via the dividend cut to help on the three-year plan.

As the offshore drilling industry braces for a potentially prolonged decline, owners of jackups in Asia face especially bleak prospects. The region's supply is [BLANK] to swell, with 53 uncontracted newbuilds to be delivered before year-end. The Middle East appears to be the only bright spot, with national oil companies signing 40 new or altered contracts in the past two months as they seek to capitalize on the current market imbalance by locking up long-term deals at favorable rates.

Many casual-dining chains that aim to boost same-store sales with to-go orders may end up disappointed. While business-to-business catering and bundled meals on holidays, including Easter and Thanksgiving, may provide incremental sales, chains that hope to take, or maintain, market share with single meals could [BLANK] restaurant margins by cannibalizing higher-margin dining-room sales. Small delivery orders are low margin due to fewer drink sales and packaging that adds costs.

The EU is committed to fostering 5G networks across the EU, with a view to avoid lags that slowed 4G rollout in the region. While standards are yet to be [BLANK], 5G is expected to address a diverse set of connectivity needs with improvements in speed, bandwidth and latency. The first commercial 5G roll-outs are expected by 2020, with the EU calling for coverage in all urban areas by 2025. Unlike some U.S. and South Korean carriers, European industry is aligned with the standardization timeline.

The good news for Google is that the EU, while imposing a record fine for a case alleging abuse of market dominance, didn't ask for the maximum allowed or for structural changes. The EU ended one of three antitrust investigations of Google on June 27 with a 2.4 billion-euro fine and a call for the internet giant to [BLANK] how it displays shopping-search results. The company has 90 days to give equal treatment to rival services. EU regulators have scrutinized the company's operations in Europe over seven years.

Humana wants to protect the Affordable Care Act's insurance mandates and Medicaid expansion. Yet it also is exiting Obamacare health exchanges in multiple states, joining several industry peers that are also pulling out, citing [BLANK] market conditions. Industry executives are wary of the Trump administration's health-care reform plans and are pushing Congress to repeal the ACA's tax on health insurers that would extract about $145 billion over 10 years. A moratorium on the tax is in effect for 2017.

Pharmacy benefits managers can add significant value for managed-care clients by employing specialty drug adherence programs. For each dollar invested in programs that encourage people to take their medications, clients could [BLANK] $10 in medical costs for a patient with hypertension, CVS says. Savings are about $7 for diabetes and $3 for lipids. Stricter adherence to prescription therapies may reduce the risk of hospital admissions, along with the duration of the therapy.

South Korean telecom operators' 2Q earnings growth varied as their marketing costs stabilized. SK Telecom [BLANK] the worst, with operating income down 24.4% from a year earlier. Excluding retirement costs, the drop was still about 5% on a 3.6% decline in mobile service revenue, the weakest among its rivals. KT's operating income swung to a 369 billion won profit ($309 million) from a loss. LG Uplus's rose 96% mainly on lower marketing costs. Mobile service revenue grew 4.3% at LG Uplus and 1.7% at KT.

FTR's Truck Loadings Index increased 5.5% to 130.8 in February vs. the previous year, the 35th-consecutive monthly gain and the highest level since March 2007. The index is up 32.3% from its December 2009 low, and FTR [BLANK] it will increase 0.4% sequentially in March. After rising 4.1% in 2014, truck loadings are forecast to rise 5.3% in 2015. Flatbed (up 8.3%) and bulk (up 5.9%) equipment types led year-over-year growth in February, and are forecast to rise the most this year.

An FDA panel will meet to discuss Daiichi's new drug application for Edoxaban for stroke prevention and systemic emobolism on Oct. 30. The drug [BLANK] its primary endpoints in the ENGAGE AF-TIMI 48 trial, suggesting it is as good as warfarin at both reducing stroke and emobolism. The drug's safety profile may be a focus of the panel given it showed an increased risk of ischemic stroke compared with warfarin. If approved, the drug will compete with Bayer's Xarelto and Pfizer's Eliquis.

Weak orders and large backlogs may preclude wider development plans for new jets, hindering supplier opportunities for new work and revenue. Manufacturers are [BLANK] their focus to profitability and execution after years of intense product development, resulting in the service entry of a slew of new or refreshed jets over the coming years. A Boeing 757 replacement may come next decade, though timing is unclear. Bombardier, Boeing and Airbus are ramping production of new or re-engined narrow-bodies.

Although Gazprom's exports to Europe fell along with EU gas prices in 1Q, the company may be betting on a recovery in the remainder of 2015. Even after a 70% profit drop under the Russian Accounting Standards in 2014, management nevertheless [BLANK] to pay a dividend of 7.2 rubles (14 cents) per share, in line with 2013. That implies a 90% payout ratio vs. 25% historically. The dividend proposal also exceeds both consensus forecasts of 6.7 ruble a share and 5.15 rubles suggested by Russian Finance Ministry.

Natural gas prices fell after a larger-than-estimated storage injection in the week ended May 26. Average U.S. weather was mild, with a [BLANK] spring demand lull. Consumption fell vs. the prior week, led by reduced residential and commercial use. Power burn eased by 0.7 bcf a day in the period. Sluggish domestic production fell marginally to 71.2 bcf a day. Still, supply growth could advance as E&Ps express optimism and rig counts build. At 2.53 trillion cubic feet, stockpiles are 9.8% over the five-year norm.

Accor will be the first among global hotel companies to report 3Q results, shedding light on the sector's European outlook given its dominant presence in the region. Accor will be a barometer for global peers' performance as most have hotels in these markets, which [BLANK] challenges including Brexit uncertainty, forex volatility and terrorist attacks. Major topics from these calls include competitive strategies following the Marriott-Starwood merger, global revpar outlooks and progress of direct booking channels.

European companies selling into Russia experienced a 25% decline in the ruble in the 15 months since 2013 began. The recent decline, attributable to sanctions [BLANK] by the U.S. and EU and lower oil prices, has returned the ruble to its March level against the euro. The dollar has appreciated 19% since June against the euro. While companies can hedge against such sharp currency moves in the short-term, it will make those European and U.S. exports still permitted more expensive.

Toyota, spurred by its market-leading models, accounts for 29% of Japan's auto sales, double the share for No. 2 Honda. Mini-vehicle sales have fallen after consumption tax on these vehicles was [BLANK] in April, dampening sales at Suzuki and Daihatsu. Market penetration of diesel passenger vehicles are already low, and it may drop further on the VW-diesel scandal. Domestic brands make up 94% of auto sales in Japan, while German carmakers VW, Mercedes and BMW dominate foreign-brand vehicle sales.

Chipmakers faced growth challenges from weak PC and mobile markets in 2015. The two segments accounted for 39% of chip revenue, while economic weakness, particularly in China, also [BLANK] sales. Significant exposure to corporate clients or hyperscale data centers may help companies such as Intel or networking leader Broadcom. Inconsistent spending by cloud vendors may limit gains. Auto and industrial chipmakers, including Texas Instruments and NXP, are among those significantly affected by the macro environment.

China's steel mills are exporting their excess production due to weak overall economic demand and a sluggish construction market. The country [BLANK] being targeted in trade cases for its impact on prices. Chinese steel exports surged to 83.2 million metric tons in the first nine months of 2015, exceeding the total U.S. steel production of 60.6 million tons. South Korea has been the top destination for Chinese steel, accounting for more than 12% of China's total exports.

Infinity War" is [BLANK] to lead the domestic box office with $58.5 million in its third weekend, according to Box Office Pro. That will likely be the last weekend dominated by the Disney production, given that Fox's "Deadpool 2" is set to debut on May 18 and could start at about $130 million. "Avengers: Infinity War" may cross $1.5 billion in total sales this weekend as it opens in China.

A surge in coal, PGMs, iron ore and copper prices will boost cash flows at the right time as Anglo American tries to both reduce debt and restructure itself into a smaller, more-focused mining company. Higher coal prices will help garner better value for mines it wishes to sell and also encourages more competition for other assets [BLANK] noncore. With a debt level that could drop below $10 billion by year-end, the lowest since 2012, Anglo should be into its final restructuring stages by the end of 2017.

Large populations without bank accounts and rising GDP per capita should increasingly support long-term global payments growth. The Nilson Report [BLANK] 12% annual growth for worldwide payment-card purchase volumes for the six years ending 2018, including 16% for the Asia-Pacific region and 12% for companies in Latin America, the Middle East and Africa. This compares with 9% growth in the U.S. and Europe and 8% for Canada.

MorphoSys filed an amended complaint in its lawsuit against J&J and Genmab over anti-CD38 antibody patents. MorphoSys is seeking damages from J&J and Genmab for past infringement, as well as [BLANK] royalties. A typical royalty would likely be 3-5% of sales. MorphoSys is also seeking an enhanced award, alleging that the claimed infringement of its patents expiring in 2028 was willful. J&J and Genmab withdrew their motion to dismiss certain claims, as it's no longer necessary in view of the new complaint.

United Rental says 1H energy-related pressures are abating, although rates and utilization will remain challenged over the next several quarters. Used equipment sales are rising and prices are falling as the industry [BLANK] fleet size. Equipment makers may have weaker sales and margins as rental companies adjust capital spending plans and seek price concessions. Management dialed back its rental rate expectations, saying they're looking forward to increases in the longer term, yet 2016 should show little gain.

The pharmaceutical industry drives returns for the biggest health-care exchange-traded funds, with drugmakers accounting for almost half of the ETFs' exposure. While this may [BLANK] the appeal of pure-play pharma ETFs, the mix has been a boon for investors in popular health-care ETFs. For example, pharma makes up 47% of the Health Care Select Sector SPDR Fund (XLV) and 44% of the Vanguard Health Care ETF (VHT). As a result, the industry has contributed three times more to those two funds' returns than any other.

Tencent has successfully boosted its mobile business with WeChat, China's most popular social-networking app. Tencent now seeks to [BLANK] on WeChat's more than 806 million monthly active users by selling advertising through official accounts and "Moments," WeChat's popular, Facebook-like news-feed feature. Ad sales more than doubled in 2015 on WeChat's high user traffic and engagement. Tencent's ad revenue accounted for just 17% of total 2015 sales vs. 96% for Facebook.

The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau has until Nov. 25 to ask the full D.C. Circuit to rehear an Oct. 11 ruling that found the CFPB's current structure unconstitutional. The CFPB said it's [BLANK] options after a three-judge appeals panel limited the agency's independence and vacated a $109 million disgorgement order the agency issued against mortgage lender PHH. The CFPB can also ask the Supreme Court for review within three months of either the ruling or denial of a full-court rehearing petition.

Inc.'s earnings will likely be propelled higher in 2018 and beyond by its strong execution in A4 printers and especially high-margin supplies, its expansion in A3 and 3D printers, and its ability to place a larger volume of margin-rich supplies than its peers. The increased frequency of extreme weather may reduce crop yields and boost feedstock costs for biofuel producers. Recent examples were severe rainfall in Malaysia in December resulted in flooding, endangering palm oil production. A drought in the U.S. in 2012 dented corn production and reduced potential ethanol output, with high commodity prices squeezing margins.

Episodic migraine patients have 0-14 headache days a month, while chronic migraine is characterized as 15 or more headache days a month. Episodic migraines are more common than chronic migraines, [BLANK] in 17% of women in the U.S. vs. 1.3% for chronic. Patients with chronic migraine tend to have more comorbidites, such as respiratory disorders and cardiac problems. Episodic migraine can progress to chronic migraine at a rate of 2.5% a year.

Major branded drugs in Valeant's dermatology portfolio had a rebound in prescription volume in 2Q. Volume of high-margin drugs such as Solodyn, Jublia and Retin-A [BLANK] from lows, with Retin-A and Solodyn up 22%, and Jublia 5% higher. This is likely the result of a reinvigorated Walgreens push, but it comes with significant price discounting. That means organic revenue growth may be muted despite the uptick in volume.

Spartannash and Ingles Markets shares are down by about the mid-20% range this year through May 30, attributed to disappointing quarterly results. Likewise, Kroger [BLANK] 14% during the period on a persistent bout of food deflation. In contrast, Empire Co. led the group, advancing 31% amid management reshuffling and a new cost-cutting strategy expected to save $500 million a year. Sprouts grew 26% on speculation it held preliminary talks to merge with Albertsons.

Concerns of a liquified natural gas glut never came to fruition, as lower global prices helped shift demand from coal and other generation sources and cleared the market. U.S. supply will continue to hit spot markets, but with growing concerns about global warming and air quality in cities, we see room for more switching to [BLANK] supply.

The Federal Reserve could play Santa Claus this holiday season by signaling a slowdown in rate tightening in 2019. Stocks are happy to ride along for now, and we [BLANK] the S&P 500 looks set to take a crack at its 100-day moving average (MA), supported by recent momentum and size divergences. It may take stabilization in estimate revisions to support an advance beyond that level. Oil continues to garner significant attention, but appears set to find stabilization at $50 a barrel. The market has priced out a full Fed hike since early November, and until this week, financials were benefiting relative to the rest of the S&P 500. Financials shares, which were likely already starting to anticipate the shift in tone, may be waiting on curve steepening to extend their recent outperformance.

Asian ports account for about 6% of global cruise volume, far behind the Caribbean, the leading cruise destination with 36% of passenger capacity. An increase in cruise ships will likely [BLANK] hotel revenue throughout Asia. Nations with the most cruise calls are likely to get the greatest tourism benefits. They include Japan, Malaysia, Singapore, Thailand and South Korea, which recently lagged neighbors in growing hotel revenue per available room due to the MERS outbreak.

Rules in some U.S. wholesale electricity markets may limit storage deployment, including batteries, by restricting how resources are used and in turn undervaluing their services. FERC's proposed rule may allow storage providers to [BLANK] multiple services, which could improve project economics and support some deployment. Industry commenters on the rule suggest many battery systems offer one product, such as frequency regulation, but could sell ancillary or other grid services.

Bank's unit in Russia reported an increase in new nonperforming loans to a record 32 billion forint ($120 million) in 1Q, increasing the share of bad debt within total loans by 450 bps to 19.3%. Stricter lending criteria and lower demand for credit led OTP's Russian retail loan book to decline 8% in the quarter, [BLANK] with 3.5% for the industry. A further deterioration of Russia's economy may prompt OTP to join Societe Generale and Nordea in accelerating their withdrawal from consumer banking in the country.

Aerospace suppliers will be pressured by Boeing and Airbus planned production increases of 20% during the next five years, to more than 1,600 aircraft annually. Production for Embraer, Bombardier and Mitsubishi will [BLANK] to the stress on the supply chain. Production will need to rise most at engine makers such as General Electric, Safran, Pratt & Whitney, Rolls-Royce and MTU, as well as at component makers Spirit, Triumph, United Technologies, Thales and others.

Thanks to a considerable amount of low-cost production adding to Total's output, pressure on the French oil major to create value by making its own discoveries is relatively low. Oil and gas volume from new licenses in Qatar and the UAE, as well as Novatek's Yamal gas project, in which Total holds 20%, can be [BLANK] at a very competitive cost. Total reduced its exploration budget last year by almost a third, to $1.9 billion, and will cut it further to $1.5 billion in 2016, including $1 billion of capex.

Refineries located on the U.S. Gulf Coast with significant distillate flexibility and the ability to process a variety of crudes will be best-positioned to take advantage of the IMO rule change. Still, inland refineries will also [BLANK] if the rule change leads to weaker prices for heavy Canadian crude oil.

Softwood lumber production is concentrated in the boreal and temperate coniferous forests of the U.S., Canada, Russia, Germany, Sweden and Finland, which together account for 57% of world output. Excluding the U.S., which [BLANK] more than it produces, these nations are also the five largest exporters. China has become a major producer using imported logs, while Chile, Brazil and New Zealand emerged after creating fast-growth plantations. The largest consuming countries are the U.S., China, Germany and Japan.

Marathon Petroleum is the only one of the larger independent refiners that analysts don't expect to be able to achieve a reduction in leverage in 2018 and 2019. The company's 2017 consolidated net debt-to-Ebitda ratio of 2.03x is expected to rise, while other refiners, including weaker-rated Andeavor and PBF Energy, are expected to [BLANK] leverage declines of more than one turn by 2019. Valero Energy, Phillips 66 and HollyFrontier will see more modest declines in leverage.

CenterPoint Energy Inc.'s midstream exposure has dragged down its financial performance, first from earnings dilution related to the Enable MLP spinoff, and then from the oil price plunge in late 2014. The company shares a general partner stake in the publicly [BLANK] Enable Midstream master limited partnership with OGE Energy and owns the majority of limited partner shares. Growth has been relatively stable at its flagship electric utility in Texas and its six-state gas utility portfolio.

Among global specialty-generic competitive peers, Allergan leads in 2017 performance year-to-date, which has been helped by pipeline development, moves away from steep price hikes and additional M&A in diversified areas like fat sculpting and gene editing. Mylan's stong performance stems from its diversified generic portfolio, which will offset U.S. price erosion, leaving the company better [BLANK] than peers. Shire has been successfully integrating Baxalta and Dyax, which has improved guidance.

The environment for U.S. restaurants is challenging as operators struggle to maintain positive traffic and generate strong sales growth. Consumers have [BLANK] more spending from dining out to eating at home as deflation has lowered grocery prices.Prepared food in grocery stores and meal-delivery kits are also on the rise. Restaurants have continued to raise prices to offset growing labor costs. This has led to sustained industrywide same-store sales declines on both an annual and two-year basis.

The chemicals industry faces a balancing act of meeting evolving environmental and health regulations within the new market opportunities created for lower-impact products and other solutions. Measures to [BLANK] toxic materials, genetically modified food controversies and regulations governing operational emissions may harm profitability and growth. In contrast, the same regulations can create new, potentially more profitable markets for materials that can help customers meet regulatory needs.

Coca-Cola's planned purchase of Whitbread's Costa Coffee unit for $5.1 billion marks an ambitious shift in the company's growth strategy; one that offers opportunities for faster gains but which carries several key risks. Costa, with a strong market presence in the U.K. across multiple coffee businesses, would [BLANK] Coca-Cola with a powerful platform to expand in the growing global coffee category. However, the Costa acquisition would make Coca-Cola a more direct competitor to deep-pocketed Nestle, Unilever and Keurig Dr Pepper.

The European Central Bank's potential to follow the Federal Reserve's balance-sheet unwinding has proven its potential as the incremental driver of rates, the dollar and equity sector and style shifts so far this year. Markets reacted swiftly to ECB President Mario Draghi's reflationary comments a few weeks ago as yields in Europe and the U.S. [BLANK] and the dollar fell. Coinciding with the moves, value stocks recovered smartly, led by financials, and growth stocks struggled, dragged down by tech.

Recent inter partes review (IPR) patent proceedings include Biogen's filing on June 22 of a patent-owner response opposing Kyle Bass' petition, granted on March 22, challenging Tecfidera's dosing patent. AstraZeneca filed a patent-owner response in opposition to a Bass petition [BLANK] on Feb. 22 for a patent covering Vimovo. Bass may reply to both responses by mid-August. Shire's NPS Pharmaceuticals argued against Bass at a June 23 oral hearing that its patent on Gattex is valid.

Efforts to "virtualize" storage are giving rise to hybrids that integrate their own hardware and software with cloud systems. Physical storage such as NAND flash and hard disks are becoming accessible via software interfaces that allow systems to [BLANK] into all devices, based on the applications they need to run. Internal arrays of disks or high-speed NAND flash may be tied to Amazon or Google external storage, creating highly efficient "hybrid" clouds. Customers using these systems seek high capacity at low costs.

One reason for brighter expectations for the 2014 holiday shopping season is that low-income shoppers see fewer new pressures to their budgets. Last year, they faced cuts to food stamps, announced ahead of peak holiday shopping, and were [BLANK] about rising health-care costs. Wal-Mart said the food stamp reduction meant for a drop of 40 basis points in its 4Q, which includes holiday shopping. The low-income consumer may have also feared pressure from rising health-care costs.

Integrating large homebuilders can be a challenge, as highlighted by the industry's last deal combining two public companies, Pulte and Centex. Even so, management of Ryland and Standard Pacific see lower risk because there is comparatively less overlap in divisions, the two companies [BLANK] with the same technology infrastructures and timing within the cycle is much better. Neither is a stranger to M&A; both were involved in several deals in 2012-14 and have shown success with integration.

Post-2Q Earnings Outlook: Strong execution in the PC franchise, especially in higher-priced device segments, is driving HP's sales amid a robust corporate spending back drop, and is likely to continue. Gross and [BLANK] margin may be weak in the printing segment for a few more quarters due to component cost pressure and the Samsung acquisition. Operating income here should rise in 2H and long term. Gains in A3 printers, graphics and 3-D printing aid sales and add to corporate margin. Better-than-consensus EPS guidance for fiscal 3Q and 2018 showcase these trends, as does its share reduction, despite some gains in operating costs.

Quiksilver's unsecured bondholders are likely to oppose the surfing apparel and footwear company's plan for reorganizing in Chapter 11. Quiksilver filed for bankruptcy on Sept. 9 as part of a plan to [BLANK] Oaktree Capital's and other first-lien bondholders' secured debt to equity. Quiksilver argues that the plan is its only means of deleveraging while keeping the status quo at its non-debtor businesses in Europe and the Asia-Pacific region, both of which are key to the company's viability.

The gross profit margin of coal- and gas-fired power plants can be calculated from market power and fuel prices. Profits have [BLANK] in most major European markets because of oversupply. The PAM function allows users to compare the profits of power plants and complete generators, such as Centrica and SSE, in four major markets to determine which plants should or shouldn't run. The function includes efficiency assumptions and ownership filters.

AstraZeneca's Brilinta blood thinner generated 187,000 U.S. prescriptions in 4Q, up 50% from a year earlier. AstraZeneca has [BLANK] extra marketing to the drug to invigorate volumes after its slow launch. The increased investment and new initiatives included a nurse-training program. Volumes for Eli Lilly's Effient fell 1.4%, though the drug's sales will likely grow because of annual price increases.

Broadcast prime-time ratings for the top four networks gained 7% in the week ended Dec. 11, aided by the NFL, where viewership continued to recover after the elections. NBC's jumped 23% as "Sunday Night Football" ratings [BLANK] 26% and "Thursday Night Football" drew 17.4 million viewers. CBS' losses moderated to 3%, aided by shows such as "NCIS," with a gain of 29%, and "Bull," which drew an audience of 11.1 million. ABC's losses moderated to 1%, while Fox's remained unchanged vs. an 11% drop last week.

Biotech and pharma companies clarified several important timelines recently. Resverlogix will start a Phase III trial for reducing cardiac events for high-risk heart and diabetes patients in 2H, after EU regulators [BLANK] initial confirmation. Alnylam and Sanofi plan for a hemophilia treatment ALN-AT3 to enter a Phase III trial in mid-2016. The drug will potentially be dosed once a month. Durect will start a new Phase III trial of Posidur for post-operative pain in 2H to support FDA resubmission.

Wynn Resorts reaffirmed a recent pattern of sustained VIP pressure in its preliminary 1Q results, offset by a firming in mass-gaming revenue. At Wynn Macau, accounting for 61% of revenue, VIP table win [BLANK] 21%, slightly more than the city's average 18% decline in January-February. In Las Vegas, slot win was up 2% and revenue per available room rose 3%, tracking the market's 4% slot-win gain. Table drop and win, however, fell 17% and 8%, more than the city's 2% table decline in January-February.

United Rentals' growth plans, both geographically and in its general rental and specialty segments, combined with the inherent cyclicality of the sector, are key rating constraints. These prevent healthy near-term fundamentals from [BLANK] the risk outlook. Our expectations are that capital allocation will remain the most meaningful driver of credit risk near-term.

GM's capacity reduction in North America accelerates its commitment to electrified-drivetrain vehicles -- technology it already features in Chevrolet Bolt and Volt. The demand for battery-elecric vehicles (BEVs) remains uncertain, though GM appears to be the next automaker -- after Tesla and Volkswagen -- willing to [BLANK] to the pursuit of BEV segment share.

Medicaid requests for proposals (RFPs) that are being released in April suggest $18 billion of premiums are up for grabs. RFPs will be [BLANK] by Alabama, New Hampshire, North Carolina and Texas. Centene and Molina will fight intently to defend their turf in Texas, while competition will be fierce for an evergreen North Carolina contract.

Post-1Q Earnings Outlook: AstraZeneca could register one of the best earnings-growth rates among large-pharma peers after 2018, but this will depend on how it manages new-drug launch costs, as cash from externalization and other operating income ($4.25 billion in 2017) from new and old asset divestitures shrinks. As we expected, investors will have to [BLANK] with volatility for another few quarters as this dynamic plays out. Unchanged 2018 guidance suggests that this will normalize.

China's apparent crude demand, defined as oil production plus net imports, rose 6.5% to 48.6 million tons in September from a year earlier, extending August gains. Domestic output fell 9.9%, the steepest decline in 2016, though it was more than [BLANK] by the 16.9% surge in net imports. Stockpiling -- the difference between apparent crude use and refining throughput -- stayed at 4.8 million tons. Refining throughput rose 3.2%, while oil-product consumption fell 0.4%.

The rollout of its unique operating platform across the U.S. presents a significant long-term growth opportunity for LGI Homes. The company's aggressive market expansion will fuel robust community count growth while further [BLANK] from its home market of Texas.

Recent heavy-truck order weakness has similarities to 2008, when six-month annualized orders were 199,000 units in July vs. 170,000 for the same period in 2016. North American Class 8 factory shipments [BLANK] 2008 at 195,000 units, well below FTR Intelligence's 2016 forecast of 232,000 vehicles. Even if 2016 orders remain comparable to 2008 levels, an elevated backlog may allow higher production than in 2008.

Casual-dining chains can use their menu to offer more variety and increase value perception, providing they don't change so much they alienate their core customer base of baby boomers and Generation Xers. Alcohol [BLANK] additional opportunity to expand sales, with many chains underpenetrated in this area.

Novo Nordisk's 1Q sales were in-line with consensus, while earnings outperformed by 3.5%. This was driven by lower operating costs, which [BLANK] margin by 158 bps vs. FY15 to 45.2%. Sales grew 9% at constant exchange rates. This is at the top end of the company's 2016 view, driven by new launches and rebate adjustments for Norditropin, which helped offset those in diabetes, a contract loss for NovoLog and a slowdown in China. Novo maintained its growth outlook for the year in local currency.

Several biotech and pharma companies recently clarified key timelines. Resverlogix will start a Phase III trial for reducing cardiac events in high-risk cardiovascular and diabetes patients in 2H, after EU regulators [BLANK] initial confirmation. Alnylam and Sanofi plan for a hemophilia treatment ALN-AT3 to enter a Phase III trial in mid-2016. The drug will potentially be dosed once monthly. Durect will start a new Phase III trial of Posidur for post-operative pain in 2H to support FDA resubmission.

Citibank's Sept. 8 victory in getting most claims dismissed from a $2.3 billion mortgage-bond investor suit may be short-lived because plaintiffs are likely to refile the dismissed claims in state court, as was recently done in a similar suit. Nevertheless, the Citigroup unit, [BLANK] in its capacity as a mortgage-bond trustee, would likely seek dismissal of the state court claims, too. Citibank is also helped by the plaintiffs' burden of proving class-action claims on a loan-by-loan basis.

The MSCI World Beverages Index's spread to the MSCI World is about 12% above its three-year average premium, based on enterprise value-to-12-month forward Ebitda analysis. Low interest rates and [BLANK] organic growth, particularly in mature markets, could be an environment conducive to more mergers and acquisitions in the industry and further boost valuations. Global volume of proposed, pending and completed beverage M&A deals totals $4.5 billion so far in 2015.

A purer focus on luxury, rising customer appeal, wider success of brands across regions and channels, and new organizational and supply-chain enhancements at Kering support superior midterm revenue and margin expansion. Resounding spring/summer 2019 fashion shows and the best-voted digital and social media presence [BLANK] confidence. Revenue growth of 11% and a 10-bp Ebit margin advance to 28.9% for 2019, based on consensus, seem conservative, in our view. This is even amid Bottega Veneta's transition under a new director, plans for some targeted store openings for key brands globally and wider e-commerce projects.

Publicly traded dealerships generate the majority of gross profit on average from their parts and service and finance and insurance departments, essentially selling units to to generate clients for the finance and service businesses. New and used vehicles [BLANK] 48% of gross profit for the peer group in 2014, at considerably lower margins. Parts and service averaged 50% gross margins since 2008, compared with 6% for new vehicles and 10% for pre-owned.

The European banks 4Q earnings season begins in late January, with Nordic banks SEB and Nordea, and Deutsche Bank the first to report. The ECB's Jan. 22 meeting is likely to center on the announcement of a larger-scale asset purchase program, potentially [BLANK] sovereign bonds. The focus in upcoming analyst calls is likely to be on banks' participation, as well as plans to combat the inevitable rate compression and extension of low rates that this will bring.

Mid-summer promotions in July likely helped retail sales gain 2.1% in the third week of the month. Department [BLANK] sales deteriorated further, down 2%, while discounters' sales advanced 4.3% in the week through July 22. As the academic year approaches, department stores must vie for back-to-school spending on clothing and footwear as shoppers increasingly buy online and seek discounts. Johnson Redbook projects 2% overall sales growth in July.

Scotland approved a second pilot project in March for floating offshore wind turbines, building momentum for commercialization of the technology and opening up potential new areas of demand for turbine makers. The Hexicon Dounreay Tri project of up to 12 megawatts includes two connected turbines, after a 48-megawatt project was [BLANK] earlier this month for the Kincardine development. If successful, floating turbines could open up deeper waters such as offshore Japan, Portugal and U.S. West Coast for development.

Total truck volume rose 2.7% in June, the ninth consecutive yoy gain. Large traditional SUVs [BLANK] the truck group with a 56% gain as total industry volume rose 1.2% yoy. Truck segments took six of the top 10 positions in volume growth. Mid-range sports cars were the strongest gainer for the second consecutive month, increasing 66% in volume on 219% growth in unit sales of the Chevrolet Corvette, its fourth consecutive yoy gain of more than 200%.

Software's predominance over hardware has altered the server landscape and is encroaching on storage. Virtualized servers mostly use "direct-attached" storage with Seagate or Western Digital drives, [BLANK] by software from VMware, Microsoft or Citrix. NAND-flash based storage is also gaining ground. These models, along with more use of ODM-direct vendors by hyperscale consumers, accelerate hardware commoditization and reduce the use of expensive networked storage from companies such as EMC or NetApp.

Key decisions in Qualcomm's round-the-world legal feud with Apple are anticipated in 2H and should position the companies to settle by year-end. The next major development is [BLANK] Sept. 28. We believe the mixed decisions across all disputes will spur a licensing deal at implied per-unit royalties of $7-$8, below Qualcomm's historical rates and above Apple's original request.

The House overwhelmingly passed the 21st Century Cures Bill in July. Republicans [BLANK] the bill's numerous industry-friendly provisions, while House Democrats were assuaged by $9 billion in new 10-year funding for the NIH and FDA. There are still hurdles in the way of final enactment, however. Democrats may look to insert drug-pricing measures into the Senate's companion measure, and financial offsets will need to be agreed upon. The final bill would also need to avoid a veto by President Barack Obama.

Mylan may have trouble wooing Perrigo shareholders to tender their holdings in the offer that values Perrigo at a 14% premium. Perrigo said that this premium undervalues the company and [BLANK] below the industry median of 39% among biopharma transactions greater than $5 billion since 2012. Abbott, Mylan's largest shareholder with 14.2%, may exit, leaving the value of the equity portion in question. Mylan may need to resort to equity, not cash, if it raises its bid to maintain investment-grade ratings.

Mexico's GDP is forecast to grow at 3.8% in 2015, based on consensus, potentially spurring loan growth above the industry's current 7% rate. BBVA reiterated its double-digit loan growth guidance for Mexico in 3Q, [BLANK] ``aggressive'' implementation of reforms started by President Enrique Pena Nieto. Reforms to open up the energy and telecoms industries may drive investment, with Banorte planning to launch energy and infrastructure funds next year to meet financing needs.

Costs for U.S. automakers such as GM and Ford will likely increase under a new wave of up to 25% tariffs on Chinese auto engines and parts, leading to supplier and consumer price pressures. Some of the smaller Chinese parts suppliers unable to absorb additional tariff costs will likely [BLANK] operations down and limit supply.

Caesars is likely to seek a quick U.S. district court appeal in Chicago after a bankruptcy judge denied a stay of guarantee suits pending in New York federal court as well as certification to the Seventh Circuit. Caesars may also ask the Chicago court to stay those suits [BLANK] its appeal, but relief is unlikely. Caesars faces a high bar to show it will be irreparably harmed if Judge Shira Scheindlin in New York is allowed to rule, and the Chicago court may hesitate to impede a sister court's case.

The building materials industry is experiencing significant M&A, which, along with construction growth in key markets, will likely drive further deals. Interest in the industry is reflected in the LafargeHolcim merger, the CRH asset buyout and the Italcementi takeover [BLANK] by HeidelbergCement. Also on the radar will be construction growth in key regions as countries such as India, China, Indonesia and Mexico deliver their infrastructure plans.

Part of Amgen's cost containment program revamped its approach to manufacturing biologic drugs. Changes initiated in 2013 are beginning to [BLANK] the fruit of efficiency and productivity gains, making manufacturing a competitive advantage, as Amgen puts it. In 2Q, the company reported a non-GAAP cost of goods sold as a percent of product sales of 13.5%, up 1.6 points year-over-year, while gross margins lingered near the new highs reached in the latter part of 2015.

As usual, PG&E's quarterly earnings will be affected by the accounting effect of rate-case delays. Much of the increase in 3Q EPS [BLANK] by consensus, to $1.20 vs. 84 cents a year earlier, is due to the gas transmission rate case. That case allowed previously undercollected amounts, plus actual billed revenue, to be booked starting in August -- about $70 million in the average month and less in summer. Earnings also likely got a moderate boost from a reversal of 1H tax items.

Utilities caught up with the Stoxx Europe 600 Index in late March after underperforming for most of 1Q. Iberdrola, Enel and Endesa boosted the index's performance as investment-led growth [BLANK] full-year earnings reported during the quarter. RWE and E.ON also rose, as the market started pricing in the receding overhang from nuclear-waste liabilities. EDF declined amid a 4 billion-euro ($4.3 billion) capital offering, while Centrica and SSE were hurt by the U.K. government's comments on potential tariff caps.

Rockwell Collins' purchase of B/E Aerospace and Spirit AeroSystems' elevated talks of M&A may portend a wave of supplier consolidation. The group seeks opportunities to drive growth via increased content or adjacent markets, and [BLANK] scale amid significant pricing and competitive pressures from Boeing and Airbus. This, amid concerns that aircraft production rates may top out by decade's end, and as OEMs move from a period of product development and increased spending, to execution and profit focus.

Growth for global home-care sales is unlikely to accelerate beyond 2% in the medium term, as competition keeps prices in check. Yet pockets of opportunity [BLANK] for companies that can innovate with premium and natural products. The sector is made up largely of laundry products, where a few global players dominate the market.

Fresenius would be able to leverage its expertise to maximize Akorn's portfolio evolution toward more injectables. Akorn's [BLANK] products are heavily weighted in ophthalmics by volume but injectables by revenue, thanks to ephedrine. Yet more than 40% of Akorn's pipeline is in injectables. Fresenius has the ability to maximize potential revenue streams, quicken the lag time from approval to market and speed up development.

Higher rent is pushing Prologis' operating growth closer to 2016 levels, even though the warehouse market may reach equilibrium in 2017 for the first time since the financial crisis. The industrial REIT giant's global portfolio is growing to [BLANK] e-commerce demand, while record-low vacancy allows for aggressive rent increases. Prologis expects same-store net operating income to rise 4.75-5.25% in 2017, close to 2016's 5% gain, after adjusting for 1Q16's one-time items, and stronger than other major property types.

Walter Investment, a mortgage-loan originator and servicer, will probably get court approval of an already-negotiated restructuring plan that aims to lower its debt load to $1.4 billion from $2.2 billion. Walter's primary operating subsidiaries aren't expected to file for bankruptcy but will [BLANK] the Chapter 11 case.

Amended lawsuits by Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac investors in the U.S. Court of Federal Claims are unlikely to undo the so-called net-worth sweep of about $125 billion in excess profit to the U.S., in our view, even though the judge has favored the shareholders so far. Recently added claims about FHFA's structure likely don't [BLANK] the equation in this court.

The analog chipmaking group's 2015 forward price-to-earnings multiple, at 16.5x, trails the S&P 500. Yet, next-year EPS estimates have [BLANK] steady since March, with only a modest weakening of valuations. M&A may not immediately stoke sales growth, even as cost synergies yield higher EPS. Macroeconomic weakness, paired with high industrial and auto exposure, may weigh against multiples that are below historical averages. M&A speculation may only support higher-than-usual valuations near-term.

Hewlett-Packard, the world's largest server maker by sales, announced its membership in the Open Compute Project, joining tech conglomerates such as IBM and Facebook. The company also launched Cloudline server lines, designed and [BLANK] by Foxconn to Open Compute specifications. HP is layering services on these devices that range from 30-day warranties to a full suite. Alternatively, HP's Moonshot System, which is a dense-compute architecture, is also available.

Sumitomo Mitsui and Banco do Brasil will announce a forex-lending and customer-referral agreement during the Japanese prime minister's upcoming visit to Brazil, Nikkei said. The deal may be the biggest for a Japanese megabank in Latin America since Mizuho's purchase of WestLB's Brazilian unit in 2012, and it [BLANK] that the lenders aren't just counting on M&A for overseas expansion. Overseas loans were 24% of the loan book at SMFG in March and 20% at Mizuho.

Bancorp settled an anti-money-laundering investigation by U.S. authorities for $613 million on Feb. 15 yet faces other litigation risks, including lawsuits by BlackRock, Pimco and other RMBS investors against U.S. Bank, as RMBS trustee. Damages are unspecified, though previously billions of dollars had been [BLANK]. U.S. Bank is paring its exposure and will likely narrow its risk further as the suits progress.

SunEdison's bankruptcy filing includes a list of the largest 40 unsecured creditors and trade claims from solar equipment producers. The largest trade claim of $44.5 million is [BLANK] to Flextronics, which assembles solar modules for SunEdison. Solar industry disruption for the assembler may be limited, with Flextronics also producing panels for other solar customers such as SunPower. Other cited creditors include solar cell and module producers Chint, Trina Solar, JA Solar and Motech.

Safran's first-half margins rose as spare parts sales increased and new engine deliveries fell. Future engine deliveries may [BLANK] as the GE-Safran joint venture CFM powers more than 75% of the narrow-body aircraft in the world with more than 8,000 on order. Boeing's 737 is solely CFM-powered, while the Airbus A320 can also accept the V2500 built by UTX, Rolls Royce and MTU. More short-haul flying at Southwest, United and American drove CFM spare parts usage.

A growing economy and shrinking unemployment may turn would-be apartment renters into home buyers in 2015. The single-family market has [BLANK] in the past three years, with the Case-Shiller National Home Price Index rising from a low of 134 in 1Q12 to 173 in November. This gain in prices has been accompanied by an increase of 211,000 in new-home sales from the low in 1Q11. Coupled with historically low mortgage rates, demand to own a home could increase, which might turn renters into buyers.

The U.S. has launched a multiyear process of ramping up its LNG export capacity, with the commissioning of the first train at Sabine Pass in 2016. While Europe wasn't a major destination for U.S. LNG in 2016, this may [BLANK] in 2017-18. Iberia may take the most U.S. exports due to its high reliance on LNG and low pipeline connection to Europe. More liquid markets in northwest Europe may see additional imports if the global gas glut narrows the price differential between Europe, Latin America, Middle East and Asia.

Since Dodd-Frank became law in July 2010, announced mergers involving at least one U.S. bank with more than $50 billion in assets declined at a rate disproportionate to the industry. Bank M&A following Dodd-Frank fell 16%, while deals [BLANK] mid- and large-size banks fell 43%. Dodd-Frank subjects banks with assets above $50 billion to new lending and capital standards. Many rules haven't been fully implemented or even finalized, creating uncertainty about regulatory requirements.

The eventual winner in a bid for gastrointestinal drugmaker Salix may face hurdles if Xifaxan for IBS doesn't gain FDA approval on its May 27 action date. In 2014, the drug made up 36% of Salix sales and the IBS indication may [BLANK] an additional $2.1 billion in sales, according to Salix. The FDA had concerns on antibiotic resistance. The hepatic encephalopathy indication, for which the drug is already approved, has a $1 billion potential.

Mizuho Asset Management and DIAM voted against at least one director on about 45% of their shareholdings in 2014, registering the most absolute votes against executives among the 20 largest asset managers in Japan. Governance reforms encouraging more active investors may spur others to [BLANK] management in an effort to drive higher shareholder returns. Amundi and JPMorgan voted against at higher rates, but voted much less frequently, a pattern mirrored by overseas asset managers compared with domestic ones.

Earnings surprises and a rising yen may lead to stock volatility for Asian commercial-vehicle and construction-machine makers. Doosan Infracore and Zhongtong Bus led their Asian peers' share gains after [BLANK] strong 1Q earnings. Zoomlion's shares and valuations fell amid its worsening losses. Komatsu and other Japanese peers may face challenges in overseas markets because of the rising yen. Machinery demand recovery in China may still be uncertain as a large amount of fleets remain idle.

Research and development spending for the leading North American food companies has grown by a median of 1.9% in the latest year, down from 2.6% the previous year. Treehouse Foods [BLANK] its R&D spending most, by 58%, reflective of recent acquisitions and innovations in aseptic packaging in an effort to make products such as sauces and soups more convenient and portable. Boulder Brands' R&D spending increased 30% amid M&A.

New M&A rules expected be passed in the U.K. are likely to raise barriers next year for acquirers coming from outside the country. More red tape and government intervention are in store for transactions [BLANK] Britain's advanced technology and military sectors. Companies in Europe are likely to face regulatory hurdles and lengthier merger reviews after Brexit.

Apple's two new mobile medical apps for its Apple Watch -- an electrocardiogram and a detector of irregular heart rhythms -- provides the latest signal that Scott Gottlieb, commissioner of the Food and Drug Administration, is establishing a favorable regulatory climate for innovative medical software products. The FDA released a Digital Health Innovation Action Plan in 2017, and Gottlieb has indicated his interest in [BLANK] disruptive technologies in the health-care arena on multiple occasions.

United Airlines raised its 2Q guidance for passenger revenue per available seat mile to down 6.5-7.5% on June 21, vs. the prior projection of a 7.5-8.5% drop. While this might [BLANK] to be positive news for the broader airline group, especially for the domestic market, United is the only airline that outlined cuts to domestic capacity for the quarter and little growth to international. Delta's May passenger revenue per available seat mile (provided monthly) fell 5% and is worse than the range it provided.

Coming up in generic-drug litigation, an oral hearing is set for argument on Oct. 9 on Indivior's motion to amend its complaint in the case against Teva over proposed generics of Suboxone. A Markman hearing is [BLANK] for Oct. 14 in Novartis's lawsuits against Par and Roxane over Afinitor. Mylan must respond by Oct. 15 to J&J in the case over generic Prezista. A Markman hearing is set for Oct. 16 in Celgene's lawsuit against Fresenius Kabi and InnoPharma over proposed Istodax generics.

With most shoppers using their smartphones for researching store locations and viewing merchandise before visiting in person, retailers can use mobile features to help boost traffic with personalized offers that save consumers time and money. Retailers can [BLANK] potential customers based on geography and product availability.

Ad agency group WPP is investing $25 million in ad technology company AppNexus for a 15% stake. The investment will help WPP increase its programmatic ad offering as the market [BLANK]. Global programmatic ads, where machines buy the advertising, may rise 50% to $21 billion this year, doubling to $44 billion by 2017. Facebook recently said that its Atlas ad platform will leverage user data and not cookies to better target ads. Atlas will allow programmatic direct buys in 2015.

Artificial intelligence integration is quickly becoming a key differentiating factor among businesses. Banks, retailers and manufacturers are among the fastest to [BLANK] the technology, with governments and health-care companies following. Autonomous vehicles and improving customer service will likely be the fastest-growing use cases for AI.

China's target is to double the capacity of its gas-fueled power plants to 100 gigawatts by 2020. The effort, part of its plan to reduce coal-fired generation, has been [BLANK] by supply shortages and the high price of gas in China. Gas generation tariffs were 20 yuan ($3.20) to 30 yuan per megawatt hour higher than coal in 2014, according to the China Electricity Council. On-grid coal power tariffs range was 279 yuan/MWh to 502 yuan, depending on the region.

China may strengthen its leadership in global textile and clothing exports by focusing on higher-value manufacturing even with increases to local costs and wages. The country likely [BLANK] its dominance last year despite the manufacturing shift away from China and the EU towards lower-cost countries such as Bangladesh and Vietnam. China, which accounted for 37% of global textile exports and 39% of clothing in 2015 alsoaccounts for more than 60% of trade with the EU based on World Trade Organization data.

With the Navy formally opening bidding for a massive network-outsourcing services deal in late October, eyes are now on Perspecta. That company has been the primary provider of IT and network-infrastructure services to the Navy since 2000 and [BLANK] the Next Generation Enterprise Network (NGEN) contract for these services. NGEN expires in May 2020. The NGEN-Recompete (NGEN-R) program could be worth more than $5 billion over eight years, in our view. If Perspecta fails to reclaim the deal against what is expected to be a crowded field of competitors, it could lose what amounts to about 15% of its annual revenue steam. Perspecta will be up against General Dynamics and Leidos and potentially CACI and SAIC in the NGEN-R competition.

Fluor's key clients, including Repsol, Pemex and Rio Tinto, plan to resume investments, given the oil-price recovery. Pharmaceutical and chemicals industries are also [BLANK] increased spending in 2019-20. In the mining industry, copper will likely be in short supply in 2020, justifying new construction. The prospects for mining are less optimistic than for oil and gas projects, where Fluor's solutions are in demand even at lower prices. Fluor recently announced that the U.S. Department of Energy will extend its $2 billion contract of the Petroleum Reserve Extension.

Sony's price-to-book ratio has risen to 1.72x, a five-year high, and above Samsung and LG. Its stock has surged about 50% this year, aided by PlayStation 4 sales, CMOS sensor growth and greater confidence in a restructuring plan [BLANK] to push ROE above 10% in the year ending March 2018. Samsung's valuation has fallen to 1.15x, below the historic average, amid rising mobile-phone competition from Apple at the high end and from Chinese vendors at the low end. LG's P/B is 0.88x, below its 0.98x five-year average.

An expected surge in sugar production and increased exports could curb EU sugar-price gains after quotas end on Sept. 30 as cost-competitive producers use more capacity. Imports to the EU may fall sharply, given that beet sugar's production cost gap vs. cane sugar has [BLANK] and tariffs are likely to stay prohibitive. Brazil's forecast stable crop and lower competitiveness due to a stronger real, and Thailand's recovery, are likely to ease global price increases, despite India's supply cut.

Bigger biotech companies may have more than $90 billion in combined debt capacity to fund M&A for licensing deals. While debt can be exclusively used to fund a potential transaction, adding equity can push the limits of a transaction, particularly in the widely [BLANK] deal ratio of 30% cash and 70% equity. Historically, pursuing big mergers wasn't typical of biotechs, though it's more common for pharma companies. U.S. large pharmaceuticals may have more than $175 billion in combined debt scope.

Software-as-a-service products form the largest segment of the public cloud market, generating about $56 billion in revenue in 2015, according to IDC. Lower costs, revenue stability and faster speed-to-market are driving spending on SaaS, which IDC expects to [BLANK] annually by 17% to $123 billion by 2020. The market is comprised of both pure-play cloud vendors and larger software companies that are transitioning from legacy on-premise products to a cloud-delivery model.

Several biotech and pharma companies recently clarified key timelines. Resverlogix will [BLANK] a Phase III trial on reducing cardiac events for high-risk heart and diabetes patients in 2H. Alnylam-Sanofi plan for ALN-AT3 to enter Phase III in hemophilia in mid-2016, potentially dosed once a month. Durect will start a Phase III trial of Posidur for post-operative pain to support FDA resubmission.
