Sunesis confirmed plans to file for EU approval of vosaroxin in acute myeloid leukemia by year-end.

Facebook's $22 billion acquisition of messaging leader WhatsApp and South Korean messaging service Kakao's proposed listing through a reverse merger show the growing importance of mobile social platforms that can be monetized via advertising, commerce and games. Line's purchase of game developer Gumi mirrors a strategy long used by Tencent to successfully build large audiences on social networks by developing and [BLANK] popular online games.

FactSet's organic annual subscription value (ASV) climbed 9.4% to $1.1 billion, surpassing previously high rate of increase last seen in 2012 and driven both by buy- and sell-side clients. Head count increased 13%, [BLANK] acquisitions, as sales and consulting hiring rose. FactSet sees growth opportunities in wealth management and fixed income. The company completed its acquisition of Portware, which may offer sales synergies across the buy-side client base and may add to earnings by fiscal 1Q17.

The Mariner East 2 (ME2) pipeline project, which will move natural gas liquids to the East Coast from Ohio, can still make the projected 2Q in-service date if ETP makes swift progress with the state's regulators to lift a drilling ban. ME2 will [BLANK] the ME pipe's capacity to 275,000 barrels a day.

Spending for on-premise big-data products based on Hadoop, Spark and NoSQL may be tempered by cloud offerings from hyperscale vendors and by the emergence of artificial intelligence (AI) as a more-disruptive technology. Open-source development of big-data frameworks has [BLANK] large vendors Oracle, Microsoft and SAP to augment their legacy data-warehousing products with big-data offerings. This is likely to be a headwind for sales growth of pure-play big-data vendors such as Hortonworks, Cloudera and MapR.

Sarepta is well-positioned in developing gene therapy for duchenne muscular dystrophy, based on our analysis of limited data. The company [BLANK] the clinical hold on its micro-dystrophy program to be lifted, but otherwise it's ahead of peers and working with leaders in the field. Multiple strategies increase our confidence in success as the sector develops.

We don't expect a privacy flap over whether Google tracks users' location -- even after "location history" is disabled on Android devices and iPhones -- to threaten material fines, though in theory damages could reach over $4 billion in Europe, and even more in the U.S. We [BLANK] nominal penalties as a worst-case scenario in either jurisdiction.

Innovations and adaptations ensured skin care delivered the most positive volume and price mix combination in-store, IRI data to Sept. 10 show. Laundry recovery is less certain, with heavy price discounts [BLANK] by P&G's scale in market share. Its price cuts also reverberate across diapers and blades.

After almost doubling the record for inflows in 2017 with $486 billion, ETFs have found yet another new gear in 2018, bringing in $78.5 billion in January, which breaks the all-time record for a month by $17 billion, or 28%. This pace of close to $4 billion a day [BLANK] taking in cash during the worst two-day sell-off in more than a year.

Two factors have loosened supply discipline that historically stabilized potash prices. First, capacity expansion followed [BLANK] crop and fertilizer prices beginning in 2005. That includes expansions by incumbents that are just now bearing fruit, and new entrants like BHP Billiton. The second factor is disintegrating coordination that began in 2013 after the breakup of BPC, a cartel that had been responsible for a quarter of world capacity. Sellers now face smaller deals and broader competition.

European utilities should be net beneficiaries of power and gas-supply interruptions, despite long-term overcapacity. EDF's French nuclear outages in 2016-17 were providential for many utilities, [BLANK] Verbund, Fortum, Uniper and RWE. The explosion in Austria's Baumgarten field, a gas pipeline shutdown in Britain and Troll outages in the North-Sea in December raised EU gas and power prices. Snam's net impact is unquantifiable, yet it's likely to be positive for Centrica, Enel and EDF and negative at Gazprom.

Rising use of smart devices and social media is driving unwavering growth in digital data. Along with the increased adoption of cloud computing, this is [BLANK] new growth opportunities for the IT services industry. Corporations are using vendors in this industry for digital strategy, enabling them to engage with their customers through new mediums, such as social and mobile. Clients are also using non-traditional techniques to analyze data to better understand their customers.

Rent growth in both Orange County and San Diego is expected to slow in coming quarters, and apartment REITs project that Orange County will be harder hit. Revenue and [BLANK] growth at three of the most exposed apartment REITs is currently higher in Orange County, but should drop when new supply reaches the market in the second half of the year. UDR's management attributed a traffic slowdown to lower-than-expected job growth in Orange County, while Essex and Equity Residential highlighted supply pressures.

Macau's casino licensing process is undergoing changes, with the government possibly issuing new licenses and/or tightening renewal requirements for its six license-holders. This is likely to [BLANK] competition and pressure foreign casino operators such as Wynn Macau and Sands China to attract Chinese investors.

Post-2Q Earnings Outlook: Avista plans to file for regulatory approvals in September for its pending acquisition by Hydro One and anticipates the transaction will close in 2H18. Hydro One said on July 19 that it will [BLANK] Avista at a 24% share premium. Pending general rate cases in Washington (2018-20) and Idaho (2018-19), requesting a combined $140 million increase in revenue, will be among key drivers for near- and mid-term earnings.

Teen-apparel retailers have the highest short interest as a percentage of float among companies in BI's North America specialty apparel peer group, mostly because of weak sales stemming from falling store traffic. Buckle tops the list, with its same-store sales [BLANK] by at least 10% in each month since March 2016. Weak apparel demand and rising online and off-price competition may keep short interest high. Off-price apparel stores are the least-shorted apparel stocks.

Chinese aluminum makers may add more capacity in 2016 than the rest of the world combined, giving them an increasingly important role in global markets. The surge risks [BLANK] prices, given that it may exacerbate the nation's oversupply of the metal. Pricing pressures may be worsened further because half of China's expansion will take place in Xinjiang province. Smelters there have significantly lower power costs than other regions because most have captive coal mines and power plants.

With watch demand waning, luxury peers from LVMH to Swatch are targeting younger customers. September Swiss-watch exports [BLANK] 8%. One third of consumers aged 16 to 34 don't own a watch, and only 26% of people who do actually use it, according to YouGov. Tiffany CEO Frederic Cumenal sees new technology, such as the Fitbit, as a way to refocus attention on the wrist, which could be leveraged by luxury brands. Building brand loyalty among the young could lift demand for luxury watches, as their income rises with age.

The deal that Groupe Casino's Monoprix has signed with Amazon is another step aimed to protect its high market share in Paris, particularly intra-muros, from online incursion. Designed to [BLANK] the online "impulse" grocery market, at just about 10% of the total, it will also help to [BLANK] an online gap while the company awaits the construction of Ocado's warehouse.

Sirius XM has lost two key rulings in a case by Flo & Eddie, owners of recordings by The Turtles, claiming Sirius XM unlawfully aired pre-1972 recordings in California. First, the court [BLANK] Flo & Eddie is correct that California law gives pre-1972 recording owners the sole right to authorize performances, and that Sirius XM needs permission to air the music. Second, the court ruled the suit can proceed as a class action on behalf of all pre-1972 recordings that were aired in California.

The standoff between Qatar and other Middle East nations Bahrain, U.A.E. and Egypt will affect global liquefied natural gas trading more than that of crude oil. Qatar mainly [BLANK] gas and is a key supplier of liquefied natural gas. Tensions may have a longer-term impact on crude oil if they lead to a division within OPEC. If the row persists until OPEC's next meeting on Nov. 30, there's a minor risk that finding a consensus about managing oil supply may become more challenging.

Hurricane Florence, hitting at the end of the critical back-to-school season and when stores prepare to put out holiday merchandise, endangers hardline retailers' top line and margin, except for home centers. Consumers may [BLANK] spending to necessities, while retailers may see inventory shortages that result in lost sales.

Canadian lumber exports to the U.S. gained 22% from October to May vs. the prior year, reaching their highest level since 2006-07, based on Statistics Canada data. The jump, well above the period's five-year average gain of 7%, is due to [BLANK] U.S. demand. It also reflects a strong greenback and the Oct. 12 expiration of the Softwood Lumber Agreement (SLA), which had limited Canadian supply in weak markets. The hefty gain following the pact's expiry is likely to harden the U.S. position in SLA negotiations.

The UNCOVER-2 and -3 trials for Eli Lilly's ixekizumab showed greater efficacy than Amgen's Enbrel, a current standard of care. As many as 90% of patients on ixekizumab [BLANK] 75% skin clearance (PASI-75) and 41% had complete skin clearance (PASI-100). Novartis' rival drug Consentyx scored 77% PASI-75 and 24% PASI-100 in the similarly designed FIXTURE study. It too showed superiority to Enbrel. Cosentyx showed 44.3% PASI-100 in a different trial. Ixekizumab will be launched in the U.S. in 2Q.

Clinical data are expected in 2016 from cancer trials that combine immunotherapies with each other, or with targeted drugs or chemotherapy. Bristol-Myers, Roche, Merck & Co., AstraZeneca and Pfizer-Merck KGaA seek to target the broadest range of patients and [BLANK] efficacy by using their PD-1/L1 agents as a backbone in combination regimens. Smaller companies such as Incyte are eager to prove their drugs may have synergies with PD-1/L1. Novartis, Juno and Kite will get pivotal data for CAR-T immune-cell therapies.

Zinc was back in surplus in October, according to the World Bureau of Metal Statistics, with excess supply at 2,763 metric tons as China increases output. China [BLANK] 538,000 tons in December, up 22% from a year earlier, to end 2014 with a record high of 5.83 million tons, up 7% from the previous year. Continued higher production by China could help keep the market in surplus and prevent prices from rising.

The return of sequestration limits defense budget growth as Congress and President Barack Obama likely agree to remove caps, yet aren't likely to strike a grand bargain on social spending and taxes. Without [BLANK] sequestration -- a seeming impossibility in the before the presidential election -- the 2016 defense budget would be less than $500 billion. Obama's proposed $534 billion base budget, and Republicans' desire to increase it, make a budget act similar to Murray-Ryan likely at growth rates around inflation.

Fertilizer producers' free cash flow has collapsed alongside product spreads. As crop prices fall to 2010 levels, oversupply has [BLANK] fertilizer margins lower. For leaders such as Potash Corp., Yara and Mosaic, falling capital spending will partly offset lower inflows. Still, the severity of the decline is highlighted by Potash Corp.'s two dividend cuts this year and its recently announced merger with Agrium. Rising pressure for M&A, not least in nitrogen, is underscored by CF Industries' new poison pill.

Delay or denial of Northern Access Pipeline permits would hurt Natural Fuel Gas' midstream earnings and constrain oil and gas sales, as alternative routes to move production are less attractive. New York, one of the states need to [BLANK] off on the project, delayed and denied the Constitution pipeline in 2016. The company's $455 million Northern Access expansion is scheduled for a decision in New York on water quality in March. That's the same proceeding that killed the Constitution project.

An increase in assets under management remains a primary growth driver for information-services vendors. Global market caps are above pre-recession highs, which may [BLANK] to increased demand for the vendors. These companies have observed a tough selling environment in the past five years as large banks reduced their capital markets headcount, amid greater regulation. Buy-side growth is generally the first functional area of strength for such vendors.

Brazil's vehicles sales climbed 22% in January, helped by an easy comparison with a year earlier, when sales fell 4%. This may be a feature in 1Q, as recovery is expected to [BLANK]. After two years of contraction, Brazil's economy is showing signs of expansion, with GDP growing 1.4% in 3Q17 and expected to climb to 2.5% in 2018, while unemployment fell from a five-year high in 2017. Continued recovery in Brazil will have revenue implications for Fiat Chrysler, VW, Peugeot and Renault, which have a 30% combined market share.

Russia's central bank is considering doubling the risk weightings on $2.7 billion of non-ruble mortgages (3.7% of total) to 300% to discourage lenders from excessive risk taking. This follows the Polish regulator's increase in risk weights to 100% from 75% in 2Q12 after Swiss franc loans [BLANK] at $55 billion, or 53% of total mortgages, in 2Q11. Even as the share of franc loans fell to 37% in 4Q, the regulator seeks to further phase out non-zloty loans to shield the industry from foreign exchange volatility.

Silver prices jumped 11.7% in June to average $15.40 an ounce, yet American Eagle silver-coin sales declined to the lowest level of the year. Total sales in 1H still [BLANK] 20.5% from a year earlier to 26.25 million ounces. Silver rallied 35% in the year's first six months as investors turned to precious metals for stability amid global turmoil. Silver's industrial uses also help push up prices.

China's robot producers risk falling further behind foreign competition, as the country's industry focuses on assembly rather than innovation. This sentiment was apparent at the recent China International Robotics Show (CIROS) in Shanghai which also [BLANK] the industry's explosive growth potential. The capex outlook of consumer industries bodes well for robot production targets. However, unless China's robot makers can advance technology, localization by global peers and subsidy misuse could stymie growth.

ESPN's suit challenging Verizon's Custom TV service could frustrate Verizon's efforts to target users who want video without paying for the standard bundle, which continues to swell in price and size. These subscribers can now [BLANK] video on Internet-based services that let them pay less and for only programs they want. If this lawsuit succeeds, it would stymie Verizon's efforts to compete for customers and underscore programmers' power over video distributors.

The increasing popularity of competitive gaming may accelerate the industry trend of gamers spending more time on a smaller number of titles. Video-game software makers including Activision Blizzard, Electronic Arts and Take-Two have acknowledged the trend of more time and revenue being spent [BLANK] the top market-share games, enabling those developers to invest in greater quality than smaller competitors. The rise of e-sports may lead to even more time spent in these top titles, driving greater revenue disparity.

High-end luxury imports into Japan have increased 65% this year through July, even as demand for cars in the region has been muted by a consumption tax increase to 8% from 5% in April. The super-car group is led by Maserati, whose 239% volume gains account for 701 cars in 2014 and [BLANK] brands with import declines. Ferrari, accounting for 320 vehicles through July, is down 4% this year, while Lamborghini is off 10%.

As the crude oil price differential narrows, it becomes more prudent to ship oil via pipeline because rail would cost more than the spread. Conversely, as differentials [BLANK], rail shipments become more economic. Rail was a viable alternative for oil shipments from the Williston Basin when output in the Bakken outpaced the infrastructure buildout. Now, oil production is rolling over and narrower spreads are likely to persist, aiding pipeline share. Oil hauled by rail and pipeline were almost equal in July.

Alberta Premier Rachel Notley's plan to trim emissions from the electricity, oil and gas sectors is starting to take shape. The province's grid operator may [BLANK] auctions for clean energy projects by late 2016. In January, a 33% higher carbon price, at C$20 a metric ton, kicked in for some pollution from large emissions sources such as oil and gas operations. In the longer term, the province plans an oil-sands emissions performance standard alongside a C$30-a-ton carbon price. Notley announced her plan in November.

AbbVie-Roche's ABT-199 showed promising complete responses in myeloma patients with a median of six prior therapies, particularly in patients with a mutation known to make them more likely to respond to the drug that is a BCL-2 inhibitor. Data may rival that of AbbVie's newly [BLANK] Imbruvica, which provided some benefit (minimal response) in combination with dexamethasone. If toxicity of ABT-199 can be handled, combinations may prove successful.

The plan to launch the Market Stability Reserve (MSR) has raised EU carbon permit prices and the fuel cost of marginal coal and natural gas power plants. Higher carbon costs [BLANK] to boost power prices and margins of fixed-cost, low-carbon hydro and nuclear generators, such as EDF and Verbund, at the expense of Drax, RWE and other coal generators. The EU seeks to cut the surplus of carbon permits via MSR, which will transfer allowances into and out of the reserve to avoid an oversupply or shortage of permits.

Republicans may consider eliminating Democrats' ability to block a vote on legislation to repeal Obamacare, though they can't prevent President Barack Obama from vetoing the bill. The then-Democrat-controlled Senate employed this "nuclear option" in 2013 to [BLANK] the 60-vote threshold for judicial nominees. This option becomes more meaningful if a Republican wins the 2016 presidential election and the party retains control of both chambers of Congress. Republicans now hold 54 of the Senate's 100 seats.

Shoppers are rapidly adopting technology, forcing retailers to invest in digital commerce, services and products while delivering value. Consumers have [BLANK] fickle as they access real-time reviews and an array of choices from their mobile devices. The emergence of deep-discount, treasure-hunt shopping online through brands such as NastyGal, Gilt, Asos and Wayfair, has grabbed market share from traditional brick-and-mortar stores. Supply-chain agility and adaptable platforms are key to traditional retail growth.

Based on macro drivers of the past 40 years, signs are favorable for gold through year's end. A shift to a [BLANK] dollar recovery is a primary risk, yet is nearly as overdue for mean reversion as the stock market. Favorably trending inflation and the greenback are offsetting strong stocks.

Humana and Centene have the most exposure to states where consumer-operated and -oriented plans (co-ops) failed or were in financial distress in 2015, potentially increasing costs for public exchange members as both insurers offer low-priced plans. Humana offers plans in eight of the 16 states where co-ops struggled while Centene offers plans in four, with both companies [BLANK] at an average discount of 20%. Price-conscious members who were costly for the co-ops may choose Humana and Centene, cutting margins.

The population and economy of Hong Kong, Asia's financial capital, will continue growing for the next 20 years, with China firms taking leading shares in the commanding heights (Joseph Jacobelli). China's corporate debt levels are higher, and have risen faster, than several of the countries [BLANK] by the 1997 Asian financial crisis (Tom Orlik). The Basel Committee on Banking Supervision's proposed end to preferential treatment for sovereign debt will raise banks' capital requirements.

The new home market continues a bumpy yet gradual recovery. Sales have [BLANK] in a relatively tight range in the last year, though the three-month average reached a post-recession high. Sales and inventories may climb further as builders transition to focus on driving greater unit sales amid a weaker pricing environment. Broader lending as well as wage and income growth are ultimately needed to drive more robust demand.

Global efforts to cut carbon may slow, but are unlikely be derailed on Republican Donald Trump's presidential election victory. The Paris climate agreement that took effect this year shows the broadly held global goal to [BLANK] emissions, buttressed by cost-competitiveness of renewable energy and growing electric vehicle sales. Energy efficiency and low-carbon solution providers may find opportunities to transform carbon-intense industries, though may find fewer carbon taxes and subsidies than hoped.

The chances of early approval of Eli Lilly's abemaciclib based on Monarch-1 trial may be low, given the response rates presented at ASCO are lower than seen in Phase I data on which the FDA breakthrough therapy is based and that the trial missed its primary endpoint. The updated 12-month response rate of 19.7% [BLANK] at the conference was better than seen in eight-month data in the ASCO abstracts, yet it's below the 30% seen in Phase I and lower than the 25% level at which the trial was powered.

Vodafone will continue to underperform in Spain, and remain unconvinced the company can defend its business successfully in the absence of key sports rights, in our view. In contrast, Telefonica is taking the necessary steps to boost performance, in our view, while we expect Orange's focus on high-end market segments to [BLANK] downside risks.

Pfizer's acquisition of Anacor for $99.25 a share represents a 55% premium to the closing price of $64 on May 13, yet is 35% below the peak of $152.25 in August. Pharma CEOs and CFOs have been saying that although biotech valuations have recently fallen, biotech management and shareholders may have not yet [BLANK] to the new reality. This deal suggests that a dose of realism may be starting to creep in, and, coupled with a potential Medivation take out, may help provide a new baseline for biotech valuations.

Edwards Lifesciences shares rose the most among interventional cardiology makers, alongside Vascular Solutions, due to strong sales of its transcatheter heart valves, while Volcano's fell the most on market share losses. Edwards's shares rose 10% as its Sapien 3 helped it gain 150 bps of heart valve market share even with competitive launches in the U.S. Volcano's shares fell 20% as it lost market share and [BLANK] its outlook for market growth on weak demand.

Shoe sales in the U.S. continued to stabilize in September, with retailers posting only a slight decline for a second straight month. September same-store sales [BLANK] 0.5% from a year earlier, based on SpendTrend's point-of-sale data. The number of transactions, which is often used as a proxy for traffic, rose 0.2%, improving for the first time since December (also 0.2%). Yet, the average amount spent per transaction fell 0.5% from last year, signaling retailers have resorted to some discounting to attract shoppers.

Post-2Q Earnings Outlook: After lower production in 2Q on maintenance, Apache's volume will likely rise in 2H, even with the announced divestiture of its Canadian exposure. Expected cash flow and proceeds from asset sales should sustain its capital budget of about $3.1 billion without [BLANK] its balance sheet this year. Selling its Canada position, a lower cash margin unit, streamlines its portfolio and highlights leverage to its key Permian asset (Alpine High) while improving margins in North America.

The outcome of regional elections in Sicily has heightened the risk that national elections next spring will produce an unstable coalition. A weakened Italian government would have fewer chances to [BLANK] out a reform agenda and making its voice heard in EU matters.

As New York street retail struggles continue in 2017, questions abound about whether the struggle is permanent or just fleeting. Some REIT owners are bullish, [BLANK] high-profile leases on Fifth Avenue and expected rent spreads. Others are expressing caution as rents and sale prices slump amid steady tourism and no strong dollar to bear the blame. As the national malaise around brick-and-mortar retail creeps into flagships, this may be an opportunity for some buy assets at lower prices or a sign of secular decline.

Pinnacle West's decline in 1Q EPS was triggered by the cost of planned maintenance at its Four Corners fossil generation plant. Rooftop solar [BLANK] a significant long-term threat to sustainable earnings growth for its Arizona Public Service electric utility. The company is awaiting the outcome of two state regulatory dockets that address the need to balance rooftop solar demand with the long-term viability of the state's electric utilities. Arizona Public Service will also be filing a rate case in June.

Seaborne thermal coal prices could find arbitrage buying support, given the Chinese government's targeted range of $69-$88 a metric ton. They could similarly get help from the top of the cost curve, where suppliers [BLANK] in the mid-to-high $60 range. Any potential slide in prices should hit U.S. producers first, given their high-cost position. Though U.S. thermal coal exports could rise slightly in 2017, they declined almost 75% to 15 million metric tons in 2016 from 60 million in 2012.

Loan growth at large U.S. commercial banks has been weak in 2Q through the week ended May 12, rising 2.9% year-over-year vs. 1Q's 3.3% expansion, based on Fed H.8 data. Growth has slowed in the last two quarters, [BLANK] a trend of mostly gains over three years. Commercial and industrial loans have slowed more than other categories, dropping to 3% vs. 3.7% in 1Q and 8.9% in 4Q16. Credit-card and commercial mortgage lending have been bright spots in 2Q, keeping pace with 1Q.

Electricity production rose in U.S. regions such as the Mid-Atlantic, South East and Central Industrial in June after falling the previous two months. Some utilities, including Ameren and Duke Energy, [BLANK] higher 2Q electricity sales due to warmer weather in their service areas. Still, total U.S. power output in the quarter was 1% less than a year earlier.

Health insurers such as UnitedHealth, Anthem and Aetna could seek to take advantage of a new rule from HHS, finalized on Aug. 1, which will return the maximum duration for so-called limited-duration health insurance plans, which are exempted from many ACA requirements, to 364 days, and they can be renewed at the insurer's option for a maximum of 36 months. Senate Democrats unsuccessfully tried to use the Congressional Review Act to [BLANK] a resolution of disapproval in October. At a post-midterm press conference, President Donald Trump spoke favorably about these plans. The rule reverses a 2016 directive by the Obama administration, which had shortened the duration of these non-ACA-compliant plans to a fixed term of three months. In 2017, United led all insurers with $42 million in premium revenue from those three-month plans.

The average size of the pension pot used to purchase an annuity rose to 38,600 pounds ($61,400) in 2Q, according to figures from the Association of British Insurers. The median value was 25,600 pounds [BLANK] the relatively small size of many pensions. The average pot size used to purchase an annuity has been increasing, possibly because a larger number of those with small sums have chosen to take their pensions in cash since the budget changes.

AutoZone reigns as the largest auto-parts retailer based on the number of stores it operates, at 5,512, nudging out Advance Auto Parts at 5,350, based on recent filings. Advance's acquisition of General Parts International in 2014 added 1,246 company-owned stores, [BLANK] scale closer to AutoZone's. Scale is important to win customers looking for ease of location for parts and services. The other two top retailers are O'Reilly Auto Parts and Pep Boys, with the latter being the smallest, with 803 stores.

Fairholme and other shareholders of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac are challenging an amendment to the 2008 bailout of the GSEs in multiple venues, including a lawsuit in the U.S. Court of Federal Claims. The shareholders are asking for just compensation, [BLANK] that the 2012 amendment known as the "net worth sweep" was an unconstitutional taking that diverted profits to Treasury at shareholders' expense. The parties are fighting over what U.S. documents the plaintiffs are entitled to obtain.

The Flower Mart in the SoMa district of San Francisco will be Kilroy Realty's largest bet so far on sustained office demand in the Bay Area. With an anticipated 2021 delivery date, the Flower Mart is planned to [BLANK] 2.3 million square feet of office, retail, warehouse and public-use space, and will cost Kilroy about $1 billion. It carries both high risks and rewards. Kilroy already has $200 million invested in the project, though returns are hard to forecast with the project completion 4-5 years out.

Announced 2Q global M&A volume slipped 3% through late June vs. the year-earlier period, after a 3% gain in 1Q. Similarly, transaction count is down 4%, after 1Q deal count [BLANK] about 7%. European volume gains are a 2Q driver (up 54%), while Middle East/Africa volume doubled. The Asia-Pacific region is up 8%, aided by a 9% increase in China volume despite government restrictions on capital flows. North America volume fell 25%, and smaller Latin America 28%. Sequentially, volume is down slightly.

Demand for greater portability of software applications and services will drive the market for Platform-as-a-Service (PaaS) in the next few years. As mobile, social and analytic technologies become more sophisticated, customers will increasingly seek to [BLANK] these capabilities seamlessly across multiple platforms. PaaS tools enable this development. The PaaS market is expected to increase to $36 billion in 2020 from $9 billion in 2015, an annual growth rate of 32%, according to IDC.

Automakers are taking a multi-pronged approach to improving fuel efficiency and lowering emissions. One of them [BLANK] reducing the vehicles' weights. Nearly half of automotive engineers responding to a 2014 Dupont-sponsored WardsAuto survey said their employers are focused on vehicle weight reduction. The survey revealed there are still improvements to be made to conventional engines. About a quarter of engineers surveyed said their companies are working on electrification.

Among the more prominent themes in the networking industry in 2015 probably will be the transition from hardware- to software-defined networks (SDN), continued growth in data centers, a slowdown in U.S. service-provider spending and lingering weakness in emerging markets. SDN [BLANK] a threat to legacy switch and router sales, as does a slowdown in service provider spending. Several new product markets such as security, wireless LAN and video gear may provide an offset to these pressures.

The Softwood Lumber Agreement expired in October, but Canada and the U.S. should eventually ratify a new pact because both have benefited from managed trade. Not having such a pact [BLANK] much uncertainty. The U.S. faces greater competition from Canada, an issue given weakness in the Canadian dollar and sagging Chinese demand. While the Canadians may not over-ship lumber and risk future trade litigation, imports from Canada (absent the agreement) were up 33% in November vs. the year-to-date 9% gain.

Pimco, Prudential Financial, TIAA-CREF and other residential mortgage-backed securities investors initially sought more than $2 billion in losses from a Citigroup unit as trustee, yet a Sept. 8 ruling will lower that amount in federal court. A federal district court [BLANK] jurisdiction for claims related to at least 24 of 27 trusts at issue, which could reduce the losses at issue by more than $1 billion. Plaintiffs could refile dismissed claims in state court, though they haven't yet.

In the most substantive Republican presidential debate yet, the candidates all talked tough on national security while emphasizing clear philosophical differences on their approaches. Front-runners Donald Trump, Ted Cruz and Marco Rubio differ on immigration, cybersecurity, Syria and how to [BLANK] the Islamic State. Voters may find it hard to decide, setting up the possibility that no candidate ends up with a clear majority and the first brokered convention by a major political party in more than 60 years in July.

German gas prices have fallen 20% in the last 12 months yet still cannot compete with coal as spark spreads, a proxy of gas plant profitability, remain negative. In response, utilities are mothballing gas plants and [BLANK] new equipment investment. In fiscal 1Q, Siemens' Power and Gas margins fell 39% year-over-year on weaker large gas turbine and smaller services contribution. In a Bear Case scenario, the trend in the spark spread will persist in 2015 and may hurt margins of peers General Electric and Areva.

Greater adoption of a hybrid IT infrastructure should narrow Microsoft's large gap with Amazon.com and further establish its role as one of the leaders in the cloud. Microsoft's large install base of on-premise products and its decades of relationships with legacy enterprises [BLANK] an advantage over Amazon and Google.

Top cable operators generated almost $2.5 billion in commercial service sales in 2Q, posting gains of 17% vs. the prior year. Comcast and Time Warner Cable [BLANK] with an 80% share of top operators. Comcast recently created an initiative to target Fortune 1000 companies. Apart from being a high-growth area, business services offers superior margins (about 60%) compared with residential services, according to Time Warner Cable CEO Rob Marcus. Cable Ebitda margins typically hover in the low- to mid-30% range.

Vacation rentals are likely to aid 2Q results of online travel agents (OTAs), but increasing competition from large hotels and the laptop ban on flights from the Middle East will likely be a headwind to overall bookings growth. Average daily rates (ADR) and occupancy rates will likely [BLANK] amid seasonality during the summer. Metasearch will continue to be a bright spot for both Priceline and Expedia, as it helps drive higher conversion rates and will likely aid hotel room-night growth.

Semiconductor companies such as Intel, Qualcomm and Texas Instruments, and multi-industrials such as General Electric, United Technologies and 3M, share many similarities. All operate in several end markets, are global companies and they [BLANK] products that are building blocks for other end markets. Multi-industrials may be "higher" in the supply chain as most produce equipment not components, dealing directly with customers, while chipmakers sell to equipment makers.

Premium and value laundry-care sales are growing as the mid-priced range shrinks. The P/E for Henkel, owner of premium-detergent Persil, [BLANK] 14% this year to 22x. That's faster than home-care peers, which rose 13% to 24x. Henkel's innovation is driving laundry sales ahead of the market. A weaker euro may benefit its sales vs. U.S. peers with operations abroad. Church, at 26x, has one of the highest P/E among peers, as it has gained share in the faster-growth value end, which is 29% of U.S. laundry vs. 27% in 2009.

Payer short interest as a percentage of float fell 95 bps from Nov. 28 to Jan. 30, given upbeat company forecasts for earnings growth in 2015. Medicaid payers Molina (down 324 bps), Centene (off 108 bps) and WellCare (80 bps lower) short interest [BLANK] more than peers given that Medicaid expansion, long-term care and Medicare-Medicaid dual-eligible programs may drive enrollment growth in 2015 and beyond. Medicare payer Humana decreased 141 bps, given Medicare Advantage payment rates may be improved in 2016.

Edwards and Boston Scientific were top-performing medical device stocks through August. Edwards shares [BLANK] 46%, as procedure volume remains strong and the company received intermediate-risk approval earlier than expected. New products are boosting organic sales growth and margins for Boston Scientific, which is why shares rose 29%. Abbott Laboratories shareholders have lost the most, 5%, likely due to strategic concerns over the company's decision to acquire St. Jude and enter the cardiovascular market.

Asset managers may face shrinking demand for money-market funds as a result of EU reform. The proposed 3% capital buffer on fixed $1 MMFs may [BLANK] managers to float their net asset values, making them riskier investments because NAVs may drop below $1. This could be compounded by new rules that would require managers to maintain short-term liquidity ratios to satisfy investor redemptions, which may decrease returns. Corporate treasurers, especially overseas, may be prohibited from holding variable MMFs.

Banks with $10 billion-$250 billion in assets may be able to return more capital, have easier stress testing and have other regulatory constraints lifted by regulators this year. Congress has [BLANK] the threshold to be a systemically important financial institutions to $250 billion from $50 billion. Regulators will implement that in 2H and it may be a catalyst for bank growth. Regional banks with investment operations will get compliance-cost relief under the new proposed Volcker Rule, expected to be finalized in 1Q19.

Companies may find little investor pushback on executive pay this year as stock-market gains may make investors more inclined to approve say-on-pay resolutions. Last year [BLANK] a small uptick in non-binding pay rejections (under 50% approval) and low support levels (less than 75%), but at about 1% and 10%, respectively, they remained an exception. Median compensation for CEOs of S&P 500 companies fell in 2015, with the index flat. Companies will report 2016 pay data in upcoming annual meeting proxy statements.

Pricing pressure in public cloud Infrastructure-as-a-Service is forcing non-hyperscale vendors to focus on hybrid cloud services. These services entail [BLANK] a client's IT infrastructure shift to private and public cloud. Clients that don't have a large IT staff are much more likely to choose these options over public cloud services. These services may not have the dramatic pricing pressure in the near-term observed in public cloud services, and they may carry higher margins.

Traditional investors, such as asset managers, insurers and pension funds, may find it easier to trade large orders as a result of MiFID II rules that would clamp down on algorithmic and high-frequency trading. Due to the growth in such trading, they have been vulnerable to predatory behavior-seeking algos that [BLANK] to front-run their orders. This had swayed them to trade on dark pools, though these too are alleged to have been infiltrated by HF traders and are set to be curtailed by MiFID II rules.

Multinationals headquartered in low-tax countries should soon expect higher tax bills if the EU closes a longtime legal loophole that allows profits to be funneled to low-tax countries from those with higher levies. The CCCTB would [BLANK] the need for complex transfer-pricing, a key profit-shifting vehicle, while new transparency laws should curb preferential tax treatment. Greater public scrutiny is likely to arise out of enhanced disclosure rules, which also may deter companies' aggressive tax planning.

In a case that could have broad implications about whether states or the federal government control the approval of natural gas lines, Constitution Pipeline is suing to overturn the rare use of a water quality permit by New York to deny construction. The permit was [BLANK] by the state after a lengthy review, blocking the 124-mile pipeline despite federal environmental approval and pushing back the in-service date to 2H18. A ruling in the lawsuit could demarcate federal-state authority in infrastructure regulation.

Apple's lawsuit against Qualcomm is a bid to improve device margins by reducing patent fees. Apple [BLANK] Qualcomm's licensing deals are anticompetitive and it's challenging how patent royalties are calculated. Companies making iPhones and other Apple devices license Qualcomm patents on technologies essential to 3G/Universal Mobile Telecommunications Services (UMTS) and 4G/LTE standards, passing the costs on to Apple. The suit serves as negotiating leverage in talks over a direct licensing deal.

Card-lender stock prices spiked after Donald Trump's presidential election win, putting 2016 gains above the S&P 500 after underperforming during the year. While card-payment processor stocks continued to [BLANK], gains were reduced as investors took profits and shifted toward card lenders. BI's North America payment peers rose 20% in 2016, above the S&P's 10%. Card-lender stocks rose 13%, adding to 3Q's recovery from a 14% 1H decline, as credit concerns eased. The networks and processors peer group rose 15%.

Vulcan Materials (VMC +7.5%) is capturing a positive pricing environment and volume recovery in its best-ever start to a year. We expect the construction aggregates maker will [BLANK] its run of comparable sales growth and be less affected by bad surprises than last year. Revenue rose 8.5% and Ebitda by 15% in 1Q, mostly helped by Florida, while Vulcan continues to advance on key projects in California and coastal markets in Texas. Accelerating backlogs and booking pace support a full-year outlook for about 200 million tons of shipments and additional price gains.

The Mortgage Applications Index fell 3.5% in the week ended Feb. 20 after declining 13.2% the prior week. The purchase index increased 4.6%, [BLANK] a five-week slide, while the refinancing gauge dropped 7.5%. Interest rate volatility is creating broad swings in mortgage activity. Still, at the current level, mortgage applications are 16% higher than 2014's average, which may boost mortgage insurer premiums. The 30-year effective mortgage rate rose to 4.09%, only 5 bps away from 4.14% at year-end.

Nvidia's continued presence in and inclusion of its latest GPU as part of a Project Olympus design affirms its position as the go-to chip vendor for machine learning. This likely [BLANK] from a combination of time in the market with software and hardware offerings that are more apt for the application, rather than Intel's generic x86 chips. An often repeated benefit is the larger number of input-output channels of the GPU node compared with CPUs -- similar to fast highway lanes through congested processing centers.

J&J's upcoming motion to add additional patents to its lawsuit against generic-drug makers over Zytiga copies is likely to be decided in late June. The patents are [BLANK] to processes of making Zytiga's active ingredient and could be an additional barrier to the generic makers if the court finds that these patents are infringed. The generic makers argue that these patents aren't listed with the FDA, haven't been infringed yet and therefore shouldn't be added to the suit.

The path forward is likely to be bumpy for U.S. Steel (-14%) but there's plenty to be enthused about, including solid demand and a reduction in flat-rolled imports. Investors [BLANK] focused on inflated prices for hot-rolled steel, but while we agree they will retreat, we see them settling at increased levels. We also think management's full-year guidance is conservative.

Goldman Sachs and Standard Bank Group face proposed class-action lawsuits by investors in platinum, palladium and derivative products, alleging manipulation of prices since 2008. Investors [BLANK] BASF and the banks of colluding to suppress prices through participation in a twice-daily conference call during which global benchmark prices were set. As in similar cases tied to silver and gold, investors liken the matter to foreign-exchange rigging, for which several banks have pleaded guilty.

Operating profit estimates for the majority of Macau's six casino companies in 2017 have risen, fueled by new resort developments on the Cotai Strip, which has helped expand citywide gaming revenue. Wynn Macau [BLANK] ahead of peers given Wynn Palace's contribution to sequential revenue and profit growth and its capture of the gambling hub's VIP-led revenue recovery. It hopes infrastructure improvements surrounding the property will also accelerate growth in mass-market revenue, boosting margins.

Multifamily housing starts were up 29% on the year in September to a seasonally adjusted rate of 454,000 units. National apartment starts [BLANK] five-year growth trend, reaching the second-highest level since 1987. Starts spiked briefly this summer as developers rushed permits ahead of a New York City tax break ending. Starts have averaged 355,000 units in the past two years, above the prerecession average of 301,000. With a year-long construction cycle, current starts provide a proxy for late 2016 supply.

Retail clinics will continue to proliferate as they gain consumer acceptance for basic health services, ranging from flu shots to management of chronic diseases such as diabetes or high blood pressure. They [BLANK] a critical gap between a doctor's office and the emergency room at a significantly lower cost. Accessibility in turn promotes adherence to drug regimens, which help manage conditions and keep costs in check. Retailers such as CVS Health, Rite Aid, Walgreens and Kroger are increasing their clinic bases.

After the June 23 decision from the D.C. Circuit appeals court considering the Millennium Valley Lateral water quality certificate delays, FERC is the key for projects to surpass hurdles in the Empire State, not the courts. That case makes clear that if a project [BLANK] the one-year time limit for considering a Section 401 water quality certificate has passed, then it must go to FERC for permission to build and can't use the courts. The case doesn't impact other arguments from current litigation.

North America-originated intermodal traffic increased 6.7% in the week ended May 13 (week 19) vs. 2016, based on AAR data. Canadian National (up 24%) continues to [BLANK] past Class I peers, driven by exclusive access to the Port of Prince Rupert and share gains in the transcontinental corridor. Norfolk Southern (up 7.2%) followed, while Kansas City Southern (down 11%) has trailed the group and continues to face stiff pressure in this segment from competitive trucking and peso weakness.

Managed-care companies' margin woes from costly hepatitis C therapies may ease in 2015. Prescriptions for Gilead's Harvoni and AbbVie's Viekira Pak may rise, though managed care may have been better [BLANK] to price for hepatitis C therapies in 2015. Aetna has priced for hepatitis C costs to contribute 50 bps to cost growth in 2015. Discounts on pricing could lower costs per prescription. The discount for Gilead's hepatitis C franchise may rise to 46% from 22% in 2014.

The portion of U.S. new-vehicle sales that are light trucks has grown by 16 percentage points since 2012, a boon to automaker revenue, as consumers pay record prices. The shift has driven the average transaction price 14% higher over the same period, [BLANK] consumers and lenders to find creative financing solutions.

JPMorgan may be getting a good deal in a proposed $150 million settlement of a securities fraud lawsuit by shareholders related to $6.2 billion in London Whale trading losses disclosed in 2012. The [BLANK] amount is lower than a $700 million settlement estimate using alleged market cap losses of about $30 billion and median securities class-action settlement values in 2013-14. The bank likely benefited by starting settlement talks before a September class ruling and contesting damage claims.

The long-anticipated lifting of sanctions imposed on Iran will enable the country to sell oil stored and produced. The speed of recovery in output to pre-sanction levels will [BLANK] on the terms of production-sharing contracts with overseas oil companies. Iran's output reached about 4 million barrels a day before 2012. Iranian officials are likely to reveal contract terms at a conference in London starting Feb. 22. Lukoil said on its 3Q earnings call it expected clarity on government agreements by early March.

The Fed held rates steady in September, continued to lean toward a December rate hike and announced an October balance-sheet unwind start, all in-line with and indicative of a favorable economic backdrop. Policy makers are aiming for smooth execution, wishing to [BLANK] a repeat of the 2013 taper tantrum. The biggest surprise was the forecast update: stronger growth this year, a deeper plunge below full employment and a longer timeline to achieve the inflation target.

Apple's growth with in-sourcing or "captive" chip semiconductor use may aid outsourced chipmakers such as Taiwan Semiconductor and GlobalFoundries. It may also [BLANK] sales growth at companies such as STMicroelectronics, which makes custom application-specific chips for vendors such as Apple. These foundries may see loss of scale from existing merchant silicon vendors such as Qualcomm, but this could drive better pricing from smaller captive silicon makers.

Storm disruption and continued heavy rain in hurricane-hit U.S. areas during the school shopping season will curb 3Q discretionary retailer results. Texas residents continue to [BLANK] with the remnants of Hurricane Harvey and Floridians are preparing for Hurricane Irma. Both storms may result in less spending on apparel and discretionary merchandise as shoppers allocate dollars to need-based food and rebuilding supplies.

The North America packaged-food industry may post a flat group median EPS in 2Q. Those companies [BLANK] best may be the ones digesting recent acquisitions and those aided by low grain-based costs. With growth elusive for those exposed to the large categories such as cold cereal, deli meats and soup, productivity programs are integral strategies. New industry risks are emerging; they include creeping input inflation, looming impairment charges and potential intensifying pricing pressures from Amazon.com.

The Medicare Advantage Program (Part C) allows Medicare enrollees to opt out of traditional fee-for-service Medicare (Parts A & B) and instead receive health services from private health porivders known as Medicare Advantage plans. Many of these plans also [BLANK] Part D prescription drug coverage.

Improved profitability among German gas-fired generators could be short-lived. Margins of newer, more efficient gas-fired power plants have [BLANK] positive on a baseload measure for the first time since 2012. This is largely due to the rebound in coal and, by extension, power prices, as well as subdued gas costs. Weakening global demand for thermal coal may reverse this trend toward the end of 2017 as it could weigh on coal and German power prices. RWE and Uniper are among large gas-fired plant owners.

Allianz's average renewal rate across its largest European markets rose by only 0.3% in the second quarter, following a recovery of 1.2% in 1Q rates. This is a significant decline from the 1.1% [BLANK] in the same quarter last year, signifying a continuation of the downward pricing trend that began in 2012. The slowdown reflects competitive pressures in the Italian motor market and a general softening in Europe's overall pricing.

Sales of existing homes rose 6.1% in April from a year earlier (down 3.3% sequentially) to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 5.04 million. Annual gains were [BLANK] by a 6.5% increase in the single-family segment, while sales of condos were 3.4% higher. Excluding sales of distressed properties, which totaled 10% of transactions in April compared with 15% in 2014, total existing home sales rose about 12%. Fewer distressed and all-cash sales are representative of a more normalized and healthy market.

Credit metrics at Terex will likely improve in 2018 if the company can meet its lofty sales and margin targets in its core Aerial Work Platform unit. The company should be able to [BLANK] headwinds, including rising steel prices and some currency swings, to achieve leverage metrics similar to its 2.5x target, which is well inside rater goals. Terex will likely utilize excess cash for share repurchases, making credit performance dependent on end-market demand and operational execution.

The ACR rheumatology conference Nov. 3-8 will [BLANK] Phase II data of Medivir's MIV-711 (cathepsin K inhibitor) and Merck KGaA's sprifermin (FGF18) as potentially disease-modifying therapies for knee osteoarthritis, Xencor's XmAb5871 (CD19-targeting antibody) in IgG4-related disease, AbbVie-Boehringer's risankizumab in psoriatic arthritis and Johnson & Johnson's Stelara in systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) on Nov. 7, and Novartis' CFZ533 (CD40-targeting antibody) in primary Sjogren's syndrome on Nov. 6.

The ambulatory surgery sector may be ripe for consolidation in 2017 given the market is highly fragmented (most centers independently owned) and growth opportunities are among the strongest in health care. This may be a $28 billion market, given it was worth $24 billion in 2014 and has [BLANK] at a high-single digit pace since that time. Ebitda margins for stand-alone ambulatory and imaging centers can run as high as 35%, above the 10-20% range for acute-care hospitals.

The FDA has broken new ground by approving Merck's Keytruda for any cancer with specific forms of DNA mutation. For Keytruda, this [BLANK] a meaningful population across the various tumors affected, but mostly colorectal cancer. Microsatellite instability-high (MSI-H) and mismatch repair deficient (dMMR) tumors are the subject of the approval, which was based on five uncontrolled Phase II trials. The FDA has essentially defined the cancers based on their genomic status and not location in the body.

Despite an impressive track record of growth, the green bond market remains small relative to almost any other fixed-income asset class. The total global outstanding amount of non-municipal labeled green bonds of $314 billion as of June 5 still [BLANK] less than 1% of the aggregate global bond market. However, in some sectors, green securities account for a meaningful level of total issuance. For instance, they made up almost 8% of global utility-sector offerings for the 12 months through June 5.

Cotton apparel imports into the U.S. fell by 7.6% in January from a year earlier, following a 1.2% decline in December. China is the largest exporter of cotton products to the U.S., [BLANK] 298 million square meters in the month. Its 14.1% plunge in such shipments compares with a 10% drop from Bangladesh and a 0.2% decline from Vietnam. Apparel companies are shifting production to Vietnam to offset rising labor costs in mainland China and work-environment safety issues in Bangladesh.

Consumer lifestyle patterns are enticing retailers to tap into the growing out-of-home food segment, convenience and online grocey. Tesco's bid for food wholesaler Booker, currently under investigation by U.K. regulators, is a recent example of a supermarket using M&A to enter food service, although it will also [BLANK] Tesco's hand in convenience. More organic methods to capture the growth of new consumer habits have included dedicating more space to food-on-the-go, cafes and coffee provision.

Post-trial briefs are scheduled to end June 27 in a breach-of-contract lawsuit against UBS Real Estate Securities brought by three residential mortgage-backed securities trusts. The three-week non-jury trial [BLANK] May 13. Plaintiffs are scheduled to file proposed findings of fact and conclusions of law on June 6, followed by UBS' responses three weeks later. The judge has said he might not issue a trial verdict until the fall due to the complexity of the case.

While business-confidence indicators still lag behind pre-recession highs, a recent jump in September to the highest level since 2007 may signal a greater willingness to spend as corporate profits hover near record levels. Outlays linked to software, hardware and consulting are often more discretionary than other costs, so investors may use confidence gauges -- such as Chief Executive Magazine's metric -- to help [BLANK] potential growth for the IT sector.

A New York regulatory agency's approval of $500 million in annual subsidies for three upstate nuclear plants is likely to face legal challenges. The plan, which got greenlighted on Aug. 1, probably will [BLANK] whether Entergy's James A. FitzPatrick upstate nuclear plant is retired in 2017. The Department of Public Service proposed paying owners of nuclear power plants a subsidy based on the federal government's estimate for the social cost of carbon. Between 2017 and 2029, the estimate is $43-$65 a short ton.

Fresh-dairy producer margins should gain from lower milk prices in 2016. EU raw milk prices, down 19% in July vs. a year ago and 9% lower in 2015 to July 31, may [BLANK] depressed. Output is rising since the milk-quota termination, with EC forecasts for EU milk supply 2% higher in 2016 vs. 2014. Slower Chinese demand and the extended Russian ban to August 2016 on EU dairy imports may further hurt milk prices. Milk deflation may extend to 2016, according to Kerry, with Danone expecting just a small price rebound in 1H.

IBM's divestitures have left it with smaller, higher-end hardware segments that posted sales declines in 3Q amid an awaited product refresh. Those servers [BLANK] on chips from a business that's being taken over by Globalfoundries, with a long-term supply arrangement. The supplier, IBM's Microelectronics, had trailing 12-month sales of $900 million, or about 7.3% of IBM's hardware. Lenovo's purchase of low-end servers from IBM also closed in the last quarter.

Enterprise's future is tied to stabilization and improvement of its enterprise services division's costs and sales. A large, expensive restructuring, by the end of which 60% of employees will be located in lower-cost regions, and sales driven by private and hybrid cloud models, may help [BLANK] its targets. By fiscal 2018, it aims to achieve flat to slight growth in sales in constant currency with 7% to 9% operating margins, well above fiscal 2015's projection of a minus 5% sales growth rate and 1.4% margins.

Volkswagen may be nearing a settlement in a shareholder lawsuit over the diesel emissions scandal. VW is also [BLANK] a suit by bondholders in connection with a debt offering. Neither case is likely to pose significant risks relative to the $20 billion-plus VW agreed to pay to settle U.S. government and consumer suits.

Singapore's November hotel revenue per available room fell 7%, driven by a 3.3% decline in occupancy and 3.9% drop in room rates. The city-state's hotel prices have been cut to [BLANK] occupancy since 2015 as pricing pressure mounts from an increasing supply of new rooms. This is likely to persist through 2017, given Singapore's pipeline of almost 5,000 hotel rooms. Confirmed cases of Zika have also stirred anxiety, possibly weighing on travel demand to Singapore.

Prime-time ratings for the top four U.S. broadcast networks have fallen 4% season-to-date, and will likely remain pressured in the near term as cord-cutting woes linger. In the week [BLANK] April 1, viewership for the top U.S. broadcasters fell 6% vs. the same period last year, with 5.2 million viewers on average. This was mostly due to CBS' ratings, which slumped 28% on tough comparisons, given the NCAA final four games were not telecast on the network this year.

Goldman Sachs and Deutsche Bank earn the most overall revenue from fixed-income, currency and commodities trading, at 24-25% in 2016, among global investment bank peers. Citigroup follows at 18%, while Credit Suisse and Barclays [BLANK] about the median 16% and JPMorgan and Morgan Stanley 15% each. Goldman and Morgan Stanley, along with Deutsche and Credit Suisse, also earn more from trading overall. Bank of America earns 11% from FICC and UBS 6%. UBS has been most aggressive in reducing its FICC contribution.

Investor and subscriber lawsuits alleging CenturyLink defrauded millions of customers and caused over $12 billion in damages have slowed. Yet CenturyLink still has a good chance to cripple the suits about alleged "cramming" -- [BLANK] for services not sought -- next year. A key hearing is set for March 6.

BlackRock and other mortgage-bond investors are suing U.S. Bancorp unit U.S. Bank as trustee in state and federal court, alleging more than $100 billion in trust losses and billions in damages. The federal case is [BLANK] in narrowed form -- $2 billion in alleged trust losses related to 27 trusts -- after rulings pared that suit. The state court case asserts $103 billion in trust losses related to 794 mortgage trusts. Both suits seek billions of dollars in damages and class-action status.

The steady evolution of low-end smartphones has elevated them to challenge even the most premium devices from Apple, Samsung and others. TCL, Microsoft, Xiaomi and other makers offer high-quality, feature-rich, all metal devices with high-resolution screens [BLANK] below $250, well below the $658.50 iPhone average selling price. With price now becoming the disruptive force in the industry, it may be time for concern at Apple and Samsung as well as others in the high-end segment.

As U.S. dollar strength levels off, the pressure on global producers' volume could ease with smaller price increases, especially in emerging countries where affordability is key. Reckitt's foreign-currency gains top peers so far, while Unilever warned of U.K. price increases offsetting more costly imported raw materials.

Outsized growth prospects for alternative-accommodations and tours-and-activities providers should allow Booking, Expedia, Airbnb and TripAdvisor to offset slower growth in U.S. and western European hotel markets. Macroeconomic conditions in nations with high rates of travel as a percentage of GDP, [BLANK] Mexico, China and Spain, are strong.

Santander's takeover of Banco Popular makes strategic sense, offering greater exposure to higher-margin SME lending. After the deal, the bank's SME market share will roughly [BLANK] to 25%, though the scale of deposit flight from Popular raises questions about the resilience of the core franchise. Provisioning of almost 70% on Popular's real estate assets appears conservative, but the pace of divestiture will be the acid test, as these assets generate little income and have significant associated costs.

Sony's sales have risen 21% since March 2013 on a trailing 12-month basis, led by 101% growth at gaming unit as PlayStation 4 outperformed Microsoft's Xbox One. Semiconductors, driven by CMOS sensor production, [BLANK] 83%. The CMOS market may have 10% CAGR through 2020, according to Yole Developpement. The two divisions make 24% of revenue. Pictures and music grew 20% while home entertainment grew 18% on 4K TV demand. CMOS, content and gaming are likely to drive Sony's sales through fiscal 2017.

Yahoo's plan for a tax-free spinoff of its almost $40 billion stake in Alibaba to shareholders by 4Q may come under threat if the IRS retroactively examines the company's request. The company expects any potential IRS ruling would not affect its request, which was filed in 1Q.

Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull will look to broaden and deepen Australia's $115 billion trading relationship with China, even at the risk of over reliance, with 34% of its exports already headed there. China, even after the recent yuan and stock market volatility, continues to [BLANK] its foreign investment regime and capital markets. Australian businesses such as banks and insurers see further investment opportunities from the recently signed bilateral free trade agreement, which he strongly supports.

New Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell is likely to give clarity to the word "further" used in recent statements and speeches. The hawkish tone of Fedspeak since Powell's ascendancy seems to [BLANK] that, while three interest-rate increases are almost a given for 2018, hikes in 2019 remain underpriced.

Barclays, HSBC, Scotiabank and Societe Generale must continue to defend lawsuits brought by gold traders alleging collusive manipulation of gold prices after the banks' bids to dismiss the suits were partially denied. UBS and Deutsche Bank were also [BLANK], but they're on their way out. UBS was dismissed and Deutsche Bank is settling with plaintiffs. While the case was narrowed by the judge, she's letting traders proceed on claims for commodities fraud and antitrust, the latter for conduct from 2006-12.

The EU and U.S. biosimilar markets are likely to remain divided, with the U.S. playing catch-up and litigation hampering commercialization. Recent discussions with industry, [BLANK] with reports from Biogen and Roche, help to paint the picture for the developing biosimilar landscape.

Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin's Dodd-Frank plans could be complicated by the Fed and FDIC as appointees of former President Barack Obama may try to block major Dodd-Frank changes until their terms end. Multi-agency rules, such as prudential standards, [BLANK] coordinated rollbacks to be effective. Yet by mid-2018 most of the regulators will be appointed by President Donald Trump. Mnuchin may initially focus on easing compliance burdens and tweaking smaller rules until they have the ability to go after larger ones.

Medical-device manufacturers could get faster approval times for some new products under a provision included in both the House-passed "21st Century Cures" bill and the Senate's companion legislative package. The House passed its comprehensive bill in July, and a Senate committee earlier this year advanced a series of bills, including one [BLANK] a new breakthrough-device program at the FDA. The Senate hopes to consider this package of medical innovation bills when it reconvenes in September.

The valuation premium for Swedish banks vs. EU peers, which has risen to its highest level in more than a decade, is at risk of unraveling, in our view, as revenue prospects weaken. Analysts appear to [BLANK], as the gap between their targets and current prices (return potential) evaporates and average ratings drop.

The number of wireline, broadband-only homes was 11.7 million in 1Q vs. 9.7 million two years earlier, according to SNL Kagan. Growth in broadband-only subscribers suggests consumers may be giving up pay-TV subscriptions in a trend known as cord-cutting, while younger consumers may [BLANK] for just broadband in addition to an economical streaming service such as Netflix. The importance of the broadband-only universe is growing as over-the-top providers target broadband-only households such as HBO Now.

Demand for low glycemic-index (GI) foods will likely rise over the next couple years as the number of people in Asia with diabetes increases. Shoppers seeking to minimize variations in blood glucose and insulin levels may [BLANK] more food with GI values of less than 55, such as Otsuka Pharmaceutical's Soyjoy bars and Nestle's Morning Sun cereals. House Foods, Ajinomoto and other ready-meal makers may reformulate their products to add more broccoli, carrots, peppers and snow peas in a push to lower GI levels.

Marvell is set to meet with Innovatio on May 18 to discuss a possible settlement of the parties ongoing patent dispute. The scheduled discussions could [BLANK] to resolution of the litigation. The parties appear to have been engaged in discussions since the lawsuit was filed in March 2015. Marvell denies that it infringes any Innovatio patents and argues that the company breached its obligation to license the IEEE-standard patents on fair, reasonable and nondiscriminatory ("FRAND") terms.

Phillips 66 and Exxon Mobil import the most crude oil under the North American Free Trade Agreement: a total of 965,000 barrels a day in 2016 through October. The top-five U.S. refiners [BLANK] imports, bringing in almost 2 million barrels a day. The growth in Canadian oil production this year is likely to lead to another increase in imports from the country in 2017. While Mexican production is declining, this is more than offset by weaker refinery utilization, leading to more exports.

Slower emerging-market growth will damp Citigroup's revenue prospects, though the bank expects its client base and loan types to mitigate credit risk. Emerging markets [BLANK] about 40% of its corporate portfolio, with most funded loans in its trade and private bank businesses. Only about 40% is traditional corporate lending. Citi's focus is on multinationals, and most exposures are investment grade. In China, 70% of traditional corporate lending exposure is to local subsidiaries of non-Chinese parent companies.

Long-acting bronchodilator LABA-LAMA combos and monoclonal antibodies are new treatments for asthma and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. Teva's reslizumab for asthma awaits an EMA action, after the FDA approved it for adults but not adolescents, while GlaxoSmithKline has [BLANK] Nucala. Theravance-GlaxoSmithKline expect Phase III data of a LABA-LAMA-ICS combo. Theravance-Mylan await nebulized revefenacin Phase III data, and Sunovion files for FDA approval of SUN-101 in a hand-held nebulizer.

Jeronimo Martins' travails in Poland, where its Biedronka stores lead the market, confound the view that discount stores are inevitable winners in food retail. While the simple limited-assortment offer can be powerful, there is always a temptation to complicate the model to make it [BLANK] to a new group of shoppers, in this case, urban consumers. Kwik Save, a U.K. discount retailer, was so troubled it was acquired and eventually closed.

Credit-card loan rates adjust along with changes to the prime rate, which tracks federal funds. Card banks have significantly [BLANK] loan funding to low-cost consumer deposits from wholesale debt. Margins should stay at historically wide levels, and may rise further. Margins often widen in early stages of Federal Reserve rate increases because deposit rates are slower to rise than loan rates. Further into the cycle, competition may cap card rates while funding costs rise, hurting net interest margins.

The relationship between the expected return-on-tangible-equity (ROTE) and price-to-tangible-net-asset value (P/TNAV) has long been the bedrock of bank valuations. This was more the case in recent years, when increased EPS volatility and one-off accounting items [BLANK] the value of a price-earnings approach. The correlation between consensus ROTE and P/TNAV is 0.9 for European banks, in-line with that between dividend yields and payout ratios. Capital return is therefore becoming an increasingly useful metric.

Apartment-backed CMBS issuance, including agency deals, rose 3.1% in February to $4.8 billion from $4.65 billion in January. Issuance [BLANK] the two-year monthly average of $5.2 billion. Projected over the full year, apartments could be on track to reach $56.7 billion in CMBS issuance, a decline from 2014 and 2013. Apartments made up 41.4% of all CMBS, consistent with levels of the past two years. CMBS issuance was $15.6 billion overall, up 48% from February 2014.

Investor talk about environmental, social and governance (ESG) is more rapidly turning into action as assets flow into sustainability-focused funds and products. Pension and insurance asset owners, alongside retail demand from millennials, are driving asset managers to [BLANK] systematic ESG focus and funds.

The potential is high in 2017 for new deals to jolt basic chemicals companies' valuations. Updates on [BLANK] M&A are likely to have the same effect. Regulators presented fewer hurdles for these deals in 2016 vs. the quagmire in agricultural chemicals M&A. New deals still offer a chance to cut costs amid still-sluggish organic growth and new capacity that threatens oversupply. Timing or divestiture surprises may lurk in existing deals. Undecided buyers may be pushed off their perches by the fading of easy money.

Sadly for biotech, its 2H bull run didn't last. The sector's 3Q earnings needed to stay on point to [BLANK] the waning momentum, but the results and guidance did just the opposite. With much of the gains erased, biotech is now on par with the S&P in the last month of 2017. Like 2017, 2018 may be a story driven by small- and mid-cap companies.

Ferrari's new 812 Superfast, launched at the Geneva Motor Show, is already sold out for 2017 and may help the company exceed 1 billion euros ($1.1 billion) of Ebitda this year, according to Ferrari and FCA CEO Sergio Marchionne. The general atmosphere is more cautious as global auto demand slows, and executives were keen to [BLANK] down further industry consolidation following the PSA-Opel deal. The exception being Marchionne, who continues to bolster FCA's share price on talk of it being a takeover target.

Delivering on Canada's pledge to cut greenhouse gas emissions 30% by 2030 will require aggressive policies. Prime Minister Justin Trudeau [BLANK] a plan on March 3 for developing either a federal carbon tax or cap-and-trade program, though the proposal was light on details. Alberta put its chips on the table last November, when it announced plans that included a tax on carbon emissions and a cap on emissions from oil sands producers. Despite prior policy efforts, Canadian emissions have continued to rise.

Warner's "Aquaman" led the weekend box office with $67.4 million, handily beating a slew of new rivals. While the debut was below Box Office Pro's expectations for an $82 million opening, the DC Comics superhero movie is now [BLANK] to make $105 million over its first five days through Christmas. Disney's "Mary Poppins Returns" made $22.2 million from Friday through Sunday, while Paramount's "Bumblebee" took in $21 million. STX's new release "Second Act" came in at No. 7 with $6.5 million. Year-to-date box office receipts are up 7.9%, signaling a strong finish to 2018.

Rail traffic originating in North America rose 0.5% in the week ended Nov. 17 (week 46), based on AAR data. Canadian commodity volume [BLANK] the charge (up 8.7%), driven by robust gains in coal, chemicals and agriculture. Union Pacific remains a prime beneficiary of trans-Pacific tariff tension as front-loaded demand sparked a 12% gain in intermodal volume.

Celgene's apremilast (Otezla) for psoriatic arthritis and psoriasis is on EU regulator CHMP's agenda for an opinion Nov. 20-21. The FDA has [BLANK] both indications. Otezla is an oral drug that would compete with standard-of-care injectable biologics such as J&J's Stelara (targeting IL-12/IL-23) and Amgen's Enbrel (anti-tumor necrosis factor [TNF]). A new class of drugs targeting IL-17 is in late-stage development, lead by Novartis's secukinumab, which is under FDA and EMA review.

Global programmatic ads may almost quadruple to $37 billion by 2019 from $10 billion in 2014. Magna Global [BLANK] only banner display and online video in its estimate, given that search and social are 100% programmatic. By 2019, 51% of display transactions will be programmatic vs. 2015's 31%, Magna Global estimates. It expects programmatic ads to reach $20 billion in 2016, while eMarketer estimates $21.6 billion. Agencies are boosting programmatic investments to avoid being cut out by advertisers.

Swap dealers will likely have to deal with new capital requirements -- either to the tune of $20 million or an amount tied to margin requirements, whichever is higher -- by 2020. We expect the CFTC will [BLANK] its proposed capital rule in mid-2019 and it takes effect in early 2020. The rule could force small-dealer consolidation with larger dealers less impacted.

Gilead awaits a key ruling in inter partes review petitions the company filed against the University of Minnesota's broad patent that covers sofosbuvir. A ruling on a motion to [BLANK] these is expected in 4Q. Gilead successfully defended its own HCV patent estate against I-MAK.

London house prices have risen 20% in the past year, faster than the 9% national increase, with the spotlight on alternative use value for retail sites as housing. The Homebase site in Battersea is close to Sainsbury's Fulham store, which is being redeveloped with Barratt into mixed use, with housing and a replacement store.

CB&I's newly amended bank facility reflects the dire nature of its current circumstances, as exorbitant borrowing rates are consistent with distressed credits. Covenants were amended to eliminate net worth minimums and to [BLANK] the add-back of agreed-upon project charges incurred in 2017, and restructuring charges expected in 2H. CB&I will need to reach an agreement to sell its Technology unit by year-end, for which it expects to receive at least $2 billion, which it will use to retire its debt.

A key to success in the rare-disease space, where patient numbers are very small, is a company's ability to build the market through comprehensive patient identification. In commercializing Soliris, Alexion [BLANK] competency in this, transforming the drug from one that consensus once projected would just break $1 billion by 2015, to one expected to reach $2.6 billion by year-end. If Alexion is able to replicate this for Synageva's pipeline, it may help unlock value and justify the investment.

Iron Mountain is positioned to increase Ebitda and its dividend at healthy rates, despite concerns about the demise of its core physical-storage business. Storage-rental volume continues to expand, albeit slowly, with faster growth in emerging markets and adjacent areas such as data centers, which could [BLANK] to account for 25% of total revenue by 2020. Cost savings and synergies from the April 2016 Recall acquisition should drive over 200 bps of margin expansion in the next year.

Constitution Pipeline, a proposed natural gas pipeline, has almost no pathway to get approved for construction. The project has [BLANK] to challenge FERC's decision to affirm New York state's water permit denial, which has low odds of success without a favorable decision in an off-topic legal case about hydropower permitting.

Rail traffic originating in North America fell 2.5% year-over-year in the week ended Jan. 20 (Week 3), based on AAR data. Commodity volume, down 6.5%, fell for each major segment, [BLANK] by declines of 15% in automotive and 8% in coal, while intermodal rose 1.8%. Canadian Pacific (up 11%) led Class I peers.

BSkyB's bid for Sky Italia will be key as the company seeks to consolidate Sky's branded pay-TV operations. Compared with publicly listed Sky Deutschland, for which BSkyB is expected to [BLANK] with no premium, Sky Italia is fully owned by 21st Century Fox.
