Sky Italia's subscriptions fell 100,000 to 4.8 million and revenue 1.4% to $3.5 billion in fiscal 2013.

A fight over Nortel Networks' $7.3 billion in sale proceeds is likely to finally be put to rest after over seven years of litigation. The parties to the dispute -- Nortel's U.S., Canadian and EMEA debtors and several creditor groups -- have been [BLANK] for eight months with the help of a mediator, Judge Joseph Farnan. At Nortel's request, the 3rd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals and the Canadian Supreme Court have delayed setting briefing schedules because Nortel is optimistic it can reach a resolution.

Facebook, Google, Twitter and other internet platforms may lose ad revenue as the EU's new data privacy rules take effect. Requiring platforms to either have informed consent or another legal basis to [BLANK] users' data will likely meaningfully reduce the amount of personal information available for targeted advertising.

Newfield's revenue depends on commodity volume sold and average prices realized, and the company is likely to expand domestic production, adjusted for prior-year asset sales, 9%-10% in 2017 from a year earlier. As the Anadarko Basin output [BLANK] a higher percentage of production, margins are likely to improve.

Consensus's call for a 24% EPS gain at New York Times will be driven by digital revenue. The company [BLANK] low-double-digit digital growth, as print continues to face challenges. The company's cost initiatives may drive a 67% increase in 1Q consensus Ebit. Gannett pointed to improvement in print advertising, with a pickup in automotive ads at the end of 4Q. The company has forecast a 1% increase in publishing revenue for 1Q vs. $842 million in 1Q14. Magna Global expects local newspaper ads to drop 12% in 1Q.

Asset managers may dislike companies with dual-class share structures, but there is little they can do, especially for passive investors. Equity investors generally [BLANK] voting power equal to economic control, while some companies, often founder-led, have adopted structures that give certain shareholders boosted voting power. There is little investors can do to protest, other than not holding shares. The growth of passive, index investing may weaken that threat.

Asia's appetite for meat and the amount consumers spend on it will likely pick up over the next several years. Rising incomes, a growing population and a burgeoning consumer shift to higher-protein diets will [BLANK] demand. The region already consumes at least 25% of the world's beef, chicken and pork. This share is likely to rise during the years ahead, and should help boost revenue at firms such as WH Group, China Yurun, Charoen Pokphand Foods, Malindo, Godrej Tyson and Japfa.

Shares of activewear and high-performance apparel makers such as Columbia Sportswear, Under Armour and Hanesbrands outperformed fashion-focused peers during the past 12 months. A shift toward athletic apparel and away from fashion-related products boosted sales and [BLANK] margins. Market values of more fashion-focused clothing makers with large international exposure, such as Ralph Lauren, PVH and Michael Kors, declined more than 40% in the period.

With dwindling sales of the three models that make up almost 90% of U.S. shipments, Mazda may need to revamp its marketing strategy to help boost sales if it aims to keep incentives costs low. Mazda's strategy is to [BLANK] incentives to dealers and offer products directly to buyers at optimal prices. Yet, the strategy may backfire without a strong product pipeline and a strong marketing campaign. Mazda will keep using its 15-year-old "Zoom Zoom" slogan.

The Jan. 29 stock market drop of 67 bps was the largest since the first week of September but was led by defensive sectors, a signal that any follow-through is likely to be modest. Utilities leadership, a breakdown in semiconductors and transports, and [BLANK] earnings estimates are most likely candidates to lead a correction.

Relative North American spot-trucking demand slid 4.5% sequentially to 15.2 in the week ended June 24, as measured by Truckstop.com's Market Demand Index. Capacity loosened as load availability edged 0.7% lower, while the number of available trucks [BLANK] 3.9%. Average truckload spot rates per mile, including fuel surcharges, inched 0.4% higher, driven by a 1.2% gain in dry-van equipment. Average rates have risen for the fourth time in five weeks, spurred mainly by a 5.6% gain in diesel prices.

China's gasoline-demand growth is likely to weaken from 12.4% last year, the fastest growth since 2008. One of its leading indicators, car-sales expansion, has slowed and may continue to [BLANK] as cities impose limits on vehicle registration. To fight pollution, the government is tightening fuel-efficiency standards. That's led to surging sales of turbochargers and encouraged development of electric and natural gas-fueled vehicles. While SUVs are popular, cost-conscious motorists buy gas-sipping compact models.

The growth of same-hospital equivalent admissions accelerated in 3Q to 3.7% from 2.3% in 2Q. Those who [BLANK] insurance through Medicaid expansion and the public health exchanges are likely boosting demand for hospital services. Incremental growth may be more difficult in 2015 given managed-care payers can typically reduce utilization of the newly insured over time. Equivalent admissions grew most at Tenet (up 5.8%) and LifePoint (4.5% higher) in 3Q.

The gross-to-net sales discounts on Amgen's Repatha and Sanofi's Praluent averaged about 35% in 2016, while prescribing hurdles weighed on uptake. Positive outcomes data in 1Q, showing Repatha [BLANK] the risk of cardiovascular events, support a label update for the drug and should help Amgen's formulary discussions with payers. The drugmaker's bargaining power may be further enhanced by ongoing litigation surrounding Praluent, which risks being pulled off the U.S. market and is possibly dragging on volume.

Key profit drivers for the U.S. beverage group in 2Q included contributions from recent acquisitions, positive sales performance for product categories touting health, convenience and innovative flavors, and profit-margin expansion [BLANK] by only modest input-cost inflation.

Universal Truckload tempered 3Q expectations on weaker demand from steel, energy and some industrial customers which has been a common theme for the surface transportation industry. Management also blamed [BLANK] intermodal growth for the revised outlook. This may be an indication that the deceleration in truckload pricing in 3Q has started to affect intermodal pricing, even amid 2% volume growth. If widespread, it may weigh on results of other intermodal providers and third-party logistics providers.

Roche-PTC's RG7800 Phase Ib/II trial for spinal muscular atrophy may resume in 1Q, pending preclinical data expected in 2H to assess an eye-related finding in animal tests. RG7800 and Isis Pharmaceuticals-Biogen's ISIS-SMN are [BLANK] to address the underlying cause of the genetic disorder. ISIS-SMN's Phase III data are expected by early 2017. Roche's olesoxime, to protect motor-nerve cell health, has a 2017 targeted filing. Cytokinetics-Astellas's CK-2127107 is entering a Phase II trial.

While global equity issuance dropped 11.9% in December from a year earlier amid a spike in stock-market volatility that's coincided with a plunge in the price of oil, share offerings still ended 2014 up 10.6%. That growth relative to 2013 has [BLANK] from as much as 27% in September. Equity issuance correlates with hiring trends at investment banks, an important growth driver for information services providers, and any extended slowdown could pressure revenue growth.

Application delivery controller sales may remain muted through 2020, amid a saturated installed base of appliances and a shift to cloud-based software subscriptions. ADC revenue is [BLANK] to grow at just a 3.5% compound annual rate in 2015-20 to $1.7 billion, below the 6% of 2011-15, according to IDC, reflecting these market pressures. Virtual appliances are growing increasingly popular with customers and are expected to account for 31% of ADC revenue by 2020 vs. 13% in 2015, according to Dell'Oro.

Net interest margins at Australia's big four banks may stabilize after they raised variable home-loan rates in October. Some lenders also [BLANK] costs by reshuffling their mix of funding sources. These moves may offset any declines in asset yields if the RBA opts to lower the cash rate in 2016, as projected by consensus. CBA, NAB and Westpac stabilized margins in their latest results despite the low cash rate that has persisted over the past 12 months.

Near-term biotech and pharma events include FDA action (PDUFA) dates for Heron's Sustol, Sarepta's Duchenne muscular dystrophy drug, Acadia's Nuplazid, Intercept's OCA, Titan's Probuphine, KemPharm's pain drug, Exelixis-Ipsen's cabozantinib and Roche's atezolizumab in bladder and lung cancer. Biogen-Eisai [BLANK] Alzheimer's data. EU regulatory decisions are expected for Takeda's Ninlaro, BioMarin's DMD drug, Gilead's new HIV pill and Shire's Natpara. All four of the NAHB homebuilder indexes are at cyclical highs and the headline Housing Market Index is the highest in 11-years. It is hard to believe that this pace of enthusiasm can be sustained, especially as mortgage rates are climbing. According to the Mortgage Bankers Association, contract rates for a 30-year fixed rate mortgage averaged 4.3% in December, up from 3.7% in October.

MS&AD's sales of strategic equity holdings in fiscal 3Q ending December almost matched its 1H level. Sales of business-related equities for Tokio Marine also [BLANK] in the period, putting both very close to their full-year target and locking in profits. While Sompo didn't specify an annual goal, sales were about 49% of their four-year average. The lag may be a key challenge as Sompo wants to catch up on investment profit in the March quarter, and the benchmark Nikkei 225 index has lost about 15% this year.

In the absence of new acquisition opportunities that meet its deal thresholds, VF's organic sales growth hinges on expansion into underpenetrated product categories and regions. The company's projection of a 4-6% average in constant-currency growth through 2021 implies sales acceleration starting in 2019, given a [BLANK] low-single-digit outlook in 2017-18. VF's key brands -- The North Face, Vans and Timberland -- will continue to be the primary growth engines.

The U.S. policy-related issues affecting Biogen Inc. include ongoing biosimilar guidance documents from the FDA, bipartisan efforts to pass the "21st Century Cures" bill, the debate between drugmakers and hospitals over the rapidly growing 340B drug-discount program, and controversy over drug pricing. The company [BLANK] significant revenue from multiple sclerosis drugs and is working to become a force in Alzheimer's medicines. Executives are interested in policy initiatives affecting those specialties.

BI's Asia large market-cap power generation peer group fell about 3% last month, led by declines for key Chinese conventional power utilities. CR Power [BLANK] 9.7%, Huaneng fell 8.9% and Datang dropped 5%, likely on concerns about declining average coal-fired plant utilization caused by slower power-demand growth. Domestic thermal-coal prices may also rise modestly on production cuts.

Liberty Global's 9% sequential growth in mobile (7.2% of total revenue) contrasts with a 0.4% contraction so far in 2Q for European mobile operators. Liberty is rolling out mobile virtual operations in eight countries, three of which are full mobile virtual operations, which allows for full integration of mobile and cable offers.

Sugar consumption may continue expanding in step with world population growth and rising incomes, at the historical pace of 2% a year despite rising concerns about obesity and other health-related issues. These challenges are leading governments to [BLANK] guidelines and consider measures, such as sugar taxes in Europe and the U.S., to limit added sugar in packaged-food and drinks. Yet it will take time and add costs to manufacturers to switch to alternatives. EU's output-cap ending should boost world supply.

Tesco's revelation that it had overstated 1H profit by 250 million pounds may raise questions about the length of auditing contracts. PricewaterhouseCoopers has been Tesco's auditor since 1983, the fourth longest [BLANK] audit relationship among FTSE 100 companies. The EU ruled in June that auditors should be changed every 10 to 24 years to stop relationships becoming too cosy. Marks & Spencer has been with PwC for 88 years and Barclays for 118 years. The rule becomes effective in 2016.

Asset coverage for SoftBank's bonds may be 241%, based on a sum-of-the-parts valuation of company assets. Yet some of its most valuable pieces are minority equity stakes in other companies, including an interest in Alibaba [BLANK] at about $140 billion.

Mobile-shopping sales will surge almost 12x during the next four years in China to 3.2 trillion yuan ($523 billion), according to IResearch, driven by mobile Internet expansion, changing shopping habits and wider use of mobile payment systems. Market leader Alibaba may lead the charge, [BLANK] mobile to account for 57% of China's e-commerce sales by 2017. Alibaba reported a 33% sales contribution from mobile shopping in 2Q.

Several cruise lines responded to traveler concern about potential risks associated with the Zika virus by allowing directly affected passengers to postpone or change bookings. Norwegian Cruise Line specifically accommodated expectant mothers who wish to either postpone their cruise vacations, or select alternative itineraries that exclude destinations [BLANK] by health authorities as Zika-transmission zones. Other passengers have been apprised of existing CDC guidelines for avoiding mosquito bites.

China is becoming a bigger component of emerging-markets exchange-traded funds, as domestic shares get added to indexes. A new ETF offers investors exposure to emerging markets, while [BLANK] China. The EGShares EM Core ex-China ETF (XCEM) launched this week. Without China, other countries get bigger weightings than in traditional emerging-market ETFs. South Korea makes up 21% of the portfolio, followed by Taiwan, Brazil and South Africa. The ETF charges 0.35% a year in fees -- about average for the sector.

China is slowly but surely closing the gap in industrial-robotics competition. Supportive demand drivers such as rising wages and cheaper robots will [BLANK] the adoption of factory automation. Meanwhile, supply-side factors such as government subsidies may fuel a surge in new entrants.

Treasury's review of the bond markets suggests the department believes liquidity issues are limited in scope. On April 14, Treasury Counselor Antonio Weiss testified that primary markets for fixed income were [BLANK] well and pushed back on suggestions that regulation was to blame for perceived liquidity issues. Treasury's focus on market structure and high-frequency trading may prompt action in 2016, though the presidential election should dampen any move unless a Democrat is president in 2017.

A successful Schneider IPO could lead to more trucking deals. There's a number of large well regarded private trucking companies that could [BLANK] the public market. U.S. Xpress is the second-largest privately held truckload carrier after Schneider, as measured by tractors, according to Transport Topics. The company recently said Eric Fuller will take over as CEO from his father and co-founder Max Fuller. Lisa Quinn Pate, a daughter of other late co-founder Patrick Quinn, was named as president.

Skilled nursing units under construction have declined 44% since a peak in 1Q12. Construction is just 0.6% of total inventory, given government reimbursement cuts have [BLANK] skilled nursing demand. Skilled nursing total inventory has fallen 1.8% in the past 10 years, while senior housing inventory has risen 18.2% in the same period. The challenging regulatory environment has pushed health-care REITs and operators to focus on senior housing, where living costs are privately funded.

Hilton's 1Q results are likely to focus on the progress of its asset-light transformation, brand rollouts, and shareholder returns. Hilton [BLANK] to have more than 90% of earnings driven by its fee-based businesses, primarily through franchising. This has spurred efforts to create new lifestyle and midscale brands, which appeal to new hotel owners and hasten expansion. Increased free cash flow through this model should be sufficient to support dividend capacity or share buybacks through 2019.

MetLife said sales volumes on private exchanges are "materially less than they'll be long term," though employer acceptance will ultimately decide which type of exchange succeeds. It [BLANK] three models. First, an exchange may join with one or more carriers, while the employer selects one to service its employees. Second, employees are shown several carriers from which to choose coverage. Third, exchanges may help brokers build their own platform.

The Drewry Hong Kong-Los Angeles container rate benchmark declined 6.1% to $1,539 per 40-foot container (FEU) in the week ended April 29. Slack capacity has [BLANK] rates 18.5% lower since the last general increase around April 9. Liner operators may receive boosts from a new short-term market rate minimum of $2,050 per FEU expected to take effect May 1, and general increases anticipated to resume in June. Rates are down 16.8% compared with last year, and are the lowest since December 2011.

A sharp drop in oil may lower costs for farmers in 2015, partly offsetting lower crop prices. USDA data indicate fuel, lubricants and electricity are 9% of farm operating costs, and more than 30% when energy-based inputs ([BLANK] chemicals) are included. The 40% drop in oil this year suggests these costs may fall next year. In a 2006 USDA ARMS survey, one quarter of farmers said they had reduce trips over fields, or cut use of higher-priced fertilizers in response to rising energy costs.

Cablevision didn't buy back any shares during the third quarter, even as management indicated the company has more than $450 million left from an existing $1.5 billion repurchase plan. It didn't [BLANK] whether it bought back any bonds in the open market, as it did in January, when Cablevision purchased $27.8 million in aggregate principal of its 5.875% senior notes due in 2022. Leverage, measured as debt to adjusted operating cash flow, remained flat at 4.9x.

Several rulings are likely in 2016 in suits by Fannie and Freddie shareholders challenging a 2012 amendment to the 2008 U.S. bailout of the government-sponsored enterprises. The suits may [BLANK] the fate of at least $160 billion in disputed payments to the Treasury Department. Motion to dismiss briefing in the Court of Federal Claims is expected to recommence in 1Q16 with a ruling possible in 2Q16. Briefing in shareholders' appeal of a 2014 dismissal may end in Feb., with a ruling maybe in 2Q.

The revenue backlogs of offshore drillers exposed to Pemex, such as Seadrill, would likely be hurt if the company cancels a batch of rig contracts in response to low energy prices. Pemex may seek to terminate as many as 32 rig contracts to [BLANK] $2.7 billion, according to offshore-drilling data provider RigLogix. Pemex hasn't verified the report. While 32 is a high-end estimate, some terminations may have to occur, given Pemex's reduced 2016 spending budget of $5.5 billion.

Recent key timeline extensions in the biotech and pharmaceuticals industry include BioDelivery Sciences initiating the next late-stage trial of clonidine gel in painful diabetic neuropathy during 2H with enhanced patient selection vs. the previously targeted 1H. Ohr's Squalamine eye-drop Phase III start is also [BLANK]. The phase IIb readout of Trevena-Actavis's TRV027 in acute heart failure is extended to 1H16 from 4Q15, while Acadia delayed filing for FDA approval of pimavanserin to 2H15 from 1Q15.

An in-depth antitrust probe of Fresenius' proposed acquisition of Akorn, triggered by the FTC's issuance of Second Requests for Information (SRs) to the companies in early June, is unsurprising and unlikely to affect Fresenius' projected 1Q18 closing. The FTC often requires time and information to [BLANK] pharmaceutical deals. Overlaps in multiple narrow markets for both marketed and pipeline products must be scrutinized. SRs were likely for assessment of the M&A, given the companies' large and diverse portfolios.

As the storage landscape polarizes to meet high-performance needs of cloud providers such as Facebook, EMC and NetApp are selling newer products such as hybrid and all-flash arrays. They're able to [BLANK] large customer bases to offer NAND-flash in their systems rather than lose market share to pure-flash storage makers such as Nimble. While flash arrays aren't the bulk of storage used at enterprise or hyperscale companies, they provide storage vendors an opportunity to recapture some lost legacy-product sales.

Long-term contracts still dominate LNG trade. To [BLANK] their portfolio, gas buyers are likely to raise share of LNG that they buy on the spot market vs. long-term, oil-indexed supplies in the next five years. Increased spot trading will allow buyers to profit by re-selling gas to premium markets. With time, this will reduce price differentials between LNG markets, particularly as the start of spot-based U.S. gas exports takes market share from oil-linked, long-term LNG supplies from Middle East.

Global aluminum markets are being increasingly driven by Chinese producers, which plan to add more low-cost capacity this year than the rest of the world combined. The industry is still [BLANK] to Indonesia's ban on bauxite exports, which started in January 2014, by looking elsewhere for the raw material. LME premiums have eased this year from record highs, mainly on increasing exports from China. A key long-term trend may be carmakers substituting aluminum for steel.

The Walgreen-Rite Aid and CVS Health-Target Pharmacy mergers may change the competitive landscape in 2016, with implications across the health-care supply chain. Both deals are [BLANK] and require antitrust review. They will create stronger price negotiators, potentially resulting in a cascade of strategy shifts as benefit managers and distributors adapt. McKesson may have the most to lose, given that it serves both targets as a distributor and consolidates Rite Aid's generics into its global sourcing group.

Citigroup and eight other banks' $2 billion settlement of a class-action suit alleging manipulation of foreign-exchange rates has preliminary court approval and will likely get final approval. Seven banks still [BLANK] the suit lost a bid to dismiss the case on Sept. 20, a motion that had been pending a year. This loss, the threat of cooperation from settling banks and joint liability for losses caused by all alleged conspirators ramps up pressure to settle and may prompt banks to engage in talks with plaintiffs.

The $57 billion U.S. baked-goods market is being disrupted and catalyzed by Hostess Brands' operating success after its recapitalization and revitalized product line since re-emerging as a publicly held company in 2015. Its [BLANK] stock price amid lagging performance from many of its competitors may also soon attract activists to such companies urging change. Consolidation appears to be overdue, given the rapid M&A activity across the U.S. packaged-food group in recent years.

Regulations affecting Entergy and other utilities could shift dramatically based on the U.S. presidential election in November. Republican candidate Donald Trump has outlined a vision of fewer environmental restrictions, while Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton [BLANK] a continuation of many of President Barack Obama's energy and environmental policies. For example, Clinton backs the Clean Power Plan and other anti-coal regulations which could raise costs for Entergy.

Debt levels are a key differentiator among exchanges, with higher indebtedness reducing the capacity to make acquisitions or return capital. Offsetting this is the ability to [BLANK] free cash flow. As exchanges continue to seek new technologies and boost scale, M&A is set to remain an engine of growth. On a net debt-to-Ebitda basis, Nasdaq (2.9x) and ICE (2.1x) are the most heavily geared of U.S. and European exchanges. Lower leverage is also key to maintaining clearing house credit ratings.

Paragon will be mapping out a new Chapter 11 exit strategy after U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Christopher Sontchi denied confirmation of its plan to reinstate term loan lenders and swap bondholders' debt for $285 million cash and 47% new equity. The term loan lenders succeeded in [BLANK] Sontchi that the plan left Paragon with too little liquidity to ride out a lengthy downturn in commodity prices. Paragon's proposed settlement of claims against former parent Noble wasn't critiqued.

Melanoma patients treated with Bristol-Myers Squibb's Yervoy may incur $2,675 a year in downstream costs because of side effects, an AdverseEvents analysis shows. Yervoy itself [BLANK] about $30,000 per infusion, or $120,000 a year, while newly approved Opdivo [BLANK] $12,500 a month, or $150,000 a year. The combination would already be quite expensive and compounding costs from overlapping toxicity may lead to payer scruitiny if significant.

China's first Cotai Strip property will have interlinking towers with casinos and retail space. The resort, on the Strip's east side, has a planned 1,600 hotel rooms, about triple the size of MGM's [BLANK] facility on Macau older peninsula. The new property will form a premium-oriented casino cluster alongside Wynn's Palace and Melco Crown's City of Dreams. Interestingly, this positioning is the same as on the peninsula, where the three peers sit across the street from one another.

Uncertainty continues to foster angst, and recovery across the energy continuum will be delayed. Oil and gas balances may [BLANK] more acutely later in 2017, but prices will remain in a tighter range for longer. In addition, anxiety fostered by OPEC's ambiguous arrangement to scale back volume, persistent global petroleum product imbalances and potential for U.S. E&Ps to reintroduce drilling activity will drive the narrative next year. Capital markets have welcomed M&A activity yet access has inflated asset values.

Policies highlighted at China's National People's Congress should be positive for earnings of clean energy and industrial companies, mixed for property firms and challenging for some financial. In Premier Li Keqiang's work report, the environment was again at the top of the agenda, which should [BLANK] more use of nuclear, wind and solar energy. Ongoing supply-side structural reform bodes well for industrial companies at home and abroad.

Retail traffic fell 2.3% through mid-January, based on results compiled from Prodco sensors at the doors of luxury and apparel retailers in the U.S. and Canada. The data may [BLANK] traffic trends at Macy's, J.C. Penney and Nordstrom, tenants of REITs GGP and Simon Property Group.

Mazda Motor's profit margin will likely drop before it can attain its 2019 target, since it faces lower prices from increased competition and lower demand in North America, the carmaker's largest market. The automaker [BLANK] on its Mazda 3 compact sedan for about a third of global volume. It faces increasing competition as demand slows in the segment. The company's goal of selling more SUVs may face tough rivalry from major Japanese carmakers including Honda, Toyota and Nissan.

A Senate bill, S. 1217, that would wind down Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac and allow private capital to replace the GSEs could save taxpayers $60 billion over 10 years, a Sept. 5 Congressional Budget Office report said. A new entity would [BLANK] the mortgage market and a reinsurance fund would be created to protect taxpayers. This would generate business for mortgage insurers and big banks. In a Republican Congress, a savings of $60 billion may give reform new life.

Post-3Q Earnings Outlook: Demand for Schneider's energy efficiency and automation offerings should continue to rise, largely driven by its Industrial unit. The company has almost [BLANK] its organic growth guidance for 2017 and raised its adjusted Ebita margin target by 20 bps, net of currency and gains from disposals. Margin improvement into 2018 will come from increasing software and services sales, further supported by productivity measures and improving Infrastructure profitability.

Following the sale of Enterprise Services and the impending sale of its Software division, HPE will see enhanced roles for Networking and Storage. The two segments made up 20% of sales in 2Q and this may yet [BLANK], given weaker revenue growth in servers and better performance of its all-flash array products, Nimble and SimpliVity acquisitions and its Aruba division. The all-flash portion of storage revenue benefits from corporate IT growth trends as could its converged hardware division.

Rising rig counts in the U.S. should help the profitability levels of U.S. Steel's Tubular segment. The company has worked hard to streamline and produce efficiencies in this segment as rig counts fell to 421 in the middle of 2016 from over 2,000 at the end of 2011, causing the segment to [BLANK] on profitability. Rig counts are again rising, up over 80% since May. Foreign steel imports remain a headwind, especially among piping and tubing products.

MasterCard and Visa are likely to pay damages to U.K. retailers amounting to more than $2 billion, based on our calculations, after the companies lost a key legal appeal. The U.K. Court of Appeal [BLANK] on July 4 that the companies' swipe fees were anticompetitive, though it left the possibility open that a lower court reduces that amount.

Yingli Green Energy cut its 2014 shipment outlook range to 3.3 gigawatts to 3.35 gigawatts, from 3.6 gigawatts to 3.8 gigawatts on a reduction in outsourced module protection which has lower margins. Yingli aims to maximize margins, given it [BLANK] that 40% of shipments may be to China in 4Q, which has lower selling prices on more intense competition. Chinese shipments rose by 19% in 3Q from 2Q as government policy measures stimulated demand.

Oil-to-gas heating conversions are one area of growth for gas network utilities, supported by cheap gas prices and government policies in states such as Connecticut and Massachusetts. Northeast Utilities [BLANK] much of the 4.1% weather-adjusted increase in gas sales to conversions, having added 4,540 heating customers in 1H, and planning on a total of 10,000 by the end of the year. UIL is also expecting significant heating conversions.

Single-tenant retail REITs have an average dividend yield of about 4%, about 60 bps higher than mall REITs and 100 bps more than shopping center REITs. Those yields have [BLANK] as prices have risen year-to-date. During 2016, the single-tenant peer group has outperformed other retail REITs due to their yield advantage in a low-interest-rate environment. Each of the top-seven-performing retail REITs year-to-date are single-tenant focused, led by Agree Realty, up 49% through July 31.

The legacy L2-3 switch market and router market accounted for 65% of the $55.2 billion data networking market in 2014, according to IDC. The market, consisting of switches, routers, application delivery controllers, WAN optimization, wireless LAN and IP telephony, [BLANK] 1.8% in 2014. Growth is being driven by a shift to cloud-based networks, security and wireless connectivity. Segments exposed to these trends are growing solidly, while those not exposed, such as IP telephony, are contracting.

With Central Appalachian coal well out-of-the-money vs. natural gas, correlations between Powder River Basin (PRB) coal and gas may rise as possible gas-to-coal switching decisions come into play. PRB coal prices fell 13.3% in January, while CAPP prices dropped 8.3% then [BLANK] to finish the month unchanged. While natural gas prices could be supported by colder weather in the short run, the months between peak season demand are quickly approaching, which may increase the risk of switching to gas.

The Federal Reserve's effort to update the U.S. interbank payment system is blockchain technology's single-biggest opportunity to apply to financial markets in the medium term, in our view. While U.S. commercial banks will [BLANK] mutual control of interbank payments, blockchain could power a liquidity risk-management tool.

Asset managers, municipal-bond underwriters, tech companies and wind-energy producers may get more tax benefits if the House switches to Democratic control post-election and Representative Richard Neal leads the tax-writing panel. He supports mandatory 401(k) [BLANK] for many companies, expansion of muni-bond use and incentives for tech and alternative energy.

The auto sector has enough on its plate (technology disruption and diesels), yet also faces scrutiny over consumer credit, with likely restrictions on personal contract purchases (PCP) curbing EU car-sales growth. U.K. car-dealership financing is responsible for 30% of all consumer credit, [BLANK] by PCPs, with the potential for new BoE rules based on affordability.

Department store market share losses to other format stores may continue in 2015. The losses [BLANK] throughout 2014, as shoppers migrated to mass merchant, off-price and specialty-store competitors. U.S. department store sales as a percentage of general merchandise, apparel and accessories, furniture and other (GAFO) declined to 13.1% in 2014, down from 33% in 1992, 20% in 2005 and 16.3% in 2010.

Health insurers lobbying for repeal of the Obamacare excise tax have an ally in employers that complain the levy will hurt their operating margins. A study by the National Federation of Independent Business suggests that [BLANK] the tax will reduce premiums for employers and consumers by 2% to 3% in upcoming years, given that insurers will pass much of the tax's $145 billion in 10-year costs to their customers. Nonprofit organizations and employers who self-insure are exempt from the tax.

Barclays and the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission are nearing a settlement in the bank's court fight challenging a $470 million penalty and disgorgement order FERC imposed in 2013. The parties were in a court-ordered settlement conference on Oct. 11-12, after which the court vacated all [BLANK] deadlines due to the parties' substantial settlement progress. A March court ruling allowing Barclays to gather additional evidence may have given the bank some leverage it didn't have before.

Consumers are becoming more concerned about improving health and wellness, driving retailers to expand product offerings for special dietary requirements, such as gluten-free or vegan fare. Consumers are [BLANK] to expect in-store expertise about supplements, prescription and non-prescription medications and nutritional options. The use of in-store retail clinics, not only at the likes of CVS and Rite Aid but also Kroger and Wal-Mart, is on the rise to help customers with basic health-care issues.

The schizophrenia market may be worth $4.3 billion in 2018, with the growth of long-acting injectables offsetting the erosion of sales from significant generic competition. The market for the injectables, specifically J&J's Invega Sustenna, Otsuka-Lundbeck's Abilify Maintena and Alkermes' Aristada, may [BLANK] 32% to $3.2 billion in 2018. Pipeline products including Indivior's RBP-7000 and Alkermes' ALKS-3831 won't begin to make an impact until 2018 and then will face competition from generic alternatives.

If Fuji is fully vested in acquiring Xerox, it could increase the proposed special dividend of $2.5 billion. Fuji could also alleviate corporate governance concerns by clearly [BLANK] minority shareholders' rights and selecting someone oother than Xerox CEO Jeff Jacobson to lead the combined entity.

Companies with goods that appeal to opposite ends of the income spectrum appear in great demand among S&P 500 discretionary stocks, as a mix of luxury, fast food and travel have among the highest company valuations. Adjusted for [BLANK] five-year volatility, Yum! Brands, McDonald's and Coach have some of the richest forward price-to-earnings premiums in the sector. Travel sites Priceline and Expedia are also trading at large premiums to their historical valuations.

Humana may be the most exposed to the health insurer tax holiday in 2017, which could contribute as much as 20% of its EPS, depending how much it decides to reinvest in plans. Aetna and UnitedHealth have [BLANK] an EPS boost of 20-25 cents, or 2.8% each, which is similar to the amount from Medicare plans that's not easily recouped with higher premiums. Anthem and Cigna could have about a 2% boost, but both have said they will use the savings to reduce prices and improve benefits for members.

Google led a $542 million funding round for virtual-reality technology developer Magic Leap, expanding its reach to what may become the next computing platform after smartphones. Facebook [BLANK] to buy virtual-reality hardware company Oculus for $2 billion in March. Magic Leap is working on releasing a wearable device using its proprietary human computing interface technology known as Cinematic Reality, which may compete with Oculus Rift and Google Glass.

Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen can defend Dodd-Frank financial regulations such as the Volcker Rule, stress tests and capital requirements through 1Q18. The Fed has the [BLANK] role in U.S. and global regulatory negotiations in the post-crisis Dodd-Frank era, and the Fed chair is the key thought leader. President Donald Trump's bank regulation team won't coalesce until after Yellen's term as chair ends on Feb. 3. Then Trump's team can start the lengthy and cumbersome process of dismantling Dodd-Frank's parts.

Fixed-income benchmark indexes have turnover rates an order of magnitude higher than equity benchmarks, putting passive bond managers aiming to replicate the index performance at a disadvantage compared with stock-managing counterparts. Bond indexes rebalance more frequently, while recurrent bond issuance, rating actions and [BLANK] or early redemptions cause more churn. Active managers who aren't tied to the index have more room to outperform passive in the bond world vs. stocks.

A favorable economic climate and higher demand may result in an 8% gain in less-than-truckload carrier revenue and 30% higher EPS in 2015, according to consensus. Yield growth could accelerate as carriers become more selective in accounts they [BLANK] and focus on maximizing profitability. A transition to dimensional weight pricing, which is based on size, not just weight, could also aid margins. LTL tonnage (up 7%) has outpaced industrial production (up 4%) in 2014 through October, and may continue through 2015.

DirecTV and the NFL are unlikely to settle proposed antitrust class-actions challenging their "Sunday Ticket" pact in the near term. The judge assigned to the cases is [BLANK] arguments on consolidation in May, after which a new complaint will be filed. Defendants have indicated that they will seek dismissal of the lawsuits once this occurs. Briefing on the bids could stretch into 4Q, making settlement before that unlikely. At issue are the exclusive nature and structure of Sunday Ticket.

Jawbone's patent-infringement actions against Fitbit and Flextronics in the U.S. International Trade Commission and in Northern California federal court threaten an import ban on Fitbit's wearable fitness-tracking products and could require Fitbit to pay Jawbone for alleged acts of infringement. Fitbit contends that Jawbone's claims have no merit and are only aimed at [BLANK] Fitbit's business. Jawbone filed its district court case a week before Fitbit's IPO and it filed the ITC case a month later.

Chinese insurers' 2H profit growth should be stronger than in the previous six months, driven by a further recovery in bond yields and stock gains. New business value growth should be [BLANK] by the hiring of more agents and margin expansion. Yet P&C insurers should still face pricing pressure and slower premium growth.

States are active in highway-funding initiatives, with 14 introducing measures for fuel-excise tax increases in 2016. This follows [BLANK] in eight states during 2015. More states may introduce proposals since an increase in ballot measures is typically seen during election years. ARTBA analysis shows that transportation-funding ballot-measure approval rates rise in the years of and just after a presidential election, with 73% and 80% approved in 2008-09 and 77% and 85% in 2012-13 vs. a 10-year average of 72%.

A record number of customers switched energy suppliers in 2017, mainly to small and mid-tier suppliers from larger ones. Oil and gas companies also [BLANK] M&A deals, along with plans to venture into the power sector, making competition more rife in the European utility segment.

Targeted therapies from AbbVie-Roche and TG Therapeutics showed promising results in refractory patients at the European Hematology Association (EHA) meeting in Madrid. There were also some early promising results from immunotherapy in blood cancers, [BLANK] data on Bristol-Myers' Opdivo in acute myeloid leukemia and continued hints of a cure in myeloma from CAR-T therapies. Bluebird's gene therapy for beta-thalassemia showed some improvement with a new manufacturing method, though some variability still exists.

Republicans will pursue a repeal of the CFPB arbitration rule via the Congressional Review Act, with the process already beginning in the House and Senate, but it's unclear whether they will follow through. Gutting the rule would [BLANK] another regulation from being issued unless approved by Congress. Republicans can also count on a new CFPB director to tweak the rule if Director Richard Cordray resigns. Republicans are in control and can dictate the rule's future, so chances are good that changes are coming.

Business-jet deliveries peaked at 1,317 units in 2008, driven by demand for light- and mid-sized aircraft, which were 75% of deliveries. Economic growth, favorable financing and fractional ownership programs, which helped make aircraft more affordable, [BLANK] the boom. Cessna delivered 1,785 aircraft from 2003 to 2008, 3x the amount of Hawker, its closest competitor, and Gulfstream deliveries rose 27% compounded annually in the same period.

Running a bank with a 3% to 4% market share in Poland has become ineffective, Alior Bank CEO Wojciech Sobieraj told PAP on April 27. This [BLANK] further consolidation is likely in Poland's banking industry, he said. The country has one of the least-concentrated banking markets in Europe, Herfindahl index shows. Record low interest rates, a lower interchange fee and a rising contribution to the Banking Guarantee Fund have weighed on banks' profitability. BNP's growth plans in Poland will likely add more pressure.

L'Oreal raised its guidance for global beauty market growth in 2016 to about 4%, an increase vs. its initial start-of-year forecast of about 3.5%. Its 1H was solid, with sales in all divisions and most regions [BLANK] ahead of the global beauty market. France was the exception, slicing about 100 bps from sales growth. L'Oreal's biggest division, mass-priced branded consumer products, which makes up 47% of total sales and attracts the most competition globally, extended its growth in 2Q to the best in 12 quarters.

A successful party-line vote to undo recently adopted retirement-advice rules shows why banks including Wells Fargo and BB&T continue to prepare for the April 2017 applicability date of the regulation, even as efforts to block them continue. An April 21 U.S. House of Representative's panel vote saw 22 Republicans support a resolution to block the rules while 14 Democrats [BLANK] against. Without substantial Democratic support, Congress won't be unable to override an expected veto by President Barack Obama.

The global switch market grew to $6.2 billion in 2Q14, up 8.2% from 2Q13 and above the 1.5% in 1Q, according to IDC. Cisco lost market share in 2Q, which [BLANK] the fourth consecutive quarterly share loss for Cisco as it works through a difficult product transition that has allowed rivals such as Arista and Hewlett-Packard to take share. Cisco's share dropped to 55% in 2Q from 56% in 1Q while Arista, HP and Huawei gained share. (Corrects comparison period for market growth).

Warner's "Crazy Rich Asians" led the domestic box office for the second straight weekend with an estimated $25 million, 43% higher than Box Office Pro's $17.5 million estimate. We [BLANK] the film will likely cross $100 million domestically by next week, given a favorable competitive environment during the Labor Day weekend. "The Meg" continues to be a robust profit generator for Warner, taking an additional $45.7 million worldwide for a $105 million domestic tally and $408 million global take. STX's "Happytime Murders" disappointed with a $10 million debut, 29% lower than projections, likely due to weak reviews.

Lawsuits by Fairholme and other Fannie-Freddie shareholders in the Court of Federal Claims against the U.S. have become more important following dismissals of related shareholder suits in D.C. district court and Iowa. The shareholders [BLANK] a 2012 amendment to the 2008 bailout of Fannie and Freddie that diverted billions of dollars to the Treasury. A shareholder win in any of the suits may reduce the GSEs' senior preferred stock liability by $150 billion. If shareholders lose, they will likely appeal.

Jazz must respond by May 27 to Par's petition over an additional REMS patent, which was granted by the U.S. patent office on March 25. Jazz's response will [BLANK] the arguments that Par set forth in its petition. Jazz will also have to respond by June 29 to Ranbaxy's petition to a Xyrem method patent, expiring in 2033, that was granted by the patent office. Six petitions filed by Amneal and Par are due for a final decision by the U.S. patent office by July 28. One petition is still pending decision.

The generic erosion of AstraZeneca's Crestor will drive a significant sales shrinkage of year-on-year sales, though "externalization revenue" will still provide earnings growth. Still, the focus is likely to be on Astra's very heavy newsflow, which [BLANK] Mystic trial data and Lynparza's PDUFA date on July 28, as well as expectations for Farxiga heart outcomes trial interim read. Feedback on the recent roll of Imfinzi in the U.S. will also be interesting given it competes with three entrenched peers.

Obesity has become much more prevalent in the U.S., almost tripling diabetes, yet the market opportunity remains small. Novo Nordisk estimates there are 750,000 patients [BLANK] in the U.S., mostly with generic forms of phentermine. About 10% of obesity prescribers write almost 70% of the prescriptions. Novo Nordisk estimates that 190,000 doctors have prescribed medicine for obesity and 50,000 also use GLP-1s. Novo Nordisk will focus its marketing attention here first.

New paradigms on the horizon for treatment-resistant depression generated tempered enthusiasm from Dr. Eric Hollander of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine, though novel options are sorely needed and the target market is substantial. Novel trial designs that [BLANK] the high placebo effect in trials are supported, though they need regulatory buy-in.

The Brazilian central bank's 3Q lending survey indicated a 15th straight quarter of tightened supply toward small and medium sized enterprises (SMEs). Higher delinquency rates, (the average bad debt ratio for SMEs was 3.6% in 1H14 versus 2% for all business loans) have [BLANK] this tightening of credit, which may pose a threat to economic growth given SMEs account for 27% of GDP. Annual SME loan growth slowed to 4% in 1H14 from 11% a year earlier, highlighting increased refinancing risks.

Industrials are experiencing a stronger-than-expected recovery in key end-markets as customer confidence returns in commodity segments and renewed stimulus boosts China's economy. Industrials exposed to the upstream segments of the mining and oil sector have shown the fastest recovery as customers replenish stocks and upgrade or [BLANK] equipment. The strong recovery in U.S. drilling activity is also helping restore growth to its manufacturing segment, as areas such as machinery see an order upturn.

The Senate is expected to vote on and pass S. 2155, a bill that would bring regulatory relief to small, midsize and custody banks. The legislation would [BLANK] the systemically important threshold from $50 billion to $250 billion. Bill sponsor Senator Mike Crapo said that he's looking at an amendment before the vote that incorporates smaller bipartisan bills pushed by the House. Progressive senators could push other amendments to make the vote difficult for their Democratic colleagues, but ultimately the measure should pass.

Aetna, Humana and UnitedHealth may significantly cut back participation in the public health exchanges in 2017 to reduce losses, which may push some of their members to peers. Cigna and Blue Cross and Blue Shield are the most exposed due to similarly-priced plans in big states, though Centene and Molina Healthcare could also [BLANK] costly members in Florida. Insurers have increased loss expectations in 2Q as the risk pool is sicker than expected, and rate increases may not recoup all of the losses in 2017.

Urban office values are up 8.7% this year, outpacing suburban office growth of 5.2%. This reverses the 2014 trend, where 19% growth in suburban assets [BLANK] the 14% gain of urban markets. Downtown office growth has been more volatile, rising 7.5% from February through April, the most recently available data, after a 1% decline in the prior three months. Urban office values are up 149% since bottoming in late-2009 as strong demand from technology tenants coupled with limited new supply has boosted values.

Rising energy storage (electric car) demand, and battery manufacturers' interest in securing future metal supplies, may support the cobalt price. Historically, supply disruptions such as the 2008 and 2013 export bans of cobalt-concentrates mined in the Democratic Republic of Congo also [BLANK] prices up.

Medical costs on the public exchanges were lower than Centene expected, and the company's medical-loss ratio declined 110 bps vs. the prior year despite the strongest 1Q flu season since 2011. The company still [BLANK] higher costs for the exchanges may cause a 16-cent EPS hit for the year vs. 2016 (3.5%), due to typical attrition as healthier members drop coverage. Demographics are similar to prior years, with 90% subsidy-eligible and on silver plans, which could help keep costs in-line.

The knee-jerk share-price drop of 3.5% on Jan. 22 after Sanofi announced the Bioverativ deal shows that investors weren't happy with the price. But this hasn't fazed Sanofi, now offering a 112% premium to [BLANK] Ablynx. The fit is good. Bioverativ brings a growing business and immediate EPS boost, while Ablynx gives it a couple of new potential growth drivers from 2020 and a hot technology platform. Worries about pressure on Bioverativ in hemophilia, especially from Roche's Hemlibra, will continue but near-term EPS accretion isn't at risk.

With AT&T's U-Verse and Dish's satellite declines stabilizing, the overall pay-TV narrative may not be as dire as expected. Cable's 4Q reprieve from cord-cutting was short-lived, with major operators' video losses [BLANK] in 1Q. Add in virtual services such as DirecTV Now and the story improves, with the defection rate potentially slowing.

Hon Hai led the electronics manufacturing services sector with about 38% share among the top 20 such companies in 1Q. This mainly [BLANK] from assembly work for Apple iPhones, iPads and Mac PCs. Pegatron followed at 10.3%, driven by the same client. Apple accounted for about 50% of sales for both companies last year. Flex has about 6.9% share, the highest among North American-listed assemblers, likely due to the company's partnership with brands including Cisco and Lenovo.

Qualcomm and the FTC may be close to a settling the commission's antitrust suit over Qualcomm's chipset licensing practices. Ongoing discussions between the parties aimed at an accord could be [BLANK] in November. A settlement will likely require changes to Qualcomm's conduct. It's unclear whether licensing revenues would be impacted.

Pulte's 2Q closings may rise 16.5% to 4,385, driven by a backlog of 8,755 homes and a backlog conversion rate of 50%, which is slightly higher than 2Q15. Average selling prices are expected to move higher, driven in part by the higher prices [BLANK] with John Wieland Homes. While growth has inflected, profitability will face pressure from higher land costs and further dilution from recent acquisitions. Management continues to target pre-interest gross margin between 21.5-22.5% for the full year.

Securitization issuances in the U.S. reached $164 billion in the first nine months of 2014, the BIS December review shows. This is well above levels in 2009 and 2010 and [BLANK] improvement in the housing and mortgage markets. In Europe, even as new issuance increased from the same period year earlier, this is still significantly below amounts issued in the past. The revival of the securitization market using asset purchase programs is one of the ECB's key tools to unlocking euro area lending.

Historically low mortgage rates have been the linchpin to sustained levels of housing affordability as home prices continue to rise, albeit at a slower pace, and income growth has stagnated. Rates are expected to remain favorable through 2015, [BLANK] the 5% mark by 2H, based on forecasts by the Mortgage Bankers Association. As 2014 has shown, low rates alone may not be enough to fuel increased demand due to compensating factors such as incomes and the mortgage lending environment.

Managed-care companies beat consensus by a median of 5.9% in 2Q, though EPS increased just 1.4% as the Affordable Care Act tax restricted growth. The positive earnings surprise may have been driven by strong enrollment gains and [BLANK] medical cost growth within government-sponsored health plans. UnitedHealth beat estimates by 13% as operating earnings at its Optum unit rose 23%. WellCare and Molina disappointed as medical costs ramped up.

Consensus sales expectations for Roche's development stage Alzheimer's drugs are low given the excitement surrounding new therapies has waned. Clinical trial design, patient selection and [BLANK] the correct dose are still major challenges. Consensus estimates for crenezumab and gantenerumab, Roche's Phase III stage drugs, suggest 2020 sales of $460 million, after a 2018 launch. If these drugs work, the sales potential is likely to be significantly higher, suggesting estimates are highly discounted.

Recent biotech-pharma events include FDA approval of AstraZeneca's Calquence (acalabrutinib) for mantle cell lymphoma with at least one prior therapy under the accelerated approval pathway and Valeant-Nicox's Vyzulta for glaucoma and ocular hypertension. The FDA expanded the label of Johnson & Johnson-Bayer's Xarelto based on Einstein Choice trial data, [BLANK] a lower 10-milligram once-daily dose and extended treatment of venous thromboembolism (VTE) following at least six months of standard anticoagulation.

Bank of America, HSBC and Wells Fargo are unlikely to succeed in dismissing mortgage discrimination suits filed by Cook County, Illinois. BofA and Wells Fargo [BLANK] dismissal bids earlier this year in similar suits filed by the city of Los Angeles. Though not binding on the Illinois courts, the previous decisions may be persuasive. The banks settled similar claims with the Justice Department, also making dismissal less likely. The suits allege more than $1 billion in damages against BofA and $300 million against Wells Fargo.

A 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals case between AT&T and the Federal Trade Commission may spur Congress to act on both ISP privacy and net neutrality. The decision, which the FTC now wants reconsidered, said the FTC lacks power over AT&T and any company that [BLANK] as a common carrier. That leaves a gaping hole in privacy oversight, given Congress recently killed the FCC's ISP privacy rules. If the 9th Circuit denies rehearing, letting its ruling stand, it may spur Congress to clarify both FTC and FCC jurisdiction.

Noble Energy isn't directly involved in material litigation, yet wider issues could affect strategic planning for onshore production down the line. Disposal costs for onshore activities could [BLANK] from various legal challenges. If lawsuits in Oklahoma alleging injection causes earthquakes persuade regulators in other states, like Texas or Colorado, to limit injection volumes, costs will likely go up. If O&G waste is reclassified as hazardous as alleged in one suit, costs will jump.

Utilities' capital spending, long-term dividend and EPS growth plans are likely intact, even as many have issued additional equity to mitigate adverse effects on cash flow and credit metrics caused by the U.S. tax overhaul. The loss of bonus depreciation reduces [BLANK] income taxes, historically about 17% of utilities' cash from operations. A lower corporate tax rate creates excess deferred income-tax liabilities that may be returned to customers over time, posing a potential drag on utilities' cash flows. At the same time, those changes could help rate bases expand at a faster pace. Building on their robust capital spending budgets would allow utilities, including Duke, PPL, NiSource and others, to overcome EPS dilution and stay on track with growth goals.

Adobe is the largest content-creation software vendor, with products such as Photoshop, Illustrator and InDesign. The shift to a subscription model has given the company a more predictable revenue stream and [BLANK] its market. Users that were reluctant to pay a large upfront amount are now subscribing at a nominal monthly fee. This has attracted about 30% more users, including both seasonal and non-professionals. Adobe says the 2018 total addressable market of this segment is about $17.4 billion.

China's renewable energy developers will see sales volume rising through 2050 despite some short-term headwinds. Wind and solar capacity should rise to 19% of total electricity output from about 5%, thanks to the government's drive to [BLANK] pollution and reliance on coal. Longyuan, Huaneng Renewables and other operators with large clean-energy portfolios will increase output thanks to capacity growth and, in the short term, as authorities force power grids to buy more from them.

Boeing's operating earnings adjusted for the 787, 747 and aerial tanker charge rose slightly to $2.6 billion or 10.4% of revenue, as margins expanded in all major businesses except Global Services and Support. Commercial airplane margins [BLANK] slightly to 10.3%, as two more 777 deliveries helped offset four additional lower-margin 787s. Boeing military aircraft margins rose as well, even with fewer Apache, Chinook and FA-18 deliveries. The repurchase of 6.5% of shares since last year helped boost EPS.

An amendment preventing the automatic lowering of a threshold for swap-dealer registration likely won't become law. The limit is now $8 billion in aggregate gross notional value of swaps [BLANK] over a 12-month period. The measure, approved by the House Appropriations Committee April 19, may pass the House but faces opposition from Senate Democrats who won't want to be seen rejecting a Dodd-Frank provision. The best chances of a threshold change remain with the CFTC's analysis and another possible proposal in 2017.

Vipshop may continue to pursue revenue growth by expanding its product offerings in categories such as cosmetics. Besides organic growth on its own platform, Vipshop [BLANK] 80.75% of Lefeng in 2014, an online retailer specializing in makeup and fashion. Cosmetics accounted for 13% of Vipshop's sales in 2014, up from 6% in 2013. Vipshop hopes to sell Lefeng's private-label products at higher margins. Earlier attempts fell short, given Chinese consumers' preference for marquee brands such as SK-II and L'Oreal.

Avoiding a contraction in Iranian oil export volume following U.S. sanctions is unlikely, given it's contingent on the ability of its national tanker fleet to do the heavy lifting, with foreign ships effectively off limits. Theoretically, Iran has the shipping capacity, but we see challenges due to restrictions on critical procurement and vessel trades [BLANK] to size and aging fleet.

BlackRock's new iShares Edge MSCI Min Vol USA Small-Cap ETF (SMMV) is a sequel to its iShares Edge MSCI Min Vol USA ETF (USMV). The older fund [BLANK] in size this year, to $14. 4 billion in assets, as investors sought more stable securities. Yet low-volatility ETFs have started to underperform and outflows reached $600 million last month. The new ETF's fee of 0.2% is lower than the 0.34% charged by its only low-volatility small-cap peer, the $600 million PowerShares S&P SmallCap Low Volatility Portfolio (XSLV).

Online-loan originations have bounced back in 2017, but the long-term outlook is unclear. While the opportunity to refinance high-interest card debt is massive, platforms such as LendingClub struggle to balance loan growth and quality as U.S. consumer leverage [BLANK] pre-crisis levels and new rivals enter the market.

Hitachi Construction's foreign exchange-driven earnings woes may ease with a weakening in the yen since November. Japan's currency [BLANK] 1.4% against the dollar in the March quarter, compared with the year prior, which is weaker than the December quarter's 11% jump. Yet, some of the gains from a weaker yen may be offset by higher raw material costs such as steel. The company gets about two-thirds of revenue from outside Japan.

Stocks may already be discounting some risk of a government closure at the end of the month. By the time the government [BLANK] down on Oct. 1, 2013, stocks had been correcting for about two weeks. Stocks peaked on Sept. 18 and corrected 4.1% until Oct. 8. Equities bounced back for a full week before the government reopened. The 2013 shutdown was a relatively benign event for the stock market, but from Sept. 18-Oct. 8 of that year the S&P 500 did sell off 4.1%.

Thanks to a Father's Day boost, U.S. retail sales rose 0.9% in the week ended June 18, compared with a year ago, according to Johnson Redbook. Discount [BLANK] sales advanced 1%, while department [BLANK] sales inched up 50 bps, from the prior week, to a 0.8% gain. Department stores were the leading channel, listed by almost 40% of respondents in the National Retail Federation's Father's Day consumer spending survey. Even with the gain, sales are still tepid compared with the same week in 2015, when they rose 1.6%.

An 800-MW offshore-wind project in Massachusetts by Iberdrola's Avangrid and Copenhagen Infrastructure Partners will likely be the first large project in U.S. waters. The developers won a bid to [BLANK] with Massachusetts utilities for long-term power contracts, and the project is the furthest along in federal permitting. If construction starts in 2019 -- a tight timeline based on federal permitting -- the project could claim federal tax incentives. The U.S. government may auction more leases, offering opportunities for Statoil and PNE Wind.

The rise in exports of higher-value clothes, textiles and shoes from China will likely support the country's trade lead in these sectors even as volumes slide. New trade barriers from the EU and the U.S as well as a stronger yuan may [BLANK] the cost advantages of Chinese makes.

Quorum's admissions could be pressured as new hospital beds come online in Illinois. Capital commitments for projects that were [BLANK] between November 2014 and February 2016 suggest Illinois will have the most new capacity coming online within 12-24 months, according to Medical Construction and Design magazine. Quorum is most exposed to the state at 38% of beds, followed by Tenet at 5%. Seven new projects in Illinois underwent construction at various times with a total build cost of almost $1.3 billion.

Metals companies have high energy needs, with spending a median 15% of operating costs, and up to 30% for those refining and smelting aluminum. Achieving [BLANK] reduction goals set by energy-intensive manufacturers including Rusal, Alumina and Vedanta, where energy constitutes over 20% of operating costs, may help boost earnings. Anglo American reported $90 million in energy savings in 2016 (5% of its power costs) driven by business improvements, on energy use that is 5-10% of operating costs.

Telecom Italia's potential sale of its stake in Brazilian operator Tim, would leave its prospects tied to Italy. The low broadband penetration in Italy and lack of cable competition may help [BLANK] the country's telecom industry. The less significant role played by pay-TV services in bundled offers by telecom operators, relative to countries such as Netherlands and Spain, limit the risk of overspending on content. The potential for mobile consolidation is another opportunity in Italy.

Telecom Italia's consideration of an all-stock offer for a potential Oi bid would free up capital to improve its network. Should the deal be [BLANK] as proposed, the combined unit would be a mobile market leader with 45% of subscriber share and be the third-largest broadband provider with 26.4% subscriber share. While the company would have the 4G subscriber lead in mobile, its high-speed broadband coverage would trail Telefonica, which has the fastest average speed following its GVT acquisition.

The Spanish equity market will continue to suffer as share prices fall with negative earnings revisions and cuts to target prices. Despite low valuations and a recovering domestic economy, its emerging market and cyclical sector exposure as well as new government policies are [BLANK] IBEX index performance.

Financial institutions will need to adopt blockchain technologies that fit a developing regulatory framework in order to garner widespread adoption and avoid legal challenges. Banks and financial technology companies are focused on developing blockchain protocol to [BLANK] interoperability across platforms. Successful technology can't just handle the complexity and volume of cyber-currency transactions, but must also comply with existing and future regulatory constraints placed on banks and securities exchanges.

The potential introduction of negative rates to ease the pressure on the koruna may exacerbate margin pain for Czech banks, given domestic lenders hold $45 billion in deposits (20% of all assets) at the central bank. To [BLANK] this, negative deposit rates could be applied in tiers to exclude certain parts of the deposit base, the IMF said in July, citing Denmark as an example. Net interest margin on new loans at Czech banks fell 40% in the six years to 2015 to 3.26% as falling reinvestment yields took their toll.

Line Corp. will need to take full advantage of its dominance in Japan's chat app community and invest in new services. The rollout of new ad products should help [BLANK] slowing mobile game and electronic sticker sales. Performance ads are its fastest-growing product following last year's launch, while messenger-ad growth may stay tepid until Line can extend its popularity in Japan out to overseas markets. Line is growing its mobile payment and telecom services, while developing a virtual assistant.

The relative cost of U.S. pension buyouts rose in May, based on Mercer's U.S. Pension Buyout Index, which shows the average estimated cost of transferring obligations via a group annuity as a percentage of the plan's accounting liabilities. The index increased to 107.3% in May, as the spread between average annuity rates and the rate used to value plan liabilities [BLANK], boosting the relative buyout cost. Mercer estimates the cost of retaining plan obligations at 105.7% of the accounting liability.

Large partnerships, including hedge funds and private-equity firms, would face bigger tax burdens under an Oct. 26 U.S. budget deal. Estimated to raise $9 billion over 10 years, the measure simplifies partnership audit rules, making it more likely the IRS will audit them and [BLANK] additional taxes to levy. The specter of an audit may lead to tighter accounting behavior. The provision should survive a vote. It was a popular fix, part of prior bipartisan proposals, and will help offset the deal's spending increases.

The balance sheets of the U.S. beverage group remain strong enough to keep funding acquisitions while rewarding shareholders through share repurchases and dividend payments. Yet short interest is extraordinarily high for a few issues, [BLANK] Boston Beer and National Beverage.

Poultry processors and fluid milk producers may post higher margins in 2015 on a combination of declining costs and increased demand. In contrast, packaged-food companies that source beef may [BLANK] with higher prices amid lower production. According to the USDA, corn-feed costs may decline on higher global grain supplies and poultry production could increase 3.6%, while beef prices may rise 8% due to a 0.1% production decline.

Merck & Co.'s Keytruda, driven by its use in first-line lung cancer, continues to challenge rivals in the PD-1/L1 class, weighing on growth for Bristol-Myers' Opdivo and Roche's Tecentriq in 4Q. U.S. gross sales of J&J-Genmab's Darzalex [BLANK] up sequentially, with label expansion in myeloma sustaining momentum. Eli Lilly's Cyramza benefited from volume and price, while Perjeta spurred Roche's HER2 franchise ahead of biosimilar competition to Herceptin. Biosimilar drags on J&J's Remicade will heighten in 2018.

The American Trucking Association's preliminary seasonally adjusted tonnage index increased 3.6% yoy in July. The index [BLANK] 1.3% from June, 71 bps above its historical sequential average, and is the fifth sequential increase in six months. Tonnage in 2Q was 3.2% higher compared to last year, and momentum has carried over into 3Q. Trucking fundamentals continue to improve in a favorable economic environment with tighter capacity and higher demand.

A sizable drop in U.S. crude stocks due to slowing production and robust demand should support WTI prices in the near-term. U.S. oil output is down almost 5% this year, helping [BLANK] the domestic inventory glut. Stockpiles remain 33% above the five-year norm. Refinery utilization is growing ahead of summer, with four-week average gasoline demand above last year's levels. Crude imports fell slightly, augmenting 2016 output declines. U.S. oil inventories fell by 3.2 million barrels in the week ended June 3.

Rail carload volumes tend to be an early indicator of economic activity because they are reported on a weekly basis. Fluctuations in demand for goods and services from the consumer and industrial segments directly [BLANK] the need for freight-transportation services. Rail traffic may trail GDP for the second straight year in 2016 based on consensus and FTR estimates. Railroads' fortunes may change in 2017 as total carload growth of 2.5% may exceed consensus expectations for GDP growth by 30 bps.

California's utility regulator proposed a time-of-use rate structure for one utility that may ultimately encourage battery storage colocated with rooftop solar to align self-generation with peak prices. Utilities have [BLANK] peak TOU periods from late afternoon through evening. For a Sempra Energy utility, the Public Utility Commission proposed 3-9 p.m. Because that structure places top solar production in an off-peak period, it could lower the value of rooftop solar and reduce demand in the short run.

Telecom Italia, Vodafone and Wind Tre would suffer a combined compounded 4.5% annual decline in mobile-service revenue from 2018-20 if Iliad were to achieve a modest subscriber market share of 7.5% in Italy and were to reduce average revenue per user (ARPU) for all incumbents by an average 2% a year. This simple calculation [BLANK] no market growth and excludes roaming revenue that Wind Tre will receive from Iliad. Mobile ARPU rose 2.8% in Italy last year, while subscribers declined 1.6%.

Truck tonnage increased 4.1% yoy in 3Q on average through August, according to the American Trucking Association's seasonal adjusted index. FTR is [BLANK] total truck tonnage to increase 4.6% yoy in 3Q. Average tonnage growth in 3Q through August was weighted more toward energy and housing end markets, as flatbed (up 9.8%), bulk (up 6.5%) and tank (up 3.9%) equipment types led gains. Higher demand and a recovering economy helped drive tonnage up.

Titanium dioxide (TiO2) is a key ingredient that adds opacity to paints and coatings, paper and specialty products, and plastics. Production is concentrated among five global producers, with capacity additions in recent years led by Chinese players -- mostly with a process [BLANK] the sulfate route. A second process, the chloride route, results in higher-quality TiO2 pigment but requires raw materials with higher titanium content. TiO2 production costs are driven by the process and ores used.

AstraZeneca and Roche's 4Q newsflow will probably be the strongest among European pharma peers, providing significant catalysts. Astra's news will be [BLANK] by its cancer portfolio, with the potential approval of 9291 and key data on its immuno-oncology drug durvalumab, both in lung cancer. Roche will have near-term data at the Oct. 8-10 ECTRIMS conference on its multiple sclerosis drug ocrelizumab. Novo Nordisk may have the quietest 4Q, with execution on recent product launches the key focus.

The average vehicle contained $369 of semiconductors in the form of microcontrollers, memory, optoelectronics, sensors, analog, multimedia and communication chips as of 2Q, the most recent data available. The automotive semiconductor market was [BLANK] at $26 billion, having grown at an annual rate of 14% in the past five years. Sales are also stable and have high visibility, with designs secured well in advance of shipments. Safety requirements and regulations have driven high margins for these chips.

A strong economy, higher wages and elevated consumer confidence point to a solid upcoming holiday season. Overall sales growth is expected to be 4.3-4.8%, [BLANK] by an extra day between Thanksgiving and Christmas, stable gas prices and an early Chanukah, yet will be well below last year's extraordinary 5.3% result. Intense labor competition, higher wages, discounting, elevated transportation costs, e-commerce sales growth and concerns over tariffs for last-minute inventory will erode margins.

Sales of cannabis-infused edible products may reach $3.7 billion by 2020, up from about $1 billion in 2016, according to Brightfield Group, a tracker of industry data. Growth may be led by infused baked goods and chocolate candy, given their ability to [BLANK] oils, good taste and the perception that they're healthier than smoking pot. The $57 billion U.S. baked goods segment could be the most disrupted by a rise in THC-infused edibles.

A keen eye will be on whether Merck presents overall survival (OS) data for Keytruda at AACR. OS in non-small cell lung cancer wasn't mature to [BLANK] at prior iterations of data from this Phase I study. Presentations at AACR14 showed a clearly defined "shelf" of progression-free survival, which gives hope to a similar sustainable trend occurring in OS. A sustained OS benefit is a desirable element of immuno-oncology agents and will be key to determining competitiveness in the class.

For nuclear plant operators, winning New York subsidies doesn't necessarily mean success in other states. New York was easier because it [BLANK] only regulatory approval, while legislative approval is needed in Illinois. Though Exelon won in New York, it lost in Illinois, its home state. In Connecticut, a bill providing state support didn't pass. The battles also have many fronts, including environmentalists arguing both sides of the issue, consumers fighting higher prices and local governments protecting jobs.

Another massive buildup of crude oil stockpiles continues to affirm our pessimism, even though refined products fell by more than 7 million barrels. We still [BLANK] consensus is overemphasizing supply concerns and we have been much less fearful about capacity shortfalls. OPEC continues to ramp up production, even as sanctions on Iran and political strife in Venezuela inject broader skepticism. Hurricane season had distorted output, which remains resilient even if E&Ps slow near-term growth. Seasonal refining maintenance continues, but utilization remains above prior periods. Exports should recover further as wide differentials persist. We still believe crude is range-bound, with Saudi Arabia suggesting it's reasonable at $80 a barrel. Recent tensions with Riyadh shouldn't derail global supply, in our view.

Burlington Northern Santa Fe accounts for 40% of coal carloads and has been gaining share, about 445 bps vs. last year, in a shrinking market. BNSF's coal volumes are up 5% in 2014, while regional competitor Union Pacific's fell 14%, [BLANK] a 297-bp drop in its share. BNSF's growth may be attributed in part to easier year-over-year comparisons. Canadian National's 22% drop in coal has cost the rail only 59 bps in share, whereas Canadian Pacific boosted its share by 47 bps on a 5% gain in volume.

Sales growth for asset-light operators, Marriott and Wyndham, may be more resilient amid slowing U.S. revpar gains and geopolitical risks with their fee revenue tilt. This business grows with expansion of long-term management and franchise hotel contracts and is less sensitive to [BLANK] volatility compared to owned and operated hotels. It also offers incremental revenue when hotels turn a profit. Hyatt will likely trail in revenue gains given its higher tilt toward managing its owned properties.

A provision in a Senate bill, based on Sen. Sherrod Brown's Leveling the Playing Field Act, would de-emphasize profitability in the International Trade Commission's determination of whether a U.S. industry has been hurt by imports and whether antidumping or countervailing duties are warranted to offset the harm. The provision in S. 1015 would also [BLANK] the ITC to consider other factors, such as capacity utilization. Improving industry-wide financial performance also wouldn't preclude the ITC from finding harm.

The fears of crude-oil shortages driven by Iranian sanctions tightened the market in August before production gains in Russia, Saudi Arabia and Iraq, along with Iran maintaining about 2 million barrels of exports, created an oversupply. The physical market will be the key to the front of Brent and WTI curves to [BLANK] supply warnings.

Few large western base-metals miners have a common takeover defense or anti-activist measures. This could render the industry more appealing to those investors [BLANK] to follow Carl Icahn's lead after his Aug. 27 disclosure of an 8.46% stake in Freeport McMoRan. None of the miners have a poison pill and only Teck Resources employs unequal voting rights. Alcoa, Alumina and Kaiser Aluminum have staggered board elections, which, while entrenching a board, can also be an excuse for activist governance reform.
