European pharma companies GlaxoSmithKline, AstraZeneca, Roche, Novartis and Sanofi could see their trials approved 40% faster if the new EU Clinical Trial regulation is enacted, provided it doesn't get held up by the European Medicines Agency's move to Amsterdam. Approval times would likely be [BLANK] to 45 days from an average of 75.

Innovation and expansion of new therapies has helped the medical-device sector outperform the S&P 500 in 2018, and continued R&D productivity is expected to drive 5% revenue growth and a low-teens EPS increase in 2019. The macroeconomic environment is largely favorable with high U.S. employment and [BLANK] GDP growth, but hospital consolidation remains a key risk to implant prices. Abbott Laboratories, Boston Scientific and DexCom are among the device companies with major new products that should drive above-peer organic growth. Companies Impacted: Edwards Lifesciences, Stryker and Tandem Diabetes have the biggest clinical data releases set for 2019. The data could expand adoption of less-invasive heart valves, robots for knee replacements and automated insulin pumps.

The cost of clearing derivatives may become too high for U.S. and EU banks due to rules that require banks to count a client's collateral as their own assets when calculating leverage ratios. The EU rule sets a 3% equity-to-exposure level, and the U.S. [BLANK] 5%. Banks that take on higher amounts of collateral may have to seek costly capital buffers. In March, 70 U.S. Futures Commission Merchants took on about $163.8 billion in client collateral, compared with 74 with $165 billion a year earlier.

Cement plants are increasingly flexible, with more freedom to change the mix balance of the energy they use. This has [BLANK] advantages for the industry as energy changes often go hand-in-hand with upgrades, with cement producers being less at the mercy of energy-cost volatility. Such expense is at the lowest level in a decade.

Disney's 'Guardians of the Galaxy" took in $22.2 million over the Labor Day holiday weekend through Monday, beating estimates of $20.5 million and giving it a domestic total of $280 million. Paramount's "Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles" was second with $15.7 million. Warner's "If I Stay" brought in $11.6 million, while Fox's "Let's Be Cops" took in $10.6 million. Universal's new release "As Above/So Below" opened to $10.3 million. Overall summer box office [BLANK] 14% yoy.

PGNiG, EDF, Eni and the other European importers of liquefied natural gas (LNG) are likely to be the real winners in an antitrust probe opened by the European Commission in 2Q against Qatar Petroleum. The company faces allegations of [BLANK] intra-EU trading of LNG by imposing resale bans in supply agreements. The investigation could last at least three years, and possible appeals could add another five. Yet in our opinion, the parties may reach an agreement and close the probe in about two years.

Tata Motors and Ashok Leyland are India's leading truck and bus builders, accounting for 81% of medium- and heavy-duty truck unit sales last year. Both truckmakers' products [BLANK] the greatest value for the money, with their relatively low cost of ownership. Daimler subsidiary BharatBenz is a newer manufacturer in India, established in 2011, specializing in the mid-market. Volvo AB targets the premium-truck segment. The Daimler subsidiary also plans to export trucks to other emerging markets in the region.

The development of required technologies for full vehicle automation has surged. Yet barriers [BLANK] to the adoption of autonomous, self-driving vehicles. One is the absence of artificial intelligence needed to react to other vehicles and to changing road conditions. Vehicles will evolve with the incorporation of technologies such as lane-departure detection systems, blind-spot sensors and automatic braking. In the meantime, many roads will require upgrades to accommodate these vehicles.

Preliminary countervailing duties as high as 81.3% on Chinese tire imports were announced by the Commerce Department on Nov. 24. U.S. importers of those tires must now [BLANK] deposits to U.S. Customs equivalent to the preliminary rates. The final duty rates are expected to be announced in April, and those will take affect if the International Trade Commission finds that U.S. tire industry was injured by the imports. Preliminary anti-price dumping duties are expected on Jan. 20.

Claire's and its senior lenders, including Elliott and Monarch, are likely to prevent Oaktree, Claire's largest second lien lender, from challenging key aspects of Claire's $2.1 billion reorganization plan, in our view. Oaktree's pursuit of certain avoidance actions potentially impacting first lien lenders' collateral rights will likely be [BLANK], but challenges to Claire's enterprise valuation may be allowed.

Comcast is well-positioned to counter challenges in the video segment, thanks to its X1 system. Broadband investments, especially in DOCSIS 3.1, will help it [BLANK] ultra-fast gigabit speeds and maintain a leading position with 26 million customers. A foray into wireless using its Wi-Fi hotspots and Verizon's network is aimed at increasing user engagement and reducing churn. Comcast's data dominance, combined with NBCUniversal content give it a unique position among peers. A proposal to acquire Sky will increase its overseas footprint, but could also eventually spark a bidding war with Fox and Disney.

MiFID II will now apply on Jan. 3, 2018, a year later than planned. With Brexit, EU lawmakers may seek to push the date out again to [BLANK] a conflict with exit negotiations or as they may no longer see any need to acquiesce to U.K. requests. A quick-fix law making the delay official was published in the EU rulebook on June 30. It also contains changes exempting package- and securities-financing transactions from new transparency rules. Meanwhile, the EU's securities regulator will develop supplementary rules.

After the April 2013 implementation of the Legal Aid Sentencing and Punishment of Offenders Act, motor insurers cut rates in anticipation of lower claims. Yet claims frequency and inflation [BLANK]. General damages for small bodily injury claims rose 14% year-over-year in September and the number of claims registered through the Ministry of Justice Claims Portal rose almost 50%. Insurers responded by raising rates in a U.K. motor insurance market that hasn't made an underwriting profit since 1994.

Biotech and pharma events include Galmed's aramchol interim Phase IIb data in nonalcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) patients. Gilead may be able to [BLANK] for accelerated FDA approval of simtuzumab with 96-week data from Phase IIb NASH trials, available in 4Q. Tobira expects cenicriviroc data from a pivotal Phase IIb trial in NASH patients. Novo Nordisk will reveal semaglutide's Phase II trial design in NASH. Durect, Sucampo and Ionis have early-stage agents intended for NASH that will have Phase I data.

Acquiring InterOil would add to Total's LNG growth in Papua New Guinea, which may emerge as the world's lowest-cost exporter of the fuel to Asia. InterOil has a 36.5% interest in Elk-Antelope fields, which could [BLANK] an LNG project with annual production capacity of about 7 million metric tons. Total bought a 40.1% interest in Elk-Antelope fields from InterOil last year, and may want a bigger stake. InterOil hasn't ruled out a takeover. Shell's $70 billion bid for BG was driven mainly by LNG assets.

The construction industry's challenges will become more pronounced in 2020, in our view, with accelerating inflation and rising interest rates offering a less-attractive outlook for infrastructure providers more-exposed to the next economic cycle. However, for now, the companies in our coverage have two years of visibility and unquestionable drivers boosting earnings, with stronger order books and project deliveries, and considerable productivity gains [BLANK] since the last financial crisis. A full industry rebound is likely before the next cycle's nadir that's predicated in the IMF's slower global growth forecasts. Our overview is based on healthy conditions for European construction companies, their resilience and innovative approaches to business.

A group of holders of about 26% of Seadrill's $2.3 billion of unsecured bonds and a committee of unsecured creditors may persuade Seadrill to reduce shareholder recovery and increase the holders' participation rights in new financing. This could [BLANK] bondholders' recoveries and lead to a smoother bankruptcy exit.

European and U.S. multinationals doing business in China will likely keep their profits there rather than repatriate them, because China's 0% rate on reinvested earnings is too difficult to resist. France is reducing its corporate rate in response to the U.S. tax overhaul, which lowered the business rate and included a special, discounted tax on U.S. companies' overseas earnings [BLANK] to raise hundreds of billions of dollars in revenue over a decade. China's tax breaks threaten these efforts and contribute to an international global race to the bottom on corporate tax, with multinationals the winners.

Enel Green Power, one of the world's largest clean energy generators with 9.6 gigawatts of capacity, signed a deal with Tesla to test its energy storage systems, which may allow increased solar and wind generation into the grid. A pilot project with a storage capacity of 3 megawatt hours will be [BLANK], likely using Tesla's Powerpack, which is being sold at $250 per kilowatt hour. Enel Green Power has also partnered with battery providers Toshiba and Samsung SDI to test emerging-energy storage products.

Giving shoppers value via deep discounts hurts retailer margins, but is key to wooing shoppers. This is especially true during the week of Black Friday, when shoppers [BLANK] on getting "steal deals." More than 50% of respondents to a Kantar Retail survey of 3,617 people in October said "getting a good deal" was most important in holiday shopping, while 34% said "spending as little as possible" was also important. Stress-free shopping, easy returns, price match and safety of personal data all mattered more this year.

JPMorgan and Citigroup lead global trading revenue, helped by FICC strength. Morgan Stanley, the equities leader, [BLANK] net share along with Bank of America and Citi. JPMorgan topped 2016 gains. Reporting differences may affect absolute shares; directional changes reflect relative performance and mix.

The less-than-truckload (LTL) market comprises freight that is less than 10,000 pounds, typically 300 to 3,000 pounds. The market is difficult to [BLANK] because operators need asset-intensive networks, including cross-dock and sorting facilities, that require significant capital investments. The top 10 LTL carriers hold about 66% of the $42.5 billion U.S. and Canadian markets. The largest companies are FedEx Freight, YRC Worldwide, XPO Logistics, Old Dominion and UPS Freight.

Banks are adjusting their pricing models for investment research in preparation for EU reforms that will prevent research from being paid for directly using dealing commissions. In an unbundled world, based on execution-only commission rates where payments for research are separated, competition in equity research, as well as fixed-income, currency and commodities research, is likely to [BLANK]. Managers may look beyond traditional sources, triggering fragmentation. They may also move research in-house.

Traditional media companies are pursuing online video multichannel networks as consumer video viewing shifts to online sources such as YouTube. In March, Disney bought Maker Studios, [BLANK] the asset for as much as $950 million. DreamWorks' Awesomeness TV bought Big Frame for $15 million as large, diversified entertainment companies seek to expand their online presence, especially with younger audiences. Europe's RTL Group is expected to complete its acquisition of StyleHaul, valuing the network at $151 million.

Gazprom Neft's proposed dividend increase doesn't appear justified given the likelihood of a sustained low oil-price scenario mid- to longer-term, free-cash outflows and a substantial investment program. Representing a payout ratio of about 25%, the company will likely resort to new debt to [BLANK] the disbursal. Gazprom Neft plans to raise capital spending slightly above last year's level ($6.2 billion vs. $6 billion), with an easing likely only in 2019, and most funds destined for oil-field development.

Adlyxin's U.S. approval in 3Q is unlikely to be a major growth catalyst for Sanofi, with consensus expecting the drug to drive less than 1% of 2020 group sales. It's the sixth entrant in an already crowded GLP-1 class, which is [BLANK] by Novo Nordisk's Victoza, followed by Eli Lilly's Trulicity, both of which have more competitive profiles. Sanofi will need to appeal on price to gain favorable insurer coverage, which was a strategy pursued by GlaxoSmithKline for Tanzeum after its launch in 3Q14.

The eight- to 14-day forecast may not provide enough near-term support to natural gas prices, down more than 8% ytd due to less cooling demand vs. last year. Injections during refill season are above the five-year average, though gas storage [BLANK] about 18% below. That should have supported prices, yet cooler weather in summer limited demand. Pricing may be muted until heating demand takes hold during winter withdrawal season, which traditionally starts in November.

A lawsuit accusing 16 banks of rate-fixing in the currency market is proceeding on two tracks. Nine banks [BLANK] preliminary court approval of a $2 billion settlement with investors. Credit Suisse, Deutsche Bank, and Morgan Stanley haven't settled and moved to dismiss the suit. RBC, Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi, SocGen and Standard Chartered, all added later in the suit, joined the motion. Standard Chartered on March 31 won a separate bid to dismiss based on its lack of U.S. presence.

London is the preferred European hub for global lenders, and is a key reason why the U.K. has more than ten times the number of high-earning banking jobs than its closest rival, Germany. Yet the Brexit vote could mean this gap [BLANK] significantly in the absence of any agreement on continued passporting rights. Major considerations for financial companies considering relocation are the stance of local regulators, corporate tax rates and the top rate of personal-income tax -- which is key to retaining senior staff.

Global investment bank senior credit-default swaps have fallen a further 14 bps so far in 2014, following median declines of 53 bps in 2013 and 112 bps in 2012. CDS have [BLANK] broadly across individual banks with improved markets and liquidity, with the exception of Nomura's rise in 2014. The peer 63-bp median is now the lowest since December 2007's 49 bps. Bank CDS spiked in the first quarter of 2008 with the Bear Stearns distressed sale rising to an interim peak in 1Q09 before reaching a peak in 4Q11.

Chinese metals makers are stepping up acquisitions of overseas resources, locking in ore supplies as the country builds infrastructure and produces more electrified vehicles. Peru will play a vital role in [BLANK] China's copper needs after emerging as the world's second-biggest supplier of the metal, following Chile. China has snapped up mines from Australia and Africa to South America. Not all projects have gone smoothly; some have been delayed by a lack of infrastructure and social issues. Companies Impacted: Jiangxi Copper, Chalco and Zijin are among Chinese metals makers that have made overseas purchases to secure resources. Suppliers including BHP, Rio Tinto, Vale and Glencore may lose market share as a result.

Investors have confirmed expectations for production of more than 10 million barrels a day of crude oil at the end of this year as the most likely trajectory for U.S. output. WTI is expected to remain in a tight range this year ($55-$64 a barrel) after [BLANK] from 2016's low of $26.

Biotech and pharma events in Alzheimer's disease include Axovant's intepirdine Phase III data in 3Q and RVT-103 Phase I/II data in 1H. Roche is expected to decide whether to move forward with additional Phase III trials of two, late-stage amyloid-targeting Alzheimer drugs: gantenerumab [BLANK] from MorphoSys and crenezumab from AC Immune, after the recent failure of Eli Lilly's solanezumab. Phase III data of Lundbeck-Otsuka's Rexulti in agitation associated with Alzheimer's dementia are due in 2Q.

Broadband-only U.S. homes rose to 15.3 million at the end of 2016, according to Kagan, and may reach almost 18 million by year-end. The growth of [BLANK] video such as Netflix, and virtual pay-TV services including Dish's Sling TV and AT&T's DirecTV Now, are prompting users to subscribe only to high-speed broadband. As these services expand, the number of broadband-only households may jump to 28 million by 2021, rising at a 13% compound rate from 2015. The latest streaming entrant was Hulu Live.

Democrats are in control of Nevada's state Legislature this year, which may bode well for measures to boost the state's residential solar market. The state's Republican governor has also [BLANK] legislation to reinstate electricity net metering. The utility commission in 2015 decided to add new fees to the electricity bills of rooftop solar owners and cut the price they get paid for excess power sold to the grid, hampering demand growth. The Legislature make take up a bill before May.

The U.S. Army plans to spend $1.7 billion through 2020, and potentially billions more in the next decade, on handheld and backpack-portable radios that are major pieces of its Joint Tactical Radio System. The Army plans to contract with multiple vendors, giving it flexibility to [BLANK] suppliers as technology improves. That approach means initial awards may carry large maximum values but won't lock in long-term orders. General Dynamics, Rockwell Collins, Harris and Thales are among the top Pentagon radio suppliers.

PayPal continues to show the fastest account growth, with a 15% yoy gain in active accounts, after growth of 16% in 2013 and 15% in 2012. MasterCard [BLANK] second with 11% growth. Card and account growth are leading indicators, providing the base for network and issuer volume and loan growth. Customer spending and balance growth follow over time and international opportunities remain the general focus. Visa reports accounts with a lag and grew 7% as of 1Q.

It will be hard for Oaktree to convince the court of an enterprise value for Claire's meaningfully higher than the $1.4 billion in the retailer's proposed Chapter 11 plan, we believe. The plan is [BLANK] by private-equity sponsor Apollo, senior lenders such as Elliott Management and Monarch, and the unsecured creditors committee.

Nickel inventories have been pushed to historic highs as nickel production has exceeded. Analysts had expected Indonesian ore export ban would cause a draw-down of inventories, yet this has not [BLANK] and the price of nickel has risen by a mere 5% since the beginning of 2014. LME stocks expanded 58% last year and climbed to a record 26,324 metric tons on Feb. 9, a year after Indonesia banned on the export of nickel ores.

Safran's Zodiac acquisition is likely dilutive unless the target recovers mid-teens margins for its seat business by 2018. If the deal were to close today, Zodiac's depressed earnings would [BLANK] 10% off the combined EPS, based on consensus. Zodiac's net income is expected to more than double by 2018 as it improves the seat-making business. At 2018 estimated 367 million euros ($395 million) in net income and without synergies, dilution would be minimal. With synergies of 200 million it would be accretive.

Biotech and pharma events include Mast's vepoloxamer Phase III data in sickle cell disease vaso-occlusive crisis in July or shortly after. Vical-Astellas' cytomegalovirus vaccine Phase III trial is [BLANK] to be fully enrolled in 3Q. Advaxis plans to start Phase III of ADXS-HPV in 3Q after the FDA agrees to the protocol. Phase II data are expected for Neurocrine's valbenazine in Tourette syndrome and Alnylam-Medicines Co.'s PCSK9 drug, and Phase III data of Indivior's RBP-6000 in opioid use disorder.

A technology advancement to heat-assisted magnetic recording will hasten the pace of areal density growth in hard-disk drives, which has been anemic in recent years. This could [BLANK] price declines for the industry. Though capital needs are higher, Seagate and Western Digital can't avoid the transition, as competing solid-state drives may become significantly cheaper upon a move to 3D NAND and tri-level-cell memory. Samsung is ahead on 3D NAND, while Intel, Micron and SK Hynix are likely to produce volume in 2016.

Most electric transmission projects in a U.S. pilot program to speed permitting have been waiting at least six years for approval. Such lengthy permitting times boost development costs, and a measure in a Senate energy bill, S. 2012, could [BLANK] approvals. It has bipartisan support, though the House's energy bill lacks the provision, which lowers the chance it appears in combined legislation. The measure requires the Energy Department to coordinate agency inputs and streamline some reviews.

Bluebird's data for Lentiglobin at the European Hematology Association conference hit the high expectations set previously at ASH. Importantly, patients with sickle cell disease in the key Group C of its HGB-206 study had surpassed adequate levels of modified hemoglobin at three months, which [BLANK] well for prospects that may be transfusion-free. In beta thalassemia study HGB-207, a majority of patients had modified hemoglobin levels above target, though one poor performer did need a subsequent transfusion. These data now form the platform for further presentations at ASH. Data disclosed by the company precedes presentations June 16.

A recovery in Spain's construction industry is becoming evident in the housing segment, which is set to increase demand for building materials. New home permits rose 54% in September, compared with a year earlier, to 4,419, based on Spanish Ministry of Development data, [BLANK] greater confidence. The IMF forecasts Spain's GDP will expand 3% this year, the fastest in the euro zone after Ireland. Unemployment fell to 21.8% in 3Q from 24.2% a year earlier.

Awards may come by February in five major federal contract competitions with a combined potential value of $27.6 billion. The Education Department may [BLANK] winners of a $5 billion competition for student-loan debt collection and a $1.1 billion student aid deal. Prison operators may be selected for $1.2 billion in detention facility contracts. Additional awards might come in the Pentagon's $22 billion drug competition after AmerisourceBergen's victory in November.

The aging population is the primary demand driver for health-care real estate. Demographics will [BLANK] in a growing population of American elderly, increasing demand for all types of health care. The 2010 expansion of health-care coverage under the Affordable Care Act enhances demographic demand by providing insurance to millions of Americans.

Natural gas skeptics are relying too heavily on resilient production growth, which we think is softening as producers highlight a less-prolific cadence next year. Our initial read of cooler weather in the East through mid-November should [BLANK] a more constructive tone. Our broader bull case for U.S. gas rests on low stockpiles year-over-year heading into winter and structural demand growth across end-markets.

Caterpillar's Energy and Transportation dealer sales fell 2%, a disappointing turn after four positive months, even with similar year-ago comparisons. All units except Industrial [BLANK], with declines led by Power Generation, down 12% vs. an easier comparison. Industrial's sales recovery accelerated to 23% after June's 10% gain. Oil & Gas deteriorated, falling 2% vs. up 6%, against a tougher year-ago comparison of down 25% vs. 35%. Transportation's slump persisted after May's expansion.

Bristol-Myers and Pfizer filed 24 separate lawsuits against the generic-drug makers that have filed applications to market generic Eliquis, and the parties will likely request that the proceedings be combined into one large lawsuit in Delaware federal court, where most of the suits were filed. This may [BLANK] the start of the litigation, yet it will be far more efficient and less costly to Bristol-Myers and Pfizer. The generic defendants will also be able to coordinate defenses.

The dollar's recovery should relieve the revenue and earnings pressure that has squeezed several European banks as protectionism concerns intensify and the timetable for U.S. rate hikes is accelerated. Deutsche Bank's latest plan to [BLANK] back U.S. operations, and notably rates trading, will dilute any pickup from currency translation as the dollar strengthens. BNP, Barclays and Natixis (asset management and trading, respectively) stand out as some of the greatest beneficiaries. UBS and Credit Suisse also both report in Swiss francs, though they earn sizable share in dollars.

Asia's financial industry is lining up behind Blockchain, an emerging fintech to promise friction-free, peer-to-peer transactions to help banks and new challengers cut costs for transferring money and other assets. Asia's Blockchain startups may gain share in the global market after fintech funding [BLANK] to $10.5 billion in the first nine months of 2016, more than double the $4.3 billion for full-year 2015. China's comprised over 90% of the region's total, thanks to fundraising by internet giants.

Technological change provides insurers with opportunities to make their businesses more efficient and potentially drive claims lower. New technology may [BLANK] safety in areas including auto and aviation insurance, though it can also give rise to new challenges such as cyber risks. The value of personal data stored on corporate databases is rising rapidly, and with it the increased incidence of data breaches, as hackers become more sophisticated. This is resulting in demands for new forms of insurance coverage.

While Xerox's cost reductions are proceeding as expected, its new products targeting growth markets were not introduced until 1Q-end and likely will not have an impact on results until 2H. Xerox reiterated its outlook for margin expansion in 2017 as $600 million in gross cost savings should [BLANK] currency headwinds and continued sales declines. Overall 1Q results were in line with management's limited expectations as the company remains in the early stages of its strategic transformation.

Google is among companies that got a surprising win when the 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals on Aug. 29 said the FTC lacks jurisdiction over AT&T. Under the court's rationale, any company that qualifies as a "common carrier" at all is outside of FTC jurisdiction, even when it isn't [BLANK] in common-carrier activity. Since Google's a common carrier for its Google Fiber project, the FTC now can't oversee any Google activity, including its search business. The FTC typically polices unfair and deceptive practices.

Unlike most rules the president has set to, at least in part, reduce climate change-causing pollution, natural gas pipeline and underground gas storage requirements focused on safety have bipartisan support and may advance in 2016. A bill to re-authorize a pipeline program (S. 2276) would also require PHMSA to set gas storage requirements and [BLANK] a rule on gas pipeline safety. Those measures could in turn reduce methane emissions, which has been a priority for the president.

Puerto Rico faces slim odds in its Supreme Court bid to reverse a ruling striking down its restructuring law. The high court is likely to [BLANK] only on the narrow issue of whether a federal district court correctly interpreted the Bankruptcy Code without considering the equities related to Puerto Rico's fiscal crisis. And even if the high court reverses, potential deals with bondholders could prevent the utilities from using any restructuring laws that become available as a result.

Dividends are the latest casualty of Macau's collapse in gambling revenue, with Wynn Resorts' 67% cut being the most eye-catching. Recent payout reductions at Galaxy, Melco Crown and MGM China [BLANK] consensus expectations for an average 30% drop in 2015 net income across the city's six casino operators. Estimated dividend ratios in 2015 range from 94% to 125% for Las Vegas Sands, Sands China, MGM China, SJM and Wynn Macau. Wynn Resorts has said it won't borrow to make payouts.

BI's Macau gaming peer group dropped 18% in September, extending a decline of 39% from a year high reached in mid-January. The slump [BLANK] revenue disappointments, reduced consensus earnings estimates, labor unrest and the impact of protests in Hong Kong on stocks. A benign resolution of the Occupy Central demonstrations could spark a rally in Hong Kong traded stocks. New resorts may revive revenue growth late next year by adding capacity to a constrained industry.

The Specialty Equipment Market Association Show features future auto parts and technology while serving as a proving ground for carmakers building excitement for future concepts and the flexibility of existing vehicles. Selling, general and administrative expenses as a percentage of sales for global automakers were 14% in 3Q, with spending for operations and [BLANK] segment leading products. Tougher competition amid rising interest rates could see future marketing expense increase.

Venezuela's inflation is soaring with consensus expecting a rate above 200% in 2016. The declining value of crude oil exports is exasperating a shortfall of foreign currency, [BLANK] by continued money printing by the government. Crude oil production has stayed above 2 million barrels a day for much of the past decade. PDVSA, the state-owned oil company, has been unable to expand production amid declining investment. There may be a 12% budget shortfall in 2016, following a 10% shortfall in 2015.

Investors that brought an antitrust lawsuit against 16 banks in the global foreign exchange market may be emboldened by a $2 billion agreement reached with nine defendants that triggers extensive cooperation on their part, if the pact wins final court approval. The remaining defendant banks lost a bid to [BLANK] most of the claims in the suit on Sept. 20. Neither Credit Suisse, Deutsche Bank nor Morgan Stanley have been fined by regulators and all deny taking part in a currency-rigging conspiracy.

Facebook and Snapchat may struggle to replicate WeChat's monetization given entrenched usage of existing services by internet users in developed markets. China's mobile-first internet adoption enabled WeChat to integrate services such as payments, [BLANK] and e-commerce in its platform. Facebook is trying to work around this issue by focusing on spurring organic conversations between businesses and consumers via the proliferation of chatbots.

Millennials aren't the only generation to significantly increase investments in ETFs in the past three years. Gen Xers with TD Ameritrade accounts [BLANK] up their ETF allocations by 50% in the period. ETFs now make up 15% of those investors' portfolios, up from 10%. That's part of the group's broader move toward passive investing, with almost 20% of their portfolios allocated to index funds or ETFs. Like millennials, they favor Vanguard ETFs, the PowerShares QQQ Trust Series 1 (QQQ) and the SPDR Gold Shares (GLD).

Cree's International Trade Commission case against Feit Electric and its Asian supplier, Unity Opto Technology, could block Feit's LED bulbs and lighting products from U.S. markets. Cree alleges Feit and Unity have [BLANK] a number of Cree patents covering technology used in general purpose LED bulbs used in homes and businesses. Cree also argues that Feit has made false and misleading statements regarding the power-saving performance of Feit's LED products.

Teva could make $600 million in sales alone from Actavis' generic Crestor in 3Q, which may be the first quarter after the deal closes. The company should be competition-free for 90 days, as it will have half of the 180-day exclusivity [BLANK] to first-to-file Actavis. Sales will continue after that, though a significant price discount may be needed to retain market share from other ANDA filers. Analysis takes into account prescription data, historical U.S. sales of Crestor, and a 6% price discount from the brand.

Deutsche Bank, Goldman, HSBC and JPMorgan are among banks to have disclosed probes related to hiring practices, including in Asia. The probes focus on potential Foreign Corrupt Practices Act violations, an anti-bribery law enforced by the Justice Department and the SEC that [BLANK] bribery of non-U.S. officials. Penalties under the FCPA can reach 2x the value of the benefit the violator obtained. The banks are under investigation in part for allegedly hiring government officials' relatives in exchange for business.

Aerovironment, Amazon, Boeing and other drone operators will have the opportunity to push back against Federal Aviation Administration draft rules on commercial unmanned aircrafts at the end of the year. Upon release of the proposed rules, companies can provide feedback to [BLANK] the final regulation that may restrict flight altitude and times and require pilot licenses, which may be stricter than expected. Small drone operators may seek exemptions for extra small aircraft.

Post-3Q Earnings Outlook: MasTec continues to post strong growth in Oil and Gas, though other businesses are slowly becoming greater profit contributors. Oil and Gas revenue remained above $1 billion, due to a rise in pass-through spending on a cost-reimbursable job, which also [BLANK] margins lower. Communications remains flattish but will ramp in 2018, reflecting more traction in wireless, buoyed by 5G and FirstNet. PowerGen/Industrial and Electrical Transmission are also ramping, but are only modest contributors.

Vivendi should meet its own targets for revenue growth (excluding Havas) of more than 5% and Ebita of about 25%. It's important that Canal+ [BLANK] further positive momentum in the French market to reassure on the sustainability of the trend. Havas should deliver a further improvement in organic revenue growth (0.1% in 3Q17) given the modestly improving trend being seen across the advertising industry. Management needs to provide some further definition of the mid-term strategy, to better articulate how the seemingly disparate parts of the strategy can work together, its intentions on Ubisoft and also on Telecom Italia.

The increasing threat and complexity of cyberattacks should prompt more IT budget allocation toward security, fueling growth for vendors such as Palo Alto Networks, IBM and Cisco. Spending will likely skew toward emerging-technology offerings, [BLANK] legacy vendors' share while driving demand for IT services.

The seasonal decline in U.S. distillate inventories may accelerate as agricultural demand picks up. Crack spreads have fallen slightly in the past couple of weeks to about $14.50 a barrel, $5 lower than year-earlier levels, which may [BLANK] refiners' 3Q margins. Projections of a warm winter due to El Nino may mean that heating oil use in the Northeast will be far lower than usual. Consensus expects a decline of 677,000 barrels in the week ended Oct. 2, more than last year's 267,000 drop.

Providers of credit cards, debt-collection services, auto leasing, checking accounts and other consumer financial products likely would see an uptick in class-action litigation under the CFPB's arbitration proposal. The rule would [BLANK] contractual pre-dispute arbitration clauses that act to block class-action lawsuits. It requires providers to insert contract language explaining this. Firms would have to give the agency detailed information including claims as well as awards and final payouts to consumers.

Demand for storage batteries is likely to increase, as governments set aggressive targets to increase the share of energy generation from renewables. Batteries can be used in the electric grid to [BLANK] excess energy and decouple intermittent power generation from demand. They are responsive and can easily be sited close to areas or regions of high demand. Batteries may compete with other grid-balancing options, such as pumped-hydro and compressed-air energy storage.

In a Bear Case, a prolonged emerging-market slowdown could hamper the performance of IT services providers, which routinely cite countries such as Brazil, Russia, India and China as important sources of growth. While these countries currently constitute a small portion of IT spending, their share is [BLANK] to increase. IBM, Hewlett-Packard and Cisco have struggled in China, and Accenture has faced challenges in Brazil.

Gilead may be trying to take some public heat off its drug pricing when it chose $74,760 as the list price for a 12-week course of its new hepatitis C drug Epclusa (sofosbuvir plus velpatasvir). This may be taking a cue from Merck, which [BLANK] its new drug at $54,600. What Gilead could be doing is then offering a lower rebate to offset the lower list price. Media and political criticism of Gilead's drug pricing had largely and erroneously centered on list price.

The MSCI World Tobacco Index has surged 17% this year, well ahead the MSCI World's fractional decline of less than 1%. The performance may reflect the group's relatively high dividend yields within a low interest rate environment, a pickup in M&A and [BLANK] U.S. cigarette consumption. The MSCI World Tobacco Index is at year-to-date highs, bolstered by Japan Tobacco's $5 billion agreement to buy the international rights to Reynolds American's Natural American Spirit brand.

WellCare is increasing its exposure to Medicaid expansion by announcing its second acquisition of a health plan in Arizona. The deal should ease losses for hospital provider Tenet Healthcare, which is seeking to [BLANK] all of its health plans in 2017. Arizona enrollment has grown faster than other expansion states, but WellCare may need to improve the plans as they are among the lowest rated. The deal is WellCare's fourth in 2016, three of which were for Medicaid members in new states.

Amazon requires warehouse workers to undergo a security screening after shifts to ensure they aren't stealing merchandise. The Supreme Court is [BLANK] the case of workers suing their temp agency to pay for waits of as long as 25 minutes for the screenings. Liberal Justices Ruth Bader Ginsburg and Elena Kagan, who are in the minority unless there is a swing vote, showed some sympathy toward the workers' reasoning, while the U.S. solicitor general's office argued the activity wasn't compensable.

Delta's June yields fell 5.2% and 3.7% for 2Q as excess capacity and currency keep hurting revenue. The airline's fuel costs fell 17% year-over-year, improving margins 340 bps before hedging, likely leaving profitability flat to slightly lower in 2Q, as competition [BLANK] much of the gain from lower fuel prices. Delta cited international and, in recent months, domestic markets for the weakness. Domestic challenges are rising as carriers attempt to drive profit with increased U.S. flying, given better yields.

Since late August the price-target cuts of Standard Chartered and HSBC, coupled with share price declines, have altered the order of EU banks trading furthest from their objectives. ING, Commerzbank and KBC are unique among large-capitalization EU lenders, [BLANK] more than 20% below targets, supplanting Asian-focused peers which were previously between 30% and 40% below theirs. On average, the EU banks trade 15% below average price objectives with Handelsbanken the only lender trading above its consensus target.

Women's and girls' clothing makes up the largest segment of the U.S. apparel market, comprising more than 60% of the total value. The category's sales in the U.S. may have reached $171 billion in 2014, almost [BLANK] the $90 billion market for men's and boys' apparel, according to Bureau of Economic Analysis estimates. Children's and infants' clothing represents the smallest segment in the market at $19 billion, or 7% of the total.

China has recorded 124.1% of global refined nickel demand growth during the past 15 years, as the demand from the rest of the world shrank. Global nickel demand [BLANK] 50.5% to 1.73 million metric tons in 2014, from 1.15 million in 2000, a 2.8% annual growth rate. China's need for the metal, driven by the increase in stainless steel production, climbed 18.9% annually in the same period. China's share of nickel demand has soared to 44%, from 5% in 2000, making it the main driver of global appetite for the metal.

New capital requirements, effective on Jan. 1, may reduce Polish banks' new lending capacity by 75% to $20 billion according to Pekao, challenging consensus loan-growth estimates. A bank multiplier, a ratio of loan growth to GDP growth, [BLANK] the correlation between economic expansion and lending growth. This has averaged 2x in the period 2010 to 3Q in Poland. Based on this multiple and the 3.5% 2016 GDP growth projected by economists, loans would grow 7% next year, in-line with consensus.

Energy Corp.'s long-term annual earnings growth forecast of 6-8% is driven by cost cuts and new investment, including gas generation and renewables to replace coal retirements. The company's growth forecast is among the highest of all U.S. utility holding companies, even [BLANK] its Michigan peer DTE, which invests in pipelines to boost growth. New CEO Patti Poppe isn't expected to alter CMS' focus as a pure-play regulated utility, with almost 100% of profit coming from electric and gas utility operations.

Better traction in footwear, along with strong gains in digital expansion, should keep DSW (DSW -5.6%) on a fast pace for sustaining its sales expansion through 2018. The specialty [BLANK] footwear retailer isn't likely to be hampered by a fiscal 1Q 60-bp drop in merchandise margin, given our belief that was due to colder weather hampering sales of spring products. Online growth and robust demand for fashion-focused women's shoes is framing the company's full-year outlook for low-single-digit comparable sales growth.

Facing a long-term shift in global energy demand away from oil and toward a low-carbon future, BP is responding with an upstream strategy increasingly weighted toward gas and LNG. The company's production mix has historically [BLANK] one of the highest oil weightings vs. peers.

Health policy topics at the Senate HELP Committee's Jan. 18 "courtesy" hearing for HHS nominee Tom Price included a pledge not "to pull the rug out" from under individuals affected by Obamacare-repeal efforts. On the drug-pricing issue, Price pledged to address the "root causes" of rising drug prices, implying he continues to oppose giving CMS authority to [BLANK] drug prices directly with manufacturers. Price faces a formal confirmation hearing in front of the Senate Finance Committee on Jan. 24.

Rising capital needs and declining used-equipment prices could significantly change the structure of the U.S. construction-machinery market. Emissions standards have [BLANK] U.S. new equipment prices by 40% since 2003. Emissions technology doesn't transfer to export markets lacking supplies of the required fuel. Shrinking export markets may affect used-equipment prices and residual values. An emerging sharing economy, or new online services for rentals, may raise utilization and reduce new equipment demand.

Signs are favorable for Deutsche Bank in its defense against multibillion-dollar lawsuits by BlackRock and other RMBS investors who allege the bank failed in its RMBS trustee duties. Recent court rulings should help [BLANK] the suits. While damages are unspecified, the suits allege billions in trust and noteholder losses.

Apartment REITs' asking rent per square foot in the New York metro area fell 3.2% on average in June vs. a year ago. Stronger-than-expected job growth to [BLANK] 2016 has supported demand, but supply has also risen due to the 421-a tax abatement program. UDR COO Jerry Davis said 25,000 apartment units are likely to be added in 2016 and 30,000 in 2017. Starts and permits spiked in June 2015 as New York development surged prior to the expiration of the abatement; that supply is coming to market in the next 18 months.

Mortgage originations among owner-occupiers in Australia, after slowing to a six-month low of 13.6% in August, may further wane as weak affordability and muted wage growth offset the impact of low rates. The affordability index was 59 for Sydney and 70.9 for Melbourne in 3Q, [BLANK] caps in home-buying power. Average wages rising only 2.1% in 2Q, the slowest pace since 1998, may limit home sales and loan demand. These negatives could counter the impact of interest-rate cuts consensus sees through 2017.

The moratorium on new coal leases on federal land could have surpassed the Clean Power Plan as former President Barack Obama's most significant climate-change policy. Yet President Donald Trump's administration is [BLANK] to unwind both. Ending the leasing moratorium isn't likely to have much near-term effect because of the long lead times associated with developing new mines. About 400 million tons of coal are produced on federal land each year.

Relative rotation graphs show European industrials outperformed benchmark indexes this year. However, falling relative-strength momentum may [BLANK] to a reversal in the trend in the near future. The outperformance has been driven by optimism surrounding a commodity-market recovery. Industrial companies' valuations are already close to all-time highs, suggesting earnings expectations would need to recover if the sector outperformance is to continue in 2017.

A spinoff of VW's (VOW GY -0.1%) truck and bus unit will only meet market expectations, so the creation of a super-premium division including Porsche and Lamborghini would be welcomed as part of a bolder review of corporate assets focused on generating shareholder value. New CEO Herbert Diess is a popular choice, given his cost-cutting credentials, but the appointment of a labor representative to the main board [BLANK] less positive. China, Audi and Porsche account for 66% of VW's pretax profit and, with consensus already ahead of 2020 targets, the ongoing asset review will be the stock's main catalyst in 2018 -- unless Diess can raise earnings expectations across the company.

Bank holding companies and certain savings and loan holding companies with at least $50 billion in assets have until Aug. 5 to provide comments on the proposed net stable funding ratio (NSFR). After analyzing, regulators will likely try to [BLANK] the rule by year-end but delays into 2017 are possible. The U.S. election should have limited impact. The NSFR has been planned and shouldn't be a surprise to banks, so regulators likely expect limited pushback. The proposed rule would apply beginning on Jan. 1, 2018.

China Holdings Ltd. faces heightened competition from major new resorts on the Cotai Strip before its property opens there in 2Q17. It's been losing revenue share, [BLANK] it has stabilized and improved profitably through cost savings and shifting its focus to the premium end of mainstream gambling. It competes with rival Wynn, right across the street on the Macau peninsula, for premium-mass market and VIP business. This relationship will extend to Cotai as it opens its property across from Wynn Palace.

Oil and gas producers that curtail flaring can reduce a source of pollution and local community tension, and monetize associated natural gas. Some 27 oil companies, including Shell, BP, Total, Eni and Statoil, as well as a number of national oil companies, have pledged to [BLANK] routine flaring by 2030. Led by Total, most producers report a decrease in flaring relative to production. Chevron and Exxon Mobil are noticeably absent from the World Bank pledge, and saw flaring rise in 2015.

Helmerich & Payne owns half, or 162, of the 324 high-specification (AC drive/1,500 horsepower) rigs idle or cold-stacked throughout the Permian, Eagle Ford, Mid-Continent, Bakken and DJ Basin. In the Permian, the company has 56% of the high-spec rigs that could [BLANK] to work, followed by Nabors, Patterson-UTI and Precision, with 8% each, and Independence (7%). Potential additions in the Mid-Continent also favor H&P, given its 44% share of idle or cold-stacked rigs in the region.

The Health Resources and Services Administration has delayed implementation of a final rule criticized by drug companies until July 2018. HRSA's proposal, responding to instructions contained in the Affordable Care Act, would impose monetary penalties on drugmakers for failing to comply with statutorily [BLANK] ceiling prices for medicines sold to 340B-eligible facilities. The rule also drew the industry's ire by creating the possibility that the ceiling price for a handful of drugs could be 1 cent.

North American beverage producers generated a median 10.5% EPS gain in 3Q on 5.3% higher sales, fueled by acquisition benefits, stable raw material costs and strong demand for energy drinks. The group is [BLANK] for the future: Capital spending as a proportion of sales reached 4.4% in 3Q, up from 3.8% in the year-earlier period. This in part reflects facility expansions by brewers Boston Beer and Constellation Brands.

Consensus oil price estimates for the reminder of 2015 and 2016 may be elevated, given wide supply-demand imbalances, which may result in further revisions to benchmarks. Lower crude oil prices will challenge E&P volume targets and weaker price realizations will [BLANK] profitability and cash flow. Yet lower cost structures may partially arrest deteriorating E&P netbacks. Weak fundamentals may constrain E&P liquidity as underwriters move to reassess credit availability by cutting price decks and reevaluate reserves.

Absorption of U.S. office space is expected to increase 38% in 2016, based on Reis forecasts, following a 48% gain in 2015, driven largely by the expansion of technology companies, especially in San Francisco, New York and Seattle. Since the end of 2010, U.S. office absorption has [BLANK] new office deliveries by a net 13 million aggregate square feet, boosting occupancies and rents. Reis forecasts 3.8% office rent growth in 2016, the highest since 2007, and 15.9% vacancy, the lowest since 2008.

Clean Power Plan opponents, granted a stay of the rule by the Supreme Court on Feb. 9, may also benefit from the high court's move in the merits portion of the case before a U.S. appeals court. The high court's stay, a 5-4 decision along ideological lines, is a strong indication of how it may [BLANK] if the case makes it to the Supreme Court. The lower court will undoubtedly take this into account when reaching its decision, bringing the case closer to even odds than before the stay decision.

Office REIT shares rose in June but couldn't top the broader REIT index, and still trail for the year. Many of the top-performing office REITs for the month were among the worst performers year-to-date, as investors [BLANK] toward beaten-down stocks looking for value and income.

Sales for U.S. clothing retailers continue to improve, driven by accelerated growth in demand for women's apparel. January retail sales at clothing and accessories stores (including jewelry) [BLANK] by 3.8% vs. the same period last year, according to U.S. Census Bureau data. This was a 60-bp improvement from December (up 3.2%). The largest increase in sales is driven by women's clothing stores, which accelerated 10.7% in December, outperforming men's and family apparel.

After finalizing a $5.1 billion settlement with the Justice Department's RMBS task force on April 11, Goldman Sachs still faces investor and shareholder lawsuits over mortgage-related products, including one related to the Abacus CDO. Goldman is also [BLANK] proposed class-action antitrust suits related to interest-rate swaps, ISDAfix, U.S. Treasury securities and platinum/palladium. The bank's role is also being examined as part of bribery and corruption probes related to Malaysia's 1MDB fund.

Reckitt's $16.6 billion offer for Mead Johnson is approved and due to close June 15. It plans to raise sales growth and [BLANK] regional reach. Mead's mid-term sales growth of 3-5% is partly on China's infant formula rebound. Cost savings of 200 million pounds are sought by 2020. That's less than 4% of Ebitda. Slight EPS accretion is forecast in the first year, double-digit EPS gains by the third, and ROIC cover by the fifth. Typical of Reckitt, these seem conservative.

Microsoft Windows server-operating systems generate $8 billion a year, or 68% of the $12 billion market, according to IDC. Linux- and Unix-based systems each account for 11% of total spending on these products, which [BLANK] resources across a server network. Unix usage is in steady decline as clients choose the relative flexibility and portability of Linux, which is seeing revenue expand rapidly. Growth in mobile and cloud may accelerate demand for virtual machines to displace physical servers.

SunEdison, the renewable energy company laden with over $16 billion in debt, filed for bankruptcy on April 21 in New York. Its yieldco subsidiaries, TerraForm Power and TerraForm Global, didn't seek Chapter 11 protection and [BLANK] to continue operating as usual. SunEdison received bankruptcy court approval of a $300 million debtor-in-possession financing commitment from some of its first- and second-lien lenders. The DIP also includes a rollup of $1 billion in prepetition debt.

The U.K.'s pending EU withdrawal and the Trump administration continue to exacerbate financial policy uncertainty in 2H, compounded by the potential instability of a new U.K. minority conservative government. Regulatory relief from Dodd-Frank is likely to come from the U.S. regulators long-term, but legislative efforts such as the Financial Choice Act are unlikely to [BLANK] by 4Q end. Brexit negotiations should intensify in 4Q, while regulators across the EU focus on MiFID II as its start date nears.

Commodity market liquidity may wane due to MiFID II rules that could push commodity trading firms, and companies that trade ancillary to their main business, to exit the market. Traders may [BLANK] to maintain capital reserves (8% RWA for banks), which could reach $6.7 billion per company, EFET estimates. Buffers, position limits and compliance costs would exacerbate this. With fewer counterparties, the market may suffer reduced liquidity, volatility spikes and wider bid-ask spreads.

Athenahealth is seeing slower demand from its core, while adoption of new initiatives trails its expectations. The company [BLANK] to spur demand by adjusting its offerings. Entry into the acute-hospital market remains in early stages and faces stiff competition from larger peers. However, it's still adding providers and patient records at a solid rate and remains focused on creating a connected health-care network. An investment by an activist investor is spurring management and operational changes.

As sanctions ease, Iran may re-emerge as a significant source of new chemicals supply. While sanctions have [BLANK] foreign investment and exports, the country has proven capabilities, as local ethylene capacity rose by 5 million metric tons (4% of global) in 2006-10, followed by an increase in derivatives capacity. With 67 unfinished chemical projects prioritized by Iran's National Petrochemical, partnerships that bring global technology and capital may quickly have impact.

Post-1Q Earnings Outlook: NetApp's all-flash arrays (AFA) will likely propel 2019 sales to expand above its mid-single-digit growth guidance, as might product mix, software impact and strategic enterprise license agreements (ELA). AFA's are 14% of the installed product base and 37% of sales, [BLANK] room for growth. Public-cloud sales to Google, Amazon.com and Microsoft are expanding but remain less than 2% of sales. Corporate IT spending is now a main driver of near-term sales and margins. NetApp reported better-than-consensus EPS of $1.04, powered by accounting rule changes, ELAs, share-count cuts and tax benefits, all totaling 24 cents on stronger sales of $1.47 billion. Fiscal 2Q sales guidance was in-line with consensus, but the company raised 2019 EPS and margin guidance.

Following the first true biosimilar in the U.S. with FDA approval of Novartis' (Sandoz) version of Amgen's cancer drug Neupogen, several more biosimilars such as Celltrion's biosimilar Remicade may see approval in 2016. Sandoz was the first company to [BLANK] U.S. approval under a the pathway that was part of the Affordable Care Act. Drugs approved before this pathway existed, such as Teva's version of Neupogen called Granix, aren't true biosimilars.

North American packaged food M&A this year through mid-November totaled $23 billion in pending and completed deals, far below 2015's full-year total of $98 billion. The slowdown reflects foodmakers' emphasis on assimilating businesses [BLANK] in 2015, and a shifting focus toward small deals. This contrasts with the industry's emphasis last year on large and transformative acquisitions. M&A may resume as food producers seek to address weak consumer spending on packaged foods and tepid demand in developing markets.

An estimated 44% of analog chip sales may be used in products sold in the Asia-Pacific region, according to IDC. Regional sales breakdowns from companies may be misleading, as they may [BLANK] revenue data by chip, rather than device type. Analog sales into Asia TVs, industrials and autos may be smaller than elsewhere, yet macroeconomic weakness in the region still has an impact. For handsets and PCs, the size of the market and rate of decline in Asia matters. Wired communication sales may also be affected.

Jewelers in China could face greater competition in the non-gold category as lower import tariffs in 2019 prompt Pandora and Tiffany to extend price cuts on their items in the country. Asian rivals such as Chow Tai Fook could retaliate by offering more promotions to [BLANK] more spending by younger Chinese shoppers at its stores and online.

Growth in floating LNG regasification capacity (FSRUs) globally is underpinned by faster unit deployment and flexibility vs. onshore LNG import terminals. FSRUs can be built in half the time, and conversion from existing LNG tankers can [BLANK] up completion. FSRUs also offer greater flexibility, and have the ability to relocate to new regions. Under its deal with Kuwait National Petroleum Company, shipowner Golar charters FSRUs for nine months a year, being free to pursue other opportunities the rest of the time.

Enterprise-blockchain initiatives by Walmart and Kroger should push suppliers to more quickly embrace the technology. Yet widespread use [BLANK] improved transaction speed and better-understood off-chain data. Cryptographic anchors, which can act as tamper-proof digital fingerprints, need to be developed.

Acorda filed an appeal on May 24 of its loss of four of its patents covering multiple sclerosis drug Ampyra in its lawsuit against Teva, Mylan and Hikma's Roxane. Acorda's Ampyra is [BLANK] until July 30, 2018. That's the case even if Acorda loses on appeal. The timeline coincides with the expiration of the only Ampyra patent that survived the court's scrutiny. The trial focused on the validity of Acorda's patents after generics makers agreed to infringement. The invalidated patents would have expired in 2025-27.

Tighter Brent-WTI differentials have slowed the decline in U.S. imports of seaborne blends, though the broader structural trend remains intact, driven by resilient domestic crude oil production. Imports [BLANK] 7.35 million barrels a day in the week ended March 27. Canadian heavy blend flows to the U.S. have averaged 3 million barrels a day for the past four weeks, while Saudi Arabia shipments averaged 954,000. Latin America has gained market share as distillate spreads invited heavier crude blends.

Yelp may maintain its local ad sales growth strength as mobile usage of the review site grows and an expanded sales force becomes more productive. The company could continue speedy growth of transaction revenue, which includes in-app bookings and Eat24, as users [BLANK] to transact with businesses via built-in tools on Yelp's sites and apps. Insight on Yelp's strategy to maintain user engagement amid growing competition from Google and Facebook may offer transparency to the company's longer-term sales-growth outlook.

Sky secured the broadcasting rights to 126 out of 168 Premier League soccer games at a cost of 4.17 billion pounds ($6.4 billion) in the latest auction. This [BLANK] an 83% increase in cost compared with the 2012 auction when Sky acquired 116 out of 154 games. BT acquired 42 games at a cost of 960 million pounds compared with 738 million pounds for 28 games in 2012. At 11 million pounds a game, Sky's bidding was more aggressive than BT's 7.6 million pounds a game.

Operating profit may fall at AutoNation in 1Q as dealer margins come under pressure amid a new-vehicle inventory pileup and as investments are made to create additional or enhance existing revenue generators. SG&A will remain elevated in the near-term as the company adds stores selling only pre-owned autos; the first are set to [BLANK] in 2Q. The improved value proposition of used vehicles will result in increased volume and offset some of the decline in consumer demand for new autos.

J&J-Pharmacyclics's Imbruvica faces some competition from Gilead's Zydelig in relapsed and refractory chronic lymphocytic leukemia, yet offers a better safety profile. Zydelig carries a black-box warning and requires [BLANK] for colitis, diarrhea and liver toxicity. Imbruvica is also a single-drug therapy, while Zydelig is given with Rituxan.

Importers of biodiesel from Argentina and Indonesia could face paying antidumping and countervailing duties retroactive to as early as May 23. The Commerce Department is likely to [BLANK] U.S. biodiesel producers' request for retroactivity, which was made on July 10. By alleging "critical circumstances" apply, the U.S. producers are required to prove a "massive" surge in imports. Initial countervailing and dumping estimates are expected around Aug. 21 and Nov. 8, respectively.

Endo's $8.05 billion offer for Par values the generic-drug company at 10x to 11x 2016 adjusted pro forma Ebitda, which is in-line with other bids in the generic realm. As assets are becoming sparse in a wave of consolidation, generic makers have [BLANK] higher premiums. Acquirers such as Endo have cited the growth of the U.S. generic pharma market, which may grow at a 6% annual rate. Specialty pharma assets have had even higher premiums.

Liberty Global's commitments in order to secure regulatory approval from the European Commission for its acquisition of Ziggo suggest rising scrutiny of pay-TV deals that lead to consolidation. Agreed remedies may include the divestiture of one of its premium pay-TV channels, offering access to over-the-top competition and [BLANK] arm's length when offering content to rivals. The rising presence of telecom carriers in pay TV may increase the number of consolidating deals.

Armstrong faces challenging 1Q comparables from a volume perspective though management noted robust 4Q activity carrying over into January and February. A continuing mix-shift toward the higher-end of the mineral fiber ceilings market and increased participation from the Architectural Specialties segment will [BLANK] favorable pricing. Progress on improving margins in underperforming international markets and plans to increase penetration in adjacent segments of the ceiling market will be focal points.

Though not the only buyers, offshore-domiciled utilities and funds have been a major presence in the U.S. utility-buyout wave. For growth-minded Canadian utilities, the view is simple -- there aren't many utilities to [BLANK] at home. For large utilities and funds, acquiring a U.S. utility effectively provides an equity return of 10% vs. the low cost of debt financing. Though not high growth, many U.S. utilities' stable cash flows can increase about 5% from reinvestment, and they typically provide yields of about 3%.

Eli Lilly, with few key clinical catalysts anticipated, faces increasing risk for its core growth-driver diabetes franchise, particularly from Novo Nordisk's rival drugs. This [BLANK] tremendous pressure on its key diabetes drug Trulicity to show a cardiovascular benefit in the Rewind outcomes trial, due in late 2018.

Pearson identified Online Program Management (OPM) services (5% of 2015 revenue) as a key driver of higher education growth. It [BLANK] OPM revenue to increase in-line with what it considers a conservative estimate for the market of 10% a year, as it rebuilds momentum in new programs, after slower growth in 2014-15. Typically OPMs are based on revenue-share models with the educational institution and take two-to-four years to break even. Peers' long-term margin expectations range from high teens to mid-thirties.

Ethanol producers including Valero and Archer-Daniels-Midland are forecast to consume about 5.15 billion bushels of corn in the 2014-15 marketing year, according to USDA estimates, about 25 million more than expected in October. Corn, the main feedstock for U.S. ethanol producers, is still likely to be [BLANK], even though the forecast was lowered by 68 million bushels, to a record 14.41 billion bushels. The U.S. corn harvest season is coming to an end, with 80% collected as of Nov. 10.

The rapidly changing global metals landscape has shown a sharp increase in metal price volatility, which has in turn increased the volatility of miner equities. Investors who [BLANK] metal exposure will invest in ETFs, while equity investors push more toward cash flows. This means miners can no longer only focus on the supply-side and costs. They must also consider the revenue side of their business. Managements need to explain whether they will or won't hedge and why, and be transparent on costs and opportunities.

Deutsche Bank discussed the ramifications of quantitative easing at some length on its full-year analyst call, and said a protracted QE would be a concern because of the associated "low volumes and activity" that this might bring. While lower overnight and 10-year rates would continue to [BLANK] net interest margins, though much pain had already been taken, increased volatility may benefit sales and trading. Spanish banks noted that some securities portfolio income may be at risk.

Operating margins for AbbVie, Bristol-Myers Squibb, GlaxoSmithKline, Eli Lilly and Johnson & Johnson are expected to show meaningful improvements in 2016, based on consensus. Of these, Glaxo and J&J should [BLANK] the best 1Q gains, partly reflecting widening margins in their consumer health divisions. Lilly is reaping the rewards of rising profitability in its animal health unit and new drug launches. Novartis margins are pressured by Alcon and the genericization of Gleevec, its largest drug.

Evolving regulation and institutional client challenges will keep rivalry for global trading revenue intense, in our view. Deutsche's business must [BLANK] stabilization and Goldman's progress against its growth plan. Credit Suisse's investor update needs to bolster confidence in its ability to meet strategic goals after weak trading this year.

Laredo Petroleum isn't involved in material litigation, though broader legal issues may increase operations costs. Lawsuits in Oklahoma alleging wastewater injection [BLANK] earthquakes could persuade state regulators in other states to limit such injection volume, thereby increasing disposal costs. Average disposal costs in the Permian Basin are already higher than most plays at 19% of total well costs. Increased waste compliance or limited disposal well use could result from any of several pending lawsuits.

Activist investors are calling for Johnson & Johnson to consider splitting itself up. Using consensus data and comparative valuations [BLANK] a $295 billion enterprise value (EV) for J&J's three businesses separately. This equates to $23 billion of value locked in its conglomerate structure compared with an EV of $272 billion. This might be higher if J&J gave more disclosure on its drug pipeline and improved operating margins in its consumer health arm. The analysis suggests an EV range of $252.4-$365.7 billion.

Chinese gas utilities' market values have been rising faster than Asian peers. Their revenue will get a boost if the government hits its target of [BLANK] gas consumption from 2010 to 2020. The aggregate market value for China's five largest gas utilities jumped 73% in the past five years, tracking the nation's 68% jump in gas consumption. Japanese and South Korean peers lost market value in the period. China's group of city-gas distributors is now the largest in Asia, led by Hong Kong & China Gas.

Global ads may rise to 4.9% to $545 million in 2015, according to ZenithOptimedia, which pared its forecasts slightly on weak European growth and the lack of major political and sporting events. Display may reach a milestone in 2015, [BLANK] to almost $70 billion, driven by video and social ads. Programmatic ad buying is also growing rapidly. Agency stock prices are up 4% this year after falling 1% in 2014 amid European weakness and failed M&A. Most agencies, including WPP and Omnicom, are cautious about 2015.

Health insurers have announced $45 billion worth of M&A in 2015, a trend that may eventually leave just three major competitors, boost premiums for consumers and spur more consolidation among U.S. hospitals. Insurers have [BLANK] lower rates and raised premiums after prior mergers, studies found, which could raise antitrust hurdles for deals such as Aetna's proposed purchase of Humana. Hospitals also tend to charge higher prices after their mergers, which may push consumers into plans with higher deductibles.

Several states have mulled measures that could expand gaming and raise competition. A Connecticut bill would [BLANK] the fate of a third state casino in the hands of a publicly traded company, rather than the two tribes (operators of Foxwoods and Mohegan Sun), whose proposed casino in East Windsor is near Massachusetts-based MGM Springfield. Pennsylvania's 2017 law permits airport slots and small-scale casinos. A Michigan bill allowing existing casinos to have online games, and an Illinois bill permitting six new casinos and racetrack slots, may be revisited. Companies Impacted: Pennsylvania expansion could affect casinos run by Penn, Boyd and Churchill, while development in Illinois could impinge on Penn's properties. Slots in Missouri bars could affect Eldorado, Penn and Boyd, which will operate two being sold by Pinnacle.

Sumitomo Mitsui and Mizuho's $3.3 billion in U.S. dollar-denominated subordinated debt fell an average 1.7% from recent peaks. Since August, the dollar has [BLANK] 6.2% against the yen. Lower sub-debt prices may boost lenders' offshore funding costs, and appreciated dollar bonds may translate into higher liabilities in yen, making it more expensive for the banks to raise offshore funds for overseas expansion. These debts contributed to 7.8% of Sumitomo Mitsui's and 8.1% of Mizuho's Tier 2 capital.

Chinese banks, major constituents in widely followed stock indexes, remain market bellwethers. Lenders' values would be trimmed in Hong Kong dollars if the yuan continues to [BLANK]. They also face operating challenges such as revenue slowdowns and weaker credit quality. The nation's 13th Five-Year Plan starting in 2016 asks banks to loan more to high-risk sectors. The nine largest listed banks have a combined market cap of more than $900 billion for a 19% weighting in MSCI China, 42% in HSCEI and 16% in Hang Seng.

One reason for the gap in retail REIT discounts to their underlying assets is that investors don't believe the underlying values given the struggles facing retailers and therefore landlords. And while a large transaction would go a long way toward [BLANK] market pricing and helping bridge the gap, no such transactions appear on the horizon. Even though many REITs and institutions are flush with cash, there are no high-quality malls for sale. And mall REITs aren't eager to sell their best properties.

Regulated U.S. utilities may step up sales of unregulated and overseas assets this year, as a record average forward P/E above 17x encourages a greater focus on core assets. American Electric is [BLANK] the possible sale of unregulated power plants in Ohio. Duke has said it may shed Brazilian hydro holdings following its earlier sale of Midwest Generation to Dynegy. AES's DPL unit could also revive plans scrapped in July to sell unregulated generation and retail operations.

Food retailers increasingly need to improve productivity as they expand their discount businesses and price competition escalates. Many retailers operating in [BLANK] markets have scope to streamline distribution and purchasing, even as costs such as wages and rents rise. Depreciating currencies have affected reported results in Latin America in particular, though weaker home currencies have boosted food retailers in South Africa.

We foresee Qualcomm's multifront licensing dispute with Apple starting to take shape in 2H, as trial decisions are made in key lawsuits in China, Germany and the U.S. The widespread litigation serves as a proxy for [BLANK] discussions, where Qualcomm aims to recoup $4 billion in annual [BLANK] revenue from Apple.

Enthusiasm regarding a near-term increase in U.S. crude oil exports may need to be tempered. Exports had [BLANK] a new high mainly due to cheaper shipping costs and, to a lesser extent, the arbitrage of oil benchmark prices. The spread between Brent and WTI has hovered over $2 a barrel since OPEC's agreement to curtail output. Wider differentials are predicated on adherence to the pact, higher U.S. liquids volume, bloated inventories further pressuring WTI prices and ongoing weakness in tanker rates.

Russian oil companies are well-positioned for the foreseeable future, with a strong growth outlook thanks to relatively resilient capital-spending programs continued through oil's downturn. The companies offer significant shareholder return potential given their [BLANK] valuation to global peers due to political risk. Russian oil output has become increasingly important and closely watched since the country forced its way into a key negotiating position at the OPEC table with a linchpin contribution to the earlier non-OPEC quota cuts that played a critical role in the oil-market rebalancing. The sliding scale fiscal system, which provided a cushion and bolstered the Russian companies' resilience during the low oil price environment, plays a vital role in the sector.

Credit spreads on European corporate bonds have narrowed significantly since 2013, in-line with falling corporate default rates, according to a report by the Joint Committee of the European Supervisory Authorities. European life insurers hold about 26% of their invested assets in corporate bonds, with about half the portfolio [BLANK] to financials. In a Bull Case, narrowing spreads should improve the value of insurers' corporate bond holdings and enhance capital.

Social media sites such as Facebook, and messaging apps, now allow payments to merchants, but the functionality has been slow to catch on. Sites have focused on [BLANK] domestic payments between consumers. Western Union has teamed with Tencent's WeChat and Rakuten's Viber, two popular messaging apps, to facilitate crossborder transfers. PayPal is integrating the acquired Xoom, a Western Union foe, into its core app and seeks to extend its popular Venmo person-to-person and social message app to merchant payments.

Hyatt's profit and margins will be under pressure this year from slowing gains in revenue per available room, geopolitical risks, and weakening overall demand. It's increasing the pipeline of new properties through 2018, with strong [BLANK] brands like Hyatt Place and Hyatt House, to boost revenue growth. Revenue dropped 2% in 4Q as rates declined in Europe, the Middle East and Africa, and Southeast Asia. That offset an 8.4% increase for managed and franchised hotels, driven by openings and increased fees.

Former Petrobras executive Venina Fonseca may be the key to keeping investor cases against Petrobras alive. The court [BLANK] a large portion of a June 25 hearing on each side's interpretation of Fonseca's activities and whether they amounted to notifying former CEOs and the board of directors of irregularities in accounting. Corporate knowledge is a key element here. If the court credits the investors' presentation of Fonseca's actions, then it will likely allow the case to move forward.

Post-2Q Earnings Outlook: Wynn Palace's revenue and Ebitda growth should pick up this year while its flagship Cotai peninsula property undergoes hotel, retail and dining upgrades. Wynn must maintain its high-end appeal to keep pace with the competition for VIPs, as it's likely to generate the second-largest [BLANK] chip volume among Macau casinos this year. VIP volatility means Wynn must also cultivate its premium-mass client base to stabilize profit growth. The premium-mass segment is expanding with the East Cotai cluster development, including the new MGM Cotai. Wynn Palace's growth should get an added boost as it links to City of Dreams, and from the opening of SJM Cotai in late 2019. Wynn is expected to bid for a license in Japan, but faces intense competition from Caesars, Melco Resorts and Las Vegas Sands.

Reinsurers' earnings calls should shed some light on January's renewals and capital management, giving a clearer picture on pricing trends and their commitment to either writing more business or returning capital to shareholders. We believe Hannover Re is likely to [BLANK] a special dividend for 2017, while Swiss Re needs to give clarity on capital management.

A group of Baupost-led Westinghouse creditors who paid $2.16 billion for $7.6 billion of bankruptcy claims previously owned by Toshiba, Westinghouse's parent, is projected to receive as much as $3 billion on their claim. The transaction [BLANK] Westinghouse's path to winning approval of its Chapter 11 reorganization plan.

Units of Deutsche Bank, HSBC, U.S. Bancorp and other banks face multibillion-dollar lawsuits alleging they failed in their duties as mortgage-bond trustees. Suits by BlackRock, Pimco and other investors [BLANK] the trustees caused more than $280 billion in trust losses. In similar suits, the NCUA claims about $38 billion in losses, Royal Park alleges $13 billion, Phoenix Light claims about $2 billion, Commerzbank more than $1.5 billion and the FDIC $695 million. Many suits have survived dismissal bids.

Eli Lilly is unlikely to settle its Alimta patent dispute against Teva, now on appeal, after the court ruled a second time that Teva infringed Lilly's patent on a vitamin-dosing regimen. The Alimta litigation spans four other lawsuits against other generic-drug makers, which all [BLANK] to be bound by the Teva case decision. Teva's appeal of Lilly's earlier victory and the latest infringement decision are likely to extend into 2H16 before a final decision on appeal is issued.
