NRG's 14% drop in 2016 adjusted Ebitda from the Generation segment, which comprises its merchant portfolio, was countered by higher adjusted Ebitda across its other operating segments including NRG Yield. The company's diversfication into renewables and its hedging strategy helped [BLANK] weakness in the merchant power sector. NRG said merchant power will contribute to a further earnings decline in 2017, based on the forecast Ebitda range of $2.7-$2.9 billion vs. 2016 adjusted Ebitda of $3.26 billion.

Retail property deal volume and cap rates saw little movement in January, with overall cap rates flat at 6.6%. Shopping centers continued to [BLANK] at 6% for the third straight month, with volume down 12% from December. Yet mall cap rates rose 20 bps to 7.2%, on volume that was 29% lower than the prior month. Urban street retail saw the largest drop in cap rates in January, with properties trading at 4.5%, down 20 bps and the lowest level since at least 2000.

Card- and auto-loan gains are likely to keep slowing as banks tighten lending criteria and consumer demand slows due to rising leverage. While the jobless rate is low and consumer balance sheets are generally sound, the market has been [BLANK] in the late innings of a credit cycle, driving card lenders to low valuations. However, slower loan-growth should ease credit-provision expense increases as loss rates stabilize. Net interest margins should also remain wide. Card-network revenue will likely keep rising by double digits as payments shift away from cash and checks.

Facebook could confront damages of over $7 billion in a lawsuit over privacy rights and its face-recognition database. The suit may also undercut the social media company's bid to [BLANK] the sweeping database. Plaintiffs say they're suing on behalf of all Illinois residents that Facebook obtained face-scan details of while they lived in the state. The class may exceed 7 million people, based on user counts, and the law allows $1,000 a violation. Only Illinois, Texas and Connecticut have laws on the issue.

Kimberly-Clark plans to reward its shareholders by boosting dividends and increasing buybacks this year. With a 5.4% increase in the dividend per share and planned share repurchases of $800 million-$1 billion, the amount spent will [BLANK] the 2016 level ($2.1 billion). Supported by efficiency gains, cost-savings programs and commodity deflation, Kimberly's cash flow from operations increased 40% last year. While it may be hard to achieve the same savings this year, the company should raise dividends in the future.

American Realty Capital Properties (now VEREIT) investors suing the company and its underwriters over accounting errors got a boost in 2017 from a court ruling granting class status, as well as the criminal conviction of ARCP's former CFO. Investors may [BLANK] $3 billion, though settlement for much less is more likely.

Samsung and LG Electronics have launched virtual-reality cameras that could challenge GoPro's plans in the segment. Samsung's Gear 360 -- released in June -- can be [BLANK] to its latest smartphone, the Galaxy S7, for video editing and sharing. LG Electronics launched a 360-degree camera and a virtual-reality headset for consumers to create and view content. GoPro's solution requires six cameras and a spherical holder to create virtual-reality content.

Gazprom's proposed Nord Stream 2 pipeline faces numerous political hurdles despite advocacy from backers like former German chancellor Gerhard Schroeder. Shell, OMV and other European companies have provided financial support for the project, which faces potential delays if permits are [BLANK] for regulatory reasons.

Ctrip, a blip on the online-travel radar a decade ago, will keep narrowing its market-share gap with Expedia and Priceline owner Booking Holdings, in our view. As it basks in Asia-Pacific growth, its rivals face challenges in [BLANK] high bookings rates as competition intensifies and the pace in Europe and North America lags.

Digital will continue to solidify its position as the world's biggest ad platform. The medium that's mainly gained share at the expense of print is also expected to [BLANK] TV, taking the top spot in 2017 at $200 billion. Social media and mobile will make internet the fastest-growing ad platform, about 14% annually in 2015-18. Yet the market faces a duopoly in Google and Facebook. Google makes up a third of the digital ad market, with Facebook at 18-20%.

The 2018 box office is off to a good start thanks to Disney's "Star Wars: The Last Jedi" and Jumanji: Welcome to the Jungle. " Despite the headstart, due to fewer major releases, January likely won't [BLANK] last year's $958.6 million tally.

European gas (Gas Natural, Engie), nuclear and hydropower (EDF, Fortum) generators would like to see a higher carbon price boost power prices and squeeze coal generation out of Europe's power mix. Even as the cost of renewables continues to fall, the global coal-fired power fleet may only [BLANK] about a third by 2040, according to Poyry. BMI Research expects coal to dominate global electricity mix through 2025. Yet, western -- but not eastern -- Europe is likely to lead the way in coal-power closures.

Automakers' electric vehicle sales won't be blunted by the loss of a federal tax credit, which is retained in the final tax reform bill. The credit, worth as much as $7,500 per vehicle, was [BLANK] by the House bill passed Nov. 16. The Senate bill didn't do away with it. Tesla, GM and Nissan have sold the most EVs in the U.S. and are approaching the credit's 200,000 vehicle sales per automaker cap. Ford, Toyota, VW and others have plans to offer more EV models over the next few years.

Freddie Mac faces pressure from a Congress seeking to overhaul the government-sponsored enterprise (GSE) model to reduce housing finance risk borne by taxpayers. Several bills have proposed winding down Freddie and Fannie Mae by [BLANK] much of their mortgage securitization and guarantee business to the private sector. If there's any change this year, it's likely a limited approach from Republican Sen. Richard Shelby that would prevent Freddie's privatization and put the GSEs in Congress's control for later reform.

Deutsche Bank estimated in 2015 that regulation could increase its risk weighted assets (RWA) by more than $110 billion. With more capital required to offset this, bank ROE targets may become even harder to [BLANK], without further significant cost cuts. Regulatory expenses have increased for European banks by billions of dollars since 2009. The harmonization of risk weighted assets and requirements for increased operational RWA, to reflect litigation and management risk, will add yet more cost.

Wholesale power generators arguing to void a FERC rule may be more likely to succeed after the Supreme Court heard argument Oct. 14. Two justices -- Scalia and Kennedy -- appeared to support the lower court [BLANK] voiding the rule. Three justices -- Breyer, Sotomayor and Kagan -- seem to favor the rule. With Justice Alito recusing himself, the court could be split 4-4 if the other three justices fall along ideological lines. Such a split would leave the lower court decision nixing the rule in place.

Key EU economic measures against Russia won't be eased at least until 2019, following the extension of the technological measures until June 2019 and the ongoing economic sanctions until January 2019. Sanctions affect the availability of company funding and target individuals, yet after four years, their impact is likely now [BLANK].

Infrastructure and Project Finance leadership should benefit Scotiabank. Its Capital Markets business is the second-largest in Canada and has a global presence, [BLANK] a strong position in Latin America. Particular strengths are loan syndication and infrastructure finance. Stability in energy prices would support the bank's Power and Utility customers, playing into the business strength in the region. A rebound in fixed-income trading could continue benefiting the Capital Markets business.

Fannie and Freddie shareholders assert in an Iowa lawsuit that an amendment to the 2008 government bailout of the government-sponsored enterprises resulted in $130 billion of excess payments to the U.S. The shareholders seek to return to FHFA dividend payments made under the "net worth sweep" or [BLANK] the payments as a pay down of the Treasury's liquidation preference. The GSEs' pro forma balance of the senior preferred shares may be $151 billion less than book if the "net worth sweep" is vacated.

The Supreme Court upheld tax credits for purchasing health insurance on federal exchanges, helping 6.4 million Americans keep insurance. Hospitals were most affected, given they were [BLANK] off more than 30% of revenue before the Affordable Care Act was passed due to uninsured patients not paying bills. HCA has the most exposure to the exchanges at almost 5% of Ebitda vs. 3.4% on average for publicly traded hospitals. About 14 million Americans have acquired insurance since the ACA was implemented.

Ofcom's proposal for a wholesale price cap on 40 mbps broadband offers, with a path starting from 66.28 pounds in 2018 and declining to 52.77 pounds by 2020, could result in combined revenue losses of 376 million pounds ($470 million) for BT's Openreach through 2020. This is based on a scenario where non-BT fiber connections increase at 33% annually, last year's growth rate, starting in 2018, regardless of whether price caps are [BLANK].

Recent launches will accelerate growth of AstraZeneca's respiratory portfolio, which is showing signs of improvement. For the second quarter [BLANK], volume gains in 3Q, were almost on par GlaxoSmithKline's, albeit off a lower base. Glaxo has best-in-class combos that are helping reduce its exposure to generic Advair. These include Trelegy, which is off to a good start.

The prospective merger of PotashCorp and Agrium reduces the North American potash market to just two major producers, based on 2016 shipments. This [BLANK] regulatory risk for the transaction. PotashCorp-Agrium would control 47% of volume post-deal, followed by Mosaic, with 34% of the market. Either entity would have the potential to capture more. Smaller competitor Intrepid Potash shuttered its high-cost conventional potash capacity, reducing its share to 6% at most.

The S&P 500's P/E is breaking the "Rule of 20," but strong EPS estimate revisions could ease concerns. Bottom-up estimates likely [BLANK] to fully incorporate the new U.S. corporate tax rate. The financials sector kicks off an earnings season focused on taxes. Watch for revisions in European industrials and financials.

Bristol-Myers Squibb and Merck are pushing the use of Opdivo, Yervoy and Keytruda in the neoadjuvant and adjuvant treatment of advanced and metastatic melanoma patients who are at high risk of relapsing. Bristol-Myers is [BLANK] Opdivo vs. Yervoy as adjuvant options in the Phase III CheckMate-238 and Opdivo plus Yervoy as an neoadjuvant regimen in a Phase II trial. Merck is evaluating Keytruda vs. placebo as adjuvant therapy in the Phase III Keynote-054.

Video-game makers may continue a long-term trend of outperforming benchmark indexes amid the prospect for sustained strong sales and earnings growth and margin expansion. Multiples are rising as game makers increase their share of revenue from recurring sources, reducing the hit-driven risk [BLANK] with large game launches.

Alibaba widened its dominant position in Chinese e-commerce by grabbing 57.3% of business-to-consumer spending in 2Q, or 670 bps higher sequentially, according to IResearch, even as rivals launch unique promotional events. JD.com's 6.18 promotion, which [BLANK] several discounts, significantly boosted user metrics, though the company's market share declined 210 bps to 21.2%. Amazon dropped out of the top five, surpassed by electronics retailer Gome.

It's unclear if the largest U.S. retailers will enable Apple Pay or Android Pay in 2016. Mobile wallets have improved payment data security by [BLANK] card numbers from transactions, but they also don't capture data that might be valuable for targeted marketing. Like Apple Pay, Android Pay only works with newer smartphones and requires the retailer to have an updated terminal that accepts "tap to pay." Chase is the only major card issuer not yet enabling Android Pay.

Molycorp will request court approval on Dec. 18 of the disclosure statement for its Oaktree-backed plan of reorganization and proposed bidding procedures. The official unsecured creditors committee and an ad hoc group of secured noteholders are likely to [BLANK] both motions and seek to terminate the debtors' plan exclusivity period so they can file a competing proposal. The objectors are likely to argue Molycorp's plan won't attract the best bids and will disadvantage other creditors beside Oaktree.

Seema Verma, administrator of the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services, has Medicaid-overhaul experience in Indiana that may serve as a model for other states. Republicans are looking to reform the program as part of their Obamacare-repeal legislation, and President Donald Trump also [BLANK] cuts in his fiscal 2018 budget proposal. Verma toed the party line and expressed support for the Part D prescription-drug program that incorporates private plans during her Senate confirmation hearings.

North America-originated commodity carloads fell 9.1% in the week ended July 23 (week 29) vs. a year earlier, based on AAR data. Norfolk Southern's carloads [BLANK] 9.9%, driven by a 25% decline in automotive and 19% drop in coal volumes. Norfolk's auto volumes may suffer in 2H amid challenging comparisons, competitive losses and plant-specific outages, as certain manufacturers retool. Persistently high stockpiles may push its utility coal carloads 36% lower in 3Q, while export coal might fall 21%.

Relative North American spot trucking demand fell 5.1% sequentially to 35.2 in the week ended June 16, as measured by Truckstop.com's Market Demand Index after demand surged 29% a week ago from truckers parking the tractors to avoid annual roadside inspections. Capacity loosened as the number of available loads [BLANK] 0.8%, while truck availability increased 4.5%. Despite looser capacity, flatbed drove the average spot rate 1% higher. Fuel surcharges fell 2.2%, the largest sequential decline this year.

Sabine Oil & Gas will seek approval of its bankruptcy reorganization plan on June 13. The company has [BLANK] threats of creditor lawsuits and prevailed in a fight over rejecting midstream contracts, yet unsecured creditors are likely to object to the plan. Bankruptcy Judge Shelley Chapman denied creditor standing to sue on claims related to Sabine's ill-fated merger and also granted Sabine's motion to reject gathering agreements. Mediation begins June 3 concerning the plan.

Bernie Sanders' "Medicare for All" single-payer health plan has no chance of passage near term. However, the proposal --which would be catastrophic for hospitals and health insurers -- may [BLANK] politically important as a marker for Democrats seeking the party's nomination for president in 2020. Co-sponsors thus far include Kirsten Gillibrand of New York, Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts and Cory Booker of New Jersey.

The expected patent claims interpretation order from the court in Teva's lawsuit over Treanda copies could favor the generic-drug makers. Teva [BLANK] at the April hearing that its patents in the lawsuit broadly cover multiple forms of bendamustine, Treanda's active ingredient. The generic-drug maker defendants have argued in court filings that Teva's patents cover only two specific forms identified by the X-ray defraction patterns, leaving their forms of bendamustine unprotected by Teva's patents.

New multimillion-dollar transportation projects probably will advance as a result of a final infrastructure bill signed into law Dec. 4. The U.S. will [BLANK] about $230 billion over five years to states to spend on highway and local road projects, in addition to about $50 billion for public transit. The bill may also improve trucker operating ratios by dedicating funds to cut congestion on high-capacity roads. It also eases a rail regulation that railroads argue is expensive and isn't proven to boost safety.

Xinjiang's primary aluminum output jumped 73% in the first 11 months of 2014 to 3.77 million metric tons, accounting for 17% of China's production. The boom, spurred by new low-cost smelters at captive power plants, is [BLANK] the nation's oversupply. Xinjiang's output may increase further in 2015 assuming new capacity meets the target for the end of the 12th Five-Year Plan. That could further depress aluminum prices and squeeze out high-cost smelters.

Prudential Plc's Asia new business profit rose 22% in 1Q assuming constant exchange rates, vs. 24% growth for AIA, which competes in the same key markets of Hong Kong, Singapore and China. Prudential's annualized new premiums in Hong Kong [BLANK] 74% as agency sales expanded, helped by strong demand for dollar-policies from mainland clients. China's annualized new premiums rose 37%. New business profit rose 2% in Singapore, despite a 19% drop in ANP due to a high base and the end of some bancassurance relationships.

UnitedHealth's Optum may have an edge in predictive analytics, given it has 20 years of claims history for 170 million patients and is experienced in the health-care industry with a focus on services. Optum has helped some hospitals reduce readmissions up to 10% while [BLANK] costs up to $20 a month for insurers through its analytics and coordinated care programs. As Medicare shifts reimbursement to value-based arrangements, hospitals need to cut costs and reduce readmissions to avoid penalties.

Biotech and pharmaceutical events include longer-term data of Spark's gene therapy for inherited retinal dystrophies and Anthera's first Phase III data in systemic lupus erythematosus. Phase II data of Aurinia's AURA trial in lupus nephritis and Retrophin-Ligand's sparsentan in focal segmental glomerulosclerosis are [BLANK]. Galapagos-AbbVie await Phase II data in cystic fibrosis. FDA actions (PDUFA dates) are expected for Aralez's Yosprala, Lexicon-Ipsen's telotristat and Cempra's solithromycin.

The European Commission's plan to abolish retail roaming charges in the EU is reaching the final stages after a political agreement on wholesale roaming price caps in February. Once the European Parliament [BLANK] the agreement, the roaming elimination will be applicable by July 15. While roaming drag on revenue is expected to be at least 1% this year, the impact on Ebitda may be mitigated due to prevailing low wholesale data prices. The EU agreement sets up a steep decline in wholesale price caps.

Delta favored Latin America expansion in 2014, yet plans to slow 2015 growth to low-single digits even as Brazil capacity is cut 15% in 4Q. This focus [BLANK] amid lower yields, which fell 7% in 2Q, given Asia fares have suffered on unrelentingly strong growth by Asian carriers. Delta may see room to expand since overall Latin America yields are higher than the Pacific. Delta's, at 12.99 cents, compare well with American's 16.5 cents, allowing market-share gain. Delta's Latin American capacity rose 8% during 2Q.

Average truckload spot rates per mile, including fuel surcharges, decreased 1.1% to $2.14 in the week ended May 29, according to Internet Truckstop. Rates for reefer (down 7.1% to $2.30) and dry-van (4.6% lower to $1.97) equipment types drove the decline, while specialized rates [BLANK] 5.2% to $2.69. A 36% drop in fuel surcharges has driven total spot rates about 9.3% lower vs. a year ago. Spot rates excluding surcharges decreased about 1%, weaker than the 3% to 5% gain expected for contractual rates.

Snap may see an increase in its shares floated on the public market after the expiration of its lock-up period, which is likely to occur 150 days after its IPO, based on company filings. GoPro [BLANK] its equity float increase 228% from its IPO three months after the lockup ended on its secondary offering. Fitbit saw its float rise 267% in the corresponding period after its IPO. Snap also aims to have some investors commit to a one-year lock-up, although it has no binding commitments, based on filings.

Gilead's lobbying spending more than doubled to $3 million in 2014-15, vs. $1.3 million in 2009 when hepatitis C (HCV) wasn't a near-market stage interest. The jump goes in-line with the increasing number of HCV-related references in lobbying reports [BLANK] from 2009-16. Given that Gilead leads the industry, this may set $1.5 million as the upper limit to what rivals may spend. But a significantly higher mention of HCV in 2015 and 1H suggests Gilead may have reallocated funds to maximize HCV efforts.

Cloud infrastructure companies from Microsoft to Amazon are boosting their security portfolios by adding new functionalities such as identity management and advanced analytics to detect malicious code in network traffic. Amazon is offering a security service, Amazon Inspector, that [BLANK] a customer's applications running on its cloud. Additionally, these companies are also offering products of other security software companies from Barracuda to Fortinet in conjunction with their cloud services.

ARM's sales may continue to increase amid the proliferation of its architecture across chips in servers, handsets and Internet of Things devices. A slowdown in smartphone sales will disproportionately [BLANK] growth in the near term as the size of this market is unlikely to be offset by growth in areas such as networking equipment, servers or microcontrollers. License growth, a measure of the rising use of its architecture, may be 5% to 10% a year. Royalties, a lagging indicator of chips using ARM, rose 31% in 1Q.

AstraZeneca's lawsuit over Onglyza and Kombiglyze generics is down to one patent expiring in 2023. It's the only remaining patent [BLANK] the drug pair and is separately being challenged in inter partes reviews. An adverse decision at the patent office could lead to generic-drug makers launching copies of both diabetes treatments as early as 2H after the decision of the U.S. Patent Office, or as late as 2023, if the office upholds the patent as the court did.

Improved U.S. chemicals demand has helped drive global chemicals companies' earnings guidance since 2014. This [BLANK] in-line with the Markit Flash Manufacturing PMI index rising to 55.3 in March, above the median analyst estimate of 54.6, from 55.1 in February. While lower oil has squeezed local producers' margin advantage, U.S. volume growth supports plant utilization globally. U.S. oil and gas remains a weak spot, said index respondents, which poses more challenges for specialty chemicals and industrial gases.

Hollywood was hit hard again by franchise fatigue and a lack of strong films as summer receipts plummeted 15% from last year, for the season's worst result in 11 years. This was surprising, especially after 1Q receipts set a record, [BLANK] 4.6% year-over-year. Still, superhero movies delivered, claiming the season's top spots.

Netflix may spend about $2 billion on original shows in 2017, or almost a third of its $6 billion content budget, as it aims to retain subscribers and lure new ones. The service plans to [BLANK] the number of original series, releasing at least 1,000 hours of original programming vs. 600. Netflix has evolved from a distributor of older, licensed content to a destination for originals as it competes with established TV networks. Ultimately, Netflix's aim is to have half its content be original.

Political and regulatory risk to Wells Fargo remains limited to news headlines, increased compliance costs and more regulatory scrutiny after bank scandals and "a one year later" hearing on Capitol Hill. Regulators, including the Federal Reserve Board, the San Francisco Fed and New York Department of Financial Services, will likely increase their examination authority, which may [BLANK] to enforcement actions. Yet drastic moves, such as firing board members or impacting the bank's capital review are unlikely.

The rate of electricity consumption growth in China until 2020 is hazy. Planners may [BLANK] it difficult to gauge the level of the recovery of industrial demand. Forecasts range from 3-5% CAGR. The lower that number is, the longer it will take for coal-power utilization rates to recover. The low rate has hurt generators' profitability. Demand rose 5% in 2016, perhaps due to 2015's low base, when it was up by less than 1%. It increased 6.4% in the five months through May, but the pace may slow in 2H.

Micron shares have risen 9% since the beginning of June amid a third week of gains in DRAM spot prices. Contract pricing hasn't seen any increase, yet declines have [BLANK] over the period. Even amid attempts to diversify from PC DRAM, Micron still has significant exposure, and any improvement in pricing may help offset persistent weakness in PC unit demand. Pricing weakness in PC DRAM has spilled over into server and mobile DRAM, despite content growth in these products.

Unstable U.S. output, along with narrow WTI-Brent spreads, will likely invite incremental imports, suppressing much-needed stockpile drawdowns and further stressing U.S. benchmarks. Seaborne prices may remain rangebound as concerns of global balances persist, and restrained Brent prices [BLANK] Atlantic Basin imports. Overall import flows were down for the week ended Oct. 2, yet Middle East blends will continue to regain share given price discounts. Refining margins will keep tightening on seasonal maintenance.

The U.S. Justice Department and the Securities and Exchange Commission may expand the available defenses for companies accused of violating the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act. U.S companies and those [BLANK] on U.S. exchanges can already decrease penalties by fully cooperating with enforcement agencies, though this rarely gets them entirely off the hook. Under the Trump administration, the agencies may narrow FCPA enforcement by expanding these defenses. This could give businesses more certainty.

Even with weak 1Q demand, chipmakers have posted strong performances in 2015, with forward P/E at its highest level since early 2013, likely driven by M&A activity. Mobile chipmakers' sales have [BLANK] from flagship product releases and 4G LTE transition, even amid slowing price growth. Increasing data-center server demand may be helping offset weakness in PCs, which represent more than 30% of the chip market. Auto and industrial content is rising, and memory makers have turned to development amid weak pricing.

Samsung forecast greater competition in the Ultra HD and large-size TV market this quarter as companies step up promotions for the peak year-end sales period. That could [BLANK] to lower prices and thinner margins for TV makers. Samsung, Sony and LG are all targeting premium sets to boost sales and profits. Sony has cut its full-year TV shipment target as it focuses on profitability over sales.

The net number of banks seeing stronger business-loan demand decreased across customer sizes in the April Federal Reserve Senior Loan Officer Survey, with a flat reading for large customers the lowest since 4Q09. Large banks [BLANK] weaker demand for the first time since October 2013, with a relatively worse reading for larger borrowers. Increased receivable financing, along with plant and equipment investing were cited across banks as key demand drivers. M&A was most cited by large banks.

Banco do Brasil's below-10% phase-in Core Tier 1 capital ratio puts it at a significant disadvantage to private peers such as Itau and Bradesco that are better placed to fund loan growth in 2017. Key to boosting solvency levels will be the disposal of the non-core units, with the lender [BLANK] a sale of its 59% stake in Argentine bank Banco Patagonia. Falling loan-loss provisions, with management projecting a double-digit decline, should also boost organic-capital generation this year.

Compact, mid-size and large cars, along with large pickup trucks, carried the highest U.S. incentives relative to transaction prices in August. The incentive ratio for large cars was 11.8%, [BLANK] with 7.6% for the industry. The three non-luxury car segments all ran the most aggressive deals in more than a year as affordability draws buyers to luxury segments. All six luxury car and truck segments carried an incentive ratio below the industry average in August.

Unilever, Danone and Nestle may get the biggest boost of the EU packaged-food peers from global population growth, given they have built up the greatest sales exposure in emerging markets. The population is expected to rise one-third from 2014-50, [BLANK] to 9.6 billion from 7.2 billion, according to the United Nations. This is an annual growth rate of 0.8%. The U.S. Census Bureau highlights an annual population growth rate to 2025 of 2.1% in Africa, 1.4% in the Middle East and 0.9% in Asia and Latin America.

China metal firms are seeking to acquire mining assets abroad to stabilize the supply of raw materials. Valuations are competitive [BLANK] with the previous overseas M&A boom in 2008. China Molybdenum bought Freeport-McMoRan's stake in the Tenke copper-cobalt mine in the Democratic Republic of Congo in November. China Molybdenum, formerly a pure molybdenum-tungsten producer, has been diversifying its asset portfolio with other metals since its 2013 acquisition of Australia's Northparkes copper mine.

Huaneng Power said gas-fired plants will make up 49% of the 8,380 megawatts of capacity it plans to add this year and next. Other Chinese generators, such as Huadian, CR Power and Datang, are also adding gas plants to [BLANK] emissions, even though generating costs are more than double coal-fired plants. Huaneng's plans also include 36% from coal plants, and 15% from wind, hydro and other renewables. Gas plants' output costs $71.58 per megawatt hour vs. $32.30 for coal.

North American sales of large farm machinery increased across most categories in January after posting mixed results in December. Combines [BLANK] a modest decline after healthy sales growth throughout 2017, ending a streak of 11 consecutive months of increases. Inventories of large two-wheel-drive tractors show signs of stabilization.

Eastern European trade with Russia rose 65% from 2009 to 2013 when it totaled $95 billion (7% of the region's GDP). With Russian GDP forecast to slow to 0.25% this year, the lowest since 2009, trade disruption from [BLANK] and new sanctions could derail recovery in Eastern Europe. Customer-care challenges drove the decline in Commercial segment margins, which are significantly below Healthcare/Public Sector. Conduent is enacting profit improvement initiatives, including renegotiating contracts, to [BLANK] losses and establish a new operating framework. Should a U.S.-North Korea rapprochement occur, it won't mean lower defense budgets at home. There is also a readiness deficit, as training suffered under smaller budgets and the focus on wars in Iraq and Afghanistan.

Chinese independent refiners' throughput from domestic oil production fell 36.96% in the first five months, and may continue to drop this year on oil majors' production declines. Refining throughput from Cnooc's offshore oil production accounts for 84.65% of independent refiners' total domestic oil source, thanks to their proximity to Bohai Bay, one of China's major offshore oil [BLANK] areas. Offshore oil throughput fell 33.65%, less than the 48.08% decline from oil processed at Sinopec's Shengli oilfield.

The oil and gas fleet is shrinking and backlog dwindling on weak oil prices and less capital spending by oil majors. The peak was 1,940 aircraft in service in June 2015, just more than six months after the price of oil [BLANK] to about $60 a barrel from almost $100. Since the top, the fleet decreased by nearly 300 aircraft. Airbus absorbed much of the blow for Leonardo and Sikorsky, as the H225 Super Puma fell out of favor after a fatal accident in Norway in April 2016 and the subsequent grounding of the fleet by Norwegian and U.K. authorities. Leonardo has picked up market share since with its very popular AW139 and sister copters the AW189 and AW169 and now matches Airbus market share at 22%. Share of more than 30-year old helicopters in oil and gas service increased to 14% from 6% in 15 years, with Bell highest at 25%.

Sales at family apparel stores grew by 2.2% yoy in August, a 210-bp acceleration from the 0.1% gain at midmonth. Traffic rose 2.8%, though average amount spent [BLANK] 60 bps, according to First Data. This may bode well for retailers H&M, Zara and Uniqlo, especially ahead of back-to-school and with college resuming. Gap was likely an outlier, given that it reported weak August sales, down 2%, due in part to merchandise missteps, with sales worst (down 6%) at its namesake brand.

One of the major drivers of pay-TV M&A has been the need to build scale to reduce rising content costs. Average monthly costs for a DirecTV customer are $17 lower than U-verse, which may [BLANK] annual savings of about $1.1 billion at AT&T for 5.6 million U-Verse clients. Charter may save over $8 a month per customer, giving it more than $460 million annually for 4.4 million subscribers. Ultimately, both AT&T and Charter may be able to drive down rates even further, given their combined 43 million customers.

Church & Dwight could carry out more deals to reach its long-term target of 20 power brands, up from 11 after the $1 billion acquisition of Water Pik. The company has a strong balance sheet and robust cash-flow -- its 5% free cash-flow yield [BLANK] the peer average -- as well as potential proceeds from selling non-core brands.

The average spread between the Stoxx Europe 600 Utilities Index dividend yield and government bond yields approached a 10-year high in 2015. The short-lived rally in bond yields, which [BLANK] from concern about mounting Greek sovereign debt, has reversed amid deflation and the potential for continued ECB stimulus measures. In contrast, generators' dividend yields have stabilized, as the pace of decline in power prices slowed and signs emerged of increased demand for energy in parts of Europe.

European stocks should be able to move higher in 2018-19 despite the old adage: "Don't fight the Fed...or ECB." Yes, equities [BLANK] a risk as monetary policy tightens, especially on valuation. But the earnings phase of the market should prevail, even as yields rise modestly, unless trade tensions stifle the global expansion.

BlackRock litigation includes defending against excessive-fee lawsuits and pursuing cases against RMBS trustees. Advisory units of the company are favored to [BLANK] investors' excessive-fee suits, with about $1.5 billion at stake. BlackRock funds have filed several suits against RMBS trustees Bank of New York Mellon, Citibank, Deutsche Bank, HSBC, U.S. Bank and Wells Fargo, seeking billions of dollars in total for RMBS investors. So far, the trustees mostly have the momentum.

European airlines increased Asia-Pacific capacity 7% in 2Q, the most of international regions, likely pressuring fares due to strong competition from expanding Chinese and Middle-Eastern airlines. Turkish Air and IAG [BLANK] the most. IAG's expansion seemed well received on 6% capacity growth as load factors rose 240 bps to 81. Turkish Air load factors fell to the mid-70s on double-digit growth. Air France growth was minimal as the carrier manages weakness into Japan, its largest market in the region.

Tyson and other poultry processors accused of colluding to control broiler-chicken prices may get a 4Q court date to argue their motions to dismiss the lawsuit. Purchasers [BLANK] that a conspiracy to limit output since 2008 artificially inflated prices. Defendants counter that the complaint is bereft of evidence of an agreement, and that output increased during that period. No date has been set for oral arguments on the motion, but briefing was done in April and the case has thus far proceeded with little delay.

Powder River Basin coal has made inroads into northern Asian markets, notably South Korea, while test shipments made their way into Japan earlier in the year. Cloud Peak Energy's recent acquisition of Westmoreland's Westshore capacity indicates that management is confident growth can come from [BLANK] to Asia. At current prices, PRB coal seemingly can compete with other suppliers, though little appears to be left over for producers after costs.

Celgene's filing of a patent-infringement lawsuit blocks any FDA approval of Lannett's marketing application for generic Thalomid for 30 months, until June 2017. Lannett must [BLANK] to the complaint by Feb. 23. Celgene asserts 11 patents listed in the FDA Orange Book expiring from 2017 to 2023, including U.S. Patent 7,230,012, which claims the drug product. That patent expires in 2023. Thalomid is used to treat patients with leprosy and multiple myeloma.

BP's latest salvo in an $18 billion battle over potential Clean Water Act fines could reduce its penalties by $5.5 billion, though it's a legal longshot. BP [BLANK] that the fines are illegally inflated, and the proposed maximum should be reduced to $3,000 per barrel of oil spilled, from $4,300. The court, already displeased with BP trying to unwind a settlement, is unlikely to grant its request, as that would open up a broader challenge to government agencies' authority to increase statutory penalties.

KDDI's mobile unit has improved average revenue per user since 2012, selling more data and value-added services via its 4G network. The services [BLANK] flat-rate, unlimited access to videos on mobile and online-to-offline business. NTT Docomo's ARPU has recovered with its new family bundled packages yielding higher data consumption in the past three quarters. The ARPU for SoftBank's mobile business has been rising year-over-year on increasing smartphone users and data consumption.

Performance attribution for emerging market local currency debt funds is primarily a function of country exposure, given the disparity between government bond returns in 2017. Among EM hard currency bond funds, sovereign returns are [BLANK] to credit quality while corporate returns are largely sector-driven, with commodity issuers outperforming.

The trend favoring highly franchised restaurant chains offers stable cash flow to investors, though it may make the implementation of progressive technology and customer analytics more difficult. This could present long-term challenges for chains including Burger King, McDonald's Wendy's, Popeye's, Jamba Juice, DineEquity and Denny's, which have to [BLANK] franchisees to pay for the upgrades. Unifying franchisee opinions can take time, giving chains that are primarily company-owned an advantage.

Rising trade tensions between the U.S. and China could hamper box office quota negotiations, and in turn, slow Hollywood's growth prospects in the region. Currently, the U.S. box office is [BLANK] to showcase about 34 movies in China, of which 20 are regular titles and 14 in IMAX or 3D format. That has helped the Chinese box office reach $7.9 billion in 2017, 20% of the global total. Hollywood studios are hoping to increase the number of films allowed in China, and improve the 25% revenue share split, which is low by world standards.

Capital One, Discover and AmEx have been adding to card-loan loss reserves, due largely to loan growth, but also on the expectation that loss rates will rise from all-time lows. JPMorgan Chase and BofA have [BLANK] card reserves flat as loans remained unchanged. Citigroup has continued to release significant card reserves. But the return of loan growth in 1H could signal that Citi's reserve releases, which aid earnings, will turn to builds. Citigroup's global card business was 26% of 2015 net revenue.

Statoil's exploration results at its Korpfjell wildcat well in the southeastern Barents Sea were disappointing. It encountered an [BLANK] uncommercial quantity of 6-12 billion cubic meters of gas in the primary reservoir target. Korpfjell may have been Europe's most anticipated exploration well of 2017 as seismic imaging suggested a super-giant, multi-billion barrel prospect. Pre-drill estimates were for its structural closure to be 3-4x the size of Johan Sverdrup, Norway's fifth-largest discovery.

October has been a mixed bag for investment grade corporates thus far, with Treasury yields helping last week, though pressuring total returns month-to-date. A heavy calendar of earnings, including many industrials, will add insight into whether trade might [BLANK] into corporate margin pressures. Macau casinos generated 50% of July table revenue from the mass-market segment, steadily rising from 26% in 2011, as operators strategically focus on the more profitable mainstream gambler. The possibility of mass-market revenue contribution topping 50% could help fuel a gambling recovery in 2H and offset declines and volatility in the VIP business.

The oil and natural-gas services industry is set to release 3Q earnings starting Oct. 16, with Baker Hughes and Schlumberger first to report. Consensus [BLANK] for a median 12% increase in sales from a year earlier, a 19% jump in Ebitda and a 17% gain in earnings per share. Among diversified servicers, Calfrac (up 61%) and C&J Energy Services (up 57%) may post the highest sales increases. Among capital-equipment providers, Flotek sales may rise 16% and Oceaneering's 17%.

Raising the bar for designating banks as systemically important financial institutions (SIFIs) is a top policy priority for Regions Financial. Regions could shed SIFI status -- and the tougher capital rules and oversight that come with it-- if Congress [BLANK] the threshold above the company's $126 billion in assets. The U.K. is likely to be the first EU country to produce commercial shale gas on a large scale. The government [BLANK] the U.K. to become more self-sufficient in meeting its energy needs by increasing domestic production from unconventional sources such as shale. A bidding round for exploration permits for much of the U.K.'s onshore acreage was staged in late 2014. The licensees are likely to be announced after the general elections in May. After that, more onshore drilling is likely.

Snap's IPO comes on the heels of successes and missteps of "hot internet startups" namely Twitter, Facebook and LinkedIn. Twitter's lost market cap may teach Snap to [BLANK] on its own strengths and emphasize metrics that it can improve over time. It can be challenging to get approvals for large electric transmission projects that involve joining 50-150 foot towers installed over many miles, but once the approvals are made and construction begins, the projects can pay off many times over. Transmission owners usually start booking profit as soon as construction begins, based on authorized returns on equity that [BLANK] 11% for many projects. Once the transmission project is completed, returns are based on formula rates and a forward test year.

The outlook may be gloomy for Hong Kong stocks, but the city is a growth market for China's brokerage upstarts. Hong Kong-listed brokers face stiff competition from global players like JPMorgan and UBS, and low stock volumes [BLANK] brokerage income. Hong Kong Exchanges' settlement fees also hurt profits. Nevertheless, Chinese brokers in Hong Kong are in expansion mode, and more M&A involving city brokers is possible this year. They're scrambling for enduring investment flows from the mainland to the offshore city.

Chinese aluminum smelters have responded to an Indonesian ban on bauxite exports by turning to new suppliers, building alumina refineries overseas and importing alumina. Indonesia [BLANK] 68% of China's bauxite imports in 2013. That share fell last year to 24%, primarily consisting of shipments delayed from 2013. Imports from Malaysia have jumped as Chinese companies switched sourcing countries. More bauxite imports from Africa are expected once China's overseas projects start.

International markets provide opportunities for colocation providers to continue expanding due to their bigger size and growth that may [BLANK] a year beyond projections for the U.S. market Still, $32 billion in overseas spending may be difficult to exploit in some markets without partnerships due to a more localized focus.

Infosys is losing share of the revenue generated by major offshore IT services companies, which rose 13% annually from 2012 through 2014, according to IDC. Infosys [BLANK] less than 20% of the $39.6 billion in total sales -- the sum of revenue from Infosys, Tata Consultancy, Cognizant, Wipro and HCL Technologies -- in 2014, down from 21.1% in 2012. Compound annual growth of 9% for Infosys during the period trailed every peer except Wipro, underscoring the challenges for new CEO Vishal Sikka.

Singapore insurers may see new health-insurance premiums continue to decline in 2H following a 34% drop in 1H, life insurance association data show. This is probably because citizens are [BLANK] the November release of MediShield Life, the new national health scheme. This plan is a baseline component of the broader private Integrated Shield Plans (IPs), and will offer enhanced benefits and expanded coverage to those with pre-existing conditions. The IPs made up 87% of new health-premiums in 1H vs. 92% a year ago.

Biotech and pharma events in immuno-oncology include FDA action on Roche's atezolizumab in bladder and lung cancer. Merck and Bristol-Myers [BLANK] Phase III data in first-line lung cancer. Incyte expects data of epacadostat combined with PD-1/L1 that may lead to a Phase III start. Inovio seeks FDA advice on Phase III design of a cervical-cancer therapeutic vaccine. Pivotal data are expected from Novartis, Juno and Kite's CAR-T therapies for leukemia and lymphoma. Click the image for a full calendar.

BCA's return on equity is second only to Bank Rakyat among large-cap Asian lenders over the past 5 years. This is [BLANK] by its strong focus on asset quality and a solid deposit base thanks to its transaction-banking business. While return on assets have been robust, return on equity has tapered. Consensus expects ROE to fall over 2016-18 to 18.3% from 21.9% in 2015, primarily on higher capital retention, as banks prepare for higher capital requirements under Basel III.

Hospital operators may see significant near-term disruption as President Donald Trump, HHS Secretary Alex Azar and CMS head Seema Verma try to focus the U.S. health-policy debate on increased price transparency. Senate Republicans struggled to [BLANK] key Obamacare provisions and convert Medicaid into a per-capita cap program during 2017, though another attempt is possible in 2018, ahead of the November midterm elections. Such plans risk increasing the number of uninsured Americans in the near-term during a transition period, thus pressuring hospital operators' profit margins.

Carbon Black's growth has been aided by the ineffectiveness of antivirus software in dealing with new types of security attacks. The company's non-signature-based approach that relies on [BLANK] and analyzing large amounts of data is driving adoption over legacy incumbent endpoint vendors such as Symantec and McAfee.

The low anti-subsidy and anti-dumping estimates applied to corrosion-resistant steel imports from South Korea and India, relative to those on China, can be partly attributed to a Commerce Department methodology for non-market economies. While the agency typically uses in-country pricing and subsidy data to set rates, it [BLANK] to third-country data for non-market economies. This method consistently results in higher rates on China, which says its non-market economy status should expire in December 2016.

Merck KGaA's MSB0010718C drug for a rare form of skin cancer may be ahead of Merck & Co.'s Keytruda, the only other PD-1/L1 therapy being developed for this disease, based on estimated trial completion dates on ClinicalTrials.gov. The Merck KGaA drug is also being [BLANK] in lung cancer. With Phase I trials under way, its development trails Roche's MPDL3280A and AstraZeneca's MEDI4736 which are in phase III trials. Like Merck's MSB0010718C, both drugs are IgG1's monoclonal antibodies which target PD-L1.

Acorda may be a tough pill to swallow for most suitors, given impending generic competition for best-selling drug Amprya due midyear. This [BLANK] much of its valuation is wrapped up in stalled Parkinson's disease hopeful Inbrija. Any potential acquirer is likely to have an established CNS sales force to bank on synergies or have faith in a risky pipeline.

Increased volatility is making the European natural gas and electricity markets more interesting for traders. Overall, EU wholesale energy prices have [BLANK] steadily since 2011. The global commodity rally earlier this year, along with EU power and gas outages and intermittent wind-power generation, introduced price volatility prized by traders. Higher energy prices may boost unit margins for Fortum, EDF, Centrica, Engie, Gazprom and other companies with unhedged power and gas output.

Statoil may be hard pushed to add sufficient gas reserves in Norway and remain a key gas supplier to Europe when its giant Johan Sverdrup field starts up in 2019, tilting the company's output toward oil. At present, the company's output is roughly equally [BLANK] between both oil and gas. For gas, the only main field startup will be the delayed Aasta Hansteen development in late 2018. Growth in output in Norway will primarily come from the Barents Sea, where most discoveries are oil.

Consensus estimates fell for all six public Class I rails in the past four weeks, sliding 3.8% on average. EPS expectations [BLANK] the most for Union Pacific (off 5.1%) amid a 5.7% decline in total 2Q traffic. Canadian Pacific estimates were revised 4.4% lower, though EPS is still expected to rise 21%, aided by efficiency and yield gains, as well as the stronger U.S. dollar. Analysts typically finalize their EPS estimates after AAR releases full-quarter traffic data, which is scheduled for July 8.

Shire and generic-drug makers will appear before the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit on May 6 to argue over the generic makers proposed copycat versions of Vyvanse and whether the lower court's ruling in favor of Shire should stand. The parties [BLANK] briefing the court on March 9 in preparation for oral arguments. The lower court ruled in June that several of Shire's patents covering Vyvanse were valid and that the proposed generic Vyvanse copies infringe those patents.

Antitrust scrutiny of Visa and MasterCard include regulatory investigations, and both face possible EU fines for competition law violations. The European Commission, the EU's executive arm, preliminarily [BLANK] that certain swipe fees and and acquiring rules of the card companies are problematic. MasterCard disputed the findings in a 2Q submission. Visa has resolved some of the commission's concerns with commitments. The U.S. Justice Department is also probing Visa's competitive responses to the Dodd-Frank Act.

Chinese palladium imports are up 30% vs. the prior year, suggesting an end to levels that were subdued as auto production surged. Through 2012 and 2013 imports were well below 2009-11 levels, while auto production [BLANK] 20%. The rebound may suggest that domestic supplies, which reduced imports, are depleting, and will strengthen the effect of China's growing auto industry on palladium demand. Palladium is a key element in making catalytic converters.

Legacy retailers are playing catch-up in technology, especially in e-commerce, mobile and supply-chain management. Increased investments are essential to remaining in the game vs. online rivals, and the options offered will need to [BLANK] or be close to Amazon's same-day delivery capabilities. Differentiation will come from greater personalization and prioritizing customer experience. Expedited shipping and the ability to shop on mobile and online will be table stakes for the industry.

Department stores must evolve or shrink as consumers shop online and spend on experiences over material goods. Comparable sales in December were the weakest among 12 [BLANK] sectors, falling 6.6%, largely on an 8.8% decline in traffic, according to First Data. Average amount spent grew 2.4%, indicating margins may fare better from leaner inventory. Negative earnings pre-announcements at Macy's and Kohl's reflect a weak sales trend and elevate concern over the longer-term viability of department stores.

Citigroup tripled its dividend to a 1.5% indicated yield, exceeding consensus, with a $8.6 billion buyback, in-line with estimates. CEO Michael Corbat indicated June 2 the bank would [BLANK] the importance of dividends for certain investors types. With its stock trading below tangible book, ambivalent investors likely prefer more buybacks. Buybacks are 80-90% of the bank's total $10.5 billion estimated payout, similar to last year. Higher capital ratios and lower legacy costs may support further boosts.

Trucking volumes continue to rise, albeit at a tepid pace, on the heels of the sluggish U.S. economy. FTR forecasts truck loadings to increase 2.2% this year, [BLANK] expected GDP growth of 1.5%. Loading growth has decelerated since the 3.9% increase in 2014. This year it's expected to be buoyed by flatbed (up 6.9%), followed by dry-van (1.9%) and reefer (1.8%). Dry-van loads are the largest part of the truckload market at 36%, FTR data show, and typically move with GDP growth and consumer confidence.

Industrials supply the mining sector with products that facilitate mineral extraction and processing. Demand is [BLANK] by customer investment and output, which drives service need. Falling commodity prices pushed mining investment down by about 70% after the 2012 peak. First-quarter results were again hurt by weaker mining demand, with peers reporting double-digit sales declines. Share prices have generally remained depressed, with the exception of Weir, which slightly increased 1H earnings estimates.

At just 12% of overall sales, Hewlett Packard Enterprise's storage and networking segments are small, yet have brighter sales prospects. More than half of storage revenue could [BLANK] from growth trends in corporate IT, while networking sales have gained from the purchase of Aruba. Both segments may gain from the sale of a 51% stake in H3C Technologies to a China state-owned company. H3C will exclusively resell HPE's products in a growing market. Cisco and EMC dwarf HPE's share in switches and networked storage.

Regeneron and Gilead may realize the biggest earnings boost of mature U.S. biotech peers if Republicans successfully overhaul the U.S. tax code. Regeneron's last [BLANK] effective tax rate was the highest among big biotech at 32%. If Republicans can drop the corporate tax rate to 20%, mature U.S. biotech companies could see a 2.4% boost in earnings on average. Regeneron could benefit the most with a 13% increase, followed by Gilead at 4%.

Revenue guidance and interest-income momentum disclosed in 1Q results needs to justify increased expectations following the rise in yields (from late 3Q16), to prevent European banks' average 25% share-price rally stalling or unravelling. Iberian banks, where benefits of the ECB's targeted LTRO facility will [BLANK] to come through, and where leverage to sovereign yields is greatest, will be most closely scrutinized. Top six-month performers include CaixaBank (61%), UBI (47%), Sabadell (43%) and Santander (41%).

Digital lighting goes beyond improving energy efficiency. As part of a network, it's an ideal, if not ubiquitous, way to demonstrate the efficacy of the technologies that [BLANK] the ever-expanding Internet of Things. Major makers of lighting worldwide are focused on digital lighting, addressing the rapid growth in connected objects expected in 2017-20. Digital lighting should dominate sales growth early, with lighting services and data analytics likely to advance beyond the initial flurry.

Domestic receipts for this year's holiday releases could reach $2.6 billion, almost 9% lower than last year's haul of $2.85 billion. A strong performance from last year's films was instrumental in the setting of a 2015 box office record, as domestic grosses [BLANK] $11 billion for the first time. While receipts so far are running 3% higher year-over-year, momentum isn't likely to be sustained without a holiday movie to match Disney's "The Force Awakens," which pulled in $742 million by the end of the 2015 holidays.

Cloud-based content applications are projected to grow faster than the overall software-as-a-service market over the next five years, according to IDC. These applications [BLANK] users to organize and analyze data -- primarily unstructured data -- via the cloud. Customer relationship management and enterprise resource management cloud applications, which make up a combined 56% of the overall market, are growing at a slower pace, given they were early adopters of the cloud.

Liquidity spreads are rising toward levels seen when the ECB allocated 82.6 billion euros ($103 billion) in TLTRO1 on Sept. 18. Since reaching a 52-week low of 7.15 bps on Oct. 24, the three-month LIBOR-OIS spread has risen 3.25 bps, potentially [BLANK] a lack of confidence in the ECB's stress tests. A Markit iTraxx basket of euro financial CDS has risen 11 bps since TLTRO1. Ahead of December's TLTRO2, the ECB is mulling expanded asset purchases to boost liquidity, Reuters reported.

Origin's upstream Australia Pacific LNG project faces two main hurdles. The long investment cycle has raised debt and [BLANK] it into equity raising and asset sales. Secondly, its distribution breakeven of A$54-57 ($41-43) a barrel of oil equivalent doesn't augur well for cash flows, given low and volatile oil prices. The company has a put option for fiscal 2017 at A$55 a barrel and wants to cut production costs by A$3-5/boe. Current oil forecasts indicate the pricing challenge is likely to remain for some time.

Associated Estates shares gained 3.5% in December, leading the apartment REIT peer group again, as it did in November (up 14.8%). Activist investor Jonathan Litt asked management to consider [BLANK] the company, which boosted the stock price, making Associated Estates the top-performing apartment REIT in 2014. The four largest apartment REITs, Essex Property Trust, AvalonBay Communities, Equity Residential and Mid-America Apartment Communities, rounded out December's top five performers.

Post-2Q Earnings Outlook: Strong aerospace and defense and automotive sales momentum buttressed sales and helped offset disappointing cellular results in 2Q. While 2Q sales [BLANK] consensus by 2% due to the soft orders from Apple, the company was able to offset the lower cellular volume with better results in other areas to help drive a 160-bp gross margin beat to 17% and lead to a 31% EPS beat. Anaren outperformed in the quarter, contributing $62 million in sales, which implies 4% organic growth. Cellular revenue is expected to sharply rebound in 3Q with the iPhone launch on the horizon. The company's cellular guidance implies record quarterly sales for a 3Q, which marks content Apple gains. The uptick in cellular will aid gross margin 3Q, with scope for upside to its implied 16% to 17% gross margin target.

Adobe is increasingly partnering with system integrators such as IBM, Accenture and Cognizant to expand the reach of its Marketing Cloud. These large IT-services vendors have [BLANK] digital transformations in their customer base as a major growth driver amid greater use of social media and mobile devices by consumers. The advertising landscape is changing as companies look to enhance their customer's digital experience, customize products and measure the effectiveness of their campaigns.

The clock is ticking on the European Commission's antitrust assessment of the Dow-DuPont merger, after the companies formally notified the jurisdiction on June 22. This led to a provisional deadline of July 28, which will be moved back by 10 [BLANK] days if the companies offer concessions. A draft notification was made to China's competition agency in May. An initial 30-day clock will start when China's merger review authority, MOFCOM, deems the notification to be complete.

Pandora's May 6 win in a federal appeals court against the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers (ASCAP) is likely to stand, given the chances of the Supreme Court taking the case are exceptionally low. The appeals court made quick work of ASCAP's case, affirming that the lower court properly set Pandora's royalty rate and ruling that parties couldn't selectively [BLANK] from ASCAP to set their own fees. ASCAP may drop the case instead of asking for Supreme Court review.

AstraZeneca's 2Q will look a lot like 1Q, where product sales grew while externalization and lower margins led to a large EPS decline. But the key thing for Astra is its guidance and any hint of how 2019 may look, given 2018 is [BLANK] to be a trough earnings year, setting it up for a very strong rebound. Core selling and administrative costs are expected to rise in 2Q as the company invests in new drug launches, so it's paramount that the broad swath of newer drugs Brillinta, Farxiga, Imfinzi, Lynparza and Tagrisso deliver strong growth. Crestor and Nexium will continue their downward trajectory, dragging profitability, while Symbicort's profit contribution shrinks on price pressure. Volume for diabetes drug Farxiga has continued to rise, though its realized net price may have been under pressure in 2Q.

Wal-Mart's aim to boost its digital business, along with a focus on grocery delivery in the U.S. should help it better compete with Amazon.com and prevent market-share loss. Sales strength in the U.S. and abroad, with the exception of U.K. and China, show its focus on value is resonating with shoppers and [BLANK] trips to stores. Margins may be aided by lower product costs, lean inventory and higher amounts of products in stock. Still, rising pressure from higher shipping costs, rollbacks and wages are headwinds.

Even with the 32% Brent rally in 2016, U.S. floating storage has proven resilient as onshore crude oil inventories remain near record highs. A floating strategy requires [BLANK] oil on tankers temporarily until prices move higher, offsetting costs. As chronic oversupply strains domestic storage capacity, stockpiling crude at sea may provide a logistical -- albeit expensive -- alternative for trading houses. This year, U.S. floating storage has risen 16%, but increases may slow if the oil-price rebound persists.

Senior housing occupancy fell to 88.3% in 1Q, its lowest level since 1Q12, reversing a brief stabilization seen in 2H17. Absorption of senior housing units in 1Q fell to the lowest level since 1Q15, resulting in a significant gap vs. the amount of new units [BLANK]. First-quarter absorption is seasonally the slowest of the year, exacerbated this year by the magnitude of the flu outbreak. Rent growth slowed 20 bps in 1Q, as owners continue to navigate the low occupancy environment; this was the sixth straight quarter of slowing rent gains.

Plans to lower corporate taxes may advance further in 2015 than in recent years, only to be vetoed by President Barack Obama. A GOP-controlled Senate would seek to [BLANK] corporate taxes. A fast-track process for passing spending, tax and debt bills only requires 51 Senate votes, pushing Democrats out of negotiations. Obama is expected to veto tax plans that don't increase progressivity of individual income taxes, a policy opposed by Republicans.

The emergence of rail as a viable transport alternative has provided oil market participants with additional options as Williston Basin production volume continues to increase. Not all rails are falling in-line with AAR's position on one-man crews. With heavy competition for senior housing assets keeping prices elevated, the largely untapped hospital market could be the next wave of REIT expansion. Bayer's and Sanofi's consumer health businesses have had positive growth in the past five years, while their drug businesses have also grown, especially in the case of Bayer. GlaxoSmithKline's drug business has been under severe pressure from pricing, while its consumer growth hasn't [BLANK] rivals. Exposure to consumer health with Bayer and Sanofi also brings exposure to drug units, including vaccines, which are estimated to grow at a 7% annual rate until 2020, vs. GlaxoSmithKline's 3% growth, based on consensus.

Samsung Pay users spend a little more within an average week than Apple Pay users and report fewer problems, according to a March/April 2016 survey by Auriemma Consulting Group. This finding [BLANK] counter to data from Custora that shows nearly 75% of mobile orders come from Apple iOS devices vs. 25% for Android. For both services, according to Auriemma, only the newest and most expensive phones support payment, so users of both tend to be affluent.

If Aetna and Humana choose to defend through to a conclusion the Department of Justice's lawsuit challenging their merger, it could take about six months to get to a final decision, give or take a month or two. The process generally [BLANK] more quickly than traditional lawsuits and should get to a hearing within a few months. The DOJ's challenge to H&R Block's proposed takeover of TaxAct took about five months from complaint to final order. Its lawsuit against Oracle and PeopleSoft's merger took about 6.5 months.

Universal's "Minions" may be summer's most profitable movie with a projected 65% profit margin. The movie has taken in $989 million at the global box office, with margins [BLANK] the 36% average for animated films, the most profitable film genre. "Jurassic World" may be next with a projected 63% margin on to-date ticket sales of $1.6 billion. Disney's "Avengers: Age of Ultron" may have a 57% margin. The average profit margin among wide-release films from 2005-14 was 16%.

A Lockheed Martin-Boeing joint venture faces new competition from SpaceX as well as complications tied to its Russian supply chain as it seeks to defend its position on a $70 billion Air Force launch program. The venture, United Launch Alliance (ULA), had been the sole supplier until SpaceX won the right to [BLANK] in 2015. Bidding is under way for the first competitive satellite launch. Congressional efforts to limit ULA's purchase of Russian-made engines threaten to impede the alliance's competitiveness.

Decisions on whether two of Acorda's Ampyra patents will be reviewed by the U.S. Patent Office are due on Aug. 26 and Sept. 19, in each case three months after Acorda responded to patent challenges filed by Kyle Bass's Coalition for Affordable Drugs. If the patent office institutes [BLANK] inter partes reviews, Acorda would have three months to file a formal response. A decision on the patents would be due no later than a year after institution of the IPRs.

Oracle's strategy to broaden its cloud-based products in areas such as sales, marketing and human capital depends in part on actively pursuing acquisitions, according to the company's filings. Oracle [BLANK] 25 takeovers in the three years through 2014, spending at least $11.6 billion. That eclipses the number of deals completed Microsoft (15), Salesforce.com (12) and SAP (11), though trails IBM's activity (28). Recent Oracle deals include the purchase of TOA Technologies and Responsys.

Shares of Nomura and Daiwa plunged through June 30, while Chinese brokers narrowed losses. Japanese brokers face more challenges in retail revenue as their domestic markets [BLANK] on the yen's strength and a gloomier outlook for more BOJ easing. Chinese firms Citic and Haitong have narrowed losses since February and are among the region's best performers. Shares of the Hong Kong units of Haitong and Guotai Junan, last year's frontrunners, lost about 3% in 1H.

Capturing luxury-goods sales from discerning millennial buyers is a complex and shifting task, yet fits well with the industry's model of design-driven freshness, mixed with innovation and exclusivity. Brands such as Canada Goose or Kering's Gucci and Saint Laurent are [BLANK] this to drive exceptional revenue growth, but efforts from jewelry and watchmakers to seize the opportunity are still building. Engaging in the cultural shift that younger generations bring and connecting through experiences and digital are necessary. Bain estimates that 85% of the personal luxury goods sector's buoyant 2017 growth came from generations Y and Z.

Branded apparel companies are boosting their investments in e-commerce to capture additional sales in the fast-growing channel. As consumers continue to make purchasing decisions at home or on the go, away from retailers' brick-and-mortar locations, the brands are [BLANK] their strategies and increasing investments in their online channels, occasionally at the expense of short-term profitability. Tablets and smartphones are drawing more attention and now generate more than 25% of sales.

The Bear Case contends that deployment of wind energy may be slowed by insufficient grid connections. The uneven and far-spread distribution of wind farms and variable nature of wind energy may need expensive, politically unpopular grid upgrades, plus new high-voltage transmission lines to transport wind energy to [BLANK] hubs. The Bear Case suggests these may be delayed by planning or technology issues, as in the case of connections for new German offshore wind projects.

American Homes 4 Rent is re-accelerating its expansion activity, by raising its run-rate for individual asset acquisitions and increasing development plans. COO Jack Corrigan says the company plans to [BLANK] about 1,000 homes in 3Q and 1,250 in 4Q. In 2018, American Homes plans a $1 billion pipeline, with two-thirds coming from acquisitions and one-third in development. Alexion's (ALXN +15%) strong 1Q and positive results from the ALXN-1210 switch trial position the company for continued growth in 2018 and remove risks to lead asset Soliris, in our view. The launch of Soliris in generalized myasthenia gravis [BLANK] to be going well, which supports the company's increased revenue guidance for the drug and offsets some drag from the ALXN-1210 trials. Data from the switch trial further support approval of the product and its commercial viability to capture Soliris patients and expand the treatment opportunity.

Spain's power market has traditionally been dominated by natural gas. This grip has [BLANK] because of rising wind generation and a shift toward coal, given low carbon and fuel prices. Overall power output has stabilized as the slow economic recovery bolsters demand. The surge in renewables may cool because of lower capacity payments and new regulations reducing support for clean energy and thermal power. Spain is likely to reach its 2020 goal of generating 20% of energy from renewables in 2015.

Celgene-Acceleron's Luspatercept may open the door to treating MDS patients who don't need a transfusion. The drug is being [BLANK] in low-risk patients who depend on transfusions, as well as those who don't, and the studies have generated data on both patients who have tried erythropoietin-stimulating agents (ESAs) and those who haven't. Patients have met the working group's criteria for response in MDS. Sotatercept is also being tested in lower-risk patients. The drugs may be used to treat anemia in patients who don't respond to ESAs or are resistant.

High operating costs and unfavorable fiscal terms aren't deterring Total from continued investment in Angola, in contrast to many peers. Significant volume potential for resources and output [BLANK] appeal to deep offshore operations, even if prices remain low for longer. Total isn't just launching its large Kaombo project early next year, which should double the French major's output there from 2018. It has also acquired Maersk's Chissonga project, and has a share in the Angola LNG plant.

New supply has already cut apartment rent gains in East Coast gateway cities, but the timeline of expected completions indicates there are still thousands of units to come. Apartment owners such as Equity Residential, UDR and AvalonBay will be hardest [BLANK], as developments sap potential tenants with rental incentives.
Loan growth at U.S. regional banks remained weak in 4Q, though management teams are more optimistic about 2018's potential. Commercial loan gains are stabilizing after [BLANK] in recent quarters.

Generic-drug makers may get a quicker path to approval under a Senate bill that aims to ease spikes in brand names' prices. The measure requires the FDA to [BLANK] on a generic's application in 150 days if there aren't at least two other producers of the drug. A new generics priority-review voucher program would encourage companies to address unmet needs. Generics account for 88% of U.S. prescriptions but less than 30% of drug spending. Generics use saved the U.S. health system $1.68 trillion in a decade.

China's slowdown in industrial growth, which picked up steam in 1Q, may extend into 2015 as housing construction and investment falter. Steel, cement and power production, which together make up more 80% of Chinese domestic demand, may [BLANK] as overcapacity deters investment. Lower demand for thermal coal may put additional pressure on imports, which are expected to fall for the first time since China became a net importer.

Wells Fargo is among several banks facing RMBS probes by the Justice Department, and a settlement could reach multiples of the bank's $335 million pact with the FHFA in 2013. A Wells Fargo unit, as mortgage-bond trustee, [BLANK] multibillion-dollar lawsuits by BlackRock, Pimco and other mortgage-bond investors. Wells Fargo is one of many banks defending an ISDAfix manipulation suit. Wells Fargo's wealth management business may be impacted by industry suits challenging the U.S. Labor Department's fiduciary rule.

The glut of horizontal drilled but uncompleted wells (DUCs) could take over a year to work through in some shale regions. The Marcellus inventory would take about a year (11.51 months), even if 60% of new wells were from DUC inventories [BLANK] for more than three months. Should completion activity slow considerably in 2016, the times would lengthen. Even if 100% of all new wells brought to market came from DUC inventories, it would take until 2H to exhaust the abnormal backlog.

Polish banks face increased capital demands of as much as $2 billion, assuming 10.25% minimum capital requirement, on proposed higher risk weights on these loans. The Financial Stability Committee proposals to increase risk weights to 150% from 100% is seeking to force lenders to [BLANK] foreign-currency mortgages into zloty. This is equivalent to about 85 bps of the industry's risk-weighted assets. The committee does not recommend the government's plan to impose an additional levy on forex loans.

A long legal battle against American Express by the Department of Justice and states is likely to end in 4Q with a final AmEx victory. Though the DOJ has bowed out of the matter, 11 states petitioned the Supreme Court to review an appellate court decision that reversed a lower court finding that AmEx rules [BLANK] antitrust laws.
