A firming North American backdrop for heavy-duty trucks, and Meritor's commitment to continue improving metrics and ratings, will likely lead the company's credit profile to [BLANK] in the year ahead.

Flaring, or the burning of excess natural gas produced during hydrocarbon extraction, has come under scrutiny from both oil companies and regulators as focus on the environmental effects and carbon emissions grows. Statoil flares the least among oil majors, [BLANK] by Norway's ban on the practice under routine circumstances. While North Dakota allows much more flaring, it has cut its limit this year after the rapid expansion of Bakken drilling. Statoil, BG Group, Eni, Shell and Total pledged to stop flaring by 2030.

Given the recent weak share price performance of many oil and gas companies, management is turning to either buybacks or dividends to improve returns. This strategy [BLANK] counter to the companies increasing need to invest in the development of new oil and gas fields needed to maintain future production levels. An increasing number of new assets are located offshore, in the Arctic or in other challenging environments, driving up developing costs.

Record corn production has pressured grain prices, curbing farm equipment demand. Projected U.S. corn ending stocks in 2014-15 were [BLANK] by 50 million bushels in WASDE's April report due to less feed and residual demand. Corn's average price range was narrowed by 5 cents, though the midrange remained at $3.70 a bushel, 34% below the 2010-14 average. Farmers intend to plant 2% fewer corn acres in 2015, according to the March planting intentions report. If realized, the crop may be the smallest since 2010.

Crude shipments by rail out of the Bakken/Three Forks shale will likely decrease substantially if the Dakota Access Pipeline goes online. The pipe has the capacity to [BLANK] half of the area's total daily output. Crude in the Bakken has been shipped by rail more than any other play due to the lack of traditional pipeline infrastructure. Dakota Access Pipeline is projected to transport 470,000 barrels a day, almost 200,000 barrels more than have been carried daily by rail in September.

France's fiscal deficit is set to surpass 3% in 2019 as the measures and concessions granted by President Emmanuel Macron following the country's civil unrest exceed 11 billion euros. The investor-driven response is a widening of the 10-year yield spread between French and German bonds, [BLANK] outflows from fixed income ETFs and the CAC40 index's decline by almost 9%. However, the budget deficit should be back under control in 2020, preventing a conflict between Paris and Brussels.

Numerous global banks continue to face billions of dollars in potential risk in antitrust government investigations and proposed class-action lawsuits. The risks [BLANK] even after a host of multibillion-dollar settlements by banks with regulators and institutional investors related to currency, Libor and other market manipulation.

Energy Transfer Partners continues to deal with the aftermath of demolishing the Stoneman House historic property in Ohio, though the issue isn't a threat to the construction schedule at this point. By letter dated May 17 from FERC, Rover has three weeks (June 7) to [BLANK] a dispute over its agreement with the Ohio historic preservation agency before FERC makes its own recommendation on the issue. Under the terms of the agreement, FERC's recommendation would go to the federal historic preservation agency.

The tide is starting to turn for Macau casino operating profit expectations. Forward [BLANK] for Sands China, MGM China and Wynn Macau have ticked up in recent months, in contrast to a citywide-average 53% plunge since the end of 2014. The drop stemmed from a 34% decline in gambling revenue in 2015 on slower economic growth, China's anti-extravagance push and a smoking ban. New resorts are supporting stabilization in revenue and more casino openings later this year should aid a 2016 recovery.

Lockheed Martin's recent losses in major new U.S. weapons competitions leave the company with a calendar dominated by smaller bids. One remaining opportunity to [BLANK] a new system is the Navy's carrier-based drone, which faces a reduction in funding because the program is being restructured. Also on the horizon is new competition from SpaceX for national security satellite launches and potential bids from rivals for a major national-lab management deal and a special operations logistics contract.

Consensus EPS estimates for Class I railroads were mostly unchanged in the past four weeks. Canadian Pacific (down 1.7%) and KC Southern (2.6% lower) were the only rails whose 3Q expectations were [BLANK] lower. Analysts may have trimmed KC Southern estimates amid concern about the cost implications of various 3Q events, such as flooding, bridge outages and the Mexican teachers strike that obstructed parts of its network. KC Southern also expects headwinds related to wage inflation and incentive compensation.

Indonesia's LNG exports, which rose 18.5% in 1Q from a low base a year earlier, fell 27% in April as exports to South Korea plunged 29%. Indonesia's rising domestic gas demand and falling output at mature fields will eventually [BLANK] its LNG exports. While Indonesia was once Asia's leading LNG exporter, it will start importing in 2018 via PT Pertamina's contract with Cheniere Energy's Corpus Christi project. PT Pertamina's tentative agreement with Woodside is a prelude to buying LNG from Australia in 2019.

Johnson & Johnson's top-end risk in about 29,000 pelvic mesh cases continues to grow as multimillion-dollar verdicts mount and may reach $375 billion, based on average federal court verdicts to date. A settlement may be the likelier outcome as more cases [BLANK] toward trial, and could fall short of $5 billion.

Vehicle buyers' demand profile, influenced by low gasoline prices, favors the truck-heavy portfolio of U.S. automakers. Advances in fuel economy have reduced the cost of truck ownership, helping U.S. brands [BLANK] on consumer preferences. A proliferation of crossover SUVs plays to the strength of Asian automakers capable of providing truck utility with car driving characteristics. Fiat Chrysler's June sales were 75% trucks, compared with 68% for General Motors. Ford was most diverse at 63%.

Google has until May 22 to file its opening brief in Oracle's appeal of a jury verdict in a copyright dispute over Java's application program interfaces (APIs) in the Android operating system. Oracle's bid for more than $8 billion in damages [BLANK] when the jury said it was fair use for Google to incorporate the Java APIs. Oracle's opening brief took issue with the fair-use decision and with the district judge's handling of the case. Google's brief was due in March, but the company received an extension.

Earnings from ventures with overseas automakers can make up all the reported earnings for Dongfeng, BAIC, Guangzhou Auto and Brilliance, even compensating for losses. Sales and [BLANK] income from ventures aren't reported in the automakers' profit and loss statements because they use the equity method of accounting. BAIC consolidates its venture with Mercedes because it owns 51%, while results from its venture with Hyundai are only disclosed as earnings from joint ventures below the operating income line.

European retailers face a tough challenge as consumers contend with a return of inflation amid political and economic uncertainty. The rising cost of fuel, food and raw materials will [BLANK] real incomes, and wage growth could potentially stagnate. This is particularly worrisome for the U.K., where sterling weakness has increased import costs and a housing shortage has put pressure on rents. Germany, which is renowned for ensuring price stability, is also facing higher inflation.

Near-term biotech and pharma events include data of Bavarian's respiratory syncytial virus vaccine Phase II booster trial in 2Q. Updated data of Spark's Phase I/II trial of SPK-8011 gene therapy in hemophilia A and data from Ovid's OV101 Phase II Stars trial in adults and adolescents with Angelman syndrome are [BLANK] in 3Q. Biohaven's Phase III trial of rimegepant orally-disintegrating tablet fast-dissolving formulation is due to report data in 4Q. Data of Regulus' RG-012 renal biopsy study in Alport syndrome are postponed to year-end. Data of Incyte's ruxolitinib registrational Phase II trial Reach-1 in steroid-refractory acute graft vs. host disease (GvHD) are expected in 2Q. Alnylam's givosiran Phase III Envision trial in acute hepatic porphyrias has interim analysis data expected in September.

Post-3Q Earnings Outlook: Merck's raised 2018 EPS guidance to the midpoint of $4.33, vs. consensus of $4.29, this time fueled by a $10 billion share buyback (of which $5 billion is accelerated), is less of a positive than at first glance. If all the $5 billion falls in 2018, this is essentially a downgrade, given the previous $4.26 midpoint including a 1% drag, and [BLANK] higher marketing and R&D spending may be pushing operating costs to the top end of guidance for a low-to-mid single digit increase. A tightened revenue target is in-line with consensus. Merck needs to continue driving Keytruda, which it can do with its spate of trial successes, and work through 2018-19 Vytorin and Zetia patent expirations. Keytruda, despite its lead, will remain exposed to trial news from rivals potentially moving the goal posts.

The U.S. sales pace of compact crossover SUVs in March indicates consumers are quickly turning away from compact and midsize cars. Automakers will likely [BLANK] supply to reflect this change in taste. Days to turn of small crossovers averaged 45, tied for fourth-best among the 23 segments, compared with an industry average of 70. Only the compact and midsize car segments outsold compact crossovers in March, yet respective days to turn of 80 and 73 indicate these car classes may start choking on inventory.

An existing law requires new federal buildings to phase out fossil-fuel energy use, including in electricity consumption, by 2030. Implementation may be [BLANK] by late 2015 and could shrink the market over time for utilities with coal and gas capacity. A U.S. House committee is meeting to discuss a draft energy-efficiency bill on April 30 that contains a provision to repeal the law. While the Republican-backed measure is controversial, it could be used as a bargaining chip for other measures and thus could pass.

Managing the trade-off between sovereign debt capital gains and lower interest income may have a bearing on bank revenue as ECB QE commences. Intesa's net interest income fell 2% as sovereign debt yields declined, while ING said its government bond holdings rose in 4Q by 2.7 billion euros ($3.1 billion) in anticipation of QE, when 10-year Dutch yields [BLANK] 42 bps to 66 bps. Euro zone banks, led by Italian and French lenders, shrank balance sheets by selling a net 28 billion euros of sovereign holdings in 4Q.

The Drewry Hong Kong-Los Angeles container-rate benchmark soared 97.5% to $1,418 per 40-foot container (FEU) in the week ended Jan. 6. The jump was driven by a $1,200 floor [BLANK] by the Transpacific Stabilization Agreement and rising demand ahead of the Chinese New Year starting Feb. 8. The holiday is a boon for liner trade as shippers seek to move goods before Asia factories close for weeks. Slack capacity should continue to pressure rates, which are down 28% year over year despite this week's increase.

A Jan. 22 explosion at International Paper's Pensacola, Florida kraftliner and fluff pulp mill is reported to have caused significant structural damage to parts of the complex and may keep the mill idle for many months. The lost production volume [BLANK] an already tight kraftliner market that operated at a robust 97% of capacity in 2H. The mill represents 2.5% of North American linerboard capacity (including recycled) and 2% of kraft linerboard capacity, as well as 4% of the company's containerboard capacity.

The computer hardware and storage industry may experience more large acquisitions and spinoffs as traditional vendors such as IBM and Hewlett-Packard change to more services-oriented business models, and emerging competitors such as Lenovo seek to increase product offerings. Markets such as networked storage may be [BLANK] as cloud-based models adopt "direct-attach" storage. EMC, which has also been considering options under activist pressure, has been reported to be exploring a spinoff or sale of the company.

Refinery outage leaves more crude to fill storage tanks. U.S. gasoline demand typically slows in autumn as the summer driving season ends and refiners [BLANK] down some capacity to perform maintenance. Refinery outages and events for crude distillation units (CDU), as tracked by REFO , indicate that about 580,000 barrels a day of refiner CDU capacity will go offline in PADD 2 (which includes Cushing) in September and October. The next refiner maintenance season occurs in March and April.

The global copper market may return to deficit by 2020 if demand surpasses an average of 3.5% from 2015 on. This [BLANK] with the previous four-year growth rate of 3.76% and an assumed 5.2% in 2014 based on year-to-date figures. An apparent property slowdown in China may make this rate tough to achieve. There are at least 14 projects in the new supply pipeline vulnerable to delays or cancellation, though, which could lower the threshold.

The global switch market grew to $6.2 billion in 2Q, up 6.9% from 2Q13 and above the 1.9% growth in 1Q, according to IDC. Cisco lost market share, [BLANK] its fourth consecutive quarterly decline. Cisco is working through a difficult product transition that has provided an opening for rivals such as Arista and Hewlett-Packard to take share. Cisco's share dropped to 55.6% in 2Q from 56% in 1Q, while Arista, HP and Huawei all gained.

Well completions in the gas-focused Fayetteville play rose in August thanks almost entirely to Southwestern Energy. While the data for August are only partially complete, [BLANK] the figure will likely rise as more information comes in, the August figure of 22 is already higher than July's 17 completions. Southwestern's hedges, combined with its 34% growth in average 30-day initial production rates since early 2012, are allowing the play to remain economically viable for the company despite sagging gas prices.

Pipelines that need FERC approval to be built are taking longer to go from initial filing to notice of construction than they were prior to 2015. For those pipelines that have received a letter order [BLANK] construction since 2015, the median processing time was almost 60 days longer than before then. The average time was only slightly longer for the same period, but given the 73 projects pending before FERC with filing dates as far back as June 2013, the spread between pre- and post-2015 will only increase.

The U.S. oil rig count rose by two in the latest week as operators added horizontal rigs in the Mid-Continent and Bakken, overshadowing losses in the Permian and Eagle Ford. Gains will likely continue to slow or [BLANK] in the next few weeks if oil prices languish near $45 a barrel. Prospects for a broad-based recovery that extends to areas outside the Permian remain dim in the short term. A significant pickup may have to wait until 2017 as E&Ps seek prices comfortably above $50 and closer to $60.

Orange Belgium's convergence drive is needed to remain competitive, and promises to be a sustainable source of growth. As a mobile-only operator, Orange Belgium would be exposed to a declining churn pool from competitors Telenet and Proximus, which are [BLANK] in fixed-mobile bundle sales that are reducing the companies' mobile attrition. Proximus has proved resilient in defending its market share, yet Orange Belgium's fixed-line expansion goals appear credible over the mid- to long-term.

Netflix started charging a premium for 4K content, according to Engadget. That may mean more content for the ultra high-definition format will be available, which in turn may [BLANK] sales for 4K TVs. Sony also has a 4K video store with more than 200 movies. Sales of 4K TVs may top 100 million units by 2018, according to IDC, as growing supply shrinks the price gap in relation to conventional sets. Samsung, Sony and LG are leading makers of high-end 4K TVs.

The U.K. vote to leave the European Union may exacerbate the challenges facing life insurers as financial- and currency-market volatility increases, business confidence is threatened and interest rates likely remain lower for longer. U.K. life insurers face the prospect of volatile equity markets, falling commercial property values and sharply lower bond yields, which may [BLANK] investment flows and dislocate the pipeline for pension transfers. The additional uncertainty may jeopardize short-term growth.

Home insurers may see higher marginal demand from additional supply as new home sales rose 6% in January, 10% in 4Q and 11% in 2016. Still, more aggressive competition has [BLANK] in essentially flat pricing in this line, which could pressure margins in 2017. Conversely, demand growth for personal auto insurance could ease with sales unchanged in the first two months of 2017 vs. 5% growth for the same period in 2016. February auto sales fell 0.4% to a 17.5 million seasonally adjusted annual rate.

The clock is ticking on U.S. automakers' dominance of profitable light-truck and SUV sales, and a stronger tariff stance may be the only thing that slows this market-share erosion. A 2% gain in 1H unit sales and a 4 percentage point shift in truck mix has [BLANK] into $12 billion in retail revenue gains for manufacturers riding the wave.

Liberty Global will likely retain an acquisitive strategy after a plethora of deals ranging from a Netherlands joint venture with Vodafone to the purchase of multinational carrier Cable & Wireless. The deals were [BLANK] by scale efficiencies, fixed-to-mobile convergence and demand for content. Acquisitions in mobile, where Liberty has expanding, or majority, broadband coverage, remain likely. Liberty's network expansion in the U.K., where efforts to consolidate the mobile market failed, boosts the logic for a deal.

Tronox's $1.7 billion bid to acquire Cristal's titanium dioxide (TiO2) business is likely to obtain EU approval despite a short suspension of the merger review by regulators. The companies may need to [BLANK] concessions in some coating and plastic segments to gain approval. A decision is likely in 2Q, but may slip into 3Q.

Hedge fund outflows improved to $1.4 billion in 4Q for fixed-income-focused relative value arbitrage (RVA) strategies, after the worst quarterly outflow ($4.1 billion in 3Q) in years, using HFR data. Redemptions of $1.7 billion in 2016 follow years of inflows, though were modest [BLANK] with other hedge fund strategies. Fixed-income relative flow strength returned vs. equities, similar to 2010-14, after trailing in 2015. The organic cut to assets was less than 10 bps in 2016 compared with 2% for the industry.

The consolidation of the convenience segment within U.K. grocery has gathered pace, as large operators seek to extract growth opportunities in the channel by penetrating more neighborhood locations, while lower industry margins mean many independent shops will close, be sold or [BLANK] symbol groups.

Average dividend yields for EU generators have exceeded government bonds by 2.07x in February, the most in 10 years. This was driven by the ECB's quantitative easing package, which will [BLANK] at the end of March. Its goal is to stimulate the euro zone economy. Low interest rates have contributed to the decline in sovereign yields. By contrast, generators' dividend yields stabilized, as lower utilization rates and increased political interventions were offset by falling commodity prices.

Clearinghouse volumes may drop if U.S. and global leverage ratio rules aren't amended before they take effect in 2018. A group representing clearinghouses estimated the cost of [BLANK] exchange-traded derivatives could be as much as 5x levels now. That could decrease use of these products, contrary to regulators' desire. Exchanges may also see reduced trading levels. Interest-rate products such as eurodollars and Treasury contracts may be affected the most because they have some of the highest trading volumes.

The European Commission is likely to set minimum disclosure standards to help investors price covered bonds across the EU more accurately on the basis of the issuer's strength and cover pool quality. In 1Q, most issuers and investors [BLANK] the idea of full harmonization. In their view, the existing regime, while fragmented, works. While an overly prescriptive regime would be impractical, a voluntary system may be too weak. A new rule that sets out minimum standards may strike a good compromise.

Morgan Stanley's litigation risks include lawsuits and investigations that may cost $1 billion. The bank faces antitrust suits related to swaps and stock lending platforms, ISDAfix and Treasuries, which may end up [BLANK] several hundred million dollars total. Morgan Stanley may also be facing probes over foreign exchange, ISDAfix and Treasuries manipulation, all of which could also cost hundreds of millions. The bank is settling a forex antitrust suit for $50 million, yet still faces a forex "last look" suit.

Post-2Q Earnings Outlook: Pandora's user base fell to its lowest level since early 2014, overshadowing an improving sales path and heightening concern about longer-term growth and M&A scenarios. Potential suitors may take a wait-and-see approach as they assess whether user gains [BLANK]. If usage continues to fall, it may crimp potential ad inventory. Pandora backed away from guidance for 2017 paid subscriber growth, suggesting a renewed focus on ad-free users and competitive challenges.

National Australia Bank's earnings prospects will depend on an ongoing strength of business and corporate banking, which jointly contributed 65% of its 1H pretax profit. These units helped [BLANK] fiscal 3Q margin on loan repricing and improved funding condition. Market income also fuels revenue, as market volatility bodes well for risk management and its treasury business. Lower credit costs augur well for its profit, too. Separately, NAB and peers' profit will suffer from the new 6-bp levy on liabilities.

Micron's valuation has wide-ranging bull and bear scenarios, depending on memory supply and demand. It could be higher if the company was weighted like other chip stocks, or as a participant in an industry that's structurally [BLANK]. Using P/book value on the capital-intensive company during oversupply weakens valuation.

India's construction-equipment unit sales may rise 14% in 2016 to the highest level since 2012, following a 2% gain last year, according to Off-Highway Research. India's government has taken steps to reform the project approval process and improve financing access, budging [BLANK] projects. The largest categories, backhoe loaders and crawler excavators, account for 86% of unit sales and may rise by 9% and 23%, respectively. India's plan to invest $150 billion in highways and shipping through 2019 supports growth.

Foreign exchange will likely hurt Accenture's sales growth by about 8.5% when the company reports fiscal 1Q16 results on Dec. 17. In addition to currency, Accenture will have to [BLANK] tough comparisons in sales growth from fiscal 2015, when constant currency growth was about 10-12% in each of that year's four quarters. Accenture expects sales growth of 5-8% for the full fiscal year. Digital products from cloud to analytics will likely remain the company's primary growth drivers.

Investors' tepid response to U.S. packaged-foodmaker 1Q results reflects skepticism about the sustainability of industry growth, in our view, with lower tax benefits fading as the year progresses. Despite a relatively strong 13% median EPS gain, 1% above expectations, the sector [BLANK] weak consumer demand and cost pressures.

Gold ETFs have gotten all the attention -- and nearly all of the flows -- in 2016 after a 25% rebound in the yellow metal. Yet gold still [BLANK] behind the returns of precious metal peers silver and palladium. SPDR Gold Shares (GLD) is up 24.7%, which trails silver and palladium ETFs. The iShares Silver Trust (SLV) has gained 41.5% and the ETFS Physical Palladium Shares (PALL) is up 25.7%. Of the $17 billion of inflows into precious metals ETFs, gold tracking products have $15 billion of that.

FirstEnergy and Duke meet with investors on Feb. 18. Both own merchant generation in the Midwest, though Duke's is under contract to be [BLANK] to Dynegy. Duke might also discuss whether it will divest Latin American hydro assets. Con Edison, which reports after the market close on Feb. 19, doesn't hold a call. Feb. 20 calls are scheduled by Public Service Enterprise, a big mid-Atlantic merchant generator, and Pinnacle West, which has an issue with rooftop solar.

House Speaker Paul Ryan issued a plan in June that called for a repeal of all climate-change regulations issued under the Clean Air Act. When President Barack Obama took office, greenhouse gas emissions weren't [BLANK] by the federal government. By the time he exits the White House, his administration will have proposed Clean Air Act regulations that cover 55% of U.S. greenhouse gases. Legislation to roll back such rules (for example, H.R. 3880) faces an uphill battle in the Senate.

Large database sellers such as SAP, Oracle and Microsoft focused on in-memory databases in the 2Q earnings season. SAP touted strong adoption of its in-memory database HANA and is now [BLANK] most of its software suites, including Enterprise Resource Planning and ByDesign on HANA. Microsoft's SQL Server revenue -- with in-memory capability -- grew 19% in 2Q, while Oracle also highlighted in-memory as key feature for its new 12C database.

The most frequently cited violation for apparel supplier code of conduct audits are around issues of wages, including issues of full and timely payment, overtime, and deductions. Paying a "Living" or "Fair" wage often goes beyond meeting legally required minimums and [BLANK] worker pay meets certain basic costs or standards. H&M, Inditex, Adidas, Puma, M&S and Hugo Boss disclose policies and programs to pay suppliers' workers a fair wage. Preventing worker exploitation may reduce reputational risks.

AbbVie's patent-office win is unlikely to be threatened by a Sandoz appeal. The PTAB [BLANK] Sandoz' inter partes review petition challenging an AbbVie patent on a method of treating psoriasis using adalimumab, as well as Sandoz' request to reconsider the decision not to institute. Sandoz is appealing the former denial, given that institution decisions can't be appealed. A Federal Circuit ruling is expected in late 3Q or early 4Q.

North American airlines cut Atlantic capacity by an average 1.6% in October as Air Canada and Delta were the only two carriers in growth mode. Air Canada [BLANK] 12.2% more capacity as it expands its low-cost subsidiary Rouge on trans-Atlantic routes. Air Canada posted a 210-bp gain in load factors while its Star Alliance partner United cut capacity 1.5% as load factors rose slightly. Delta added 2.3% more capacity as load factors fell 250 bps, indicating that demand may be softening under expansion.

Liquefied natural gas import growth in China, India and Thailand exceeded that of Japan, the world's biggest importer of the fuel, in the first eight months. Imports in Asia, the top LNG-importing region, [BLANK] 14.9% to 138 million metric tons. The region may buy more as new projects in Australia and the U.S. commence.

The ultimate location of product desks that may be affected by a loss of passporting rights is a growing area of debate for non-U.K.-domiciled banks. While it is increasingly agreed that euro-denominated business is probably fair game, with relocation likely, many non-euro lines of business fall into a grey area where consensus is [BLANK]. Research from The Boston Consulting Group shows that cash equities, prime services and debt capital markets also fall into this category.

Euro strength, if sustained through ECB actions, economic growth and relative calm in geopoliticals, will influence European earnings and stocks in 2H. After 18 months of stability, the trade-weighted euro is the world's major currency on the rise, with Emmanuel Macron's presidential victory in France and leading indicators [BLANK] for a EU revival after years of euro-scepticism. The pound is also surprisingly firm after dramatic weakness spurred by last year's Brexit vote, while the dollar and yuan are waning.

A Senate panel will consider competing proposals on April 22 to use free-trade deals as a tool to combat currency manipulation. One proposal, offered by Democrat Debbie Stabenow of Michigan and Republican Rob Portman of Ohio, would [BLANK] trade deals to include rules and sanctions against "large-scale intervention in one direction." Another, similar to S. 433, would impose tariffs on currencies deemed undervalued. U.S. trade partners, particularly Japan, are unlikely to agree to deals containing such provisions.

Average commercial insurance rates rose 1% in October, a slight deceleration from September and in-line with monthly gains since midyear, according to MarketScout. Two of 14 lines reported lower increases than in September, gains in 10 lines were stable and two [BLANK]. Commercial auto rates are rising the most (3%) after posting the highest 2013 underwriting losses (107 combined ratio) of five major industry segments.

Holiday shopping may be off to a slow start, but it's better than consensus expected, based on reported monthly same-store sales. Comparable sales for six apparel, mass-merchant and off-price retailers [BLANK] 0.5% on a revenue-weighted basis in November vs. a 5.2% gain a year ago. But consensus expected a decline of 1%, excluding Gap. L Brands' sales led the group, with a 7% boost as all segments saw growth. Buckle trailed, missing consensus and falling 7.9%, likely as mild winter weather cools apparel demand.

Weakness in domestic benchmark commodity prices will impact Cabot's cash flow and margins in 2015. Additional operational and capital efficiencies, along with enhanced well productivity could partially [BLANK] margin pressure from soft oil and gas prices. Cabot and other Marcellus-levered operators have a more competitive per unit cost structure relative to producers in other gas plays in the U.S. While its cash unit costs have declined by two-thirds since 2010, improvement may be more tepid.

The 2Q earnings season for Class I railroads came and went in the last 10 days and railroads demonstrated an ability to overcome a sluggish economy as well as service and network performance issues. Canadian Pacific, Kansas City Southern, Norfolk Southern and Union Pacific all [BLANK] record operating ratios in the quarter. Management teams appear confident in their ability to improve network fluidity, increase volume, price over inflation and expand margins.

The chance of IBM's proposed purchase of Red Hat failing in the long period between the deal's announcement and its close is about 25%, based on its closing price on Nov. 1. Any disruption may be the result of antitrust scrutiny the deal may face in the U.S. and EU, for which IBM would have to make some behavioral remedies before being able to [BLANK]. Red Hat is unlikely to get a competing offer from other large tech companies such as Google, Microsoft, Amazon.com and Cisco, in our view, amid similar antitrust concerns. Methodology: We calculated the probability of the deal's success or failure based on two likely outcomes: That it goes through at $190 a share, or it fails and Red Hat goes back to its pre-offer price of $116.68 a share.

Iraq's July oil production decline appears to be unrelated to fighting waged by Islamist militant group ISIS in the north and west of the country, according to JBC Energy. Output dropped on lower flows at the Kirkuk field, [BLANK] by forces of the Kurdistan regional government in Iraq. While Kirkuk is an important oil field in the north of Iraq, the remaining key oil fields are located in the south, putting them beyond the reach of ISIS.

Proposed antitrust class-action lawsuits accusing American, Delta, Southwest and United of conspiring to fix passenger capacity and artificially raise price are unlikely to settle in the near term. The airlines concluded briefing on motions to dismiss the case in July and are now [BLANK] for the judge to schedule oral arguments. The parties will likely await a decision on dismissal before contemplating settlements. With oral arguments on the motions not yet set, a ruling before the end of 2016 is unlikely.

Low-carbon indexes may continue their outperformance as President Donald Trump's energy policy could do more to cap oil prices rather than curtail renewable energy. Indexes that avoid high carbon emission and fossil-fuel extraction companies [BLANK] their benchmarks in 1Q, largely reversing 2016 declines. Trump easing fossil fuel extraction rules may help foster production, countering OPEC efforts to cut supply. Easing power and auto rules would support longer-term fossil fuel demand.

Defense prime contractors continue focusing on share buybacks to boost earnings per share in 2015, with revenue pressured by weak defense budgets and stable profit margins. Most will [BLANK] cash to buy back shares or pay dividends as a means to provide returns to shareholders in an environment where few management teams see strong prospects for investing in defense businesses. Acquisitions are likely to be focused on niche capabilities around technology and probably of smaller size.

National Australia Bank's fiscal 1Q results highlight its expense and capital outlook. While costs rose 5% in 1Q, NAB may have laid the groundwork for lower expenses ahead, as full-time employees [BLANK] by 488 from 35,000 as of September. Lower bad-debt charges on mining and agricultural loans and a stabilizing net interest margin may also aid earnings. Yet NAB's capital position may be a concern, as CET1 ratio dropped to 9.5% in December from 9.8% in September.

Microsoft's legal battle over the protection of customer e-mails stored in Ireland reflects growing international concern about the efficacy of U.S. data privacy policies that could undermine U.S.-based companies' cloud business. Microsoft is appealing a federal district court's decision to allow the U.S. government to demand customer e-mails [BLANK] in data centers in Ireland. Microsoft argues that the decision ignores existing avenues for law enforcement agencies to coordinate with international counterparts.

A key policy focus for 21st Century Fox is retransmission fees for its FOX network, which could nearly double by 2021. FCC rule changes could [BLANK] this revenue. Spectrum, a la carte and media ownership rules -- all affected by a rewrite of the Communications Act of 1934 -- are being monitored. Pending trade deals could help limit film piracy, particularly in developing countries. It has $851 million in cash and marketable securities overseas and proposals to repatriate earnings may impact the company .

A wave of novel oral agents for inflammatory gastrointestinal diseases is edging closer to entering the market, possibly shifting the way these diseases are treated. These treatments may be [BLANK] ahead of injectable mainstays and vie for a slice of the potentially $18 billion market. At the forefront is Pfizer's Xeljanz, but Celgene, AbbVie, Gilead (and partner Galapagos) have skin in the game.

Oral arguments are expected in 2Q related to renewed bids to dismiss by ARCP (now Vereit) and other defendants in an amended fraud lawsuit by investors over the 2014 disclosure of intentional accounting errors. Dismissal briefing ended April 5 after investors filed amended claims in December after the court allowed fraud claims to proceed and asked plaintiffs to [BLANK] flaws in their class-action complaint. A ruling on the renewed dismissal bids may not come until 3Q.

A large number of European TMT companies are due to report the week of July 16. We expect Nordic telecoms Telenor (July 17), Tele2 (July 18) and Telia (July 20) to [BLANK] broadly upbeat 2Q results, though Telenor may show more muted progress than in 1Q. TalkTalk (July 17) should remain in-line with full-year guidance and will likely try to calm concerns after the aborted sale of its B2B customer-base to the Daisy Group. Meanwhile, we're fairly positive about results from Millicom (July 19), Orange Belgium (July 20) and the first of the large advertising agencies to report, Publicis (July 20).

Rising food inflation in Brazil may again limit retail sales volume growth, encouraging retailers to cut prices and expand discount operations. Supermarket food sales volume fell by 1.7% in September vs. the prior year, extending the drop from January, while inflation [BLANK]. A similar situation occurred in 2013 from January to April. As consumers cut spending in the slowing economy, discounters are gaining popularity, with Carrefour, Wal-Mart and GPA all expanding those formats in Brazil.

The NII International manager vetting a bankruptcy settlement with bondholders may be considering how the announced sale of NII Mexico to AT&T may affect creditor recoveries under a reorganization plan. Debtors agreed to give Zolfo Cooper's Scott Winn an extra week, until Feb. 6, to decide whether he [BLANK] NII should approve the settlement. The debtors project they will receive at least 25% more in sale proceeds than NII Mexico was valued at under the plan.

The almost $15 billion settlement that Volkswagen entered into with the EPA, the Justice Department, the FTC and current and past vehicle owners does away with most of the company's liability from the diesel emissions scandal. The secondary liability, those claims that don't have the same magnitude of risk, [BLANK] claims by independent dealers, lawsuits by shareholders and a criminal investigation. VW's 3.0 Liter models are also still at issue, though these claims are likely to be disputed by VW.

Sirius XM likely won't settle any of the three suits it faces from the owners of the recordings for the Turtles. Sirius already limited its exposure by settling with record companies that [BLANK] 80% of the oldies recordings at issue. Sirius's need to settle is further reduced by the fact that three separate appeals courts will soon review the issue. No appeals court has found that recording owners have the exclusive right to air pre-1972 recordings that the plaintiff claims here.

The broader trend of lower imported crude oil into the U.S. will remain intact during 2015. U.S. imports averaged 7.1 million barrels a day in the week ended Feb. 13, a decline of 181,000 from the prior week, given the Brent-WTI spread has [BLANK] from near-parity levels. Canadian oil to the U.S. is at about 3 million barrels a day, while Saudi Arabian shipments rose to more than 900,000. Venezuela and Columbia gained some share as pricing affected flows. OPEC capacity curtailments will affect future flows.

Novozymes logged sales growth of 19% in bioenergy in 2014 on record U.S. ethanol output amid low feedstock costs and positive margins. Market share gains [BLANK] growth, along with new products such as the 4Q launch of Eversa for the biodiesel market. Novozymes projects little change in U.S. ethanol output in 2015 with increasing product share. If low oil prices are sustained, this may cut biofuel growth and investment in next-generation plants that need enzymes from producers such as Novozymes, DSM and DuPont.

Post-3Q Earnings Outlook: Product challenges at Victoria's Secret and PINK are expected to take a bigger toll on 4Q results for L Brands, as executives look to clear inventory and start leaner in 2019. With limited commentary from management on a VS turnaround, the future of the banner [BLANK] uncertain. New brand leadership in place for 2019 lends to cautious optimism that sales can improve. Same-store sales fell 2% in 3Q at VS and operating margin also slid. Bath & Body Works results continue to stand out, with 13% comparable sales growth in 3Q.

A government-led increase in the payout ratio for Russian oil and gas companies, meant to help combat the widening deficit, could damage their capital spending. The government [BLANK] on the dividend for state-owned companies such as Gazprom and Rosneft. A dividend increase would support stock prices and help narrow the deficit, which has suffered from a slump in oil prices. Yet higher dividends may come at the expense of lower spending, which would jeopardize future growth potential.

Luxottica owned, Oakley's wearables may increase revenue as demand for such products grows. Shipments of eyewear wearables are [BLANK] to grow exponentially from current 300 thousand and reach 18.7 million in 2020, according to IDC. In cooperation with Intel and spurred by changing lifestyles, Oakley launched Radar Pace, a voice-activated device that deepens data analysis and provides users with personalized real-time coaching.

Dynegy's gas-generation volume will again get a boost in 2017 from its latest acquisition, given the Engie fossil portfolio it acquired is close to 90% gas-fired. Its M&A binge has raised total generation volume and profit, even as per-kilowatt margins have [BLANK] with low power prices. Generation-volume growth this year will likely exceed that of earnings, because the high share of Texas plants in the Engie portfolio lacks the stream of capacity revenue associated with those in the Northeast.

Cavium's chip sales into wireless service providers are inconsistent and hurting its efforts to reach consensus 13% sales growth for 2016, despite new products. Its 1Q sales into wireless networks grew amid an expanded product platform, but 2Q sales may [BLANK] due to carrier deployment delays in India. Data center and broadband chip sales may rise in 2Q despite mixed markets. Inconsistent demand offsets the server chip opportunity starting in 2Q. Cloud customers' buying patterns remain volatile.

Societe Generale's litigation risks include lawsuits and investigations in the U.S. related to alleged manipulation of currencies and benchmark rates. The bank is [BLANK] antitrust lawsuits proposed as class actions related to foreign-exchange rates, Libor, U.S. Treasury securities and London gold prices. Societe Generale has disclosed it is cooperating with investigating authorities in probes related to Libor and similar rates, precious metals and possible violations of trade sanctions.

While we, and many others, thought an extended shutdown of Norsk Hydro's Alunorte alumina refinery -- possibly into late 3Q -- was a foregone conclusion, it may turn out not to be. A Brazilian judge is expected to [BLANK] on the matter within the next 15-30 days.

Robust tourism growth exceeding 4%, based on UNWTO data, should extend in 2018, raising shopper demand for mid-, premium-beauty and personal-care products. Yet [BLANK] spending is a major challenge for manufacturers, with changing purchasing trends, currency volatility, shifting traveller routes and new locations.

Computer Sciences' potential willingness to sell itself in pieces may represent an expansion opportunity for CGI. Even amid speculation of CGI's interest in Computer Sciences' Global Business Services segment [BLANK] to enterprise customers, it may make more sense for the Canadian firm, which bought Stanley in 2010 to bolster its U.S. business, to pursue the North American Public Sector unit, which is exposed to U.S. government spending. Capturing that business may pressure competitors such as Booz Allen.

Macau casino stocks' performance is supported by the return of wealthy, Chinese gamblers and new resorts debuting on the Cotai Strip. Those resorts and the VIP segment should continue to [BLANK] casino revenue growth through the end of this year.

China Unicom's monthly subscriber gains dropped 48% sequentially to 888,000 in July, its lowest in almost five years. China Mobile [BLANK] 3 million subscribers, boosted by its market-leading 4G network. China Mobile's 4G marketing push has helped draw more than 20 million 4G subscribers in 2014. China Unicom expects to step up 4G capital spending in 2H, given the government may award FD-LTE licenses, creating 4G competition for China Mobile.

Rail traffic originating in North America rose 7.8% in the week ended July 7 (week 27), based on AAR data. Intermodal (up 9.8%) remained the growth driver, [BLANK] by a tight North American trucking market. Commodities (up 5.9%) were fueled by strong Canadian crude fundamentals.

Solar module producers are continuing to build new manufacturing capacity, with the largest five suppliers by shipments in 2015 seeking to add a combined 7.1 gigawatts of new supply this year. This new growth phase was driven by strong Chinese domestic-solar demand in 1H and the need to [BLANK] supply outside China to allow tariff-free exports to the U.S. JinkoSolar aims to challenge Trina Solar to become the largest producer by nameplate capacity in 2016, with as much as 6.5 GW of manufacturing.

Valeant, Mylan and Shire have the biggest payments due on debt and interest out to 2018. When taking into account estimates of free cash flow, Valeant may be the only one of the three on the cusp of having issues [BLANK] it back. As long as they all meet company estimates, debt should be repaid, though that may reduce cash available for share buybacks or potential M&A. Valeant has $9.3 billion in debt plus interest payments due by 2018, while Shire has about $6 billion and Mylan $5 billion.

The latest switch market update from IDC suggests that port volumes remain healthy even amid falling port prices as customers increasingly adopt cheaper, generic switches. Growth in the overall L2-3 switch market [BLANK] in 1Q amid falling prices. Switch revenue rose just 0.7% vs. 1Q14 to $6.2 billion, down from 3.7% growth in 4Q14 and 1.1% in 1Q14, according to IDC. Still, port shipments rose 4.4% in 1Q vs. the prior year, posting a more modest decline relative to 5.1% growth in 1Q14.

Orders on Northrop Grumman's KC-10 tanker maintenance contract appeared to rebound in 2H, possibly indicating increased military usage of the planes. Orders [BLANK] $286 million through Oct. 9, the latest date for which data are available. That compares with full-year orders of $388 million in 2014 and $257 million in 2013. The uptick in orders is probably most meaningful for AAR and Sequa, subcontractors that get a larger share of their revenue from KC-10 work than Northrop does.

Tempur Sealy preannounced revised 2016 revenue and Ebitda guidance amid weak 3Q sales. The expected sales decline of 1-3% and Ebitda growth of 12% vs. the prior estimate of 17% corroborates recent U.S. retail sales figures showing consumers [BLANK] back on discretionary spending. That could cause industry group ISPA to further lower its 2016 outlook. As profitability improvements from lower costs slow, Tempur may miss its 2017 Ebitda goal of $650 million, a key metric for CEO Scott Thompson's compensation.

We expect Qualcomm's multifront licensing dispute with Apple begin taking shape in 2H as trial decisions are made in key lawsuits in China, Germany and the U.S. The widespread litigation serves as a proxy for [BLANK] discussions, where Qualcomm's tech-licensing segment aims to recoup $4 billion in such annual revenue from Apple.

Macau's casinos are transitioning toward the mass-market segment, given it represents almost 50% of the venue's March gaming revenue. Junket-supported "high rollers" [BLANK] about 54% of the total, compared with a peak of 74% in 2011. Casinos are strategically focusing on the more profitable and sustainable mass-market segment with the expansion of Cotai-based integrated resorts. Melco Crown's Studio City, which opened in October, has multiple non-gaming attractions and no VIP rooms.

It would probably take an act of Congress for the U.S. government to oversee induced seismicity, or earthquakes caused by oil and gas wastewater injections. While the Environmental Protection Agency oversees waste wells, states are [BLANK] on the matter of earthquakes. The EPA sets injection-well requirements to protect drinking water that states can oversee if they have similar standards. Most run those programs and some have begun to address seismicity with specific requirements or monitoring.

More power plant deals are likely following Talen's announced sale of 996 megawatts of power plant capacity in Pennsylvania to Canadian energy infrastructure companies TransCanada and Brookfield Renewable Energy Partners. Talen may [BLANK] to sell at least 400 megawatts of additional capacity as a regulatory requirement for its merger of the PPL and Riverstone asset portfolios. NRG has also said that it plans to sell some of its fossil-fuel burning plants.

A reinstatement of the expired blenders' tax credit (BTC) may be less likely with strong pro-American business-policy rhetoric from U.S. President Donald Trump. The $1 tax credit per gallon of biodiesel that has historically been reinstated about a year after lapsing could thus [BLANK] into a producers' tax credit.

Property and casualty insurers generate a large portion of revenue from the investment of premiums prior to paying claims. Premiums are primarily [BLANK] in fixed-income assets with an average credit rating of AA/Aa and duration close to four years. Changes in interest rates have a prolonged effect on revenue, yet flow through earnings gradually. After falling to an average 2.57% in 2012, AA rated, 10-year corporate yields rose to 3.05% in 2013 and 3.18% through Nov. 14.

Investment banks and independent research houses have a chance to sway IPO reform, as the U.K. FCA's consultation on planned changes remains open for comment until June 1. Meanwhile, the U.K. prepares for the June 8 general election, as the result will [BLANK] the direction of Brexit negotiations and financial-services companies' access to the single market. In Brussels, the European Parliament's financials committee will debate the pros and cons of introducing a pan-EU covered bond framework.

Canada Goose's weak corporate governance resembles European luxury peers that tend to score lower on board oversight and shareholder rights measures than North American apparel companies. Many luxury companies have [BLANK] shareholders, but corporations should put in place governance structures to protect minority investors. Canada Goose's board is stacked with its owners, and unequal voting rights that entrench their control may not reassure potential outside investors.

Shanghai hotels' demand-supply gap may narrow further through 2017 as more tourist attractions lure overnight visitors. A projected 10 million annual visitors to Shanghai Disneyland [BLANK] citywide hotel demand growth given the theme park's proximity to the city center, ease of access via the metro and limited hotels. Shanghai's room night demand has expanded 41% since 2011, outpacing room night supply, which rose only 13%. It has filled excess room supply faster than other cities across China.

Given improved holiday sales momentum, the focus is expected to shift to Nordstrom's 2018 guidance when it reports 4Q results. Over the holidays, same-store sales rose 1.2%, with [BLANK] momentum across all segments. Still, pressure at Rack stores from lack of compelling inventory remains a headwind, which may take some time to reverse. Margins are expected to stay pressured from rising shipping costs and investments in technology. Consensus estimates call for $1.25 in 4Q EPS and $3.20 in 2018.

Drugmakers in brand-generic patent disputes are shifting to new settlement strategies, after an unfavorable Supreme Court ruling opened up reverse payment pacts to antitrust scrutiny and litigation. Such "pay-for-delay" agreements [BLANK] by 65% from their peak in fiscal 2012, according to Federal Trade Commission data.

Exchange-traded and mutual funds with significant exposure to derivatives may have to decrease holdings if an SEC proposal is ever finalized -- a tall task. The proposal would [BLANK] a fund's derivatives exposure, calculated by one of two alternative limitations, and require segregation of liquid assets (cash and cash equivalents). The plan also would require funds to have a derivatives risk management program. The agency is also considering whether to increase disclosures of derivatives holdings data.

China's power sector continues to suffer from oversupply, despite consumption growth recovering in 2017. The government's agenda to [BLANK] the generation mix toward clean-energy sources further clouds the outlook for coal-fired plants.

Jazz and generic-drug maker Roxane will address Roxane's pending motion to dismiss a portion of Jazz's complaint related to a Xyrem method patent at an Oct. 27 court conference. The patent, [BLANK] in 2033, covers treatment methods using sodium oxybate, Xyrem's active ingredient, with a mood stabilizer. Roxane argued that interactions between the drugs are laws of nature and that the patent covering that method is invalid. Jazz contested those assertions.

Bank of Montreal's 2018 loan-loss provisions may be C$720 million, according to estimates, down 7% year-over-year (even lower excluding a 3Q17 allowance). Provisions in 1H were lower due to recoveries [BLANK] by an improved economic outlook. Management continues to expect provisions to be in the low- to mid-20-bps level for 2018, implying stability with 2017. BMO's gross-impaired-loans ratio of 58 bps and provision for credit losses on impaired loans ratio was 18 bps. Adoption of IFRS-9 may add provision volatility on a quarterly basis.

Relative North American spot trucking demand jumped 12.3% sequentially to 26 in the week ended March 31, as measured by Truckstop.com's Market Demand Index. Capacity tightened as available loads increased 6.3% while the number of available trucks [BLANK] 5.3%. Average spot pricing rose for the sixth straight week, as rates rose for all equipment types led by dry-van and flatbed (each up 2.6%). Fuel surcharges inched 0.5% lower, falling for the third consecutive week.

Bombardier's CSeries and CRJ program was shut out at the show, while the Q400 garnered an order from WestJet. Bombardier has time to sell more CSeries to [BLANK] its goal of 300 firm orders by the time the aircraft enters service late this year. The miss on 10-seater sales to AirCastle, a lessor, and Guizhou Airlines was concerning. The programs most efficient aircraft is likely the CS300, sized about 130 seats, which may compete better, although against smaller-sized Boeing and Airbus narrow-bodies.

A below-normal withdrawal from U.S. natural gas storage is expected for the week ended Feb. 10, as warmer weather eased consumption. Average temperatures were above the 10-year norm in the period, [BLANK] heating-degree days below last year's level. Gas delivered to consumers fell, driven by reduced residential and commercial use. Still, robust flows to Mexico and LNG exports provided an outlet for nearly 6.2 bcf a day of supply. At 2.559 trillion cubic feet, storage is already 1.8% above the five-year norm.

Declining loan-application volume and gain-on-sale margins suggest weakness in U.S. mortgage-banking revenue in 2Q. Refinancing applications [BLANK] the generally declining trend since early 2017, with the exception of a brief period of increases earlier this year. Housing prices are on the rise, reaching new peaks.

Fastweb is the only broadband operator to have expanded its subscriber market share consistently in Italy in the past five years. Its early fiber-to-the-cabinet network investments drove expansion and [BLANK] in its largest 50% share of high-speed broadband in 4Q. As a result, Fastweb has achieved the lowest churn of peers and a stable revenue. With a virtual mobile network agreement and pay-TV partnership with Sky, the company represents the greatest risk to Telecom Italia and Vodafone's fiber-expansion plans.

Fitness tracker makers such as Fitbit and Garmin can lure Android users in the near term, as the smartwatch ecosystem is still nascent. The Apple Watch only [BLANK] with iOS, which has 16% of the market. Fitbit's cheaper prices, longer battery life and weaker competition from Android smartwatches may aid near-term sales growth. IDC projects 43 million smart wearables will be sold in 2016, led by Apple, while basic wearables may jump 30% to 68 million.

A Citigroup unit won dismissal on Sept. 8 of most claims in a $2.3 billion suit by Pimco and other residential mortgage-backed securities investors, yet those claims may resurface in a state court in 4Q. The federal court [BLANK] jurisdiction on claims related to 24 of 27 trusts at issue against Citibank in its role as RMBS trustee. In a similar suit against U.S. Bank, investors refiled claims in state court about a month after a federal court declined jurisdiction on most claims.

Higher average amount spent per transaction spurred sales at U.S. fashion-focused shoe retailers from March 31 through April 24. While the number of transactions, a proxy for shopper traffic, declined 0.5% from a year earlier as the rate of consumer purchases slowed after Easter, average transaction size [BLANK] by 1.6%. Combining these two factors, the category's total sales advanced 1.6% compared with the same period last year, according to SpendTrend's non-cash, point-of-sale data.

Intuitive Surgical is on the verge of a new product cycle after its da Vinci X system was approved by the FDA at the end of May. Early color on the launch trajectory of the X will [BLANK] a significant amount of attention. Analysts have boosted revenue estimates for the full year only modestly since 1Q, even after management raised guidance for procedures. Estimates may not have caught up to expectations, given Intuitive has been the best-performing large-cap medical-technology stock in 2017, up almost 50%.

The rapid growth in China's tourism industry is a key driver in the country's shift to a consumer-oriented economy. The sector's contribution to 2016 GDP is [BLANK] to be more than double the 4% in 2014. Burgeoning Chinese travel, increased tourism investments, improving infrastructure and new attractions support the industry's growth. This aids revenue gains for tourism-related businesses such as hotels and transportation, while also creating opportunities for relatively new ones such as car rental.

CEOs and directors at industrial companies have the lowest average level of potential over-commitment for serving on other company boards, possibly improving oversight.
