FERC's second announcement, a proposal that all pipelines would have to adjust rates or justify no adjustment based on corporate tax rate decreases, [BLANK] only to natural gas pipelines at this time.

With integration activities that disrupted OneMain's branch-level collections in 2016 and early 2017 complete, we expect credit losses to further dissipate in 2018. A shift toward secured loans, which typically [BLANK] 50% lower losses, should also moderate OneMain's loss rate. The company expects a net loss rate of less than 7% for 2018 vs. 6.7% in 2017. Delinquency rates are trending lower. Secured loans were 43% of the 2017 total, up from 36% a year earlier.

Further compression in investment grade has reduced option-adjusted spreads to 106 bps, the lowest levels since spring, though returns have struggled to keep pace amid rising rates. With a busy week ahead for the Treasury, and the Fed expected to tack 25 bps onto the benchmark rate on Sept. 26, high grade returns will again [BLANK] on rates.

Consensus expects 6% median per-share growth in North American food dividends in 2015, amid slack domestic demand and weakening developing market conditions. On a market capitalization weighted basis, 7.6% dividend per share growth in 2015 is expected, [BLANK] by Grupo Bimbo (37%) and Gruma (22%). These companies are supported by recent acquisitions and lower grain-based animal feed costs. The projected group dividend payout ratio is 45.1%, modestly below its 48.5% three-year average.

Community has been the most acquisitive hospital operator, though its scale and abundance of experience hasn't boosted Ebitda margins. This is partly due to poor admissions and lower revenue per [BLANK] admission at legacy HMA facilities. Similarly, the company has focused intently on acquiring rural hospitals, which typically have to pay more to recruit doctors. Still, the company can improve Ebitda margins by divesting unprofitable HMA facilities, which would likely also reduce bad debt expenses.

Comcast's Universal has taken in $1.93 billion at the domestic box office this year as of Aug. 3, thanks to "Jurassic World," which has grossed $632 million to-date, and "Minions" at $288 million. Universal may [BLANK] the $2 billion mark by summer's end, making it the first studio to reach that milestone this year, with its biographical drama "Straight Outta Compton" expected to take in $37 million in its Aug. 14 opening and a $105 million total. Disney is No. 2 with $1.37 billion, followed by Warner's $1.2 billion.

Enterprise's Nimble Storage M&A expands it in fast-growing all-flash storage arrays. The $1.2 billion valuation is roughly in-line with peers and [BLANK] $12.50 a share in cash and $200 million of equity awards. HPE faces declining IT spending, which is moving to the public cloud, and faster, more agile corporate IT. With this deal, HPE's slowing servers and storage grow in high-growth all-flash systems, enabling it to better compete with Dell, NetApp and cloud vendors Google, Amazon and Microsoft.

Automakers in China may continue to add capacity at a faster pace than car sales in the next two years, despite declining factory utilization rates. That may [BLANK] the view that China auto sales haven't reached full potential. China had about 99 cars per 1,000 people last year, vs. over 400 in the U.S. Tough competition also pushes some carmakers to build more capacity to protect market share. Sales, at 21 million units last year, have a way to go to catch up with capacity that could reach 35 million in 2017.

Copper demand in the European Union has been helped by rising auto sales. New passenger-car registrations in the EU [BLANK] 9% in April, pushing the total in the first four months of 2016 to more than 5 million units, up 6.3% from a year earlier. An average midsize car contains about 50 pounds of copper, implying EU copper demand tied to vehicles may reach 788 million pounds (357,217 metric tons) in 2016. Europe's total copper demand rose 9.6% to almost 1 million tons in 1Q.

The largest EU and Swiss banks hold aggregate goodwill of 114.4 billion euros ($125 billion). The calculation of these intangible assets may get greater scrutiny following 4Q goodwill impairments taken by Santander and RBS, and [BLANK] gyrations in emerging-market currencies that could trigger a reassessment of carrying values. Goodwill restatements and levels were discussed on 3Q earnings calls for Credit Agricole, UBS, Societe Generale and UniCredit and will likely be a feature of 4Q calls.

Debt issuance by NRG and Abengoa in 3Q marked the first high-yield green bonds to be brought to market since the first green bonds were issued in 2008. NRG's $500 million August issuance was rated BB+ by Standard & Poor's, while Abengoa's $600 million September issue [BLANK] an S&P rating of B. This may indicate that green-bond investors are starting to go down in rating quality in pursuit of yield in the nascent market.

Republican support for faster federal LNG export approvals increases the odds the measure will be raised in Congress in 2017. Two energy bills that [BLANK] the House and Senate differ considerably in other areas, and negotiations that began in September to combine them are probably dead after the election. Republicans have little incentive to negotiate with Democrats, since they can probably more easily advance their energy priorities in 2017 under President-elect Donald Trump.

The average age of North American heavy trucks (active and idle) will remain close to record levels in 2015, at 9.3 years vs. 9.48 in 2014, even with higher retail sales, according to FTR Associates. Aging vehicles and rising maintenance costs are supporting new equipment purchases as retail sales [BLANK] at a six-month annualized rate of 304,000 units, well above estimated replacement demand of 250,000. Daimler and Paccar are the largest North American truckmakers.

Teva's patent disputes over the 40-milligram formulation of multiple sclerosis drug Copaxone are becoming more crucial as the drugmaker increasingly switches patients from its daily 20-mg dosage. The three-times-a-week 40-mg regimen is [BLANK] by four patents at the center of a lawsuit and subject to inter partes reviews at the U.S. patent office. The 40-mg formulation accounts for 73% of Copaxone prescriptions. Teva's 20-mg version already faces generic competition from Sandoz's Glatopa.

Macau's May casino revenue surged 24%, the highest since 2014, driven by the ramp-up of Wynn Palace and Sands' Parisian, easier annualized comparisons and the return of VIP gamblers. The Cotai expansion adds capacity, non-gaming amenities and premium facilities to [BLANK] mass-market and high-rollers. The latter's growth has hastened revenue gains, given their high spending habits. MGM China and SJM's Cotai debut should fuel Macau's revenue expansion even with tougher comparisons.

Legislation to require the Transportation Department to set a natural gas storage safety rule within two years and to reauthorize a pipeline safety program could pass the House in 2Q. Since the gas storage measure is also in a Senate-passed bill, it would likely [BLANK] Congress' process for resolving differences between the two bills. Although Congress' schedule is tight because of the upcoming elections, bipartisan support for pipe safety measures may keep the legislation moving.

JPMorgan has gained market share in 2015 to lead U.S. equity underwriting by a healthy margin. Morgan Stanley is second and Credit Suisse gains the most share among the top 10 to [BLANK] third. Citigroup lost share to rank No. 4 from its top three position in 2012-14. Bank of America slipped a notch to No. 5, Goldman Sachs fell again to No. 6, and Barclays dropped further, to No. 7. Deutsche Bank and Wells Fargo were stable vs. 2013-14. RBC Capital held its top 10 rank, gained in 2014, above Jefferies and UBS.

Global economies have continued to implement stimulative policies to promote growth, driving down interest rates and local currencies. The European Central Bank's bond purchase plan will pump additional liquidity into the region, [BLANK] investment yields and weakening its benchmark currency. Investors seeking channels to deploy this liquidity may push capital into the U.S., bidding up the dollar. Any strength in WTI crude oil prices may be restrained, as they tend to be inversely correlated with the dollar.

The Labor Department's fiduciary rule probably will be delayed before it takes effect in April, but dismantling it will be challenging for President-election Donald Trump and Republican lawmakers. The agency likely won't pursue a new rule at first, instead [BLANK] for a change from Congress. If lawmakers fail, the Labor Department could propose a watered-down version of the rule in 2H17. Congress' efforts to alter the rule will depend on whether Senate Democrats negotiate or try to block financial regulatory bills.

Auto sales at STMicro, Texas Instruments and NXP may be diverging. At STMicro, the Auto and Discrete group made up about 39% of sales, and grew a low 5% when [BLANK] with TI's double digits. It claimed that auto sales spread out across segments accounted for the difference. It also cited multiple design wins which likely become sales in the future, but a prolonged contrast between growth rates reaffirms TI's share gains. Leader NXP's auto-segment sales will clarify near-term trends on its EPS report on May 3.

The U.S. Census Bureau expects a decline in population among those aged 82-86 in 2016, an age group that data provider NIC says is the driver of senior housing demand. The age bracket is [BLANK] to grow again in 2017, with the pace quickening in the 2020s as Baby Boomers age. In the near-term, the 69-75 cohort is spiking, but this group is too young to drive senior housing demand. Economic and housing price strength will likely be demand drivers in 2016, before these demographics kick in.

Same-store non-cash retail sales rose 2.4% in the first half of October from a year earlier, according to First Data's non-cash point-of-sale data. The mid-month gain was [BLANK] by 2.1% growth in traffic and 30-bp increase in amount spent. Four of 12 subsectors exceeded the overall gain: sports apparel, mass merchants, grocers and department stores. Mid-October sales at fell at women's accessory, sporting goods and shoe stores compared with last year.

Energy, materials and industrial sectors top our scorecard model, as earnings revision, growth prospects and price performance favor cyclicals over defensive plays, much like last month. One caveat: following recent outperformance, the upside potential to consensus targets is now limited for these groups (2-5%), making potential positive surprises during the upcoming results key to [BLANK] what is increasingly a momentum market.

The Cass Freight Shipment Index decreased 2.6% in July vs. last year. Shipments were little [BLANK] from June, which is 320 bps above the 10-year average. The Cass Expenditures Index fell 5.1% on a yearly basis, and inched 0.6% lower from June. Expenditures are pressured by excess capacity and cheap fuel that drives surcharges lower, influencing shipper pricing. Year-to-date, shipments are 4% lower and expenditures are down 8%. High inventories and conservative consumer spending may limit growth in 2H.

Rail-maintenance demand in China should jump this year, especially for equipment installed during the 2009 construction boom. This is likely to [BLANK] Zhuzhou CRRC's profitability. Railway-maintenance machinery, at about 10% of revenue, probably has wider margins than other segments, giving it potential to accelerate profit growth. In the past seven years, Zhuzhou CRRC's revenue from rail-maintenance machinery has been closely correlated with the length of China's railway network.

Post-4Q Earnings Outlook: Results reflected double-digit revenue growth and a much better margin performance than last quarter, though guidance implies some moderation in fiscal 2018 due to tougher energy comparisons and lingering wage and insurance cost pressures. Organic uniform growth is expected to [BLANK] about 200 bps from 2H17, to 2-3%, though recent industry consolidation offers upside potential via share gains and better pricing. Specialty Garments and First Aid both contributed positively to earnings growth.

Solar cells and modules imported to the U.S. from China are at risk of new tariffs within the next several months, yet since most imports are from other countries, the impact on the U.S. solar market would likely be subdued. The U.S. Trade Representative on June 15 [BLANK] new tariffs on some products from China, including diodes for semiconductor devices, which includes solar equipment. The tariffs would be in addition to existing duties. The USTR also finalized 25% tariffs on other Chinese products on June 15. Solar companies in China include Trina Solar, JinkoSolar, Canadian Solar, JA Solar, Hanwha Q Cells and Yingli. Most Chinese solar exports are to Japan and India, limiting exposure to the U.S. tariffs, according to BNEF data.

Telecom carriers may be able to reduce the speed gap with cable's broadband network by using new technologies to extending the life of copper networks. Deutsche Telekom's CEO, Timotheus Hoettges, has said that after upgrades that the cable operators might then start [BLANK] about whether they have a "huge advantage." This highlights rising confidence in the strategy. Demand for speed, discounts and cable companies' progress in upgrading to ultrafast-DOCSIS 3.1 will ultimately determine broadband competition.

Drug pricing pressures are unlikely to dissipate given payers' continued focus on controlling costs, often pitting products against one another to secure higher discounts. This is particularly true in areas such as diabetes and respiratory, leaving companies such as Sanofi, Novo Nordisk, Eli Lilly, AstraZeneca and GlaxoSmithKline most [BLANK]. Innovation is key to boosting drugmakers' bargaining power with insurers, especially if Congress lowers regulatory hurdles, increasing competitive dynamics in the market.

Department stores must change their business models as consumers shift retail spending to off-price chains, online and mobile devices from full-priced and brick-and-mortar shops. The industry is trying to figure out how to [BLANK] with too much square footage and create brand loyalty with online shoppers keen on getting the best price. Chains are developing shop-in-shops, their own off-price stores and online and mobile platforms to spur sales. These programs are likely to attain varying degrees of success.

Milk supply, and fat-content, is likely to increase sharply in 2H vs. last year given more productive herds and pasture-boosting rain across key European producing countries, such as France, the U.K. and Ireland. Higher prices have motivated New Zealand's farmers to [BLANK] production. This will contribute to a more-balanced world milk market and may halt further price hikes. Poor weather, herd reductions and additional storage investment for milk powder and cheese led to farmers exiting the business in 1H.

The U.S. corn harvest jumped to 80% in the week ended Nov. 10, up from 65% last week, and in-line with the five-year average for the first time this season. The soybean harvest [BLANK] to 90% and is behind the five-year average by 1%. While the harvest season is normally completed by the end of November, snow and cold weather forecast this week may delay it. Mature corn may be left in the cold, yet is susceptible to damage by wind and heavy snow.

REITs have comprised 23% of Manhattan office acquisitions in 2015, according to Real Capital Analytics data, trailing institutional (33%) and international investors (29%). SL Green has been the most active REIT acquirer of such properties, [BLANK] by its $2.6 billion purchase of 11 Madison Avenue. With private equity and global pension fund liquidity continuing to push Manhattan office values higher, REITs have looked elsewhere for acquisitions, and in some cases have become net sellers.

The commercial success of Gilead Sciences' breakthrough hepatitis C drugs has made the company a target for Democratic campaign calls for more government influence over drug prices. The company is also disproportionately [BLANK] to the Affordable Care Act's drug tax in coming years. Gilead supports policies that can boost the diagnosis of hepatitis C in multiple populations, wants passage of the "21st Century Cures" bill and is wary of alleged abuse of the 340B drug-discount program by safety-net hospitals.

While Home Depot's (HD -1.6%) 1Q revenue missed estimates for just the fourth quarterly report in the past five years, and same-store sales missed consensus as well, strong growth has returned in 2Q. We [BLANK] much of 1Q's troubles due to significant weakness in the garden category from cold weather, as weather has warmed and same-store sales so far in May are up by double digits. Home Depot is likely to exceed its goals of $115-$120 billion in sales and 15% operating margin by 2020, based on growing momentum in its interconnected retailer strategy, disciplined capital allocation that led to a 370-bp increase in 1Q ROIC and macroeconomic trends.

The CKCVR Buying Index rose 6% from the 3Q survey to 101.1, with both power units (trucks) and trailer indexes up a similar amount. The Power Index typically [BLANK] Class 8 truck data, yet actual orders are running well below the index growth, and other industry data has weakened. Seasonally stronger 4Q orders may narrow the gap. Most surveyed fleets plan 2016 orders similar to this year, suggesting no meaningful drop in 2016 sales. Initial industry forecasts assume declines of 5-15%.

Forward P/E multiples (fiscal 2014) for top U.S.-based lodging companies have declined since late July, with Starwood shedding half its gains in one month, following its share buyback plan announcement. Overall results remain positive year-to-date, [BLANK] by Hyatt, up 27% to 53x, with a total return of 25%. Hilton and Marriott have increased more than 20%, with Marriott sustaining record stock prices. Starwood and Accor have underperformed peers on a relative basis.

A potential purchase of Telefonica's U.K. unit, O2, by Hutchison Three would create a combined unit with about 30% of spectrum available for mobile use and a leading 45% share of mobile subscribers. This compares with about 50% of total spectrum BT would [BLANK]. While stricter deal review criteria may require the merged unit to surrender spectrum, this may be limited given the relatively small holding in relation to market share for O2 and Three. Network quality may suffer with capacity constrained.

Multibrand apparel companies' valuations remain mixed going into 2015. PVH's price-to-earnings multiple fell below its three-year average as the strengthening of the U.S. dollar vs. the euro and Japanese yen [BLANK] concerns about sales and margin performance in international markets for the maker of Calvin Klein and Tommy Hilfiger brands. VF's relative P/E remains above the high end of the three-year range as results in the action and outdoor brands such as the North Face and Vans may offset weakness in jeanswear.

First Data's point-of-sale, noncash comparable sales for Sept. 1-25 show that all apparel retailers struggled, likely on hurricane woes and lack of a spending catalyst. Of the reported sectors, women's accessory, department stores, men's and women's [BLANK] steep high-single-digit declines.

The six-month lockup clause on Chinese online beauty-products retailer Jumei International Holding expires Nov. 12, allowing general partner Sequoia Capital to sell shares. Jumei's stock has risen 10% since its May IPO and the company is expected to [BLANK] 3Q results Nov. 19. Sequoia invested in 13 Chinese companies in 2014, six of them in communications and four in the technology industry.

A U.S. exit from Nafta could increase both supply-chain costs and the risk of cross-border investments for the oil industry, even as direct costs through tariffs would be minimal. Nafta's collapse could [BLANK] Mexico's demand for U.S. petroleum products. Trump is ever more likely to signal a U.S. exit, even if only as a negotiating ploy.

Porsche SE completed the acquisition of PTV in 4Q, and lacked revenue in 2017 given pretax profit is derived from it's 30.8% VW stake. Porsche's unchanged 2018 net-income guidance of 3.4-4.4 billion euros compares with Volkswagen's consensus 2018 net income of 13.6 billion euros, [BLANK] 4.2 billion euros of pretax income for Porsche, excluding expenses and adjustments.

Samsung's patent case against Nvidia, and its partner companies, at the U.S. International Trade Commission seeks to block products containing Nvidia's graphics chips from the U.S. and generate bargaining power in cross-licensing negotiations. Samsung is targeting almost all of Nvidia's core products, including the Tegra and GeForce lines and products [BLANK] the components. Graphics processing units and Tegra processors made up 94.4% of Nvidia's $4.7 billion in fiscal 2015 revenue.

The North American telecom market has been consolidating for several years, with AT&T acquiring DirecTV and Leap Wireless, and Verizon purchasing Vodafone's 45% stake in Verizon Wireless for $130 billion. T-Mobile [BLANK] for sale after a failed merger with Sprint, according to Deutsche Telekom's CEO, with potential bidders including America Movil and Dish. The carriers also have made several tuck-in acquisitions aimed at gaining valuable spectrum, while Canadian telcoms remain active.

Standard Chartered's new CEO Bill Winters faces a difficult task reorganizing and restructuring the emerging-markets lender while combating litigation threats that are obscuring near-term earnings visibility. Along with peers such as HSBC, Barclays and RBS, the embattled bank is [BLANK] a terrorism-financing lawsuit in a New York federal court. The Financial Times reported in September that the bank had dealt with Iranian clients in potential breach of U.S. trade sanctions, raising the specter of further redress.

Business barriers arising from the U.S.-China trade conflict are likely to yield new opportunities for other countries, many of which stand to gain from the search for alternative sources. China is [BLANK] options for commodities such as liquefied propane gas, animal feed and pulp, potentially to the benefit of Russia, the U.A.E., African countries and Canada.

This week's votes on the Senate budget will test sentiment on high-profile energy regulations. One Republican amendment would allow certain states to [BLANK] out of the Environmental Protection Agency's upcoming greenhouse gas rule for the power sector. Another would allow state hydraulic fracturing laws to take precedent over the Interior Department's rule for fracking on federal land. Yet there is probably enough Democratic opposition to limit congressional action on both rules this year.

Brazil's hotel revenue per available room continues to contract after rising 68% in August due to the Rio Olympics. The country's hotel demand is [BLANK] by a surplus of hotel rooms, even with easier comparisons. Aside from the Olympics, revpar has fallen for most of the past two years following the World Cup in June 2014. Still, global operators are maintaining an active pipeline in Brazil with hopes of a possible recovery.

E-commerce has become a significant revenue catalyst for small-package and last-mile carriers as consumer behavior evolves with the spread of high-speed internet access and the proliferation of mobile devices. As marketing and distribution channels adapt, density and carriers' margins should [BLANK]. E-commerce growth is expected to outpace the overall economy by 3-4x, and presents the biggest opportunity and challenge for carriers. The last mile to consumers is the costliest part of the e-commerce supply chain.

Bonus depreciation and an R&D tax credit are among dozens of breaks Congress will probably revive in 4Q in a bill resembling S. 2260, though prospects for the renewable production tax credit and others remains uncertain. House Majority Leader Kevin McCarthy reversed course on the credit, which aided the wind industry, saying he'd [BLANK] it stay lapsed. Opposition to the credit may be politically risky for lawmakers in districts with wind jobs.

Hillary Clinton's plan to cap out-of-pocket drug costs may mirror Covered California, the state's health-insurance exchange. Beginning in 2016, Covered California will [BLANK] patient out-of-pocket costs for high-priced specialty drugs. Members who purchase silver plans will pay a maximum of $250 a month, after deductibles are met. Insurers can either raise premiums or cut costs in order to offset additional drug expenses. California's premiums may increase just 4% in 2016, vs. 4.2% in 2015.

Consumers waging antitrust lawsuits against Johnson & Johnson and other contact lens makers alleging they conspired with eye care professionals and distributors to set prices are likely to overcome attempts to dismiss the suit. The assigned judge has [BLANK] a J&J bid to dismiss a sister case brought by Costco based on the same allegations. A history of anticompetitive conduct by the companies and evidence of increased prices since the alleged conduct began also support plaintiffs' case.

Indicating rebalancing, normalization and improving total returns, energy futures lead all commodities in shifting toward backwardation. Heating oil, with its one-year curve about 6% in contango on Dec. 20 (vs. 24% a year ago), followed by Brent crude, natural gas and WTI crude, [BLANK] 2016's shift away from the contango leader board. Low prices appear to be a primary cause, helping spur demand and deter production. Natural gas is a prime example as heating, electricity use and exports increase rapidly.

Ericsson's battle with TCL over patent licensing fees threatens to reduce the royalty rates paid to license the Swedish company's standardized wireless-communication patents. TCL [BLANK] the court to set a lower rate, saying Ericsson is ignoring obligations to offer reasonable licensing fees for patents required to practice 2G, 3G and 4G LTE standards. Ericsson reported 10 billion kronor in 2016 IPR revenue, down 29% from 2015, negatively impacted by a lack of deals with Chinese handset companies.

Biogen beat expectations with Spinraza's first full quarter on the market, and details of the launch largely distracted from Tecfidera's miss. Strong progress was made in securing reimbursement for the drug, and this momentum may [BLANK] forward. Biogen was convinced that patient demand will continue to ramp up, and this quarter's strength isn't isolated. But Spinraza alone wasn't all that drove the EPS gain -- a one-off gain on Tysabri, better collaboration revenue and lower operating expenses helped significantly.

Multinational companies can expect President-elect Donald Trump to stoke trade disputes and retreat from global trade deals, reversing decades of U.S. policy dominated by liberalization. Tariffs and other import barriers are likely to rise, particularly those aimed at China or those [BLANK] as propping up struggling U.S. manufacturing sectors. The Trans-Pacific Partnership is probably doomed. It's unclear if Trump can fulfill a promise to change or exit Nafta without Congress. Renewed sanctions on Iran are likely.

Aggregate cable prime-time ratings (persons age 2 and above) fell 0.1% in May for Disney, Time Warner, Viacom and Fox. Disney led the ratings drop, partially due to ESPN's weakness as the NBA games [BLANK] fewer viewers than the previous year. Time Warner and Fox benefited from the NBA playoffs, which helped boost their ratings to 4% and 11.9% respectively. The election cycle also aided these networks as CNN's ratings surged 54% while Fox News jumped 24.3%. Viacom's ratings declined 1.6%.

State Street's quantitative measure of institutional investor sentiment rose again in June, reaching the highest level since 2003 and signaling an increase in equity allocations, which may be positive for managers of equity assets. North American investors' confidence jump is the driver, reaching the highest level since [BLANK] began in 2005. Measured sentiment is 39% higher than January. Both Europe and Asia are lower, each falling in June, with Europe down 27% since its peak in September.

Snap's early ad tech and audience-targeting offerings trail Facebook's and Google's, which may crimp the ad spending on the platform. Heavy cloud-infrastructure spending and revenue [BLANK] with content providers hinders gross-margin expansion and may see operating-leverage gains lag early Facebook and Twitter results.

Emerging countries such as China and Brazil were historically seen as a source of long-term growth by food retailers, as sales stagnated in mature and concentrated markets. Operating in these markets has become more challenging, as growth has [BLANK], with both food inflation and retail sales easing. Persistent cost inflation has also eroded retailers' margins. Wal-Mart and Carrefour's China same-store sales worsened since 2010, while sales growth at Wal-Mart's Brazil hypermarket slowed after 2013.

Express and courier service median 3Q EPS growth was 3% above consensus estimates. Package volumes were up about 4.7%, while operating margins [BLANK] for most carriers. In 4Q, carriers will look to the peak holiday season for a boost in volumes, and are optimistic that they will avoid mishaps from 2013. FedEx will report fiscal 2Q15 (ending Nov. 30) results on Dec. 17, which may provide insight into 4Q results for the express industry.

Slower oil-consumption growth from a loss of economic momentum, juxtaposed against accelerating production into 2019, is our overarching concern. With U.S. oil output resilient, growth may [BLANK] if spending recovers with price strength. India, Turkey and China seeking sanction waivers to import oil from Iran likely eases views on tightening balances.

Average EV/Ebitda multiples for historic, large-scale M&A hospital transactions show that Community Health has paid more than peers for comparable facilities. Community has paid 10.1x, based on [BLANK] 12-month data, while peers paid an average of 9.2x. The HMA deal was scale-driven and gave Community access to nearby rural facilities, while its Triad acquisition was scale- and growth-driven and positioned it in some urban markets. Triad also provided Community with faster-growth ambulatory surgery assets.

Recent biotech-pharma events include FDA approval of Novartis subsidiary Advanced Accelerator Applications' Lutathera for somatostatin receptor-positive gastroenteropancreatic neuroendocrine tumors including foregut, midgut and hindgut tumors, marking the first FDA approval of a peptide receptor radionuclide therapy. Synergy's Trulance also [BLANK] FDA approval for an additional indication of constipation-predominant irritable bowel syndrome (IBS-C).

Hyperscale vendors including Amazon.com, Microsoft and Google may escalate pressure on the growth prospects of smaller cloud providers by adding more capabilities. They have the advantage of bundling products and [BLANK] on price to gain market share. Amazon Web Services, which is now at an annual revenue run-rate of about $12 billion, has expanded beyond infrastructure-as-a-service into databases and analytics, while Microsoft has been adding security features to drive adoption of its cloud service.

Homebuilders likely will face easing order comparisons as the one-year anniversary of the rate-induced slowdown approaches, following weaker-than-expected demand through the spring and summer. The pricing environment, use of sales incentives and resulting impact on gross margins will be key focal points as builders [BLANK] their focus to a more volume-oriented sales approach. Developments among entry-level buyers and lending standards are also key areas to watch.

Health-care REITs have $7.4 billion of debt maturing between 2015 and 2016 at coupons above current rates. In 2015 alone, the three large-cap health-care REITs Ventas, Health Care REIT and HCP have a combined $2.1 billion of debt maturing, [BLANK] $1.3 billion of unsecured bonds. With an average interest rate on these 2015 bond maturities of 5.2%, and recent REIT bond issues pricing under 4%, interest expense could fall as bonds are repaid.

In the building-materials industry, Europe is behaving like a developing market. Yet the only country raising real concerns is the U.K., while the continent is showing [BLANK] growth prospects. The lack of cement-price increases in 2017 in Europe vs. rising input costs means that adjustments need to be made in 2018. CRH appears more positive on this year's volume, while HeidelbergCement is conservative, yet confident that prices will rise instead. In Europe, HeidelbergCement projects greater pricing power, with cement prices in Germany accelerating by more than 2 euros a tonne, Belgium-Netherlands (3 euros), France (stable) and eastern Europe set for significant increases. In Poland, the company seeks to hike cement prices by at least 10-12 euros a tonne.

Gas output in the Marcellus has increased to more than 16 billion cubic feet a day, even as price volatility has been subdued since benchmark natural gas prices declined in 2008. The rig count has been stagnant after [BLANK] in 2012, while output has risen because of the positive impact from productivity. While the Marcellus is the most prolific gas play in the U.S., the resilience of the Haynesville and the Barnett also showcases how output can be maintained during periods of low prices.

The three large-cap health-care REITs have executed different acquisition and disposition strategies as they manage their portfolios. Acquisitions, albeit [BLANK] for the most part, have been focused outside of senior housing, where asset prices remain elevated. Dispositions have been largely focused on skilled nursing and reducing exposure to specific operators.

Rice Energy isn't defending any lawsuits alleging material damages, making issue-based litigation the company's more likely focus. State-level litigation and regulation in Pennsylvania are likely top-of-mind for Rice, such as the potential for seismic activity concerns related to disposal wells [BLANK] costs for fracking operators. Regulatory delays experienced in connection with proposed projects, such as the Constitution Pipeline, are also a focus as midstream development is a value creator for the company.

Average truckload revenue per mile, excluding fuel surcharges, rose 0.5% higher in October vs. September, according to TruckloadRate.com, 51 bps above the 10-year average. Dry-van (up 0.7%) [BLANK], followed by reefer (0.5%) and flatbed (0.4%). Average truckload rates rose 2.6% vs. last year, which is shy of FTR's estimate of a 3.4% gain in contractual pricing in October. Rates may rise 1.8% in 2017 and 4.9% in 2018, according to FTR, amid easier comparisons and the looming regulatory capacity crunch.

Samson and its creditors committee got approval to solicit votes on competing bankruptcy plans and will face off at a March confirmation hearing if a deal isn't reached beforehand. Samson [BLANK] its plan - - which pays down its first lien revolving credit facility and gives all of the reorganized company's equity to second lien lenders -- to provide a cash recovery of $168 million to unsecured creditors. Samson gave the committee a Jan. 6 deadline to abandon its own plan and support Samson's proposal.

The S&P 500 Packaged Foods Index traded at a 36% premium to the S&P 500 in January, based on EV-to-forward Ebitda. Premiums [BLANK] at the beginning of 2015, due to Berkshire Hathaway's joint acquisition (with 3G Capital Partners) of Kraft Foods, and have remained above three-year averages since. Industry profitability will remain in focus in 2016, supported by low input-cost inflation and sweeping cost-cutting initiatives undertaken by companies including Mondelez International and General Mills.

Aldi's new investments to add and renovate stores underscores how the popularity of limited-assortment grocers is growing and poses an increasing threat to competitors such as Kroger, Ingles, Ahold Delhaize, Publix and Wal-Mart. The move also [BLANK] Aldi's foothold, making it more difficult for Lidl to steal market share as it expands its nascent U.S. business. Smaller-sized stores enable discount grocers to reach more neighborhoods and divert some spending away from competitors.

Eni's gearing ratio (net debt-to-capital employed) is relatively high in the mid-20% range, yet will improve markedly in 2018. Record production volume, driven by major project startups, [BLANK] commodity prices and aided by asset-disposal proceeds and easing capex, suggest a gearing ratio of about 20% is possible.

Keurig Green Mountain isn't likely to settle a lawsuit with rival coffee makers and consumers that have accused the company of monopolization this year, given that a ruling on its bid to dismiss the case hasn't yet been issued. If the company [BLANK] in paring claims, it may have more leverage in negotiating a settlement. Keurig successfully defended efforts to prevent the launch of its 2.0 brewer and the company will likely wait to see if its defense strategy succeeds again.

The court battle between Microsoft and the Justice Department could dictate how Congress deals with privacy issues in connection with Internet users' data stored in the cloud. The House Judiciary Committee on April 13 unanimously approved a bill [BLANK] to the law Microsoft is challenging. The draft legislation doesn't include meaningful changes to provisions of the law that let the government perpetually delay Microsoft's ability to tell customers that their communications have been handed over to the government.

Several Asian nations will be growth markets for the building materials industry, driven by infrastructure projects, increasing urbanization and rising population. In South Korea, robust cement demand [BLANK] output volumes and continues to expand at a faster rate. Trade with Vietnam, which exports 30% of its cement output because of production overcapacity, is helping ease Korea's cement shortage. The Philippines also represents a growth market. The outlook in Thailand and Japan is clouded by economic weakness.

The 7th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals ruled in Caesars' favor when it reversed the bankruptcy court's decision on the threshold issue of its authority to stay guarantee-related lawsuits pending in New York federal district court. Caesars' request to [BLANK] the suits will now go back to Bankruptcy Judge Benjamin Goldgar to consider whether a halt is warranted. It's unlikely the victory will affect the cases in New York though, given Goldgar's decision on the merits will be appealed either way.

Product mix, end-market exposure and technology transitions are key factors in a memory market that's prone to oversupply. Enterprise solid-state drives, tri-level-cell and 3D mix will [BLANK] NAND chipmakers' sales growth. Server DRAM may help sales, while PC and smartphone exposure has risks and opportunities. A stronger Asian market and higher-than-expected PC and phone shipments could drive a DRAM imbalance because these devices carry high memory capacity. IDC expects declines in NAND and DRAM, with a stronger 2H.

Bank litigation risk continues to evolve, cutting profit, capital and valuations, though some of the most costly legacy mortgage disputes may be behind some banks. Further mortgage-backed securities settlements with U.S. authorities may be imminent and some of those costs may be [BLANK] by existing bank legal reserves. Federal Housing Finance Agency lawsuits are mostly settled. Other probes and civil suits related to Libor, ISDAfix, Treasuries and foreign exchange might extend risk for years.

In a technical pattern similar to 2010, if sugar plays out the same, it should recover to extend above the 2016 high. In 2010, the period around the closing low of 13.67 cents a pound [BLANK] the last time raw sugar futures were more extended below the 52-week moving average than the current 28%. The 2010 low followed a sharp rally in 2009, similar to 2016. At 13.13 cents, sugar is at levels similar to the 2010 bottom, but a key difference is positions. Managed-money net positions are near the shortest ever.

Juno's chimeric antigen receptor T-cell (CAR-T) programs JCAR015 and 017 trump Kite in acute lymphoblastic leukemia. JCAR015 showed an 87% complete response rate, [BLANK] with 70% for Kite's KTE-C19. Novartis CTL019 had a 92% rate. Both Juno's JCAR015 and Novartis's CTL019 have orphan designation in acute lymphoblastic leukemia. Both also have breakthrough therapy status. Juno will be starting pivotal Phase II trials this year, while Novartis's Phase II program is under way.

Steel output in Japan fell 4% in January, the biggest decline since October 2012 for the world's second-largest producer, as demand contracted. Japan's PMI in February was 51.6, the lowest since August, [BLANK] that manufacturing slowed. Japanese vehicle sales sagged by 17% in the first two months of 2015, triggered by a consumption-tax increase to 8% from 5% that took effect on April 1, 2014. Japan also may face tough competition from China, South Korea and India.

Down 19% since the start of 2014, EU refined-sugar reached a three-year low, at 508 euros ($633) at the end of September, though the price may drop more, given the end of the 2017 quota is nearing and global prices remain about 40% lower. The EU sugar premium to the London-quoted world future price [BLANK] by 16% in the third quarter. Producer outlooks remain cautious, with Suedzucker forecasting a 77% drop in its sugar profit in fiscal 2015.

Hyperscale customers are significantly changing the data-center server and component markets. A shift toward non-branded hardware [BLANK] chipmakers such as Broadcom, Micron and Intel take advantage of direct exposure to augment sales. Margins aren't necessarily lower for chipmakers, given that Amazon.com, Google and Microsoft are willing to pay premiums for higher-end, customized products. Hardware makers such as Hewlett Packard Enterprise are altering go-to-market models to stay competitive.

Three New York state appeals court judges will soon decide if a lone judge's order allowing FanDuel and DraftKings to continue to operate was proper. That order temporarily blocked a lower court's ruling requiring the websites to [BLANK] down in the state. The Attorney General wants the stay lifted, which would require the sites to shut down pending the appeal. The appeals court could decide whether to lift the stay anytime after Jan. 4, though a ruling may not be issued for a few weeks.

A new class of migraine treatments being developed by Amgen, Teva, Eli Lilly, Alder and Allergan may face difficulty getting covered by payers if they prove to be only marginally better than placebo. Currently, they [BLANK] as effective as Botox with two migraine days less than placebo. It's challenging to get payers to pay for Botox for chronic migraine, according to Dr. Robert Cowan, director of the Stanford Headache Clinic. Out-of-pocket costs for patients may be $1,500 every three months.

Headship rates increase with age because older populations are more likely to form a household. Headship rates are highest for the 65-and-older population, a segment that will [BLANK] the largest rise in total population. Headship rates show the largest increase in the 25- to 34-year-old cohort, which also happens to be the largest population group in the U.S. These trends may lead to improved household growth, particularly as cyclical constraints gradually subside.

Comcast, Time Warner Cable and Charter have all quietly rolled out new streaming services following the launch of Dish's $20 Sling TV service in February 2015. Comcast's Stream TV was debuted for $15 in Boston and Chicago in November, although the cable operator has called it an IP-video offering and not an over-the-top service because it's [BLANK] over Comcast's cable network rather than the Internet. Charter's Spectrum TV costs $12.99 per month for its broadband-only subscribers.

As EU banks approach the sweet spot of cyclically low credit costs, an end to regulatory drag and nascent expectations of rising rates and yields, valuations for many large-cap names remain in line with longer-term means. Key considerations remain the rate of normalization for credit costs, how painlessly excess liquidity can be [BLANK] and underlying consumer confidence. Societe Generale, ABN Amro and BBVA typify diversified large-cap banks, where valuations remain in-line with historic mean levels.

Covanta's capital-allocation program features a dividend with the highest yield in the waste group, though it will likely consume virtually all projected 2017 free cash flow. The company is [BLANK] to the $1-a-share annual dividend and plans to boost it through cash-flow growth over time, though another increase may not be in the offing for some time, with the payout ratio well above its 50% long-term target. At 7x, Covanta's net debt-to-Ebitda is also well above its long-term goal of 4x.

Standards to make freight trailers more efficient may begin in 2018 under an upcoming U.S. rule to cut greenhouse gas emissions and fuel consumption from medium- and heavy-duty trucks. Trailer costs could rise 5% by 2027 due to the [BLANK] adoption of aerodynamic equipment and low-resistance tires. Since that equipment is mostly available, federal agencies proposed a faster phase-in for trailer mandates than for engines and tractors, which will require new technologies by about 2021.

Wind-turbine suppliers are set to receive some margin stability this year from a rising share of servicing business, which offers improved margin vs. increasingly price-pressured turbine sales. Service should retain a higher margin profile in 2018, yet longer term, it will [BLANK] with competition from utilities and independent service providers.

France may boost marine power equipment demand with the installation of 14 megawatts (MW) of OpenHydro turbines and 5.6 MW of Alstom turbines off the coast of Normandy to test tidal energy generation. The Alstom project is expected to [BLANK] operations in 2017, with the OpenHydro project expected to start generating electricity in 2018. France has some of the best natural resources for marine power in Europe and has not raised capacity since building the 240 MW La Rance Barrage in 1966.

Express Scripts' exclusion of Gilead's Harvoni, arguably a better drug and requiring fewer pills vs. AbbVie's Viekira Pak, may deter smaller health plans from using their national formulary. Health plans with fewer members typically adopt pharmacy benefits manager formularies in order to [BLANK] drug discounts. Smaller health plans MVP Health, Paramount and United American Insurance, signed on by CVS Health in 2015, will all adopt CVS Health's advanced formulary strategies.

The largest U.S. banks, already subject to stricter capital and supervision rules than smaller competitors, could see the regulatory gap widen in 2017. One key plan that Republicans are pushing, the Financial Choice Act, would [BLANK] the Fed's stress testing and capital review for all banks over $50 billion. Yet it could also increase capital requirements for large banks. Those banks might also be left in the cold if midsize banks get some regulatory relief amid efforts to draw bipartisan support.

The global packaged-food industry's underperformance in 2017 (up 13% vs. up 20% for the MSCI World Index) came amid intensified group growth challenges. In developed North American and European markets, producers will focus on cost cuts and deals to [BLANK] profit goals amid intense price competition and shareholder activist participation. In less-developed markets, producers will prioritize meeting rising demand for convenience and natural foods.

Greece's four largest banks reported aggregate first-quarter non-domestic assets of 71.4 billion euros ($79 billion). National Bank of Greece's Finansbank Turkish unit, a large subsidiary, [BLANK] almost 25% of its assets. As deposit outflows continue and the Greek government and central bank consider the partial or full nationalization of its banks, sales of assets considered non-essential to the domestic franchises will likely be explored. Finansbank rose 10% in July 6 initial trade on sell-off speculation.

The growth of high-margin digital revenue remains a prominent theme in the video-game industry and should continue to aid results in 2Q. The launch of eighth-generation consoles in 2013 enabled higher-margin full-game downloads for console games as [BLANK] to disc sales. This should account for about 35% of full-game sales in 2017. Game makers are increasing post-launch revenue from micro-transactions and expansion packs, a high-margin revenue source. Mobile game growth further supports digital gains.

In addition to seasonal strength, easier order comparisons during the next several months may be a catalyst for U.S. homebuilders. The peer group posted declining order growth in 3Q and 4Q13 as higher interest rates [BLANK] demand. In addition to easier year-over-year comparisons, homebuilder order growth is likely to improve as builders continue to aggressively open new communities for sale, boosting orders amid slower absorption paces.

Security continues to be a challenge for enterprises of all sizes, given the vulnerabilities of open-source software and processors used in PCs and servers. New threats are likely to multiply amid the proliferation of endpoint devices with different [BLANK] systems, which will drive demand for cloud and artificial intelligence (AI)-based security products.

Allergan may face tougher odds at the upcoming trial against generic-drug makers after the court's patent interpretation order found two key terms indefinite, even while largely favoring Allergan's construction of four others. The terms relating to the extended-release mechanism of Namenda XR found to be indefinite could result in [BLANK] patents containing the indefinite terms. Several other patents in the suit however which also expire in 2026 may be found valid and infringed.

Global investment in U.S. office buildings totals $24.7 billion year-to-date, on pace to exceed 2015's record $27.1 billion, according to Real Capital Analytics data. Germany [BLANK] all countries in 2016, followed closely by China. Canada, the largest such investor in 2015, ranks third, despite a significant year-over-year slowdown. Macroeconomic risks such as currency fluctuations and global economic challenges haven't curtailed investment activity, helping sustain asset values in most major markets.

Cocoa and chocolate product makers such as Barry Callebaut are expanding production and marketing to capitalize on booming emerging-market chocolate demand. Sales volume may grow the fastest in India, 5x quicker than worldwide through 2021, Euromonitor [BLANK] show. This is from a low base, as Indians ate about 9x less chocolate in 2016, or just 0.1 kg per capita. Western Europeans devour the majority of all chocolate consumed, or about a third, followed by North Americans, and have been preferring cocoa-rich treats.

The funded status of the top 100 defined-benefit corporate pension plans in the Milliman 100 Pension Funding Index rose by $12.4 billion in July after June's $20.2 billion gain. Still, the group [BLANK] a $108 billion deficit. The July improvement reflected a $13.2 billion investment gain, partly offset by a $787 million increase in projected benefit obligations as benchmark interest rates fell by 1 bp. The pension funded ratio, a key factor in assessing the feasibility of plan buyouts, increased 70 bps vs. the prior month to 93.4%, the highest since October 2008. The group's pension funded ratio has ranged over the last 18 years from a high of 138% in August 2000 to a low of 71% in May 2003. Prudential leads in the large-case pension transfer market, while MetLife, Principal, Athene and AIG are active competitors.

Nevada's governor signed a bill on June 15 that restored net-metering rates close to the retail level for an incremental 80 megawatts of new installations that, if built, would expand distributed solar capacity in the state by about 45%. Rates that rooftop solar owners [BLANK] for self-generated electricity sold to the grid will decline to a low of 75% of the retail rate as capacity increases. Retail net-metering supported Nevada's rooftop solar sector until the utility regulator lowered rates in 2015.

Forward EV/Ebitda multiples for truckload companies have contracted 4.2% from a peak of 7.4x on June 10, yet are trading 6% more than the one-year average of 6.7x. The group [BLANK] 15.1% above the three-year average and 19% above the five-year average. J.B. Hunt has the highest EV/Ebitda at 10x, given that most of its business is asset light. Long-term debt-free carriers Knight (9.2x) and Heartland (8.3x) multiples also trade at significant premiums to the group.

Contracted and new-loan pricing has declined at Japan's four city banks since 2012, when Prime Minister Shinzo Abe returned to office, because of BOJ easing and weak domestic demand. Contracted-loan rates fell to 1.02% last year, the lowest since at least 1992, while new-loan rates [BLANK] to 0.66%. The decline has damped asset yields and net-interest spreads at Japan's three megabanks.

Shinzo Abe's election in Japan marked the start of a female leadership drive that coincides with a 778 bp outperformance over the Nikkei 225 for companies with women on the board. A strategy of selecting firms with consensus price targets above the sector median and at least one female director has [BLANK] the Nikkei since December 2012; previously they trailed. Twenty-seven companies currently meet the criteria. The group was weighted by market cap and rebalanced quarterly.

Utilities and telecom operators are searching for new businesses where they can leverage their client bases and customer-service systems. CEZ and RWE are [BLANK] the telecom space via tie-ups with Telefonica and Deutsche Telekom. Enel proposed to use its power-grid infrastructure to roll out a broadband network. Telecom operator Orange Poland plans to start selling power to retail customers, putting it in direct competition with local power utilities such as PGE and Energa.

Lexus is beating German competitors by bringing entry luxury SUV buyers into the brand and using affordable vehicles and incentives as the introduction. For the second consecutive year, Lexus [BLANK] BMW and Mercedes-Benz as the U.S. top luxury brand during the summer months. Lexus NX totaled 8,785 units in July and August, averaging $1,638 in incentives over the two months. Mercedes GLA-Class required the least cash back at $561, while BMW X1 averaged $1,329 to move units off dealer lots.

Chinese search provider Baidu has beaten earnings expectations 19 times in the past 20 quarters, while U.S. portal Yahoo! has done so 18 times, the most among global Internet companies. China-based Sina and IAC have [BLANK] 17 positive surprises and Google 10. The group exceeded quarterly consensus by an average of 18% in the period. Tencent posted the most earnings increases, with 17, while Qihoo's EPS growth has been most consistent, averaging 106%.

Casino, which began to cut prices in December 2012, is still facing same-store sales declines which are compounded by the current high level of deflation in fresh food. There is volume growth for the second year as more consumers [BLANK] more items. Casino's extended price repositioning, with its protracted sales payback, may concern those who anticipate a quick payback from similar price cutting at Morrisons and Tesco in the U.K.

Both SAP and Oracle have improved their human capital management (HCM) offerings to better compete with pure-play cloud HCM vendors such as Workday and Cornerstone. SAP has added functionality in core HR and [BLANK] its SuccessFactors acquisition with its Employee Central package, while Oracle has merged its Taleo purchase into its broader Fusion suite. Oracle has used discounts to lure clients to its products. Workday is offering flexible payment terms to new customers to offset aggressive pricing from Oracle.

Commerzbank's non-core asset portfolio fell 10% sequentially to 92 billion euros ($122 billion) in 2Q, with shipping loans making up 14%. Having accelerated its 2016 target for runoff of these assets, the lender announced the sale of nine container ships, enabling the redemption of $216 million of [BLANK] loans. This is a further example, similar to Deutsche Bank's casino sale, of European banks boosting capital ratios and profitability by exiting non-core businesses.

Coca-Cola should increase its stake in Monster Beverage to enhance its sales and profit growth prospects, given this year's steep drop in the price of the shares. The company already [BLANK] 18.2% of Monster shares.

The two leading military air charter contracting teams have increased market share following the bankruptcy of Global Aviation. With Global Aviation out of the program, the Patriot Team that includes the Air Transport Services Group has [BLANK] 52% of $500 million in orders in 2015. The FedEx-led team that includes Atlas Air was awarded 40.2%. Global Aviation's team took 23% of $3.1 billion in orders in 2013-14. The FedEx team captured 39% in those years, while the Patriot Team got 35%.

Chairman Tom Wheeler finally provided some clarity on the timing of the 600 MHz spectrum auction, saying in a blog post that the auction is expected to begin in 1Q and could cost carriers as much as $54 billion. Factoring in delays caused by litigation, this [BLANK] timeline suggests the auction could extend into 2Q16, depending on carrier interest and the intensity of bidding. The AWS-3 auction, which wrapped in February, lasted three months, while the 700 MHz auction in 2008 lasted two months.

Indian coking-coal imports are likely to level off in the months ahead as steel output flatlines. April imports [BLANK] 31% from March to 2.9 million tons. As with thermal coal imports, 1Q coking coal shipments were elevated compared with a relatively low base in 1Q14. Growth comparisons will ebb in the remainder of 2015, given that imports from 2Q14 to 4Q14 averaged 11 million to 12 million tons. Indian pig iron production, the main driver of coking coal demand, rose more than 8.4% in the four months through April.

The dispersion of sales and shopping to online and mobile is prompting retailers to boost e-commerce spending to maximize conversion. Retail store visits fell 8% in the week [BLANK] Sept. 17 amid a 10% decline at apparel retailers, according to Prodco. Luxury traffic fell 7%. Retailers are under pressure to improve store experience, where more than 90% of sales are still captured, based on U.S. Census data. Stores are allocating spending to improve online and shipping capabilities to capture sales moving online.

Biotech and pharma events include data of Zealand's dasiglucagon first Phase III trial in severe hypoglycemia in mid-2Q and Bavarian's respiratory syncytial virus vaccine Phase II booster trial in 2Q. In small-molecule CGRP receptor antagonists, data in acute migraines are expected from Biohaven's rimegepant Phase III trials in 1Q and Allergan's ubrogepant second Phase III trial in 1H, with data in 1H from Allergan's atogepant Phase IIb trial in [BLANK] episodic migraines. Data of Regulus' RG-012 renal biopsy study in Alport syndrome are postponed to 2H.

Major themes affecting the North American crude oil industry include increased production driven by unconventional drilling in the Bakken, Eagle Ford and Permian. This may continue to help [BLANK] dependence on foreign imports, which have fallen to 30-year lows. Calls for crude exports may continue on strong production growth and falling WTI prices. Globally, China remains the main driver for oil growth, while OECD demand may stagnate.

Schneider National is a leading intermodal marketing company and competes with J.B. Hunt, Hub Group and XPO. The company [BLANK] its fleet of 53-foot cubed containers and tractors, providing the pickup and delivery truck service, while railroads offer the line haul. It has relationships with BNSF, CSX, Canadian National, Kansas City Southern and other regional carriers. Schneider puts the North American intermodal and dryage market at about $22 billion. FTR expects intermodal 2017 volume to increase 4.9%.

Nvidia's damages in Samsung's Virginia patent suit could reach $45 million in a worst-case scenario. Samsung [BLANK] Nvidia's chip-manufacturing processes and memory technology infringe Samsung's patents. The case was narrowed before trial and damages can be estimated as a reasonable royalty (about 1-2%) on Nvidia's U.S.-based revenue (about $3.2 billion since 2011). Samsung could also seek triple damages if Nvidia willfully infringed the patents, though such awards are uncommon.

Asia-based producers of memory chips, application processors, and wireless components can look forward to market-share gains if protracted trade tensions with the U.S. drive China to tap alternative sources. U.S. companies [BLANK] these components generated $60 billion in sales from China during the past 12 months.

The shipping industry continues to be plagued by excess capacity, which has driven price-to-book valuations to a median one-year average of 0.95x and a three-year average of 0.93x. Dry-bulk companies, which have been most [BLANK] by the glut, have a median one-year average of 0.77x, compared with 1.10x for containerliners and 1.05x for tankers. The overall group is at a deep discount to the S&P 500 Index's 2.74x price-to-book and the Hang Seng Index's 1.36x.

Sinclair remains on track to get an FCC nod for its acquisition of Tribune in 2Q, despite snags over divestitures. The FCC is [BLANK] about Sinclair's divestment plan, the Wall Street Journal reported April 10. Sinclair still can tweak its approach to win approval. If it waits too long, though, it risks not closing before a court rules on a related FCC case. That could threaten the deal.

Cotton's 30% price decline since April may take as long as a year to benefit margins for apparel makers such as VF and Gildan. Hanesbrands, for example, routinely [BLANK] its largest raw material six to nine months before delivery. It may take as many as six additional months for the purchased cotton to run through its inventory systems, delaying any boost for margins until 2Q15.

The Drewry Hong Kong-Los Angeles container-rate benchmark was unchanged at $1,271 per 40-foot container in the week ended July 19. Rates failed to budge despite additional general increases [BLANK] by some carriers on July 15. These should help prop up rates until U.S. imports from Asia pick up for the back-to-school season. Carriers will aim to capitalize on peak-season demand in 2H, with rate increases to exceed break-even contract levels. Rates are up 2% from last year and are 76% higher on average in 2017.

New EU rules designed to preserve the integrity of financial indexes would apply to some commodity benchmarks, imposing strict rules on contributors. This may [BLANK] participation in the price-setting process, as well as transparency. A legally binding price-assessment process would rely more on transactional data than bid/offer figures, which could limit the discretion exercised by price-reporting agencies for certain illiquid assets to reflect variables such as location, grade and quality.

Biotech-pharma events include Xenon's XEN801 Phase II data in treatment of moderate to severe acne in 1Q. Paratek expects sarecycline (partnered with Allergan) Phase III acne data in 1H, and omadacycline data in 2Q from Phase III trials in community [BLANK] bacterial pneumonia and acute bacterial skin and skin structure infections (ABSSSI). Ultragenyx's Phase II seizure data in Glut1 deficiency syndrome patients are due in 1Q, and Phase I/II data of Tesaro's niraparib combined with Keytruda at the ASCO conference.

Bank of New York Mellon, Deutsche Bank, U.S. Bancorp and other mortgage-bond trustees seeking court approval of a $4.5 billion settlement between JPMorgan and RMBS investors may get the court's blessing in 2Q. A week-long evidentiary hearing was held in January, during which one of the last remaining objectors, Ambac, [BLANK] its opposition. The same judge took about six weeks to approve a similar Citigroup $1.125 billion settlement after a summary determination hearing in 4Q15.

Medical-device manufacturers are closer to winning repeal of the 2.3% excise tax on their products following House passage of H.R. 160, though hurdles, including a veto threat from the White House, remain. The House passed a similar bill in 2012, though unlike then, Republicans now [BLANK] the Senate. GOP leaders may seek to include the tax's repeal, which enjoys bipartisan support, in a broader measure, as passage on a stand-alone basis is unlikely given President Barack Obama's veto vow.

Large-cap industrial and semiconductor stock holders are similar based on objectives of the mutual funds that own U.S.-based 3M, Intel and Qualcomm. Blend and Value funds [BLANK] about half of 3M and Intel and hedge fund ownership of either company is less than 4% of each of them. Sector and hedge fund ownership of Intel and its peers is less than 3.5% of outstanding shares and has been dropping over time.

With chemicals firms globally facing higher naphtha feedstock costs since oil prices rose in 2010, many have increasingly shifted raw materials toward propane. In the 2012-14 time frame, the propane-to-naphtha ratio [BLANK] 40% below the 2001-11 period as U.S. propane output expanded. People bullish on both non-U.S. petrochemicals and propane-to-propylene plants globally suggest the new, lower ratio can persist, given supply growth has structurally severed the impact of propane and oil prices.

Neither FERC nor the court case's petitioners are likely to consider settlement in the federal appeals court action related to the challenge to AIM's FERC certificate. The case - seeking to vacate FERC's order [BLANK] facility siting - doesn't have a monetary component, meaning there would be little for the parties to take part in settlement talks. This is more of an all-or-nothing action, making an accord highly unlikely. And neither side has an incentive to come to the negotiating table.

Alior Bank projects about 300 million zloty ($80 million) of annual cost synergies from 2019, following its planned merger with Bank BPH. This adds to the $40 million of savings sought by BPH from its restructuring [BLANK] last year. This is key to lowering BPH's cost-to-income ratio to 55% from 96% in 2015. Cost savings from IT system migration and personnel expenses form the bulk of synergies. Low interest rates and a rising regulatory burden may result in more consolidation in Poland's banking industry.

Macy's mall REIT landlords are willing to work with their department-store tenants, often with the goal of replacing them. While Macy's has [BLANK] its in-store challenges to declining shopper traffic, mall REITs contend they can bring in non-department-store anchor tenants that will increase traffic to the rest of the mall. The problem is, those malls where the space would be in demand from other users are also the ones where Macy's would like to remain.

Hunt, the largest intermodal marketing company in the U.S., expects its revenue and demand to increase next year. Excluding fuel surcharges, revenue per load may rise 2% to 4% on the heels of 7% to 10% higher demand, management said in [BLANK] its 2015 expectations. Originated loads from the East (up 12%) are expected to outpace growth in transcontinental (up 6%) loads. Norfolk's and CSX's intermodal franchises are most exposed to eastern growth.

U.S.-based shoe retailers' sales remained unchanged through the first two weeks of July as a decrease in transaction size offset improved traffic. Transactions volume [BLANK], most likely due to higher e-commerce traffic and in-store stabilization. The number of transactions jumped 1.5% from a year earlier, based on SpendTrend's point-of-sale data. The average amount spent per transaction declined 1.4%, signaling that the number of online purchases, which are often smaller than in-store, continues to expand.

Hyperscale, or "Cloud 2.0," customers are reverting from drives with PCI-Express connectivity to older, slower SAS technology, SanDisk said on its 1Q earnings call. This unusual move is likely [BLANK] by economics. Cost-conscious buyers such as Facebook and Amazon may favor SAS for their solid-state drives as they seek storage that's faster than hard-disk drives and cheaper than newer PCI-Express systems. That's unusual for hyperscale data centers that typically favor the fastest systems for better user experiences.

Domestic crude inventory growth trends continue to imply elevated storage levels even with a slight expected draw of over 668,000 barrels in the week ended Nov. 27, based on consensus. Near-term prices will remain pressured even though crude benchmarks are down more than 20% in 2015, driven by inventories across the petroleum value chain [BLANK] demand. Geopolitics and sectarian tensions persist, which may inspire a transitory price recovery. Yet OPEC output will be maintained, suppressing global prices longer.

Demand for distributed solar systems relies on customers saving money on their electricity bills, in part via compensation for excess solar-generated power exported to the grid. States are responsible for compensation rules and at least 15 have regulatory cases to [BLANK] them, a risk to future demand for installers.

Merck's R&D expense from 2011-13 was among the highest in the large pharma peer group, yet this, with the exception of Keytruda and its hepatitis C vaccine, hasn't translated into meaningful sales. The ILLUMINATE trial failure for the lupus drug tabalumab may have weighed on Eli Lilly's R&D return, which [BLANK] second lowest. Both companies have shown improvements on this metric since the last analysis in May, driven by consensus sales increases for cancer drugs Keytruda (Merck) and Cyramza (Lilly).

Consumer financial-service providers have until Aug. 22 to comment on the CFPB's arbitration proposal, and then the agency will analyze responses. After that, the agency probably won't [BLANK] much public feedback. Companies won't need to comply with the CFPB's proposed ban on pre-dispute arbitration agreements until early 2018, at the earliest. Dodd-Frank requires that the regulation apply only to arbitration agreements entered into at least 180 days from the final rule's effective date.

Many Asian economies face an extended credit downturn and a rising U.S. Fed funds rate in 2017, and President Donald Trump's policies could darken the outlook. Slowing exports to the U.S. from China may [BLANK] some nations' loan quality. Higher U.S. rates might weaken Asian currencies and asset prices. Higher Asian rates, which may be delayed in several economies due to ample liquidity, should help banks' margins but dim their credit-quality outlook. Trade could be disrupted by proposed U.S. tax policies.

Deutsche Bank and Credit Suisse restructurings helped drive 2Q fixed-income trading revenue declines vs. the year-ago quarter. This [BLANK] with broader gains at other global investment bank peers and an aggregate increase vs. both 2Q15 and 1Q. The late-June Brexit vote helped to fuel volumes, especially for currency and rates businesses, after March strength carried into April and May. Trading volumes and tighter spreads show a healthy start to 3Q, though seasonal trends may yet prevail.

Independent producers of natural gas in Russia need to work with Gazprom, the monopoly pipeline owner, to transport supply from their fields to domestic and international customers. Gazprom gives priority to its own production, which has [BLANK] to conflicts with competitors including TNK, now part of Rosneft. Private and independent gas producers may continue to struggle to monetize production as long as Russia has a gas-pipeline monopoly. For new pipelines to China, Gazprom's privileges may be scrapped.

China Holdings Ltd. is focusing on cost savings and increasing its mass-market business in the face of more competition from new Cotai resorts before its property opens there in 2H17. Revenue [BLANK] an inflection in 3Q16, but its sustainability hinges on MGM's ability to increase mainstream appeal, given its lack of a Cotai presence. Yet it has expanded its market share by shifting focus to the mainstream business. The company's new resort should boost revenue and Ebitda market share.

Liberty Global (Nov. 7), Deutsche Telekom (Nov. 8) and Telecom Italia (Nov. 8) will be the center of attention in another busy week for TMT results. We expect Liberty to have accelerated operating free-cash flow generation, DT to have [BLANK] Ebitda growth sequentially and TI to have remained resilient against Italy's new entrant Iliad.
