High wage costs at full-service European airlines remain an obstacle to competition and the focus of management and pilots in 2017. Air France and Lufthansa profit is likely to [BLANK] behind as they lose share to low-cost carriers such as Ryanair, EasyJet, Norwegian and Wizz Air. The carriers will aim to drive down labor costs through work rules and wages at low-cost subsidiaries Eurowings and Transavia, as they compete against budget carriers. IAG has an easier path since it uses Vueling as its low-cost subsidiary.

Qualcomm won the dismissal of federal antitrust claims from lawsuits filed by mobile-device buyers, but continues to face the risk of tripled damages under a California state law. Plaintiffs are [BLANK] damages for mobile devices sold since 2013 and allegedly overpriced by as much as $10 each. Trial is set for 2Q19.

Hutchison and Vimpelcom's forecast annual 700 million euros ($761 million) in cost-savings from a merger of Wind and 3 Italia implies annual savings of 11.3% in combined operating costs and 4.8% of capital expenditure. As a result, the merged entities' pro forma Ebitda margin is [BLANK] to increase to 40% from 32%. For a company that generates 70% of revenue from mobile operations, this projected margin is above peers, and the forecast operating saving exceeds the 5% to 10% cited in comparable deals.

Sluggish U.S. industrial production is challenging less-than-truckload tonnage in 3Q, given they are closely linked. FedEx [BLANK] its 2015 Industrial production growth forecast 60 bps lower to 1.6%, as robust imports, driven by the strong dollar, are pressuring manufacturers and swelling inventories. Aside from weak industrial production, which has edged only 1.1% higher in 3Q through August, carriers must contend with tough 2014 comparisons when a tight truckload market pushed loads into the LTL network.

China's brick-and-mortar banks will face more competition from Internet banks, which are being promoted by the government. New policies allowing consumers to [BLANK] bank accounts online and setting a regulatory framework for online payment may boost client bases for Web-payment platforms and Internet banks at the expense of traditional lenders. China banks may also face a squeeze on fees as the PBOC promotes low-cost or free online fund transfers.

Regeneron's Dupixent and Merck KGaA's Bavencio, which are co-developed with Sanofi and Pfizer, respectively, were the standout novel FDA drug wins among biotech companies in 1Q. Other highlights include Tesaro's Zejula, which will [BLANK] against AstraZeneca's Lynparza and Clovis' Rubraca. Comparing survival benefits across Phase III trials suggests Zejula, as a maintenance therapy, should dominate non-BRCA-mutant ovarian cancer regardless of HRD status for now, while Lynparza will lead the BRCA-mutant market.

Sustained weakness in the Mexican peso may mean a decline of refined product exports to Mexico. A collapse in crude prices in the past year has hurt oil production, and government revenue from the industry, and as much of this year's output was [BLANK] at a higher price the impact may be more severe in 2016. U.S. refiners may find that gasoline and diesel exports from the Gulf Coast into Mexico become less competitive, made worse by a weaker Mexican economy which will mean lower gasoline consumption forecasts.

Retail property cap rates rose 10 bps in 1Q to 6.6%, the second straight quarterly increase, according to Real Capital Analytics. Overall deal volume [BLANK], despite the fact that it included Regency Centers' almost $5 billion acquisition of Equity One. Cap rates of large, multi-tenant centers rose 50 bps in 1Q to 7.4%, the highest since 4Q13. The Regency/Equity One transaction made up about one third of the deal flow. Small and/or single-tenant property cap rates were flat at 6% in 1Q.

Qatar took the first steps on July 31 at the WTO against Saudi Arabia, Bahrain and the United Arab Emirates' blockade imposed last June. An extra-judicial solution [BLANK] unlikely despite other countries' efforts. A decision could come as early as in 3Q18, possibly in Qatar's favor.

The House's top transportation policy writer, Bill Shuster, a Pennsylvania Republican, voiced opposition to Canadian Pacific's proposed merger with Norfolk Southern. He [BLANK] a growing list of lawmakers and state delegations who have raised concerns about the plan to the Surface Transportation Board. While Congress has no direct authority over mergers, it does set the STB's budget and conducts oversight. As chairman of a transportation panel, Shuster has some sway, though input from senators may carry more weight.

Medtronic expects initial data from one of its studies for renal denervation in 2017, which will help it decide if it will pursue a randomized clinical trial for the therapy. The company will release three-month safety and efficacy data for patients [BLANK] with renal denervation in two groups, those with and those without anti-hypertensive drugs. Medtronic's results may be a bellwether for peers such as St. Jude Medical and Boston Scientific as they determine whether to also pursue full-scale clinical trials.

Rising demand for drilling rigs in offshore Norway is driving rents higher. Proposed counter measures, such as creating a common North Sea rig market, [BLANK] the working-hour arrangements for offshore personnel and expanding the rig fleet, could help to reduce costs by as much as 30% and ultimately add 1 trillion kroner ($160 billion) in value to the market by making more projects profitable, according to Norway's Ministry of Petroleum and Energy.

Large-cap profitable specialty pharmaceutical companies have a slightly lower 2015 EPS median consensus P/E of 17.5x vs. 18.5x, though specialty pharma's P/E ratios have risen 2.4% on average this year as large pharma's have fallen 2%. Deals among specialty pharma companies have driven P/E, with Valeant's deals for Dendreon and Salix and Actavis's closing of Allergan [BLANK] P/E ratios higher in the year.

Sony will feature NanoTech's 4K streaming service, UltraFlix, in new TVs, as it seeks to boost ultra-HD set sales through the addition of more content. The Japanese company may sell 7.1% of 4K TVs worldwide this year, [BLANK] Samsung's 23% and LG's 8.8%, according to WitsView. Annual global 4K TV shipments may surpass 100 million by 2018, based on an IDC forecast.

China's position as the world's most important commodity consumer will remain intact for several years. This is likely to mean that the world's financial markets continue to be [BLANK] to changes in China's metals consumption and its transition to a consumer-led economy. China's refined copper demand this year to March was almost three times that of Europe, twice of Asia (excluding China and India) and six times the U.S. The country's consumption is 24x that of India and 91x Africa's.

JPMorgan CEO Jamie Dimon has weighed in on the debate between banks and regulators about what and how much regulation is appropriate, suggesting that banks are now "hamstrung" by regulation and this will increase the volatility in future financial crises, the Financial Times reports. As banks react to new capital and bail-in rules, lenders including Wells Fargo said new rules may actually [BLANK] banks' liquidity quality. New rules have weighed heavily on share prices, notably at Deutsche Bank and Barclays.

Economic fundamentals are firmly supportive of U.S. stocks, though our regime-detection model also shows that the shift to late-cycle conditions could stunt average returns and cause volatility spikes. Late-cycle periods with strong economic gauges [BLANK] to keep cyclical performance at the forefront of sector returns. Value investors may benefit from better risk-reward propositions.

Nissan's revenue and profit are more exposed to the effects of the yen's climb vs. the dollar as it steps up exports of vehicles produced in Japan. The strengthening currency lowers repatriated revenue and earnings when [BLANK] back into yen.

Biotech and pharma events include Phase III data of Synergy's plecanatide for irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) with constipation, now extended to 4Q, and Cosmo's colon-cancer diagnostic agent in 3Q. Ablynx awaits more Phase II data of a rheumatoid arthritis drug and AbbVie's decision on whether to [BLANK] in. Synthetic's Phase IIb C. difficile trial has an interim analysis. RedHill expects pivotal data in acute gastroenteritis and gastritis. Ampio seeks FDA input on potential to file after mixed data.

Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac shareholders have asserted in an Iowa lawsuit that the 2012 "net worth sweep" amendment to the government-sponsored enterprises' U.S. bailout resulted in $130 billion of excess payments to the Treasury. The shareholders seek to [BLANK] the sweep and return excess payments to FHFA as Fannie and Freddie conservator. Alternatively, they've asked that the payments be treated as a paydown of the liquidation preference on Treasury's senior preferred shares.

Croatia fixed its exchange rate of 6.39 kuna to the Swiss franc for a year, putting it 20% lower than existing rates as it aims to ease rising debt burden after the Swiss National Bank removed the euro cap on Jan. 15. The Jan. 23 move by Croatia may [BLANK] banks as much $73 million, the central bank said. About $3.2 billion in Swiss mortgages make up 16% of Croatia's total retail loans. Foreign banks, such as Italy's UniCredit and Intesa and Austria's Erste and Raiffeisen, have more than 80% of the lending market.

A likely approval for IL-23 drug guselkumab in psoriasis in 3Q will widen J&J's autoimmune franchise, helping it contend with biosimilar drags to Remicade and competition to Stelara. Volume growth for Stelara has so far been [BLANK] through label expansion, but its price is being pressured by novel biologics, which have shown superior efficacy in head-to-head trials. AbbVie-Boehringer's risankizumab will need to follow suit if it's to mount a late challenge in the IL-23 class, with data due in 4Q.

Metal producers may divest lower-margin upstream businesses and diversify into more processed and more profitable segments. Alcoa has [BLANK] plans to separate into two companies. The value-added part, named Arconic, will produce more highly engineered products for downstream sectors, including aerospace and automotive. The upstream company, Alcoa, will focus on bauxite, alumina and aluminum businesses. Other producers with diversified businesses may follow Alcoa's splitoff of non-core assets.

No limits on consumer finance rules are likely if Congress moves the fiscal year 2017 spending bills by "regular order," a goal of congressional leaders. Senate Democrats would probably [BLANK] the financial services spending bill if it limits the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau's rulemaking ability. To achieve the goal of individually advancing each of the 12 spending bills, known as regular order, Republicans wouldn't be able to include many, if any, policy riders, particularly any that curb the CFPB's power.

Wynn investors are likely to ask about the structural and cyclical causes of Macau's contraction, as high rollers are restrained by a Chinese crackdown on extravagance. They'll also [BLANK] perspective on the intensifying competition for premium mass-market gamblers. The impact of China's slowdown on Las Vegas and how this balances with other key drivers of the U.S. business is also critical. Investors will also want an update on Wynn's many development projects.

Mexico's retail sales volume growth slowed for the third consecutive December, as El Buen Fin (Mexico's Black Week) gains popularity and pulls spending forward to November. December retail sales volume [BLANK] 2%, 160 bps below estimates. The 2017 holiday season was up against tough comparisons with 2016's 9-11% sales-volume gains. Antad's 8.2% gain in nominal retail sales was mostly driven by December's 6.8% inflation rate.

For-profit hospitals are typically in the southern part of the U.S., with a strong presence in both Texas and Florida, where there is generally less competition from surrounding providers. HCA [BLANK] 19% of total inpatients in Florida during 2012, and almost 16% in Texas, based on American Hospital Association data. For-profit hospitals have begun to expand throughout the U.S. as they acquire distressed assets from non-profit counterparts.

Scripps Networks said its targeted brands, such as HGTV and Food Network, and upscale audience put it in a unique position. CEO Ken Lowe said the company is [BLANK] on quality rather than quantity and doesn't have a need to get bigger. Media consolidation has come into focus after two large distributors, Comcast and AT&T, announced deals that would give them majority control of the pay-TV market. 21st Century Fox recently made a bid for Time Warner, which it later withdrew.

Air cargo volumes for Asia Pacific airlines declined at a faster clip in January than cuts in capacity on weak global demand. Volumes fell 8.4% in January from December even as carriers [BLANK] capacity by 2%. Freight load factor declined to 59.6%, a level last seen in December 2008. Air-cargo yields are likely to be pressured as the slowdown in volumes in January indicates the absence of the traditional pre-lunar new year shipment demand, likely due to ongoing weakness in the global economy.

The U.K. power market is unique in Europe for setting a carbon permit floor price. This should deter the operation of coal-fired power plants [BLANK] by Drax, SSE and others in favor of gas-fired plants. At current market prices, the carbon floor cuts coal generators' profits by 22 pounds ($36) a megawatt-hour by October 2016, allowing for a profit of 10 pounds. The SD function allows users to model individual power plants and market scenarios.

Wynn Resorts' profit growth is likely to hinge more on what happens at its Macau business during the coming months than on what happens to former CEO Steve Wynn's shares. Selling a portion of its 72.2% stake in Wynn Macau to a consortium of Chinese investors would help Wynn protect its shareholders by locking in gains, freeing up cash for investment, and [BLANK] it more favorably for its Macau license renewal in 2022. China-based property developers, and tourism companies with deep pockets and long-term Macau ambitions are likely acquirers. Chinese casino regulators have yet to disclose their license-renewal terms, clouding Wynn's profit picture.

German pure-play biofuel producer Verbio warned of product pricing pressure in 2015, if EU anti-dumping and anti-subsidy tariffs on U.S. biodiesel imports are not extended at the end of 2014. A removal of the duties may [BLANK] large volume imports of U.S. biodiesel to Europe. U.S. biodiesel companies such as Renewable Energy Group and FutureFuel produced record fuel volumes in 2013 and are seeking new export markets as U.S. biodiesel policy remains unclear.

Exxon Mobil is likely to pay something in civil fines for emissions permit violations from its Baytown complex, based on the instructions to the lower court from the appeals court, yet the total will likely be far below the $642 million alleged by plaintiffs. The appeals court acknowledged that some of the claims overlapped and affirmed the lower court's finding that Title V deviation reports -- 4,000 days' worth of violation allegations -- weren't a basis alone for [BLANK] civil fines.

If the legal challenge to the EPA's new rule regulating methane and VOCs from the oil and gas industry fails, then the agency can issue a rule regulating these emissions from existing sources. The Clean Air Act requires new sources to be [BLANK] before existing ones. Existing source rules are in the works and will likely have higher compliance costs. The new methane rule also pulls in oil well completions, which weren't previously regulated by a 2012 VOCs rule that required further controls for natural-gas wells.

Royal Bank of Scotland is defending two lawsuits by Fannie and Freddie conservator FHFA related to mortgage-backed securities sold to the GSEs, including one involving $32 billion in securities and a smaller one that RBS and Nomura lost at trial. RBS also faces a Justice Department RMBS probe, which may [BLANK] in a multibillion-dollar settlement. The bank is defending proposed class-action antitrust suits related to ISDAfix, Libor (on appeal) and credit-default swaps, and is settling a foreign-exchange civil suit.

Smaller energy companies, including Woodside, are joining global majors, such as BP and Shell, in LNG portfolio sales and spot trading because of the growth of flexible-destination U.S. exports. Woodside said portfolio sales, which [BLANK] using a flexible variety of LNG sources to meet contract obligations, can help boost returns as it's possible to better time when new projects start. The company and Singapore-based Pavilion Energy also plan to re-sell U.S. LNG in the spot market.

Truck tonnage still exhibits a pattern of elevated month-to-month volatility, though November was the second consecutive month of growth, up 2.3%. The Cass freight-shipment index has [BLANK] positive momentum since December, rising 2.9% in October.

The Labor Department under President-elect Donald Trump could delay its new fiduciary regulation, giving the agency time to tweak or perhaps undo the measure via the normal rulemaking process. The regulation takes effect April 10, but the agency lacks the ability to immediately order that the rule be [BLANK]. If the Labor Department does take action before Congress, it likely will focus on limiting legal provisions and watering down the "best interest" standards. Yet that process could take several years.

Jack Ma's Ant Financial is investing in the China P&C insurance unit of Taiwan-based Cathay Financial. The experience Cathay gains from Ant may help it [BLANK] online-insurance sales, which are almost non-existent now in Taiwan. Cathay and competitor Fubon said in their 2015 outlooks they will increase sales and cost efficiencies by relying more on the Internet. Taiwan's regulators eased rules last year by letting insurers sell a wider range of products online.

Naturgy, Centrica, Enel and other EU utilities are likely to continue facing headwinds from rising inflation and stronger domestic currencies beyond 1H. To ease the pressure on operating expenses, the companies continue to [BLANK] cost cuts, but it will be harder to do so if inflation accelerates further.

The Midstream Bear Case argues that softening gas and liquids production growth may limit demand for gathering, processing and transportation services. Limits on fracking may further curb production and regulations on midstream emissions could [BLANK] costs. Frac spreads may fall with the projected decline in oil prices. Moreover, ethane prices may remain depressed until new petrochemical capacity comes online and exports begin.

Hyperscale customers' reliance on original design manufacturers, such as Quanta and MiTac, has significantly improved the relationship between key chipmakers including Intel and end-cloud customers such as Google, Facebook, Amazon or Microsoft. Historically, and at Fortune 500 corporations, these relationships were heavily [BLANK] by the service arms of companies such as Hewlett Packard Enterprise, Dell and IBM. Cloud vendors designing and building their own servers have reduced the role of hardware vendors.

The U.S. horizontal rig count plunged by 29 in the week ended April 10, after falling by 13 the prior week. The pace of declines [BLANK] up in the three biggest shale plays, with the Permian, Eagle Ford and Bakken losing a total of 18, after decreasing by 11 a week earlier and five the week before. Horizontal rigs from outside the core oil and natural gas plays fell by a combined 11. Vertical rig-count declines held steady at eight, as directional rig losses accelerated to three.

Nuclear power has struggled to establish a foothold in Asia. Only in China is it bucking the trend, as the nation [BLANK] to almost triple capacity by 2020 from 2014. South Korea is building more reactors, but nuclear won't increase its share of the energy mix. Japan has struggled to restart almost all its reactors after the Fukushima disaster in 2011, which temporarily halted construction of plants in China, delayed work in South Korea and put nuclear power in limbo in many of Asia's developing markets.

Farm-equipment sales may remain pressured by low corn prices that are 57% below the 2012 peak. In the USDA's April WASDE report, 2015-16 corn-ending stocks are [BLANK] at 1.862 billion bushels, a 25 million increase from March. That's 1% above consensus and the highest since 2005-06. Lower feed and residual usage reduced corn use by 50 million, offsetting an increase of 25 million in the ethanol demand forecast. Projected farm prices were cut 5 cents to a midpoint of $3.55 a bushel, in-line with 2015 lows.

Rising corporate indebtedness poses a key threat to Brazilian bank earnings, given corporate loans account for 53% of total credit outstanding. The average net-debt-to-Ebitda for Brazil's benchmark Bovespa index has [BLANK] to 4x from 2.6x in the last year, well above the five-year average of 2.8x. Loan-loss provisions at Brazil's four largest listed banks increased an average 21% in the first nine months of 2015 vs. a 10% rise in loans, with Itau predicting delinquencies won't peak until the end of 2016.

Chipotle's ability to retain customers even amid long lines stems from the restaurant chain's unique approach to brand development and a focus on throughput. The company [BLANK] transactions by 9.4% at lunch and 13.3% at dinner in 2Q. The use of non-traditional advertising such as short films and satires has helped build traffic, loyalty and line tolerance while avoiding typical tactics of fast food operators, such as limited-time offers or price promotions.

Expense reduction and shareholder capital returns have driven the sales-growth-challenged hardware industry in 2014. For larger companies such as Hewlett-Packard, better PC sales have been [BLANK] by segment weakness in servers, storage, networking and services. EMC and NetApp are cutting costs and buying stock as well. Their sales growth issues stem from weaker storage systems demand, as enterprise customers and public cloud vendors adopt directly attached hard drives amid growth of virtualization and cloud.

Delta and AirTran continue to defend antitrust lawsuits initiated seven years ago accusing the carriers of colluding to fix checked-baggage fees even after a judge's ruling in March throwing out the cases. Passengers who filed the proposed class-actions [BLANK] the decision. The airlines also have an appeal pending, but theirs is over a 3Q16 order certifying a 28-million-passenger class. Plaintiffs seek damages for overcharges for checked bags since 4Q08, which would be tripled if the antitrust laws were violated.

U.S.-based banks and asset managers will enter 2016 with regulators focused on finalizing Dodd-Frank and a Congress unlikely to pass much legislation affecting the financial-services industry. The largest U.S. banks will need to [BLANK] with new capital requirements and will see the cost of trading swaps and derivatives rise under new rules. Regulators will look to identify and address systemic risk from the asset-management activity. Insurers will grapple with capital standards and divergent national regulations.

Recent fossil fuel and renewable energy investments are aligned with levels necessary to meet national pledges to lower carbon emissions under the Paris climate accord. However, capital spending would need to [BLANK] dramatically to limit future warming to 2 degrees Celsius, according to the International Energy Agency. Meeting the target would require annual fossil fuel investments to fall 38% through 2040 from an average of about $1.1 trillion. Renewables spending would have to rise 78% from around $300 billion.

The Internet of Things (IoT) has evolved to become the next major force driving broad-based growth across all major technology sectors from software to services. IoT capitalizes on the growing adoption of cloud infrastructure and advancements in machine learning, creating new revenue streams for enterprises and [BLANK] costs.

The industrials and materials sectors of the S&P 500 Index have decoupled from the energy sector and oil prices, helping to support stock-price resilience to oil-price weakness. While oil prices are down 16% over the past three months, energy stocks have [BLANK] 9.4%. However, industrials and materials stocks are up a respective 4.6% and 3.7%, more than offsetting the drag from energy stocks. The negative 0.023 correlation between industrials stock prices and oil prices is near a nine-year low.

Indivior is unlikely to settle its Suboxone film lawsuit against generic makers before the trial decision. Indivior kept its advantage gained by the claim construction (Markman order) through the trial, as indicated in the post-trial briefs, which will likely [BLANK] into a favorable ruling. Indivior has scant incentive to settle before it's issued. Even if Indivior decides to settle after the trial ruling, it would have a better negotiating position after a negative ruling for the generics.

Increased pressure on smaller vendors to improve profitability amid declining sales growth will likely drive more consolidation in the software segment. Recent announcements, including Salesforce's pending acquisition of Demandware, Thoma Bravo's agreement to purchase of Qlik and Vista Equity's deals for Marketo and Cvent, [BLANK] continued interest in pure-play cloud companies. Hyperscale vendors such as Amazon, Google and Microsoft, along with private-equity firms, may have appetites for further M&A.

Celgene provides the best potential EPS boost for Pfizer, based on our model, while its fit is near-perfect. It does bring with it some concentration risk and a patent expiry in 2022, but that may be far enough away to not [BLANK] any worries. Regeneron would also be a very good fit and an earnings booster, yet its relationship with Sanofi could be an issue.

Delta faces consolidated antitrust lawsuits by consumers that could cost hundreds of millions, if not billions, of dollars. Consumers [BLANK] the four major U.S. air carriers of conspiring for more than five years to limit capacity, causing fares for most domestic flights to be inflated. They seek a return of the alleged overcharges, tripled as allowed under antitrust laws. Motions to dismiss the cases have been denied and discovery is ongoing. A related Justice Department probe closed without penalties.

The difference in 4G coverage and network quality among Belgian carriers is narrower than for other European markets. As a result, operators are focusing on advanced 4G+ deployments to [BLANK] service, with Orange leading in nationwide coverage. Belgium's small size allows for faster nationwide deployment, reducing scope for premium pricing, and leaving rising demand for mobile data to mainly fuel service-revenue growth.

Shares of China's eight largest banks lost an average 17.2% in the first two months' trading after their slumps last year. The HSCEI Index lost 18.1%, with the CSI 300 [BLANK] 22.9% through February as the nation's stock market fell on yuan weakness. Worsening economic indicators, such as the PMI, continue to hurt investment sentiment. China banks' share performance may hinge on any policies emerging from the National People's Congress, and on management's 2016 guidance during upcoming 2015 earnings reports.

Sempra's consolidated return on equity may increase substantially once LNG exports from its Cameron facility begin in 2018. Sempra projects that it will earn $300-$350 million a year when LNG exports reach fully [BLANK] capacity in 2019, with no added equity for the joint venture with Engie, Mitsui and Mitsubishi. The company contributed the Cameron site in Louisiana for its 50.2% stake in the project. Sempra's California utilities' authorized ROEs are 10.1-10.3%.

Tesla will probably exceed its target of selling 5,000 cars in China this year with the debut of the new Model X SUV. The Model S alone [BLANK] 74% of Tesla's target as of the end of August, according to China vehicle registration data. With the debut of the Model X, the company will likely exceed its 2016 sales target for the nation. Tesla remains popular with Chinese consumers even after it was sued in Beijing over a fatal autopilot function death.

Prices for kraft linerboard fell for the first time since September 2009, with RISI cutting January estimates by $15 a ton and corrugated medium by $20. RISI's reported linerboard price is widely used in contracts to [BLANK] corrugated box prices. The price for the kraft linerboard benchmark grade was cut to $615 from $630. The decline stems from competition with new recycled supply and a $50 price gap with recycled linerboard, even with mediocre box demand and a December boost in mill production discipline.

Stellar's appeal lies in mass adoption by those with limited access to financial services, most notably in developing markets. Often [BLANK] to Ripple, the Stellar network aims to facilitate a faster, more cost-effective transfer of value between parties, including cross-border and cross-asset transactions.

The most acute impacts from Europe's General Data Protection Regulation will likely persist until 2020, with secondary effects, such as increased compliance costs, remaining indefinitely. As we expected, the new data privacy law had immediate ramifications for the tech sector, [BLANK] user growth problems for social media companies. The GDPR's likely to be a moderate tailwind for data security and cloud companies for a long period, and we are likely to see further effects across the retail, advertising and telecom sectors.

Announcements by Dr. Reddy's, Sagent, Impax and Mayne Pharma that they intend to acquire assets being sold by Teva and Allergan to gain antitrust clearance for their generics deal means FTC approval is likely near. When parties to M&A are [BLANK] divestitures, details can take time. Buyers and purchase agreements need FTC approval before the underlying deal will be cleared. The asset sales suggest that the four buyers have been approved and signal that Teva's purchase of the Allergan unit is in the homestretch.

An increase in higher-end PCs being built for 4Q, cited by Microsoft, may result in higher solid-state drive (SSD) demand for makers such as Samsung and SanDisk. Higher-end PCs are more likely to [BLANK] performance-based SSDs, rather than hard-disk drives (HDD) that offer more capacity. This may further hurt HDD makers Seagate and Western Digital, which are already affected by weaker PC demand. As SSD pricing declines, this trend may move beyond the high-end, cutting HDD makers' share among mid-range PCs.

Western Digital aims to have greater exposure to the highly profitable, higher-priced enterprise storage market. This segment tiers its storage between hard disk drives and solid-state drives, and Western Digital has both options that are vertically [BLANK] in their manufacturing after its SanDisk acquisition. This enables the company to offer a compelling alternative across a variety of performance and cost choices, even as sales and profit are more biased to hard drives over solid-state.

China's new telco tower company, mandated by the government, may help China Telecom and Unicom narrow coverage gaps with market leader China Mobile. Sharing towers may also increase [BLANK] efficiency by cutting construction costs. The three carriers injected their towers into China Tower Corp. China Mobile, which has the most towers and a head start in 4G build-out, holds the largest share in the venture at 38%.

The highly anticipated holiday season is about to begin and may account for 25% of annual box office sales. Studios are banking on strong performance from a handful of blockbusters to [BLANK] weak box office sales that are down 4% from last year. "The Hunger Games: Mockingjay 1," "Interstellar" and "The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies" are projected to take in about $1 billion in sales and may compensate for summer box office sluggishness.

The judge presiding over Cisco's second ITC patent infringement case against Arista is scheduled to make her initial trial ruling (the "Initial Determination") on Nov. 7. The ruling will set forth whether Arista products [BLANK] six Cisco patents. The ITC may decide to review the judge's ruling and is set to issue a final decision by March. Arista is also seeking to invalidate the patents in separate proceedings before the U.S. patent office, the last of which is set to finish by June.

Biotech and pharma events in immuno-oncology include data of Bristol-Myers' study 227 of Opdivo and Yervoy in first-line lung cancer by early 2018, and Roche's additional Phase III trials of Tecentriq in combination with chemo in 1H. Merck's Phase III trial of Keytruda plus Alimta and platinum will [BLANK] in early 2019. Incyte and Merck expect data of Phase III epacadostat/Keytruda combo in melanoma in 1H. Updated Phase I data of Celgene-Bluebird's BCMA CAR-T will be presented at the ASH conference on Dec. 11.

As Adobe's shift from licensing sales matures, subscriptions account for about 85% of the company's revenue, providing more predictable results. Profitability should continue to improve amid this shift, as the amount of sales and marketing dollars needed to [BLANK] new sales decreases.

Bristol-Myers is widely expected to announce the interim analysis of its CheckMate-227 trial of Opdivo plus Yervoy by the time of its 4Q announcement, possibly with the results. The trial outcome will determine how well Bristol is [BLANK] to compete with Merck and Roche in first-line lung cancer, with a real risk of failure, at least on the first progression-free survival read from Part 1a. For now, Opdivo continues to do well despite pressure from Merck, and the weak dollar will help 4Q and 2018 guidance.

The aromatics chain, named after the odor of its products, contains six-carbon rings and forms the building blocks of styrene (white foam cups), polycarbonate (DVDs), and cyclohexane (for use in nylon). Benzene, toluene and mixed xylenes (often [BLANK] BTX) are the three commodity chemical products that feed the aromatics value chain. The main sources are naphtha-based ethylene plants, which produce benzene and toluene, or oil refining for mixed xylenes.

Global fixed income ETF inflows slowed for the week ended June 21, mostly on large U.S. high yield outflows as oil prices slid to the lowest levels year-to-date. While the Federal Reserve proceeded with a well-telegraphed rate hike on June 14, the yield curve continued to flatten last week as long-term bonds rallied on [BLANK] inflation and doubts about global growth. Recent ETF flows show investors added duration, while continuing to favor the additional yield of emerging market and U.S. high grade corporate debt.

Kellogg's venture capital fund, called eighteen94 capital, made a $4.25 million investment in Kuli Kuli, a small manufacturer and distributor of moringa-based products. The investment is the most recent for the venture fund focused on direct or adjacent categories Kellogg serves, and [BLANK] the new boundaries that U.S. food companies are pushing in pursuit of growth. Moringa is a plant protein whose leaves, pods and oil can provide good sources of iron, calcium and other nutrients.

Demand for luxury jewelry in the U.S. is recovering this year, probably to the detriment of watches. Tiffany [BLANK] brisk sales growth in its Tiffany T jewelry collection and statement pieces. Michael Kors' declining U.S. watch sales were partly linked to a rise in demand for its branded jewelry. Swiss exports of watches to the U.S. rose 3% in April, which is slower than the 9% gain year-to-date. The U.S. is the second-largest market for Swiss watch exports, accounting for 11% of global exports.

Macau casino revenue dropped 21% in January, extending monthly declines since early 2014. Yet signs of an inflection are [BLANK]. Gross gaming revenue may be bottoming, ranging mostly from about $2-$2.5 billion since last year. This is supported by new casino resorts that attract more stable, mass-market business, which offsets declines in VIP clientele. Gambling activity this month may elevate revenue with the Lunar New Year holidays starting on Feb. 7.

The $4.4 billion that Kantar Media's CMAG estimates will be spent on political ads won't be distributed equally among states and broadcasters. In 2016, broadcasters in states such as Nevada and Florida, which in addition to being presidential swing states also have competitive Senate races, are [BLANK] to account for a major share of revenue. About 60% of campaign cash is spent on congressional races and 40% on presidential. In 2012, 85% of TV ads were aired in seven states, according to the Cook Political Report.

Large biotech companies had 22 licensing deals in 2014, down 12% from 2013. Celgene led peers with 10 deals focused mainly on cancer, while [BLANK] Nogra's Crohn's drug for an initial fee of $710 million, the second-highest disclosed to date. Biogen deals with Array and Regulus expanded its autoimmune portfolio, while a deal with Eisai added BACE inhibitor E2609. The drug's development trails that of rival Alzheimer's drugs from Merck & Co. and AstraZeneca-Eli Lilly, which are in Phase III.

Torrential rain in France this month has served as a reminder of the vulnerability of Paris and many European cities to floods. Paris [BLANK] major floods in 1910, 1924 and 1955. The Great Flood of 1910 took almost two months to subside. It is estimated that a similar event today would affect 900,000 people and 170,000 business, including 58,000 in the flood zone, causing more than 30 billion euros ($34 billion) of damage. It could affect 70% of the Paris subway and half of the Paris suburban train network.

Commercial vehicle stocks trade at a median 7.8x 2015 consensus enterprise value-to-Ebitda, a 23.6% discount to the S&P 500 Index in June, widening from 22% in May. Most companies expect 1H order strength to [BLANK] elevated build rates in 2H, yet have concerns about freight demand. Truck orders are at a three-month annualized rate of 267,932, and 5.4% lower than a year ago through May. Commercial-vehicle stocks typically trade at a discount to the S&P 500, reflecting cyclicality of sales and earnings.

Medical-device manufacturers are pressing a Republican-led Congress to eliminate Obamacare's 2.3% excise tax on most medical devices, though the chances for action during the remainder of 2016 have dwindled. The most recent federal budget bill [BLANK] a two-year moratorium on the tax, lessening the urgency for repeal. The Congressional Budget Office estimates that full repeal would add about $24 billion to the deficit over a decade, unless the cost of eliminating it were offset by spending reductions.

The Stoxx 600 European telecom index outperformed the Stoxx 600 Europe by 4.87% on a total return basis in 2014. This [BLANK] with December's 1.25% underperformance. M&A news was the strongest driver of stock moves. Swisscom dragged industry performance most on concerns that the acquisition of Orange Switzerland by Iliad founder Xavier Niel will fuel fiercer competition, followed by Telefonica on being sidelined by EE in BT's pursuit of mobile. Altice surged most on its acquisition of Portugal Telecom.

Rising incomes and low car penetration in Vietnam, the Philippines and Indonesia bode favorably for Southeast Asia's long-term auto sales growth. Thailand is likely to [BLANK] the region's largest production hub with its superior supply-chain infrastructure, even amid stagnant domestic sales. Thailand, Indonesia and Malaysia are pushing fuel-efficient "green" cars to draw foreign investment. The strategy in Malaysia may help foreign carmakers offset heavy taxes.

Kimberly-Clark's sharp price cuts to fight off competition are hurting its U.S. baby diapers and adult incontinence sales. Kimberly's pass-through of high pulp costs in 1Q will [BLANK] P&G's recent diaper price rises, but fewer births and online shopping challenge diaper in-store volume. Innovation and better marketing are boosting incontinence sales.

Hedge fund flow pressure lessened in 2Q, and returns helped boost industry assets to essentially offset outflows in 1H, according to HFR data. Performance is a key variable in 3Q as outflows [BLANK] to follow negative returns. Three consecutive quarters of inflows followed the 4.2% drop in the HFRI Fund Weighted Composite Index in 3Q15. A 1.2% monthly drop in December and 2.6% decline in January likely further fueled redemptions. A 2% gain in 2Q was the best quarterly result since 1Q15 and followed a 2.1% March rise.

Growth within the spirits category has switched from being driven by Asian consumers appreciating scotch whisky, to young consumers wanting the right drink for any occasion. Though brand heritage is important, consumers' choice of brands, including dark and white spirits [BLANK] on the time of day, and the experience sought. This offers opportunities and threats to spirits companies, with their management teams trying to understand what consumers want and innovate accordingly. If they fail, growth may stagnate.

Internet of Things (IoT) connected lighting solutions, capable of gathering and analyzing data, can lead to value-added services capable of boosting margin. Acuity's industry-leading margin and growth are [BLANK] by its less capital-intensive, solutions-based strategy. The company's tiered-product approach to building automation and commercial applications, like its Indoor Positioning System and retail-asset-tracking technology, improving retailers' sales and operational efficiency, also enable margin expansion.

With crop farmers' profits under pressure, North American sales of tractors with more than 100 horsepower plunged 28.5% in November, according to AEM. While November isn't an important selling month for tractors, poor sales in the peak months of September and October [BLANK] this year's total down 10%. Strong profits for livestock and dairy farmers have spurred mid-size equipment purchases, pushing sales of 40- to 100-horsepower units up 7.4% this year. High-horsepower four-wheel-drive tractors fell 45% in November.

Office REITs ended May at 18.7x forward price-to-funds from operations, 6% below REITs overall average of 19.8x. At the beginning of the year, negative sentiment from SL Green on lower New York City job growth, as well as expectations of slowing demand in San Francisco [BLANK] multiples. Office REITs rallied back to 4Q15 levels after the Federal Reserve's suggestion in February that rate increases would slow if economic growth is weak.

Coherus has many opportunities that take aim at $40 billion in branded-drug sales but none is more important than the U.S. approval and launch of its Neulasta biosimilar. An approval will [BLANK] the company to be more liberal in spending to further R&D efforts for biosimilars to Eylea (CHS-2020) and Lucentis (CHS-3351).

Exxon Mobil's effort to enforce a partial arbitration award in New York federal court against Venezuela has a threshold jurisdiction issue that needs to be resolved in the U.S. Court of Appeals for the 2nd Circuit before the lower court will unfreeze the enforcement action. That decision could come at any time, as it's been [BLANK] for over a year. The lower court agreed with Venezuela that the issue of whether the court has the power to hear the enforcement action needs to first be decided by the appellate court.

Renewed vigor for the euro, away from the dollar and sterling, will have far-reaching ramifications for many industries, from an investment and growth perspective. ECB President Mario Draghi's attempts to [BLANK] down rate hike and QE-end hopes have failed to stymie the euro's rally. With about 60% of FTSE 100 aggregate revenue generated outside the U.K., dollar weakness reverses a crucial top-line driver. For 70% of STOXX 600 members, an average 45% of sales are non-domestic, highlighting the importance of currency.

A potential acquisition of T-Mobile by Dish, as reported by the Wall Street Journal, would reduce the number of bidders in the 600 MHz spectrum auction, which could severely limit bidding prices. T-Mobile is expected to be a significant bidder, given its pressing need for low-frequency spectrum, while an acquisition by Dish would likely [BLANK] its bidding. AT&T and Verizon don't have an immediate need for low-band spectrum compared with smaller rivals and Sprint may not have the funds to bid aggressively.

Bears suggest EU economies may remain subdued and characterized by high unemployment and public debt, amid a tepid recovery. While low yields pressure life insurer profitability, particularly for those offering guaranteed investment products, reduced guaranteed rates may [BLANK] higher lapse rates, as policyholders seek higher-yielding investments. Alternatively, higher exposure to illiquid assets, in the search for higher yields, may increase investment risk.

If currency-hedged ETFs are any indication, interest-rate hedged ETFs could attract billions in inflows if interest rates continue to rise and they work as designed. Currency-hedged ETFs take long positions in a country or region's stocks while [BLANK] out the currency via forward contracts. The funds began beating their unhedged peers when central banks in Japan and Europe ramped up bond buying, and they grew to $60 billion from nothing in three years. These ETFs have underperformed in 2016, leading to outflows.

Commonwealth Bank of Australia's Aug. 14 pledge to undertake climate-change scenario analysis may open the door to wider investment reconsideration. CBA has eschewed limits on coal financing, such as Westpac and ANZ have [BLANK] in place. Scenario analysis may open the door to considering broader carbon risks across the energy sector, as well as high carbon-emitting industries. CBA reports 2.2% of its total committed exposure is across the energy value chain, with funding by sector, unlike peers.

The Indian rupee appreciated about 2% yoy against the dollar in 3Q and may make third-quarter comparables easier for operators with restaurants in India, including Domino's, Yum! and McDonald's. As the rupee increases vs. the dollar, sales [BLANK] in India are worth more when converted. Domino's operates about 700 locations in India, McDonald's has about 250 and India represents 1% of Yum's revenue. The rupee was down 7% yoy in 2Q.

SunPower is to offer its high-efficiency solar modules for ConEdison Solutions and Dominion Energy Solutions to provide a residential product in New York State and New Jersey. The deals will [BLANK] competition with residential solar companies active in those states, including SolarCity, Vivint Solar and NRG's Home Solar unit. The agreements will push SunPower's equipment demand above that of the existing network of dealerships in the region, as it leverages ConEd and Dominion customer relationships.

Amid weak oil prices, some companies may postpone the construction of proposed LNG export projects, where shareholders haven't made the final investment decision. Projects already under construction are likely to still go ahead as investors [BLANK] them as sunk cost. The Brent crude price of about $61 a barrel translates into $8.50 per million British thermal units of LNG at 14% oil indexation. This is lower than the price a number of Australian and Canadian projects need to achieve a 10% return.

Despite bipartisan support in both the House and Senate, legislation to allow owners of renewable energy assets to qualify for master-limited partnerships, which offer some tax advantages, probably won't advance in 2H. MLPs could [BLANK] the cost of financing for clean energy projects through access to public markets. Yet similar investment structures -- yieldcos with wind and solar assets -- have recently lost value, and industry pressure on Congress to expand MLP eligibility to renewables may be waning.

PolyOne's (POL -0.7%) Color segment will receive a boost with the successful integration of acquisitions. The company is [BLANK] toward faster-growing specialty polymer products and away from volume-driven commodity plastics. Investments in SG&A and product development are paying off. PolyOne added 1,000 customers in the past three years. Input costs were up 10-15% in 1Q, while freight rose 8%. We believe the company's 2020 performance targets, including double-digit annual EPS growth, may be ambitious.

If Internet providers earn an automatic right to air broadcast programming, broadcasters lose a major check against Internet disruption. Distributors [BLANK] a program license and, when the FCC labels it a multichannel video programming distributor (MVPD), a broadcaster's consent. If FilmOn wins a license in this case, broadcasters can't charge more for it. And they can't demand a transmission fee if FilmOn isn't an MVPD. Transmission fees from traditional MVPDs may shrink if Internet delivery spreads.

European telecoms' 4Q earnings will bring focus to handset sales, with delays in iPhone 7 delivery in 3Q likely shifting the bulk of handset upgrades into 4Q. Guidance risk remains low, and most operators are on track to [BLANK] their full-year targets. Still, Telefonica and Swisscom's revenue and KPN's Ebitda are trailing their targets based on performance this year. Guidance for 2017 will likely set a modest tone for growth, given the removal of roaming charges, while Ebitda growth is in sight given cost control.

Guidelines introduced in February 2015 by China's banking regulator may encourage more bank loans in M&A deal structures and provide more flexibility for financiers. The rules increase the tenor of loans and deal-leverage ratios and relax collateral requirements, [BLANK] more bank financing of companies domestically and internationally. This increases opportunities for domestic and foreign banks, brokers and advisers to participate in China's M&A activity.

China's recently delayed entry into Cotai will likely be in focus on its 4Q16 call. On Jan. 17, the company announced MGM Cotai's opening had been postponed to 2H from 2Q due to [BLANK] complexities and market conditions. Macau market win rose 10% in 4Q, following openings of rivals Wynn Palace and Sands Parisian, though MGM win may have been closer to flat. On a November call, management said it would likely open in Cotai without the junket operators who play an important role at its peninsula flagship.

China and Japan's big banks still trade at a fraction of the average valuation for large-cap Asian peers. The four largest Hong Kong-traded banks [BLANK] 0.75x estimated 2017 book value as of Aug. 31 vs. 1.36x for BI's Asian bank group, even after 19% average stock-price gains. Provision risk clouds their earnings outlook. Japan's megabanks averaged 0.58x as their shares retreated after an average 35% surge to year-end 2016 from November's U.S. presidential election.

The return of inflation means EU packaged foodmaker growth will be 2H-weighted as higher pricing is adopted, increasing the temptation for companies to flex their strong balance sheets. Kraft Heinz's flirtation with Unilever [BLANK] the attraction of sustained cash flow and cost-savings potential. The move reversed fading P/E premiums to the Stoxx 600 Index on concerns of developed-market inflation. Debt financing is attractive, and earnings accretion likely, yet shareholder returns may come under pressure.

China's revenue has continued to drop for five quarters and is now below the $700 million quarterly run rate achieved through much of 2011-2012. Before the current city-wide decline, MGM had [BLANK] Macau Peninsula rivals Wynn Macau and SJM in the 2013-14 expansion with a smaller, VIP and premium-mass base. Competition is expected to intensify into 2016 with Galaxy, Melco Crown and Wynn Macau's new Cotai-based resorts opening before MGM's own property is completed.

The beauty and personal care sector's appetite for M&A will likely remain strong in 2018, after deals by L'Oreal, Natura, Estee Lauder and Dabur last year. Rising demand for natural cosmetics, which are [BLANK] to grow faster than mass-market items, could fuel buyers' interest for L'Occitane.

Order comparisons for U.S. homebuilders will be easier in the third and fourth quarters vs. the prior year. Though order growth is seasonally slower in the second half of the year (while closings accelerate), the rapid rise in mortgage rates last year [BLANK] a double whammy to builders, sidelining many would-be buyers. Demand remains somewhat stagnant. That said, improved order growth without the broader use of sales incentives may be a share catalyst for the group.

Following AT&T's acquisition of DirecTV, its content costs will fall, turning its pay-TV business profitable, CEO Randall Stephenson said at an investor conference. AT&T and DirecTV will be the second-largest U.S. pay-TV provider behind a combined Comcast-Time Warner, [BLANK] both deals gain regulatory approval. Stephenson also said that AT&T-DirecTV will become more aggressive in securing mobile content rights by using the added scale as leverage.

Insurers say commercial price gains are slowing and in some lines, such as commercial property, 2Q rates fell in the mid-single digits. Most carriers said competition is increasing, though Travelers [BLANK] out, insisting competition was unchanged. With rate changes beginning to fall short of the expected rise in claims costs in certain lines, analysts are starting to question the timing and degree of margin compression as the underwriting cycle progresses.

With low fuel prices and rising interest rates, economics favor maintaining older planes at the expense of sales of new equipment. Sales and margins of engine makers such as General Electric and United Technologies would [BLANK] from more spare parts sales, as would hydraulics and other components makers. At an average fuel price of less than $4 over 12 years, a $20 million, 10-year-old Boeing 737 or Airbus A320 is cheaper to operate at 225 million available seat kilometers flown a year. Spot prices are about $2.60.

Biotech and pharma events include Phase III data of Rigel's fostamatinib in immune thrombocytopenic purpura and Seattle-Takeda's Adcetris in cutaneous T-cell lymphoma. Vertex [BLANK] VX-661/Kalydeco Phase III cystic fibrosis data. Infinity's duvelisib Phase III DUO trial in chronic lymphocytic leukemia has an interim analysis. Dynavax's Heplisav FDA action date has been extended. Celgene expects the first Phase III data of Revlimid in diffuse large B-cell lymphoma from the REMARC trial.

Miners' spending cuts are forecast into 2017, given low metal prices, global economic weakness and slower China growth. Consensus expects the top 10 metals mining companies, accounting for 75-80% of spending, to [BLANK] capital spending by 26.3% in 2016 and 9.9% in 2017. Coal spending is projected to fall 20.5% in 2016 and 8% in 2017. Spending plans were cut in 4Q as commodity prices worsened, confirming that a rebound is unlikely in the near term. Komatsu expects miners to refrain from buying until at least 2017.

Google's new messaging apps Allo and Duo likely face strong competition from Facebook, which has a more established product. Allo, a smart messaging app, [BLANK] Google Assistant, letting customers use smart reply and Google search. Facebook Messenger's billion monthly active users means it may get better traction by adding missing features to its services while Google tries to poach users. Allo may face skepticism as Google's previous social products, such as Hangout and Google Plus, had little success.

Telekom Austria's 0.2% sales drop in 2Q was driven lower by foreign-exchange rates, with constant currency revenue increasing 2.6%. This supports [BLANK] guidance of modest growth on an underlying basis for the the full year. The sharp rise in handset subsidies in Austria continues to boost growth, offsetting the erosion in average revenue per user, which declined by 6.7%. The company managed to limit pressure from higher subsidies, with the Ebitda margin narrowing only 2 bps to 31.9%.

Vale's CEO Murilo Ferreira told BI'S LME Week Forum that he is positive on the outlook for iron ore and nickel, though is concerned about copper due to supply. Ferreira also said he doesn't expect to see a "disaster" in China and [BLANK] the country's economy is moving in the right direction, albeit with "some bumps." The company's new iron ore project, S11D (also known as Serra Sul), is the world's largest iron-ore mine project and will help boost Vale's future iron ore production.

Endo and Impax may be exposed to damages of as much as $1.6 billion if held liable in Opana ER "pay-for-delay" lawsuits. While actual damages depend on an expert's showing of overcharges due to the drugmakers' pact, a rough estimate suggests this could reach $535 million, which would be [BLANK] under antitrust law. Restitution sought by the FTC in its lawsuit against the drugmakers may not ultimately be incremental. The agency is likely to allow any payments to be used to settle private cases.

Southern's Mexican exposure will provide above-average long-term growth. Manufacturing and energy investments should [BLANK] growth in domestic traffic as well as cross-border moves with the U.S. Risks include a volatile peso and increased protectionist stance of the current U.S. administration.

Portfolios excluding fossil fuel sectors in the S&P 500, would have outperformed over the last one, three and five years with better risk-adjusted returns, according to a Sustainable Insight Capital Management report. The analysis [BLANK] different degrees of divestment -- producers through to heavy end-users -- finding similar results. Long-term demand concerns for fossil fuels, especially high-carbon coal, may also soften.

The Memorial Day weekend capped a tepid May box office with $172 million in receipts, the lowest since 1999. Disney's fifth "Pirates" installment, "Dead Men Tell No Tales," led the weekend, though poor reviews [BLANK] in a $63 million haul over the first three days, the second-lowest for the series. A host of other films have disappointed. Warner's "King Arthur," Fox's "Alien: Covenant" and Paramount's "Baywatch" all came in below expectations. To-date, summer receipts are 6% lower vs. 2016 and 21% below 2015.

The valuation premium between potash producers and all fertilizers remains below average amid weaker pricing and concern about excess capacity. The potash P/E premium [BLANK] to 2.6x in July, below its five-year average. Potash shares have slid a median 8% in the past three months vs. local equity benchmarks. The potash price-to-earnings ratio premium is historically tied to price discipline among suppliers and the relatively more-consolidated control of capacity for this fertilizer globally.

Among emerging-market ETFs, the biggest challenger to the dominance of the iShares J.P. Morgan USD Emerging Markets Bond ETF (EMB) is the PowerShares Emerging Markets Sovereign Debt Portfolio (PCY). The latter fund [BLANK] itself by giving each country an equal weighting and only holding sovereign debt. The iShares fund has 18% allocated to corporate bonds. Since launching in 2007, the PowerShares ETF has outpaced its rival, rising 85% vs. 72%. It also yields 5% vs. 4.6% for the iShares fund.

An onslaught of proposed regulations, if implemented on schedule by 2016, could worsen a shortage of truck drivers as rebounding construction and manufacturing industries compete for labor. FTR estimates the shortage may reach 234,000 at the end of 2016, and almost [BLANK] the current level by 2018. New regulations address areas including hours of service, immigration, driver qualifications, health, safety and electronic monitoring.

Based on Oct. 5 D.C. Circuit arguments, the court will likely affirm a lower court decision denying the preliminary injunction motion. The court showed skepticism at the Tribes' legal theory and [BLANK] remedy at various points during arguments. Lawyers for the Army Corps effectively argued ACE did everything required of it in the tribal consultation. The Tribe appears to have failed to cure the defects identified below. If a reversal does happen, the Tribe conceded that only three to four miles are at issue.

Several bitumen upgrader projects have been canceled in Canada's oil sands as market access for heavier crudes improved, Bakken shale production ramped up and price differentials shifted unfavorably. Suncor [BLANK] 31% of Canada's upgrading capacity and is looking to increase its stake in Syncrude, which operates 30% of throughput. There are five mining project with adjacent upgrading facilities that process bitumen via coking, hydroprocessing, hydrotreating and reblending into a light, sweet synthetic crude oil.

The court in Amgen's newest lawsuit against Novartis' Sandoz over the proposed biosimilar version of Amgen's blockbuster drug Enbrel will likely set a date in early 2Q for a scheduling conference, where the parties will discuss the timing of the case. Unlike generic lawsuits under Hatch-Waxman, the filing of this suit doesn't [BLANK] any stay of FDA approval, so that timing is even more important. Sandoz must first answer Amgen's complaint by April. Amgen requested a jury trial.

Investments in unregulated activities overseas may allow utilities to complement their lower risk, lower return regulated network businesses at home. Enagas acquired a 16% stake in Trans Adriatic Pipeline while Fluxys raised its stake to 19% after E.ON (9%) and Total (10%) [BLANK] the project, which will carry Azeri gas to Europe starting in 2019. Enagas has established its presence in Mexico, Peru and Chile since starting to expand internationally in 2011.

CEO's 20% total pay increase in 2015, including a 38% bonus boost, has come under fire ahead of the company's April 14 say-on-pay vote. BP has had significant headcount cuts and been [BLANK] to capital discipline amid weak oil prices. CEO Bob Dudley's pay is 80% higher than former CEO Tony Hayward's in 2009. Shell CEO Ben Van Beurden received a 6% higher annual bonus on the year, while reporting average employee bonuses fell 17%. His overall compensation was down, and was below former CEO Peter Voser in 2009.

Nordic Industrials appear set to end four years of organic sales-growth drought in 2017, as stronger global growth and a revival in commodities spur demand. Almost all peers [BLANK] 1Q profit estimates with early cyclicals posting the strongest beats. China's reviving economy was a key theme, driving demand for Volvo's construction equipment and helped SKF's record Asia-region double-digit organic sales growth. Mining orders at Atlas Copco and Sandvik rose about 30% as miners replaced equipment.

European pension funds and utilities are investing more in pro environmental, social and governance (ESG) companies and assets. This comes as players industrywide are more aware of the risks [BLANK] with fossil-fuel-driven corporates exposed to regulatory and commodity-price issues.

Trucking has about 72% modal share of freight in the U.S. as measured by tons, according to FTR data. Railroad service [BLANK] amid a spike in demand while the industry was recovering from a severe winter in 2014. If the rail industry isn't able to improve service, it may provide truckers with an opportunity to win market share along longer routes, especially for time-sensitive loads. Unless the industry is able to fill empty tractors with drivers, it will be a lost opportunity.

Hurricane activity is projected to be about average in 2018 as reinsurance-premium rate gains are expected to slow, following a modest jump after 2017's severe storm season. Risk-adjusted returns will likely remain under pressure, [BLANK] to a tepid, prolonged recovery in reinsurer book values.

Valeant's Xifaxan has long-term safety data because it has been approved since 2004 in traveler's diarrhea, which may make it preferable to Allergan's Viberzi in irritable bowel syndrome with diarrhea that has outstanding safety concerns. Repeat treatment with Xifaxan in the Target-3 trial [BLANK] concerns over antibiotic resistance. Viberzi has less safety data as well as contraindications that currently limit use. Risk of severe constipation also remains an overhang.

Valuation of Yahoo's patent portfolio could have a significant effect on auction bids for the company's core businesses. The patent portfolio contains core and non-core assets that could be [BLANK] through licensing campaigns and selling groups of patents to third parties. Estimates vary wildly, valuing Yahoo's patents anywhere from $200 million to more than $3 billion. Yahoo has signaled it expects the monetization of non-core assets, including real estate and patent holdings, to generate between $1-$3 billion.

Daiwa's retail-revenue slump, mostly due to fewer trades amid weaker financial markets, may weigh on group profit going forward. The unit's revenue for 3Q [BLANK] December extended declines, falling 9.2% sequentially to 51.8 billion yen ($436 million). This led to a 24.5% drop in ordinary income, as more-lucrative equity and fixed-income sales fell more than 14% from 2Q. Nomura and megabanks' securities units may show similar weakness. Retail comprised 41% of ordinary income in the nine months ended December.

Trading losses and mounting bad debts on spillovers from Greece's woes to euro-area GDP and neighboring bank systems may drive a further deterioration in near-term credit indicators. These include iTraxx European senior and subordinated financial indexes, which [BLANK] investors' outlook on credit. A recent, albeit gentle, increase has pushed these indexes toward one-year highs. The 2Q trading results of global investment banks like Citigroup, Barclays and Deutsche Bank will be studied for Greek knock-on effects.

Hong Kong banks' 2018 earnings could trail bullish market expectations, dragged by margins, loans and fees. Margin gains [BLANK] from a rising Hibor may fall short of analyst estimates due to higher deposit cost and compressed lending spreads. Deposit funding may restrain lending growth, while fees should soften on weaker securities markets and loan demand. Average revenue growth could fall to high-single digits at the four banks in our coverage, vs. 13.6% in 2017, based on our analysis.

Steel's domestic Flat-Rolled operations differ on many fronts from its Europe-based USSE segment.
