This trend could [BLANK] pace as firms add more products that claim compliance with FOSHU (Food for Specialized Health Uses) standards.

Less-than-truckload carriers have benefitted from e-commerce growth of heavy and large shipments that parcel carriers such as FedEx or UPS are not well-suited to handle. Parcel carriers have been adding surcharges to irregular packages to [BLANK] additional handling costs. ArcBest home-delivery shipments increased by 40% in 1Q from the prior year. One driver is able to handle shipments of up to 250 pounds, which includes products such as safes, appliances, furniture, mattresses and sporting goods.

The Drewry Hong Kong-Los Angeles container-rate benchmark jumped 17% to $1,371 per 40-foot container in the week ended Dec. 6. Rates rebounded following a number of general rate increases, [BLANK] the first sequential increase in five weeks. Rates will likely decline in the coming weeks since slack capacity has made general increases' impact short-lived this year. Additional general rate increases scheduled for Dec. 15 and Jan. 1 should provide some downward protection. Rates are down about 17% quarter-to-date.

The 2016 outlook for specialty chemicals varies widely by end markets and regions. The sector encompasses 28 different sub-segments, as [BLANK] by the American Chemistry Council. Volumes could be tepid for energy (including green chemistry), mining and chemicals used in heavy equipment manufacturing, all depressed by lower commodities. Markets where demand is improving include construction, most coatings, food and flavor, cosmetic as well as pharma ingredients, aerospace and catalysts.

A key driver behind U.S. distributed solar energy growth has been the 30% investment tax credit that can be obtained on solar energy systems and helps support the business model for residential installers such as SolarCity and Vivint Solar. This tax credit is [BLANK] to be reduced to 10% on Jan. 1, 2017, which may impede future growth prospects. Industry proponents claim falling equipment costs and rising retail power prices may lesson this impact.

Growing patent holdings among banks and other financial institutions shows companies are investing in next generation financial technologies and adopting defensive legal strategies. Litigation trends show banks, while typically loathe to [BLANK] patent lawsuits, are often the target of such challenges. The suits threaten big-money damages and undermine efforts to establish industry interoperability. Legal strategies could rely on broad technology disclosures and court decisions undermining patents on software.

Luxury automakers are adding more premium compact models in China because volumes are usually higher than for larger, higher-priced sedans. The compacts' greater sales may also [BLANK] thinner margins. BMW intends to build 2 Series Active Tourer hatchbacks and X4 SUVs in China with partner Brilliance. Daimler's Mercedes is set to produce CLA compact sedans and B-Class hatchbacks through Beijing Benz.

Australia's banks may surprise investors by repudiating gloomy expectations. The lenders' margins may continue to [BLANK] if the Reserve Bank of Australia keeps its cash rate at 2% in 2016. Credit quality may also come in better than expected, as signs of loan-quality deterioration remain muted. Investors may also be appeased by the banks' commitment to maintain dividend payouts even as they face slowing mortgage growth and tighter capital rules.

Exxon Mobil added four horizontal drilling rigs in the week ended June 26, according to RigData, the most of any U.S. operator. The company is [BLANK] a wide array of plays, adding rigs in the Bakken, Utica, Marcellus and Permian. The activity closely resembles the well permit approvals in prior months, indicating that permits are an effective gague of the geographical distribution of Exxon's rigs in coming weeks. Continental dropped two horizontal rigs, one in the Bakken and one targeting the Anadarko Woodford.

China's demand for gasoline is growing much faster than for diesel, thanks to the steady increase in passenger-car sales over the past several years. Diesel demand is [BLANK] behind as China shifts away from energy-intensive heavy industries and focuses on its consumer economy. Diesel and gasoline account for more than half of China's demand for oil products.

Domestic crude inventories growth may slow, rising 790,000 barrels in the week ended Nov. 6, based on consensus, after jumping 2.8 million the prior week. Refinery maintenance in the Midwest is close to [BLANK], though more Gulf Coast refineries may have outages in the next few weeks. New pipelines are temporarily supporting demand, especially in the Midcontinent, which will further pressure the economics of moving crude by rail. Bakken and syncrude oil prices may rise more than WTI.

European-focused ETFs have thrived despite the region's constant political drama, growing to almost $60 billion in assets from virtually nothing 10 years ago. More than 100 ETFs offer exposure to the continent, with half providing [BLANK] versions of regional coverage and half targeting single-country exposure. On top of differences in cost and liquidity, investors face additional dilemmas when picking an ETF in this category, such as whether to include the U.K. and to hedge out the euro.

Diesel residuals are falling, particularly on pre-Euro 6 models sold before 2015 in Europe, on concern about recalls, pollution and potential city bans. This [BLANK] with a more optimistic line taken by automakers. Though gasoline average residuals, as a percentage of new vehicle price, have now overtaken diesel, no cliff edge has yet appeared. A sharp fall in residuals would result in significant writedowns for automakers' financial-services divisions.

Compliance costs for refiners might decline if President Donald Trump pushes to revise the Renewable Fuel Standard (RFS). Billionaire investor Carl Icahn, who is advising Trump on regulatory reform, is pushing to shift the RFS compliance burden from refiners to [BLANK] blenders. The regulatory steps to implement such a change would probably take years. House Republicans have sponsored numerous RFS-overhaul bills that would lower the amount of biofuel that must be blended with gasoline and diesel.

Twitter's mobile ad purchase TapCommerce and South Korean messaging service Kakao's proposed listing show the growing importance of mobile social platforms that can be monetized via advertising, commerce and games. Line, a popular messaging application in Japan, may also consider [BLANK] in the U.S. Mobile social engagement has become a global focus, as demonstrated by Facebook's $19 billion acquisition of messaging leader WhatsApp in February.

The national security debate on cyberthreats vs. privacy will likely cross the presidential campaign trail in the next few months. Social media's role in terror networks has some candidates [BLANK] for a fix via collaboration with technology companies. Others reject government involvement and encryption backdoors. These viewpoints transcend party lines. Net neutrality is a more partisan issue. Some Republican candidates have pledged to undo FCC rules that reclassify broadband Internet service as a utility.

Stryker's knee-implant business has gained steam outside the U.S. and is growing much faster than its competitors, driven by a more-efficient operating structure in Europe. Stryker lagged behind the market in 2014 as an enterprisewide shift to SAP software [BLANK] operations, allowing Zimmer Biomet and Johnson & Johnson to grab market share. As Stryker completed that and focused its European sales force by product, sales went from a 40-bp decline in 2014 to 6.7% growth in 2016, above 3.8% for peers.

European sales for offshore IT services companies should pick up in 2H and in 2018 amid increased immigration-related scrutiny in the U.S., which will force companies such as Tata Consultancy Services and Cognizant to put more focus on newer markets. The need to modernize IT amid a shortage of such labor in Europe is also forcing large corporations to [BLANK] for offshore. The model is a lot cheaper than hiring for IT in Western Europe, where costs are attracting more attention ahead of Brexit-related dislocations.

Booz Allen Hamilton's orders from U.S. civilian government agencies are on track to help the company deliver sales growth in its fiscal 2017, which began April 1. Orders from non-defense agencies, which make up about 30% of Booz Allen's revenue, increased 24% to $969 million in the calendar year through July 22, [BLANK] with $779 million in the same period in 2015, helped by higher IT orders from the Department of Veterans Affairs. Booz Allen reports 1Q17 results on July 27.

Qualcomm may still prevail in its challenge against daily fines of 580,000 euros imposed by EU regulators for missing the June 30 deadline to provide data in an antitrust probe. An EU court on July 12 [BLANK] the company's request to suspend the fines, yet it still has to decide whether Qualcomm has the obligation to provide this material in the first place. If Qualcomm wins, the fines would likely be annulled. Fines aren't automatically collected and EU regulators can decide when and if to claim the money.

China Unicom's 1H sales and profit may show an improvement, reflecting its mobile-subscriber growth so far in 2016. Its fixed-line broadband business [BLANK] stiffer rivalry with new arrival China Mobile, especially as the latter gains market share. China Unicom's 4G user growth got a boost from better technology and networking sharing with China Telecom. China Unicom's 4G users accounted for 28% of mobile subscribers at the end of 1H, still lower than China Mobile's 47% and China Telecom's 44%.

Stocks appear to have broken out of their latest consolidation, with recovery in the technology sector pushing the S&P 500 to a new high to finish last week. The S&P 500's closing reading on July 14 qualifies as a breakout of the tech-led malaise that [BLANK] on stocks for much of the last month. Momentum and breadth have turned as well and are moving in the right direction, but are less bullish than price at this point, indicating that a relatively weak advance is afoot.

Boston Scientific will likely provide an update on the status of its FDA filing for MRI-safe defibrillators at its investor day in New York on June 27, indicating whether approval by 4Q is still feasible. The company is also [BLANK] its Empower leadless pacemaker, and may provide some formal launch timelines as well as details on plans to use it with its subcutaneous defibrillator. That could give it a unique advantage vs. competitors, which don't offer a leadless defibrillator.

Oil and gas companies including Exxon Mobil, Chevron, and BP have been sued en masse by a local flood-control board in Louisiana alleging potentially as much as $470 billion in damages for what appear to be legal activities. The oil and gas companies are alleged to have impaired the flood board's ability to manage future deluges by harming local soil and vegetation through legally [BLANK] operations. A lower court decided in the industry's favor and the flood board has already made known its intention to appeal.

Consumer tissue capacity may grow 5x faster than demand in mature markets, keeping selling prices low and crimping margin. That's due to Essity, Kimberly-Clark and P&G being slow to cut capacity in mature markets while smaller producers expand, [BLANK] the effect of high pulp costs. With 3% of sales in Canada, tariffs on U.S.-made tissue will affect these companies' results.

The U.K. financial-technology industry is going from strength to strength, even with Brexit on the way. Innovative regulation means the sector is well-placed to [BLANK] four key challenges: access to data, talent, investment and the EU's single market.

More Australian companies are opening up about their gender pay gaps, but fewer than a tenth of ASX 200 members provide data on the difference, which would signal openness and engagement. Almost all of the companies that [BLANK] data on gender pay report little or no gap, including Tatts Group, Iress, Westfield, Ardent Leisure and Stockland. Australian women earn 16.2% less than men on average, almost unchanged from 20 years ago, according to the Workplace Gender Equality Agency.

Otsuka-Lundbeck's Abilify Maintena serves as a good proxy for Alkermes' Aristada launch, which bodes well for future growth. Sales of Abilify Maintena rose 167% in its second year on market and 66% in its third year with the addition of acute data to the label and a prefilled syringe [BLANK] growth. That would imply Aristada sales of $126 million in 2017, above current consensus, and $209 million in 2018. Aristada was approved in a range of doses and is also available in a prefilled syringes.

Among the largest U.S. subprime-auto lenders, Santander Consumer's revenue may continue to be dragged down in the near term by subdued loan growth and a declining net interest margin. However, it's poised for EPS growth, driven by lower loss provisions, after [BLANK] back on its core subprime-loan originations for almost two years to focus on credit quality. In the medium term, the company may gradually return to loan growth, while seeking to expand its servicing income and to resolve regulatory issues.

China has turned to the Philippines to fill the gap left by Indonesia's 2014 ban on nickel ore exports. Last year, China imports from Indonesia [BLANK] 74% to 10.64 million metric tons as the ban took effect, while supplies from the Philippines surged 76%. This year, with Indonesia imports at zero, Philippines shipments are more than 95% of total Chinese nickel ore imports. Indonesia's share of Chinese nickel ore imports fell to 22% in 2014 from 58% in 2013. China's total import volumes slumped 33% last year.

REITs were net sellers of office properties for the third consecutive month in November, as total transactions reached a one-year record. Overall office real estate deal volume [BLANK] 24% from October, however, to its lowest point since July 2017. Cap rates fell to 6.5%, resuming their slide after a brief pause last month.

Retailers are aligning stores with online platforms to create seamless, or omni-channel, shopping that integrates inventory across all outlets. Internet sales are [BLANK] those at brick-and-mortar stores, increasingly accounting for a larger portion of the sales mix. That is making shopping easier for consumers and driving market share gain. Higher online sales have come at the expense of margins as retailers invest online and absorb shipping costs.

Clovis will present data for rucaparib, a PARP inhibitor, at the EORTC-NCI-AACR cancer conference on Nov. 20. The study [BLANK] effectiveness of the drug in ovarian cancer patients who don't have the BRCA mutation, yet have other genetic traits that potentially make them respond to the drug. PARP inhibitors such as AstraZeneca's olaparib are restricted to tumors with BRCA mutations where they have proven effective. If this trial is successful, Clovis may broaden its eligible market.

Environmental groups have sued to void California's emergency rules on wastewater-injection and enhanced oil-recovery well operations in certain aquifers. The new regulations allow these operations to [BLANK] until February 2017 without undergoing a lengthy application process during which activity would cease. The California Department of Conservation has identified about 2,500 wells that may be forced to shut down if the rules are voided. Non-emergency regulations are being proposed.

The FTC has been asked to investigate the proposed changes to WhatsApp's privacy policy to see if those changes violate a consent order Facebook is under. WhatsApp users can choose not to have their phonebook data [BLANK] with Facebook. The FTC must determine if an opt out regime provides sufficient notice to users. Under the consent order, Facebook is required to get consumers' "affirmative express consent" prior to sharing the collected data in a manner that exceeds the user's privacy settings.

The number of mobile-service accounts is likely to keep growing in Japan as customers increasingly opt for a second device, such as tablets, Wi-Fi routers and even auto accessories. Japan's mobile penetration has [BLANK] more than 130%, and total subscriber growth remained at 9% in the quarter ended December, up from 6% in the same period a year earlier. The growth is driven by fast 4G networks and rich web content, which attract users. Japan's 4G penetration was only around 60% at the end of 2015.

German wind-turbine supplier Senvion acquired a 250-megawatt production facility from Kenersys in India, along with its product portfolio rights and service business, as it seeks to secure new Indian demand. The company, once [BLANK] by Indian turbine maker Suzlon, has experience in the market. Senvion's acquisition of a local turbine operation will speed its time to market in India and offer a range of low-cost turbines and local contacts.

Aerospace manufacturers should benefit as Boeing boosts 737 builds by five a month (to 52) in 2018, and from higher service spending as air traffic grows above trend. Airbus raised A320 builds to 50 a month in 2Q17, with 60 [BLANK] for mid-2019. Bombardier's C Series deliveries rise, while Embraer's E-Jets are lower as the E2 is introduced.

While Kite is on track to have the first CAR-T approved in the U.S. for diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL), Novartis' approval may be 6-9 months behind. This [BLANK] availability, preference and nuances in the treatment will have an impact on uptake. Lymphoma expert Dr. Josh Brody of Mount Sinai gave his views.

Fuel surcharges typically lag behind spot prices by a week, which boosts truckload margins when prices decline quickly. The average price for diesel [BLANK] 2.6% in 3Q from 2Q. Diesel prices declined in 12 of the 13 weeks in the quarter, which, combined with the surcharge lag, should push truckload 3Q EPS slightly higher. The effect of falling fuel prices on consumers' disposable income also raises freight demand for trucking carriers.

Japanese makers may be shipping lower-value industrial robots since September, even before the rise of the yen against the dollar in February, which may help gain market share. Slowing factory upgrades in China, the largest market for industrial robots, should be short-lived as [BLANK] labor costs adds pressure to improve productivity and quality. The surging yen may further pressure Japan's industrial-robot sales, especially in the lower-end segment such as sequence and playback robots.

AstraZeneca's Lynparza SOLO2 trial is in BRCA-mutant patients only. Tesaro's niraparib has [BLANK] a benefit in BRCA-mutant and non-mutant patients, with a 73% reduction in the risk of disease progression in the former group. If approved, niraparib would have a much broader label vs. Lynparza, even if its safety profile appears worse. Clovis is testing rucaparib in a similar patient population to that of Tesaro, but its data isn't due until 4Q17, a full 12 months later than Tesaro's.

Hyperscale cloud vendors including Amazon AWS, Microsoft Azure and Google Cloud have leveraged their core IaaS offerings to bolster adoption of PaaS products. Additionally, large SaaS providers, such as Salesforce.com, ServiceNow and Workday, are bundling some PaaS capabilities [BLANK] application development and integration tools with their offerings. While IBM and Oracle have rolled out PaaS offerings recently as well, they're also rebuilding their IaaS infrastructures to bolster adoption.

FirstEnergy said its EPS could fall by 7%, or 20 cents, a year under a Republican plan to eliminate the federal interest-expense deduction. Duke [BLANK] a 5-7% decline, and Southern, 5%. The three carry large parent-level debt, and that interest expense can't be passed to ratepayers. Losing the deduction would increase total utility taxes by about $7 billion. Cutting the corporate tax rate to 20% from 35% would increase earnings by about $6 billion, leaving a $1 billion hole for the companies to plug.

Rare-earth miner Molycorp failed to attract bids for its entire business and is pursuing a stand-alone reorganization of the Neo unit. The plan has support from Oaktree Capital, which is Molycorp's largest [BLANK] creditor and post-petition lender, as well as the creditors' committee, which settled for a 7.5% stake in the reorganized company. Molycorp is now engaging with secured noteholders, who opposed the proposal, in an effort to negotiate a global plan resolution.

China needs to upgrade its coal-producing technology to keep its promise to reduce CO2 emissions after 2030. Cement, steel, aluminum and other heavy polluters seek to [BLANK] coal consumption. China is also pushing electric vehicles and cleaner diesel. The world's biggest emitter, China accounted for 27% of the global total in 2014, more than the U.S. and EU combined. Whereas the 1997 Kyoto treaty required only developed nations to cut emissions, China is set to agree to limits at this month's COP21 meeting.

Indian generic-drug makers are likely to pursue more U.S. acquisition targets to shore up their manufacturing presence in the world's largest pharmaceuticals market and meet FDA quality requirements. Cipla's purchases of InvaGen and Exelan will [BLANK] its sales base in the U.S., where it currently gets 11% of revenue. The deals follow similar moves by Lupin. Cipla's $550 million combined acquisition is its largest to date and first in the U.S.

In May, Sirius XM and Flo & Eddie will argue Flo & Eddie's appeal of a Florida federal court's ruling that Sirius didn't need to pay recording owners to air music made before Feb. 15, 1972. A federal appeals court in Atlanta is set to [BLANK] the issue, and has tentatively scheduled the argument date for the week of May 16. The names of the three judges who will decide the case will be announced on May 3.

The American Hospital Association supports the bipartisan House agreement to reform Medicare's physician-payment formula, even though hospitals are bearing some offsetting cuts. Under current law, for example, hospitals would [BLANK] their Medicare reimbursement rise by 3.2% in 2018; the bill (H.R. 2) would instead phase in this increase gradually in six years. Even with this, the AHA supports the bill because other reform proposals likely would have imposed greater costs on the industry.

Video-game makers' shift toward recurring revenue sources is reducing the risk to results and driving near-term outperformance of EPS, even if new games don't live up to high expectations. This is justifying elevated valuations, even as growth may eventually revert back to the long-term average of about 5%, given margin expansion and [BLANK] visibility to future results.

Momentum on the S&P 500 is touching nosebleed territory again, suggesting stocks are likely due for a period of consolidation just as earnings season gets underway next week. The 14-day relative strength index (RSI) for the S&P 500 [BLANK] 70 this week, a level breached only twice in the last year. Each time the index went above 70, stocks consolidated for at least a month. Value sectors -- industrials, energy and financials -- are the most overbought in the index at this time.

Energy drinks surged 12%, coffee rose 10% and wine was up 6% to lead U.S. beverage sales growth in the four weeks ended June 14. These likely [BLANK] from lower gasoline prices and the associated increase in consumer trips to gasoline station convenience stores compared with the prior year. Milk was the lone exception, with an 8% decline, mostly reflecting weakening industry pricing on falling raw milk costs. Industry product innovation is at a high level.

Kuka reports strong price pressure in robotics, driven by the weakness of the yen. The currency's 8% depreciation against the euro and 3.4% vs. the dollar in 2Q is likely to have also [BLANK] ABB. Both European industrials primarily compete against Japan's Fanuc and Yaskawa in robotics, with all four companies accounting for 65% to 70% market share. Kuka has already begun cost cutting to compensate for the increased price pressure, as well as higher R&D spending.

German consumers, who had been among the most optimistic in the euro zone, now seem worried about the slower economy. Their willingness to [BLANK] durables fell for the third month in September. This indicator usually leads the overall confidence index, and may predict declines in hard-good retail sales. Euro zone major purchase intent has been broadly stagnant since 2008, even from early 2013 to May 2014, when overall confidence improved.

Google's Inbox app may help expand its users on smartphones, which have been waning as apps and social media services such as Facebook and Twitter gain in popularity. Apps account for 80% of U.S. internet use, and Facebook accounts for 17% of time spent vs. Google's 14% ([BLANK] YouTube), according to Flurry Analytics. With mobile expected to generate one-quarter of Internet ad sales this year, Inbox may help keep Google's lucrative search business relevant.

RyanAir left capacity unchanged in August, during the height of summer vacation season, as Norwegian, Vueling and EasyJet increased growth rates slightly from July. Norwegian's yields appeared to [BLANK] from peak season, falling 6%, half of the previous months. Fuel prices also fell 6%, which likely made a 400-bp impact on margins. Load factors rose at most, with RyanAir and EasyJet reaching the mid-90s, while Norwegian and Vueling were mid-80s.

Branded apparel companies may increase their direct sales as the year progresses, accelerating revenue growth and margin expansion. By opening more owned brick-and-mortar locations and e-commerce sites, brands [BLANK] interactions with consumers, often selling merchandise directly to them at a higher price than to a third-party retailer. The portion of revenue generated through traditional wholesale accounts, including department stores and other specialty stores, continues to shrink.

After indefinitely postponing its deadline, Australia cleared AB InBev's acquisition of SABMiller on May 5 with limited concessions. The regulator had been [BLANK] that AB InBev distribution agreements with Lion could increase the ability for coordination between Lion and the merged entity, two large suppliers of beer in Australia. AB InBev terminated the Lion agreements, which appeased the regulators. The outcome is good for AB InBev as it now won't have to divest any brands in Australia.

Chinese aluminum makers may add more capacity this year than the rest of the world combined, giving them an increasingly important role in global markets. Boosting capacity may make costs more competitive, as Chinese smelters [BLANK] captive power plants. China has increased its bauxite imports from Guinea after Indonesia banned exports of the raw material. Key long-term trends include carmakers substituting aluminum for steel and the rising use of aluminum wiring instead of copper in the power sector.

The U.S. bank loan-to-deposit ratio has dropped 114 bps to 78.4% this year through March 15, based on Federal Reserve H.8 data. The measure declined 54 bps [BLANK] with the prior week and 75 bps vs. the prior year. Loans to deposits fell after the financial crisis in 2008, then began rising in 2015 as loan gains approached the long-term average and deposit growth decelerated. Deposit attrition is a possibility at interest rates rise. Low-cost core deposits cut funding costs for banks and fuel revenue.

Bank of Canada stress tests found that a hypothetical, low-probability house-price correction shouldn't threaten the big six Canadian banks (RBC, TD, Scotiabank, BMO, CIBC and National Bank). Their estimated losses weren't large enough to [BLANK] funding risk or asset fire sales. Bank of Canada's scenario assumes a 20% housing price correction, accompanied by a sharp increase in financial stress, which amplifies the macroeconomic effects. BoC's Household Risk Assessment Model derived estimated increases in arrears of 0.5 percentage points for mortgage debt and 3.6 for credit cards (both higher than what was seen in 2008). Combined with the effect on businesses, the risk scenario may generate a 14% impact on bank earnings and C$24 billion of credit losses -- below our extreme test -- and a 1.2% reduction in the CET1 ratio.

Further advancement in Mexico's consumer confidence in October reinforces our view of a resilient consumer, reflecting favorable conditions including lower inflation, strong remittances and a focus on wage gains, which have offset pressure from rising energy prices. At 103, the confidence measure [BLANK] expectations of 101.1, improving 1.3% sequentially and 16.8% year-over-year. Such sentiment points to a robust holiday season that should bring strong 4Q results for retailers such as Liverpool, Walmex and Femsa. Consumer confidence rose in October in part for the same reason the peso lost almost 8.7%: the government's cancellation of the new Mexico City airport. This highlights the likelihood that there's more volatility to come when President-elect Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador assumes office on Dec. 1.

CenturyLink and associations for wired and wireless Internet-service providers sued the FCC to overturn net-neutrality rules that prohibit ISPs from blocking, degrading or favoring Internet traffic. The FCC [BLANK] greater power over Internet service by labeling it a "telecommunications service," over which it has broad authority, instead of a largely unregulated "information service." Challengers claim that the FCC didn't follow proper procedures and classified Internet service unlawfully.

Aided by low unemployment and economic growth, we expect workers' compensation insurance to produce strong industrywide results over the next few years, though pricing headwinds are clearly picking up. Insurers that [BLANK] a meaningful portion of their profit from this line include Hartford, Travelers and WR Berkley.

Johnson & Johnson and Bayer's X-VeRT study may add to the rationale for using Xarelto, though unless the guidelines are changed, this study is unlikely to have a strong commercial effect. The 1,500-patient study [BLANK] Xarelto halved the number of undesired events vs. warfarin in patients undergoing cardioversion (rebooting of the heartbeat with a defibrillator). While this is a positive signal, a much larger study will be needed to give it an edge vs. Pfizer and Bristol-Myers's Eliquis.

Display boosted 2Q sales 7% sequentially, compared with 3.4% decline a year earlier. PC monitor sales rose 12%, and TV LCD sales increased 9.6% driven by higher prices and [BLANK] shipments of larger-size panels and Ultra-HD displays. The company forecast double-digit sequential revenue growth in 3Q on favorable LCD prices and a shift toward large-size TV panels. Continued LCD area growth may also aid sales at other panel makers, such as Samsung, AUO and Innolux.

Critical developments are expected in 4Q in several lawsuits challenging portions of Dodd-Frank financial regulations. In the U.S. government's appeal of MetLife's court victory [BLANK] the insurer's "too-big-to-fail" SIFI designation, oral arguments are on Oct. 24 and a ruling may come by year-end. The CFPB has until Nov. 25 to seek full court (en banc) review of an Oct. 11 appeals court ruling that the agency is unconstitutional because its director can only be removed for cause.

The Democratic Party's platform, which was approved on July 25, would extend many policies supported by President Barack Obama that aim to reduce coal, gas and oil consumption. Some aspects of the Democrats' plan are easily doable if Hillary Clinton [BLANK] the White House. For example, she could aim to strengthen anti-coal regulations such as the Clean Power Plan. Some parts of the platform, including the passage of a carbon tax or cap-and-trade program, aren't likely to become law.

Railroad companies operate in a capital intensive industry, which is mostly funded without using taxpayer money unlike federal dollars spent on the highway system, which benefits truckers. Class I [BLANK] invested an average of $14.5 billion in capital in the past two years, which is about 19.4% of revenue. Depending on topography, it costs an estimated $2 million to $4 million to install a mile of new track.

Aircraft lessors have been rapidly expanding in Asia, with leased planes accounting for 36% of total fleet in the Asia-Pacific region, second only to Europe. Asia is one of the fastest-growing regions for airlines: capacity rose 7.5% in 2014 and has more than [BLANK] since 2010. As lessors target China, India and Southeast Asia for growth, China Southern, Lion Air and AirAsia are taking a significant number of deliveries through lessors.

Lukoil has boosted drilling in its mature assets and launched new fields in the Caspian and Western Siberian regions to maximize the most profitable output. Geologic conditions and tax exemptions mean production in the Arctic Timan-Pechora and Caspian regions [BLANK] the best returns, while more drilling raises costs. Downstream, the company aims to revive profit growth after an ambitious refinery upgrade that enables higher-value product exports.

Financial institutions in the 10 EU countries that want a financial-transaction tax may become less attractive trading partners if the levy takes effect. Taxes may end up being [BLANK] into the system in the form of higher transaction costs. This may reduce liquidity and create short-term volatility, potentially increasing costs by as much as $43 billion, based on an Oliver Wyman study, or about 33% of the 3Q net revenue of the 10 biggest banks in the EU-10 by revenue.

Although natural gas output remains below 2016's lofty peak, Northeast volume has stabilized and the level of well completions has risen, suggesting a potential boost in future output. The Northeast, which [BLANK] the Marcellus and Utica shales, had been the primary driver of U.S. gas-volume growth. While associated gas from liquids drilling in the U.S. also contributed to the significant rise, the Appalachian Basin is the largest, most economic natural gas resource located near large population centers.

Sirius XM and Flo & Eddie have concluded their briefing in Sirius' appeal of a lower court's ruling that the satellite radio company needs permission to air pre-1972 recordings. Flo & Eddie, owners of the rights to songs by the Turtles, [BLANK] a judge that ownership of a recording includes the exclusive right to play it publicly. The appeals court is expected to select a date for oral argument soon. The argument will likely take place in 1Q16.

Managed care companies may start bidding in mid-2015 in the next round of contracts to provide health-insurance services to U.S. military personnel. The military plans to select two contractors, with each [BLANK] the TRICARE program for one-half of the country starting in April 2017. Currently, three contractors provide regional services. The Defense Department is seeking industry input on the plan by Dec. 8. Bidding may involve lengthy protests.

Activist investors and Hunter Harrison have their eyes on CSX, the WSJ initially reported. They could unlock some value but not of the magnitude seen at Canadian Pacific, which [BLANK] its margin jump by 18 percentage points under Harrison's tenure. CSX has improved its operating ratio by 210 bps since 2014, while it's lost about $1 billion in high-margin coal revenue. The "CSX of Tomorrow" strategy appears to be showing promise as the railroad better aligns resources with a focus on merchandise and intermodal growth.

With many states and utilities resisting the EPA's proposed sharp carbon reduction in 2020, the requirements in the agency's upcoming Clean Power Plan may be delayed. A slower phase-in could leave more coal plants [BLANK], weakening nuclear's competitive position and hurting gross margins at nuclear power-plant operators such as Exelon and Entergy. Chicago's 2021 and 2022 power prices tumbled in the last month after the EPA suggested easing the carbon rule's implementation. A final rule is expected in August.

Apartment REIT acquisition volume surged more than 16-fold in December to $4.8 billion, up from $261 million in November. Deal volume was [BLANK] mostly by Mid-America's acquisition of Post Properties on Dec. 1 for $4.4 billion. The new company is now the largest apartment REIT by number of units and the fourth-largest by enterprise value. Without this merger, REIT property-buying volume was still up 33%, with Essex Property purchasing two Los Angeles buildings for $185 million.

Sainsbury online grocery sales grew only 7% in its 2Q period, amid intense customer acquisition efforts by competitors. Sainsbury's online sales have not [BLANK] momentum since the website upgrade. While online grocery shoppers spend significantly more with the retail brand in total, marketing costs to gain customers can be large. In online grocery, these typically take the form of discount coupons, the cost of which represent many months of profit.

Solar power may become at least as cheap as grid power because of falling production costs and improved efficiencies in silicon and thin-film solar technology. First Solar, for instance, [BLANK] a new record for thin-film cadmium telluride efficiency of 21% in August. SolarCity also cited high cell efficiency as a driver behind its acquisition of Silevo. The Bear Case argues that some solar producers may get left behind as new disruptive technologies emerge.

Infrastructure-as-a-service and platform-as-a-service are two essential components of the cloud infrastructure. Microsoft, Amazon.com and Google have been in a price war to [BLANK] market share in the IaaS segment, forcing other companies to focus on managed services. Rapid adoption of all facets of cloud services is driven by the need for greater productivity and agility in utilizing IT assets. Security, privacy and regulation are some hindrances to cloud services growth.

Airline routes to Africa and the Middle East are strongly contested this year on competition from Persian Gulf-based carriers, while civil unrest and war have cut travel demand. The Gulf super-connecting carriers, including Emirates, Qatar and Etihad, as well as Turkish Air, are increasing capacity over 10% a year and the proximity of their hubs [BLANK] an advantage when sorting travelers into Asia or Europe. Regional unrest exacerbates the yield challenge for European airlines.

Electric utilities plan to retire plants with 10.5 gigawatts worth of coal-fired capacity, or about 4% of the installed base, in 2016-20. Those plans could shift depending on how legal uncertainties [BLANK] regulations are resolved. For example, if the Clean Power Plan moves forward, coal retirement decisions may be accelerated. The 2016 election may also affect retirements. Republican vice presidential candidate Mike Pence reiterated his ticket's position against the "war on coal" on Oct. 4.

Investors may need to wait until 2019 to see tangible results from the latest UPS (UPS +4.2%) attempt to transform itself. The company embarked on a three-year program in 2018 that may pressure near-term margins as it [BLANK] to become a more nimble and profitable. The transformation will be implemented with a mix of modernization, added capacity and cost reductions that include early retirement offers to some non-operations employees.

Asset managers for pension and retirement accounts may face tighter restrictions, including a change to fee-based revenue from commission-based, when the Labor Department re-proposes its fiduciary standard rule in the upcoming weeks. The proposal would [BLANK] the standard to IRAs and 401ks. It comes after a leaked White House memo said investment-adviser abuses could cost investors $17 billion annually. The proposal would be followed by a comment period for affected firms to respond.

About 15 million square feet of new office space is expected to be delivered in Midtown Manhattan in 2017-21. This [BLANK] a 5.6 million-sq. ft. peak in 2019, according to Reis. SL Green's 1.7 million-sq. ft. One Vanderbilt is scheduled for completion in 2021, toward the tail end of that surge in construction. As SL Green moves toward its planned timeline for leasing the remaining 1.5 million sq. ft. at One Vanderbilt, much of the other newly developed space will have been leased, reducing competition for tenants.

Rising risk and regulation means companies need better protection against cyberattacks by 2Q18, when the Network and Information Security Directive applies. The new EU rule will require financial-services companies and others to establish and maintain robust systems and controls to [BLANK] the risk of attack and minimize damage. Certain attacks will be reportable and may attract an unlimited fine. The risk of breach and penalties is increasing demand for cyber-liability insurance.

Macau's February casino revenue of $2.4 billion remains range-bound within the past two years' dispersion of $2-2.5 billion, despite revenue from the Lunar New Year holiday. In addition, newcomers Wynn Palace and Sands' Parisian, have added hotels, dining, retail and gambling tables to [BLANK] the attractions of the Cotai strip. MGM Cotai's 2H17 opening will feature only mass-market gaming tables, which should help revenue climb and may give it the extra boost needed to break through that range.

Green's Stonehenge property portfolio was primarily built in the 1940s, with half containing less than 100 units, which differentiates it from typical New York City REIT apartments. Older and smaller assets usually [BLANK] more repairs and are often more management intensive. Large public apartment REITs tend to buy properties with hundreds of units to keep these costs low, and as a more efficient use of management's time. AvalonBay has the newest buildings because it develops many of the properties it owns.

Commercial property insurance rate increases accelerated to 3% in October, the strongest gain since August 2014, according to MarketScout. Pricing for commercial auto coverage rose 4%, a slight slowdown from 5% increases [BLANK] from July through September, while workers compensation rates fell for a seventh straight month, down 2%. As many carriers are pledging to raise pricing more broadly, each of the 11 other lines tracked by MarketScout rose 1%, driving a 1% increase in the composite index.

The ATA releases monthly truckload and less-than-truckload statistics on an eight-week lag. ATA's truckload metrics, categorized by equipment type, length of haul and revenue, [BLANK] volumes, miles and yields. On average, monthly truckloads have historically increased 2.3% yoy. The top less-than-truckload metrics are tonnage and shipments. Shipments have slowly recovered from their low in March 2010.

American Express's U.S. card loan growth accelerated to 7.7% in November from 6.2% in October and 6.4% in September, while Discover slowed to 6% from 6.3% in October and 6.5% in September. Capital One's growth, at 5.9%, continues to improve since [BLANK] positive in May, more accurately reflecting its organic run-rate as it moves past the effects of its HSBC card acquisition and subsequent Best Buy portfolio sale. All three companies are outpacing the industry's unadjusted 3.5% pace.

Internet and e-commerce stocks have had mixed performance this year as macroeconomic turbulence dominated the first quarter. Amazon, Facebook and Tencent all [BLANK] amid strong earnings. On the downside, Yelp, LinkedIn and Google fell due to questioned growth outlooks. Ongoing mobile monetization spurred Facebook, while a slowdown in user growth and ad sales is pressuring Twitter. Yahoo! solicited bids for a reverse split, driving shares higher based on capturing the sum-of-the-parts valuation.

Faced with mounting challenges competing in the slowly growing and consolidating U.S. packaged-food industry, some publicly traded companies may opt for the greener pastures of private ownership. Companies whose share prices have [BLANK] by more than 50% over the past year include Lifeway Foods and Dean Foods.

LightSquared's new bankruptcy reorganization plan proposes to convert the $1.3 billion claim held by Charles Ergen's SPSO into new debt on the same economic terms as other LightSquared lenders, though with covenants to prevent SPSO from exercising control over the company. The new plan, [BLANK] on Dec. 18, once again pits SPSO against all other stakeholders. If no one buys SPSO's debt, plan proponents including JPMorgan, Fortress, Centerbridge and Harbinger will have to defend SPSO's treatment at plan confirmation.

Exelon's announced acquisition of Pepco, which primarily serves electric distribution and transmission customers, for $12.1 billion in cash and debt may be the largest utility M&A deal since Duke's purchase of Progress was completed in 2012. Four network utility acquisitions have already been [BLANK] with valuations above $1.5 billion in 2014. Total M&A for U.S. gas and electric network utilities may reach a record $25 billion this year.

Companies in the S&P health-care equipment peer group gained 6% in April, with only Hologic and Abbott posting declines. St. Jude shares rose 39% during the month, mostly after [BLANK] a takeover offer from Abbott. This signals confidence that minimal product overlap won't inhibit deal completion. Edwards shares gained 20% after presenting data at ACC that indicated its transcatheter valve product may be superior to surgery. Boston Scientific shares rose 17%, driven primarily by strong earnings.

The slowdown in San Francisco 1H rent growth was more severe than apartment REIT managements expected, which may cast doubt on current forecasts. Fresh supply is likely to [BLANK] to pressure rents through 1H17, after REITs such as Equity Residential underestimated the impact of new class-A deliveries on rents in 1H. On the demand side, future job growth in technology and other sectors remains a much bigger unknown, with venture-capital funding trends and major office leasing only part of the picture.

Sandoz's launch in the U.S. of its FDA-approved Zarxio is delayed at least into July and likely later after Amgen won its injunction bid on May 5. Amgen had [BLANK] that if Zarxio launches, its Neupogen wouldn't recover from the price erosion. While the Federal Circuit agreed by granting the injunction, the court didn't state its reasons in the order. This may signal the Federal Circuit believes Amgen can win, which would send the case back to the lower court for further proceedings and delay a launch even further.

Permian Basin bottlenecks are widening the WTI Midland-Cushing oil-price differential and risk further eroding U.S. E&Ps' margins, with no immediate relief in sight. While producers likely will continue to [BLANK] for the next 12-18 months, mid-continent refiners should benefit. Pipelines will be built to take crude to the Gulf Coast, where further bottlenecks await. There aren't any quick, short-term solutions. Truck-driver shortages and long-term agreements will keep pipeline owners from making significant profits. The infrastructure constraints may hurt the competitiveness of U.S. production vs. foreign alternatives. Taking lessons from history, we see mergers as inevitable, at first for refiners and pipelines and later for upstream.

Shares of Nomura and Daiwa, Japan's largest investment banks, rose by an average 8.4% in October on the broader global market rally. Their performance still trailed the Topix index, which gained 10.4%, [BLANK] September's 8.2% decline. October's average daily stock turnover slowed 6% from September, extending a fall from August, despite Japan's market rebound. Nomura and Daiwa both reported sequential revenue and profit declines in fiscal 2Q, which may have resulted in their lagging behind the Topix.

The iPath S&P GSCI Crude Oil Total Return Index ETN (OIL) was the best-performing commodity ETF in August, returning 11% amid uncertainty across the oil industry's global supply-and-demand chain. The month's rally was at least partly driven by speculation of an OPEC output freeze, slowing U.S. production and [BLANK] Chinese factory PMI levels. The ETN's returns topped the United States Oil Fund (USO), which does the same thing, except in an ETF wrapper.

A fragmented and increasingly competitive midstream industry, coupled with a need to fuel cash flow growth, is driving a robust M&A market. MPLX LP's $20.2 billion proposed purchase of MarkWest Energy and Energy Transfer's $17.4 billion acquisition of Regency Energy [BLANK] M&A this year. Yet Williams Co.'s plan to buy Williams Partners is uncertain after Energy Transfer's recent bid. Ten M&A deals worth at least $1 billion have been announced this year, twice as many as in the same period last year.

Oil's price collapse has set off intense interest in when and how U.S. crude production will react, and rig counts, historically a leading indicator of output, are losing their predictive value as the two metrics diverge. The new oil environment is causing operators to [BLANK] well completions while simultaneously looking at re-fracking as an investment with a high rate of return to drive production. When completions and re-fracking fail to keep up with the declining output from older wells, production will fall.

Buffalo Wild Wings, Cracker Barrel, Texas Roadhouse, Cheesecake Factory and other casual-dining chains are interested in developing or acquiring fast-casual concepts to boost sales. Casual-dining traffic is [BLANK] as fast-casual chains such as Shake Shack lure millennials and other customers with high-quality ingredients, customization and reasonable prices. Chains are more likely to initiate lower-risk moves, such as making small equity investments in emerging companies or developing concepts internally.

Cisco has a slight early advantage in the patent litigation against network-switch rival Arista, even though the cases are just beginning. Cisco used an aggressive strategy from the start, [BLANK] four separate lawsuits attacking Arista's network-switch products: two federal district court cases and two in the International Trade Commission. A judge recently denied Arista's request to consolidate the two ITC cases, which means Arista will have to defend its products in two separate trials next year.

Increased merchandise flow at West Coast port suggests the labor-related backlog is near an end. This should [BLANK] in an upbeat 2Q outlook for retailers, which faced delays and merchandise shortages. Inflows rose 31.5% at Los Angeles ports in March and 25.8% at Long Beach vs. a year earlier, according to Datamyne. There were no anchored ships outside West Coast ports as of May 4, according to the Marine Exchange of Southern California. This indicates that retailers should have inventory to support 2Q demand.

Chinese imports of iron ore rose about 6.3% year-to-date through February. China's increased demand for iron ore could be the elixir needed to [BLANK] some slack capacity that has pressured rates to historic lows. Its uncertain if the increase in Chinese imports is from economic demand or to replenish the 4.5% decline in iron ore inventories during the first two months of 2016 vs. 2015. The government's pledge to avoid a hard landing, with 2016 growth targets of 6.5-7%, may bode well for iron ore demand.

Mid-America's purchase of Post Properties added 895 units in Houston, and its development project there adds 388 more. Its Houston same-store revenue fell 3.5% in 1Q, though exposure to the city is less than 4% of same-store net [BLANK] income. Camden Property Trust, an apartment REIT peer based in Houston that earns 11% of pro rata NOI there, expects 2017 same-store revenue to decline 4%, on par with its worst declines for the city in 2003 and 2010, as supply continues to exceed demand.

An FCC ploy to keep the net-neutrality legal dispute in the D.C. Circuit appeals court, without holding a second venue lottery, has little downside and may keep the case where the FCC would prefer. The FCC is seeking to use the court-lottery pick from two suits, which the agency [BLANK] were filed prematurely. The move signals the FCC thinks it can prevail in the D.C. Circuit and aims to avoid the conservative Fifth Circuit. While the ploy may not work, the worst case for the FCC is another court lottery being held.

The $38 billion of Swiss franc-denominated mortgages in Poland may attract investor attention after Bronislaw Komorowski lost in the first round of presidential elections on May 10. If the opposition candidate wins in the second round, that might pave the way for the PiS (Law and Justice) party to [BLANK] parliamentary elections this year. PiS has praised Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orban for his handling of non-forint loans, which have cost banks billions of dollars in the past four years.

Orange Belgium is headed for low-single-digit medium-term growth underpinned by a strong mobile network, which generated the highest postpaid net adds after rival Proximus in 2017, and the company's expansion into fixed-line services, which make up 55% of domestic industry revenue. Yet the loss of MVNO contracts in 2018 (expected to generate a 30 million-euro loss), and further roaming drags (26 million euros) will keep growth [BLANK].

Use of chip stockrooms on manufacturing floors and the storage of chips in raw or "die form" vs. as-finished goods has only partially offset big swings in distributors' ordering. As chipmakers rely more on distributors such as Arrow and Avnet, companies such as Texas Instruments and Cypress Semiconductor are [BLANK] to "double-ordering" and inventory writedown risk. Texas Instruments is using this to its advantage to build inventory during lean demand periods to sell it later.

Credit-default swaps on Deutsche Bank widened more than any other member of the Markit iTraxx Europe Senior Financial index this year. But so far, credit markets aren't particularly concerned that the bank's troubles might [BLANK] to the broader European financial system, as reflected by the growing [BLANK] difference between Deutsche Bank CDS and the index. Wider index spreads like what occurred during the European sovereign debt crisis would signal growing credit concerns for the broader European banking sector.

China set ceiling and floor prices for crude oil on Jan. 13 to mitigate the impact of extreme volatility on gasoline and diesel. As the largest oil consumer after the U.S., China is sensitive to crude, with high energy costs [BLANK] on its economic growth, and low prices putting upstream oil operations at risk. China's regulator has said that dependency on imports may increase if oil prices stay at low levels. Imports accounts for about 60% of China's total oil consumption.

Google upped its commitment to compete in smartphones by introducing two new phones under the Pixel brand name, in a bid to best Apple on many key iPhone features. At an event [BLANK] the new phones, it was clear that Google was specifically targeting Apple, as it touted free photo storage vs. Apple's paid iCloud service as well as free 24x7 support on Pixel vs. Apple's paid AppleCare program. Also, Google touted its new video-chat app called Google Duo, aimed at competing with Apple's FaceTime.

Plaintiffs in a class-action lawsuit against Cablevision have until March 31 to file their motion for summary judgment. Cablevision is expected to [BLANK] its own motion for summary judgment, though there's no concrete timeline for when Cablevision's motion will be due. The parties will argue over whether a two-week channel outage, which was due to expiration of a retransmission agreement, triggered Cablevision's pledge to offer credits for interruptions lasting longer than 24 hours.

Owners of ships required to adhere to stricter sulfur emissions limits by the International Marine Organization (IMO) will likely have a harder time avoiding the higher costs of compliance after an October IMO meeting. A proposed ban on the ships [BLANK] noncompliant fuel will probably be approved at the meeting.

Asian companies should become more active in buying U.S. tech start-ups, heeding President Trump's call for job creation and possibly in return for more favorable policies. This would reverse a 38% decline in U.S. tech mergers and acquisitions [BLANK] at $50 million-or-below, according to IDC statistics. Samsung has focused on software targets since Dongjin Koh became head of its handset division in 2015. Its move to venture capital investing dates back to 2013 when it built an innovation center in Silicon Valley.

Petrobras will take another shot at getting a shareholder class-action lawsuit thrown out at a Nov. 25 hearing, the defendants' latest bid to dismiss. The oil company may [BLANK] in dismissing class claims tied to bond purchases as it did earlier in a set of individual investor suits. Investors will also have to explain how they relied on alleged Petrobras misstatements, even after they began suing the company in 3Q15, to succeed in extending the class period to July 28, 2015, from March 19.

Ferrari looks set for another estimate-busting quarter, when details of a likely SUV launch in 2019/20 may be announced, which would be very well received. Full-year guidance will likely be [BLANK] in 3Q on a better mix of specialty and limited-edition models and higher engine sales to Maserati. The European Financial Services unit deconsolidation will provide another year-over-year Ebit-margin boost. R&D costs will likely rise as cars transition to hybrids from 2019.

Elevated order cancellations may put truck manufacturers' production and sales at risk. North American Class 8 truck cancellations remained [BLANK] at 11% in December, down from the high teens in three of the previous four months. December marked the ninth month above 10%, the rate at which manufacturers typically cut production. Some customers have deferred deliveries as tight freight capacity eased. Cancellations indicate less need for new capacity and point to an industry peak.

Natural gas producers may gain the most from a new Environmental Protection Agency emissions rule, though the direct impact will be muted by the Trump administration's pro-coal stance. Coal-to-gas switching will instead [BLANK] largely a function of other factors. A new rule will probably set requirements at the plant level.

The keystone of Exxon's defense against climate change investigations is the Texas litigation, which has a good chance of surviving an early argument that the court doesn't have jurisdiction to hear the case. Prior arguments against the court's having the power to [BLANK] the case don't perfectly match up with the cases the states cited. The company arguments seem to clear the lower bar necessary for a claim to continue past the initial motions stage. Arguments will be fleshed out on Feb. 1.

Extraordinary strength among technology bellwethers in 3Q reporting elevates the pace of S&P 500 EPS growth, now on track for a 6.4% year-over-year increase. The tech sector's strength remains pervasive, leading on breadth of surprise, growth, revisions and guidance, and the positive tone [BLANK] infectious. For the first time this season, index EPS estimates for the quarters ahead are moving higher on both the top and bottom lines.

Fossil-fuel prices for Asian power utilities may be flat or lower in 2015, based on consensus. That may [BLANK] China and other countries to press ahead with market reforms, particularly if inflation is low. Falling prices could also boost utilities' cash flow. This effect may only last a few months in markets such as Japan, where regulated tariffs are closely tied to fuel prices. The impact may last longer in countries including China with no link or delayed adjustments.

GlaxoSmithKline's near-term focus remains on its HIV unit, a main growth driver in the face of likely Advair generic competition this year. Yet the franchise may face increasing competitive pressure, with Phase III data in 2H key to [BLANK] this growth engine. The quiet 2H sets the scene for a busy 2019 that's occupied by readouts, though most will be from early-stage trials.

Even though Germany issued Gazprom a construction permit for the Nord Stream 2 natural gas pipeline on Jan. 31, the company will probably miss its goal of operating the pipeline by 2H19. The company is still [BLANK] on uncertain approvals from Denmark, Finland, Sweden and Russia.

April 23-29 features the FDA panel on Eli Lilly-Incyte's baricitinib. Takeda has an April 25 deadline under U.K. rules to [BLANK] if it will make a firm offer to acquire Shire. Karyopharm's pivotal Phase IIb data in multiple myeloma are due at the end of April. Titles for abstracts (including late-breakers) of the ASCO cancer meeting will be released, with potential late-breakers on OS data of Phase III trials by Merck ('042) and Roche ('150) in first-line lung cancer. The FDA will post briefing documents for SIGA's tecovirimat.

Bills seeking to handicap President Barack Obama's legacy rule on the power sector's carbon emissions may have better luck in the next Congress. The Clean Power Plan won't be [BLANK] until the next president's term, and under a Republican president, the bills would have improved odds. Several Republicans in Congress recently called for more action against climate change, yet that's unlikely to sway the Republicans running for president. More than half of the states are also challenging the rule.

Key litigation for 21st Century Fox includes a battle against an internet company, FilmOn X, that claims the same automatic right to play Fox programs as traditional cable operators. Fox has joined with other TV networks to argue internet streamers must [BLANK] for programming rights. Fox is also suing a news clipping service that copies Fox content, and challenging the FCC over a national TV ownership cap. In another case, Fox News is battling Charter Communications over programming rates.

Bitcoin Cash, a hard fork of Bitcoin (that doubles the supply of coins) with larger block sizes and lower fees, has struggled significantly since its December high, but protocol improvements could [BLANK] enthusiasm for the fourth-largest crypto asset.

Many casual-dining chains have resorted to bundled offers, such as an appetizer or dessert and two entrees for $20, or $6-$8 discounted-lunch combos. While these offers may have helped offset traffic declines since the recession, over time they could limit a chain's profitability if servers are unable to get customers to order extras, [BLANK] up to full-priced items or return for dinner. Thus, discounts may become a permanent fixture on the menus of many casual-dining chains.

While the bulk of exchange-traded fund assets under management remains in equity-focused funds, growth in fixed-income ETFs has outpaced both stocks and commodities since 2010. This [BLANK] demand for bond exposure with the convenience of the ETF vehicle. Emerging debt and investment grade U.S. corporate funds grew fastest.

Baidu's billion-dollar investments in selling local services online may secure its dominance of mobile search, which has contributed more than 70% of revenue in 1Q17. Its search and map services helped Baidu [BLANK] 21% of China's online takeout food market in 2Q16, according to Analysys, after entering the business in May 2014. Baidu has opportunities to attract search users seeking high-frequency offline services such as restaurants, and transform them into registered and paying customers.

Key global aluminum market indicators are painting a relatively downbeat price picture. Surpluses [BLANK] to manifest for the seventh straight year. Premiums have surged and will go unchallenged as new offloading rules at LME warehouses are overturned, leaving room for a new physical delivery CME contract to launch. Imported alumina has risen above domestic Chinese alumina, indicating smelters may switch to domestic sources which may pressure imports.

A trade case by steelmakers in the U.S. against cold-rolled steel from China and six other countries will likely be finalized in 3Q. Estimates of anti-subsidy duties released Dec. 16 slapped top Chinese exporters with retroactive tariffs of more than 200%, even as the Commerce Department [BLANK] the application of subsidy duties on South Korean exporters. The case affects more than $1.2 billion, or 1.5 million net tons, of cold-rolled steel imported in 2014.

The solar industry is supporting margins by driving down its silver use per kilowatt. We estimate solar-cell producers' silver cost per kW may drop by 26% by 2020 vs. 2017, [BLANK] by technological advances and lower silver prices. Yet the solar industry's total demand is set to rise by 2020 with increased installs.

Profit outlooks for Japan's three megabanks, especially Sumitomo Mitsui and Mizuho, are likely to brighten on signs of increased stability in their lending income. Both lenders' profit growth in 1H exceeded the pace [BLANK] by the full-year consensus estimate. MUFG's operations are likely to remain stable, based on our analysis.

Forward price-to-earnings multiples for single-brand apparel makers vs. the S&P 500 Index are at the low end of the three-year average. Ralph Lauren's valuation [BLANK] to its low end at 1.1x, following a brief increase when the opening of a flagship store in New York and the unveiling of Polo women spurred optimism about the brand's future. Michael Kors's relative valuation fell to its lowest level on concerns about margins.

At EADV 2016, J&J-Morphosys' guselkumab was superior to placebo and AbbVie's Humira on IGA scores of zero or one and PASI-90, stringent measures of disease-improvement in psoriasis. Cross-trial comparisons [BLANK] the IL-23 drug's efficacy is at least as good as other novel biologics and J&J's Stelara, based on placebo-adjusted treatment differences on the less-robust PASI-75 metric. These novel agents include IL-17 therapies by Eli Lilly and Novartis. Stelara and Humira are current standards of care in psoriasis.

After its Alstom Power acquisition, General Electric's portfolio almost spans the entire spectrum of power generation products, and has enhanced its ability to service competitors' plants. Measured in gigawatts, the gas and liquid-fuel power plants market [BLANK] 54% in 2015, according to a McCoy Power Report, though the industry remains competitive. Such competition is fiercer in the less-than-500 megawatt segment, where companies such as Wartsila and Ansaldo are pitted against the likes of GE and Siemens.

Most large retailers are overhauling their IT infrastructure to better connect their brick-and-mortar stores to their online business. These changes include revamping inventory management systems to more effectively [BLANK] supply chains. Known as omni-channel, this initiative by retailers to provide a unified customer experience has been a growth area for the technology industry. Amazon's same-day delivery is likely a major driver of these changes as retailers defend their market share.

Late last year Congress assured its lead role in remaking the U.S. housing finance system with a bill that blocks the Treasury Department from divesting its senior preferred shares in Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac. The bill [BLANK] that at least through 2017, the two government-sponsored enterprises can't be recapitalized and released from conservatorship without Congress' approval. Both the bill and the GSEs' shrinking capital buffer put pressure on Congress to move on an overhaul in 2017.

Three recent, major actions by Aecom we view as supportive to the company's creditworthiness. Exiting fixed-price, combined-cycle EPC projects, as well as selling and [BLANK] some oil and gas operations, reduces the risk of major project charges that have plagued peer Fluor. Instituting a leverage target, albeit above what we would view as conservative, at least provides bondholders with goalposts. And focusing on organic growth, instead of acquisitions, limits integration risk. Yet several risks -- secular, cyclical and financial -- remain.

Biotech and pharma events in Alzheimer's disease include Axovant's intepirdine Phase III data in late September. Lundbeck-Otsuka are seeking the FDA's input on the potential to file Rexulti by year-end for treating agitation [BLANK] with Alzheimer's dementia, after only one of the two Phase III trials met the primary endpoint. Eisai-Biogen's BAN2401 large Phase IIb trial primary endpoint data are due in 4Q. Eisai then is expected to decide whether to opt-in to co-develop aducanumab with Biogen.

Updated Phase I data from ASCO GI 2018 for Roche's Tecentriq-plus-Cotellic combo heighten the focus on the ongoing IMblaze370 Phase III trial, with efficacy in the microsatellite stable (MSS) patient population under the lens. These early data suggest IMblaze370 could [BLANK], helping to spur Tecentriq growth. A recent halt in recruitment in another study, Modul, raised safety questions on the Tecentriq-Cotellic combo, but after discussions with the company, we found this uneasiness to be misplaced.

Data from Bristol's CM-040 trial at ASCO confirm Opdivo's approvability in liver cancer, which has an FDA decision date in September. If [BLANK], Opdivo will be the first immuno-oncology drug for this tumor type and likely change the treatment paradigm, given the current standard of care, Bayer's Nexavar (for first-line treatment) and Stivarga (for patients who progressed after Nexavar) only showed overall survival of 10.7 and 10.6 months in Phase III trials. But competition to Opdivo is on the horizon.

The European TMT 3Q earnings season hits the ground running next week, with seven stocks under our coverage reporting. We [BLANK] Telekom Austria (Oct. 16) to register an improvement in Ebitda generation, after tough 2Q comparisons, and Pearson (Oct. 17) to deliver at least slim underlying revenue growth. Com Hem (Oct. 18) should post healthy Ebitda expansion on synergies ahead of its de-listing and merger with Tele2. Meanwhile, we think Elisa (Oct. 18) will mention some easing in domestic competition, and expect results for other Nordic telcos Tele2 (Oct. 18) and Telia (Oct. 19) to reflect stable market dynamics in 3Q vs. 1H. Finally, we think Publicis (Oct. 18) will have improved sales growth after a weak 2Q.

SunPower's (SPWR -0.2%) pending acquisition of closely held SolarWorld Americas will expand its cell and module production capacity by a third and mitigate the effects of U.S. import tariffs, even if it doesn't receive exemptions. The deal can [BLANK] up to half of SunPower's U.S. product needs and has safe-harbored inventory, two actions that will cushion the blow of the tariff increasing to 30% in the first year. It may still seek to accelerate global growth, given its 80% sales exposure to the U.S.

Long-term data on Bristol-Myers' Yervoy as an adjuvant in melanoma presented at ESMO bodes well for immunotherapies such as Merck's Keytruda in the same setting. Data showed that despite there being just microscopic residual disease in patients, enough is there to [BLANK] a response. A higher 10 mg dose of Yervoy looks more efficacious, but brings toxicity. Agents with less toxicity -- Opdivo and Keytruda -- could be preferable in the adjutant setting.

Makers of drugs, biologics and medical devices should be pleased now that the Senate has confirmed President Barack Obama's nominee to head the FDA. Dr. Robert Califf had been criticized by Democrats for his ties to the drug industry; he's led several clinical trials and once [BLANK] that regulation can be a barrier to innovation. The FDA approved 45 new medicines in 2015, the most in about two decades, and the drug and device industries have just begun negotiating the next five-year user fee agreement.

Mark Calabria, chief economist to U.S. Vice President Mike Pence, if nominated to run FHFA, may slow the release of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac to private shareholders. Calabria favors privatization of the government-sponsored enterprises, but his strident libertarian slant will complicate negotiations as he [BLANK] less taxpayer backing.

Wind turbines have traditionally used gears to transfer power from slowly rotating turbine shafts to higher speed generator shafts. Gearless, or direct-drive, designs instead use magnets, which [BLANK] the number of parts and potentially boosts reliability. This can also cut maintenance expenses, particularly offshore. Adoption has been held back by higher production costs, partly caused by the need for large volumes of rare-earth metals, such as neodymium.

Mastercard's gross-revenue growth may get a boost across the pond as rival Visa raises fee rates for bank clients it acquired with Visa Europe. In contrast to Visa, Mastercard has [BLANK] on driving nontransaction fees, but its consulting fees may be more recession-sensitive than the core business and come with lower margins.

Tech and media companies are filling up office space in West Los Angeles, supporting leasing spreads for REITs in the region. We [BLANK] increased content production from media and entertainment firms will continue to drive demand into 2019. More traditional technology firms, including those migrating from Northern California, are also fueling office demand.

While California state regulators weigh a change to net-metering rates in the next few years, or the tariff paid to a distributed solar owner who sells to the grid, Governor Jerry Brown signed a law in early October to extend the state's existing Renewable Portfolio Standard. The law requires 50% of electricity [BLANK] and sold by the end of 2030 to come from wind, solar, geothermal or other renewable sources. Suncor, Cenovus and Canadian Natural Resources (CNRL) completed a combined C$34 billion in oil sands acquisitions to strengthen their grips on the region's production. As global majors seek to [BLANK] capital elsewhere, Canadian companies have pounced on M&A opportunities to bridge an expected growth gap in new oil-sands projects left by the plunge in crude and the lofty upfront costs to build new mines. Output growth is driven by M&A and expected completion of two mines, CNRL's Horizon and Suncor's Fort Hills.

Bunker-fuel prices have fallen to near five-year lows mainly because of a slump in crude caused by a supply glut. That may boost margins for [BLANK] companies as fuel makes up the majority of voyage costs. Fuel prices have tumbled about 40% from last year's high of $615.78, on March 4, 2014, and are down about 50% from the March 2012 high of $735.29.

Pacific yields fell 3.3% in 3Q, showing no turnaround on long-haul routes in a region challenged by intense competition from Asian carriers. At United, the largest carrier to the region, yields fell 4% as it [BLANK] 5% more capacity. Delta yields fell 3% even on unchanged capacity as it battles a weaker yen. Air Canada yields were flat in Canadian dollars as it increased capacity almost 10%. American yield rose 2.2% on capacity increases of 22.6%, although the carrier is smallest to the region.

Danaher's announced purchase of Nobel Biocare provides complementary products and services to its dental business. It's paying 16.7x consensus 2014 Ebitda, a premium to past deal multiples, [BLANK] it sees cost-cutting opportunities. Management aims for 5 cents of EPS accretion in 2015 and 10 cents in 2016. Danaher's M&A capacity will exceed $8 billion, after more than $3 billion of deals this year including Nobel, based on its CFO's comments and BI's M&A capacity model.

The commodity price collapse has forced the mining industry to ask governments around the world to provide relief on various criteria, including concessions on royalties, export duties and minerals extraction taxation. For miners [BLANK] at breakeven levels and below, helping incentivize economic growth, increasing investment and providing jobs are issues. Governments can withdraw or reduce fees, as seen at the end of 2008, when India withdrew its export duty on iron ore fines when the price sank more than 30%.

Banks may face further U.S. fines in 2015, following the likely confirmation of Loretta Lynch as U.S. attorney general in March. While risks remain for banks including Barclays, Deutsche Bank, Goldman Sachs and UBS, much of the largest legacy mortgage issues have been [BLANK]. This may mean lower future costs. U.S. penalties of $4.5 billion in 4Q bring the 2014 total to $61.7 billion, exceeding the record $43.5 billion in 2013. The cumulative total is $140 billion from 2008-14.

A seasonal withdrawal from U.S. natural gas storage is expected for the week ended Feb. 3., as the return of cooler weather boosted consumption. Average temperatures [BLANK] below the 10-year norm in the period, though heating-degree days remain 8% below last year's level. Gas delivered to consumers gained, with residential and commercial demand the primary driver. Dry gas production decreased slightly to 71.4 billion cubic feet a day. At 2.711 trillion cubic feet, total storage is 2.2% above the five-year norm.

The distribution of insurance premiums across Africa is starting to shift toward developing markets with low insurance penetration, such as Nigeria and Kenya. This [BLANK] increased migration into urban areas and more widespread and varied economic growth. The majority, about 80%, of sub-Saharan African insurance premiums are still written in South Africa, including more than half of all non-life premiums and 90% of life premiums.

While the growth of new streaming services throws the pay-TV video bundle in jeopardy, it may further strengthen cable operators' broadband dominance. YouTube said its global viewers [BLANK] more than 1 billion hours of video every day, a 10x increase vs. 2012. As consumers watch more online videos, usage-based pricing will give cable operators greater data-revenue potential, especially as net neutrality rules may be weakened by a new FCC. Nortel Networks reached a global deal paving the way for the company to exit bankruptcy proceedings in the U.S. and Canada in 2017. The settlement resulted from several months of mediation, while coordinated rulings on [BLANK] Nortel's $7.3 billion in sale proceeds were on appeal to the Third U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals and the Canadian Supreme Court. The company seeks to confirm a U.S. reorganization plan on Jan. 24. Nortel has incurred over $2 billion in fees since the case was filed in 2009.

An oil price of $40 a barrel until 2020 will cut U.S. shale output by 3 million barrels a day (MMBBL/D), said International Energy Agency Executive Director Fatih Birol. The average price of WTI a barrel fell to $49 in 2015 from $93 in 2014. U.S. output peaked at 9.2 Mmbbl/d in June last year and has fallen by 5.5% since, U.S. Department of Energy data show.

Bancolombia's 17 percentage point sequential drop in coverage ratio to 123% in 1Q may not signal markedly lower provisioning. The bank's coverage ratio [BLANK] 13 points in 1Q14 and 20 points in 1Q13, before rising again by year-end. A switch to IFRS reporting in 2015 also contributed to seemingly lower coverage ratios, highlighted by a revised 4Q ratio of 140%, down from 155% under local GAAP rules.
