Merck will have one of the key presentations at AASLD from its C-SWIFT trial combining its Hep-C agents with Gilead's Sovaldi for shortening treatment durations to four to six weeks. The 18,000 patient IMPROVE-IT trial of Vytorin, looking at cardiovascular outcomes in acute coronary syndrome will be [BLANK] at the AHA conference. This may significantly alter the competitive landscape if it shows a reduction in cardiovascular mortality and morbidity.

Facebook, Apple and Google are likely to be major players in deriving revenue from chatbots and virtual assistants by integrating services. The Android/iOS mobile phone duopoly [BLANK] each company's general purpose voice assistant, as IDC projects 72.4% of devices with embedded virtual assistants will be mobile phones in 2020. Facebook is focused on deploying chatbots on Messenger, some of which may assume customer service functions. This may yield a revenue stream for the chat platform used by 1 billion people.

The potential removal of Fox News CEO Roger Ailes as reported by NY Magazine may cast uncertainty over its long-term operations. Fox News is the most-watched prime-time cable network, [BLANK] an average of about 2.2 million daily viewers. The network generated $1.48 billion in 2015 cash flow and could make $1.63 billion in 2016, based on SNL Kagan. That makes it the most profitable cable TV network, with a 64% cash flow margin and the largest profit generator for its parent, accounting for 22-25% of total Ebitda.

The sharp decline in oil prices since June has led many major European oil companies to rethink their strategy and appoint new leadership. An increasing number of older oil executives are making way for younger leaders who may be more willing to take risks by trying alternative ways to [BLANK] costs and maximize cash flow. Wintershall CEO Rainer Seele's decision to join OMV as CEO is another example of this trend. Seele will succeed Gerhard Roiss, 62, who steps down on June 30.

Game hardware and software revenue may benefit the most from the rise of e-sports, as greater interest and time spent in video games should drive higher spending on games and more-advanced game hardware. Popular e-sports titles may [BLANK] an increasing share of industry profit, driving further consolidation.

Maintaining a low-cost position is a key driver for success in the global basic chemicals industry. In commodity chemicals, cheap feedstocks are the most common way for a producer to [BLANK] its cost position. New ethylene plants planned in the U.S. are a prime example. As highlighted by BASF, a more-diversified producer, integration and scale are also key means of lowering costs. Technology is widely available for most commodity processes, via licenses, yet it can help more-tailored materials makers.

Backlog-to-build ratio for Class 8 trucks remained at 4.8 months in June vs. 3.9 a year ago as daily build rates rose 10.1%. It has remained above 4 since November, the level at which truck producers [BLANK] production. The ratio remains healthy, with backlog up 44.2% yoy on robust truck orders. Heavy-truck production rose 15.9% yoy to 24,737 units. An elevated ratio should support increased 2H production for Daimler, Paccar, Volvo and Navistar.

Lannett, Mylan and Sandoz risk more than 60% of the estimated $1 billion achieved through sales of generic levothyroxine since 2013 due to purchaser lawsuits. BlackRock, Fidelity and other Momentive creditors have good odds of success securing Supreme Court review of a U.S. appeals court ruling that denied them about $200 million in make-whole premiums. Momentive shareholders including Apollo and Oaktree would likely [BLANK] the Supreme Court bid.

Declining hotel room rates are likely to be the first sign of an inflection point in revenue per available room, triggered by higher supply and rivalry from alternative lodging sites and online agents. Lodging metrics from STR, the industry's leading data provider, help to [BLANK] changes in U.S. revpar. This metric has risen for eight straight years, its longest recorded growth streak. Occupancy has been stagnant as room rates rise, with operators driving revpar gains by charging transient guests higher prices.

Micron, Samsung and SK Hynix, makers of dynamic random access memory (DRAM), are unlikely to succeed in efforts to dispose of lawsuits by buyers of DRAM and DRAM-containing products alleging a multiyear conspiracy to drive up prices by limiting supply. Bids to [BLANK] indirect buyers' suits will likely be decided in 2019.

Medical device prices weakened further in 2Q, likely due to biennial price cuts in Japan, increased competition and bulk selling. Orthopedic prices fell about 3% from a year earlier, down 100 bps vs. 1Q, which [BLANK] to Zimmer's and Stryker's gross margins declines. Carlyle's fee-related earnings are expected to benefit from accelerated fundraising and closing funds in 2H, but marketing costs will weigh on their results. The company recently increased the number of investments it is exiting, but fewer sizable deals may not provide 3Q much of a tailwind to distributable earnings.

Coal's shrinking market share for electric power generation in the U.S. can be attributed to two primary factors: cheap natural gas and environmental requirements. The delivered natural gas price paid by electric power companies [BLANK] about $2.74 per MMBtu in the past 12 months, which gave the fuel a slight cost advantage compared with coal. Had natural gas prices been higher, some companies may have opted to retrofit certain coal plants with mercury controls rather than retire them.

California's governor signed into law one of the highest renewable energy requirements in the U.S. on Oct. 7. In September, the state's legislature [BLANK] a requirement that 50% of electricity that utilities generate and sell must come from clean sources by 2030. The current portfolio standard requires 33% renewables by 2020. The new law also aims to double energy and natural gas efficiency savings by 2030, which would require utilities to implement new customer energy-savings programs.

Declining cocoa and sugar costs could offset higher dairy prices, boosting margins short-term for chocolatiers such as Lindt and Nestle. Lower cocoa-bean prices are [BLANK] profitability for processor Barry Callebaut, but further combined-ratio increases could be curbed if prices remain soft for cocoa-derived products.

November U.S. hotel revenue per available room declined 20% sequentially, worse than the average 16% drop over the past four years. This was mostly due to weaker occupancy, or demand, that was [BLANK] by inclement weather in parts of the central and southern U.S., a worldwide travel alert over terror threats and a stronger U.S. dollar. This, combined with slowing room rate growth, dented revpar across the nation as hotels become increasingly reliant on overseas and domestic transient leisure demand.

Take-Two has successfully stymied any threat posed by Electronic Arts in basketball by embedding new game modes and improving game-play to stay ahead. It may continue to do that and also lean on the size of its online multiplayer user base to resist EA's [BLANK] push to expand NBA Live. The size of its online user base poses the biggest hurdle for EA, as players will migrate to the game with the largest user base to ensure shorter wait times in online lobbies.

While Las Vegas' recovering economy has buoyed Red Rock's results, the city's local-market win fell 3% year-over-year in April and May, the most recent months for which state-reported data are available. Assuming Red Rock Native American management fees equal 1Q's, its Las Vegas revenue would have to gain 1-2% for total sales to match the consensus forecast.

The $50 billion global adhesives market benefits from diverse end-uses, which reduces cyclicality for manufacturers. Higher-value engineering, construction and durable assembly applications will grow faster than the market. As the industry continues to consolidate, an uptick in M&A activity will broaden geographical exposure and product portfolios, delivering value to shareholders.

Midwest refineries again led the reduction in overall U.S. utilization, with the region expected to undergo a heavier maintenance season than the rest of the country. Midwest utilization [BLANK] as Marathon Petroleum began maintenance at two of its refineries. Refiners may face weak margins in 4Q, even amid maintenance, as gasoline demand falls and crack spreads weaken. In the week ended Oct. 2, overall U.S. refinery utilization fell to 87.5%, though the Midwest fell to 79.2%.

Crude oil markets may be experiencing deja vu as E&P hedging ramps up in response to a 30% price rally in 2H, locking in supply growth. When WTI oil topped $55 a barrel toward the end of 2016, U.S. shale producers [BLANK] with an acceleration of drilling and output that pushed the benchmark price back down to $45.

Electric utilities plan to retire plants with 17 gigawatts worth of coal-fired capacity, or about 6% of the installed base, in 2016-20. Those plans could shift depending on how legal uncertainties [BLANK] U.S. regulations are resolved. For example, if either the Mercury and Air Toxics Standards or the Clean Power Plan survives court challenges, coal retirement decisions may be accelerated. The 2016 presidential election could also sway the direction of regulations that will affect coal plants.

Cisco and Arista haven't hinted at a litigation settlement. Cisco is [BLANK] four separate intellectual property lawsuits against Arista, including a copyright suit and a patent-infringement action in federal district court in California. It also has two patent cases in the International Trade Commission. Cisco seeks money damages and orders blocking Arista products from the U.S. Public filings and comments from key personnel at both companies suggest a settlement isn't currently on the table.

In this week's generic-drug litigation update, Celgene agreed with Natco and Actavis to dismiss four patents from a Revlimid lawsuit. Endo went to trial to [BLANK] Opana against generic makers Actavis, Boehringer, Ranbaxy, Teva, Novartis and Impax. Teva is settling its lawsuit over Treanda with Sun, and dismissed its suit over Copaxone against Synthon. Generic makers in Novartis's Exelon lawsuit asked the court to narrow issues for the pending trial. Eli Lilly's cases over Alimta were consolidated.

Deutsche Bank's planned $8.5 billion capital increase still leaves its leverage ratio (4.1%) some way short of its 4.5% target. Closing the gap [BLANK] $5.8 billion of extra Tier 1 capital or a 9% ($128 billion) reduction in leverage exposure. Major impediments to bolstering the capital ratio are a stronger dollar and rising interest rates, which make issuing additional Tier 1 debt more costly. Deutsche Bank's difficulties may also re-open the U.S.-EU debate on the netting of derivatives, key to leverage exposures.

Emerson and Honeywell have reported lower discretionary spending from oil and gas resulting in fewer small, repeat orders. Process automation and control products are [BLANK] hardest by cuts in upstream spending. In 2Q, ABB and Honeywell reported resilient backlogs with no cancellations, but organic orders fell on weak discretionary spending, which makes up the bulk of new orders. Due to the uncertainty in the oil price, the likelihood of projects being delayed into 2016, or cancelled altogether, is high.

Financial-market volatility following the U.K.'s vote to leave the EU has exacerbated concerns about BT's burgeoning pension deficit. The next triennial pension review will take place in June, with the outcome [BLANK] by early 2018. A review heightens the risk for increased contributions amid a sharp drop in bond yields and a potential legal separation of Openreach, BT's highly cash-generative infrastructure arm. Rising business risk would be a factor in the pension trustees demanding greater contributions.

The recent combination of lock manufacturers Kaba and Dorma, though a private transaction, provides a reference point for security sector valuations. Closely held Dorma was [BLANK] at 10.1x trailing 12-month Ebitda. Publicly traded Kaba's multiple was 12.2x, in-line with the pure-play security company average of 12x 2014 enterprise value. Using security peer multiples, Stanley Black and Decker's Security Systems unit has a hypothetical value ranging from $4.4 billion to $4.6 billion.

Oil and gas industry groups' requests to join the legal fight on behalf of the EPA were denied by the court, leaving environmental groups and the agency to begin briefing their arguments in 1H17. Without the industry groups in the case over oil and gas waste disposal rules, there's a higher likelihood the environmental group plaintiffs and the EPA will quickly [BLANK], as is often the case in such challenges. The "sue-and-settle" tactic isn't likely to surface until after some briefs have been filed.

European insurance shares have proved something of a rollercoaster ride since bouncing from their Oct. 16 low. Ahead of the Jan. 1 renewals, the peer group of European reinsurance stocks [BLANK] most on the prospect of capital returns, only to fall back as global reinsurance renewal rates fell. On an equal-weighted basis, all three peer groups have fallen since the start of 2014, with the life insurance group down about 15% and reinsurance and property & casualty down about 8%.

The total U.S. rig count rose by six in the week ended Dec. 1, reflecting an increase of two for oil and four for natural gas. The addition of six horizontal rigs [BLANK] a trend towards more efficient and profitable horizontal wells.

Volume and open interest along the commodity curve offers insight into liquidity and participation in the futures and options trading market. Limited liquidity affects volatility, obstructing E&Ps and other counterparties seeking to [BLANK] directional views on prices via hedging. Volatility has retreated recently as prices have weakened for WTI, yet remains above 2014 lows. Changes in regulatory and margin requirements, shifts in product preferences and market share have affected intermediaries as well as E&Ps.

Randal Quarles, the Fed's vice chair of supervision, will begin pushing proposals to loosen Dodd-Frank rules for midsize and large U.S. banks in 2018. He largely [BLANK] with the views of Fed Chair nominee Jerome Powell, suggesting his priorities may be changing leverage ratio requirements, stress tests and the Volcker Rule.

Fare wars may intensify as Avianca, Latam Airlines and Copa respond to rising competition for long-haul flights to Latin America. Costs per available seat mile are 2 to 3 cents lower at the Latin airlines, driven by labor costs in a range of 1 to 2 cents a mile, [BLANK] with 3 to 4 cents for European and North American carriers. With latitude to reduce fares and maintain profitability, a market share war will likely emerge in Latin America, though business customers may favor local airlines.

China metals demand will face continued pressure based on sluggish improvement in its manufacturing sector. China October PMI readings [BLANK] a slowing growth rate. The export orders index declined below the 50-point level, which signals contraction, for the first time in four months. Backlogs orders slipped further to 44.7, the lowest since July 2013. Raw material inventories also fell to a four-month low, indicating many companies were destocking.

Wal-Mart's low price strategy vs. rivals to lure shoppers to its stores for back-to-school could more easily facilitate cross shopping, increase basket size and may result in higher margins. It's also key for it to [BLANK] and increase market share. Wal-Mart's in-store school supply prices are lower than rival Target's, but online prices including third-party sellers are higher. Higher online prices could deter shoppers that demand the convenience of online shopping plus low prices.

Federal Reserve surveys in 2015-18 indicate incremental easing of mortgage-lending standards for the past few years, supporting home-purchase volume. Still, weaker demand driven by higher rates and seasonal trends may [BLANK] in the near term. Standards have been loosened across most loan types -- with GSE-eligible loans most notable -- since 2015 and in the most recent survey. Subprime has generally remained tight and non-qualified non-jumbo lending was the only category to show modest tightening in July's reading. Demand broadly lessened for the past year, which may reflect the dampening effect of higher interest rates, though subprime remains volatile. Wells Fargo, JPMorgan Chase, U.S. Bancorp, Bank of America, SunTrust and BB&T are among the largest bank originators of residential mortgage loans.

A proposal from U.S. financial regulators will place incentive compensation restrictions on senior executives and "risk-takers" from banks. The rule, one of Dodd-Frank's last remaining to be finalized, would require a significant portion of incentive-compensation be [BLANK] and subject to clawback. The regulation applies in varying degrees to financial companies with more than $1 billion in assets. Banks with over $50 billion would be subject to tougher restrictions. The rule may be finalized by the end of 4Q.

Hewlett Packard Enterprise's operating income growth, driven by its server segment, may pick up as a result of its services spinoff. Cost cuts are [BLANK] operating income, though currency issues and customer exposure to telecom carriers are affecting margins. Near-term, continued restructuring of enterprise services should bolster operating income. Following the spinoff, the hardware-heavy business may face challenges, with commoditization in the hardware industry affecting revenue and margins.

Oral arguments or a ruling may occur by mid-2Q on Allergan's bid to throw out Shire's antitrust lawsuit over Restasis. Shire claims Allergan has unlawfully conditioned rebates for the dry-eye therapy and Allergan's glaucoma portfolio on Part D plans excluding or [BLANK] coverage of Xiidra, Shire's rival product. Allergan has countered that its discounts are procompetitive. Briefing on the motion began on Dec. 5 and will end on Feb. 8. The court hasn't yet scheduled oral arguments and could rule without them.

Exelis holds the largest of three Air Force satellite launch contracts being consolidated into a single deal known as LISC. Exelis's [BLANK] award had average annual orders of $114 million. The other two contracts, held by InDyne and a Raytheon-PAE joint venture, had less than $80 million. Raytheon's Nov. 6 win overcame Exelis's advantage as the largest of the three incumbents. Exelis and PAE protested Raytheon's win on Nov. 24, extending their current contracts at least three months.

China's new yuan loans rose 73% from a year earlier to 2.5 trillion yuan ($389 billion) in January, fueling a 67% surge in social financing, the broadest measure of credit. This [BLANK] a bigger push to use bank lending to stimulate China's economy, which is expected to slow to 6.5% growth in 2016, based on consensus. Chinese banks may front-load lending in 1H, which bodes well for their net interest income. New yuan loans in January amounted to almost as much as the first two months of 2015.

The spread between higher-quality marine gasoil (diesel) and high-sulfur fuel oil may widen if the new low-sulfur fuel standard takes effect in 2020. Refiners may not be able to [BLANK] enough of the cleaner fuel to meet demand. Vessels may switch to 0.5% sulfur marine gasoil (MGO) or the 0.1% sulfur MGO used in restricted-emissions zones in northern Europe and North America. This may spur adoption of scrubbers, or filters that allow ships to burn high-sulfur fuel while still complying with emissions standards.

Bard's agreement to be acquired by Becton for $317 a share represents an 18-20% premium to similar medical-technology transactions. Becton is [BLANK] up for Bard's industry-leading revenue growth. The acquisition diversifies Becton into interventional devices and creates multiple opportunities to drive returns, including through international expansion and bundling for customers. The synergy estimate also is likely conservative, given Bard's size. Becton quickly increased its synergy target after buying CareFusion.

North America-originated intermodal traffic increased 6.8% in the week ended June 24 (week 25) vs. 2016, based on AAR data. Canadian National volume (up 19%) continues to [BLANK] peers, fueled by share gains and exclusive access to the Port of Prince Rupert. KC Southern (up 13%) followed, which could be a positive sign for the 2017 laggard in the category (down 5%). Management remains optimistic that new service offerings and facilities can spur growth this year, despite competitive trucking and peso weakness.

Combined oil production from the Permian, Eagle Ford and Bakken plays could grow by 700,000 barrels a day in 2018, if crude trades at $55-$65 a barrel during the year. Permian operators would likely add rigs and complete wells as quickly as possible, contributing 67% of total growth in the three plays, while the pace of increases would be more [BLANK] in the Eagle Ford and Bakken. The rig count in the plays may need to rise to a little over 400, or about half its 2014 peak, to achieve this growth.

Consumers' growing preference for widescreen TVs has driven an 11% increase in the worldwide average TV sales price since 2011 to $626 last quarter. Sets of 40 inches or more have [BLANK] to 54% of global units from 34% in the period. The trend may boost sales and margins at TV makers, including Sony, Samsung and LG Electronics. IDC expects shipments of larger TVs to jump 19% this year as makers increasingly focus promotions on bigger sets.

Currency movements affected software companies' sales in 1Q. Salesforce.com's revenue growth was [BLANK] by 400 bps due to the strong U.S. dollar. A weak euro bolstered SAP's sales by about 1,200 bps and Dassault's by 1,300 bps. The companies all reported greater demand for their software in local currency. At SAP, an increase in customers choosing subscriptions over licenses pushed some revenue into future quarters.

The S&P 500 Tobacco Index traded at a 20% premium to the broader S&P 500 Index on a 12-month-forward P/E basis at the end of 2015. The industry has [BLANK] a premium since March 2014, mainly due to the weakening of competing U.S. Treasury yields and consolidation. Tobacco stocks trade similar to bonds and offer relatively high dividend yields. The tobacco index generated a 21.9% annualized total return since March 31, 2014, triple the 7.3% for the S&P 500.

A greater proportion of sales from California drove strong growth in KB Home's average selling prices, resulting in the company raising its full-year revenue outlook. Improved top-line growth is also driving better operational leverage, which will [BLANK] operating-margin expansion in 2017. Unit order growth of 5% in the quarter was below expectations and is likely to be muted in 2H amid flat community counts and KB's strategy of maintaining absorptions in favor of pushing price, as evidenced in 2Q.

The farm-margin outlook has modestly improved following the USDA's May WASDE report. This first look at the 2016-17 crop year [BLANK] a drop in soy ending stocks will lower the world stocks-to-use ratio to about 21% by September 2017. Tighter soy availability was the main positive catalyst for prices. A composite index of crop prices is up 3% since the report, with corn 6% higher, soy rising 3% and wheat up 2%. The amount of soy output lost to April flooding in Argentina is a key factor, yet remains uncertain.

Robust secular growth elements, informed by structural shifts, underscore rising natural-gas consumption. Higher pipeline [BLANK] to Mexico, stout export LNG and lower Canadian gas imports drive U.S. prices. Ascendant fundamentals in the industrial segment offer a constructive longer-term view of gas dynamics. This stands in contrast with demand in the power-generation sector, which is exposed to erratic weather cycles and conservation initiatives that have slowed residential and commercial sector growth.

Tax reform appears to be the catalyst for those looking to take advantage of extreme discounts for value- vs. growth-factor equities. After their worst year in relative terms since the Great Recession, value stocks have [BLANK] above several resistance lines compared with growth over the past month. Some buyers are starting to put money to work in value-oriented exchange-traded funds as well, with $3.7 billion more inflows than growth ETFs so far this quarter.

Copper's mid- to long-term fundamentals are set to dramatically improve on the automotive industry's electrification revolution and new technologies. Copper producers are ramping up volume in the short-term, amid a price boost from recent supply disruptions. Yet further supply boosts and new projects underway may fail to meet the massive long-term demand from global electrical vehicles.

BI's European packaged food peer group was unchanged in 1Q, underperforming the Stoxx 600 index by 16%. March losses [BLANK] February's 5% gain. The franc's 15% appreciation vs. the euro, and 3% vs. the dollar, is hurting Swiss-based food peers with global exposure. An 11% weaker euro vs. the dollar wasn't enough to offset euro zone consumer price deflation, which worsened in 1Q. Political tensions compounded already falling sales and profits, with deflation in most euro zone countries and low inflation elsewhere.

Unit sales of Guangzhou Auto's (GAC) proprietary Trumpchi brand surged 57% in the 12 months through June this year, making it one of China's fastest-growing automotive brands. Sales at its Honda venture also surged, up 12%, [BLANK] 36% of total sales. GAC also works with other Japanese automakers such as Toyota and Mitsubishi. Its venture with Fiat Chrysler has unveiled the Jeep Cherokee and Renegade SUVs in the past 12 months to revive sales.

Zhongsheng's 2015 earnings could decline by as much as 10%, according to consensus, implying an 88% surge in 2H net income, with net margin improving from a year ago. Foreign luxury brands' sales in China quickened in 2H and could help [BLANK] some sales pressure on dealers. Yet, results reported earlier by peer Dah Chong Hong suggest narrower margins may be here to stay due to license registration caps and store closures in cities such as Shenzhen.

Commerzbank's update, ahead of a 2Q earnings release due on Aug. 2, detailed various items that negatively affect its Common Equity Tier 1 ratio while suggesting that reported profit would be broadly in-line with consensus. Chief among issues flagged by the lender was an increase in its pension liabilities as the discount rate used by the bank [BLANK] to 1.7% from 2%. The latest CET1 ratio of 11.5% is 50 bps below its 1Q level. Pension deficits are a growing concern for U.K. defined benefit schemes.

North American medium-duty (Class 6-7) truck shipments are forecast to exceed replacement demand of 125,000 units for a second year in 2015, following six years of below-replacement levels. FTR Associates projects factory shipments of 141,519 units, up 6.3% from 2014, when shipments [BLANK] 23%. Retail sales of medium-duty trucks climbed 5.5% through August on construction growth and improving state and municipal budgets, trends which should continue. Daimler and Navistar are the largest medium-duty truck producers.

FedEx's diversified portfolio of businesses, end markets and global reach is becoming more exposed to the consumer economy. E-commerce is [BLANK] increased business-to-consumer shipments at Express and Ground. Freight is its smallest segment but is highly leveraged to the industrial and manufacturing economy.

Bombardier sold $1.5 billion of convertible shares to Quebec pension manager CDPQ in 2016, redeemable for 30% ownership of the rail business. The transaction [BLANK] Bombardier's cash and allowed management to utilize the rail business's value without selling equity at distressed prices. The deal offers Bombardier flexibility to work through challenges at its aviation businesses and gives CDPQ significant influence over Bombardier management and financial policies.

Deutsche Bank, HSBC and other mortgage-backed securities trustees sued by BlackRock, Pimco and other investors concerning $2 trillion in MBS are due to respond Dec. 15, though they'll likely get an extension until 1Q. The trustees may further [BLANK] responding to Trust Indenture Act claims until an appeals court issues a related decision. Some of the cases may be consolidated with similar suits by other investors and the National Credit Union Administration, which would help minimize legal costs for all parties.

Wilbur Ross, Donald Trump's pick for commerce secretary, said renegotiating Nafta would be the incoming presidential administration's first trade priority. But reopening and [BLANK] the 22-year-old deal is likely to be a protracted process that could stretch beyond Trump's term. Ross said all aspects of Nafta "would be put on the table" during talks, signaling a contentious process for U.S., Canada and Mexico negotiators. The U.S.'s most recent trade deal, the Trans-Pacific Partnership, took eight years to finish.

NorthWestern aims to increase its earned return on equity for its Montana gas distribution and production assets with the latest rate case, filed in September. The company [BLANK] that the earned ROE for its Montana gas business has been about 8.5% vs. an authorized 9.8%. NorthWestern is one of the only utilities in the country that is authorized to acquire natural-gas reserves and put them into its rate base. Owned reserves may help stabilize utility bills by locking in gas prices.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority's efforts to tighten oversight of non-bank mortgage lenders could damp risks for banks, such as HSBC, BOC Hong Kong, DBS and StanChart. Citywide mortgage delinquency rose to 0.03% last quarter, from 0.02% in the previous quarter, while property prices surged. Forward FFO multiples for shopping center REITs are down 7% in 2015 to 17.3x, 14% below the January peak of 20.2x. Strong retailer demand, minimal new construction and M&A interest in the sector, especially from Blackstone, [BLANK] stock prices up earlier in the year. As economic-growth and interest-rate concerns grow, share prices have fallen. Shopping centers have been active issuers of debt this year, showing a need to lock in lower interest rates.

Motor Corp., China's fifth-largest automaker, makes cars under its own brand and has production ventures with Hyundai and Daimler's Mercedes-Benz. The tie-up with Hyundai may see a better profit margin in 2016 after China [BLANK] the vehicle-purchase tax to arrest falling auto sales, and the automaker cut inventory of unsold vehicles. Rivals like VW and GM should see a similar trend. BAIC's profit may get a lift as it started shipments of the new Mercedes GLC SUV in November last year.

The 2016 launch of the first virtual reality headset from Facebook's Oculus may accelerate development of the next computing platform. Microsoft, Sony, Google, Intel, Nvidia and possibly Apple are gearing up to [BLANK] the nascent market. Virtual and augmented reality may be widespread in consumer devices by 2020 if manufacturers can address bandwidth, content, design, processing power and cost challenges. Gaming may be the main use at first, followed by adoption in e-commerce, advertising, education and medicine.

Japanese P&C insurers have made large acquisitions, expanded into new services and bought back shares, and raised dividends as they aim to lift their ROEs to around 10% from an average 6.6% projected for fiscal 2015. Tokio Marine sees [BLANK] ROE at 9% by FY 2017, including HCC Insurance. MS&AD said group ROE may hit 10% by FY 2017 with contributions from Amlin. Sompo, which has invested in nursing-care businesses, aims for over 10% ROE and to be among the world's 10 most-profitable listed insurance companies.

Oasis agreed in October to purchase 55,000 net acres in Williston Basin from SM Energy for $785 million. The acquisition adds acreage and inventory alongside its existing positions in the Basin, and allows it to [BLANK] existing operational knowledge and infrastructure. It increases Oasis' core inventory of drilling locations by about 25%. The company is paying about $36,000 per daily barrel of oil equivalent and $6,000 an acre, according to 1Derrick Research.

California's last nuclear will close as less power demand and the declining cost of renewables make replacing it cost-effective. PG&E cut a deal to [BLANK] down Diablo Canyon by 2025 without seeking a license extension, a nod to anti-nuke sentiment. The California utility is looking to environmentalists for support in recovering decommissioning costs -- about $1 billion above reserves -- and other expenses. PG&E also has an eight-year glide path to replace Diablo earnings via transmission and distribution investments.

FedEx's fiscal 2Q (ended Nov. 30) results may offer insight into the 4Q earnings season for less-than-truckload carriers. FedEx Freight [BLANK] a 2.4% decline in revenue and 9.8% drop in Ebit. Volumes were weaker than expected amid worsening manufacturing. Shipments per day rose 0.9%, while revenue per hundredweight sank 2.2%. Weight per shipment fell 0.8% as heavier shipments returned to truckload networks amid looser capacity. To control costs and preserve margins, management is aligning head count with demand.

Fortescue, the world's fourth-largest iron-ore miner, is likely to be more exposed to the yuan's devaluation than its Australian competitors. It [BLANK] more than 94% of revenue from China over the past seven years, more than BHP, Rio Tinto and Vale. The yuan's devaluation makes it more expensive for Chinese steel mills to import the dollar-denominated raw material. Fewer purchases from China could add to oversupply in the iron-ore seaborne market, putting further pressure on already weak prices.

Basic chemicals P/E multiple discount to global equities, which averages 1.1x over the past five years, has fallen to 3.3x -- its lowest since 2009. A key factor is a weaker volume growth outlook, with global manufacturing indicators slowing, volumes up just 1% in 2Q and the approach of multiyear capacity expansions [BLANK] oversupply. Regionally, chemicals makers in the Americas have fared worst, as lower oil prices lessen the advantage of shale-gas based feedstocks and set up a possible 2016 margin squeeze.

Banco BPM and UniCredit are the two lenders within the STOXX 600 Banks index that trade furthest below average price targets. Against a wider sector that promises an average 20% return to [BLANK] this gap, both banks trade at about half consensus price objectives. For BPM, a thin capital base and concerns about the ability to deliver on revenue targets have weighed heavily. For UniCredit, the exposure to Turkey and fears that the trajectory of net interest income remains poor are the major unknowns discounted into the price.

Meat processors such as Tyson Foods, Pilgrim's Pride and Hormel Foods may need to boost their product innovation initiatives to offset increased price competition for processed meats this year. USDA-projected declines in cattle, hog and broiler prices in 2016 may [BLANK] a 3% increase in total meat production and more industry inventory. Tyson Foods warned of an 11% decline in 2016 sales on expected lower market prices for processed beef and pork.

Property and casualty insurer income may gain from higher interest rates in 2018 as carriers generate a large portion of total revenue from the investment of premiums prior to paying claims. Premiums are mostly invested in medium-term, fixed-income assets with an average credit rating of AA/Aa, so portfolio income [BLANK] to rise gradually from changes in rates. Yields for AA-rated, 10-year corporate debt averaged 3.57% in 2018 through June 1, up from 3.12% in 2017 and 2.77% in 2016.

Credit Suisse likely persuaded a New York appeals court in October to preserve a ruling that dismissed fraud claims from an RMBS lawsuit by bond insurer MBIA. Dismissal of those claims would help [BLANK] the damages that MBIA can seek in the suit, likely cutting them from about $675 million to $436 million, plus interest. Settlement value may be about $300 million.

Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac shareholders probably didn't convince a Philadelphia federal appeals court last week to revive one of their many lawsuits challenging the sweep of Fannie and Freddie profits to the U.S. The sweep [BLANK] safe for now despite a Texas federal appeals court ruling in July that the FHFA is unconstitutionally structured.

Low launch costs, the shift toward online viewing and an opportunity to better monetize content assets will bolster pay-TV's efforts to expand by way of over-the-top models across Europe. Telefonica's plan to [BLANK] an online video service in Germany and the U.K., as reported by El Pais, follows Sky's Spanish entry later this year. These, together with entries from content producers such as HBO, and expansion by pure online video players such as Amazon.com, herald an increasingly crowded market in Europe.

Smaller pay-TV operators have had varying degrees of distribution success in the early days of skinny bundles. Scripps has had its three largest networks [BLANK] on the base package of Dish's Sling TV and Verizon's Custom TV, while AMC has also had its flagship network added. Both companies have smaller networks in add-on packages. This may help ensure greater distribution to customers seeking cheaper TV options. In comparison, Discovery's networks aren't included in either provider's base package.

Data at the ACR 2015 meeting showed as many as 27% of rheumatoid arthritis patients on Sanofi's sarilumab achieved 20% improvement in the disease (ACR20), adjusted for placebo. The drug will compete with Roche's Actemra, which [BLANK] ACR20 in up to 40% of patients uncontrolled by TNF-therapy. Results appear in-line on the more stringent ACR50 and ACR70 metrics. About 30% of sarilumab patients achieved remission, on a par with Actemra. Higher placebo rates in Sanofi's trial may suggest earlier-stage patients.

Multifamily commercial mortgage-backed securities issuance totaled $14.3 billion in the U.S. in December, the largest individual month since at least 2012. Issuance, which includes Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac-backed deals, [BLANK] 42% from November and was up 62% year-over-year vs. December 2016. Strong year-end activity brought 2017 apartment CMBS issuance to a record $94.7 billion, up 14% over 2016. Overall CMBS issuance totaled $186.4 billion in 2017, rising 19% over 2016 and the highest since 2007.

Massive retirements of coal-fired power plants are projected before the 2015 deadline for compliance with the Mercury Air Toxic Standards, which may be extended to 2016 in some cases. The Energy Information Administration [BLANK] that coal retirements in 2015 and 2016 may exceed 30 gigawatts. Natural-gas generation is likely to increase with coal-to-gas switching. Plant retirements may lead to supply constraints, possibly driving up power and capacity prices.

Roche Diagnostics, General Electric and Medtronic may be most exposed to lower tariffs on medical equipment, given they were the largest exporters to China in 2013. A global trade agreement among the U.S., China and about two dozen other countries may [BLANK] tariffs on X-ray machines, magnetic resonance imaging equipment and other medical instruments. China, the second-largest importer of U.S. devices, charges as much as 7% tariffs on these products.

The traditional demand boost from summer driving is balanced by strength in U.S. crude oil production, while price differentials among domestic markets are wider on infrastructure bottlenecks. Exports [BLANK] an outlet amid wide discounts while tighter product inventories and robust demand support constructive views of crack spreads.

Ready-to-eat popcorn/caramel corn sales surged 15.5% in the 52-week period ended May 15 to lead U.S. salty snack sales to 3.4% growth, according to all-channel IRI data. Brands with strong gains [BLANK] PepsiCo's Smartfood, Angies Boom Chicka Pop, Popcorn Indiana and G.H. Cretors. Ready-to-eat popcorn is still a small portion of the market compared with other snacks. The segment accounted for about 5% of U.S. salty snack sales in the period, well below potato chips (33%) and tortilla/tostada chips (22.5%).

Scarcity makes spectrum one of the most valuable assets in the telecom industry. Carriers have [BLANK] about $65 billion in the last three years at FCC spectrum auctions, while the secondary market remains active. Spectrum prices, particularly for frequencies that offer high capacity, have risen rapidly as carriers brace for a surge in mobile-video use. Wireless operators are focused on deploying new spectrum to stay ahead of this data growth while eyeing new spectrum bands for future 5G services.

India's new budget should benefit mini-vehicle sales the most. The nation [BLANK] to increase rural spending to double farmers' income in the next five years. Among other initiatives, the budget will boost credit to farmers and implement crop insurance to protect farm income. Mini-vehicle sales rose 4.7% in the first two months of this year. Mini-vehicles like Maruti Suzuki's Alto and WagonR, which are priced below $8,000, are more attractive to rural car buyers.

Biotech and pharma events include Phase III efficacy data of Alkermes' ALKS 5461 in depression, Synergy's plecanatide in irritable bowel syndrome with constipation and Cosmo's CB-17-01 colon-cancer diagnostic. Phase II data are [BLANK] for Allergan's bimatoprost sustained-release implant in glaucoma, Clovis' lucitanib in breast cancer and BioLineRx's BL-8040 in leukemia. Galena's NeuVax Phase III breast cancer trial has an interim analysis. Spectrum submits apaziquone to the FDA for bladder cancer.

A trade case filed by Domtar, PH Glatfelter and others against copy paper rivals in Brazil, Portugal, Indonesia, Australia and China comes to a head Feb. 9, when the International Trade Commission votes on whether imports have hurt the U.S. industry. Final anti-dumping and anti-subsidy rates released Jan. 11 [BLANK] as high as 260%. Those duties become final with the ITC vote and would remain unchanged until 2017. Punitive duties are likely to remain for five years, with variable rates.

Total pig iron output in Japan, Korea and Taiwan rose 3.8% in July from the previous month and was 3.6% higher than a year earlier. Even with the solid gain, seasonal trends suggest production in Asia, [BLANK] China, may fall in the months ahead. This is unwelcome news for already struggling coal producers that are waiting for pig iron production increases to help stabilize floundering metallurgical coal prices.

Vanguard, the fastest-growing asset manager with $4 trillion in assets, has plenty of room to expand before it hits potential ownership limits on U.S. stocks. Using Apple as a microcosm of the entire U.S. stock market, Vanguard collectively [BLANK] 6.3% of the shares, but none of its funds has more than 2%. The biggest holder is the $428 billion Vanguard Total Stock Market Index (VTSMX). As a diversified fund holding good assets, its stake could rise fivefold before running into ownership caps.

Cisco's opening appeal brief seeking to reverse its Northern California trial loss to Arista is due in August. A jury in January found Arista [BLANK] Cisco's copyrights, yet determined that the violation was protected by a legal doctrine safeguarding use of indispensable elements ("scenes a faire"). Cisco promptly filed post-trial motions challenging the verdict, which the presiding judge denied in May. Cisco's appeal will likely argue the law wasn't correctly applied to its case and ask for a retrial.

Credit Agricole, Deutsche Bank and Societe Generale may be among the next banks to be fined by U.S. authorities for sanctions violations following Commerzbank's $1.45 billion penalty announced on March 12. These banks have each [BLANK] sanctions-related probes, with Credit Agricole's possibly the most advanced. Potential future settlements may be lower than Commerzbank's, which may have been inflated by conduct related to intentional compliance failures and a client's accounting fraud.

The CFTC likely won't require banks to post full margin levels for swaps between affiliates when the regulator approves its final rule on Dec. 16. That decision would be in harmony with U.S. banking regulators, which [BLANK] their rule Oct. 30. By not requiring margin posting by both affiliates, banks will save billions in potential additional margin. Some critics, including Sen. Elizabeth Warren, had called for the CFTC to adopt harsher measures, but the CFTC will likely follow the banking regulators.

Internet-service providers have asked the Supreme Court to hear a challenge to the Federal Communications Commission's 2015 net neutrality order, which put broadband service under the threat of open-ended regulation. The court will likely [BLANK] the issue, leaving it to the FCC to undo itself.

The FDA is expected to issue draft guidance on interchangeability for biosimilar-drug makers in 2015, which may accelerate development and uptake of biosimilar products in 2016. The guidance will allow manufacturers to [BLANK] their clinical studies to have interchangeable designated on the label, which will let pharmacists automatically substitute the biosimilar for the reference product, aiding uptake and taking away from biologic makers' market share.

Eli Lilly is likely favored in its argument over the meaning of claims in one of its method patents covering the administration of prasugrel, Effient's active ingredient, with aspirin. The generic makers argue that Lilly's patent should be limited to administering a single pill that [BLANK] both ingredients. Their argument centers on Lilly's second patent in the case and may not be sufficient to persuade the court to limit the patent in a way that doesn't cover Effient as sold.

Viewership on Discovery's networks fell 11.4% in May on average during prime time among those aged 18-49, based on Nielsen data, vs. a 0.3% rise in April. Its namesake Discovery Channel had ratings [BLANK] 18.9% during the month, following improved trends in 1Q. TLC's viewership declined 6.8%, remaining volatile, though it has shown strength recently, rising in five of the last eight months. Brent may average $59 per barrel this year, according to the U.S.'s EIA, which is similar to the $58 implied by forwards and little changed from the current $54. The agency expects OPEC's average surplus capacity to rise by 100,000 bpd this year to 2.1 million, [BLANK] by Saudi Arabia. Coupled with rising oil inventories, that may prevent large price rises. Declines are also unlikely as cheap oil is fanning demand and forcing production cuts, especially in North America. The region drove 92% of 2014 supply growth.

Sales growth in 2014 may be driven by square-footage expansion and increased investment in e-commerce platforms intended to combat declining traffic and shifting buying tendencies. The teen unemployment rate remains above 20%, which may hurt already [BLANK] teen retailers. An increased promotional environment may be the new normal, which might suppress gross margins. Retailers blamed weather for 1Q sales weakness as traffic continues to decline.

The fragmented structure of the truckload industry makes it perfect for more consolidation. Carriers are [BLANK] to increase geographic presence, tractor count and qualified drivers. Smaller carriers may be more motivated to sell because new regulatory pressure will create added operating and financial challenges. TransForce has been particularly active in 2014, acquiring Vitran, Transport America and Contrans. Knight's acquisition of Barr-Nunn was another notable 2014 transaction.

Post-2Q Earnings Outlook: We believe revising capital spending guidance higher will overshadow Continental's boost to production, which places an even greater burden on 4Q and exit-rate output. Higher spending in 2H, back-end loaded activity as additional rigs are [BLANK] by year-end and a buildup in inventory of wells in progress redirects volume and aids the cadence of production in 2019. Improved capex guidance is a modest positive on well productivity and capital efficiency, but industry cost pressure is bubbling.

Top financials litigation analysis since the week of July 10 included Wells Fargo appearing to get closer to settling with the U.S. Department of Justice's RMBS task force, based on the CFO's comments on July 14 about reasonably possible potential litigation losses. Banks facing DOJ-led probes over RMBS, which also include HSBC, Royal Bank of Scotland, and UBS, may not [BLANK] much relief under U.S. Attorney General Jeff Sessions. Pimco RMBS lawsuits against Wells Fargo have expanded to address a legal reserve Issue.

Improved store traffic and average amount spent per transaction continued to drive sales at U.S. fashion-focused retailers through May 25. The number of transactions, a proxy for shopper traffic, [BLANK] 0.6% from a year earlier, according to SpendTrend's non-cash point-of-sale data. Consumers may have flocked to stores for seasonal items as the weather turned warmer. With the average amount spent improving 1.6%, the category's sales advanced 1%, possibly at better margins compared with a year ago.

A week of industrial data could underscore the divergence in economic fortunes between the U.K. and euro area. British factory output is likely to confirm the sector [BLANK] on growth in 2Q. Industrial production for Germany and Italy may pose upside risks to GDP forecasts for the quarter, while for France the data should show a solid contribution to growth. Further east, a first take on Russian GDP for the quarter is likely to point to an accelerating, albeit sluggish recovery.

Net neutrality, the principle of treating all Internet data equally, is gaining prominence in regulation amid expanding demand for connectivity from video services to machine-to-machine connections. The U.S. Federal Communications Commission is leading the effort, after [BLANK] to regulate broadband services as a public utility. Rules on net neutrality remain under review in the EU. Vodafone, Nokia and Deutsche Telekom have raised concern the Internet of Things may call for more flexible net neutrality rules.

Cloud-based acquisitions will likely focus on the $217 billion infrastructure-software segment as unstructured data, security and storage software gain traction. Legacy providers with large amounts of cash may seek deals to boost capabilities as cash repatriation could [BLANK] more attractive under a Trump administration.

Amazon and Microsoft's partnership to integrate the functionality of their digital assistants is likely the first of many such pairings and should help Amazon Alexa keep gaining share of customer usage. Alexa has an early lead in the home, with a number of appliance and auto integrations, while use of Amazon's Alexa-driven Echo smart speaker is [BLANK] to outsell Google Home 3-1 in the U.S. for 2017.

Ziggo launched its virtual mobile services in 3Q13 and has since amassed 84,000 subscribers. Liberty may [BLANK] a more aggressive mobile strategy, having acquired Ziggo and secured nationwide coverage, with a new focus on market-share growth in addition to multi-play penetration. This together with Tele2's network roll out will likely increase competitive pressure in the mobile segment.

Chesapeake Energy is defending a lawsuit accusing company directors of impropriety around $1.1 billion in loans to former CEO Aubrey McClendon in furtherance of his personal stake in well development. Shareholders allege the directors breached their fiduciary duty to Chesapeake by failing to [BLANK] the existence of the loans. McClendon's borrowing allegedly created a conflict between him and Chesapeake because the loans' terms required him to act in the lenders' best interests and not the company's.

Lockheed-Korean Aerospace ditched ideas of offering a new aircraft model in the competition to build the Air Force's new training jet, leaving Northrop-BAE and Boeing-Saab teams as lone clean-sheet offerings. Lockheed [BLANK] for a lower-risk solution with the proven T-50 platform, making it more competitive on cost. Raytheon enters the fray with its prime-role on a team with Finmeccanica and CAE, giving a boost to Alenia's M-346-based T-100 platform, which had previously lost General Dynamics as lead partner.

Members will be passively enrolled in South Carolina's Medicare-Medicaid dual-eligible pilot during June. Centene and Molina are both [BLANK] in the program, which covers 53,600 beneficiaries. Requests for proposals for Louisiana's managed long-term support services are also set to be released in June. Legislation in Alabama has proposed moving long-term care services from fee-for-service to managed care, which could aid enrollment and premium growth for managed-care companies.

Asthma-COPD drug sales exceeded $24 billion in 2014 and could grow at an annualized rate of 2.9% to about $29 billion in 2020, based on consensus. The increase is being [BLANK] by rising disease prevalence and novel drugs such as monoclonal antibodies used in severe asthma, and LABA-LAMA combinations. Generic-drug pressure will likely increase in 2016 on the LABA+ICS class, which includes GlaxoSmithKline's Advair and AstraZeneca's Symbicort. This will add to the strains of a slowing respiratory market.

JPMorgan and Bank of America are maintaining their underwriting lead in U.S. high-yield debt, which they've held since 2009. These generally [BLANK] top global ranks, though BofA is much stronger in U.S. than in European high-yield. Citigroup follows, similar to 2013-14, as Goldman Sachs gains share to move above Deutsche Bank, with Barclays also gaining to rank next. Morgan Stanley has lost share, along with Credit Suisse, which also moves down a level. Wells Fargo and RBC were stable, rounding out the top 10.

Sequis Life, Nippon Life's insurance partner in Indonesia, seeks to move up 10 spots to become the nation's third-largest life insurer by 2020, according to Nikkei. It plans to [BLANK] that goal by expanding the sales force about fivefold to 66,000, reinforcing its strategy of focusing on agencies, which accounted for 94% of its 2013 new premiums. Market leader Prudential got about 73% of new business from agents. In contrast, Dai-ichi Life's Indonesia venture focuses on bancassurance.

The prevailing black market for fuel in Poland affects fuel sales for local companies such as PKN Orlen and Lotos, as well as international sellers, such as BP and Shell. Tax-evading fuel trade makes up a large part of the Polish retail market, [BLANK] by the second-highest tax as a share of the retail diesel price among all countries in the former Eastern Bloc. The significant discrepancy between disposable income and taxation drives the black market in the country.

Private-equity managers have benefited from an exceptional fundraising environment in the past several years, with last year marking a record at $547 billion. The pipeline remains healthy and activity [BLANK] in 3Q, reaching $309 billion this year, despite slower 1H. Investors are expected to keep favoring alternative investments in search of higher returns and reduced market correlations.

A souring of trade and investment relations between the EU and China may be brewing, as tensions increase between the two economic powerhouses over their opposing approaches to the rules of globalized trade. Major legislative changes are afoot with the EU's decade-long debate on how to [BLANK] global trade and protect its industries from unscrupulous practices, over-capacity and predatory investment strategies. Meanwhile, China is upping efforts at the World Trade Organization to get improved exports treatment.

Pandora is likely to appeal a federal trial court's decision that it must pay Broadcast Music 2.5% of gross revenue to play music for the period from 2013 through 2016. Pandora has other options, including [BLANK] the court hold a new trial or amend its judgment. The most likely course, though, is an appeal to the Second Circuit, which recently decided a related case in Pandora's favor. If Pandora elects that route, it must file its appeal before the end of June.

An additional 18.6 million shares will be available for sale by HubSpot's executives, directions and stockholders following the June 1 lockup expiration on the cloud software provider's March offering. The company's stock is up about 112% since its 2014 IPO, in which it [BLANK] $143.8 million. Following the initial listing, HubSpot's venture capital backers, including Google Ventures, Charles River Ventures, General Catalyst Partners and Matrix Partners, sold $120.8 million of shares in the company.

Utilities in the Stoxx Europe 600 generated a median return of 3.3% in the 12-months ended July 6. This may slow to 1.4% in 2016, as earnings are projected to [BLANK], based on consensus. Utilities in south and central Europe have higher return potential vs. U.K. peers possibly because U.K. utilities have mostly recouped their post-Brexit vote losses. Analysts have ascribed higher price-target premiums to non-U.K. water and waste companies, as well as utilities with more renewables and networks exposure.

Train speed for Class I rails accelerated by 1.4% sequentially to 22.8 mph in the week ended March 20 (week 11), AAR data show. Canadian National (up 5.5%) [BLANK] the most, as the company's network returns to normal following crude train derailments on Feb. 14 and March 7. The group's velocity rose 3.4% vs. a year ago, based on a four-week moving average, and should improve as rails deploy more locomotives and employees to enhance network fluidity.

Infrastructure-as-a-Service (IaaS) software provides the ability to deliver core computing resources and storage via the cloud. Centralizing such functions [BLANK] vendors to lower costs by customizing product scale and price based on customer usage. This flexibility is difficult for on-premise products and offers a competitive advantage to IaaS. This is forecast to reach $28 billion in 2019 from $8 billion in 2014, a 27% annual growth rate, according to IDC.

The life science industry faces a similar demand environment in 2016, driven by steady underlying fundamentals. Analysts [BLANK] mid-single sales and double-digit EPS growth from the group. The rapid uptake of genomics will require the industry to stay ahead of the technology curve. The search for top-line growth continues and, given strong balance sheets, establishes 2016 for another year of M&A. Currency movements may crimp growth, though to a lesser extent than originally expected for many global companies.

The business and tax qualities of renewables fit well into big U.S. utilities' growth plans. The basic utility business faces top-line stagnation, [BLANK] even modest targets of 4-6% EPS gains. Healthy balance sheets and engineering skills make the utilities logical owners of expensive renewables facilities. The typical 20-year power purchase agreement for renewables provides stable cash flow. Utilities such as PG&E and American Electric Power have secured favorable regulatory deals by agreeing to build solar.

Brexit, the Trump administration and elections across Europe continue to exacerbate financial policy uncertainty in 2H, compounded by the potential instability of a new U.K. minority conservative government. Regulatory relief from Dodd-Frank is likely to come from the U.S. regulators long-term, but legislative efforts such as the Financial Choice Act are unlikely to [BLANK] by 4Q end. Brexit negotiations should intensify in 3Q, while regulators across the EU focus on MiFID II as its start date nears.

Private-equity and hedge-fund managers may face a $17.7 billion tax increase over 10 years on their carried interest income whether a Democrat or a Republican becomes president in 2017. Donald Trump, currently the leading Republican presidential candidate, repeated his support for [BLANK] taxes on carried interest during the Sept. 16 Republican debate. Republican candidate Jeb Bush and three out of five Democratic candidates, including Hillary Clinton, have also said they support such a tax increase.

With Deutsche Bank having agreed to settle a lawsuit alleging that four banks colluded to set silver prices for more than a decade and UBS dismissed by the judge, HSBC and Scotiabank are left to defend the suit. Traders of silver and silver derivatives [BLANK] that the banks conspired to manipulate prices using the "London Silver Fix," a now-defunct ritual in which they conferred daily to set benchmarks. Deutsche's settlement was notified to the court in 2Q. UBS was dismissed and the claims narrowed on Oct. 3.

Actelion's cadazolid met its primary endpoint in one of two Phase III trials in clostridium difficile. The result is a setback given the FDA typically [BLANK] two successful late-stage studies for approval. Detailed data and patient characteristics, which are due, may help to explain the efficacy discrepancy between the two identical studies. While a disappointment, the anti-infective therapy won't move the needle on sales for Johnson & Johnson, which will own global rights for the drug after the Actelion deal.

Life science peers consistently articulated weak demand for international academic and government markets in 2Q, however expectations for Europe and the impact from Brexit remains less clear. Agilent has taken the most conservative posture, as it's seeing constrained European budgets and [BLANK] uncertainties. Similarly, Bruker observed funding delays in Germany and France, which it expects to be resolved in 2H. Waters foresees improving U.S. demand in 2H, while funding from the NIH could also be a positive.

The mid-March corrugated price hike initiative appears very likely to succeed. The increase is primarily being [BLANK] by the industry's need to restore earnings margins in the face of higher input costs, particularly for old corrugated containers (OCC). It's also justified by strong industry fundamentals, as reflected in the February data, which remained firm for the sixth consecutive month, with solid box shipments, high containerboard operating rates (abetted by robust export levels) and still-tight inventories.

Pinnacle Entertainment's 1Q earnings followed preliminary results announced April 11 and completion of its OpCo distribution and real-estate asset sales to Gaming and Leisure on April 28. Pinnacle sales rose 1%, on par with consensus and in the middle of a preliminary range [BLANK] April. Excluding the impact of flooding in Texas and Louisiana this year and a vendor-payment refund and retention costs last year, Ebitda would have risen 5%, rather than a reported 1.6%, also within Pinnacle's April guidance range.

Health's Larry Merlo tops the list of highest paid CEOs of companies in the Russell 1000 Consumer Staples index, at $31.3 million in 2013, higher than CEOs at companies such as Philip Morris and Coca-Cola. In contrast, Walgreen's Greg Wasson [BLANK] $13.6 million and Rite Aid's John Standley received $7.8 million in total compensation. CVS shares appreciated 33.4% annually during the past three years vs. 28.6% at Walgreen and 69.2% at Rite Aid.

Dr Pepper Snapple's agreement to merge with closely held JAB Holding's Keurig Green Mountain subsidiary in a cash-and-stock deal valued at $23.2 billion would create a larger and more diverse beverage company. The proposed deal would position the new company to [BLANK] more effectively with the likes of Coca-Cola and PepsiCo because of its sizable distribution reach and high market share in many fast-growing segments, such as non-cola sodas, flavored waters and single-serve coffee pods.

Corn demand is nearing extreme heights relative to supply that it may be just a matter of time before higher prices rebalance the market. Elasticity of demand appears to be [BLANK] to multiple years of declines. The current situation appears similar to 2009's bottom in corn prices. From that low to the 2012 peak, front-corn futures surged about 170%. Despite an extended run of U.S. bumper crops, the ratio of USDA global corn consumption-to-production has risen on the back of more-rapid demand growth.

Paribas and HSBC likely have the most risk of further fines in the U.S. related to foreign-exchange trading practices. Both have [BLANK] forex probes by some regulators, yet Justice Department investigations and potential fines linger for each bank, likely in the hundreds of millions of dollars.

The MBA mortgage applications index fell 0.5% for the week ended Aug. 18 as the purchase index slipped 1.5% to the lowest since the week ending Feb. 17. Refinancing activity [BLANK] 0.3%. The 30-year effective mortgage rate was unchanged at 4.23%, down 29 bps since year-end 2016. On a year-over-year basis, total mortgage applications dropped 21%, with refinancings down 38% and purchases improving 8%. Still, the purchase index is down 12% from its June 2 seasonal peak and July new home sales fell 9% year-over-year.

Citigroup, Deutsche Bank, Barclays and UBS consistently rank among the top four global foreign exchange currency traders in the last several years, according to Euromoney and Greenwich Associates, though ranks and relative shares vary between surveys and years. The four hold an [BLANK] 47% share, according to Greenwich, and 54% based on the broader Euromoney survey. The top 10 have held 77% to 80% share since 2009, according to Euromoney, and 71% to 75%, according to Greenwich.

If efforts to get the case dismissed fail, Barclays and other banks possibly face billions of dollars in damages in a lawsuit by pension funds and others accusing the banks of manipulating the financial benchmark ISDAfix. ISDAfix rates are used for various financial instruments, including to value "swaptions" and price bonds [BLANK] by commercial real estate mortgages. Plaintiffs claim that damages could reach billions of dollars. Under antitrust laws, calculated damages are tripled.

Wells Fargo is among several banks facing RMBS probes by the U.S. Department of Justice, and a settlement could be multiples of the bank's $335 million pact with the FHFA in 2013. A Wells Fargo unit, as mortgage-bond trustee, [BLANK] multibillion-dollar lawsuits by BlackRock, Pimco and other mortgage-bond investors. Wells Fargo was fined by the CFPB and faces government probes and civil suits for opening unauthorized accounts. The bank is one of many defending ISDAfix manipulation suits and probes.

Upbeat China export data for January boosted the valuation for BI's Asia-Pacific commercial vehicle makers in February, as higher trading activity translates into greater demand for trucks. The valuation for BI's Asia-Pacific construction and mining machinery peer group rose in February amid growing optimism about China's [BLANK] asset investment goals this year, particularly in infrastructure development and its manufacturing targets.

Lower fuel retail prices may persist in 2015 with slipping Brent, barring unplanned refinery maintenances or a sudden surge in demand. The recent fall in crude already [BLANK] European retail fuel prices, even in western Europe where taxes on gasoline and diesel account for more than half fuels' retail cost. Average U.K. gasoline prices fell to 1.24 pounds ($1.96) a liter in November, lowest since 2011. Low costs may help cyclical sectors that use diesel, such as transportation.

Weaker auto demand, a visible risk to chemicals volume since 2017, is persisting into 2H. Chemical manufacturers have telegraphed that 3Q results will [BLANK] to show this strain. The slowdown in the U.S., ongoing since early 2018, is the easiest to see. Data for Europe is more volatile. Numbers for China, the world's largest auto market, are now negative.

Banks, broker-dealers and asset managers will get a peek at what U.S. regulators' are planning for 2016 at the Securities Industry and Financial Markets Association's annual meeting in Washington on Nov. 10. Key topics for discussion [BLANK] fixed-income liquidity concerns, algorithmic trading, the systemic risk of asset managers and potential conflicts with EU regulations. Market participants will also learn from several U.S. lawmakers on their expectations as to what the U.S. Congress may or may not do in 2016.

Over 75% of Tempur Sealy's global sales are via third-party distributors such as bedding specialty, furniture and department store retailers, with 49% of sales from its top ten customers. Wholesale distribution will continue via new stores and also by increasing product and brand penetration within its existing doors, benefiting sales and margins, particularly as marketing costs are [BLANK]. Direct, under 5% of sales, is growing, albeit from a small base, and includes three flagship units, e-commerce and catalog.

The latest food halls and communal eateries cropping up in urban hot spots are an upgrade from generations past, offering curated, higher-end dining options that now pose threats to chains' traffic. Food halls could [BLANK] in the U.S. in two years, according to Cushman & Wakefield, and are taking anchor tenant spaces due to their strong draw. Food hall Urbanspace, as well as Restaurant Norman and Threes Brewing (both in unique communal settings), were stops on the Underground Culinary Tour in New York.

A federal court previously ruled the U.S. Health Resources and Services Administration lacks statutory authority to introduce a formal omnibus rule for the 340B drug-discount program. So it's unclear whether program participants would be legally bound to adhere to new "guidance" [BLANK] stricter criteria. Congress may clarify the office's authority if stakeholders successfully challenge enforcement of the proposed guidance, and the health department continues to delay finalizing a number of rules.

The decline in Brent crude has outpaced WTI, assisting refineries based in Europe. With U.S. production [BLANK] to grow for the first half of 2015, the futures market indicates a widening of the Brent-WTI differential. The wider the spread, the stronger North American refinery margins tend to be. This may allow U.S. refiners to increase market share, as well as improve earnings, as the year progresses. Pressure on EU refinery capacity rationalization may therefore continue next year.

A settlement with Rio Tinto is highly unlikely after Vale won a bid to throw out a lawsuit alleging that Vale participated in a conspiracy to misappropriate Rio's mining rights in the Simandou region of Guinea. While the court made no final judgment as to Rio's common-law fraud claims, [BLANK] them to be refiled in state court, these are weak bargaining chips to use in settlement talks. Unlike plaintiff's dismissed racketeering claims, the fraud claims don't provide for triple damages.

Many Bakken E&Ps added to hedges in 2016, likely as a requirement to continue to borrow from banks. Continental Resources has just 3% of estimated 2016 oil production [BLANK] as CEO Harold Hamm remains bullish on the oil price. Continental's pipeline asset sale earlier this year strengthened the company's balance sheet and will help fund its drilling program. Continental was the first mover in the play, owns much of the prime acreage and may be the lowest-cost E&P in the play.

Subsidiaries of AES and LafargeHolcim and coal-fired power trade associations continue a lawsuit against key parts of the Environmental Protection Agency's rule on coal ash disposal, even after enactment of a law overhauling its oversight provisions. The legislative fix - centered on state-based enforcement - could foment legal action by environmental groups, which already sued to [BLANK] the current rule's control over the 110 million tons of coal ash produced annually by utility boilers.

As part of Hewlett-Packard's plans to separate its PC and printer business from its enterprise systems division, the company may focus on expanding switch sales for data center applications to boost growth. As customers increasingly outsource networking functions, data centers have [BLANK] a significant growth area. Switch sales for data centers accounted for only 19% of HP's $569 million total switch sales in 2Q, trailing Arista's 96% and Cisco's 41%, according to IDC.

Sanofi's basal insulin (glargine) franchise market share held stable at 74.4% in the U.S. in October, down only 50 bps vs. a year earlier. Sanofi's franchise and Novo Nordisk's Levemir volume growth have all but [BLANK] in the past five months, potentially due to the drag from the SGLT-2 drug class. Sanofi's glargine franchise includes Lantus and its newly launched Toujeo, which was introduced in 1Q. Sanofi has resorted to deeper discounts to protect its volumes ahead of potential biosimilar competition in 1Q17.

Health care's piece of the $20 trillion 13f pie grew 0.3% in 4Q, led by market value advances of J&J, Pfizer, Gilead and Allergan. Only the IT industry [BLANK] more. The S&P Health-Care Index rose 9%, hinting that share price appreciation, rather than position increases, is the most likely driver of growth in holdings. The first quarter has seen significant share-price erosion especially in biotech and spec pharma as investors rotate out of more volatile assets.

Silicon Labs is among the few companies well-positioned to derive meaningful revenue growth from the dynamic Internet of Things semiconductor market. IoT is a multiyear opportunity for Silicon Labs, and the company's microcontroller and wireless chips [BLANK] it to a market expected to reach $12 billion by 2021. That should support 20%-plus growth for Silicon Labs' IoT segment. Its recent Sigma Designs Z-Wave deal should add $40 million in 2018. The Infrastructure business' 10% growth complements IoT and should help offset expected weakness in the Broadcast and Access segments. Earnings gains are likely to moderate in 2018, as Silicon Labs invests in growth. Margin should be toward the low end of the company's 21-25% long-term model, but increased expenses may modestly trail revenue expansion vs. prior years.

Global beverage sales may rise 2.5% to 3% a year through 2018 as 4% annual increases in the developing Asia-Pacific consumer markets outweigh 1% to 2% gains in the mature Europe and North American markets. Still, growth in 2015 may be [BLANK] by weak macroeconomic conditions in the large Asia-Pacific, Europe and Latin America regions, which have accounted for most of the industry's recent sales growth. The strong appreciation of the U.S. dollar may weigh on near-term sales.

After $300-$400 million of expected 2017 cash outflows for legacy contract charges, KBR should begin to generate a more reliable stream in 2018 and beyond with improved execution. The company used $150 million of proceeds from its recent resolution of a receivables dispute with Pemex to repay loans, [BLANK] it virtually zero net debt. Amid low interest rates, KBR also may capitalize short-term bank debt (used to fund recent acquisitions) to long-term status.

A suit in federal claims court by Fairholme and other Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac preferred shareholders may have about $33 billion at stake. The shareholders are seeking just compensation for the U.S.'s alleged taking of their shares' value, including a liquidation preference which the complaint [BLANK] at $33 billion as of 1Q13. Given a Feb. 21 D.C. Circuit ruling dismissing many claims, this suit may provide shareholders some leverage if and when GSE reform efforts are taken up in Washington.

Medical-device manufacturers are closer to winning repeal of the 2.3% excise tax, following House passage of H.R. 160 on June 18. The House passed a similar bill in 2012, though unlike then, Republicans now [BLANK] the Senate. Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell of Kentucky thus has no political incentive to protect President Barack Obama from following through on his threat to veto this popular bill, so it's likely the Senate will act on either H.R. 160 or a companion measure (S. 149) by the end of the year.

Near-term biotech and pharma events in nonalcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) include data of Galectin's pivotal Phase II NASH-CX trial in patients with cirrhosis in early December, and Madrigal's Phase II data by year-end. Gilead's GS-9674 (FXR agonist) 24-week Phase II data will likely be [BLANK] at the EASL liver meeting in April. Viking's VK2809 Phase II data in patients with fatty liver disease and hypercholesterolemia are due in 1H and Galmed's aramchol Phase IIb Arrest trial data in NASH in May.

Essilor's proposed merger with Luxottica is undergoing scrutiny by various global antitrust regulators. Approvals are likely, though concessions may be [BLANK]. The deal combines market leaders in opthalmic lenses and frames, which may raise competition concerns about vertical and horizontal overlaps. Canada approved the deal in 4Q and Europe may follow in 1Q. Clearances from the U.S., Brazil and China are needed to close, but in-depth scrutiny may push some approvals into 2Q.

In a sign that a U.S. government shutdown can be averted, Congress and President Barack Obama appear to have agreed on a five-day extension to complete the omnibus spending package. This [BLANK] the bill deadline at Dec. 16 and the number of riders that can affect any given industry continues to fall. Those measures that now seem less likely as talks near the finish line include those blocking the fiduciary rule and re-enforcing trade and travel restrictions with Cuba. Still, anything can happen in the final hours.

Citrix hasn't been able to replicate its desktop success in mobile, where large peers such as VMware and Microsoft have gained market share. Growth expectations remain high in the $2 billion enterprise mobility management (EMM) segment, given its importance in [BLANK] security across smartphones, tablets and Internet of Things-type devices. VMware's AirWatch purchase and Blackberry's Good Technology acquisition have aided their market share, while Microsoft has bundled its EMM product with the Windows 10 release.

GoPro said viewership on its YouTube channel surged 200% yoy in 2Q, highlighting how it is counting on a unique content ecosystem to maintain its lead in the action-camera market. The ecosystem, which [BLANK] editing software and video-distribution channels, contrasts with the mostly hardware-only offerings at rivals, such as Sony, Garmin, Panasonic and JVC. GoPro had a 41% market share in 1Q, according to IDC.

Delta trans-Atlantic Yields rose 3.3% in 3Q, the best of international regions, as it expands its Virgin Atlantic joint venture and access to London's Heathrow Airport. American may [BLANK] similar improvements via its access to Heathrow through its British Air partnership. Delta's yields were also aided by the Air France strikes in September although United is not likely to see such improvements with more of its focus on a slowing continental Europe and Germany.

A more-supportive tone on French telecom-market consolidation from Arcep, the national regulator, has unsurprisingly buoyed the share prices of carriers Altice (ATC NA +53%), Iliad (ILD FP +7.3%), Bouygues (EN FP +4.5%) and Orange (ORA FP +4.1%). We still deem a combination of Bouygues and SFR the most viable M&A option, [BLANK] the greater jump in Altice shares today.
