However the sky-rocketing Altice price also reflects the ongoing separation of the company's U.S. business from the parent (Altice N.V.). Yesterday, before the share-price adjustment for the separation, the shares fell 7.25%, in part reflecting the company's removal from MSCI indices.

Morgan Stanley and Bank of America continue bank earnings on Jan. 19 followed by Goldman Sachs a day later. Since the new year, dollar-denominated bank issuance has been [BLANK] by non-U.S. lenders. JPMorgan may lead the charge of big U.S. banks making their inaugural debt offerings of 2016 this week after reporting 4Q earnings. These lenders issued $22 billion of debt last year in January led by JPMorgan ($6.2 billion), Morgan Stanley ($5.5 billion) and Goldman Sachs ($3 billion).

With cost-control and share gains, Principal has offset a meaningful part of the drag in its retirement unit from lower industry fee rates. Though a significant ongoing challenge, this issue may [BLANK] less of a focus in 2018, given Principal's leverage to the firming economy and strong momentum in its other units.

Fairholme and other shareholders of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac are challenging an amendment to the 2008 bailout of Fannie and Freddie in multiple venues, including this lawsuit in the U.S. Court of Federal Claims. The shareholders [BLANK] that the 2012 amendment known as the "net worth sweep" has been an improper diversion of profits to the U.S. Treasury at shareholders' expense. In this lawsuit, plaintiffs are asking just compensation for what they claim was government taking of their property.

The $200 billion-a-year market for application software is dominated by large vendors, including Microsoft (12% market share), SAP (7%), Oracle (5%) and IBM (2%), according to IDC. Many segments are [BLANK] rapidly as new products emerge in response to increasing demand for mobile, cloud, social and analytic capabilities. Salesforce.com, a pure-play cloud vendor, joins the legacy providers as a top-five application software company by revenue, with a 2% market share in 2014.

Roper (ROP +0.8%) is likely to return to M&A mode this year, in our view, and could deploy more than $7 billion through 2021. After a transformational 2016, when the equipment maker [BLANK] $3.7 billion on software acquisitions, it cut debt by $1.6 billion as net leverage dropped to 2.6x. A reduced tax rate and more than $500 million of repatriated cash should bolster its acquisition capacity.

China Internet giants Alibaba, Baidu and Tencent may benefit from industry consolidation given their significant investments in verticals, including online offers of travel, video and local services (restaurants, takeout, and taxi hailing). These companies have dominant market shares after acquisitions, [BLANK] in more rational competition and better revenue focus. Most initiatives are at an early stage with slim sales, while capital expenditure has been increased for market expansion and attracting new users.

Tesla and SolarCity made efforts to demonstrate an improving liquidity position at SolarCity after a slump in cash was reported at the end of 2Q on rising manufacturing costs and financing delays. SolarCity said the cash balance [BLANK] sequentially in 3Q on increased proceeds from system sales rather than leases, and about $1 billion in newly arranged project financing. Assuming that installation growth persists into 4Q, this may continue to bolster the cash balance.

The launch of commercial 5G networks in 2H presents growth opportunities for carriers due to its facility in the deployment of Internet of Things, machine-to-machine communications and connected cars. 5G allows for network slicing to [BLANK] multiple virtual networks within a single network, paving the way for unique new pricing models.

A decline in the number of U.K. traffic-accident minor-injury claims reduces the urgency of the legal reforms on whiplash included in the Civil Liability Bill, which is unlikely to be implemented before April 2020. Yet insurers still face rising claims costs, as car technology [BLANK] increasingly sophisticated and more expensive to repair.

While the idea that China could go on the same gold standard as countries have done in the past is virtually impossible at today's gold price, it doesn't rule out any chance at one. China has two currencies, internal and external, and also does not have to start a gold standard at the market price, so the idea that a "foreign currency" [BLANK] by a high gold price is something that, in order to become a widely held reserve currency, China might have the potential to implement in the future.

Woolworths has curtailed the expansion of its Masters stores to steady the floundering chain by improving product selection and launching new store formats. Slowing the pace of store openings risks [BLANK] the chain further behind Wesfarmers' Bunnings. Masters has posted wider operating losses every year since the chain opened, leading some investors to suggest that Woolworths would be better off closing Masters and focusing on its core supermarket business.

President Barack Obama seeks a 45% cut to methane pollution from the oil and gas sector by 2025, yet new emissions rules may not be implemented during his term. The EPA may [BLANK] its rule on fracked wells sometime this summer, and the Interior Department is aiming to wrap up its flaring rule in 2016 too. The regulations will likely be challenged by lawsuits. If a rule is sent back to an agency, the next president may shape its successor, and a Republican might try to ease requirements.

A number of cloud-related deals this year including Microsoft's pending purchase of LinkedIn, Oracle's planned acquisition of NetSuite, Salesforce.com's deal for Demandware and Vista's Marketo purchase and pending deal for Cvent point to ongoing consolidation in cloud. The primary catalysts for M&A this year have been a correction in the valuations of high-growth cloud vendors in February this year, a slowdown in sales gains and [BLANK] competition and pricing pressure from large vendors.

Ctrip will sustain robust sales growth for the next several years on Chinese consumers' burgeoning travel appetites and the integration of its acquisitions. Waning competition following the merger with second-ranked Qunar, and a push to [BLANK] online bookings overseas with Skyscanner, will further drive revenue growth. The lodging and transportation segments should flourish as cross-border travel surges and as Ctrip improves its technology and expands services to capture rising demand for travel bookings.

Ratings weakness, skinny bundles and corporate turmoil have taken a toll on Viacom with ads falling 4-5% over the past few quarters and affiliate revenue under pressure. Even so, its flagship Nickelodeon network has shown improvement as investments in original programming have [BLANK] ratings. In particular, Nick Jr.'s turnaround has been noteworthy. The Nick networks, along with TV Land and CMT, form the Kids and Family group of Viacom's media networks and account for 40% of the company's profit.

The 57% drop in average monthly WTI oil prices since June 2014, combined with increasing U.S. self-sufficiency for crude, cut Saudi Arabia's exports to the U.S. by 68% in September vs. April 2014's peak. This hasn't been [BLANK] in Saudi spending, with its imports of all U.S. products rising 14.5% in September to 104% of the kingdom's exports. The gain was largely driven by Saudi autos imports, which reached $578 million. Continued weakness in oil prices and U.S. imports may soon require a cut in Saudi spending.

Henry Hub natural gas prices may average close to $4 as resilient domestic output collides with potentially lower winter season heating demand. Prices recently topped $4 per million BTU, as the market [BLANK] the first substantial withdrawals from storage in November due to colder weather, though this optimism faded when demand was not sustained. Last year's price volatility was driven by bitter cold, and intermittent capacity constraints and freeze-offs of wells may not repeat though output will likely remain elevated.

Volatility in the debt and equity markets have prompted office REITs to retreat from capital raising. Office REITs have [BLANK] no unsecured debt since Boston Properties' $1 billion January bond offering. No office REIT has raised equity in almost a year. On the secured lending front, commercial mortgage-backed securities spreads have widened and lenders have indicated a willingness to pull back on riskier loans. Well-capitalized sponsors such as REITs can still find financing for high-quality office assets.

The codification of data storage and transmission principles between the European Union and the U.S. will aid large cloud providers' efforts to run large-scale facilities that manage data in fewer locations. The rules are onerous yet [BLANK] location dependency for storage and transmission. The older Safe Harbor agreement came under substantial pressure following data leaks attributed to Edward Snowden. The new rules clarify what and how data can be transmitted overseas and how it can be stored.

Top Democratic Senators Chuck Schumer and Richard Durbin unveiled a proposal to address corporate inversions by targeting earnings stripping. With no bipartisan support for legislation this year, the proposal will serve mostly as a campaign issue when Congress goes home Sept. 23 to [BLANK] for November elections. When lawmakers returns for the lame-duck session, Schumer and Durbin may try to include the language into a bill extending tax breaks (S.2260) and fail.

Fairholme and other Fannie and Freddie shareholders may get a ruling on a U.S. dismissal bid in 2Q in the shareholders' Court of Federal Claims lawsuit challenging a change to the U.S. bailout of the GSEs. Plaintiffs are scheduled to end [BLANK] documents and taking sworn testimony on Dec. 31. They'll then finish briefing the U.S. dismissal bid and likely have oral arguments, teeing up a ruling. Plaintiffs won early discovery in February 2014, which is helping them contest the U.S. dismissal bid.

Currency swings will have a growing impact on the Asia-Pacific region's corporate earnings. The U.S. Fed's [BLANK] balance sheet, the North Korea threat and Asian central banks' shifting policies cloud the exchange-rate outlook. If the Fed's unwinding is predominant, Asian currencies could weaken, boosting profits for infotech and industrial firms that depend on exports. Selective stock picking will gain importance after emerging markets led Asian stocks higher this year.

The fracking industry could see an increase in patent-infringement litigation among competing drilling-services companies and between smaller R&D firms and larger service companies. The lack of patent licensing revenue generated by drilling-services companies suggests that the value of excluding others from using the patented technology is greater than [BLANK] income from licensing. If that is the case, litigation is likely the next step as the patent holders look to protect their competitive advantage.

A low, yet persistent number of poorer-quality company audits in the U.K. points to continued risks in accounting, even among large FTSE 100 companies.The quality of FTSE 350 company audits has been trending upward during the last three years with 69% good or needing limited improvement, up from 56%, according to the Financial Reporting Council. Still, the number of audits [BLANK] "significant improvement" has edged upward as well to 11% from 8%, the council said.

Falling oil and gas rig counts may pressure frac sand demand and rail carload growth. Rig counts may [BLANK] 40% from their peak this year, based on consensus. U.S. Silica Holdings expects that a 30% to 35% reduction in average rig count could equate to 15% to 20% lower sand demand in 2015. Rig count reductions should be mitigated by a 15% to 20% increase in the amount of sand used per well. Frac sand has been a growth area for rails. For example, Union Pacific's five-year sand compound annual growth rate rose 30%.

Given declining revenue per transaction, which may be exacerbated by recent commission cuts, online brokers Schwab, E*Trade and TD Ameritrade launched robo-advisers in 2016 to increase their fee-based revenue. They join a growing number of asset managers and startups offering automated portfolio management in response to [BLANK] for low-cost investment products. While early results are positive, competition may make it difficult to add meaningfully to earnings and offset trading revenue pressure.

Little North American fracking capacity has been taken out of the market, though oil prices have halved in the past year. Ongoing attrition won't have a noticeable impact until there's a call on equipment as demand [BLANK] up and utilization rises. That now looks less likely to happen in 2015 or even 1H16. For attrition to gain momentum, time must pass as rig owners forgo maintenance spending and cannibalize fleets for parts. Increased service intensity will speed up attrition rates, yet job-size growth is fading.

Caterpillar dealers' power systems sales rose 4% in August on strength in transportation, up 12% on an easier year-ago comparison, and oil and gas demand, which rose 17%, vs. 21% in August 2013. Both segments sell big ticket items, which can [BLANK] monthly volatility. Purchasing of locomotives ahead of Tier 4 emissions regulations, which take effect in January, may be bolstering sales. General Electric, Siemens and Alstom are key locomotive competitors.

Bristol-Myers Squibb and AstraZeneca will have the highest EPS growth from 2017 through 2020, based on consensus. While both are being driven by increasing sales of cancer drugs, Astra is [BLANK] a broader range of drugs than Bristol, which is highly dependent on Opdivo and its combination strategy with Yervoy, and faces risk of disappointment. AbbVie's 12% growth is driven by Imbruvica, which may face several hurdles, while Lilly's 11.3%, like Astra's, is based on the growth of a range of new drugs.

As U.S. stock indexes remain at all-time highs, free-cash-flow yields generally remain depressed across the consumer sector. Some sub-segments -- especially health and home furnishings -- have fallen out of favor, though, causing stocks to drop and [BLANK] yields. While many consumer stocks are still popular, companies including Pier 1 Imports (16.7%), Office Depot (16.4%), Bed Bath & Beyond (16%) and Michaels (13.7%) have attractive yields. Lumber Liquidators, At Home Group and Wayfair have negative yields.

Cable companies are reporting strong subscriber gains amid weak results from other pay-TV operators. Excluding [BLANK] gains by Dish's Sling TV, the entire industry lost 157,000 subscribers in 1Q vs. a 22,000 gain a year earlier. This highlights the risks of skinny bundling to pay TV. Cable is driving stronger results on promotions and capital spending boosts. Comcast's capital intensity will stay at 15% in 2016. Charter's all-digital upgrade of acquired assets will keep near-term capital spending elevated.

Chinese base-metals producers should benefit from buoyant prices in 2018. Demand for copper and electric-vehicle (EV) battery metals such as cobalt will continue to [BLANK], while tight supplies support prices. Aluminum remains squeezed by supply-side reform. Most major base-metal producers reported higher revenue and gross margin due to price hikes in 2017. Volatility in global geopolitical and labor situations is also likely to further compress world supply.

A bill approved by a Senate panel on March 16 may expand opportunities to operate unmanned aerial systems, or drones. The bill would give the FAA the authority to [BLANK] rules allowing drones to fly beyond an operator's line of sight. Implementation of Amazon Prime Air, a future small UAS-based package-delivery system, would be hindered by sight requirements. Amazon.com asked the FAA in 2015 to provide a way for small UAS operators to conduct beyond visual line-of-sight operations.

GlaxoSmithKline's Diskus device U.S. patent expiration in 2016 will leave its lead drug Advair exposed to generics, adding to the contracting woes that pressured sales in 2013-14. Advair could [BLANK] a $2.9 billion cumulative drop in sales in 2016-20, based on consensus. The decline of AstraZeneca's Symbicort is more muted with patents expiring in 2017 in the U.S. and 2018 in most major EU markets. Teva's Duoresp (generic Symbicort) and Sandoz's Airflusal (generic Advair) have already launched in parts of Europe.

The global net supply of U.S. dollar-denominated credit assets, including public and private-sector bonds and loans, rose at an annualized $2.4 trillion in 2Q, 18% faster than 2Q15, based on Federal Reserve data. The net supply of agency and GSE-backed debt [BLANK] markedly to $581 billion in 2Q vs. a net $221 billion expansion in 2015, while mortgages continued trend growth to an annualized $521 billion, the most in eight years, as the mortgage market continues its recovery from the 2008-09 financial crisis.

Volkswagen's financial services unit uses lower leverage than some peers such as Ford, General Motors and Toyota, which underpins credit quality. S&P [BLANK] Volkswagen's finance receivables (mostly vehicle-financing term loans) as excellent, based on annual net credit losses of less than 1% in recent years. Operating profit should remain near record levels, based on company comments, with about 34% market penetration, including China. A 100-bp increase in interest rates would have raised earnings and equity by less than 100 million euros, a consideration given expectations for rising rates in the U.S.

The 2016 IPO of Silver Run Acquisition Corp I, led by former EOG CEO Mark Papa, and Silver Run 's subsequent purchase of Centennial, is a seminal event in the history of energy SPACs. The offering's success was aided by a convergence of improving crude oil benchmarks, [BLANK] investor sentiment and asset values, sponsorship by well-known private equity firm Riverstone and marketing by more established underwriters. But waning optimism, commodity weakness and elevated M&A prices suggest challenges this year.

Mylan-Biocon's biosimilar of Amgen's Neulasta, a longer-acting form of Neupogen that prevents infection in cancer patients, faces a high hurdle for FDA approval. The copy is slated to be reviewed by the agency by Oct. 9, though past reviews have indicated that the demonstration of biosimilarity is difficult for this molecule, likely due to the addition of a molecule called PEG that slows the metabolism of the drug to make it longer [BLANK]. If approved, it would be the first, given peers have been delayed.

Transmission grids and renewables developers and operators should be global winners if emissions policies accelerate. Wind and solar are widely supported by policymakers, and new transmission is needed to [BLANK] them to power users. Coal is being phased out in most western economies and scaled back in much of Asia.

Groupon could secure strategic litigation victories that provide sound defenses against IBM's patent infringement claims, providing the company leverage in parallel patent licensing and settlement discussions. Groupon has challenged two of the four IBM patents in suit, [BLANK] they cover subject matter not eligible for patent protection in view of recent Supreme Court precedent. A third patent is being challenged by Priceline in parallel proceedings. The fourth patent has expired, limiting future liability.

Republicans and Democrats are looking to advance related initiatives before the end of 2016. Republican leaders in Congress [BLANK] to pass the 21st Century Cures bill, while Democratic Vice President Joe Biden is pushing the White House's cancer moonshot initiative. Executives can expect the Republican-led Congress to push an updated version of the House-passed Cures bill in the lame-duck session that follows the election, which could also provide funding and support for the moonshot program.

European airlines earnings are largely expected to rise in 4Q as currency boosts yields and lower fuel costs aid margins. While underlying markets are quite competitive for these carriers, currency swings vs. 4Q14 are improving yields for companies that [BLANK] in euros and kroner and book pound revenue. On international routes, the stronger dollar and yuan are boosting proceeds. Lower fuel prices, albeit diminished by large hedges, are improving margins vs. a year ago, though airlines give some back on labor costs.

Two health-care reform stabilization programs - risk corridors and reinsurance - expired at the end of 2016. Premiums for 2017 federal health-exchange plans are [BLANK] an average of 25%, with the program expirations responsible for about 600 bps of the increase. The maturation of these programs removes the limits on gains or losses a health insurer can generate from public health-exchange plans. Over the long term, Centene and Molina may be able to achieve operating margins exceeding 5% for exchange plans.

Prudential is set to be India's largest life insurer by market value via an IPO this year. ICICI Bank, which holds a stake of almost 68% in the venture, plans to [BLANK] about 12.7%, and that stake could fetch about 50 billion rupees ($740 million), according to Reuters. That may imply a valuation of 2.84x its embedded value as of March, placing it in the mid-range among recent transactions. The valuation would trail deals done by Dai-ichi Life and Nippon Life, and surpass those by Standard Life and Sun Life.

Supply-side reforms in China underpin a constructive outlook for most materials markets in 2018. Progress of such measures will [BLANK] in different sub-sectors, with the government likely to backtrack only on coal cuts in the short run. The moves create an environment rife with opportunities for investors. In urea/nitrogen, analysts' estimates may be too bullish, hinging on inflecting sector fundamentals. Metals projections may understate the staying power of high prices, while pulp and paper's outlook is clouded.

BP's strategy of attacking every facet of claims brought by investor-plaintiffs will likely further pay off as a narrowed class action tied to the Gulf of Mexico oil spill heads to a July trial. Decisions are [BLANK] in 1H on the company's class-action summary judgment motion and bid to toss assigned claims in a fourth set of cases. BP won dismissal of all claims against corporate defendants in a pension suit and dispatched a purported class of pre-spill investors now suing individually.

Mobile-chip sales and margins will continue to face pressure in 2016 amid slowing smartphone-unit growth and rapid price declines. Commoditization of chips, aided by China demand, and competition from in-house chips made by handset makers Samsung, Huawei and Apple may [BLANK] the outlook. Gains from converting 2G and 3G users to 4G may be partly offset by royalty payment hurdles for Qualcomm. Thus, Qualcomm, MediaTek and a less-interested Intel may be driven to go after smaller, more competitive mid-tier handsets.

A slowdown in data-center spending on networking gear, together with a shift in spending to software-defined networking and white-box gear is expected to weigh on incumbent vendors' sales in 2H. Customers [BLANK] heavily on switches and security appliances in 1Q, but may pare spending as the year progresses. Non-branded white-box switches are adding to this pressure by taking share from incumbents. Cisco, HPE, Juniper and others in this group are releasing new products to counter the threat.

The midyear spinoff of Altice USA should help the company shed the overhang that has plagued it since parent Altice NV posted underwhelming Europe results. The move helps [BLANK] on momentum in the U.S. business and drive organic gains. The integration of Cablevision and Suddenlink has yielded operational savings, with Altice USA targeting further cost cuts. To raise data speeds, the company is taking a revolutionary approach by deploying a fiber network that bypasses the lower-cost DOCSIS 3.1 upgrade.

Tropicana and Caesars are among the casinos that stand to capitalize on the $150 billion-a-year sports betting industry if New Jersey wins its case at the U.S. Supreme Court. The Garden State is favored as the law [BLANK] states from legalizing sports betting may be held unconstitutional.

Roche is taking steps to carve out a potential market in first-line kidney cancer by better trying to characterize which patients respond to its combination of Tecentriq and Avastin. The combination previously reported efficacy in patients whose tumors have expression of PD-L1, though this [BLANK] a smaller slice. Yet targeting patients with high immune cell infiltration in their tumors (Teff-high) appears to have better results. However, such a test needs development and oncologist buy-in.

Arista will learn by April 19 whether the patent board will institute a third review in the company's challenges to Cisco patents. Arista has already secured one review of the subject patent, which has been [BLANK] in Cisco's second International Trade Commission cases and its Northern California federal lawsuit against Arista. The parties will know by mid-June if any of Arista's nine pending petitions lead to reviews of the seven Cisco patents being challenged.

Theater chains' risk of lower ticket sales is highlighted by Paramount's short-run deal with AMC Entertainment and Cineplex. Viacom-owned Paramount will make some of its films available on home video 17 days after its theater distribution is [BLANK] to 300 locations. The average time between a movie opening in theaters and its home video release was 106 days in 3Q. Paramount's deal this year is limited to two horror movies it considers suitable for the strategy as it seeks to reduce its marketing expenses.

Online grocery appeals to more customers, given dwindling delivery charges. The attraction is the convenience and cost certainty, given the lesser temptation to [BLANK] impulse items. Online activities remain a challenge for food retailers on lower profitability, particularly when goods are delivered. Click-and-collect grocery, the dominant variant in France, has the potential to reduce a retailer's costs, with its convenience appeal for working families.

Homebuilder confidence fell across all U.S. regions in February, though was higher than year-ago levels in each market except the Northeast, the only region with an index level below 50 indicating more builders view conditions as poor. Public builders continue to [BLANK] markets in Northern California, the Pacific Northwest and the Southwest as areas of relative strength, while the Midwest and Northeast lag. Houston, the largest new-home market, continues to slow amid depressed oil prices and job cuts.

The level of volatility in forward operating estimates for offshore drillers may be driven by the percentage of a company's fleet available for a new contract. Vantage, Ocean Rig and Pacific are the most exposed drillers in 2015, while Ocean Rig and Diamond [BLANK] the 2016 list. On the flip side, Atwood and Transocean have the lowest percentage of contracts to renew in 2015, while Ensco and Pacific Drilling have the least in 2016.

Volkswagen brand unit sales have decreased 8% in 2014, even as new vehicle volume in the U.S. rose 6%, as its products occupy the most competitive car segments. The group's Audi premium make sold 15% more units in 2014, while its Porsche brand's volume [BLANK] 11%. BMW has also benefited from the attraction to luxury products, with a 10% gain in U.S. vehicle sales. Low interest rates and gasoline prices easing total ownership costs will continue to motivate U.S. consumers to buy more expensive models.

The secular decline in coal has been driven by regulations and the abundance of natural gas as a cheaper alternative. Regulations from the Obama administration aimed at coal has forced electric utilities to [BLANK] between either installing costly new pollution controls or retiring certain coal plants. The eventual fate of coal-focused regulations including the Environmental Protection Agency's Mercury and Air Toxics Standards and Clean Power Plan could affect the pace of coal retirements.

Alliant's consolidated return on equity has exceeded 10.7% in recent years, more than 100 bps above the average for U.S. utility peers. This is [BLANK] by Wisconsin and FERC authorized returns on equity above 10%. Its Iowa utility also gets incentive authorized ROEs above 10% for some projects, including the Marshalltown gas-fired plant under construction. FERC cuts to Midwest transmission ROEs may not have much impact on Alliant's consolidated ROE since transmission only represents a small share of earnings.

The top 25 U.S. lodging markets are an important barometer for industry health in the biggest global hotel market, measured by room count. They account for one-third of all U.S. hotel rooms and more than 45% of hotel revenue, [BLANK] by Orlando, New York and Chicago. The top 25, which excludes Las Vegas, is expected to support nationwide 5% revenue-per-available-room growth in 2016, according to STR. Yet, looming concerns of supply growth in these markets may hinder revpar gains through 2017.

The latest "Jason Bourne" movie cost $120 million to make, lower than $125 million for the "Bourne Legacy" in 2012 though higher than previous installments. Even so, the film may generate a solid profit for Universal given it's [BLANK] to take in about $200 million in domestic receipts, according to BoxofficePRO. Globally, it may generate about $450 million in ticket sales. Assuming $40 million in marketing costs would yield about $50 million in profit for Universal just from its theatrical run.

November's jump in new home sales was not a sign that potential homeowners are insensitive to rising mortgage rates. Instead, the spike in rates likely brought demand forward at the expense of future sales, as potential buyers rushed to lock in rates before they [BLANK] further. The expected decline in December's new home sales could be the first indication of higher rates hurting demand. Builders' initial post-election optimism retraced in January, mainly driven by a drop in present single family sales.

Viacom's prime-time ratings losses moderated to 4% in 2016 vs. a 16% slump in 2015, as the company's turnaround plan under new leadership helped the network recover some viewership losses. Despite volatile ratings performance throughout most of the year, Viacom [BLANK] a roadmap to tackle viewer declines. That translated into ratings gains in December as MTV's viewership rose for the first time in five months, while Nickelodeon's remained robust throughout 2016.

China's auto industry will face a pivotal year in 2019 as the nation's new energy credit-trading program sets hybrids up for aggressive sales growth, and redraws the contours of consumer purchasing patterns. The drive to sell more new-energy vehicles will [BLANK] more capital to electric-vehicle startups such as Xpeng, WM Motor and Future Mobility, all of which are based in China. A new auto purchase-tax incentive, if enacted, probably won't rejuvenate sales.

Veeva, Ultimate Software and Cornerstone OnDemand have been able to maintain steady growth along with operating margin in the range of 20%-25%, unlike other cloud peers. Hyperscale vendors including Amazon and Google have [BLANK] on infrastructure software, which has made the competitive landscape a bit easier for smaller cloud application software makers. Large legacy vendors, such as SAP and Oracle, still generate a very small portion of their total revenue in the cloud.

Rig counts in the Permian Basin rose by two in the week ended Aug. 28, while those outside the major oil and gas plays fell by eight. In the major oil plays, all but the Cana Woodford's rig count either [BLANK] or was flat. While the overall gas rig count fell by nine, declines were mainly driven by regions outside the major gas shale plays, as the Marcellus fell by one and the Haynesville added one. If oil prices remain near current levels, recent rig-count stabilization may give way to rig losses in all basins.

Canadian National's management team will lay out its vision for the future and how it plans to execute on its longer-term strategy at its June 13-14 investor event. The railroad already [BLANK] one of the most profitable Class I networks in North America. CN will highlight the technology initiatives it will leverage to push its cost curve lower and maintain its best-in-class margins. Management will also likely highlight some of its growth prospects and how it will get a bigger share of shippers' spending.

Barry Callebaut is shifting more cocoa products to its growing internal chocolate divisions by not renewing less-profitable supply contracts with food manufacturers. That, along with ongoing restructuring, could help profitability [BLANK] next year amid still-challenging cocoa markets. The company's chocolate-product volume grew 7.6%, outpacing a 1.7% drop in markets where it operates in the year to Aug. 31. Though improving, global consumer chocolate demand remains depressed, with hiked prices and smaller packs.

Same-store U.S. sales of sporting goods slid 8% in February, probably due to the continued weak traffic that led to multiple 2016 bankruptcies in the category, along with delays in tax refunds compared with last year. The number of transactions, a proxy for retail traffic, [BLANK] 5.6%, based on SpendTrend's point-of-sale data. The average transaction value contracted by 2.5%, implying retailers may have resorted to deeper discounts to lure shoppers and clear inventory.

Anadarko subsidiary Kerr-McGee has completed more horizontal drilled but uncompleted wells that spent more than 150 days in inventory than any other E&P, with 53 so far in 2016, all in Weld County, Colorado. The group of 53 wells spent on average 280 days in inventory before being [BLANK]. EOG has had 33 of these wells tapped, which were spread across five separate regions. April and May figures are only partially complete and will almost surely rise as more data comes in.

Crude oil and energy have proven in 2017 to be markets for range traders, but they're gaining upside momentum. With a 2017 WTI range of $42.05-$55.24 a barrel, indications at the end of July [BLANK] revisiting the upper end. The near-historic onslaught of futures position liquidation from February through June has been withstood with futures curves indicating demand in excess of supply. One-year futures curves ended July with the steepest backwardation in almost three years.

The pickup in U.S. packaged-food deal volume highlights the near-desperation that leading companies are displaying in an effort to generate growth. Slowing profit, coincident with a rising level of debt-financed deals, may soon [BLANK] on the companies' flexibility to juggle dividend hikes, share buybacks and acquisitions.

Merck & Co. is active in all cancer types with immuno-oncology. It is clearly dominant in the gastrointestinal space, with 55% of recruitment; in breast cancer, where it reinforced its leading position with a staggering 400% enrollment growth since September, and in colorectal cancer, now [BLANK] 47% patient share vs. 32% in September. First-line colorectal monotherapy data for Keytruda is due in mid-2016, while second-line is due mid-2017. Data in triple-negative breast cancer is due in 2017.

New York apartment demand could improve in 2017, meeting new supply, if the Trump administration is a boon to the financial sector. A rollback in regulation may help financial companies, [BLANK] to hiring. Job growth in finance could be offset by cuts in the tech sector, where concerns about the president's immigration policies persist. Overall job growth under Trump would likely help New York City's apartment demand, though REITs' high-priced rentals are generally reliant on higher-paying sectors.

Paragon Offshore put its confirmation hearing on hold until September in order to file an amended Chapter 11 plan and to add evidence on a deal with former parent Noble Corp. The plan is [BLANK] by 77% of bondholders and almost all the lenders on a revolving credit line. It releases claims related to Noble's 2014 spinoff in exchange for Noble's assumption of Mexican tax liabilities. Bondholders would swap $984 million in unsecured notes for $345 million cash and 35% of new equity. Current shareholders will keep 65%.

The rush to acquire industrial software companies may ease in 2H, replaced by partnerships and collaboration after the heightened pace of activity seen over the last 12 months. Companies such as GE, Siemens and Honeywell have [BLANK] the charge, but may now take a breather to digest past acquisitions. In the near term, they will rely on relationships with cloud and infrastructure partners, such as Cisco and Microsoft, to further develop their Industry 4.0 and Internet-of-Things offerings.

The abstracts encompassing key clinical data are now available for the American Society of Hematology annual meeting. Significant data to be [BLANK] include AbbVie's ABT-199, Merck's Keytruda and Bristol-Myers's Opdivo. Johnson & Johnson-Genmab also present noteworthy clinical data as companies developing drugs for blood diseases meet to present their findings in an attempt to address unmet medical needs.

Convenience store sales may get little boost from cigarettes in 2017, as fewer purchases prompt deceleration. Cigarette sales in convenience stores [BLANK] in 2015, reaching 5.2% of total sales, with volume rising 2%, IRI data show, aided by lower gas prices. Unit volume may be flat in 2017, Convenience Store News has said, as a $2-per-pack levy in California curbs consumption. Convenience stores are an important venue for cigarettes, with 70% of such sales generated in such locations, according to IRI data.

There could be a silver lining to the EU regulatory blocking of Hutchison's planned acquisition of O2 UK, which denied owner Telefonica a quick way to deleverage and exit a strategically challenging mobile-only venture in the U.K. Short-term, reconsolidation of O2 UK means boosting credit metrics, given growth in U.K. Ebitda, with capital spending past its peak. O2 UK's customer mix has [BLANK] in the past year, which may also help justify a premium vs. nearest peer O2 Germany on a private sale or possible IPO.

Video-game makers are poised to sustain strong growth through 2018 and beyond amid strong industry tailwinds and new game releases from the largest developers. Game makers should [BLANK] driving strong digital revenue growth thanks to full-game downloads, mobile games and in-game spending. We believe that the console industry's shift to digital downloads has a long road to play out, with games expected to increase to 40% digital in 2018 vs. 35% in 2017, supporting about 100 bps of gross margin expansion a year and propelling EPS growth in excess of sales.

Automakers and the energy industry are being buffeted as policies and market dynamics converge to influence the adoption of plug-in electric vehicles (EVs). Gasoline demand in the U.S. [BLANK] a long-term threat from the wider use of EVs, but the transition is in its infancy and policy support remains a crucial factor. Tesla and GM have passed the eligibility cap for a federal tax credit for buyers this year, which could affect the pace of their sales in 2019. Some states, such as California, provide additional policy support, but it varies widely.

Xcel Energy and its subsidiaries are among 21 U.S. utility and power companies now excluded from the Norges Bank's Government Pension Fund Global due to their coal exposure. The exclusion of Xcel came even though it's the largest U.S. wind energy supplier and has [BLANK] its carbon emissions by over 22% since 2005. Increased scrutiny of coal generation by investors may pose a long-term threat to the ability of some U.S. utilities to raise capital to fund growth.

AT&T's new $180-a-month unlimited data plan for four lines is priced below offers from rivals Sprint, T-Mobile and Verizon. AT&T's unlimited plan throttles users to 2G speeds after they [BLANK] 22 GB per device each month. This equates to $2.05 per GB a month for 88 GB of high-speed data across four devices. The price falls below similar offers from Sprint ($3 a GB a month), T-Mobile ($5) and Verizon ($10), suggesting AT&T's relatively attractive pricing may attract subscribers away from rivals.

From recent late June highs, dated Brent crude prices have fallen 28% and iron ore plunged more than 40% in price to date this year. Compounded by euro strength as expectations that U.S. interest rates will rise are [BLANK], the threat of deflation is increasing in Europe. The IMF has been vocal in its call for full quantitative easing, beyond the covered bond and asset backed purchases announced thus far by Mario Draghi. Should deflation choke GDP growth further, banks will be unlikely to restart lending.

Nvidia's petitions targeting Samsung patents test the patents' enforceability and could undermine Samsung's cases in the International Trade Commission and Eastern Virginia U.S. District Court. The petitions seek a U.S. Patent and Trademark Office review of eight patents Samsung has [BLANK] in lawsuits involving graphics processors used in the company's Galaxy brand mobile devices. The challenges, part of a larger patent-licensing dispute, could influence any settlement talks between the companies.

Valeant and activist investor Bill Ackman's Pershing Square amended their complaint against Allergan in Delaware, calling the drug company's scheduled Dec. 18 special meeting a sham and asking the court to compel Allergan to call a special meeting 45 to 50 days after the court's post-trial order. A trial is [BLANK] for Oct. 6-8, though the post-trial briefing timeline has yet to be set by the court. Allergan must answer the amended complaint by Sept. 9.

Mid-America's largest market, Atlanta, at over 13% of net operating income, posted the second-strongest NOI gain, at 6.5%, behind Fort Worth, Texas (8.8%). Growth was weakest in Houston, which is [BLANK] oversupply. Mid-America earns 3.5% of NOI in Houston. Mid-America's combined same-store NOI grew 3.6% in 1Q, weaker than the prior year's 7.1% but stronger than its 3-3.5% forecast for the year. Rent rose 2.9% and occupancy averaged 96% in 1Q, only 10 bps lower than the prior year.

Post-3Q Earnings Outlook: A worsening currency drag on profit, sharp volume loss in Brazil and destocking in China led Colgate to cut its target for earnings growth and gross margin (with a margin decline now expected vs. a gain seen at the start of the year). This [BLANK] its inability to pass on escalating input costs due to competition. It'll be tough to accelerate organic sales growth to 2.5% in 4Q, needed to reach its low-single-digit goal. Restructuring limits crucial investment toward online expansion and advertising to support premium innovation, such as the Colgate Total toothpaste relaunch in 1Q and naturals rollout (70 markets targeted in 2018), and to regain share from locals. A boost from the lower U.S. tax rate and professional skincare acquisitions (added 1% to volume growth) provide some EPS relief.

Retail sales growth of 3.2% in the second week of March began an acceleration ahead of an earlier Easter in 2018. The data may [BLANK] trends at department stores such as J.C. Penney, Macy's and Sears, and discounters Walmart, Costco, Dollar General and Dollar Tree.

Retailers' ability to seamlessly sell products between stores and online is key to market-share gains and helps minimize margin pressure from logistics and shipping costs. As shoppers increasingly order online, [BLANK] deals become a competitive pricing factor. Technology to track inventory across channels gives retailers an advantage, as stores can be used as distribution centers to fulfill online orders and offer pickup in-store, avoiding growing supply-chain expenses.

A mix of fading returns and longer loan terms may chip away at peer-to-peer loans' growth momentum in China. The average P2P loan return [BLANK] to 9.8% in December from 12.5% a year earlier and 16.1% in December 2014, mirroring lower market rates and PBOC rate cuts in China. Average loan duration grew to 9.3 months in December 2016 from 6.9 months a year earlier. A surge in platform defaults may also cap P2P lending. Loan balance grew at a slower pace in 2H16, according to Wangdaizhijia.com.

New clinical data for Abbott Laboratories' heart valve trials are the biggest device catalysts coming up, given they could usher in competition for peers and open a new therapy to mitral valve patients. Abbott's mitral study is the first U.S. randomized trial that could unlock a market of 1.1 million patients, while its aortic study could help it [BLANK] the $1.9 billion U.S. market to compete with Medtronic and Edwards Lifesciences. Boston Scientific has data for its first-ever drug-eluting stent for peripheral arteries, which we expect will add another driver of organic growth for the company. Medtronic has some good news as it unveils its new robot for spine surgery in partnership with Mazor. But other companies such as NuVasive and Stryker are also launching systems, heightening competition.

Bank, India's second-largest private lender, may continue to shine on asset quality in the bad-debt-riddled Indian banking sector. Its NPL ratio [BLANK] among the lowest of its peers, despite rising slightly to 1.24% in June on farm-loan, waiver-related defaults. In contrast, State Bank of India, the country's largest lender, had a 9.97% NPL ratio as of June. HDFC Bank's conservative lending standards allow it to keep bad loans under control, and boost profitability by keeping credit costs low.

The FCC approved AT&T's $66 billion acquisition of DirecTV, which makes AT&T the largest pay-TV provider in the U.S., with 26.4 million subscribers. As part of the deal, AT&T made some steep yet manageable concessions, [BLANK] to expand its fiber buildout to 12.5 million locations and abide by some net neutrality-related clauses. There was no mention of Title II regulation as part of this oversight. More clarity on the conditions may be provided when the FCC publishes the full memorandum opinion and order.

Gold traders sued six banks in 2014 for conspiring to rig gold prices in violation of antitrust and other laws. Plaintiffs seek recovery for losses incurred as a result of prices they claim were artificially [BLANK]. Barclays, HSBC, Scotiabank and SocGen have lost dismissal attempts. UBS is seeking dismissal a second time after having won a dismissal bid in 4Q. The bank was reinstated to the case in 2Q due to new evidence turned over by defendant Deutsche Bank, which settled with plaintiffs in 4Q for $60 million.

Snap's longer-term user growth may not match Facebook's billion-plus scale, with a focus on a younger users potentially creating a lower ceiling. Android performance issues and Snapchat's data-intensive application may [BLANK] international user growth, even amid extensive core demographic penetration in the U.S.

Japanese steel mills probably will need to import more coking coal in 2Q after a weak 1Q. Buyers likely deferred purchases because the new quarterly benchmark contract was set to [BLANK] close to $150 a metric ton, $135 less than the 1Q contract. Mills may seek to source additional tons from Canada and the U.S. if Australian supplies come under pressure from rail disruptions. Australia provided more than half of Japan's coking coal last year.

North American rail revenue may fall a median 3.8% in 2Q, based on consensus. Declines are [BLANK] for all but three railroads. Genesee revenue may rise 32%, driven by acquisitions in the past year. Canadian Pacific (up 2.4%) and Canadian National (1.2% higher) follow, aided by the stronger dollar, which rose 11% year-over-year in 2Q vs. the Canadian dollar. These railroads benefit from generating revenue in dollars that is translated into Canadian dollars, and from Canadian exports to the U.S.

Singapore's consumer leverage barometers may flash a false stress warning by not reflecting buffers that reduce systemic riskiness of household balance sheets. Mortgage NPLs should increase marginally with higher interest rates or job losses, but still [BLANK] benign due to the regulator's prudence.

In 3Q, the median net interest margin (NIM) at the largest U.S. regional banks was 3%, unchanged from 2Q. This may signal the end of a downward trend that's [BLANK] since 2011. Improved balance sheet efficiency contributed to stable or slightly higher net interest margin for a number of banks including Citizens Financial and SunTrust. SVB Financial and First Republic were among those that saw the largest sequential NIM declines and were mostly affected by non-core items in the quarterly comparison.

The SD-WAN market is still in a nascent stage of development and is composed largely of start-ups. But Cisco's recent acquisition of Viptela gives it the lead position in this market and may [BLANK] further consolidation as the market evolves. In 1Q, Cisco had a 28.8% share of the data-center SD-WAN equipment segment, according to IHS, with VeloCloud second with a 13.7% share and Talari third at 10.6%. Other vendors include Riverbed, FatPipe, CloudGenix and Citrix, among others.

Lockheed Martin and AM General, which lost to Oshkosh for the U.S. Army's $30 billion Joint Light Tactical Vehicle program, may protest the award with the Government Accountability Office. While rarely successful, such protests about major awards are routine, given the potential payoff far [BLANK] the cost. The losing bidders will likely be briefed about the Pentagon's Aug. 25 decision in the next several days and have 10 days from that date to protest. The GAO then has 100 days to issue a decision.

Corporations and public cloud providers such as Google and Amazon will continue using server virtualization, now a standard for deploying processing power. Europe hotel revenue per available room ranges widely across different regions. Alibaba likely will reach its fiscal 2017 sales-growth target of 53%, boosted by rising Chinese online consumption, booming cloud computing, and the media and entertainment sectors. the company's multiple income streams such as ads, [BLANK] synergies from the integration of acquisitions and big-data analysis support faster growth than at rival JD.com. Housing demand in Australia may not increase significantly with the latest Reserve Bank of Australia interest-rate cut, as major banks haven't reduced consumers' mortgage costs by the same extent to preserve their loan margins. Homes may close about 4,200 homes in 2016, representing 23% growth from the 3,404 units closed in 2015. Strong truck sales propelled GM and Chrysler to volume gains in September vs. a year ago. Intel's sales expansion is unlikely to be as profitable as before. Growth in unique visitors to Amazon.com app properties has stalled since August, ending three years of steady gains, ComScore data show. Recent results from stock buybacks across industries are mixed and do not confirm the efficacy of repurchase programs, in our opinion. This [BLANK] concerns about shortsighted capital allocation and value destruction. Rather than buying back stock during robust periods, we would prefer raising dividends or enhancing liquidity for capital intensive, more-levered and volatile industries, such as upstream Energy, among other segments. While investors demand that excess capital be returned to shareholders, repatriation runs counter to investment funds' conventional practice of building and retaining cash when opportunities to deploy capital are sparse.

The Middle East is becoming more competitive in the export of oil products with a surge in refinery construction increasing capacity. While analyst estimates show that leverage at Southwestern Energy may fall to 3.6x by the end of the year, from 6.8x in 2016, year-to-date returns on its outstanding bonds have been relatively flat. PetroChina and Sinopec's lifting costs may be rising more slowly than global oil companies, such as Exxon and Shell. Greater adoption of the public cloud will likely continue to pressure basic IT infrastructure costs and growth for traditional outsourcing companies. Endo and Mylan's 4Q sales and EPS growth were among the top of specialty-pharma and generic peers. Mylan, which [BLANK] a deal for Meda, may have additional firepower for deals in 2016. Duke Energy, Williams Cos. and others building the Southeast Market pipeline system and the Sabal Trail pipeline likely [BLANK] a shutdown coming Feb. 7 after FERC issued a final supplemental review on Feb. 5. Oil and gas exploration and production may not be the best fit for utilities as they undergo industry transformation toward more nimble, customer-centric and carbon-light businesses. The trucking industry could receive some regulatory relief if President Donald Trump's EPA decides to roll back parts of new fuel efficiency and emissions standards for medium- and heavy-duty vehicles. Banks and other financial services companies have until 2018 to comply with new rules designed to boost benchmark integrity. Corporate PC sales are helping the hardware and semiconductor industry. Hardware vendors have been de-emphasizing PCs, yet the industry is having a better year than what PC and IC makers had [BLANK]. Biotech and pharma events include Trevena-Allergan's TRV027 Phase IIb acute-heart-failure data in 2Q. New U.S. rules that may advance in 2016 would limit methane and other emissions from oil and gas well completions, well operations and some oil and gas equipment. In addition to increased R&D on emissions, automakers are expanding efforts on connectivity, digitalization and autonomous driving. North American industrials are poised for a bright 2018, as 2H17 saw a broad-based rebound in global end-markets including energy, mining, construction and trucking. The probable change in regulatory oversight, from Brussels to London, may mean any buyer will want to hold back pending certainty on London's view and jurisprudence over a possible telecom-market consolidation before [BLANK] to firm bids.

MetLife may have persuaded a three-judge panel to side with the insurer, at least in part, in the U.S. appeal of the ruling rescinding MetLife's "too-big-to-fail" tag. Though judges Patricia Millett and Sri Srinivasan were appointed by President Barack Obama and side with the U.S. at a rate higher than the court's average, at oral arguments Oct. 24 they [BLANK] concern that the U.S. didn't properly consider MetLife's vulnerability to financial distress or specify how that might impact other companies.

Wireless displacement of landline voice services may continue to weigh on wireline carriers, as lower prices and quality improvements from wireless drive more households to cut wired voice services. Key near-term events in the biotech and pharmaceuticals industry include the FDA action (PDUFA) dates for GlaxoSmithKline's Breo in asthma, Amgen's ivabradine in heart failure, and Salix's Xifaxan and Actavis's eluxadoline in irritable bowel syndrome. Analytics for big data captured via the connected devices making up "the Internet of Things" presents a huge opportunity for Amazon, given its lead in cloud computing. Pure-play analytics rivals such as Tableau, Qlik and Splunk, as well as large software vendors including IBM, Microsoft and Salesforce.com, are focused on building analytics products that can ingest and analyze data from [BLANK] devices. After a three-year break, M&T has hired a lobbying firm to push for a regulatory relief bill that could reduce its compliance costs and burdens. The financial-services sector's exclusion from the TPP's data localization ban could threaten the deal's enactment. Amazon.com is targeting the "Do It Yourself" customer seeking aftermarket auto-parts, an approximately $50 billion market and an immediate risk to the largest retailers. Republican efforts to raise the threshold of $50 billion in assets that designate banks systemically important financial institutions may allow E*Trade to keep growing without heightened regulation. Soft commodity prices are a key indicator of packaged-food manufacturers' input costs, impacting margin. On June 23, the House passed H.R. 1190, which seeks to repeal the Affordable Care Act's Independent Payment Advisory Board. A steady rise in acquisitions within the North American packaged-food industry has coincided with an increase in the proportion of company goodwill to total assets during the past 15 years. Companies with high ratios are at greater risk of incurring asset-impairment charges, which can reduce reported earnings. TreeHouse Foods, General Mills and McCormick have ratios of 39% or higher.

The gold-price multiples to silver and platinum have increased to historically high levels but may be in-line for a reversal. Yet stricter emission controls and declining inventories are depressing the gold-to-palladium price ratio, which is close to a decade low.

Tesla was granted more time by a court to resolve a proposed consumer class action over claims of defective safety and autopilot features in its Model S and X and the company must report back to the court by Feb. 15.
