If negotiations fail, Tesla will likely try to narrow the claims by the March 15 deadline to respond to the complaint.

Family apparel preliminary February sales rose 7.6% from a year earlier, the most in more than two years, according to First Data. Sales were [BLANK] by a 5.2% jump in traffic and a 2.3% increase in ticket, or amount spent, and may have been helped by an easier year-earlier comparison. Gap, a family apparel retailer, will report February sales on March 5. Consensus calls for same-store sales to rise 1.6%, driven by Old Navy and Banana Republic.

Momentive's first-lien and 1.5-lien trustees are likely to continue their quest for an additional $200 million to $400 million in interest and premiums by appealing to the Second Circuit. Momentive, [BLANK] by shareholder Apollo, got a win on May 5 when district Judge Vincent Briccetti affirmed the bankruptcy court's confirmation order in all respects. Like Judge Robert Drain, Briccetti held that senior lenders' interest on replacement liens should be calculated based on a formula, not the market.

Electric vehicles are set to disrupt the truck market, yet adoption is likely to be measured and confined to niche markets with defined routes in the near term. Increased adoption of advanced technologies should [BLANK] levels of automation, though highly or fully automated trucks are unlikely in the next decade.

Nvidia has gained share from AMD within a discrete graphics chip market characterized by falling sales and shipments, particularly in desktop PCs. The applicability of this chip within PCs may be waning, yet it may continue to [BLANK] premium pricing due to its specialized nature and the complexity of the PC video games it supports. A rise in laptop and mobile gaming may also aid sales. Graphics chips may also be used for parallel processing within servers in high-performance computing and data center applications.

Lantus's share of U.S. prescriptions for long-acting insulins remained above 75% in February, representing the third month of stable market share, after falling to a low of 74.8% in November. This is still lower than the 78.5% share in February 2014, as the Levemir FlexTouch pen and more competitive discounting have boosted Novo's [BLANK] franchise. Sanofi has resorted to deeper discounting to maintain volumes ahead of the 2Q launch of its new insulin drug Toujeo, and biosimilar competition in 2016.

Rakuten is well-positioned to cut mobile phone bills and boost smartphone adoption in Japan, even though its modest budget for expenditure will likely limit its network coverage. The e-commerce company should focus first on grabbing data-heavy users before [BLANK] them by cross-selling internet services.

Reliance Steel & Aluminum's strong operational performance coupled with its long-term commitment to investing in value-added processing equipment has it positioned to take full advantage of higher margins and a strengthened domestic steel market. As [BLANK], Reliance reported 1Q earnings well above guidance and consensus expectations as demand levels across its key end-markets, including energy, improved and supported higher pricing. Overall demand levels are expected to remain strong through 1H.

Production rates, revenue and profit pose little risk to the aerospace industry in 2016 as backlogs are full. Rather, planemakers ponder the risk and reward of [BLANK] money to raise future production rates. Twin-engine wide-body and narrow-body aircraft have the longest backlogs, though there are risks of some production-rate cuts. Slowing emerging markets may trim growth in air travel. Long backlogs, low fuel prices and higher interest rates likely hurt sales, leaving book-to-bill rates below 1x.

Managed-care payers with an increased level of market share on the public health-insurance exchanges may operate with higher margins, given Anthem's margin is at the high end of its 3% to 5% targeted range. Exchange plans offered, as a percentage of total by state, is highest at Anthem (29%) and UnitedHealth (16%), based on state marketplaces [BLANK] by the federal government. Cigna (5%) and Humana (3%) trail peers. A more stable pricing environment in 2015 may also aid margins.

JPMorgan Chase is the largest credit card issuer in the U.S. by loans and is also the biggest U.S. merchant processor by sales volume. But its Card Services segment, primarily a U.S. business, made up less than 20% of its 2015 revenue and [BLANK] income. Among the top six U.S. card issuers, AmEx and Discover derive most of their revenue and earnings from cards. Capital One, which has diversified in recent years, generated about 60% of its revenue and profit from credit cards in 2015.

Roche's $11.2 billion of free cash flow in 2015 is one of the highest in the industry, with only Johnson & Johnson beating it. Pfizer has yet to [BLANK] cash flow. Roche's InterMune acquisition in 2014 propelled net debt to $14 billion at the end of 2015 vs. $7.5 billion in 2013. Johnson & Johnson has the least-efficient balance sheet in the large pharma industry, with $18.5 billion net cash, while AbbVie has the highest net debt after its May 2015 acquisition of Pharmacyclics for $20 billion cash.

Liberty Property aims to expand its warehouse business in the U.K., even though it earns only 2% of its industrial NOI there. Management says supply is especially constrained and e-commerce is [BLANK] demand. Growth in the U.K. will take resources away from domestic expansion, and adds uncertainty as well as volatility to Liberty's quarterly results. Changes in the exchange rate pulled industrial same-store NOI gains below 3% in 1Q, and may hurt 2Q's growth, though not by quite as much.

The Momenta deal bolsters Mylan's long-term capabilities in biosimilars, adding to the nine it is working on with Biocon. A biosimilar Orencia was only drug [BLANK] in the pact. Branded Orencia is expected to sell $1.8 billion in 2015. The total opportunity for Mylan's biosimilar portfolio after the Momenta deal is $63 billion, based on estimated 2015 global sales for the reference products. Mylan will only see a portion of the $63 billion in reference product sales.

Estee Lauder's high cash generation, and with an adjusted net debt of less than 1x Ebitda, will likely lead to more deals. CEO Fabrizio Freda is [BLANK] on cash and debt use for M&A and buybacks. Sales from its most recent acquisitions, "Too Faced" and BECCA, contributed 4 percentage points to the 9% constant-currency sales growth in the March quarter. Lauder spent $1.7 billion on those deals, and $363 million to repurchase 4.2 million shares in the March quarter, with 15 million shares still for repurchase.

The proliferation of sensors in industrial equipment, medical devices, autos and electric meters is expected to increase the devices connected to the Internet. This has [BLANK] a growth opportunity for equipment makers such as GE and Cisco in aviation, freight, transportation and smart cities. There are 9.1 billion devices connected to the Internet, which anticipates 17.5% compound annual growth of 28 billion devices through 2020, according to IDC data.

A trade group representing collateralized loan obligation managers and arrangers is mounting a legal challenge to a Dodd-Frank risk-retention rule requiring them to retain at least 5% of the credit risk for securitized assets. In its lawsuit, the group argues, among other things, that the rule shouldn't apply to CLO managers because the industry [BLANK] well during the financial crisis. The lawsuit was brought in a federal appeals court, which transferred it to district court.

Zika virus is no SARs or Ebola, because it can't be spread by air or through liquids. So far, the main impact [BLANK] to be on pregnant women. Yet, it may lower demand for airline flights into Latin America during the winter season. Such cutbacks on Latin American travel come as both European and U.S. airlines have been cutting their rate of expansion on routes to South America as weakening economies cut demand and fares. In extreme cases, airlines may move capacity to other regions.

Growing labor costs in Asia may pressure branded apparel margins, offsetting any benefits obtained from lower cotton costs, supporters of the Bear Case contend. The region [BLANK] 63% of U.S. clothing. A 2013 factory collapse brought unfavorable international attention to the apparel industry in Bangladesh. Factory owners agreed to raise the country's minimum wage by 77%. China's labor costs are increasing, too, and wage inflation may spread to Indonesia and Vietnam.

Copper mine supply is still expected to rise in 2015, yet less than previously estimated. World copper mine output is now [BLANK] to rise 5% to 19.5 million metric tons in 2015, and 20.5 million tons in 2016, according to the International Copper Study Group. Mine outages related to the weather and to labor strikes are keeping some production off-line. The ICSG expects global refined copper markets to be in a small surplus in 2015-16, with refined copper use growing slower than slower than production.

Mortgage-bond investors have until April 1 to file for class certification in a $3 billion lawsuit against Bank of New York Mellon alleging the bank failed in its duties as mortgage-bond trustee. Briefing on the class certification bid is [BLANK] to end in July, followed by oral arguments on August 5. After a class-certification ruling, which may come in 4Q, the parties may seek summary judgment rulings on the merits. Expert discovery is proceeding in the meantime.

Transistor shrinkage will likely slow substantially at the 15-nanometer range, after which it becomes increasingly cost-prohibitive to reduce size and improve density. As a result, chipmakers seek to raise the bits [BLANK] per cell (Toshiba-SanDisk) or use vertical architecture -- 3D NAND -- to raise transistor density per chip (Samsung, Micron, WD-SanDisk/Toshiba, SK Hynix). Transistor sizes regress to the 40-50 nanometer range with 3D NAND, leaving room for future transistor shrinkage after this transition.

Kia's rising incentive and marketing costs may be headwinds to a loftier operating profit margin. South Korean automakers, including affiliate Hyundai Motor, will likely use short-term promotions to woo car buyers at home and in the U.S., where sales are [BLANK]. Kia and rivals including VW, GM and Toyota are likely cutting global production as they adjust inventory for lower retail sales, lowering margin. Kia may see higher domestic labor costs following workers' strikes demanding higher pay.

China's state owned banks, traditionally reliant on deposit taking and lending, may lose market share to new financing techniques if they don't adopt them. While China's 2016-2020 plan is [BLANK] to emphasize internet-based financing tools amid yuan internationalization, these reforms are relatively new. Regulatory issues such as money laundering, data privacy and investor protection may still arise despite Internet finance guidelines released in July by the central bank and other regulators.

Global investment banks' profit and capital buildup have been hurt by legal risk, costing a median 10% of 2014 revenue through 3Q. Banks aim to accrue much of expected near-term costs into fiscal 2014, [BLANK] the profit drag in 2015 and beyond. Group settlements reduce potential reputational harm to any one bank, though business restrictions may be a risk. Civil liability costs may extend for years, hampering profit and valuations vs. historical averages. Moving past the bulk of charges should reduce risk.

Major Russian oil and gas companies will not regain access to EU capital until 2018, EU leaders indicate in their June summit. The renewal of the 2014 measures [BLANK] on July 31 should formally take place next month. The measures prohibit EU entities from granting loans and purchasing or selling bonds, equity and other financial instruments with a maturity exceeding 30 days and issued after September 2014. They are likely to further push the companies' capitalization and debt-financing efforts outside the EU.

A drop in China's urea fertilizer exports may help ease concerns the country's oversupply will depress global prices. China's urea exports fell 16% in July from a year earlier as the annual low-tariff period [BLANK]. The potential for added pressure on global prices has been closely watched, as total exports jumped 319% in January through June. The July dropoff suggests a change to peak-season tariffs this year, which reduced the tax to about 15% from 77% in 2013, drove the 1H surge.

If Vivendi is successful in its pursuit of Ubisoft, it would probably accelerate the video-game maker's shift toward digital revenue from physical sales, boosting margins and cash flow. Digital sales, [BLANK] full-game downloads, have higher margins than disc sales. Digital in-game purchases and extra content would provide Vivendi with new revenue-growth opportunities. Ubisoft has trailed peers in digital migration, and Vivendi could address this with a more significant effort to boost digital sales.

Post-1Q Earnings Outlook: Currency cloaked a margin improvement in Performance Products in 1Q, masking a key aspect of better downstream business strength. Meanwhile, the margin outlook for 2Q is [BLANK] by many factors that were a transitory drag in 1Q. These include unplanned plant shutdowns, a slow seasonal start in Agricultural Solutions and drag from currency. Solid volume growth suggests price increases should catch up to raw materials pressure, while fixed costs from new plants are slowly absorbed. With a margin surge in Chemicals partly borrowed from Functional Solutions, earnings trends are improving.

Supermarkets and convenience stores wouldn't need to comply with a $1.2 billion U.S. menu rule if a bill easing the requirements to disclose calorie counts becomes law. The bill exempts companies generating 50% or less of revenue from prepared food sales from the rule, which requires establishments to disclose calories [BLANK] in standard menu items. Less than 20% of Whole Foods' 2014 sales came from prepared food. Food service sales were 14.9% of convenience stores' in-store sales in 2013.

Ensco is estimated to report a steeper adjusted earnings loss in 3Q as revenue stalls and expenses climb, with four jackups undergoing surveys. After 3Q, Ensco completed its acquisition of Atwood, [BLANK] four, young active floaters (and two under construction) and five jackups. The fleet has near-term idle risk, underscoring the need for new work, especially for its high-spec ultra-deepwater floaters. Ensco management doesn't expect an uptick in floater work before mid-2018, and no material increase until 2019.

Appalachian hydrocarbon production has consistently outrun pipeline infrastructure, causing the pace of growth to periodically stutter. Yet recent additions have helped relieve some of these chokepoints and will likely [BLANK] to another leg of near-term growth. However, delayed approvals may shift projects past 2016, while other pipeline partners reassess capital spending relative to benchmark commodity prices. Still, improving well results and economics across the prolific basin suggest risk to higher output.

As president, Donald Trump could issue an executive order to revoke or ease U.S. sanctions on Russia set to expire in March 2018. Trump has supported easing tensions with Moscow and possibly [BLANK] sanctions imposed in connection with Russia's annexation of Crimea in 2014. The president has broad authority over the sanctions, which have affected Russian banking, oil and gas industries. Congress could make it harder for Trump to waive them via legislation. EU sanctions' expiration in June may spur action by Trump.

Increased gas use in Italy may boost the need for grid company Snam to invest in new infrastructure, and raise volumes of gas suppliers, such as Edison and Enel. Snam expects gas use in Italy to [BLANK] 1% annually through 2025. It forecasts a 2.7% CAGR for gas use in power generation, and no change in industrial and household demand. There may also be an increase in gas transit via Italy to Europe. Annual gas demand growth of about 1% in the EU through 2030, and declining output, will boost storage capacity needs.

The percentage of higher rates that are passed through to deposit rates, i.e. deposit beta, is a key determinant of banks' potential earnings benefit from rising rates. Banks [BLANK] that deposit betas in the next rising rate cycle will be above the prior cycle due to more deposit competition driven by new liquidity regulations and growth in online banking. Comerica estimates that a 25-percentage-point increase in its deposit beta would reduce net interest income gains from a 100-bp rate hike by 17-28%.

Mining companies with weaker safety records may indicate a higher risk for catastrophic accidents that could halt production and bring lawsuits, as well as be a potential drag on operating efficiency. Antofagasta [BLANK] last or second-to-last across key safety metrics among large base metals mining peers, based on the latest available data from 2014. Its lost-time incident rate rose in 2015. Teck Resources was one of only two companies to see rates for lost-time incidents and fatalities increase in 2014.

The Milliman Hedge Cost Index fell 8 bps to 129 bps in September vs. August. The index shows the annual cost to [BLANK] variable-annuity withdrawal benefits. Milliman assumes a 115-bp rider fee and product features that reflect those in the annuity market, using a dynamic lapse rate and a 10% target fund volatility. For details, use MLHCI DES. The index typically moves inversely to swap rates, which are key drivers. Hedge costs are a limited but important component of annuity margins.

Sabine will seek court approval of its bankruptcy reorganization plan on June 13. The company has [BLANK] threats of creditor lawsuits and won a fight over rejecting midstream contracts, yet unsecured creditors oppose the plan. The creditors committee argues Sabine improperly calculated secured lenders' adequate protection claims by overvaluing collateral as of the petition date and undervaluing it as of the plan effective date. It also opposes proposed releases of claims against third parties.

Annual dividends in the $300-$400 million range wouldn't be unreasonable for United Rentals to pay shareholders but could be a constraint to credit quality. For cyclical industrials in the BB tier, dividend payouts [BLANK] about 35%, or about $400 million for United Rentals, based on its 2018 outlook. Peers using fiscal 2018 outlooks, Ashtead and H&E Equipment, spend about 12% of Ebitda on dividends, or about $430 million for United Rentals.

The Environmental Protection Agency's Clean Power Plan, which aims to cut U.S. coal consumption by an estimated 28% by 2030, was stayed by the Supreme Court on Feb. 9. Yet the rule itself, or a modified version, may eventually be implemented because the high court is unlikely to [BLANK] the EPA's authority to regulate carbon emissions from power plants. Other regulations, such as the Interior Department's moratorium on new coal leases that was announced on Jan. 15, may also reduce coal consumption.

Consumers' desire for value is clear in the outperformance of off-price retailers such as TJX, Ross Stores and Burlington Stores. Each has [BLANK] at least low-single-digit same-store-sales gains over the past year, while full-price rivals posted declines. The key for off-price competitors has been a steady flow of traffic drawn by their constantly changing mix of product, which creates excitement and drives repeat visits. The use of packaways also helps insulate them from any capacity constraints.

Electronic Arts' announcement that it will no longer report non-GAAP revenue amid new SEC guidelines related to compliance and disclosure interpretations may spur peers to do the same. Video-game companies [BLANK] Activision, EA and Take Two report non-GAAP revenue, which equals GAAP sales plus the quarterly change in deferred revenue, to better align expenses with sales. Because most games are online-enabled, developers must defer a portion of revenue for six to nine months under GAAP.

Operators on U.S. land added 58 rigs in November, the biggest monthly gain since the May bottom. Public E&P momentum [BLANK] as the group similarly had its best month yet after the trough. Private E&P activity picked up as the incremental decline in rig additions slowed from August through October, after the group added 76 rigs during the first two months of recovery. Gains have been centered in the Permian and Mid-Continent, with the public-private split at 50%/41% in the former and 43%/55% in the latter.

Pimco, Prudential Financial and other mortgage-backed securities investors seek to recoup more than $2 billion in losses from a Citigroup unit, the trustee for 27 MBS trusts at issue. If the court doesn't allow the investors to [BLANK] on behalf of the trusts, the investors are asking to be compensated directly as a class-action, which may somewhat reduce their overall recovery. A recent ruling by New York's highest court may bolster investor claims that trustees didn't fulfill their duties on time.

There's a little more uncertainty for E&Ps heading into 3Q earnings season compared with other periods, in our view, given the oil rally appears transitory and closer to resistance levels. While commodity benchmarks have popped, money [BLANK] into energy-focused ETFs are soft although inflows into upstream-focused companies are resilient.

Stocks in BI's large-capitalization global asset-manager peer group returned 9.1% in 2017 through the end of May, underperforming the 11.3% market gain as measured by the MSCI ACWI. Signs of extended market share increases by passive funds and further broad fee pressure continue to [BLANK] on the industry even as bond and equities prices have generally gained. The prospect of less U.S. regulation after Donald Trump's election as president is a positive, though coming MiFID II unbundling rules are a headwind.

The federal appeals court overseeing a lawsuit challenging a Dodd-Frank risk-retention rule for CLO managers seems inclined to dismiss the case on jurisdictional grounds. If that [BLANK], the trade association representing BofA, Citigroup and other collateralized loan obligation managers and arrangers will likely refile the suit in U.S. district court. If the appeals court does keep the case, two of the three judges on the panel are Republican-appointed and likelier to rule against the government.

The odds that Volkswagen will be forced to run a corrective advertising campaign and provide consumer redress increased with reports that the U.S. Federal Trade Commission said VW appears to have made false claims about its clean diesel technologies. If the agency formally alleges VW made false claims, the parties would likely come to a settlement, [BLANK] as a consent order. The FTC has broad authority to seek monetary relief for consumers and may go after a company's gross receipts, rather than gross profits.

Air freight routes out of Shanghai gained about 8.5% in October vs. September, recovering from May's lows. The seasonal strength in rates will likely be short-lived, since excess capacity and irrational pricing probably will lead to [BLANK] rates in January. The Shanghai-to-Los Angeles route gained the most, rising 15%. Rates for Shanghai to London rose 5.9%, while Shanghai to New York was up 4.5%. Excluding fuel surcharges, rates from Shanghai to the U.S. increased about 25% from September.

NASA's selection of Boeing and SpaceX as the winners of a competition to shuttle astronauts to the space station under a $6.8 billion program reflected the agency's larger investments in the two companies' initial development work over losing bidder Sierra Nevada. Boeing [BLANK] development goals ahead of the other bidders, making the aerospace giant the least risky pick. SpaceX's experience carrying cargo to the space station also reduced risk.

The Office of the Comptroller of the Currency and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation may give fodder to Democratic policymakers opposed to allowing municipal debt to be classified as high quality liquid assets. The OCC and FDIC didn't [BLANK] on to the Fed's final HQLA rule and likely aren't supportive of congressional attempts to classify muni debt more liquid. Banks under their oversight aren't allowed to count muni debt against their liquidity buffers and their resistance may make lawmakers uneasy as well.

Broadband has been a bright spot for cable operators, becoming their main growth driver as video subscriptions fall. Comcast, Time Warner Cable, Charter and Cablevision [BLANK] 469,000 data customers in 2Q, 37% more vs. 2Q14. While consumers shift from traditional video offerings to other options, including Netflix, cable's data dominance will help lower the risk posed by streaming. Cable added 239,000 stand-alone data customers vs. a 331,000 loss in stand-alone video. Bundled subscribers also increased.

Energy Future Holdings' confirmation hearing for the spinoff plan for Texas Competitive Electric Holdings is scheduled to begin Aug. 17. The proceeding could be delayed if the bankruptcy court [BLANK] the motion of E-Side creditors, Contrarian Capital and Fidelity, to mediate plan issues such as TCEH's proposed use of EFH net operating losses for tax benefits. EFH's original plan was confirmed on Dec. 3, but fell apart when the Texas Public Utility Commission demanded concessions from the proposed Oncor purchasers.

Biotech and pharma events in Parkinson's disease include Sunovion's Phase III efficacy data for treating off-episodes of Parkinson's and long-term safety data by 1Q. Acorda will find out in February if the CVT-301 resubmission is [BLANK] by the FDA for review, and also report SYN-120 Phase II data in Parkinson's disease patients with dementia in 1Q. Neurocrine is expected to give an update in February about the filing requirements of opicapone after meeting with the FDA in January.

Key health-care REIT operating indicators were positive in 3Q, as rising senior housing occupancy reached a seven-year high. Absorption almost [BLANK] from 2Q and remained above accelerating new construction levels. Rent growth jumped to 2.3% from 2% in 2Q, its highest level since 1Q13. Key transaction indicators show volumes rising after a slow start to 2014, including activity by REITs. Average senior housing cap rates are flat over the past year.

With about 60% of its revenue in Washington, the increasing probability of a rate pushback by state regulators may threaten Avista's 4-5% long-term earnings and dividend growth targets. Despite its modest outlook for earnings expansion, Avista's stock has [BLANK] the S&P 500 Utilities Index by about 20 percentage points over three years as of May 2, aided by surging industry takeovers of smaller utilities. Besides Washington, Avista Utilities provides electricity and gas in Idaho and gas in Oregon.

The 2003 law that created the Part D prescription-drug program explicitly prohibits the U.S. government from interfering in price negotiations. Insurers must adhere to a framework outlined by the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) for their Part D [BLANK]. Yet they have freedom within a tiered formulary system to encourage the use of cheaper medicines. Insurers and PBMs negotiate drug prices directly with manufacturers. Democrats have repeatedly, but thus far unsuccessfully, tried to alter this provision.

Energy companies may feel investor pressure to better articulate long-term strategies, particularly around climate change, with the spread of proxy access. At least 21 energy companies, including more than 40% of S&P 500 energy members, have [BLANK] proxy access, largely due to the New York City pension fund's climate concerns. Coal companies would be the most vulnerable to climate regulations, including Arch Coal (filed for bankruptcy in January), Peabody and Cloud Peak Energy. All have adopted proxy access.

Among specialty pharma peers, Allergan is expected to post the biggest revenue gains in 2015 due to the addition of legacy Allergan products but is expected to see a 3% drop in 2016 due to the selloff of its generics division to Teva. That sale will [BLANK] Teva's 2016 revenue gains following a loss in 2015 as generic sales of Pulmicort, Niaspan and Xeloda decline. Endo is expected to see the largest revenue gains in 2016 as the effects of the Par acquisition are felt.

Key upcoming events in energy sector litigation include an expected decision on the fight over Constitution Pipeline's water quality certificate in New York, which is overdue at this point based on the court's average time to decide such cases. The decision could speak to the line between federal and state power in the natural-gas pipeline [BLANK] process, which has direct read through to National Fuel Gas's Northern Access Project. A decision is expected before the end of the quarter.

Zimmer has been losing U.S. hip and knee implant share since it closed its acquisition of Biomet in 1Q. Stryker and Johnson & Johnson [BLANK] the most, likely due to disruption as Zimmer organizes its sales force. Stryker has been driven by its leading Accolade hip and Triathlon knee, while J&J's gains have been driven by the Pinnacle hip and Attune knee, according to Millennium Research Group. Zimmer may continue to lose a bit more market share before sales stabilize in 2016.

Boeing and Airbus's 20-year outlooks are heavily dependent on Asia for new fleet sales. Boeing [BLANK] Asian fleets to increase 2.8x and Airbus expects 2.4x growth, the most of any region worldwide. The expansion is based on strong traffic gains, with Boeing expecting 6.1% over 20 years and Airbus 5.7%. Traffic data from the largest airlines in Asia show a 3% year-to-date increase, with the largest gain from Chinese and Hong Kong airlines. Some have increased capacity by 15% to 25% in 2015.

The energy industry may find oil and natural gas leasing rounds for Mexico's offshore acreage [BLANK], among other possible effects, if leading candidate Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador wins Mexico's presidential election on July 1, but U.S. natural gas exports likely won't be affected.

The funded status of the top 100 defined-benefit corporate pension plans in the Milliman 100 Pension Funding Index fell by $13.2 billion in October after September's $20.1 billion increase. As such, the group [BLANK] a $104 billion deficit. October's decline reflected $56.9 billion of investment losses, partly offset by a $43.7 billion decrease in projected benefit obligations as benchmark interest rates climbed 22 bps. The pension funded ratio, a key factor in assessing the feasibility of plan buyouts, slipped 100 bps vs. September to 93.4%, but this is well above the level seen a year ago. Over the past 18 years, the group's pension-funded ratio has ranged from a high of 138% in August 2000 to a low of 71% in May 2003. Prudential leads in the large-case pension-transfer market; MetLife and Athene are active competitors.

An ITC judge is scheduled to rule Jan. 11 in a patent case concerning technologies used to automatically collect tolls from drivers. Neology is seeking to block competitor Kapsch TrafficCom from [BLANK] products Neology claims infringe its patents. A ruling favoring Neology could complicate a push to have a uniform U.S. standard for electronic toll collection. At trial, ITC staff generally adopted Kapsch's patent claim construction positions, though the judge isn't bound by staff recommendations.

China's online payment growth is fastest in the investment segment, driven by soaring demand for online wealth-management products. Among the most popular is Ant Financial's Yu'E Bao, which [BLANK] customers attractive interest rates, even for short-term deposits. Yu'E Bao's ability to provide higher, bank-beating returns stems from its lower costs and absence of physical branches. China's rapid e-commerce and online travel growth are also likely to keep its online payment growth engine running.

The Solvency II regime for insurers follows former central banker Alexandre Lamfalussy's decision-making process. This [BLANK] four levels, where each level focuses on a particular stage of implementation. In Level 1, the European Commission develops the framework directive, requiring the interpretation of implementation measures, which is then formally decided in Level 2. Level 3 involves EIOPA finalizing the guidelines, with the European Commission monitoring the implementation of the rules in Level 4.

Truckload fundamentals are far from out of the woods despite some positive anecdotal evidence that demand is picking up. Carriers face a number of headwinds from low rates, increased regulation, wage inflation and [BLANK] gains from equipment sales. Flatbed has the brightest short-term outlook due to strength in construction and drilling-related loads. Capacity has stabilized, yet the adoption of electronic logging devices could result in a 5% capacity drop in 2018. LTL fundamentals seem on a more solid footing.

With its first volume drop since 2009, as demand in U.S. metals, energy and Brazil slumped, Praxair is cutting costs. Cuts in Asia [BLANK] the China growth outlook is also weakening. The project backlog fell to $1.7 billion as one major U.S. project was adjusted, yet bidding is active. North America accounts for 40% of capital spending, Asia 30% and South America and Europe the rest. Weak South America volumes and North America manufacturing drove the 2015 EPS forecast lower, with savings targeted for 4Q.

Morgan Stanley disclosed in February a preliminary $2.6 billion settlement with the Justice Department, yet that amount may exceed $3 billion if New York and other states are added to the accord. The bank also faces investor lawsuits over mortgage-related products it sold or sponsored -- and a suit by Virginia -- all of which might [BLANK] the bank more than $1 billion cumulatively. Morgan Stanley also is defending civil antitrust suits related to foreign exchange manipulation, ISDAfix and credit-default swaps.

Yahoo Japan's sales will continue to be supported by a recovery in ad sales growth and rising e-commerce. New mobile products, timeline and video ads, [BLANK] to Yahoo Japan's growth. That happened even amid intensifying competition for online ads, with Line and Facebook gaining share. E-commerce growth slowed at Yahoo Japan, which may spend more on sales and marketing to compete. Operating margin will remain under pressure with the consolidation of Askul, which has much lower profitability.

Ebitda per claim increased 9% in 2Q at Express Scripts (excluding one-time payments) and 26% at CVS Caremark from a year earlier. Growth in the generics dispensing rate, more-favorable drug purchase prices and supply chain efficiency gains [BLANK] growth. More aggressive management of national formularies also allowed Express Scripts to increase Ebitda amid declining prescription volumes. Catamaran continued to decline as its arrangement with Cigna constricted margins.

Favorable demographics will likely support strong mortgage demand in countries such as India, China, Brazil and Indonesia, as their young populations join the work force. Urbanization should further [BLANK] growth prospects. For countries with an aging populace, reverse mortgages could gain popularity.

If enough Democratic Senators oppose Representative Jeb Hensarling's CCAR reform plan, its chances of becoming law are slim. Key Democrats [BLANK] stress testing is the most important tenet of bank supervision. The annual stress-testing program is the primary enforcement mechanism for higher capital requirements. To pass the bill, Hensarling and other Republicans may compromise to give the Federal Reserve enough discretion to curtail dividends or buybacks during a financial crisis, authority the Fed lacked in 2008.

The prodigious volume output in the Appalachian basin has outpaced seasonal demand and infrastructure, affecting differentials and prompting operators to access destinations outside the region to diversify flows and pricing risk. Those flows may [BLANK] against volume native to other regions. Meanwhile, Haynesville gas output may grow, given the recent price increase from previous lows and steady rig count rise, along with operator commentary.

Worker accident rates may indicate a chemical company's safety culture and risk of other types of safety incidents. Events due to accidents, fires or chemical releases may [BLANK] to operational downtime, fines and lawsuits. Dow and Praxair report among the lowest worker lost-time incident rates, along with reductions of over 15% since 2012. K+S, Agrium, CF Industries and Linde trail peers, with above the median lost-time incident rates and increases over the latest reporting period.

Apple's watch creates another opportunity for developers to reach consumers via applications, an opening that may pressure Microsoft should the watch succeed as a product category. Microsoft says its Windows Phone Store houses more than 300,000 apps, [BLANK] the more than 1.2 million apps for both iPhones and Android devices. Apple's tethering of accessories such as the watch to iPhones may hinder Microsoft's ability to attract Windows developers.

Asia-Pacific GDP growth is likely the largest single risk to Boeing and Airbus backlogs. Orders from the region's carriers [BLANK] in anticipation of strong economic expansion and rising middle-class incomes make up 22% of the combined total. Indonesia (596 planes), India (421) and Malaysia (406) account for 53% of the Asia-Pacific backlog and 73% of narrow-bodies, with China and Japan at 14%. Most Asia-Pacific orders are to add capacity, while North American and European orders replace older aircraft.

Bond insurer Ambac has filed several residential mortgage-backed securities lawsuits against units of Bank of America, the largest being a 2010 action seeking more than $2.2 billion from Countrywide and other units. A May 16 New York state appellate court's ruling may [BLANK] the amount of damages Ambac can seek. The court held that the insurer is limited to damages for claims payments it made or will make that can be linked to loan breaches or misrepresentations.

Canadian non-oil sands production maintained its gradual yet steady decline in February, falling 12.1% from a year earlier to 1.05 million barrels a day. Alberta was behind the majority of the decline, [BLANK] its lowest output over four-and-half years with 498,065 barrels a day. British Columbia was the only province where oil production rose with a 9,837-barrel gain from a year ago. With Canadian rig counts at multiyear lows and investment drying up, Canadian non-oil sands production may decline further.

North America-originated commodity carloads fell 6.5% in the week ended Jan. 7 (week 1) vs. a year ago, based on AAR data. Despite difficult New Year's comparisons, which culled one more working day from this year, metallic ores and metals carloads [BLANK] 10%. Strength was driven by metallic ores (up 34%) and coke (up 4%) -- which offset weak scrap and other metal products. Canadian National's volumes in metallic ores/metals, where it has 29% share, rose 43%, pushing its commodity volumes up 9.2%.

Garmin may see slowing sales growth in its fitness division as demand for basic activity trackers slows. A [BLANK] market segment, along with competition from lower-cost device makers including Xiaomi, is hurting Garmin's growth. The company is focusing on the higher-end segment and is leveraging its GPS-tracking technology to differentiate its products such as Forerunner 935 from those of its competitors. Fitbit, a leading basic wearable maker, offers a model featuring an integrated GPS-tracking function.

The EPA is seeking a 30% reduction in CO2 generated from U.S. power plants by 2030 vs. 2005 levels. This target refers to state-level emissions, rather than individual power plants, meaning that theoretically no coal power plants may need to [BLANK] if other measures are enacted, though this is an unlikely outcome. The new ruling presents a sales opportunity for electrical equipment makers such as GE, Siemens and Alstom, across a range of products and services.

Celestica's 3Q sales missed consensus by 2.5%, mainly because of reduced demand from telecom equipment customers. The assembler also said the telecom slowdown may [BLANK] through year-end. That could similarly weigh on sales at Flextronics, Sanmina and Benchmark. Celestica's 3Q sales fell 4.6% to $1.4 billion.

Sinclair's most significant legal battles relate to its purchase of Tribune Media. The company is working to [BLANK] approvals of the deal at the Justice Department and FCC. It will also defend moves by the Federal Communications Commission to ease media-ownership restrictions, which created room for the deal. The company has intervened in a case challenging the FCC's easing of a U.S. cap on TV station ownership, and it may defend an agency decision to allow one entity to own more stations in local markets.

Easy to store commodities track more closely by rolling long future positions with lower roll costs. Gold is the best example of a total return futures index [BLANK] close to spot changes. More expensive to store crude oil is generally reflected in a negative roll cost, but can be positive in times of strong demand.

The ECB unveiled cuts to all three of its main rates as well as plans to restart its covered bond purchases and the readying of a ``sizeable'' asset-backed purchase program to start in October. The bank [BLANK] both its growth and inflation forecasts. ECB President Mario Draghi also explained that these programs could take the ECB's balance sheet back to ``2012 dimensions. '' Currently total assets are 2.04 trillion euros ($2.66 trillion), having peaked at 3.1 trillion euros in June 2012.

Revenue for Brilliance's venture with BMW may improve with the debut of the redesigned 5 Series scheduled for mid-2017. The venture should be able to [BLANK] the decline in factory selling prices with the new 5 Series and X1 SUV. The new 1 Series sedan, launched in February, should also lift revenue. The partnership's revenue in 2H last year probably rose on the new 2 Series Active Tourer and revamped X1 SUV, after it fell in the 18 months through June last year.

China's transition to a services-oriented economy from a manufacturing-based one during the second half of the 2020s will slow growth in oil demand, according to BP forecasts from its January 2014 Energy Outlook 2035. The London-based oil company projects that India's oil consumption gains will overtake China's during the early 2030s, [BLANK] by an expanding middle class, the gradual opening up of the subcontinent's burgeoning economy and low-cost labor invigorating the manufacturing sector.

The market for systems-management software will be driven during the next five years by demand for cross-platform systems and the need to balance resources across virtualized and cloud environments. This market is forecast to [BLANK] to $25 billion in 2019 from $19 billion in 2014, a 6.3% compound rate, according to IDC. This software helps provision resources across applications and workloads, monitor system performance, diagnose infrastructure problems and configure systems to optimize performance.

The already-low odds the Obama administration will recapitalize Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac and release them from U.S. conservatorship could sink to zero. A measure in bill S. 2038 would prohibit the Treasury Department from [BLANK] its shares in the government-sponsored enterprises. It may be included in a budget deal the week of Dec. 14. That would lock in the conservatorship of the GSEs, eliminating the possibility of the administration's action without congressional approval, which is unlikely before 2017.

Unilever, Nestle and Meiji seek to capitalize on China's growing appetite for premium frozen snacks, with General Mills highlighting the market as a growth opportunity for its Haagen Dazs brand at the CAGNY consumer conference. Market leaders Mengniu and Yili are also bulking up product portfolios to [BLANK] over the middle class.

Blockchain has the potential to revolutionize the food chain, from farmers to consumers. Early adopters will be able to reduce supply-chain costs and offer fresher, safer food with a new degree of transparency to consumers, [BLANK] loyalty. Walmart, Kroger and others are partnering with companies such as IBM to validate the potential of blockchain and reap future benefits as challenges such as adoption and transaction speed are resolved.

Exchange-traded fund fees have touched a new low, with BlackRock reducing the expense ratio for the IShares Core S&P Total US Stock Market ETF (ITOT) to 0.03% a year. That equals $3 in fees for every $10,000 invested in the ETF, undercutting the 0.04% [BLANK] by the Schwab U.S. Large Cap ETF (SCHX) and Schwab U.S. Broad Market ETF (SCHB) and inching closer to free exposure to the stock market. ETFs have waged a fee war since Vanguard entered the market in 2001, further fueled by Schwab's launch in 2009.

DirecTV and the NFL scored an early and decisive victory in an antitrust lawsuit brought by the Mucky Duck pub and other Sunday Ticket subscribers. The case was dismissed on June 30 without any option for plaintiffs to [BLANK] their complaint. Plaintiffs challenged as illegal a DirecTV-NFL pact setting up DirecTV as the exclusive carrier of live "out-of-market" game telecasts. The judge ruled that they failed to plead several elements needed to bring an antitrust case. Plaintiffs have 30 days to appeal the decision.

The combined Lowe's-RONA entity will have revenue of C$5.6 billion ($4.1 billion), adding RONA's 496 locations to Lowe's existing infrastructure of 42 stores and giving Lowe's a foothold in the critical Quebec market, where it previously had no presence. Lowe's forecast more than C$1 billion of sales and [BLANK] income expansion as its improves RONA's product mix and cost structure and expands customer reach and omnichannel capabilities. Lowe's is acquiring RONA for $2.3 billion, more than 11.1x forward Ebitda.

ISPs are lobbying the FCC for the same regulatory framework that Internet companies have under the Federal Trade Commission. Internet and ISP companies have [BLANK] data on users for years. But now the FCC wants to place ISPs under a separate, stricter set of rules that would force the providers to give customers the ability to opt out of having their data shared. Internet companies could continue to collect and sell data to advertisers under FTC regulations.

Mortgages are poised to assume growing dominance on Indian banks' balance sheets as home loans become more sophisticated and banks pursue more retail assets. Mortgages offer relatively stable returns with low risk, and carry potential cross-selling benefits that corporate loans [BLANK]. Slower business lending growth may also contribute due to weakening demand for investment loans by high-credit-quality corporate borrowers, and waning appetite for business loans among bad debt-plagued public banks.

The most effective exchanges in last night's Republican presidential debate, giving business some clarity if the party takes the White House, were calls to rebuild the military, level the playing field with China and reform corporate taxes. Candidates were mostly united in calling for more defense spending, curbing China's anti-competitive behavior, cutting corporate taxes to [BLANK] inversions and repatriating cash. Foreign policy and immigration differences remain and have favored the non-establishment frontrunners.

Congress isn't expected to act on Puerto Rico relief before or immediately after a possible Aug. 1 default by the island's Public Finance Corp. (PFC). Even after calls from some lawmakers to [BLANK] H.R. 870, congressional Republicans remain resolved to let creditors continue negotiations, and the House adjourns for its August recess on July 29. The PFC faces an Aug. 1 deadline to make a debt-service payment of about $58 million. The PFC on July 16 failed to transfer enough funds to cover the payment.

Owners of lower-tier malls view discount retailers as a potential leasing option to fill vacancies. From the retailers' perspective, such malls [BLANK] a lower-rent way to reach more customers. CBL & Associates, which has discussed the trend of leasing mall space to discount tenants, is 92.5% occupied vs. a peer group average of 94.8% and has an average rent of $30 a square foot vs. a peer group average of $45. Higher-tier malls offer neither space availability nor low rents for discount tenants.

Nexstar's proposal to acquire Media General for $14.50 a share amounts to an enterprise value of $4.1 billion. This [BLANK] a forward cash-flow multiple of 11.1x, given 2015 consensus Ebitda estimates of $367 million. The deal is expected to achieve $75 million of synergies in its first year after closing. The Nexstar-Media General multiple of 11.1x would be about 30% higher than recent 2015 TV M&A deals at 8.5x. TV and radio broadcasters trade at 10.1x 2015 Ebitda and 8.4x 2016 Ebitda.

Following the oil-rig count's jump in the week ended Nov. 25, the focus shifts to potential implications of this week's OPEC meeting. If the cartel can deliver a production cut and push prices above $50 a barrel, rig-count gains could [BLANK] beyond the Permian and Mid-Continent to plays such as the Eagle Ford and Bakken heading into 2017. If OPEC fails to restrain output, prices may struggle to push past the $50 mark and leave rig additions more localized.

The success of Apple products has elevated the importance of design and user experience, which is now central to new product development across all industries. This trend has raised the visibility and demand for Adobe's creative products, which should see continued growth with increased adoption of [BLANK] technologies such as virtual reality. The shift to a subscription model, which reduces the upfront capital required to use these products, has also been a key growth driver.

American is the most likely North American airline to issue more aircraft-backed bonds in 2014. United's second aircraft-backed bond likely closed out its aircraft financing needs as it has [BLANK] airplanes into May. American has 84 aircraft, largely narrow-bodies, coming by the end of 2015 as it continues to refresh its fleet. Delta has only 28 aircraft in the same period, though they are Boeing 737s, which are easy to finance.

Cinemark's expansion into Latin America, now generating over 25% of the company's sales, is a key secular growth catalyst as the U.S. cinema market matures. In contrast with the U.S. market, the penetration of digital media is much lower in Latin America and theaters there have [BLANK] from strong attendance despite economic and political crises. Cinemark targets 5% long-term screen growth in Latin America vs. 1% in the U.S. Cinemark is the No. 1 operator in Brazil, with 29% market share, and Argentina, with 36%.

Morgan Stanley had the highest revenue from equities trading among global peers in 1H, extending the lead it gained from Goldman Sachs in 2014. Goldman's revenue fell after it [BLANK] its reinsurance business, which accounted for $317 million in 2013 and $1.1 billion in 2012. Even without the unit, Goldman still would have led in those years. JPMorgan held at No. 3, followed by Bank of America, Credit Suisse and UBS. U.S. banks revenue fell 9% in 1H, well outperforming European peer declines of about 25-35%.

Medicaid funding in 2015 represented 3% of GDP and 17% of total U.S. health expenditures, which could draw significant political attention, given the new administration. Fewer new Medicaid contracts and [BLANK] uncertainty over the future of Medicaid expansion is causing competition to intensify. Molina is most exposed, with Medicaid members representing 86% of enrollment as of 3Q, followed by Centene with 84%, WellCare with 64%, Anthem with 16% and UnitedHealth and Aetna with 11% each.

The Reserve Bank of India bought significant amounts of gold when oil prices plunged in 1986, the early 1990's and 2009. Lower oil prices [BLANK] India's balance of payments, giving the central bank room to make gold purchases. India is the world's largest buyer of the metal, according to the World Gold Council, driven by jewelry demand. Crude oil has fallen about 50% since July. Gold is down about 10% in the period.

Shale-gas exploration will not top PKN's agenda in the near term as unconventional gas hopes in Poland faded with a series of poor drilling results and weak gas prices. A keen government and resource potential had brought majors Chevron, Exxon and Total into shale exploration in the country, though they no longer [BLANK] there due to inadequate drilling results. While the primary aim was to reduce reliance on imports, this reliance will likely rise without any shale development as Polish domestic output declines.

Health insurers might see cost pressures ease if legislation favored by Senate Judiciary Chairman Chuck Grassley is enacted. Supporters of the measure, which would increase restrictions on drug patent settlements involving cash payments to generic-drug makers, can argue that it could be used to partially offset the cost of [BLANK] other measures. The CBO estimates the bill would result in quicker introduction of cheaper generic drugs and reduce the federal deficit by almost $3 billion over 10 years.

The Environmental Protection Agency will postpone a decision on the 2014 renewable fuel standard mandates until after the compliance year has ended in 2015. This will [BLANK] that biofuel producer uncertainty persists and may delay new investment plans. The cuts to 2014 renewable fuel mandates, originally proposed in November 2013, will not occur this year, ensuring that neither biofuel producers, nor obligated parties such as refiners, are content with the outcome.

The minutes of the June FOMC meeting further emphasized the confidence among policy makers to maintain a gradual pace of interest-rate increases. While the underlying inflation trend was moving closer to the Fed's objective at the time of the June meeting and labor conditions appeared [BLANK] to drive the unemployment rate further below neutral, there was scant evidence that hawkish-leaning participants were pushing for a more aggressive pace of normalization. Click on the blue link for the full REACT report, published on July 5.

Stocks are struggling to maintain this week's upward bias despite strong 1Q earnings. A simple lack of capitulation may be in the way, as equity strategists and investors alike appear to [BLANK] hopes for recovery. Our regime model harkens back to 2005, the last time markets shifted into late cycle, and suggests the bull is alive but much changed. This year's price action shows when in doubt, investors buy makeup, real estate, power and a little tech. Commodities continue to surge, benefiting energy and materials, while developed markets best emerging markets.

Optimism is increasing for equities even as some manager comments imply caution, State Street's quantitative measure of global institutional investor sentiment shows. The level increased marginally above April 2016 to the highest since 1Q of that year, even as global equities reached a new high as [BLANK] by the MSCI ACWI. North America's jump pushed its reading to the highest since April 2016, again amid price strength. Europe slipped after recent gains, remaining above a year ago, though below 1Q16.

The increase in regional sports network prices has caused multiple programming blackouts, including the most recent dispute between the Yankees' YES Network (80% owned by 21st Century Fox) and Comcast. Comcast is [BLANK] rate demands of about $6 vs. YES' current fee of $5.36. YES' monthly affiliate fee per subscriber has jumped almost 45% from 2011-16. That's 1.7x more than the increase of about 27% in the average monthly cost of a regional sports network to $2.2 per subscriber in 2016, according to SNL Kagan.

Falling commodity costs may allow EU-based packaged food producers to ease food price increases, driving volumes higher, while boosting margins. Through August, the FAO food price index [BLANK] 17% vs. last year, against a drop of 4% in 2014. Petroleum plummeted 41% in the period. August's food prices plunged 22%, with some of the biggest declines in dairy (33%) and vegetable oils (19%). Given the time lag from futures contracts, food companies may be able to delay implementing price increases even longer this year.

Mall REITs ended September at an average forward funds-from-operations multiple of 19.4x. This was down 11% from a record high of 21.8x in January, though [BLANK] 26% higher than the 10-year average. A divergence in valuations persists depending on the quality of the centers REITs own, considering the strong retailer demand for flagship locations. Taubman, Simon and Macerich, which own malls with tenant sales above $600 a square foot, trade at multiples above the peer group average.

The three main types of offshore drilling systems are jackups, semi-submersibles and drill ships. Jackups [BLANK] on solid ground, and can be used in water up to 150 meters (500 feet) deep. Semi-submersibles float and can be used in depths of up to 3,000 meters. For deeper waters, drill ships are used. These are held in place and automatically directed by computer-controlled propulsion systems that counteract any displacing caused by water currents.

Unilever targets 40% sales growth in global e-commerce this year, keeping up last year's fast pace, focusing investments in the U.K., the U.S., Brazil, China and Singapore. The company's partnership with Alibaba, [BLANK] on July 20, reflects efforts to harness booming Chinese e-commerce. Online sales are forecast to expand the fastest in China, at a 43% rate vs. 18% globally this year, according to EMarketer. Online makes up only 1% of Unilever's global sales compared with 5% in both the U.K. and Chinese markets.

Global investment-bank peers generally reported equities trading results that trailed stronger trends in fixed income, with only Citigroup (10%), Bank of America (7%) and JPMorgan (2%) showing year-over-year gains, and UBS flat. In aggregate, revenue fell 4%, yet was 13% higher sequentially, with most banks' revenue [BLANK] in-line with seasonally stronger industry trends. Morgan Stanley and Goldman Sachs remain global revenue leaders, though each had modest drops vs. 1Q16. Banks broadly cited derivatives strength.

With Congress, Treasury officials and now Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen weighing in on the effects of regulation on bond market liquidity, the only conclusion is more study is needed. At a July 15 House hearing, Yellen said regulation may have [BLANK] to Treasury market liquidity deterioration on Oct. 15, but there's no evidence so far. The Fed may pursue additional study as recommended in a multi-agency staff report. Republicans in Congress will continue to investigate, with hearings later this year.

Pep Boys, Monroe Muffler and other retailers may be better prepared for potential tariffs on Chinese tire imports after diversifying sourcing in the wake of tariffs from 2009 and 2012. Pep Boys said it expanded its sourcing to [BLANK] tariff disruption. Chinese exporters lost half of their U.S. market share after the tariffs to other non-U.S. tire makers, whose market share increased to 41% in 2011 from 34% in 2008. U.S. preliminary tariffs may be announced in November.

China and Japan are pursuing the most aggressive monetary easing in Asia to help revive growth. China [BLANK] interest rates five times and banks' reserve ratios three times to boost liquidity since November 2014. Yet Chinese banks' operations have weakened. The BOJ has an 80 trillion yen ($670 billion) annual easing program, which helped weaken the yen and revive domestic lending for Japan's megabanks. Australia has cut its cash rate twice this year, which continues to squeeze margins at the big four banks.

Smart machines -- that improve the overall cost of ownership and enhance food-safety compliance -- will assist in cutting costs in a consolidating food and beverage industry, in our view. The [BLANK] capital-spending boost will likely help bridge the gap between food and drink machinery makers and their European-industrial counterparts.

Pulte is seeking operational efficiencies to lower its SG&A-to-home-sales ratio and support operating margin. SG&A costs were [BLANK] as the company relocated its corporate headquarters to Atlanta from Michigan and increased its investment in information systems and technology. The company cut 350 corporate employees in 3Q to lower its SG&A ratio to 9.7% of home sales. Its goal is 9% or lower. Improved revenue growth in 2017 should drive the company's SG&A ratio toward the target.

Covanta's 2Q earnings should rebound from a disappointing 1Q. More improvement is likely in 2H as Fairfax insurance reimbursements [BLANK] in, maintenance spending abates and the new Dublin plant enters service. 2017 guidance implies low-single-digit Ebitda growth and flattish free cash flow, which could be achievable if commodities remain firm and execution remains strong. Debt repayment should remain the favored use of excess cash, though not much will be left after the dividend.

While not all diabetes mechanisms have shown benefits in liver disease, GLP-1 and SGLT2 drugs appear promising. Data for Novo Nordisk's semaglutide and Eli Lilly's Jardiance at EASL 2018 provide further evidence [BLANK] exploration of these drug classes in fatty acid liver disease and NASH, which are co-morbidities of diabetes.

Reynolds's pending acquisition of Lorillard for $27 billion in cash and stock is the global tobacco industry's second-largest deal since 2004, behind Altria's spinoff of Philip Morris International in a $107 billion transaction in 2007. The industry has [BLANK] 161 deals for a total of $211 billion since 2004. North American companies have been involved in 68% of completed or pending deals, even though the region accounts for only 15% of global sales.

Micron, which is boosting its Inotera stake to 100%, is consolidating DRAM production, streamlining transistor-node migrations for greater control of the company's cash flow. The deal will [BLANK] to margins and earnings, but capex will rise. Financing is flexible, with some Micron equity issued to Inotera's other stakeholder Nanya in a share swap and the raising of Taiwanese debt subject to the market. Like Micron, Inotera is moving to 20-nanometer DRAM. Micron has also restrictively licensed technology to Nanya .

Capital expenditure in the oil and gas industry may increase 2.1% this year to $785.9 billion, before declining 1.6% in 2015, according to consensus. Capex is expected to decline at a rate of 1.7% a year in 2015-17, after [BLANK] a 17.3% CAGR in the 10 years ended 2013. A slowdown could weigh on equipment makers, such as Smiths Group and Alfa Laval. The numbers are based on the top 295 oil and gas companies for which data is available for all periods. Total industry capex is higher.

For the second straight month, a higher percentage of used-equipment sales were made through the retail channel in October. Retail is [BLANK] by used-equipment sellers because values are much higher. Retail proceeds were 95.8% of fair-market value in 2015 vs. 54.4% for equipment sold through auction. Though retail proceeds fell to 94% in October from 97% the previous month, higher volume indicated a stronger market for used equipment. Used-equipment values are a critical factor in new-equipment sales.

Medtronic and Abbott Laboratories will take the spotlight at the 2017 American Diabetes Association medical meeting in June, releasing data on new devices that should boost sales growth throughout 2017. Medtronic will [BLANK] detailed outcomes for its 670G insulin pump, the industry's first hybrid closed-loop system, which has better algorithms, and launch the device to an early group of users. Abbott will have economic data for FreeStyle Libre Pro, which eliminates finger sticks for patients.

Capacity payments, whereby power plants are paid a sum for the electricity they could produce rather than the electricity they actually sell to the grid, may aid the outlook in Europe for electricals. Forms of this practice exist in the U.K. and Spain, though the idea has lost political momentum in Germany, while the Dutch government has [BLANK] against using it. In the absence of a capacity market, gas plants in countries with high renewable penetration may struggle to be profitable.

When consumer confidence is buoyant, food inflation passes unnoticed, with currency volatility the only disturbance. As U.S. interest rates are likely to [BLANK] several times during 2017, currency moves could make products unaffordable in certain countries, as soft commodity costs are generally dollar denominated. If emerging-market economies survive any currency wobbles due to rising interest rates, exposure to these geographies will become an important volume-growth driver.

Cocoa output will fall through 2019 if El Nino hits as expected in 4Q or 1Q19. That would [BLANK] price increases, even if supply in the 2017-18 season (ended Sept. 30) is likely stable vs. the prior year and current cocoa crops are enjoying favorable weather. Price increases decelerated, despite a rebound in demand in mature markets and fast growth in emerging countries.

ITV's "mixed-economy" strategy of building its content production unit, ITV Studios, was reiterated at 4Q results. Given hit shows commonly drive a large part of a producer's revenue, ITV Studios intends to avoid relying on any one content type by [BLANK] the risk across a mix of multiple scripted, as well as unscripted, format investments, such as Talpa Media. Peer production company RTL-owned FremantleMedia saw earnings fall last year, hurt by the cancellation of the U.S. version of its hit show X-Factor.

Southwest Airlines 1Q net income increased 198% as Ebitdar margins expanded 1,210 bps to 24.6%. Performance was [BLANK] by lower jet fuel costs, which fell 37% per available seat mile and generated $400 million in savings. Passenger revenue rose 6%. Southwest increased traffic the most of major domestic carriers, by 7.1%, as it expanded capacity at its Dallas base by 145% to compete with American Airlines. Yields fell marginally at Southwest by 70 bps yet are among the highest of the major domestic carriers.

Takeda's Millennium is appealing its loss at trial against generic-drug makers Sandoz, Accord and Allergan over proposed copies of its multiple myeloma drug Velcade. The Aug. 20 decision [BLANK] one of Takeda's patents, which would have expired in 2022 and covered the bortezomib mannitol ester, Velcade's active ingredient. The decision allows generic makers to launch in 2017, after Takeda's broader compound patent expires. Velcade accounted for $949 million in revenue for Takeda in 2014.

The Federal Reserve said it intends to keep to its view of the Collins Amendment, treating insurance SIFIs as banks for regulatory capital purposes, when it announced a Quantitative Impact Study on the topic. This approach may [BLANK] to onerous standards, especially for separate accounts. The study data is due by year-end and the Fed may propose capital rules in 1H15. MetLife said the study highlighted the need to pass the Collins-Brown bill, which gives the Fed greater flexibility.

Absent an effort to fully repeal the Volcker Rule, policy makers likely will emphasize differences between proprietary trading and market making. In January, Fed Governor Jerome Powell said Congress should revisit prop trading restrictions with the idea of making it easier for banks to [BLANK] and make markets. Banks probably will want to change the rule's market-making exemption, including the definition of reasonably expected near-term demand of customers, or RENTD. Loosening RENTD may increase trading volumes.

Commissioner Scott Gottlieb is aggressively pushing the FDA to speed the review of applications for generic versions of older, off-patent drugs that lack competition, taking particular aim at actions by branded manufacturers designed to slow the generic approval process. The FDA is also looking to [BLANK] outcomes-based pricing discussions and update its policies for new digital tools.

The U.S. and European large pharmaceutical industry ended 2015 with a price-to-earnings ratio of 16.6x. This [BLANK] it fifth among the top-10 BICS industry groups, including only those companies with a market value of more than $40 billion, based on 2015 consensus. The pharma P/E was 18.1x at the start of the year, when it ranked as the third most highly valued. Bristol-Myers Squibb and Novo Nordisk are the highest-valued large pharma companies based on P/E multiples. AbbVie, Pfizer and Sanofi are the lowest.

Cemex's 4Q earnings closed out a year of strong deliveries, from operating efficiencies and lower costs to significant cuts in debt. Ebitda margin [BLANK] estimates on solid contributions from price increases across markets and core products. Free cash flow is the highest since 2007 and negative working capital days moved to minus 4 in 4Q from 12 in 4Q15. With no debt maturities coming in 2017, Cemex can maximize cash from a new cycle of asset disposals, estimated at $2.5 billion.

Sen. Jeff Sessions, Donald Trump's attorney general pick, cited "abuse" of the H-1B visa program for highly skilled workers during a Jan. 10 Senate hearing. If confirmed, he could [BLANK] probes of companies believed to be in violation of the program. Penalties for violations could include fines or ineligibility to apply for future visas. Sessions has been among the fiercest critics of the program during his Senate career, with particular scorn for companies that lay off U.S. workers after securing the visas.

Crude by rail is growing due to rails' faster delivery time, ability to preserve the quality of crude and flexibility. Originated petroleum carloads are up 12.6% year-to-date, with growth [BLANK] by Eastern rails Norfolk Southern (51%) and CSX (28%). BNSF is the market-share leader, with 43.5% growth this year, followed by Canadian National at 18.9%. Union Pacific has lost 1.1% of its petroleum product market share from 2013, the result of a 3.3% decline in petroleum carloads this year.

A trend to high-efficiency solar modules to supply U.S. and Japanese demand is boosting mono-silicon products' market share vs. cheaper, less-efficient multi-silicon. The coming of new contracts in Asia for base metals and gold may lead to increased volatility for these metals. The HKX expects to launch new yuan-denominated copper, aluminum, zinc and metallurgical coal contracts in 4Q, while the SGX expects to [BLANK] one for physical gold later this year. The introduction of the Dalian iron ore contract in 2013 has correlated with iron ore becoming the most volatile of five popularly traded metals.

Becton's leverage ratio should fall by 1x by the end of fiscal 2018. The company's leverage is projected to reach 4.7x Ebitda after using $10 billion in debt to [BLANK] a portion of the Bard deal. Becton has laid out a target of being below 3x within a period of three years. A pro forma analysis of 2018 models $5.3 billion in Ebitda. Assuming Becton can pay down $1.5 billion in debt in the first year would leave it at 3.7x exiting 2018. It paid off its $1 billion CareFusion term loan within a year.

Terex affirmed its EPS forecast during its 2Q earnings call, though lowered share count and interest expense to offset weaker revenue and margin targets. Based on the midpoint of Terex's updated projections, [BLANK] income-to-interest expense should be about 4.7x for 2014, which compares with 6.8x for similarly rated peer Oshkosh over the last 12 months. Industry cyclicality, financial policies, and operational execution may drive credit quality going forward.

Conversations with participants at the 2018 International Builders' Show revealed a broad optimism that the industry's cycle still has years of growth ahead. Robust economic activity is expected to drive the market, though the effects of tax reform and the potential for higher rates have [BLANK] as key risks.

Loyalty-program integration at the Palms, which Red Rock acquired Oct. 1, should buoy 4Q revenue. Yet disruption from facade and interior renovation at flagship Palace Station may [BLANK] Ebitda at that property for the next 12 months. Las Vegas casino and total revenue grew 6% in 3Q, exceeding the locals market's 0.6% July-September win advance. Casino and hotel margin improved in Las Vegas, but food and beverage margin dipped because of new restaurants and service enhancements.

India's coal demand could mitigate lower shipments to China. Seaborne thermal-coal deliveries to India may [BLANK] 13% in 2015 to 160 million tons, according to consensus forecasts. India imports mostly sub-bituminous grades from Indonesia and higher calorific-value coals from South Africa via Capesize, Panamax and Supramax fleets. India's highest court cancelled most of the country's permit allocations for captive use, stoking demand for coal imports. The fuel is used to generate more than 60% of India's power.

Stock buybacks among the five largest defense contractors slowed to $4 billion in 2Q from $5.8 billion in 1Q, as shares reach record highs. Reduced spending may [BLANK] EPS growth. Lockheed cut share repurchases to their lowest since 2005, though plans to resume in 3Q. General Dynamics expects to reduce the pace of repurchases after spending $2.7 billion in 1H. Buybacks have aided EPS growth among defense primes, including a 1,100-bp boost to Northrop's 2Q EPS.

Toyota raised its operating income forecast for the fiscal year ending March, but investors may still be disappointed. The Japanese auto giant increased [BLANK] income by 150 billion yen ($1.33 billion) for the year on lower forex losses and higher sales volume. Excluding currency-move impacts, operating margin would likely be less than the prior forecast of 6.5%. Higher marketing and incentive costs to drum up sales in the U.S. may dent profit margin. The yen depreciated 11% in the four months through January.

Tata Motors' revenue should grow as it exports more Jaguar Land Rovers (JLR) to China. Chinese consumers are likely to [BLANK] more imported JLRs in the coming quarters in the wake of July's lowering of the nation's auto-import tariff to 15% from 25%. The automaker's proprietary branded commercial vehicles should get a sales boost in India as the country steps up its investment in infrastructure. Yet sluggish JLR-branded unit sales in the U.S. and Europe could partially offset revenue growth in Asia. Profit margin could get squeezed as JLR increases incentive spending to prop up shipments to the U.S. Luxury marques such as Mercedes, BMW and Audi are also likely to boost their U.S. promotional spending. Europe's diesel issues and Brexit uncertainties could weigh on JLR production, raising per-unit manufacturing costs.

Of the 70 gigawatts of electricity entered in the U.K.'s 2020-21 auction, 25% failed to secure capacity payments. Uniper, RWE and Centrica [BLANK] aggressively low to boost the visibility of future cash flows for their existing U.K. power plants. This helped them secure capacity payments for at least 90% of their entered capacity. A higher rejection rate for SSE, Iberdrola, Drax, E.ON and National Grid is partly due to their plans to build new capacity, which requires a higher price compared with operational assets.

Equity Residential's portfolio sale to Starwood Capital is part of a trend of apartment REITs selling while private-equity firms buy. Equity Residential plans to [BLANK] a special dividend rather than recycle the $6 billion into acquisitions. The company didn't even consider pursuing New York City's Stuyvesant Town, which Blackstone is buying for $5.3 billion. No REITs were in discussions for Equity Residential's portfolio sale, showing that private equity is more willing to buy at these prices than REITs.

The global M&A cycle has further potential to run, based on historical measures. M&A as a share of global GDP has [BLANK] about 5% over the past 15 years. The most recent annual peaks were about 7% in 2006-07 vs. 10% in 2000, with higher quarterly peaks. In 4Q, global and European metrics exceeded historical averages for the first time since late 2015. Europe may be earlier in its cycle than the U.S., whose measure also exceeded its average in 4Q but was generally above over the past two years.

Housing demand due to population growth may total about 1.5 million units annually during the next five years, based on U.S. Census data. Household projections [BLANK] what underlying housing demand may look like based on population growth and headship rates, which can fluctuate significantly. Demand from population growth is just one component of total housing demand and doesn't account for the effect of excess vacancy levels, which can absorb some of the need for new construction.

The U.S. net rig count rose by five to 1,052 in the week ended July 6, driven by an increase of four horizontal and two directional rigs, while one vertical asset was released. Bottlenecks and price differentials will continue to challenge new additions as companies focus on completing drilled-but-uncompleted wells and optimizing [BLANK] crude prices.

Lung cancer is the leading cause of cancer-related mortality in the Western world. Its incidence rate typically [BLANK] it among the top five cancers, though its severity and poor patient prognosis makes it one of the most lethal of all cancers. Lung cancer is linked to inhaled airborne chemicals such as cigarette smoke or industrial pollution. The declining trend in smoking in the U.S. has been a key contributor to a reduction in lung cancer-related deaths.

December's U.K. capacity auction will allow power interconnector owners across European countries to generate additional profit from capacity payments. De-rating factors will [BLANK] the scope, as the IFA (Interconnexion France-Angleterre) owners will be able to seek capacity payments via the auction for just 52% of their 2 gigawatt capacity compared with 69% for a rival BridNED's power link. By contrast, conventional power plants will be able to seek capacity payments for 82% to 95% of their installed capacity.

Baidu's share of Chinese desktop search queries decreased 90 bps to 75.9% in July, according to IResearch. Closest rival Qihoo's share increased modestly by 30 bps to 15.4%, [BLANK] it faces more competition from Baidu's innovative deep-learning algorithms and brand marketing efforts. Qihoo's market share peaked at 16.4% in January. It gained just 80 bps of share year-to-date vs. a 350-bp gain a year earlier.

Macau's casinos face persistent challenges in 2H. The obstacles include wealthy Chinese [BLANK] conspicuous consumption, a smoking ban at mass-market locations, a lack of hotel space and rising labor costs. On the brighter side, two new resorts, easing growth comparisons and Chinese economic stimulus offer hope for gaming stabilization. Operators in the U.S. await a rebound in gambler visits and spending. More are considering REIT spinoffs to achieve higher valuations, following Penn National's lead.

Vectrus is seeking to retain one of its four largest revenue sources by winning a U.S. Army order for logistics support in Kuwait.
