The Army [BLANK] the request for proposals under the Army EAGLE program in October 2015 and plans to issue an award in September 2016. Vectrus's orders under the current version of the contract have topped $1 billion over five years. Possible challengers include Honeywell, Lockheed Martin, DynCorp and Aecom.

Asia-Pacific mobile telecom operators are in for stiffer competition amid slowing voice revenue and obstacles to monetizing data use. Mobile newcomer TPG Telecom will [BLANK] the fray in Australia and Singapore in 2018. In Malaysia and Thailand, higher spectrum costs loom. Established competitors in China, Japan and South Korea could fare better, as their market structures are relatively stable triumvirates. Capital spending on 4G should ease in most markets, but will remain high enough to support rising data traffic.

Japan had the biggest growth in Chinese visitors among their top-12 destinations in the first nine months of 2015. Japan had 112% more Chinese visitors in 3Q vs. 3Q14, driven by female tourists, COTRI [BLANK]. The rate of Chinese women traveling to Japan grew 151%, twice that of men. This may spur more spending on women's luxury goods, in a market already estimated to be four times that of men's worldwide. About 80% of Chinese women wear well-known brands with heritage vs. 50% men, based on a Euromonitor survey.

China raised its consumption tax on certain refined products for a third time since the start of November after the price of Brent crude was cut in half. The new tax [BLANK] Jan. 13 is 52% higher than before the adjustments. It will be collected via refiners including Sinopec based on sales to their marketing units. While the levy is likely to impact refiners' working capital in the short term, they can pass it on via higher prices for finished products, minimizing any burden on profit margins.

The MBA's mortgage applications index fell 3.2% in the week ended Nov. 20, after rising 6.2% the prior week. Home purchase applications [BLANK] 0.5% after an 11.9% surge the week before, while refinance activity fell 4.8%. The 30-year mortgage effective rate slipped to 4.28% from 4.31%, modestly above year-ago levels. Even with interest rates slightly higher since mid-October, mortgage demand remains strong relative to the prior year, supported by a solid housing market and gains in the economy.

The documentary "Under the Dome" shows a China that needs to reduce coal plant production, steel production and overall metals demand. Homes for 3.4 billion people are planned for a country of 1.3 billion shows the over-spending and inflated metals demand that has plagued the country, and spurred the government to [BLANK] for more centrally planned, slower growth. Over-development of real estate may have caused a massive glut which will take years to fill, causing a long-term decline in metals demand.

Brexit negotiations are set to intensify as EU chief negotiator Michel Barnier hosts a meeting on Sept. 18 with the EU-27 to discuss U.K. withdrawal terms and a new framework for future relations. While Barnier claims agreement is possible by early November, many issues, including the Irish border, remain deadlocked, [BLANK] the 21-month transition period at risk. Meanwhile, on Sept. 19 the EBA's consultation on proposed standards regarding the calculation of capital requirements of securitized exposures (KIRB) closes for comment. Companies Impacted: BNP Paribas, Commerzbank, Amundi, Allianz Global Investors, Adyen and Trustly are among EU-27 companies to use a passport to access the U.K. Goldman Sachs, RBS, BlackRock, Schroders, 3i, Revolut and American Express use a passport to access the EU-27.

Damage to reputation is the main cause of economic loss after cyber incidents, according to Allianz's 2016 Risk Barometer survey. This is [BLANK] out by a survey from public relations firm Edelman, which indicates that 71% of customers would leave an organization following a data breach. Business interruption is also a growing concern. With an increasing number of companies relying heavily on technology, the potential disruption caused by cyber crime, data breaches or IT failure are becoming more significant.

With a purchase of Telecity, Equinix would bolster its presence in Europe. The combination may give Equinix a greater advantage for new European customers that are seeking direct connections to other customers, which may [BLANK] more consolidation by rivals to better compete. Interxion, which had agreed to be purchased by Telecity in February, could seek additional scale elsewhere, while smaller local companies as well as wholesale providers may also pursue M&A.

The award of $9 billion in punitive damages in Takeda and Lilly's product-liability case over risks related to their diabetes drug Actos will stand for now, after the judge in the case refused to overrule the jury's verdict. The judgment will probably be [BLANK] on appeal, as these types of damages are generally in line with awards to plaintiffs, which were $1.48 million in this case. A notice of appeal is due by the end of September.

European banks claims on central and eastern Europe almost tripled to $1.35 trillion in three years to mid-2008. This fell 14% to $1.18 trillion in 2Q as western Europe banks [BLANK] from the region in an effort to improve capital. While claims on Hungary almost halved to $70 billion, EU banks exposure to Poland and Czech Republic increased by an average 20%, reflecting a shift in banks strategy to expand selectively in the region.

Cloud vendors such as Google may be reverting to rational budget-based spending approaches similar to corporate IT departments. With specific amounts of budgets [BLANK] to storage technologies such as hard-disk drives and solid-state drives, buyers may counter SSD price increases with smaller purchases. Amazon Web Services and Microsoft Azure's capacity-building ahead of demand may be plateauing, with future growth more contingent on rational demand. Should pricing weaken, more workloads may move to SSDs.

Prescription volume for Pfizer's Xeljanz arthritis drug rose 46% in May compared with a year earlier. The volume gain and the growth rate since its launch are impressive [BLANK] with other entrants such as UCB's Cimzia and Johnson & Johnson's Simponi, which declined 3.3%. Pfizer is banking on Xeljanz to enable it to maintain sales while Celebrex and Lyrica lose patent protection. The biggest drug in the therapy class by far remains AbbVie's Humira, with volume 13-fold higher.

After the U.S. property and casualty industry's surplus fell by $28 billion in 2001, triggering substantial price gains, insurers earned quarterly operating returns averaging 455 bps above their cost of equity from 2002 through 2007. Price declines, catastrophes and the financial crisis [BLANK] average returns 204 bps below the peer group cost of equity from 2010 to 2012. With 2014 returns meeting equity costs, renewed competition may drive 2015 margins lower.

Treasury Secretary nominee Steven Mnuchin's comments to the Senate Finance Committee could indicate a milder approach toward Beijing's exchange-rate policy than presented by President Donald Trump on the campaign trail. Trump promised to prioritize labeling China a "currency manipulator" and take punitive action, [BLANK] tariffs. In written comments to senators, Mnuchin demurred from promising such a label for China, and said he would stick to the process established by Congress to address currency manipulation.

The thinking behind the recent wave of hepatitis C drugs is to interrupt the virus' replication cycle within the infected liver cell. Specifically, novel drugs [BLANK] to inhibit the protein processing stage (protease inhibitors), or are targeting the RNA replication stage (NS5A, NS5B inhibitors). The combination of these different mechanisms is proving more effective in tackling infection and emergence of resistance as the viral lifecycle is blocked at multiple stages.

Guangzhou Automobile Group Co. makes 5% of China's passenger vehicles and 4% of motorcycles. Expansion plans may [BLANK] more than 70% in capacity and boost market share. Increased capacity could help proprietary brand Trumpchi drive revenue growth and raise earnings from joint ventures with companies including Honda, Toyota and Fiat. It aims to enter the U.S. market in 2017.

All areas of drugmaking had a name on the list of biggest single-position exits among all funds in 3Q, which is in contrast to a more-targeted list in previous quarters. The biggest new positions were convoluted by Capital Group's buying spree, yet mature U.S. biotechs Amgen, Regneron and Vertex [BLANK] the list.

Credit Suisse and four bank peers named in a proposed antitrust class-action lawsuit alleging collusion in the supranational, sub-sovereign and agency bond market are unlikely to seek a settlement this year. The allegations are new and only one suit has been [BLANK]. If copy-cat complaints are filed as in similar bank rate-rigging cases, a consolidation process will follow. The banks will likely wait for this to play out and then seek dismissal of the suits before thinking about settling.

Big banks would see sharply different regulatory approaches under the two Democratic presidential candidates. In their April 14 debate, both contenders said financial companies that are too big and too risky should be [BLANK] up. Senator Bernie Sanders promised to act promptly to split up big banks, passing new laws if necessary. But Hillary Clinton offered more of a hands-off approach, deferring to regulators to exercise their judgment and authority under Dodd-Frank.

Ahold Delhaize could be an outside contender in any pursuit of Whole Foods. The company operates traditional supermarkets and is [BLANK] a small-box natural and organic concept, Bfresh, which could benefit from Whole Foods' knowledge. Ahold has the capacity for an acquisition, though tends to be quite conservative when pursuing additions to its portfolio. Whole Foods could gain online grocery expertise vis a vis Peapod, as well as insight to expand its European stores.

European Parliament revisions to Commission proposals for the Electronic Communications Code appears to undermine the investment fostering spirit of the original draft. This will [BLANK] the attainability of ambitious EU connectivity targets for 2025, including nationwide 5G coverage and fixed-broadband download speeds of at least 100 Mbps. Lacking a supportive regulatory regime, coupled with a hardened stance on consolidation driven deals, European telecoms will likely refrain from warming up to cross-border deals.

Allianz was the top seller of fixed annuities in 3Q, according to data from Limra SRI, capturing 13.6% market share. While low interest rates helped [BLANK] Allianz's $3.1 billion of sales 19% below 2Q, it was still 74% above second-ranked New York Life and 136% ahead of 3Q13. Of the top five providers, three reported sequential sales declines, including AIG (down 17%) and Security Benefit Life (28% lower), while modest growth was reported by New York Life (2%) and American Equity (3%).

A depressed period of well completions lasting three or four quarters would help larger U.S.-levered pressure pumpers in the long run by pushing smaller rivals out of the market and reducing capacity. The North American market is fragmented, with almost 50 companies [BLANK]. That number is set to shrink as better-capitalized companies gain market share, which may be favorable for pricing when completions ramp up.

Novo Nordisk's daily Victoza share of the crowded GLP-1 diabetes market has fallen to 59.2% from 67% in July, when GlaxoSmithKline launched weekly-dosed Tanzeum. Yet Victoza and AstraZeneca's weekly Bydureon volumes continued to [BLANK]. Eli Lilly's weekly Trulicity, launched in November, and Tanzeum have taken market share from Bydureon and Victoza. Bydureon's share fell to 21% from a peak of 22.4% in November 2014. Tanzeum's performance, which has a cumbersome injection process, has been driven by deep discounting.

Oil prices would probably need to rally at least 75% to more than $50 a barrel for oil-services earnings to hit the 2Q inflection point projected by consensus. Expectations across almost every industry subsector, [BLANK] the four biggest providers, U.S. onshore, proppant suppliers and land drillers, point to sales and Ebitda bottoming in the quarter and embarking on a multi-year recovery thereafter. This premise is a key reason why the underlying equities have risen 15-20% on average since late January.

Lexus has narrowed the new-car sales gap separating it from leading luxury brands BMW and Mercedes. In the nine months through September, it sold 2,000 to 3,000 fewer than its rivals, [BLANK] with 12,000 to 16,000 a year earlier. New models such as RC and NX have bolstered gains, as well as continued sales of the popular RX SUV. Consumers' ability to afford higher monthly payments on cheaper gas, as well as the desire to move upmarket to crossovers for added utility have helped luxury-automaker volume.

Technology and utilities offer the strongest combination of relative price trend and momentum among sectors in the S&P 500. Health care is recovering some momentum off an oversold extreme after 17 months of [BLANK] the benchmark. Industrials and financials continue to correct their post-election overbought condition. Energy and materials have recently struggled with breakdowns in the commodity complex, and have the weakest technical position in the index.

Automotive rail carload strength is fading in 2H as its four-week average rate of growth slowed to 1.2%, and originated volumes are 2.8% lower in 3Q. Sluggish North American vehicle sales are a main culprit, [BLANK] 2.4% in August, according to WardsAuto. U.S. sales, which comprise 83% of North American sales, slipped 4%. Carloads for the rest of 2016 may be hurt by manageable vehicle inventories and consumers that may not be motivated to shop until manufacturers boost buying incentives during the 4Q holidays.

Relative North American spot-trucking demand rose 4.4% sequentially to 53.3 in the week ended March 16, based on Truckstop.com's Market Demand Index. Capacity [BLANK] for a fifth straight week as available loads rose 3.3% while available trucks fell 1%. Average spot rates, excluding fuel surcharges, rose for the sixth consecutive week (2.4%) and are approaching peak levels from the start of the year, fueled by capacity constraints and a string of winter storms in the Northeast. Spot rates are up 28% this year.

Sales and trading revenue in 2Q for the fixed income, commodity and currency business at the five largest U.S. investment banks topped $12 billion. Disclosure is [BLANK] and accounting scope different making comparison of banks' currency business difficult. Disclosures make clear that currency is a meaningful component of the revenue pool. Citigroup posted 32% of ``principal'' transactions derived from currency. HSBC disclosed that 46% of ``markets'' revenue was currency-derived.

BT-owned EE appears in little danger of losing its 4G network performance crown any time soon, in our view, based on OpenSignal's 3Q report on the U.K. The drop in Three's average download speeds shows the pitfalls of [BLANK] a data-happy strategy with limited spectrum and Telefonica's O2 is yet to deliver any tangible improvements following its purchase of 2.3 GHz 4G airwaves in April.

The influx of new apartment supply forced landlords to increase rental concessions in 2016, but this trend may be easing slightly in the peak summer leasing season. Douglas Elliman data indicate that the share of Manhattan apartments offering concessions [BLANK] to 25% in May from 29% in April, while the median rent net of concessions increased 2.1%. Rental concessions are an effective method of maintaining occupancy levels, as apartment owners sacrifice near-term cash flow to keep their units full.

SAP's gross margin should start to improve in 1H18, show gradual progress in 2H and then accelerate in 2019. Margin expansion will come from a number of factors, with [BLANK] cloud investments the main contributor. Profit improvement has been the primary issue facing SAP for the past year.

The Interior Department on March 15 announced a plan that blocks oil and gas drilling off the Atlantic Coast, though the next president could reverse that decision. U.S. offshore oil and gas production, which primarily takes place in the Gulf of Mexico, is [BLANK] by large E&Ps including Shell, Chevron and BP. Under President Barack Obama, the agency had been mulling a plan that would have allowed leases off the coast of Virginia, North Carolina, South Carolina and Georgia.

Reinsurer views of expected returns suggest an eroding profit outlook for the industry. Expected returns inform pricing decisions and are [BLANK] from models, experience and industry acumen. Unlike primary insurers, where very large storm losses are often excluded from underlying margins, managing catastrophic loss is a required core competency for reinsurers. While 2014-15 profit was boosted by the lack of very large losses, a 2Q decline in actual returns followed lower 2016 expected returns.

Declines in both Chinese vehicle sales and manufacturing of battery-powered bicycles have curbed lead consumption in China, the metal's largest user. China's lead demand [BLANK] 12.4% through August from a year earlier to 2.55 million metric tons, or 39% of the world's total. The drop was a significant factor in the global 7.5% decline. A greater emphasis on environmental awareness, leading to stricter regulations, may be discouraging lead use in China, which could hurt the metal's price.

Slowing year-over-year declines in sugar and other commodities, such as dairy, could start affecting margins of confectioners and ice-cream makers from 1H due to the time lag from contracts. Sugar was down only 4% in December vs. a 24% average drop in 1Q-3Q15, FAO food price index [BLANK] show. In Germany, beverages top the list of major sugar-user packaged-food and drinks categories with 18%, according to WV Zucker. Candies (17%), baked goods (14%), toppings, fruit preserves, dairy and ice cream (9% total) follow.

The U.S. elections and sequester have the largest effect on defense company results. A divided government is likely and agreement will be needed to even maintain defense funding as a continuing resolution [BLANK] the Pentagon to December. Few new programs are coming, given the recent spate of mostly Navy and Air Force modernization programs and the return of sequester cuts in October 2017. Primary defense contractors use cash flow to buy shares and pay dividends as they pursue sales growth overseas.

A September 2015 IRS notice fueled uncertainty surrounding REIT spinoffs. The agency said it would [BLANK] issuing private-letter rulings to preclude the spinoff into REITs of financial asset-dominated entities without active business. A December 2015 law limited tax-free REIT spinoffs to instances where both succeeding entities qualify for REIT election. Hilton Worldwide's request for a private-letter ruling on the tax-free spinoff of its timeshare and real-estate businesses occurred before the law's effective date.

Dollar Tree's ability to buy in bulk and sell products at less than $1 across namesake stores and in bulk online sets it apart from rivals. The addition of Family Dollar further [BLANK] this with more buying power and sourcing opportunities that can lead to better gross margin.

Corporate profit and CEO confidence continues to rise, setting a multiyear record. This boosts advanced hotel group bookings, which may support [BLANK] occupancy and room rate growth in 2016. Corporate clients drive higher revenue per available room and ancillary revenue because they tend to spend more on rooms, food and beverage and other services. Business-driven guests typically fill weekday occupancy, mitigating weekday/weekend seasonality.

China's diesel demand appears to be avoiding an expected slowdown, possibly because cheaper crude is cooling a shift toward natural gas. Diesel use was expected to [BLANK] because of this fuel change, an industrial slowdown and railway expansion paring long-haul trucking. Still, commercial diesel stores fell year-on-year for a 17th month in February, dropping 7%, based on China OGP data. Apparent demand, or production plus net imports, also rose 1.5% last year and a further 3.9% in first two months in 2015.

Resorts 4Q revenue missed consensus by 0.3% and adjusted Ebitda fell short by 10%. MGM China net revenue [BLANK] 22% vs. a market decline of 25% due to mass market segment revenue growth of 19%, which cushioned a 39% VIP decline. Growth in Macau's casino industry stalled following 1Q. Las Vegas revenue grew 5.5% as non-gaming business growth offset revenue declines at some of MGM's luxury casinos. MGM's hotel revenue per available room grew 7% and the convention business mix was a record.

While Halliburton delivered on its 2010 promise to increase its deepwater business faster than the market expanded, tougher times lie ahead. Oil prices are [BLANK] offshore spending, and something may need to give in the high-margin business as capital migrates away from projects with long lead times and low operating visibility. Even though deepwater market share is relatively concentrated, Halliburton and its rivals may need to make price concessions to attract more activity amid low oil and gas prices.

Novo Nordisk's success in its LEADER cardiovascular (CV) outcomes trial of GLP-1 Victoza, with a positive impact on CV risks, boosts the likelihood of Type 2 diabetics being started on Victoza vs. a basal insulin. This [BLANK] Sanofi's Lantus and Toujeo insulins are at risk the most. About 60% of patients in the U.S. receive basal insulin as their first injectable. Lantus and GLP-1 drug Lyxumia have not shown any impact on heart disease. The positive Victoza trial will also favor Novo's Xultophy vs. Sanofi's LixiLan.

China has turned to the Philippines to fill the gap left by Indonesia's 2014 ban on nickel ore exports. China's imports of nickel ore [BLANK] 3.2 million metric tons in May, the highest in seven months, with 99% coming from the Philippines. Indonesia supplied 58% of China's imports in 2013, the year before the ban. Chinese imports from Indonesia slumped 74% last year, while supplies from the Philippines surged 76%.

The aircraft manufacturer's Bear Case includes cash and margin risks on new program cost volatility as Boeing's 787, Airbus's A350 and Bombardier's CSeries mature. Demand side risks include excess capacity, especially in Asia, as expansion by long- and short-haul airlines have led to [BLANK] yields and could lead to more deferrals or cancellations. Further risk to demand includes fracking and falling fuel prices, which may reduce sales of new aircraft.

North America-originated commodity carloads inched 1.4% lower in the week ended Oct. 1 (week 39) vs. a year ago, based on AAR data. Comparisons have eased as the drop in commodity carloads [BLANK] to 6.2% in 3Q. After coal carloads plummeted 27% in 2Q, volume declines slowed to 15% in 3Q. The overall commodity rout continues amid broad-based weakness, though agriculture was the lone bright spot in 3Q. Ag volumes rose 6.4% as farmers finally moved some stored crops to make room for the fall harvest.

Pure-play human capital management vendors such as Cornerstone and Callidus have high saturation risk, given their niche focus and small addressable markets. While Cornerstone recently [BLANK] beyond talent management to core HR, increased competition from Workday and legacy vendors such as SAP and Oracle is likely to be a headwind. Other vendors, such as Paycom and Paylocity, are also likely to face increased competition from larger rivals, such as Ultimate Software and ADP.

Oaktree will likely confront an uphill battle when it faces Claire's, its private equity sponsor Apollo and senior lenders such as Elliott Management in a plan confirmation dispute centering on Claire's $1.4 billion valuation. Lack of qualified bids and Oaktree's fully [BLANK] capital for its own bid standing at only $1.1 billion as of Sept. 12 may influence the court.

Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump wants to roll back many of the Obama administration's coal-focused regulations, but the Environmental Protection Agency's Mercury and Air Toxics Standards probably will be safe even if he wins. The EPA estimates the standards will [BLANK] $9.6 billion a year, representing 4.3-6.4% of total capital spending by U.S. electric utilities. Because of the added cost burden, the rule has been widely cited as one reason for closing coal power plants.

It was a rough 2Q for RPC with operating margins contracting to minus 17% and sales falling 26% sequentially on pricing pressures and lower utilization. The board suspended the dividend after [BLANK] it 50% in 1Q. These moves will save the company $22 million through the rest of the year. While revenue and margins are expected to be slightly higher in 3Q, pricing may continue to decline and market-share losses may start to accrue as larger service companies compete for new frac jobs.

Energy use, carbon emissions, worker safety and water management are among key environmental, social and governance (ESG) issues for the iron and steel industry, according to analysis by the Sustainability Accounting Standards Board. Steel is one of the most energy-intensive industries, [BLANK] the importance of energy efficiency to costs. It's the largest industrial emitter of carbon. Better safety performance may improve productivity and reduce fines and lawsuits.

A January ruling by a New York federal court allowing BlackRock and other RMBS investors to proceed with claims against Deutsche Bank as RMBS trustee hurts Wells Fargo's dismissal bid of a related suit by the same plaintiffs. Though the ruling against Deutsche isn't binding on the Wells Fargo judge, it's likely persuasive for [BLANK] a 2016 state court ruling the banks cite for dismissal. Several other judges in the same federal court have also allowed similar suits to proceed.

Sharp's shares are trading at 184% above their consensus target price, the biggest gap among branded-television makers. Investors are taking a far more optimistic view than analysts [BLANK] the company's strategy to revive its television business. They may also be upbeat about about the plan of the company's LCD joint venture, Sakai Display Products' to build a new factory in China.

Bank of America, Citigroup, Wells Fargo and JPMorgan are the largest U.S. energy lenders. This isn't surprising, given they also [BLANK] commercial loans, along with PNC and U.S. Bancorp. Morgan Stanley and Goldman Sachs' energy loans are 4% of their total, a higher share than these peers, but more importantly only 3-7% of tangible common equity. Along with Huntington, JPMorgan and PNC, the ratios are lowest across 27 banks tracked by BI. Citi, Wells and BofA are 12-13% vs. about 70-100% at Texas-focused banks.

Alcon, Johnson & Johnson and other contact lens makers are now battling efforts to certify consumer antitrust lawsuits as class actions after motions to dismiss the suits failed. Contact lens buyers sued the companies in 2015, alleging that their agreements with eye-care professionals to set resale price floors [BLANK] antitrust laws. Discovery has been ongoing since bids to dismiss were denied in 2Q16. Briefing on class issues will likely close in 3Q. Damages sought could be in the billions of dollars.

This week we reflected on the ongoing auction for 5G airwaves in Italy which has stirred to life, pushing the cost of 3.6-3.8 GHz spectrum beyond the previous high benchmark. We also covered BT's teach-in for analysts about the future of its Global Services unit, concluding that while the revamp is [BLANK] for near-term Ebitda progression, the mid-term outlook is still opaque. Vodafone's apparent shift toward deleveraging should boost dividend sustainability, but comes with execution risks, while Inmarsat's tie-up with Panasonic on in-flight broadband connectivity looks to us like a good move. As we head into the weekend, attention turns to Sky with an auction between Fox and Comcast scheduled for Saturday. If both sides genuinely covet the asset, we still think bidding could head toward 1,800 pence a share.

While the FCC remains more vulnerable than usual in a case over about $3.3 billion in discounts it denied Dish allies SNR Wireless and Northstar Wireless, the FCC's chances have slightly ticked up during the wait for the decision, given FCC critic Judge Stephen F. Williams likely isn't writing it. Williams [BLANK] another decision from the same sitting, reducing odds he will write in this case. That means FCC-leaning Judge Nina Pillard or tough-to-read Judge Janice Rogers Brown is likely writing the decision.

Oracle is more focused on cloud Software-as-a-Service (SaaS) and Platform-as-a-Service (PaaS) services as the Infrastructure-as-a-Service (IaaS) space becomes increasingly competitive. Amazon, Microsoft and Google are driving down IaaS pricing, [BLANK] other technology vendors to focus on higher-margin products. Oracle's cloud sales have risen during the past few quarters and management forecasts an acceleration in fiscal 2H16. Migration to the cloud has led to a drop in new license sales and margins.

Caterpillar's global dealer sales, a bellwether for construction and mining equipment, jumped 26% in November. Sales are gathering steam, with all units [BLANK] gains. Construction equipment sales rose 25%, while mining jumped 35% as all regions including North America grew.

Supermarket and convenience stores expect new rules requiring them to post calorie content on their menus will mean extra costs for nutritional analysis, new menus and employee training. The industry [BLANK] the FDA rule, part of the Affordable Care Act. It requires businesses with at least 20 locations that sell prepared foods, such as restaurants, grocery and convenience stores, to list calories on menus of in-store restaurants, cafes, salad bars and sandwich or pizza counters starting Dec. 1, 2015.

Investors appear to be rotating out of shares of orthopedic implant makers ahead of 1Q earnings results and into shares of Swiss dental maker Straumann. Shares of large-cap orthopedic makers have underperformed the S&P 500 this year, possibly on lower optimism [BLANK] further sector consolidation and the potential for sales disruptions at Zimmer and NuVasive. Straumann shares have mostly recovered from the decoupling of the Swiss franc and euro as it cut compensation and lowered exposure to the franc.

Banks may get an influx of short-term institutional deposits under EU plans that seek to force competing money-market funds away from the fixed $1 net-asset-value model, making them riskier investments. Managers already [BLANK] money-market funds with a floating share price which use investor-friendly terms (same-day redemptions) and capital-preservation strategies may have a competitive advantage. These managers are typically concentrated in France, where constant-NAV funds are banned.

Using data previously presented for Incyte's ECHO202 study to set expectations at ASCO has its challenges, given that this data, last presented at ESMO, was small in sample size and had a peculiar patient mix. Furthermore, PD-L1 testing wasn't consistently [BLANK] out. Most notably in lung- and kidney-cancer cohorts, the proportion of patients deemed PD-L1 positive, as well as those who hadn't previously had any treatment, made it difficult to align with any other PD-1 combination study data.

The Environmental Protection Agency appears on track for meeting legal deadlines related to the Renewable Fuel Standard, based on the agency's May 29 proposal. Under the terms of a legal settlement, final renewable targets for 2014 and 2015 are [BLANK] by Nov. 30. A public hearing is scheduled to take place on June 25 and an open comment period will run through July 27. After a two-year delay, the EPA's proposal could mark a return to the statutory timeline for determining the Renewable Fuel Standard's targets.

Short interest as a percentage of free float at SolarCity reached 41% as of May, which now contends with an Elon Musk-backed Tesla offer that values SolarCity at up to 30% above a prior closing price. Investor concerns may have focused on high capital use, persistent costs and a demand shift from solar [BLANK] to system ownership. SolarCity has sought to tackle these issues, such as by relaunching its solar loan product, yet business model questions may persist even under Tesla ownership.

Commercial medical costs for managed-care companies may be on the rise, given that Aetna now expects growth to be at the upper end of its 2014 forecast range, primarily from higher costs for small group members. Commercial usage may [BLANK] by an additional 50 bps to 100 bps in 2015 from 2014. Payers must increase premiums in order to offset the rising costs. Medical cost growth of government-sponsored membership has been lower than expected.

The FDA is reviewing more biosimilar applications in the U.S., possibly ushering in biosimilars of Roche's Herceptin and Avastin next, though payer adoption remains a hurdle to market penetration. The FDA has [BLANK] just six biosimilars since 2015, with Sandoz's Zarxio the first. Ongoing litigation has held up the launch of several other biosimilars that have gotten an FDA green light. Copies of Johnson & Johnson's Remicade are the only other biosimilars to reach the U.S. market.

Outages at the Syncrude oil sands project in Fort McMurray, Alberta led to missed production targets again in 2015, resulting in a fifth straight annual decline after initiatives were taken to improve reliability. Suncor's larger stake may help [BLANK] its efficiency, given proximity and possible synergy with its other facilities. Syncrude produced 91 million barrels in 2015, down from 94 million in 2014. Forest fires and planned 2Q maintenance at Syncrude led to about 250,000 barrels a day being offline.

In the big picture, excess zinc demand vs. supply is much more favorable than when prices peaked in 2010. The potential for a peak demand-to-supply ratio from a lower level than 2014's top indicates that the [BLANK] in prices from 2015's low is at elevated correction risk, though not as extreme as 40% in 2010, when consumption remained below production. Sustaining the current demand vs. supply disparity is price-supportive, potentially similar to the 380% surge from the 2004 low to 2008 peak.

Hospital admissions may grow at a slower pace in 2015 given enrollment on the public health-insurance exchanges may be lower than expected. Exchange admissions have [BLANK] up throughout 2014, though may slow if membership growth wanes. Hospitals reducing uncompensated care may be lower than expected given 30% of exchanges patients, on average, have been previously uninsured. The benefit of Medicaid expansion to hospital earnings may also be less in 2015.

Contract assemblers' 2Q industrial sales climbed 12.2%, the fastest growth among emerging products, according to IDC. The medical-devices segment followed with a 6.8% increase, while automotive sales [BLANK] 4.7%. Electronics makers, such as Flextronics, Jabil and Sanmina, are increasingly focusing on emerging products because of higher margins and longer product cycles. The industrial products they assemble include semiconductor capital equipment and smart power meters.

The Italy-inspired Treasury rally has increased conviction of our yield forecasts, which remain for the 10-year to end 2018 and 2019 at about 3%. Front-end yields continue to [BLANK] higher, further flattening the curve. This month, we also introduce our new Treasury yield scorecard.

Moderating growth in high-value end-markets is adding uncertainty as chemical companies plan for 2017. Growth in autos, a bright spot for 2016, [BLANK] to be slowing, as tax and stimulus policies make demand difficult to gauge in Asia. Consumer confidence indicators are wavering, adding to concerns, particularly in the U.S. and China. Even U.S. homebuilding faces concern over rising mortgage rates, and remains well below prior highs despite its fourth year of steady growth.

Chinese demand for liquefied natural gas is seasonal, yet as base demand gains speed, the shoulder season lows remain elevated. Residential and commercial adoption of LNG in China will [BLANK] accelerated peak seasonal demand. With LNG/LPG demand rising rapidly, Chinese investment is taking aim at Asian, African and European infrastructure to command full-cycle economics and control the fledgling LNG pricing market.

Wockhardt's inter partes review petition challenging AstraZeneca's patent to diabetes drugs Onglyza and Kombiglyze was instituted and joined with Mylan's granted IPR on the same patent. These may soon be combined with three other [BLANK] petitions by Teva, Amneal and Aurobindo. The U.S. patent office is set to decide whether to grant and join the petitions by year-end. The scheduling order issued in Mylan's challenge now applies to Wockhardt's with a May 2017 one-year deadline for a final decision.

The court date for oral arguments on a motion by Vereit, formerly American Realty Capital Properties, to dismiss shareholder class-action fraud lawsuits related to the company's accounting errors was moved to Oct. 27 from Oct. 13. The company filed its bid to [BLANK] the amended suits on May 29 and briefing ended Aug. 12. A ruling is expected within a few weeks of oral arguments, likely by year-end. Related Justice Department and SEC probes of Vereit are also ongoing.

A ruling on Bank of New York Mellon's motion to dismiss a $17.8 billion residential mortgage-backed securities lawsuit by BlackRock, Pimco, Prudential Financial and others is expected in 1Q. Briefing on BNY's dismissal bid ended in May and oral arguments were [BLANK] in July, making the motion ripe for a decision. If the suit survives the dismissal request, as similar cases have, the parties will then likely engage in document exchanges and start taking sworn testimony.

Any easing of U.S. sanctions on Russia, aimed mainly at energy companies and banks, probably won't happen before 2018. Congress is poised to [BLANK] legislation that would remove the president's ability to unilaterally revoke sanctions. Even so, President Donald Trump would likely be reluctant to ease them while the FBI and Congress scrutinize potential ties between Russia, his campaign and administration. Trump is unlikely to exercise sanctions against the Russian mining sector that Congress will likely authorize.

China is the world's largest construction machinery market, accounting for more than 26% of global units and 20% of sales (in U.S. dollars) in 2014, according to Off-Highway Research. After surging 72% from 2009 to 2011, sales collapsed 52% over the next three years as lower government investment [BLANK] demand, creating a severe inventory buildup. Sales may fall another 37% in 2015. China is the world's biggest consumer of metals and a critical long-term driver of demand for construction equipment.

Greek 10-year yields have more than doubled to 10% since September amid mounting concern the anti-austerity Syriza party may derail Greece's recovery, stymying further international support. The yield remains well below its peak in early-2012 of more than 35%, [BLANK] the fact that concerns about the knock-on effect to the euro zone are significantly lower. If Greece were to exit the euro it would likely re-ignite debate on the size of outstanding debt and deficits elsewhere in the euro region, such as Italy and France.

Mobile carriers' management-team comments during 4Q calls suggests growing confidence in the ability to mitigate the adverse effect of the elimination of roaming tariffs on Ebitda. This is a shift vs. 2015, when it was expected to [BLANK] a greater drag on revenue and Ebitda in 2017. The ability to negotiate low wholesale-data prices, as reflected in the latest EU agreement, underpins the change. Elisa said there was no major, or minor, negative effect. Telia projects only a slight negative impact to Ebitda.

The recent settlement of the Australian quarterly seaborne coking coal contract between Australian miners and Japanese steel producers at $93 a metric ton will make life even harder for already struggling U.S. metallurgical coal producers. This is likely to [BLANK] to more shuttered mines and supply cutbacks. U.S. coking coal miners are at a disadvantage to their Australian peers due to a higher cost of production, poorer proximity to demand centers in Asia and a stronger domestic currency.

Novo Nordisk's semaglutide, which may file in 2H, showed heart benefits in the SUSTAIN-6 trial. Novo Nordisk's Victoza is the only other GLP-1 to [BLANK] similar benefits. The positive data for both drugs will strengthen Novo Nordisk's lead in the class, helping to mitigate the threat of Eli Lilly's Trulicity. AstraZeneca's Bydureon could report data in 2018. Unlike Novo's and Lilly's drugs, Bydureon is based on a non-human GLP-1-like molecule, similar to Sanofi's Lyxumia, for which outcome data were neutral in 1Q15.

December U.S. retail sales through Dec. 30 indicate 4.3% growth, which suggests strong holiday selling overall, though 4Q results may be mixed. The data may [BLANK] sales results for department stores such as J.C. Penney, Macy's and Sears, and discounters Wal-Mart, Costco, Dollar General and Dollar Tree.

Affiliate revenue has been viewed as the key cable network growth engine, but gains may be slowing. Subscriber losses from skinny bundles as well as a lowering of rates [BLANK] by pay-TV M&A have been responsible. Average affiliate fee growth slowed to 4.8% in 2Q vs. 1Q's 8.7% and 8.4% in 2Q15. Viacom had the worst drop, at 10%, although the company projects mid-single-digit gains in fiscal 2017. Scripps' declines may persist through early 2017 before rebounding to mid- to high-single-digit gains.

The U.S. rig count rose by eight to 1,930 in the week ended Oct. 10, according to Baker Hughes. Oil-targeted rigs [BLANK] by 18, the largest gain since April. Rigs targeting gas decreased by 10, after dropping eight in the prior week and are down 14.4% in 2014. Drilling may slow if oil prices continue to decline and E&P companies are forced to cut capital spending in an effort to boost free cash flow.

Gasoline prices have almost fallen below $2 a gallon, the lowest since April 2009, which may boost spending in discretionary categories in 2015. While retail spending is more immediately [BLANK] in a time of rising gasoline prices, fuel prices may have to either hold steady or continue to fall before consumers materially boost purchases. Gasoline prices are down almost 40% from last year and may help offset pressure on consumers from higher health-care costs and cuts in food stamps.

Total marketed gas production is projected to rise 4.8% to more than 75 billion cubic feet a day this winter, based on EIA data. Combined with injections into storage above the five-year average to start the withdrawal season in November, gas supply is likely adequate to [BLANK] heating demand and the price spikes seen last year would be less likely. A reduction in liquids drilling due to sustained lower crude oil prices would hurt associated gas production and tighten balances.

The owners of coal-fired power plants in the U.S. face numerous environmental requirements in addition to competition from cheap natural gas. Notably, the Environmental Protection Agency's Clean Power Plan may [BLANK] power plants to steeply cut carbon emissions. The Supreme Court stayed the regulation's implementation in February, and the U.S. Court of Appeals for the D.C. Circuit heard arguments challenging the regulation on Sept. 27. The fate of the rule may not be decided until 2017 or beyond.

The key determinants of short-term gold demand are likely to be the impact of a potential U.S. interest-rate rise and the dollar's performance. Gold-jewelry consumption is likely to [BLANK], particularly from India, while investment demand for the metal could increase amid lower-for-longer interest rates globally.

Declining demand for platinum, amid a market surplus and rising above-ground stocks of the metal, could stem a metal-price recovery, in our view. The market surplus will [BLANK] 505,000 ounces in 2018 and 455,000 in 2019, based on World Platinum Investment Council (WPIC) and SFA (Oxford) data. Supply will rise to 8.1 million ounces in 2019, on greater mining supply (2%) and recycling (1%) vs. 2018. Demand may fall 4% to 7.5 million ounces on weaker autocatalyst, investment and jewelry buying in 2018, but will recover 2% in 2019. WPIC sees investment demand plunging 53% in 2018, before a 100% recovery in 2019. Above-ground metal stocks may jump 23% to 2.7 million ounces in 2018, and 17% to 3.1 million in 2019, data show. Major platinum miners include Amplats, Lonmin, Impala, Nornickel and Sibanye.

The FCC will likely adopt set-top-box rules at its Sept. 29 meeting, with Chairman Tom Wheeler and fellow Democrats voting for the rules. The cable industry will lobby to [BLANK] the rules, focusing on Commissioner Jessica Rosenworcel. A Democrat who often supports the Chairman, Rosenworcel said at a Sept. 15 Senate hearing that the FCC plan still gets it too involved with licensing. Wheeler will likely focus on her concerns. Since Rosenworcel thinks rules are needed, they'll likely find common ground.

Ethylene spot spreads have faltered, adding risk to olefins margins, despite a lagging boost to 1Q. Spreads are 40% below their January level, as plant restarts [BLANK] supply and ethane costs rise. Early 2017 outages at Dow, Chevron Phillips and Formosa worked to tighten ethylene supply, boosting ethylene margins at the start of 1Q. Integrated producers should benefit from polyethylene margins rising 7% in 2017 through March, yet the medium-term outlook remains clouded by new supply in 2H.

Chairman and CEO Joe Tucci said the $850 million restructuring that was under way before the company agreed to be bought by Dell will continue, suggesting the structural challenges facing EMC are likely to continue. The cost restructuring may [BLANK], given EMC management's comments on some cost synergies. Management reiterated that the deal remains focused on a long-term revenue enhancement potential of $1 billion, particularly for VMware, rather than cost reductions.

Banks may see a reprieve in the cross-border application of Dodd-Frank swap rules under H.R. 2289. The bill would overrule CFTC cross-border guidance, which some banks [BLANK] crimps market liquidity, and require a formal rulemaking to allow both U.S. and non-U.S. banks the ability to trade under a foreign regulator's oversight, if that country has similar rules. A formal rulemaking would require the agency conduct additional analysis and could make their guidance more susceptible to litigation.

Hillary Clinton's aim of cutting methane pollution from the oil and gas sector is similar to President Barack Obama's, yet rules in the works won't be enough to achieve the goal. If elected president, she'd likely set air pollution standards for [BLANK] wells and infrastructure, which would expand regulatory scope to far more production and equipment. Yet gas is playing a major role in reducing carbon emissions from electricity, and Clinton likely won't push for rules that would significantly impact production.

JPMorgan litigation includes a mortgage-repurchase lawsuit in which a 2015 ruling now on appeal may have shifted billions in liability to the FDIC. The bank is [BLANK] court approval of a $4.5 billion pact with bond investors and faces antitrust civil suits related to interest-rate swaps, Libor and U.S. Treasuries. JPMorgan has settled suits related to credit-default swaps, foreign exchange and ISDAfix and may be close to settling U.S. probes of its Asia hiring practices.

Aetna's acquisition of Humana and the Cigna-Anthem deal reported by the Wall Street Journal and CNBC, if both completed, may lead to some of the biggest private payers yet seen in the U.S. health-care system. This may result in these larger entities carrying more buying power in [BLANK] discounts and rebates with drugmakers. That would put pressure on margins when drugs lack sufficient differentiation from rivals because it gives the payers ammunition to pit one against the other.

Global titanium dioxide operating rates should remain elevated in 2018, helping support higher sales and earnings for key industry players vs. a year ago, though price increases may run out of steam in 2H. The potential for further consolidation with the Tronox-Cristal deal could [BLANK] incremental capacity, with improved operating rates at Cristal plants.

About 5,500 U.K.-based financial-services firms will probably lose unfettered access to the EU single market once the U.K. leaves the bloc as Britain's government is pursuing a so-called hard Brexit. In turn, over 8,000 EU-based companies [BLANK] losing easy access to the U.K. market. These companies can currently provide services across the 28-nation bloc via the passport regime, a key benefit of single-market membership. Passports are only available under nine EU regulations and about 360,00 are held.

Chinese consumer confidence fell to the lowest since 2011 in October, based on a Westpac MNI index, which dropped to 110.9 from 113.2 in September. In a Bear Case, consumer confidence will fall further as [BLANK] house prices make shoppers feel less well off. That could dent purchases of discretionary items, such as apparel, electronics and home furnishings, and prolong a four-month slowdown in retail-sales growth.

Pension buyouts can be costly because any underfunding of programs requires financing by the sponsor to make them fully-funded before the plan is sold to insurers. Low interest rates may also increase the amount of underfunding, [BLANK] sponsors reluctant to transfer pension liabilities to insurers. Valuations used by sponsors for pension fund liabilities in the U.K. and the Netherlands, are similar to those used for insurers liabilities, making them more appealing.

Seasonality at coating producers, the main buyers of titanium dioxide, may slow the pace of TiO2 price increases until 2Q. Coatings producers begin [BLANK] inventory and increasing purchases of TiO2 toward the end of 1Q, ahead of the busy spring and summer paint seasons. Consumption of coatings typically slows during the winter months in the Northern Hemisphere, which leads to lower volume across the supply chain. Sequential gains in TiO2 prices may decelerate during 4Q and 1Q17 as demand ebbs.

Box office sales are 28% higher year-over-year for the first two weeks of the summer season, thanks to Disney's "Avengers: Age of Ultron" which opened to $191 million and has brought in $372 million domestically. Universal's "Pitch Perfect 2" which [BLANK] May 15, took in $70 million, 25% ahead of estimates, while Warner's "Mad Max" [BLANK] to $44 million, in-line with estimates. The summer, which runs from the first weekend of May through the first weekend in September, makes up 40% to 45% of total box office.

China remains a key growth driver for large pharma companies, with Novo Nordisk posting a 10% sales increase in the country in 2Q, having previously warned of slowing growth. This was driven by modern insulin- and diabetes-market expansion, yet [BLANK] to the provincial bidding process suggest pricing risks still abound. Continued investment into respiratory boosted AstraZeneca's China revenue. Sanofi's drug sales rose, but disruptions related to illegal sales activity hurt vaccines. The drag could last 4-6 months.

Elevator makers may register a decline in orders this year, based on a broad 12-month lag between construction starts in China and orders. China's floor space [BLANK] fell 14% last year after an 11% drop in 2014. The latter led to the lowest organic order growth in five years in 2015 at peers Kone and Schindler. Elevator unit orders from China are already down 8% in 1Q. China's floor starts have recovered this year, mainly because of government measures.

Among U.S. large-pharma companies, Bristol-Myers Squibb and Merck continue to dominate newsflow in 2H, with big lung-cancer readouts for Bristol and Merck's second shot at the adjuvant therapy market after its melanoma win, this time in tough-to-treat breast cancer. Lastly, Lilly [BLANK] the risk of Trulicity's heart-trial setback.

Iberdrola-owned Scottish Power and Renewable Energy Generation secured financial support for a total of 892 megawatts of wind and solar power plants in the first U.K. renewables power auction. Statkraft, Vattenfall and Dong Energy are looking into getting government [BLANK] in Norway for new wind capacity. Norway may expand its wind portfolio by 3,000 megawatts through 2020. Low European interest rates may attract the listing of high-yielding renewable energy assets from the U.S.

E-Commerce represents about 30% of new development for industrial REITs, such as Prologis. This [BLANK] more than two-thirds of new warehouse construction for other purposes. Prologis, Duke Realty and DCT Industrial have all cited strong demand from food and beverage, residential construction materials and manufacturing, including autos and auto parts. Most new development is speculative and can be used for any purpose, though Prologis and Duke Realty have increased exposure to build-to-suit projects.

Initial signs of gaming revenue growth in Macau after two years of declines begs the question of sustainability. The mass-market segment, a more profitable business, is key to [BLANK] this momentum as it drives long-term, steady revenue and makes up 50% of the citywide total. Operators are vying for a share of this business with new Cotai resorts as they continue to face VIP declines. Driving profit and operational efficiency will be notable performance metrics among operators as capacity expands.

The pricing debate sparked by the actions of a small number of specialty pharmaceuticals companies has spilled over into the entire sector. Though some drug prices look very high, the reality is that large pharmaceuticals companies have been giving back an [BLANK] amount of their gross sales (37% in 2014 vs. 29% in 2012) to U.S. payors. AstraZeneca, which has been competing heavily with GlaxoSmithKline in the respiratory space, tops peers, with 57% of U.S. gross sales payed back in rebates and discounts.

Even with faster growth than peers, NXP Semiconductors' core segments aren't in high-growth, capital-intensive industries. It has focused on reducing net debt, yet its recent Freescale purchase will be partially [BLANK] by an additional $1 billion in borrowing, raising its debt-to-Ebitda ratio to 3x from 2x. NXP seeks to revert to the 2x level within six quarters, with a focus on returning free cash flow to shareholders. Its capital return goals are similar to Infineon, STMicroelectronics and Texas Instruments.

The U.S. and AIG are due to respond by Oct. 8 to the initial briefs filed by Hank Greenberg's Starr International in the appeal of AIG shareholders' lawsuit challenging the insurer's bailout by the U.S. Starr's brief presented arguments on why the trial court erred in denying damages. In addition to [BLANK] those contentions, the U.S. will try to get the court's liability ruling reversed. Briefing will probably end in late November, followed by oral arguments. A ruling is likely in 1H16.

Franklin Resources Inc.'s managed-asset and related revenue growth may be further pressured by industry challenges in 2017. These include active asset outflows and [BLANK] U.S. Fiduciary Rule regulation. Potential rule changes under the Trump administration could be a positive, though some key underlying industry trends expected to accelerate under the rule are unlikely to reverse. Tax changes could help to boost near-term capital return. Fund performance is a key long-term variable.

This week's vote to select new House leadership will be critical to anticipating the tone in Washington. Those elected will [BLANK] not only the agenda, but the level of partisanship on issues such as raising the debt ceiling (Stephen Scalise), re-authorizing the Export-Import Bank (Kevin McCarthy), GSE reform (Jeb Hensarling), and the wind energy tax credit (Jim Jordan). Hearings this week include EPA testimony on CO2 regulation, and a review of housing policy, which could touch on GSE reform.

Assuming $75 million in marketing costs takes the total cost of "Captain America: Civil War" to $325 million. With $242 million in international sales as of May 4 and [BLANK] $214 million domestic debut gives Disney about $240 million by May 8, after a split to exhibitors. Another $250 million may be needed internationally for Disney to recover costs. China is especially critical, and Marvel has a strong record. "Avengers: Age of Ultron" grossed $155 million in its China debut (5-day), "Iron Man 3" $65 million.

The U.S. Patent and Trademark Office instituted Mylan's inter partes review petition challenging a patent to Onglyza and setting a three-month deadline for AstraZeneca to respond, or Aug. 3. The response was originally due July 20, but the parties jointly [BLANK] to the new date on June 10. The patent office's grant date sets a one-year statutory deadline for a final decision, by May 2017. The patent at issue covers both Onglyza and Kombiglyze and could affect AstraZeneca's lawsuits over both drugs.

Near-term biotech and pharma catalysts include Neurocrine's valbenazine Phase II data in pediatric patients with Tourette syndrome in May, which is more important than the recently reported adult trial. Initial safety and efficacy data of Spark's Phase I/II choroideremia gene therapy trial are [BLANK] early 2017. After a long-acting growth hormone Phase III trial in adults failed to meet the primary endpoint, OPKO-Pfizer may report new data in March from a modified analysis that seeks to remove outliers.

Tech hardware and storage companies outperformed the broader S&P 500 index through June 15, and a robust IT spending backdrop coupled with 2H seasonality may continue this strength. Tax cuts and cash repatriation by large enterprises may expand IT spending and stock buybacks [BLANK] higher EPS, but P/E ratios may not grow notably.

Costs for storing nuclear waste could fall for power producers if strengthening political support for reviving the U.S. government's Yucca Mountain waste disposal site in Nevada translates into action. Site construction was [BLANK] for years by former Senator Harry Reid and allies, including former President Barack Obama. Support from President Donald Trump, who included $120 million for the project in his fiscal 2018 budget, and a Republican-led Congress increase odds of the project restarting.

Validus said it passed on a recent Structured Agency Credit Risk (STACR) transaction in 1Q due to hesitation on comparative pricing. Without elaborating, the comments [BLANK] increasing integration and analysis of mortgage credit risk by different sectors of the market. The enhanced discipline is an example of the greater scrutiny of mortgage risk, as it's priced by different portions of the private sector. While this caution may lead to higher mortgage rates, it may trim costs over the course of the credit cycle.

Rite Aid (RAD -0.6%) held fiscal 2019 guidance steady, unsurprising to us given its pending merger with Albertsons, projected to close in 2H. Albertsons' S-4 filing on April 6 provided a wealth of detail on the [BLANK] transaction. Rite Aid sentiment has subsequently shifted to trade on the combined company's fundamentals. The S-4 revealed optimistic management projections five years out. Revenue is expected to grow $1.5-$2 billion a year and Ebitda is forecast to reach $875 million by 2023 from $645 million in 2019.

Natural gas will remain a leading fuel source for U.S. power generation, driven not just by cyclical and seasonal pricing dynamics, but a long-term shift inspired by government policy promoting alternatives to coal. Gas-fired power use is propelled by winter heating and summer [BLANK] demand. Seasonal shifts will persist in the near future should gas benchmarks remain muted relative to history. Natural-gas consumption for power burning may rise more than 5% this year and drop 3% next year, based on EIA data.

Computer Sciences potential split into two companies as reported by Reuters is likely driven by weak revenue growth over the past few years as well as increased activist interest in the company. CSC has been refocusing on higher growth areas such as cloud, big data, cybersecurity and mobility amid increased competition in its legacy IT outsourcing business and [BLANK] more work to low-cost offshore locations. Its federal business has also suffered as government funding has been weak.

The outcome of the Bank of England's 2015 stress test could reflect a less resilient capital position than expected by the industry. Worsening economic conditions are likely to [BLANK] risk-weighted assets at the same time as challenges to profitability hinder capital building. Hong Kong is a key market for both HSBC and Standard Chartered where the scenario includes a 65% decline in the Hang Seng index. The 44% depreciation in the won would pressure Standard Chartered's already challenged business in South Korea.

Key themes expected from beverage producers for the three months ending Dec. 31 include the potential conflicting effects of a stronger U.S. dollar, weakening demand in emerging markets, low gasoline prices, and low input-cost inflation. The magnitude of the currency and commodity shifts may [BLANK] to a wide range of results. Soft drink leader Coca-Cola may report a 15% decline in 4Q EPS on Feb. 9, based on consensus, mostly reflecting adverse currency translations.

Wells Fargo has until June 19 to request dismissal of a consolidated, amended complaint in securities fraud class-action lawsuits by shareholders against the bank related to its fake-account scandal, pursuant to a revised schedule. The suits were consolidated in January and [BLANK] claims were filed in March. Briefing on the anticipated dismissal bid will likely end Sept. 25, after which the parties will likely be in court for oral arguments. A ruling on a dismissal motion might not come until 1Q18.

Stock prices of oil majors with more refining capacity than upstream output haven't mirrored the recent oil-price rise. That's because while higher prices raise upstream sales revenue, they also [BLANK] into higher downstream costs for raw materials and energy. The refining capacity operated by Exxon and Shell is more than double that of the oil they produce. Among the top-four public oil majors by market capitalization, only BP produces more than it processes.

The Interior Department's Bureau of Land Management has been criticized for taking a year or more to grant permits for fracking on federal land, and the BLM's rule finalized in March may make permits take even longer. The agency [BLANK] the added costs to producers for compliance will be about $7,000 to $11,400 per fracked well. Despite court challenges, that probably isn't enough to deter drilling. The BLM is expected to propose another regulation on methane emissions from oil and gas wells on federal land in 4Q.

Efforts to "virtualize" storage are giving rise to hybrids that integrate their own hardware and software with cloud systems. Physical storage such as NAND flash and hard disks are becoming accessible via software interfaces that allow systems to [BLANK] into all devices, based on the applications they need to run. Internal arrays of disks or high-speed NAND flash may be tied to Amazon or Google external storage, creating highly efficient "hybrid" clouds. Customers using these systems seek high capacity at low costs.

In this week's generic-drug litigation update, Gilead dismissed a lawsuit related to pulmonary hypertension drug Letairis against Actavis. The court overseeing Sanofi's suit against Eli Lilly over its diabetes drug Lantus issued a supplemental Markman order construing key terms of patents [BLANK] the drug. AbbVie's Androgel lawsuit against Perrigo was dismissed. Johnson & Johnson settled litigation related to the HIV drug Prezista. Eli Lilly filed a new lawsuit against Lupin over its heart disease drug Effient.

The Milliman Hedge Cost Index rose 10 bps to 137 bps in August vs. 127 bps in July. The index shows the annual cost to [BLANK] variable-annuity withdrawal benefits. Milliman assumes a 115-bp rider fee and product features that reflect those in the annuity market, using a dynamic lapse rate and a 10% target fund volatility. For details, use MLHCI DES. The index typically moves inversely to swap rates, which are key drivers. Hedge costs are a limited but important component of annuity margins.

California Governor Jerry Brown will likely sign a bill into law before mid-October that would significantly boost wind, solar and other clean-energy power generation in the state by 2030. The Democratic governor has until Oct. 11 to [BLANK] the bill under procedural requirements. The state's legislature in September passed Senate Bill 350, which would require 50% of electricity generated and sold by the end of 2030 to come from wind, solar, geothermal or other renewable sources.

Macau casino indicators suggest an inflection in its mainstream Chinese consumer-related activity is developing. After a prolonged downturn, mass-market gaming revenue has [BLANK], while Chinese visitation is improving after declines since early 2015. They both suffered from a Macau smoking ban, disruptive Cotai construction and slowing Chinese economic growth. Cotai's transformation to a multi-resort destination should spur new buzz and visitation in 2H, possibly spurring mass-market revenue.

The 3% FICC staff cut in 1Q signals a muted outlook beyond the tough start to 2016. BofA, JPMorgan and Citi said 2Q trading may rise, though 2Q15 FICC was [BLANK]. Equities may decline with a tougher comparison after a 1% staff cut. A Broadridge survey shows analysts expect FICC revenue to rise at the largest investment banks 0.2% annually in 2015-20, after falling 8.5% a year in 2010-14. That's below M&A (4.9%), asset management (4.0%), equity underwriting (3.4%), equity trading (2.8%) and debt issues (2.1%).

Facing a new consolidated proposed class-action complaint filed by commercial establishments and individuals, the NFL, DirecTV and others are likely to ask for the case to be dismissed near the end of 3Q. Plaintiffs, led by the Mucky Duck pub, claim that an agreement among NFL clubs that gives DirecTV exclusive rights to broadcast live "out-of-market" games -- [BLANK] NFL Sunday Ticket -- is unlawful. The complaint was filed on June 24. Absent an extension of time, defendants have 45 days from that date to answer.

Drilling rigs in the Permian Basin fell by the largest number in more than three years as the play shed 20 rigs in the week ended Dec. 12, the most of any oil play, according to Baker Hughes. While the U.S. rig count had been relatively stable, it appears the inevitable capital spending cuts [BLANK] from plummeting oil prices may be beginning to take hold. E&Ps may continue to scale back new drilling until there is clarity on a possible oil price floor.

Airbus' 2Q Ebit could rise to 900 million euros on 14.7 billion euros in revenue, boosted by better commercial aircraft margins. These should [BLANK] to about 7% as we expect more deliveries with a greater mix of higher-margin neo family aircraft as Airbus progresses toward the two-thirds target for 2018. Higher throughput at commercial aircraft lowers the per unit cost of overhead. Helicopter revenue should be stable or slightly higher on more volume though margins fall. We expect more medium helicopter deliveries though high-margin large machines decline on weak energy customer demand. Defense revenue and profit is expected to be flat, while A400M deliveries decrease to 15 in 2018 and 11 in 2019.

Baker Hughes made up ground in 4Q after an announced merger with General Electric in late October and partial divestiture of its North American pressure-pumping business created positive catalysts. Investor attention may shift to potential prospects for the combined entity that seemingly has more offshore exposure and less to the U.S. land market, where Halliburton [BLANK] a clear lead. Eyes are on Weatherford's turnaround story after financing concerns were allayed and the company's long-time CEO stepped down.

Genworth was the worst performer in BI's North American life insurance peer group for a fourth consecutive month in August, falling 26%. Most of the underperformance occurred when the shares [BLANK] 20% after 2Q results missed consensus. American Equity was the second-worst performer, losing 18% vs. a 6% group decline. Amid a tumultuous market, prices for two insurers, CNO and FBL Financial, inched higher in August, while Symetra was an outlier with shares rising 26% due to a takeover offer from Sumitomo Life.

Novartis' lawsuit over Roxane and Par's proposed copies of its cancer drug Afinitor is down to one patent after the parties agreed to dismiss the other two in the lawsuits. Novartis has eight patents [BLANK] for the drug in the FDA's Orange Book, though only three were asserted in this case. The remaining patent (US 5,665,772) covers everolimus, Afinitor's active ingredient and expires in March 2020. In a separate lawsuit, Novartis asserted a newer patent that expires in 2028 for a method of treatment.

The rise in U.K. home-insurance rates in 2016 has been driven by increasing insurance-premium taxes (IPT), aimed at funding flood defenses. Having raised the IPT by 4% since November 2015, the Chancellor of the Exchequer [BLANK] another 2% increase in the 2016 Autumn Statement, effective this June. This will raise the tax to 12%, representing a doubling over less than two years. While this may be fully passed on to policyholders via higher rates, it may discouraged some policyholders from taking out coverage.

Key near-term events in the biotech and pharmaceuticals industry include Phase III data releases of CTI-Baxter's pacritinib PERSIST-1 trial in myelofibrosis, BioDelivery's clonidine gel RHAPSODY trial in painful diabetic neuropathy, Sorrento's Cynviloq TRIBECA bioequivalence trial vs. Celgene's Abraxane in breast cancer and Novo Nordisk's faster-acting insulin aspart ONSET trials in diabetes. Nektar [BLANK] NKTR-102 BEACON trial data in breast cancer in March. Click image to open the full calendar.

French new-car sales sustained their robust start to 2018, increasing 9.2% in June against a moderate 1.6% prior-year climb. This was assisted by generous automaker incentives, to [BLANK] the switch to low-emission vehicles. Sales-growth comparison will become much tougher, with 10.9% prior year increase in July.

Community Health and HCA may preview 4Q earnings results prior to JPMorgan's health-care conference, if last year's pattern repeats. Community Health's same-hospital adjusted admissions could [BLANK] in 4Q, unlike the 7% decline a year earlier. Express Scripts and CVS Health may provide an update on their hepatitis C formulary strategies, along with the coming selling season. Aetna and Humana may comment on whether open enrollment for the public health insurance exchanges is proceeding as expected.

Snap's February IPO of shares with no votes pushed investors to the limit of their patience with the trend of unequal rights at founder-led companies. Some founders, particularly in technology such as Google and Facebook, have [BLANK] loath to relinquish control, even as they seek investor capital. They have used multiple share classes to cement majority voting power. Snap's IPO has succeeded in rousing investors to action, potentially severely curtailing the practice.

Follicular lymphoma (FL) is a type of blood cancer caused by the the production of abnormal white blood cells or B-Lymphocytes, which aggregate in the lymph nodes in clumps known as "follicles." Mutations to these cells, which [BLANK] part of the body's immune system, can result in sufferers of the disease being more at risk from infections. Other symptoms of FL include fatigue, fever, weight loss and anemia. The disease is the most common form of low grade (slow-growing) non-Hodgkin's lymphoma.

Apparel chains struggling to boost market share are now more focused on the portfolio of stores they operate, determining each store's individual returns and closing unprofitable ones. American Eagle plans to [BLANK] 70 stores in 2014 and 150 during the next three years. Abercrombie expects to close 60 stores each year over the next few years, while Aeropostale intends to close up to 175 namesake stores and eventually close all 125 mall-based P.S. stores.

Intime's same-store sales swung to a 1H gain, up 2.1% year over year vs. a 2.4% decline a year earlier. This [BLANK] Intime a step closer to its full-year 4% revenue growth target of 5.5 billion yuan. Rental income may rise, as the company now operates 16 shopping centres, 60% more than during a year ago. Of Intime's 13 unprofitable stores at the end of 2014, at least three are now profitable or at break even. Investors will also look for new details on the spinoff of its Beijing store into a real-estate trust.

Personal lines insurance rates decelerated to a 1% gain in April, the slowest pace in three years, according to MarketScout. Homeowners coverage drove the reduction, [BLANK] to a 1% increase from 4% gains in mid-2014. Pricing for personal articles coverage was unchanged, contributing to the slowdown. Auto premium rates rose 2%, consistent with 1Q gains, though Allstate and GEICO said they are implementing higher rates due to margin pressure in various customer segments and regions.

Johnson & Johnson's rivals are unlikely to get in the way of its proposed Actelion purchase, but President Trump could pose a stumbling block. It's possible he won't take kindly to J&J using its ex-U.S. cash to [BLANK] the deal. The whole point of initiating a conversation about reducing the tax burden on U.S. companies on income and repatriated cash from overseas earnings is to entice investment into the U.S. J&J is essentially saving whatever taxes it would have had to pay by buying Actelion with off-shore cash.

The FTR Truck Utilization Index registered 98.3% in November, 70 bps lower from last year. FTR expects the truck market to [BLANK] in 2014, forecasting utilization to increase to 98.5%, 61 bps above 2013. Rates may rise 3.6% in 2014 and 5.1% in 2015 on increased demand, tighter capacity and a driver shortage, which may help offset higher costs from driver pay increases and regulations. FTR expects utilization to decrease to 97.8% in December, a 111-bp decline from last year.

Canadian carriers have increasingly been laying fiber directly to subscribers' homes in an effort to boost sales of bundled services. Experience has shown that subscribers tend to purchase additional services after fiber is [BLANK] to their homes. BCE CEO George Cope said that sales of fiber TV subscriptions can "pull through" high-speed Internet sales. This is not always positive for the bottom-line, as bundles carry discounts to stand-alone products, pressuring margins.

Foreign-exchange average daily trading volume was 26% higher year-over-year in July, compared with a 42% increase in 2Q, based on CME data. Volume is 19% below the 2Q monthly average, which [BLANK] 5% from 1Q. An increase in currency volatility may support higher bank trading volume and revenue vs. the prior year, with a Deutsche Bank foreign exchange volatility measure running 62% above the 3Q14 average. Volatility is 6% below the 2Q average, and volume may decline sequentially with seasonal trends.

Legislation in Congress would prevent the Federal Communications Commission from regulating broadband rates charged by Internet service providers, easing companies' concerns about potential rate caps. FCC Chairman Tom Wheeler has said the commission wouldn't regulate broadband like a utility, though future FCC leadership may [BLANK] to do so. The Republican-backed bill, H.R. 2666, would bar the FCC from imposing utility-type regulations regardless of which party controls the White House in 2017.

Revenue per available room, or revpar, is the product of average occupancy and average daily rate. It is a common indicator of hotel performance because it is [BLANK] by occupancy, a reflection of demand based on fluctuating room price. Revpar growth rates fluctuate based on seasonality, the health of the economy and local competitors' performance. U.S. revpar growth in 2Q was 8.2% and has consistently expanded since 2Q10.

Tire manufacturers are benefiting from both high replacement volume and increased original-equipment sales, given that the U.S. vehicle fleet at 11.4 years is the oldest in history, requiring consumers to replace tires or entire vehicles. An influx of Chinese tires has started to affect replacement volume for premium manufacturers, as expensive brands [BLANK] margins by avoiding price wars with imports. Cheaper input costs for crude oil-based products will help offset falling prices.

Manufacturers that are earlier adopters of factory automation, including fully-automated "lights-out" facilities that can operate in the dark and without humans, will likely lead peers in sales productivity. Employees at Hon Hai, the biggest manufacturer of Apple's iPhones, are able to [BLANK] more sales per headcount due to automated manufacturing.

Plunging oil prices in 2014 have eroded stock gains at state oil firms in China and India. An oil price rebound in 2015 may be [BLANK] by slowing demand and ample supplies. Oil-linked LNG prices in Asia may struggle as new gas supplies from Australia and the U.S. come online. A price plunge similar in magnitude to the one in 2008 may be avoided if the U.S. leads an improving global economy. Reforms in India and China may support cashflows and earnings at state firms in light of weak oil prices.

The rising adoption of wearable electronics, such as fitness wristbands and activity trackers, could expand the addressable market for Garmin and may boost sales in the company's fitness division. Revenue for the segment [BLANK] 16% last year, as the company boosted marketing spending 52%. Garmin expects the division's sales to increase 10% this year, though competition could hurt margins. The emergence of smartwatches, such as the Apple Watch and Samsung Gear, could challenge the basic wearable market longer term.

Health-care REITs trade at a deep discount relative to REIT peers due to the slower-growing nature of their long-term net leases, which make this sector the most susceptible to rising interest rates. At a forward 12-month funds-from-operations multiple of 13.4x, health-care REITs ended June with the lowest FFO multiple of all REIT property segments, a position they have [BLANK] almost constantly since 2010. The discount to the overall REIT multiple has widened from almost even in 2Q13, to 22% in June.

One of the worst years ever for hurricane losses may lead to an uplift in property and casualty pricing in the U.S. in 2018. Reinsurance pricing is also likely to [BLANK]. European prospects remain mixed, with price increases limited and volumes constrained. In the U.K., where auto-insurance prices are sharply up, the outlook rests on the timing of any further Ogden discount-rate reform.
