New data protection laws in Europe promise to increase demand for cyber insurance, though risk aggregation is a concern.

A volatility pickup bodes well for equity-trading revenue, especially for derivatives. Stalling primary issuance is a negative, though [BLANK] stock prices may aid the calendar as volatility normalizes from spikes. Institutional sentiment, as indicated by risk appetite, jumped with the market's record monthly close in January, according to a quantitative measure.

Bristol-Myers Squibb has the highest consensus EPS growth of large-pharma peers for 2016-19, as well as the highest price-to-earnings ratio, on expectations it will retain its immuno-oncology edge. AbbVie [BLANK] the lowest-valued, based on P/E of 10.5x vs. a peer median of 14.6x. It also has the lowest ratio of P/E to estimated EPS growth, at 13.7%. The equity selloff has taken its toll on large pharma stocks, with the gap between share prices and average analyst price targets now the widest since 2009.

Biotech enters 2019 with headroom, after U.S.-China trade tensions spooked risk-averse investors out of the sector in 4Q. For big caps, this may make for a value play, particularly as companies work to [BLANK] revenue-generation challenges. Valuations may lower a barrier to M&A, though targets can still be selective if they are sufficiently profitable or have access to cash. We remain excited about industry advances from a catalyst perspective, particularly in the fields of cell and gene therapy. Maiden drug launches have continued to disappoint, and caution may therefore still be needed in 2019. In part, this may be a factor of the pricing environment, where payers do well to opportunistically exert pressure. Political criticisms on pricing may recur in 2H, and we expect price hikes to remain conservative.

Global building-materials peers are striving to improve investor returns through higher dividend payments or share buybacks. Still, while dividend yields have started to improve from a 2012 low, they remain far from levels [BLANK] in 2008, when they exceeded 4% vs. 2.88% expected next year.

Chipmaker forward P/E multiples rose just under 1% in 1Q amid macroeconomic concerns and weak demand in key end-markets. Cost cuts and share buybacks may be unable to [BLANK] this weakness, and consensus has again cut 2016 EPS for the group. Potential demand recovery in 2H may ease sales and earnings pressure, yet any weaker-than-expected results may compress multiples, particularly for analog chipmakers such as Texas Instruments. EV-to-sales multiples for the group are 30% above the three-year average.

Goldman Sachs' management attributes most of its 11% head-count growth in 2012-15 to increasing regulatory compliance staff. CEO Lloyd Blankfein said even before the U.S. presidential election that much of the increase may mirror the bulk-up in tech staffing that occurred as banks [BLANK] for "Y2K." The implication is that many of its hires relate to implementation of new rules, and the company may be able to eventually reduce some related head count and thus costs. This may also be true for global bank peers.

Post-4Q Earnings Outlook: Another strong cash-flow and earnings performance in-line with consensus (or slightly ahead) reflects the underlying strength of Total's financial framework. It's best evidenced by a newly [BLANK] outlook for rising dividends and a share buyback program from 2018-2020. Total's best-in-class organic breakeven of $27 a barrel (pre-dividend) is projected to decline further to below $20 in 2019. Aided by new-project ramp-ups and facilitated by acquisitions, upstream delivered its strongest quarterly earnings in three years. The segment will grow at a torrid 6% pace in 2018, with Yamal now onstream, Maersk Oil and Engie LNG deals closing shortly, and with Lapa and Iara Brazil interests recently acquired.

While Fifth Third's retail-bank unit efficiency is in-line with BI-tracked peers, its commercial bank ranks below. Optimizing its commercial efficiency to bring it in-line with peers as of 2016 would [BLANK] the companywide ratio by three percentage points, boosting EPS by 10% and ROE by 90 bps. The bank's Project North Star targets better efficiency via initiatives such as branch closings and re-engineered loan processes, and a 12-14% return on tangible common equity by year-end 2019 vs. 2016's adjusted 12%.

At its most basic, net neutrality prevents roadblocks, tolls and fast lanes on the internet. Even though internet service providers own or control the wires or wireless spectrum that [BLANK] traffic, net neutrality means an ISP can't block it, slow it down or give it special treatment. In theory, that empowers innovators at the network's edges to create services, since they don't need an ISP's permission. The FCC adopted net neutrality rules in 2015.

Boosted by the acquisitions of high-growth, asset-light companies, Church & Dwight should maintain its return lead over selected home- and personal-care peers into 2018 in terms of organic sales gains over invested capex. The beauty group has the most potential to expand returns after [BLANK] investments and Coty's refocus.

Philippine exports fell 16% in September and 8% in 3Q, driven by a 20% decline in exports to China, despite rising semiconductor exports. With the major markets of Japan and the U.S. [BLANK] the Trans-Pacific Partnership trade deal with regional competitors including Malaysia, it's no surprise the Philippine government is considering joining. This may prove far from simple, however, with elections on May 9 and as-yet uncertain positioning of most of the presidential candidates.

Senior gold producers are expected to post a median 27% decline in 3Q EPS as they cut costs in response to falling gold prices. Gold [BLANK] 4% in 3Q from the same period a year earlier. Silver producers were estimated to report a median 33% EPS decrease as the average price of that precious metal fell 8%. Management teams are likely to discuss the continuing attempt to slim down this quarter as metal prices continue falling.

Global ad gains may accelerate to about 5% in 2016, driven by the Olympics and U.S. elections. These events, which [BLANK] every four years, add 1-1.5% to the $550 billion industry. Digital may become the top U.S. ad medium in 2016, eclipsing TV for the first time. Last year, $25-$30 billion of agency account spending came under review, a phenomenon dubbed "Mediapalooza," which may affect 2016 more than 2015. Ad networks are unlikely to indulge in any big M&A, but continue to make programmatic investments.

Variations in inflation rates, combined with regulatory-review decisions, cause a divergence between network utilities in terms of profit, cash flow and share-price performance. U.K. inflation has [BLANK] that of core Europe during the past seven years and is forecast to continue, based on consensus. Returns on regulated assets in the euro area remain pressured, as utilities need to adjust to a decreasing European Union inflation-rate environment.

Gilead's forecast that the Kite acquisition will be neutral to earnings by year three implies that there may be zero synergies in the transaction. This makes sense, given Gilead doesn't have a meaningful oncology business, [BLANK] alone any prior competencies in cell therapies even remotely similar to CAR-T. Kite would essentially be a $12 billion bolt-on to Gilead, requiring everything from Kite's established manufacturing facilities, oncologist and payer-focused sales teams, and R&D personnel.

An HSBC unit is unlikely to settle a $34 billion mortgage-backed securities lawsuit by BlackRock, Pimco and other MBS investors prior to a ruling on its dismissal bid, which may come at the end of 1Q or early 2Q. The bank was likely emboldened by a Dec. 23 appeals court ruling in a similar suit that may [BLANK] the claims against HSBC. If the suit survives the dismissal bid, it may have a settlement value of about $711 million billion, based on a recent accord in a similar case against Bank of America.

The recovery in excavator sales in China may continue into 2H even with the government's housing-market curbs. The stricter measures will likely [BLANK] home prices in tier 1 and tier 2 cities, but the housing demand spillover to lower-tier cities will likely sustain sales of construction equipment. Excavators, which account for about half of China's construction-machine sales, have rebounded since 2H 2016. Unit sales surged 99% in 1Q from a low base.

Growth in the supply of health-care property types varies in accordance with demand, as those with the anticipated strongest demand attract more construction. Senior housing is facing oversupply, while cuts in government reimbursements have [BLANK] in few skilled-nursing home starts. Urban and on-campus Medical offices remain in favor, while off-campus construction is less attractive.

Continuing the optimistic economic outlook from 4Q, industrials lead January's metals gainers, with copper, silver, aluminum and zinc up about 7%. Suppressed amid political issues, aluminum is trying to [BLANK] up to copper, its top index-weighted counterpart. Driven by China, the world's largest consumer, zinc remains the best performer on a one- and two-year basis. China's Purchasing Managers' Index held above 51 in December, signaling expansion for a third-consecutive month, the longest trend since September 2014.

Paribas' FICC trading run rate -- down 25% year-over-year at 1H -- and the strength of equities activities, will be the main revenue delta in 3Q results. The French retail-revenue turnaround is being [BLANK], with flat quarter-over-quarter income likely, while BNL's revenue drop should slow to 3% vs. 3Q17. Cost of risk -- as with peers -- will likely come in below consensus, though the market will also probably continue to look through this. Capital build remains slow, and we believe the bank is on track for 11.8% for the full year. The focus of the call should be on Italy's prospects, Turkish exposure and 4Q trading outlook, in our view.

When President Barack Obama took office, greenhouse gas emissions weren't regulated by the federal government. By the time he [BLANK] the White House, his administration will have proposed Clean Air Act regulations that cover 60% of U.S. greenhouse gases. Electric power plants are responsible for the largest share of those emissions -- about 30%. The EPA's Clean Power Plan, which was stayed by the Supreme Court on Feb. 9. pending the resolution of legal challenges, would set emissions limits for electric utilities.

LEDs account for less than 20% of the global lighting market, yet contribute 35-45% of lighting sales for major European and U.S. companies gearing up to address an almost 100% increase in the market by 2020. LED lighting sales should expand faster than traditional lighting, albeit with increasing margin pressure, as competition adds to [BLANK] pressure. Lighting companies have been under-investing in and treating traditional lighting as a cash cow, which may lead to more divestitures.

Jazz is defending its top-selling drug Xyrem in several patent lawsuits by generic drug makers and inter partes review challenges at the U.S. Patent Office by generic makers and activist shareholder Kyle Bass. Xyrem [BLANK] Jazz more than $778 million in 2014, almost 70% of its revenue. These patent challenges could pose a serious risk to Jazz's main revenue source. Jazz has three groups of patents on Xyrem: compositions expiring in 2020, risk mitigation expiring in 2024 and a method of treatment expiring in 2033.

DineEquity, McDonald's, Darden and Cracker Barrel top their restaurant peers with dividend yields of more than 3%. McDonald's has remained [BLANK] to paying a dividend even with declines in revenue and net income, which its turnaround plan is addressing. Some operators prefer to return cash to investors via share buybacks rather than through higher cash dividends. Same-store sales at Olive Garden, owned by Darden, and DineEquity's IHOP have been improving as the operators focus on boosting traffic.

The shift toward online and on-demand viewing among younger generations is growing more pronounced. This gradually [BLANK] the risks for traditional pay-TV subscriptions centered on provision of premium pay-TV channels. As younger generations age, they will become the decision makers for household budgets, likely basing pay-TV choice on viewing habits. This underscores efforts by pay-TV operators such as Sky and Modern Times to hasten over-the-top models.

Fast-food workers have never unionized, mainly due to the nature of their jobs. The majority of positions are part-time, entry-level roles with high turnover rates, making employees unwilling to [BLANK] union dues. This makes unionization, with multiyear collective bargaining agreements, less enticing to what remains a transient workforce, even with an increasing number of longer-term employees. Unions seeking an industry foothold may be thwarted as restaurants add pay increases and benefits.

ICE's global presence as an equity and derivative exchange owner makes it subject to a variety of regulations. The EU's MiFID II may ultimately divert trading to exchanges, but could also [BLANK] heavier regulatory burdens on their customers. In the U.S., NYSE and ICE Futures could see rules regarding automated trading and market structures. ICE may also be affected by potential rules requiring central counterparties to conduct stress tests and hold additional capital to safeguard against a client default.

Canada probably won't use the Volcker Rule to test the North American Free Trade Agreement's limits on financial rules. It's also unlikely to bring a trade case because that would threaten its efforts to [BLANK] the Trans-Pacific Partnership. By starting a Nafta case, Canada would give credence to Democratic Senator Elizabeth Warren's warnings that trade deals may be used to dismantle Dodd-Frank. The White House would have difficulty continuing to dismiss Warren's warnings as speculative if Canada brings a case.

In Brazil, drivers of flex-fuel vehicles who triggered an average 45% increase in monthly year-over-year growth in demand for hydrous ethanol in March through September may continue switching back to gasoline. The price ratio of hydrous ethanol vs. gasoline is 0.75x [BLANK] with 0.63x on Sept. 13 as the retail ethanol price rose 36%. Flex-fuel vehicle drivers tend to buy more hydrous ethanol if the ratio falls below 0.7x, since it has about 70% energy vs. gasoline. Hydrous ethanol sales rose by 8% yoy in December.

The ECB will restart its covered bond program, originally launched in May 2010. Two covered bond purchase facilities were [BLANK]. Currently, 46.7 billion euros ($61 billion) of these bonds remain on the ECB balance sheet. The new program will focus exclusively on euro-denominated issues and start in October, targeting bonds from euro zone-domiciled financial institutions. As a reference, the ECB showed $1.94 trillion of eligible collateral from these instruments at 2Q.

The Toys "R" Us unsecured creditors committee, which includes Mattel and Lego Systems, is seeking to examine some of Toys' pre-bankruptcy transactions. The committee may be able to [BLANK] the investigation to increase creditor recoveries, but will likely be inclined to avoid threatening the retailer's bankruptcy exit.

Goldman Sachs (GS -0.1%) is likely to lose a renewed bid to prevent shareholders from proceeding as a class in a $13 billion securities-fraud lawsuit related to collateralized debt obligations. A May 22 date for oral arguments was [BLANK] to July 19, which may suggest a settlement is in the works. We estimate the settlement range is $65-$325 million, based on similar cases. The suit alleges undisclosed conflicts of interest in four CDOs, including Abacus, the vehicle whose holdings Paulson & Co. helped pick. The hedge fund took financial positions that bet against the portfolio.

The coming weekend snowstorm in the Northeast could spur same-store sales of home-improvement retailers such as Home Depot, Lowe's and Tractor Supply as consumers snap up on big-ticket cold-weather items, including power generators and snow blowers. The Northeast makes up just over 22% of the store base for these retailers, who [BLANK] January 2014 comparisons jump an average 575 bps during a period with similar weather patterns. Soon after a deal is filed with the government and "cleared" to the Federal Trade Commission or Justice Department, the reviewing agency starts its information collection by contacting the parties' top customers. Buyer and seller generally voluntarily [BLANK] the necessary contact details for top customers, as well as recent business plans and other materials. When contacted, customers are asked about their view of the deal. Complaints are given serious consideration and can set the tone of the review going forward.

Qualcomm's patent lawsuits against Apple in Germany serve to promote a quick resolution of the companies' licensing disputes, though the cases target only a small portion of the iPhone maker's revenue. IDC data show western Europe [BLANK] less than 17% of Apple's global handset sales by value in 1Q. Apple holds about 49% market share in western Europe. Companies involved in patent disputes frequently litigate in Germany because the country's courts offer strong protections to patent owners and move quickly.

Sinclair is following issues in Washington including bills in Congress (H.R. 3148, S. 1182 and S. 1910) that could exempt broadcast television stations from a Federal Communications Commission rule on joint sales agreements. Retransmission fees and exclusivity rules proposed by the FCC could also [BLANK] Sinclair. Congress may hold hearings in 2015 and 2016 on a Communications Act of 1934 rewrite. This legislation could impact all telecommunications issues now before Congress and the FCC. Expect legislation in 2017.

Leading indicators for financial information vendors have improved, with rising bond and equity issuance worldwide and consistent gains in M&A volume and consumer credit. Global bond sales more than [BLANK] from a year earlier in June to $416 billion. Stock sales also surged to the highest monthly volume since December 2009. Global M&A volume jumped 49%, while consumer credit continued a steady ascent with a 6.6% rise in May.

The ITC is set to issue a final decision in Cisco's second case against Arista by May 1. The ITC on March 1 decided it would [BLANK] the trial judge's initial ruling with respect to all of the patents at issue in the case. The presiding judge on Dec. 9 ruled that Arista infringed two Cisco patents and didn't infringe four others. The ITC isn't bound by the judge's initial ruling, though the decision is consistent with the ITC staff attorneys' view of the case and could preview the case's ultimate outcome.

The federal government's main contract for security-clearance background investigations expires in 2016, putting at risk about $500 million a year in orders for incumbents CACI and KeyPoint Government Solutions. The contract, worth as much as $2.5 billion, [BLANK] importance for both companies after a third provider, USIS, was fired in 2014 following a cyberattack on its network and allegations of fraud. The U.S. has said as many as four providers will be selected for the new program.

While October's surge in volatility is likely to boost trading revenue, SocGen envisages a "low-volatility, but unstable" market scenario unfolding. The VIX Index, [BLANK] as the fear gauge, surged 61% in the first two weeks of October, due to a perfect storm of Ebola to speculation over U.S. interest rates, before falling back to September levels, indicating the swing may be short-lived. SocGen cited low volatility and falling volumes for the 25% year-on-year decline in equities revenue in 3Q.

The Philippines has been one of the most prized emerging markets in Asia for cement makers, with urbanization the main driver. Cemex's fourth-quarter sales in the country [BLANK] 13% from a year earlier. This contrasts with average annualized growth of about 11% the company has recorded there since 2008, and validates its new $300 million investment. The cement producer recently increased Philippine capacity by 25% with an integrated production line that can produce 1.5 million metric tons of cement a year.

The most restrictive U.S. sanctions on Russia were announced by the Obama administration in September 2014 and broadly prohibit U.S. companies from doing business in deepwater, Arctic offshore or shale projects in Russia. Among the Russian energy companies [BLANK] off-limits are Gazprom, Gazprom Neft, Lukoil, Rosneft and Surgutneftegas. The measures forced Exxon Mobil to wind down Arctic exploration projects launched with Rosneft in 2012.

Businesses are increasingly encouraging employees to work remotely, including on their own smartphones and tablets. This so-called "bring your own device" trend likely will [BLANK] opportunities for IT services companies, given that corporations will need custom systems to securely provide data and applications remotely to both employees and customers. IBM's alliance with Apple to create business applications is a recent example of this opportunity.

Westpac's revenue growth this and next fiscal year hinges on net interest margin and lending growth. While a jump in retail deposits [BLANK] funding cost in fiscal 1H ended March, the bank may face hurdles of pricey wholesale funding and higher term-deposit rates, which may hurt margins going forward. CBA and NAB reported margin squeeze in the June quarter. Westpac may also rely on personal loans, which accelerated sequential growth in 1H. Its 1H cash-earnings revenue rose by 6% from a year earlier.

Despite a third-straight quarter of worse-than-expected loan growth in 3Q, BI's U.S. regional banks met earnings estimates, aided by higher net interest margins (NIMs) and lower-than-expected credit provisions. NIMs beat estimates, with the median rising 1 bp sequentially, and most banks [BLANK] stable-to-slightly lower margins in the near term, absent further rate hikes. Banks generally expect continued weak loan growth in 4Q, but remain optimistic on 2018. Estimates for 2018 EPS were stable following results.

After a small decline last week, the U.S. total rig count resumed its climb in the week ended July 1, adding 10. Driving the increase was the Permian Basin, which added rigs for the third week in a row, [BLANK] its total to 154 active rigs. Boeing and Airbus should gain in 4Q on rising production and delivery rates, while engine makers such as MTU, Safran and Rolls-Royce benefit from higher spare-parts sales on strong traffic growth globally. Smaller manufacturers such as Embraer and Bombardier have challenges, [BLANK] the business jet market and Leonardo helicopters.

Macroeconomic and industry conditions have pushed U.S. new vehicle demand to its strongest levels since 2006. Buyers are [BLANK] easy financing and low interest rates are making monthly payments affordable, even as average transaction prices are at an all-time high. Cheap gasoline has relieved pain at the pump and allowed shoppers to reach for more vehicle, which in the U.S. typically means a segment shift toward light-truck purchases.

The EU envisages it will take about 20 separate measures to build a Capital Markets Union. It acknowledges the banks' concerns that any initiative should "do no harm," [BLANK] regulation will be used only where needed. Four legislative measures have so far been put forward -- on securitization, capital rules, Solvency II and prospectuses -- as the EU seeks to rely on market-driven solutions. Yet it may not be feasible to tackle complex areas such as tax, bankruptcy and pensions in this way.

Farnborough may answer a nagging question: Are aircraft sales slowing? In the five months to May, just Boeing, Embraer and ATR -- a joint venture between Airbus and Leonardo -- have a 1x book-to-bill, with large orders [BLANK] all, including 100 737s for VietJet, 20 ATRs for Iran Air and 30 E175s for Alaska Air's Horizon. A D.C. appeals court will likely decide TV broadcasters' challenge to FCC rules for a 600 MHz incentive auction in 2Q. Analog chipmakers' forward P/E multiple, at 16x, trails the S&P 500 and broader semiconductor peers. Weaker-than-expected results may compress multiples further. M&A speculation may support higher-than-usual valuations near term.

Puerto Rico, its Cofina financing arm and general obligation bondholders will likely settle a dispute over sales tax revenue, given the court's neutral tone at an April 10 hearing. The court is unlikely to quickly decide the issue, allowing parties more room to [BLANK]. Over $50 billion in future revenue is at issue.

Growth in China's video game market will likely slow in 2017-19, following rapid gains in the last five years driven by the rise of mobile gaming on smartphones. Mobile game sales grew at a 62% compound annual rate in 2013-16, according to NewZoo, [BLANK] by the rapid adoption of 4G smartphones that supported app-based mobile games. With China's 4G penetration at 57% and rising, the pace of 4G subscription growth is likely to slow and be driven by more incremental gains in revenue per user.

Luxury-goods companies' sales growth of about 5% in 2017 will likely accelerate in the year ahead, with Asia's continued recovery playing a big part. Heritage luxury brands are being [BLANK] after world over, and is the area where demand is escalating fastest. That pits them to outperform vs. fashion brands again in 2018.

Sky's strategy to fuel growth in Italy centers on greater penetration. Sky has [BLANK] 9 million households, including 1.7 million Mediaset customers, as core prospects out of 20.3 million households without Sky. Pay-TV penetration in Italy remains low at 27% vs. a European average of 55%. But this has not translated into higher penetration. A rise in convergence, which renders telecom companies more active in pay TV, and Mediaset's revamped offer with greater sports content will likely limit prospects.

A slightly milder than expected start to winter has pushed natural gas prices lower yet further. A cold-weather snap similar to last year's polar vortex may be [BLANK] to support natural gas prices as production rises to new records. Meanwhile, Canadian gas imports may continue to be displaced, while exports to Mexico will likely increase. Longer term, resilient natural gas output, restrained domestic prices and benign consumption growth should spur exports of liquefied natural gas.

Ramifications from the July oil-price pullback that took crude into the mid $40-a-barrel range have moderated as rig-count gains slow but aren't derailed entirely. While prices quickly retraced most of their losses due to new long positions and short-covering, they've since retrenched, [BLANK] to slow oilfield activity. Labor and capital are near-term hurdles to growth given E&Ps want crude prices above $50 before altering their budgets. Many are still focused on operating within cash flow.

EQT's sum-of-the-parts discount will narrow as it rationalizes its structure following the closing of the Rice acquisition. Refining underwhelming upstream guidance will reintroduce investors to the premier natural gas play in the U.S. while more clearly delineating and accelerating synergies will [BLANK] confidence. Expediting disposition of crucial infrastructure assets is an underappreciated element of its deal with Rice. Yet imbalances heading into winter threaten near-term improvement in sentiment and prices.

Global investment banks' debt underwriting revenue may be helped by lower interest rates and tighter spreads. Global corporate debt issuance generally [BLANK] in July from June, though remains below year-ago levels in some regions. U.S. volume rose 1% vs. June with an 11% increase in investment grade and 38% lower high yield. Europe's 5% gain was similarly supported by a 12% increase in investment grade but a 12% drop in high yield. Compared with July 2015, the U.S. was 17% lower, while Europe was 10% higher.

A State Department account that funds overseas peacekeeping operations largely performed by Pacific Architects & Engineers (PAE) is set to rise 26.8% in 2016. The increase was included in the federal omnibus spending bill [BLANK] in December. The spending boost is larger than increases proposed earlier by the White House and the House. The Senate had proposed cutting the account 20.5%. PAE received $152 million in orders from the account in 2014. Aecom and Engility are also exposed to the account.

Buying online and picking up in store saves shoppers 96 seconds vs. in-store shopping, raising questions about the value of the service. Of 11 retailers [BLANK], the fastest time was at Office Depot (2 minutes vs. a 5.4-minute average) and the longest was at Home Depot and Macy's, where buying in the store is faster, according to a study by StellaService. Buy online and pickup is key for retailers developing omnichannel efficacy as it leverages inventory and items are received faster vs. shipping.

Zimmer Biomet has a short window to improve its knee implant sales given Stryker expects to release its Triathlon knee for its robotic platform in 2017. After gaining ground in 2013 with its Persona knee, Zimmer's $14 billion purchase of Biomet [BLANK] a distraction, helping Stryker and Johnson & Johnson gain market share. Zimmer may rebound in 2016 as its sales force builds relationships. Stryker may be set up for strong implant sales in 2017 given robot sales doubled in 2015 and continue to grow.

In spinning off its hemophilia business, Biogen is creating a small but cash-flow-positive biotech, with a better-exposed revenue growth trajectory. While Alprolix and Eloctate have [BLANK] profiles, hemophilia is a difficult market, given brand loyalty and patient "stickiness" to legacy products. The spinoff's midterm pipeline may face similar challenges. While growth may be steadily incremental, it may not be dominating the hemophilia market anytime soon.

Japan's aging population, shrinking families and rising numbers of single-person households will likely restrain long-term growth prospects for supermarkets, even as May comparable sales rose. Shoppers buying in smaller amounts are [BLANK] to convenience stores. Nomura's 99% director retirement bonus approval and 91% election approval may illustrate the challenge in achieving more vigorous stewardship until Japanese companies unwind their holdings in other companies. Nomura, Mizuho and Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group have among the highest levels of director approval rates at their asset management divisions, as well as [BLANK] cross holdings by market value. Mizuho and SMFG are among banks pledging to cut holdings following Japan governance reform pressure.

John Cornyn, who may become the second-ranking Republican in the Senate, has said prison reform will pass a Republican Congress. Rand Paul said that prison reform would likely be [BLANK] into law in 2015. A new lobbying group was recently formed, the Center for Prison Reform for Nonviolent Offenders, to help sway conservative Republicans, with progressives and moderates already in support of changes. Prison companies such as Corrections Corp. and Geo Group face risks reform will pass.

Margin pressure in two of Santander's three biggest profit contributing countries, Brazil and Spain, means the bank may increasingly rely on loan growth to drive revenue expansion. In Brazil, Santander [BLANK] a 30-bp sequential drop in 1Q net interest margin while in Spain loan margins fell 16 bps, more than offsetting a 7-bp drop in deposit costs, suggesting a tough pricing climate. This may spur more initiatives to boost loan growth with the bank noting a 28% jump in Spanish SME loans under its Advance plan.

Delta, Southwest and JetBlue yields rose 2% to 3% in November as Thanksgiving increased demand, while a split with December 2013 gave an easy comparison. Though yield improvement was strong, especially as margins improved 480 bps before hedging as fuel prices fell 16% in the month, domestic market prices are finely [BLANK] between supply and demand as fast risers such as JetBlue, which added 7.6% more capacity, had the lowest yield growth.

Luxury brands are investing more in protecting their intellectual property and customers against the burgeoning counterfeit industry. Luxury companies, such as Burberry, Kering and LVMH, work closely with their Internet partners, search engines and government bodies to prevent it. Both Tmall and Ebay remove unauthorized distributors of luxury goods on their portal, while Google removes advertisements for fake goods.

Creditors supported Hunt's bid for Energy Future Holdings' Oncor utility in part because they thought they could benefit from tax savings associated with a plan transferring the assets into a REIT structure. Hunt launched the first utility REIT in the country with InfraREIT, which [BLANK] certain assets of Sharyland Utilities. CenterPoint, the second-largest electric utility in Texas after Oncor, may be less likely to pursue a REIT structure now that Hunt has withdrawn its proposal.

The U.S. wireless market is likely to be very competitive in 2017, due to heavy price competition among the leading carriers and due to the likely entry of cable operators into the wireless business in 2017. Wireless industry trends in Canada should get better in the year on economic improvements [BLANK] from a rebound in oil prices and a diminishing impact from regulatory changes in wireless contracts. The launch of new wireless video apps by the leading carriers is an emerging theme in both regions.

Several government entities, including the Department of Veterans Affairs, are permitted to negotiate drug contracts based on federal ceiling prices. Studies suggest that the VA pays up to 40% less for drugs than Medicare Part D [BLANK] for the same medicines. Many Democrats want Medicare to adopt a VA-type model. The pharmaceutical industry's response is that the VA's restrictive formulary covers fewer innovative, newer medicines, leading many VA beneficiaries to seek additional coverage for drugs.

The Trump administration has proposed stringent new vehicle-content rules in North American Free Trade Agreement negotiations that could boost costs and create supply-chain disruption for automakers, particularly SUVs. An 85% content rule could [BLANK] tariffs to 25% on trucks and SUVs made by Ford, GM, Toyota and others.

An operator's decision whether to complete an oil well involves balancing three key factors: the steepness of the futures curve, the outlook for servicing costs and its own cash needs. The futures curve for oil is in contango, [BLANK] an expectation that prices will rise. Commentary from oil-service providers points to a potential 15% to 30% decline in completion costs by year-end. Expectations about such costs and future oil prices dictate whether drilled wells are completed or not.

While a bill to create a new duty suspension process advanced quickly through the House, expedited passage in the Senate could be problematic. The House [BLANK] the bill on April 27, two weeks after its introduction. The next step in the process is a vote by the Senate. The bill's backers want to reach a unanimous consent agreement on the bill, which typically limits amendments. Two lobbying groups have expressed concerns about the bill, which could lead to some senators rejecting an agreement.

Surveys from the Council of Insurance Agents and Brokers present a graphic display of the progression of the price cycle, which may lead to average declines and lower margins in 2015. In 3Q, 29% of brokers [BLANK] 1% to 10% price decreases for commercial property coverage. Only 22% of brokers reported this level of decline in 1Q. Just 24% of brokers reported price increases from 1% to 10% in 3Q, down from 41% of brokers responding in 1Q.

Humana expects to scale back its public exchange exposure in 2017 by as much as 75%, but still would have up to $1 billion of premium revenue in 11 states. The company has booked reserve charges [BLANK] $450 million related to 2016, or 11% of EPS. Humana can significantly cut its exchange losses by exiting costly states such as Florida and Georgia, but it may remain unprofitable in 2017, given premiums may rise in the teens. UnitedHealth is staying in just three states in 2017.

LendingClub has no pure publicly-traded comparable. Its closest peer is OnDeck Capital, but it focuses on making and [BLANK] small-business loans. GreenSky, another potential comparable, just went public but its low marketing expense causes its margins and stock valuation to be much greater. LendingClub trades at 11.4x consensus forward EV/Ebitda, vs. 16.7x for BI's global e-commerce-platform peer group, which includes EBay (11.4x), Alibaba (22.3) and Amazon.com (24.6x). GreenSky trades at 25x, based on our scenario for 2018 Ebitda. LendingClub's forecasts don't include costs that may arise from various lawsuits resulting from the conduct of previous senior managers. Settlements resulting from regulatory inquiries could also weigh on earnings. Resolution of these matters could remove an overhang to valuation.

Morgan Stanley's 6.2% fully phased supplementary leverage ratio is above the 2018 required 5% minimum. Its CET1 ratio of 15.8% well exceeds its 2019 hurdle -- currently 10% -- based on the Federal Reserve using its [BLANK] surcharge methodology. Morgan Stanley topped the fully phased-in 100% liquidity ratio requirement at year-end 2015, and may already be compliant with U.S. total loss absorbing capacity and minimum debt requirements, along with Goldman Sachs, with full implementation due by 2022.

Sears Holdings is the most-shorted U.S. department-store chain, at over 50% of its float. That's likely due to pessimism about restructuring efforts and the company's ability to [BLANK] lost market share. Covering the short would take about 13 days, based on trading volume. Bon-Ton also has high short interest, at more than 37%, amid concern about its rising debt levels and lower sales. Hudson's Bay has the lowest short interest as a percentage of float at 2%.

Revenue-adjusted comparable sales at the seven retailers that report monthly sales may rise 0.7% in August, aided by back-to-school shopping and easier comparisons from a year earlier, based on estimates compiled by Retail Metrics. Only three retailers are expected to [BLANK] higher sales amid the year's second-biggest selling season. L Brands may be buoyed by a gain at Bath & Body Works. Costco, which last year saw plunging gas prices hurt sales, could post a sales increase of 1.3%.

The MBA mortgage applications index rose 0.8% for the week ended Jan. 13 as refinancings improved 6.8%, though purchases weakened 5.2%. The 30-year effective mortgage rate [BLANK] 6 bps to 4.38%, the third consecutive decline after rising for nine weeks. Measured year-over-year, total mortgage applications were down 12% as refinancings dropped 23%. This reflects the 67-bp rise in mortgage rates since the end of 3Q and strong refinancing activity in 2016. Purchases rose 0.9% vs. a year ago.

China's surging labor costs amid a quickly aging population, and falling prices of robots, will propel demand for factory automation in the coming decade. Stricter access to government subsidies may slow down the number of new entrants, helping domestic industrial-robot makers to [BLANK] the gap with their global peers.

The number of U.S. natural-gas rigs in operation rose by eight to 225, rebounding from the prior week's lowest level since weekly rig counts began in 1987. The oil rig count fell by 31 to 703 in the week [BLANK] April 24, according to Baker Hughes. Oil rigs have plunged by 56%, or 906 rigs, since peaking in mid-October and are at their lowest level since December 2010. In the next several weeks, oil rig declines may moderate, given that oil prices appear to be slowly recovering.

Records, near-records or recent alleviation of extreme levels or positions may point to a continued short squeeze in bonds, similar risk for grains, gold continuing to outperform copper and greater chances of a halt in rate hikes. The historic short in bond futures has been mostly [BLANK] as covering has supported prices. Still-elevated copper vs. gold positions indicate this ratio and interest rates may decline further. Gold and U.S. dollar reversion could be in early recovery days.

McDonald's (MCD +5.8%) delivery, fresh beef quarter pounders, $1 $2 $3 Menu and Experience of the Future store upgrades will, we believe, fuel continued strong market-share gains in 2018. It outperformed the rest of the QSR Sandwich category by 270 bps in 1Q, which [BLANK] poorly for results at smaller burger chains including Jack in the Box (JACK -2.2%) and Sonic (SONC -2.2%) during the period. The value menu, which debuted in January, was a big contributor to higher guest checks in the U.S., and comparable-store sales strength was widespread, but particularly in China, Germany, France, Italy and the U.K.

Reynolds American pending $27.4 billion acquisition of Lorillard, which was formally approved by shareholders Jan. 28, is being scrutinized closely by the FTC. If the deal is [BLANK] as originally proposed, the U.S. cigarette market share of No. 1 Altria and a combined Reynolds-Lorillard would rise to about 81% from 71%. The acquisition would mark the tobacco industry's second-largest deal in the past decade.

Exxon was granted an exception from the general moratorium on hydraulic fracturing to produce natural gas from shale in the German province of North Rhine-Westphalia, regional newspaper Rheinische Post reports. The ruling was made to [BLANK] Exxon's previously granted rights. Should Exxon manage to produce shale gas from the license economically within the three-year period, the company may request a further extension.

Australia's four biggest banks will see a further increase in overall funding costs, which will erase loan-yield gains. Costs are [BLANK] on offshore wholesale funding, mostly due to higher U.S. rates. Onshore funding costs also remain steep, as reflected by a pricing of 100-111 bps over the nation's swap rate for their recent five-year bond issuance. Deposit costs may also climb amid competition. A funding cost lift could well offset the positive impact from higher mortgage rates at these lenders this year.

The risks that Nomura and RBS units face at trial in a lawsuit by Fannie and Freddie conservator FHFA may be more reputational than monetary. Monetarily, the banks could [BLANK] about a billion dollars, yet would get the securities at issue, which Fitch values at about $400 million as of March 23. The reputational risk of losing is being held liable for federal securities violations in connection with the financial crisis, compared with banks that settled FHFA suits for more money yet no admission of liability.

Retailers' margins may remain under pressure from rising shipping costs as online sales grow and become a larger portion of total sales. Most shoppers have added items to their cart to qualify for free shipping and almost all customers have abandoned a cart online, sometimes after [BLANK] shipping prices, according to a 2013 ComScore survey. The use of stores as a distribution center and for returns can help reduce shipping costs and drive share gains.

Microsoft has been aggressive in expanding its current ecosystem with deep discounts on operating system license fees for selective products. In April 2014, Microsoft [BLANK] free operating systems for devices with screen sizes of less than nine inches to drive growth in Windows-based smartphones and tablets, where Microsoft is a distant third to Google's Android and Apple's iOS. Microsoft has also adjusted the prices for lower-end PC's (under $250) and the education market to boost market share.

Shire is expected to see the best year-over-year growth in sales in 2Q among specialty pharma-generic peers on the addition of acquired products such as Kalbitor from Dyax and Baxalta's hemophilia drugs. Allergan [BLANK] at the opposite end of the spectrum due to the divestiture of its Actavis generics unit to Teva. Growth of Allergan's branded specialty products will be a focus. Endo is expected to post sales growth due to the addition of Par, which closed in 3Q, but faces headwinds in future quarters.

An exchange-traded fund that holds zero-coupon U.S. Treasuries is the unlikely performance leader in 2016. The Pimco 25+ Year Zero Coupon US Index Exchange-Traded Fund (ZROZ) has [BLANK] 8.8%. Its Treasury bonds have the coupon stripped out, giving them extremely long durations of 26 years and making them highly sensitive to interest-rate moves. Consensus had expected rates to rise, which would have dragged down the ETF's price, but they fell instead. The fund charges 0.15% and has $180 million in assets.

About 29% of new U.S. solar and 2% of wind capacity that came online in 2015 was added to take advantage of utilities' clean-energy requirements under PURPA, according to the latest government data. The law requires some regulated utilities to [BLANK] electricity from independent power producers' small renewables plants, and has become increasingly important as a driver for solar in the Southeast and elsewhere. PURPA was passed in 1978 to nudge utilities to diversify their electricity sources.

Hard-drive makers may be operating in an inelastic price market for the next one to two years, according to research firm Gartner. Even with storage costs declining, PC makers are not actively [BLANK] drive capacity higher, likely because it affects component prices and margins. Consumers are also cost-conscious and recognize that high-network speeds and permanent access makes high-capacity, inexpensive or free cloud storage appealing. Dell suggests faster speeds may push users to switch to solid-state drives.

A group of mortgage-bond investors that includes BlackRock and Prudential Financial has filed 6 suits against Wells Fargo and other mortgage-bond trustees. In the suit against Wells Fargo, investors allege $32.2 billion in trust losses and billions in damages related to 273 trusts [BLANK] at more than $250 billion at the time of securitization. Wells Fargo is being targeted in its bond trustee capacity in similar suits by other investors alleging more than $4 billion in losses.

Lithium-ion battery producers, such as A123 and Samsung SDI, may encounter new competition from Apple amid speculation the company is seeking to develop a battery division. A123 filed a lawsuit against Apple on Feb. 6, which alleges that Apple may be [BLANK] a large-scale battery division in the same field as A123, following the departure of five key employees to the technology company. A123 batteries are used in a range of applications, including electric vehicles and large scale grid batteries.

There may be a point of differentiation among the CD19 CAR-Ts, and it might not be in Celgene's favor. New data on duration of response [BLANK] at ASCO showed that more than half the patients with a partial response three months after JCAR17 lost the effect. About 80% of patients with a complete response at three months seemed to maintain this for at least a year. This differs from Yescarta's data, where 80% of three-month responders were durable. Why JCAR17's PRs aren't durable is unclear, but while it's tempting to attribute it to a difference in co-stimulatory domains of the CAR-T, it may also be that the JCAR17 Transcend study wasn't optimally dosed. Still, survival data, including the one-month landmark rate of more than 60%, is impressive given how heavily pre-treated patients were.

The European industrial-equipment manufacturing industry is mature, with high restructuring and mergers & acquisitions activity that can distort order and sales comparisons. Currency swings against the euro and the krona can [BLANK] the sales of many of these companies. Organic metrics strip out the effects of currency, restructuring and asset acquisitions and disposals, and better illustrate demand. Also, organic growth tends to correlate with the business cycle, a major demand driver for cyclical industrials.

Benchmark trades at 14.8x consensus P/E, the highest in BI's North American electronics assembler peer group. The company may [BLANK] lower telecom-equipment sales with growth in medical and industrial devices, based on the consensus estimate for little change in EPS this year. Celestica trades at 12.9x. It has risen 9.1% since March, aided by a buyback announcement. Apple supplier Jabil is at 11.5x. Consensus expects core EPS to jump 282% in the year ending August. The average peer group valuation is 12.4x.

Pfizer and Novartis' Sandoz lead development for biosimilar versions of Roche's Rituxan in cancer, with Phase III trials expected to complete in 4Q17, based on clinicaltrials.gov. While Pfizer's lymphoma study may end slightly earlier, Sandoz [BLANK] 1.5x more patients. Both use European-sourced comparators suggesting the data is eligible to support EU approval, though bridging trials may be needed to win the FDA's backing. Celltrion has a smaller ongoing Phase III trial for its candidate CT-P10.

Cheaper gas supply from the Marcellus and Utica shale plays is expected to reach New England as early as 2016 through Connecticut Expansion and Algonquin Incremental Market pipelines. Access Northeast pipeline, planned to be in service in 2018, will mostly [BLANK] gas to power generators with firm capacity agreements held by electric utilities, as opposed to contracts with local gas distribution companies. The pipeline may save electric customers about $1 billion annually, according to an ICF International report.

China thirst for clean, green energy and associated technologies, particularly in the battery segment and from the electrical-vehicle industry, will likely drive demand for cobalt to new highs. The country is the world's largest consumer of cobalt, and leads [BLANK] production. Refined-cobalt output continues to increase, as the government seeks to raise cobalt reserves. Raised U.S. defense spending under President Donald Trump may also boost consumption in superalloys for military needs.

As cash flow uses from the dieselgate scandal lessen, bondholder attention can return to underlying performance, which is solid and should remain stable in 2018. China ramped up its gold supply with mine production mainly from regions such as Shandong, Henan, Jiangxi, Inner Mongolia, Yunnan, Hunan, Gansu, Fujian, Hubei and Xinjiang. The intensity of production at these provinces, falling grades and [BLANK] mines, together with reduced capital spending as a result of the collapse in gold prices five years ago, may weigh on China's supply growth. Still, the country's gold resources are also possibly under-explored, given its vast land mass.

Fox's videogame adaptation, "Assassin's Creed" may gross $20 million over the Christmas holiday (Dec. 23-25) after opening Dec. 21. The movie will [BLANK] stiff competition from a slew of new releases including Universal's "Sing," which may take in $34 million, and Sony's "Passengers" at $30 million. Disney's "Rogue One" should lead after an explosive $155 million opening last weekend. A 40% decline in its second week (similar to "Force Awakens") may give Rogue One over $90 million this weekend.

The Croatian government's implied valuation of HEP appears to be above the peer-group average. An IPO of the government's 25% stake sale in HEP is [BLANK] to fund the purchase of a 49% stake in national oil company INA from Hungary's MOL worth 14.7 billion kuna ($2 billion). This implies the government values HEP at about $8 billion, exceeding the current market capitalization of western European utilities with much larger grid and generation assets and capital investment spending, such as RWE, Verbund and Uniper.

Proposed antitrust class-action lawsuits accusing American, Delta, Southwest and United of conspiring to fix passenger capacity and artificially raise prices are unlikely to settle in the near term. Globally, exchanges trade at an average 2015 PE of 16.9x, more than 50% higher than Moscow Exchange's multiple as the Russian-Ukraine crisis hurts sentiment. Expectations for Russia's 2015 GDP growth have more than halved to 1.5% during the past 12 months, [BLANK] earnings expectations for constituent companies. Canada's largest telecommunications company BCE agreed to buy the remaining 44% of Bell Aliant for $3.68 billion, one of the largest M&A deals in the week. Health insurers, already facing uncertainty from Republicans' on-again, off-again attempts to repeal Obamacare, are pressing Congress to fund the law's cost-sharing reduction (CSR) program that is set to provide them with $135 billion over 10 years to cover deductibles and copayments paid by lower-income individuals. A federal judge has sided with House Republicans, who [BLANK] during the Obama administration that the payments were unconstitutional since Congress hadn't appropriated funds for them.

Rising prevalence and unmet medical needs drive multiple sclerosis drug development. Biogen is planning a Phase IIb trial to [BLANK] in 4Q for opicinumab for remyelination in a subset of patients. Novartis is seeking FDA and EMA input in 1Q on the potential to file siponimod for secondary progressive MS, based on the first Phase III trial. Momenta-Novartis have planned to launch a generic version of Teva's 40-mg Copaxone in 1Q pending FDA approval. Teva is appealing a recent District Court ruling on Copaxone patents.

Markdowns and promotions, mostly in the perennially weak apparel category, led to a 0.6% drop in average ticket growth in June, according to SpendTrend. Hardlines categories, including home furnishings and home improvement, [BLANK] significantly as consumers invested in their core appreciating asset and aim to offset volatility in investment portfolios. Home furnishings rose 1.4% while building materials and garden stores jumped 6.7% on more favorable weather, suggesting 2Q strength at Home Depot and Lowe's.

A group of mortgage-bond investors, including BlackRock, filed several lawsuits in 2014 against bond trustees, the second-largest being a suit against Deutsche Bank units. Plaintiffs are expected to refile dismissed claims in state court. Deutsche Bank is named in similar suits alleging more than $20 billion in losses.

Supply-side fundamentals in the North American containerboard market have improved in the past decade, fueling rising profitability. Operating rates for containerboard in 2018 are [BLANK] to be a tight 98%, despite two new capacity-expansion projects. This is driven by an increase in industrial output and e-commerce.

Cold-weather apparel and accessories makers may report higher revenue for 3Q, after the category's U.S. sales accelerated throughout the quarter. Sales of coats and other winter-related items climbed 15%, with September [BLANK] 14% on top of 21% growth a year earlier, according to NPD's Group's retail-tracking data. G-III, Columbia Sportswear and VF (owner of The North Face) are some of the largest suppliers of outerwear to the U.S. market.

A trial that began Sept. 14 over whether PFOA caused a plaintiff's kidney cancer is the first of about 3,700 personal-injury and wrongful-death claims against DuPont. Chemours, the Dupont spinoff [BLANK] the PFOA (perfluorooctanoic acid) business unit, isn't a liable party in the trial, though it would have to pay any judgments. Chemours indemnified DuPont for any payments that DuPont is obligated to make arising out of the trials. Two cases are scheduled for trial in 2015 and four others will be set in 2016.

Bearish technicals for the iShares J.P. Morgan EM Bond ETF (EMB) suggest the pain isn't over for EM dollar creditors as both open and short interest remain elevated. The gamma-theta tradeoff is a driver of EMB option positioning, and capitulation by market makers could [BLANK] a shift in sentiment.

Sky's potential EU expansion, with over-the-top streaming, boosts the rationale behind higher investment into original programming due to a larger scale for spreading costs and possible network effects. The company is [BLANK] up its owned content following consolidation of the German and Italian units. A rising mix of owned popular content could offset pressure from growing cost inflation, mostly in premium sports. Netflix said owned content is some of its most efficient, costing less relative to viewing metrics.

European airlines are facing strong competition and fading currency gains. Intra-European yields have [BLANK] vs. low-cost and full-service airlines, while market share fights for traffic in Asia, the Middle East and Africa have hurt long-haul yields. The battle for Americas routes is less intense, though more competitors and lower demand from the weaker euro may also crimp yields. Gains from lower fuel prices and sales in foreign currencies may diminish as comparisons get more difficult.

Southern fell about 6% after Ford cancelled a $1.6 billion investment in a new factory in San Luis Potosi, Mexico, a site where the rail serves a GM facility and future site for BMW. Ford Focus and C-Max production is still [BLANK] to be moved from Wayne, Michigan to an existing Mexico plant to make room for increased light truck production. Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac shareholders aren't likely to regain control from the federal government until well after the 2018 midterm elections, despite agreement between President Donald Trump and FHFA Director Mel Watt that the conservatorship must end. A Democrat wave would [BLANK] Trump's ability to recapitalize and privatize the companies, as suggested by Moelis. Significant changes to Fannie and Freddie will eventually face macroeconomic headwinds if recession becomes more likely in 2020 and beyond.

Venture-capital companies may soon face fewer obstacles to raising funds, and asset managers likely will have a wider choice of investable assets if EU plans to promote non-bank financing come to fruition. A number of proposals may widen the eligible investor base: extending the EuVECA passport to larger managers; reducing the investment threshold for retail investors; and [BLANK] funds of funds that may attract institutional investors with greater access to capital and a higher risk appetite.

China's steel market may be oversupplied with iron ore if production continues at its current pace. China iron ore output rose 8.1% in the nine months through September from a year earlier, and [BLANK] a record high of 139.3 million metric tons in June. Prices declined 12.2% as an additional 17 million tons were delivered in 3Q vs. 2Q, and strong domestic iron ore output may pressure prices further. CISA predicts 810 million tons of steel production in 2014, up 3.1% from 2013.

Shoe retailers' sales declined through August 14, as an increase in the average amount spent per transaction failed to offset weakening traffic. Same-store sales fell by 1.4% during the first two weeks of the month [BLANK] with the same period last year, according to SpendTrend's non-cash point-of-sale data. The average amount spent per transaction has increased for seven consecutive months, signaling margins may improve at U.S.- based footwear retailers.

Goldman Sachs said its most significant gauge of future M&A, the level of client CEO and board dialogue, appears "quite good." Morgan Stanley said board engagement and dialogue remain high, with a strong issuance pipeline building; it expects 3Q deferred business will [BLANK] 4Q and early 2016. Bank of America said its pipeline looks quite strong, also attributing some of the increase to deferrals, especially equity deals.
