Proposed antitrust class-action lawsuits accusing American, Delta, Southwest and United of conspiring to fix passenger capacity and artificially raise prices are unlikely to settle in the near term. Though the airlines' motions to dismiss were [BLANK] in October and the intrusive discovery phase will soon begin, they may want another shot at a dismissal request before settling. Plaintiffs also may prefer to wait out discovery in hope of finding incriminating documents that strengthen their conspiracy claims.

Singapore retail sales will remain lethargic over the next 2-3 months, in our opinion, as moderating consumer credit and a sluggish housing market following July's cooling measures constrain discretionary spending. Retail sales excluding motor vehicles rose just 0.5% from a year earlier in October, the second straight month of [BLANK] growth. Revenue at department stores such as Robinsons, Isetan Mitsukoshi, Takashimaya and Tangs likely slumped in October, as department stores sales declined 3.6%, vs. unchanged the previous month. Turnover at grocers such as Dairy Farm's Cold Storage, NTUC Fairprice and Sheng Siong, which are facing greater competition from dedicated online supermarkets, slid 2.9%, for a seventh straight monthly decline. Government efforts to boost wages could provide a retail sales lift in 2019.

Supported by cost cuts and a shift to higher-yielding investments, Axa Equitable is well-positioned to achieve its target of 5-7% average annual growth in operating earnings in 2017-20. In addition, profitability should remain strong in its group retirement unit focused on K-12 educators, while AllianceBernstein -- an asset manager in which the company has a 65% stake -- is [BLANK] reasonably well. Still, the company's high exposure to the variable-annuity market, which has been under pressure in recent years, may result in persistently high asset outflows. Axa Equitable's IPO was in May.

Capital filed for bankruptcy on Jan. 31 with plan support from secured lenders and Luxor Capital Group, a large shareholder and unsecured creditor. RCS [BLANK] to reorganize around its independent retail advice unit and reduce debt and preferred stock by $500 million. The plan would also dissolve units that did business with former chairman Nicholas Schorsch's American Realty Capital Properties, which disclosed accounting errors in October 2014. RCS will be seeking confirmation of its plan in May.

Weak Urban Outfitters brand sales may signal a sales shortfall and sluggish teen apparel spending at peers including Abercrombie & Fitch, American Eagle and Aeropostale, when they report 2Q EPS. Urban Outfitters [BLANK] 2Q sales gains across all business segments except for its namesake brand, which had a 10% same-store sales drop, the fourth straight decline. Comparable sales rose 21% at Free People, 6% at Anthropologie and 36% in the wholesale segment.

Support from third-party game developers could help broaden Nintendo Switch's addressable market and spur a virtuous cycle of game and console sales. Switch sales have topped 17 million since the March 2017 launch, suggesting the console can capture third-party support that its predecessor, the Wii U, [BLANK].

Bristol-Myers topped peers with its 23% sales contribution in 1Q from drugs approved in 2009 or later, led by its hep-C franchise and heart drug Eliquis. This portion could rise to 62% by 2020, based on consensus, as the cancer drug Opdivo [BLANK] its peak-sales potential. Novo Nordisk ranked second, getting 17% of revenue from new drugs. The figure may expand to 20% in 2020 with the rollouts of Tresiba in diabetes and Saxenda in obesity. New drugs for Pfizer, Merck and Eli Lilly drove less than 5% of 1Q sales.

Chiquita's rejection of the $14-a-share all-cash bid from the Cutrale Group and the Safra Group is based primarily on Chiquita's determination that its shares are worth $15.46 to $20. Chiquita's analysis includes $30 million in synergies one year after its planned purchase of rival Fyffes is completed and [BLANK] its shares trade at least a 7x trailing 12-month Ebitda multiple. Chiquita shares have had an average 8.8x EV/Ebitda multiple since 2003.

In response to comments from then-Federal Reserve Chairman Ben Bernanke, 10-year Treasury yields climbed 110 bps in 2013 from May 22 to year-end. The dramatic move is a stark reminder of the multiple forces [BLANK] Treasury yields, including economic growth, Federal Reserve policy, and inflation expectations. Anticipated changes in these factors likely drove the 37-bp jump in 10-year rates in the week after the election of Donald Trump as president, though the sustainability of this shift is unclear.

MLPs are the predominate ownership structure in the midstream space, which includes gathering, processing, storage and transportation of oil and gas. Midstream MLPs make up critically essential, scarce and long-lived assets typically [BLANK] by inflation-indexed, long-term contracts offering a visible income stream. MLPS will continue to recalibrate capital spending for projects in 2016 due to weak commodity prices. Longer-term growth opportunities exist, driven by the need for building infrastructure.

Wet Seal plans to close 338 stores as operating losses mount, leaving the teen retailer with 173 stores and its online operations as it attempts to revive sales. The closings come after the company warned in December that it may have to file for bankruptcy if it can't [BLANK] its liquidity needs, and may yet be pressured into Chapter 11 should landlords decide to recoup lost lease income from the closings. Holders of the company's $21.3 million in convertible debt filed a notice of default on Dec. 27.

Swiss-franc denominated mortgages in Poland totaled $39 billion in November, down 20% from the peak three years prior. This [BLANK] 37% of all housing loans and 15% of the industry's total portfolio. About 40% of these loans have a loan-to-value ratio of more than 100%. This leaves banks susceptible to sharp changes in real estate prices and currency fluctuations. Nonperforming Swiss franc mortgages represented 3.1% of total non-zloty loans, compared with a 3.6% ratio for zloty-denominated home loans.

Sport-utility vehicles may climb to 30% of Chinese auto sales in 2020 from about 20%, according to LMC Automotive, spurred by rising wages, more model choices, and a desire for larger vehicles. Bulls [BLANK] the shift may boost automakers' sales and margins, as SUVs tend have higher prices and wider margins than regular sedans. Domestic automakers are particularly focusing on compact SUVs, which are more affordable than traditional larger models.

Large order backlogs and strong airline-traffic growth is driving aerospace returns above the S&P 500. Future production-rate increases at Boeing and Airbus are driving earnings growth, though problems with United Technologies' Geared Turbofan engine could [BLANK] Airbus gains. Above-trend airline-traffic growth helps the high-margin spare-parts business at engine and parts makers, boosting investor sentiment.

Gross margins for coatings manufacturers may contract next year, down from record highs in 2016, as input costs rise. Raw materials make up 65-80% of coatings' cost of goods [BLANK], with 25-35% of that from oil. Prices of propylene, an oil-based feedstock for a range of coatings inputs, could rise by more than 40% on average in 2017, Nexant estimates. Tighter titanium oxide (TiO2) markets, 25-30% of paint raw-material costs, helped producers push through a series of price hikes this year and more may come in 2017.

Mylan is on track to submit an application to the FDA for a generic form of GlaxoSmithKline's Advair by year-end, which may allow it to launch the first generic in the U.S. Mylan will have three pharmacokinetic bioequivalence studies supporting its application and data showing its device can also be used in Advair Diskus patients. GlaxoSmithKline reported a 19% drop in Advair sales thus far in 2015 as it [BLANK] patients to Breo and Anoro and absorbs price reductions. Glaxo doesn't expect a generic until 2017.

Twitter's momentum in daily active users is likely to have extended into 4Q, with a deeper push into live video and a simplified product. Expectations for a 4% revenue drop may be easy to [BLANK], given the company grew 1% a year earlier. Cost cuts should yield margin expansion and healthy guidance for 1Q. Investor focus will be on signs of Twitter's ability to convert user momentum into sales for 2018.

Millennium's net fees and commissions fell 7.5% to $44 million in 3Q, driven by lower interchange fees which more than halved to 0.5% as of July 1. This is likely to [BLANK] further, to as much as 0.2% for debit cards and 0.3% for credit cards, next year, Millennium said in its 3Q earnings call. The lower fees, combined with the growing prospects of further monetary easing, may add to pressure on bank revenue. Fee and commission income represents 30% of industry revenue.

Most third-party delivery aggregators, including GrubHub, Postmates, DoorDash, Amazon Prime Now, UberEats and Caviar, charge restaurants a commission of 12-30% of the order amount, and consumers a service or delivery charge. The business model relies on having enough customers and restaurants motivated to use the platform and a sufficient number of drivers available at peak periods to [BLANK] wait times to a minimum. Profitability could be pressured as labor costs rise, resulting in consolidation.

Mobile infrastructure vendors may encounter some revenue pressure as Chinese wireless carriers pull back on the deployment of 4G base stations amid slowing network expansion. China Mobile, Unicom and Telecom expect to [BLANK] a combined 420,000 4G base stations in 2H16, down from 1.1 million in 2H15, according to company guidance. The decline in base station additions is the most likely reason for a 6.3% decline in 2016 4G capex to 151.6 billion yuan ($22.8 billion) among these carriers.

About half of Accor's rooms are in Europe, making it more susceptible than global peers to the region's economy. Terror attacks in France and Belgium continue to weigh on hotel demand, [BLANK] a recovery, while Brexit has bred travel-demand uncertainty, which will likely dent earnings through 2017. Accor will probably offset the decline to some degree by expanding its base of franchised and managed hotels in stronger European markets and the Asia-Pacific and Americas regions, especially after its FRHI integration.

Gaming companies may undergo board turnover and governance scrutiny in the wake of Wynn's CEO and board-member departures. Caesars, Boyd and Las Vegas Sands have boards [BLANK] longer-serving, older male directors. Their homogeneity may be a target if other instances of executive misconduct occur in the industry.

Aging demographics in the U.S. should drive demand for health-care services such as nursing care as population growth in the 82-86 age demographic accelerates. The rate is forecast to rise almost every year in the next decade and [BLANK] 7% in 2025. Demand for Alzheimer's and dementia care is rising within the higher-need assisted living and skilled nursing segments. CMS forecasts spending on nursing care and continuing-care retirement communities will rise 17% to $198 billion in 2020 from $170 billion in 2017.

Challenges faced by Huaneng Power, CR Power and other Chinese generators in the past two years may linger in 2018. Consumption growth is unlikely to [BLANK]. It may grow at 6% or less in 2018-20. The decline in utilization rates has bottomed but is unlikely to fully recover until 2019 or 2020. This has particularly impacted the profitability of coal plants, made worse by high coal prices.

Australia miners are aiming to produce their way through falling iron ore prices, using low costs to raise output in hopes China demand rebounds and brings market share as rivals fold. The strategy, begun two years ago when China's iron ore use [BLANK], has endured with demand down in 2015 and likely in 2016. Australia may have shipped 780 million metric tons in 2015, about double 2011. Significantly more is planned in 2016. Rio Tinto, BHP Billiton, Fortescue and Roy Hill produce almost all of Australia's iron ore.

The shares of health-care supply chain companies have outperformed the S&P 500 Index so far in 2015. Demand for specialty prescriptions may [BLANK] sales for both drug distributors and pharmacy benefits managers. A strong selling season for CVS Health has pushed its P/E ratio relative to the S&P 500 well above the five-year average. Express Scripts is seeking to rebound from a disappointing season for new sales beginning in 2015, which may have caused valuations to fall much below the five-year mean.

The drop in distributions from MLP Enable Midstream is the driver of CenterPoint's outlook for a double-digit decline in 2015 earnings. CenterPoint's midstream segment [BLANK] about 40% to total earnings before the MLP spinoff. CenterPoint's long-term earnings growth forecast of 5-7% may be pressured by Enable's projections for long-term distribution growth of 3-7%, down from the MLP's expectations of 10-12% before oil prices plunged.

Consensus 2014 EPS estimates for major agricultural chemical producers have been falling through 3Q. Lower crop prices have raised concern on farm spending, while a slow U.S. harvest may [BLANK] available time for autumn fertilizer applications. Bears suggest risks to product pricing for seeds and crop chemicals. Fertilizer producers may be more exposed to lower volumes, particularly of phosphate and potash, for which farmers have skipped application in past years.

One growth area for HP Enterprise is in hybrid clouds that combine public, private and hosted clouds. HP says this market may grow to $72 billion in 2018, at a rate [BLANK] that of public clouds, driven by companies such as Google, Amazon and Microsoft. HP Enterprise would need substantial presence to drive sales away from legacy IT systems, which may produce 2.4% annual growth. The company does have the platform capable of addressing this market's end market growth potential yet execution questions may remain.

A little-known soybean ETF topped October commodity returns, climbing 5% on increased sales to China. For the year, the Teucrium Soybean Fund (SOYB) is up 12%, trailing the 47% gain for ETNs [BLANK] tin and sugar. SOYB uses three different months' futures to gain exposure. This mitigates the roll costs that hurt returns for commodity ETFs that track only the near month, but it also reduces sensitivity to moves in the spot price.

The final form of a measure to speed the Department of Energy's LNG export decisions will be determined as the House and Senate combine their energy bills in negotiations over the coming months. The Senate gives the DOE 45 days to [BLANK] applications for exports to nations without U.S. free-trade agreements, while the House offers just 30 days. For developers, the difference is minor, and the DOE has stated it could meet either deadline since it has taken an average of about three months to issue permits so far.

With Fannie Mae still under the FHA's leadership amid a housing finance reform debate, congressional pressure could sway its headquarters relocation decision. At a recent Senate Banking Committee hearing, Virginia Senator Mark Warner questioned Fannie Mae's plans to [BLANK] a 30-year lease for "very expensive real estate." Fannie Mae seeks to keep its employees in Washington, where office rents are about 50% higher than in Northern Virginia, according to Cushman & Wakefield data.

Annual information systems revenue has fallen each quarter since 4Q12 as the Pentagon cuts near-term contracts to manage budget constraints and effects of sequestration. These effects will [BLANK] into 2014 due to lower defense budgets, though margins have stabilized as companies cut expenses and scale down. Most exposed to the Pentagon segment are Exelis at 53% of total revenue, General Dynamics at 29% and Northrop Grumman and Raytheon with about 26%.

Cord cutting is expected to be a primary focus for pay-TV investors during the 3Q season. HBO and CBS are going "over the top" by [BLANK] direct-to-consumer subscriptions to their network programming. The mid-October announcements may represent the first steps of unbundling video content that has formed the backbone of the $194 billion U.S. pay-TV market. The move may spur traditional pay-TV customers to either cut their subscriptions or opt for smaller bundles.

Shire will lead the specialty-generic peer group in 2Q revenue growth, which will be driven mostly by the addition of Baxalta and growth of its rare-disease franchise. The Shire-Baxalta deal [BLANK] in 2Q, so growth for the remainder of the year will be lower, about 13%, based on company guidance. Perrigo lags behind peers in 2Q sales growth despite new launches as 9-11% price pressure remains a drag on revenue for the year. A delay in ProAir adds further pressure to Perrigo's growth.

An estimated 300% increase in the proportion of lighting sales generated on LED luminaires by 2020 will benefit the lighting semi-conductor businesses of Cree and Osram, according to the Boston Consulting Group. Acuity's chip-agnostic, software- and firmware-focused solutions should also [BLANK]. The proportion of total lighting-market sales generated on LED lamps rises to 7% in 2020 from 4% in 2014, implying higher margin pressure for the lamps businesses of lighting vendors such as Philips, Osram and Cree.

Vehicle frames, also referred to as body-in-white, are the fastest-growing application for aluminum auto sheets, as they are the heaviest components and offer the greatest opportunities to cut weight. More than 500,000 metric tons of capacity for body-in-white sheets is [BLANK] to come online by the end of 2018, according to data compiled by BI. Aluminum content per vehicle will rise 39% by 2025 to 547 pounds, according to Alcoa, because of greater use in car frames and panels.

Featured research today: Pfizer, Novartis and Eli Lilly are leading a revolution expected to drive up sales of branded breast-cancer drugs to an estimated $23 billion by 2021; Rising earnings prospects for the Stoxx 600 mask a schism developing between its two biggest components; Intesa and Mediobanca, [BLANK] by asset-management strength, are the best-positioned Italian banks going into the earnings season that begins July 28 with Banca Monte dei Paschi di Siena.

TiVo's district court case against Comcast is set to ramp up after being put on hold in October, with a trial possible before year-end. The April 2016 case was filed in TiVo's first wave of patent suits against Comcast, which [BLANK] TiVo a brief import ban on set-top-boxes with remote DVR access technologies and still threatens monetary damages.

Dollar stores' 2Q median gross margins are estimated by consensus to contract 38 bps yoy due to the highly promotional and competitive retail landscape. Gross margins are estimated by consensus to [BLANK] at all six dollar stores, including 41 bps at Family Dollar and 39 bps at Dollar General. Family Dollar noted in its 1Q call that sales shifted toward lower-margin consumables, while lower merchandise markups hurt gross margin.

Tesoro and Northern Tier lead U.S. refiners' total returns in 2014. Both companies [BLANK] mid-continent assets and have benefited from Bakken and Canadian crude discounts, which have assisted margins. Tesoro is successfully integrating the Carson, California, refinery, realizing greater synergies than originally forecast. Canadian and Bakken production may be the first to slow if oil prices stay low, potentially pressuring margins in 2015.

JPMorgan estimates it's cutting unit costs by 5% to 6% a year from 2012 through 2016 for credit card and call center checking account servicing. Technology is helping, as a mobile deposit [BLANK] only an estimated 5% of a teller deposit and ATM deposits only 12%. In 2010-14, digital log-ins grew 26% a year, as representative calls and teller transactions each fell 3% annually. Since 2011, JPMorgan cites $350 million in savings, 6% of its 2014 card expenses, by reducing direct mail and paper statements.

Oil companies generally have lower board independence levels, as governments and large investors often hold seats. Independent directors may better [BLANK] minority investors and challenge company strategies. A board's effectiveness may be weakened if it has fewer non-executive and independent directors, lacks an outside chairperson or has the company's former CEO on the board. Japanese and emerging-market companies often trail on such metrics, which may present added risks to overseas investors.

A software defect that delayed the opening of the Singapore Exchange securities market on Dec. 3 shows the importance of reliable infastructure at bourses. While Singapore Exchange was chided by the regulator for its second disruption in a month, the SEC introduced technology standards last month for exchanges such as NYSE and Nasdaq, as well as some dark pools, to [BLANK] for glitches and report disruptions. Singapore Exchange's lapse comes amid a 25% drop in the average daily value of stocks traded this year from 2013.

Coal production outside the major three U.S. basins may be challenged after output fell 20% in 1Q from a year earlier. BHP Billiton's mines posted substantial drops, [BLANK] 52% at San Juan and 32% at Navajo. Texas coal production fell 23%, or 2.81 million tons, as Westmoreland's Jewett mine slumped 36%. Arch Coal's West Elk mine in Colorado had an 8% drop.

Leaders from Bermuda reinsurers reviewed the industry outlook at the March AIFA conference, noting that margin and price pressure hasn't abated. Adding to the [BLANK] outlook, participants felt U.S. tax reform posed meaningful uncertainty. Under various border-tax adjustment proposals being discussed in Congress, premiums paid to foreign reinsurers may be deemed an importation of capital. Still, participants note that similar concepts, such as VAT levies in Europe, exclude financial services.

For a second straight quarter, fewer truck fleets are planning to add capacity, according to CKCVR's 2Q Fleet Sentiment Report. Buyers likely to add capacity with new trailers fell for a second quarter, [BLANK] to 42% from 61% in 1Q. Fleets adding capacity with new truck purchases were stable at 42%. Parked units rose to about 6%, the highest level since 1Q15, which may be a concern if the trend persists. Truck orders fell 43% from a year ago in the first quarter and cancellations are elevated.

Biotech and pharma events include EU regulatory actions on Merrimack-Shire's Onivyde in pancreatic cancer and Exelixis-Ipsen's Cabometyx in kidney cancer. Phase II data are [BLANK] from Acadia's Nuplazid in Alzheimer's disease psychosis and Arbutus' hepatitis B drug. Theravance-Mylan expect Phase III data of nebulized revefenacin in chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. Pain Therapeutics-Durect await FDA action on Remoxy, after the FDA decided a panel isn't needed.

GlaxoSmithKline's decision to end its sirukumab partnership with Johnson & Johnson was closely followed by FDA briefing materials highlighting the drug's imbalance on death. Even if sirukumab is approved with appropriate labeling, or if the signal is down to chance, it [BLANK] commercial appeal, having failed to show superiority to AbbVie's Humira, the standard of care in arthritis, limiting its use to hard-to-treat patients. J&J will need to compete on price to mitigate its less-appealing profile, assuming approval.

The need for the power generation industry to cut emissions may mean gas replaces coal as the cheapest alternative source, according to Total. The opportunity for pharmacies and drug distributors to capitalize on generic launches may accelerate in 2016, according to CVS. Compensation, notably at the board level, will continue to attract huge interest with increasing investor intervention. Shares in American Electric Power were among the most sold U.S. utilities by Norges Bank and Swedish pension fund AP2, even as stock returns topped its peer group in 2014. Scotiabank's 2018 loan-loss provisions may be C$2.3 billion, up 3% from a year ago, due to loan expansion and adoption of the IFRS-9 standard. Goldman and Citigroup are unlikely to stave off a U.S. Supreme Court review of claims on $550 million in auction-rate securities the banks underwrote. Plastic packagers have consistently used consolidation to expand and gain market share, especially in emerging markets. But in 2016, companies will be increasingly wary of [BLANK] multiples. While reporting $1.14 EPS for 3Q vs. consensus of $1.08 -- mostly due to hot weather -- Dominion cited its $500 million equity raise for its Dominion Midstream master limited partnership as an indicator of future acquisitions. China Mobile sales growth will slow in 2017 as 4G matures. A government-mandated tariff reduction and cancellation of domestic long distance and roaming charges will [BLANK] sales by 2-3%. The horizontal oil rig count, a key barometer for forward-looking oil output, dropped by six after falling by 13 last week. Consensus calls for large pharma EPS to increase at a compound annual 8.8% in 2014-17, vs. 8% after the 4Q13 earnings, when most companies gave first 2014 targets. Oil companies, agricultural producers and others are concerned that a proposed rule to limit speculation may damage their hedging activities. The legal fight against the Environmental Protection Agency's methane rule will likely be put on hold while the EPA considers how to comply with President Donald Trump's March 28 Executive Order. After excluding DynCorp International from the competition for a multibillion-dollar aviation services contract in January, the U.S. State Department has shifted course and is now considering proposals from both DynCorp and AAR, according to an Oct. 19 DynCorp court filing. Higher refinery throughput and lower imports curbed the increase in crude stockpiles to a 1.9-million-barrel gain, less than the consensus 2.65 million estimate in the week ended April 24. Private-equity managers aren't seeing the same extent of structural management-fee pressure experienced by traditional managers and hedge funds. Data show only small fee-margin compression, mostly [BLANK] investors' commitment-size concessions and product-mix changes.

Domestic natural gas storage stands at 2.9 trillion cubic feet, with less than two months remaining in the injection season, which is typically April 1 to Oct. 31. PSEG's earnings mix has shifted toward regulated utility operations due to strategic investment in that business and weakness in the unregulated power segment. State Street's quantitative measure of institutional-investor sentiment fell broadly again in August. The decision to finish drilled uncompleted wells, or DUCs, hinges on two variables: Future completion costs and oil prices. For operators seeking to realize higher prices in eight months, as suggested by the oil futures curve, well-completion costs would need to fall by at least another 10% (33% from peak) for the strategy to begin paying off.

Nestle's Jan. 16 agreement to sell its U.S. candy business to Ferrero for $2.8 billion coincides with slowing U.S. confectionery sales growth. Tiffany, Pandora and other luxury jewelry makers may boost their sales on specialized collections and marketing campaigns for Feb. 14. China's plan to accelerate its urbanization may create more residential demand for gas. Seven distribution cuts, and several implied cuts through M&A, will result in a 13% decline in per-unit distributions for a group of 25 midstream oil and gas MLPs that pay incentive distribution rights and aren't sponsored by an upstream or downstream company. Contractors with significant exposure to civilian agency spending could see reductions in orders should Republican presidential candidate John Kasich win the presidency and enact his budget plan. Entertainment M&A is heating up, with AT&T's proposed takeover of Time Warner for $85 billion and Fox's $14 billion deal to buy the 61% of Sky that it doesn't own, as lines between content and distribution blur. Cement makers in the U.S. are anticipating further price rises, even after July's cement-producer price index hit a record high of 246.7, slightly below May's all-time high of 249.30 that far exceeded 2009's prior peak of 211. The EU plans to regulate commodity benchmarks, which would impose strict rules on contributors. That may lead to less participation in the price-setting process, [BLANK] price transparency and valuation risk. EU regulators may limit the discretion exercised by price-reporting agencies for certain illiquid assets ("level 3") to reflect variables such as location, grade and quality. A terrorism financing lawsuit against Barclays, Credit Suisse and other banks filed Nov. 10 highlights a growing trend in civil and criminal litigation over sanctions violations. Banks and fund managers would likely find post-Brexit reliance on third-country regulatory "equivalence" a poor substitute for a financial passport to EU markets. Companies can't get market access via equivalence for banking services such as lending and deposit-taking, retail asset-management or payment services. Fastenal's sales rose 15.3% in November, accelerating for a second month, even with a tougher comparison with the year-earlier gain of 8.2%. Swiss watch exports increased 1.4% yoy in June, similar to May's 1.2% growth. Exports grew 3% in the year to June, with growth in the month [BLANK] to higher-priced, precious and other metals. Disney's "Moana" took first place in the domestic box office for the second straight weekend with $28.3 million, 13% higher than BoxOfficePro's projections. The EU's new anti-money-laundering rules, due 2Q17, may cause a compliance spending surge among the bloc's banks, life insurers and wealth managers. Amgen repeated its 1Q template of beating consensus estimates and raising 2016 sales and EPS guidance. Intellectual property litigation between Fitbit and Jawbone could come to an end before January, with the companies actively involved in settlement talks. Three of the cases were filed by Jawbone in California state court, the International Trade Commission (currently on appeal) and Northern California, the remaining two were filed by Fitbit in Northern California.

Discount retailers want to add smaller store formats to compete with dollar stores in urban areas.
