Wal-Mart opened 22 small-format stores in the second quarter and plans to have about 270 to 290 open by the end of the year.

Allergan's sale of its U.S. dermatology portfolio to Almirall indicates that the specialty pharma company may be willing to divest more than just its planned Women's Health and anti-infectives units. While a small deal, worth $550 million upfront with another $100 million based on performance, it's a bigger signal that Allergan is being opportunistic on non-core assets and perhaps [BLANK] to prompting from investors to do more to improve the growth profile of the company. The premium is in-line with recent dermatology deals, which suggests favorable terms for Allergan, given Aczone is facing generic competition.

Settlement seems unlikely in Johnson & Johnson's case against Celltrion and partner Pfizer (Hospira), even after the court held J&J's 2018 patent invalid and set a tentative trial date in February. J&J will likely seek a preliminary injunction while the case is [BLANK]. The court ruled in J&J's favor as to the interpretation of a key term in the 2027 patent, giving J&J an edge for trial. The parties must now brief the court on the issues of infringement and invalidity taking the judge's interpretation into account.

Prudential Financial is poised to shed its SIFI label and Federal Reserve oversight soon, providing EPS tailwinds through cost-savings and less onerous capital requirements. The Financial Stability Oversight Council under President Donald Trump is actively reducing the number of designated firms, which [BLANK] well for Prudential.

Post-1Q Earnings Outlook: Ameriprise reported strong growth in operating EPS in 1Q, powered by its Advice & Wealth Management (AWS) unit where pretax earnings jumped 27%. But the pace of Ameriprise's adjusted pretax operating-earnings growth is likely to slow [BLANK] through 2018, especially if equity markets remain under pressure, as the company faces more difficult comparisons. In addition, 1Q asset-management outflows were notably high, though should improve in 2Q, and adviser counts were flat, excluding a 3Q17 bolt-on.

China's electronics industry and automotive market could set the world's demand pace for industrial robots and other factory automation products. The country seeks to [BLANK] its production output of industrial robots by 2020, which may be challenging given its limited track record with robotic R&D. Competition may intensify as the government pays out subsidies to domestic manufacturers, fueling a surge of new competitors.

Congress, controlled by Republicans, adopted a spending blueprint that matches the Pentagon's requested $612 billion, a 4% increase over 2015. For non-defense spending, the Republican plan [BLANK] for $493 billion, about 7% below the $527 billion in President Barack Obama's 2016 request. Republicans may have to accept higher civilian agency budgets by Sept. 30 to get their desired defense funding level signed into law. Failure to reach a compromise could result in budgets being frozen at 2015 levels.

Sales at children's apparel stores strengthened in mid-April as shoppers sought clothing for kids ahead of the Easter holiday. Summer-like temperatures may have also [BLANK] demand for spring apparel. The category continues to outperform most other clothing segments, likely aided by clear pricing and product messaging. Same-store sales for children's apparel retailers surged 17.4% from April 1-14, according to First Data's non-cash point-of-sale figures. Traffic gained 19.6%, but amount spent fell 1.9%.

Retail REITs own about 17% or 1.2 billion square feet of the roughly 7.5 billion square feet of retail gross leaseable area in the U.S. REITs tend to own higher-quality retail space. Tenant sales in REIT mall and outlet portfolios have been rising since 2009 as portfolio quality has [BLANK] along with the underlying retail environment. Growth rates have slowed of late, though REIT portfolios remain relatively full due to strong tenant demand.

Post-1Q Earnings Outlook: We see acquisitions providing a further boost to Ametek's 8% organic growth in 1Q, which prompted it to raise full-year EPS guidance by 9 cents. In a strong start to the year, the backlog rose to a record $1.6 billion, which together with contributions from last year's acquisitions, should help Ametek [BLANK] its 2018 mid-single-digit organic growth goal. Acquisitions remain the top priority for free cash flow, which in turn will get a boost from strong cost control and prices staying above raw-materials inflation.

Ironwood's lead drug Linzess, developed in partnership with Allergan, has largely thwarted competition to date though its growth trajectory has been dampened. Synergy's Trulance's new label [BLANK] to be accelerating market share gains though mostly at the expense of Takeda. Still, the constipation market is large, with room for multiple therapies, and is still growing.

The expanded U.S. sanctions against Russia aim to derail major gas production and transportation projects in Russia and those involving Russian companies. The sanctions [BLANK] to punish companies, including those in the EU, that finance and facilitate construction, upgrade, maintenance or repair of Russian gas pipes. The legislation specifically opposes Gazprom's proposed Nord Stream II (NS2) pipeline. Without EU help, Gazprom's financial partners Uniper, Engie and OMV may further distance themselves from the NS2.

While share buybacks and dividends have fallen out of favor in 2017, down 7.3% in 1Q, they remain a critical means for hardline retailers to return cash to shareholders and boost earnings growth and investor total returns, often in lieu of spending internally. This is further [BLANK] by low interest rates and uncertain economic conditions. Continued buybacks may signal few growth opportunities in sight and may leave some retailers with obsolete or aging assets.

GlaxoSmithKline had the greatest number of 1H new drug (NCE) terminations among large pharma companies, mainly driven by portfolio restructuring. Notably, it [BLANK] the collaboration with Johnson & Johnson on late-stage sirukumab for rhematoid arthritis. Another late-stage termination is MK-8237, for which Merck returned rights to ALK-Abello. Roche and Pfizer trailed Glaxo, with attrition mainly in Phase II. Eli Lilly seeks to outlicense six Phase II and one Phase I oncology assets on portfolio reprioritization.

The decline of the Chinese real-estate market moved billions of dollars into the country's stock market, which saw a dramatic rise and then equally sharp decline. If Chinese investors souring on stocks [BLANK] that the historic value in gold is tempting, that could mean the next boom could come in gold. The metal has historically been viewed as a safe haven in countries that suffer from bouts of inflation as well as political upheaval. China is already the world's top gold buyer.

Analog Devices may find more of its 3D Touch technology across Apple's device portfolio, which should help support its double-digit growth expectation for its consumer segment in 2017. The 3D Touch technology is [BLANK] on the screen and virtual home button in the iPhone 7-series. The 6s lacks a virtual home button, and the SE doesn't support the technology at all. As Apple shifts production to the new iPhone 8, there's hope that some of Analog's premium technology is found on lower-end models.

Declining coal output in China suggests a drop in diesel demand as the indicators are positively correlated. Diesel is widely used in freight transport, especially [BLANK] coal from producing areas such as Shanxi and Inner Mongolia to other parts of the country. Diesel is the largest component of oil products, accounting for 34% of the total last year, so any decline in diesel demand will dampen the overall growth of China's appetite for oil products and may cause lower refinery utilization rates.

Used agricultural equipment inventories remain problematic, another deterrent to new-equipment sales. In April, prices for used large tractors fell 7% from a year earlier as combines [BLANK] 10%. Most new purchases include a trade-in and lower prices are stopping farmers from moving forward. Many dealers are reluctant to take trade-ins. In the latest Farm Equipment Magazine poll, dealers said used inventories worsened in April, with a net 42% saying they were too steep, marking the highest level since October 2015.

Legal actions by Western Digital's SanDisk subsidiary seek to disturb the sale of Toshiba's NAND flash-memory business, complicating bids and financing for a potential deal. Despite headline risk and noise [BLANK] by a litigation overhang, the legal challenges are unlikely to stymie the sale.

If an agreement isn't reached on a U.K.-EU trade deal after Brexit, WTO Most-Favored Nation tariff levels would apply, exposing U.K. companies to average EU tariffs of 10.7% on agricultural products and 4.2% on manufactured ones. EU exporters will also face MFN-level tariffs on goods [BLANK] to the U.K. However, the EU27 share of goods destined to the U.K. accounts for 16% of the total while Britain would lose duty-free access for goods to an area which buys 44% of its exports and produces 55% of its imports.

Morgan Stanley's litigation risks include lawsuits and investigations that may cost $1 billion. The bank faces antitrust suits related to swaps and stock-lending platforms, ISDAfix and U.S. Treasury securities, which may end up [BLANK] several hundred million dollars in total. Morgan Stanley may also be facing probes over foreign-exchange rates, ISDAfix and Treasury securities manipulation, all of which could also cost hundreds of millions.

Stryker and NuVasive may provide 2015 outlooks at the JPMorgan health conference next week, given they have done so in four of the past five years, as the conference focuses on 4Q utilization and major trends to focus on in 2015. A stronger U.S. economy may boost orthopedic demand for both companies, [BLANK] by new product launches. St. Jude's CardioMEMS device will likely be a hot topic, given it may save hospitals from costly penalties under the Affordable Care Act.

Positive clinical data as well as investors' growing acceptance of AbbVie's ability to protect Humira against biosimilars helped it beat peers in 3Q, and the momentum will likely extend into 4Q. Bristol's 14.4% gain in 3Q trading was second-best, [BLANK] by positive Opdivo data in adjuvant melanoma and kidney cancer, though 4Q could be a more mixed bag.

Drugmakers that provide some medicines at steep discounts, along with the hospitals that receive them, have submitted comments on proposed guidance for the U.S. 340B drug-discount program that narrows the definition of an eligible patient. Courts have ruled the Health Resources and Services Administration [BLANK] statutory authority to issue a formal omnibus rule covering the program, so the enforcement of informal guidance seeking to accomplish the same goals remains in question.

Amgen's case against Apotex over its proposed biosimilar of Neulasta is in the post-trial phase after the court held a bench trial July 11-18. Apotex [BLANK] a motion for judgment of non-infringement for one of the patents in suit. The U.S. Court of Appeal for the Federal Circuit's ruling on the 180-day marketing notice keeps Neulasta competition-free until at least six months after the pending FDA approval of Apotex's product. Amgen's 2015 revenue from the chemotherapy drug were $4.2 billion, about 18% of its total.

North American and western European foodmakers may make more acquisitions in fast-growing Asian markets in 2015 as their domestic sales slow on demographic headwinds. Hershey, for instance, recently [BLANK] 80% of Shanghai Golden Monkey to add products and distribution points in China. Asian packaged-food sales may have a 4.5% CAGR through 2019, versus 1.1% in North America and 0.5% in western Europe, according to Euromonitor. Asian foodmakers may also pursue overseas M&A.

China's low growth and subdued inflation -- with the producer price index below zero for the last 30 months -- suggest the economy is operating below capacity and makes the case for increased stimulus. Weak loan data, with new [BLANK] down 39% in August vs. the prior year, suggest current interest rates are too high for borrowers.

Investors claim Braskem is liable for as much as $31 million in ADR losses they incurred following a March 11, 2015 news report implicating the company in Petrobras' bribery scandal. Likely due to the ADR price's quick recovery afterward, plaintiffs haven't sought to [BLANK] the class period or their loss claims. This may change if new details emerge from Brazil's investigations of the scandal. The company has been twice subpoenaed by the SEC in relation to the bribery allegations.

North-Africa and Mediterranean-Basin recovery scenario math is a relevant exercise, particularly for LafargeHolcim, which owns assets in the region of more than 4.3 billion euros. That's calculated on 8.9 million tons of cement capacity in Egypt and 12.6 million in Algeria, with each ton [BLANK] at $150-$250 million.

Barclays and other banks will argue before a judge on April 20 that an antitrust lawsuit accusing them of a 10-year conspiracy to manipulate prices in the $20 trillion gold and gold-derivatives market should be thrown out. The banks [BLANK] that the plaintiffs haven't set forth sufficient facts to show there was a conspiracy. UBS also contends that it wasn't involved in gold pricing during the alleged time period. Oral arguments in April could mean a ruling in 1H, though 3Q is more likely.

Volkswagen faces more than 600 lawsuits from customers who allege the automaker cheated on emissions testing for certain diesel models. Cases were [BLANK] in a California federal court that's also presiding over the Justice Department's civil suit and related investor actions. Owners and lessees of affected models have brought class-action claims of product liability and consumer fraud. Damages could exceed $9.4 billion -- the cost to buy back the vehicles -- though negotiations for early settlement are ongoing.

Evidence of increased traction on the turnaround of the Terminix pest-control business may be seen in 4Q, though a resumption of earnings improvement is unlikely until 2018. Terminix's growth is [BLANK], but investments to improve sales and customer retention continue to drive margins lower. American Home Shield continues to post healthy high-single-digit organic revenue gains ahead of the planned spinoff, which is still on track for 3Q18. Franchise Services growth remain remains healthy, but is a lesser contributor.

Australia, Asia-Pacific's second-largest country in terms of shale-gas resources, faces the twin challenges of high E&P costs and plunging oil prices. The sharp slump and slow recovery for oil has further damaged operating cash flows for [BLANK] shale gas. Chevron exited Beach Energy's shale gas-development in March. Drillsearch has de-emphasized shale gas for now. Australia has huge untapped potential, with technical recoverable resources of 437 trillion cubic feet, according to the EIA's latest assessment.

The U.K.'s pre-election budget may add to demand for new homes if measures focused on economic growth and reducing unemployment. A cut in corporation tax to 20%, the lowest in G20, might [BLANK] capital spending and improve productivity, which in turn may drive wages. This, combined with an increase in the personal tax free allowance threshold, may raise disposable income. An average household will be about 900 pounds ($1,340) better off in 2015 vs. 2010, said the Office for Budget Responsibility.

The U.S. horizontal rig count rose by four in the week ended Aug. 14, led by gains in the Permian and Eagle Ford. The Permian horizontal oil rig count [BLANK] by six and is up 27 from the late-June low. The rally in the vertical rig count cooled as the count fell by two, increasing by 28 from a bottom in early June. Almost 80% of rigs on land are drilling horizontally, up 10 percentage points from a year earlier. Directional rigs fell by one to 83 in the week.

Precious-metals prices could face further short-term volatility amid discrepancies in market sentiment and fundamentals. Political and growth uncertainties may [BLANK] gold's safe-haven investment demand, while the autocatalyst segment remains key to platinum-group metal consumption. Yet potential dollar pressure may not help. China continues to play a vital role in the direction of these metals' prices, driven by domestic investors, a slowdown in economic growth and potential People's Bank of China purchases.

Goldcorp earnings over the last two years have been volatile due to gold prices and rising costs. CEO David Garofalo continues [BLANK] to rein in costs and give better earnings and cost clarity. Consensus estimates 3Q gold production of 736,000 ounces with a cash cost of $554 an ounce. This would compare with 2Q's 613,000 ounces of production and cash costs of $728 an ounce. Gold's almost 20% increase in 2016 has helped alleviate margin concerns and should provide needed cash flow.

Banco Santander, one of the worst stock performers in 2015 among peer banks, kicks off full-year 2015 reporting on Jan 27, having fallen more than 10% in the first trading days of 2016. Investment banks Deutsche, UBS and Credit Suisse, along with the Nordic banks, will then [BLANK]. The focus will be on dividend payout guidance, 4Q FICC trading, which is expected to have fallen year-on-year, and revised targets. Cost-cutting and plans to offset prolonged net interest margin pressures will also be key.

Japan's imported foreign-vehicle sales growth cooled to 3% last year from 16% in 2013, after an April 1 sales-tax increase that also slowed sales of domestically made cars. Growth may [BLANK] this year because of easier comparisons. Sales rose for all of the top five imported brands last year, led by a 13% increase for Mercedes following the launch of new models. The five brands made up 81% of imported-auto registrations.

Less-than-truckload carriers' median EPS is expected to rise 13.3% in 2Q, based on consensus. Carriers will likely be [BLANK] by the strong pricing environment, as well as increased productivity from efficiency gains by workers hired in 2014. YRC is expected to earn a profit in 2Q amid its focus on mix and yield management. Con-way (down 12.5%) may be the only LTL carrier to decline as it faces tough comparisons from a robust 2Q14, higher costs from driver raises and the drag from lower fuel surcharges.

A bill that would repeal an Obamacare-imposed tax on health insurers has significant support in the Republican-led Congress, though it's very unlikely to become law this year. A majority (236) of the 435 members of the House have [BLANK] on as co-sponsors. The legislation, H.R. 928, would likely pass the House. But two big obstacles stand in the way of enactment in 2016: the president's probable veto, and a need to identify $145 billion in other savings to offset the projected loss of tax revenue.

Natural Grocers' shares are down 45% through Dec. 5, as the retailer combats new-store cannibalization and sales weakness. Kroger has [BLANK] 22%. SuperValu has dropped 30%, even as it finalizes the sale of its Save-A-Lot business. Competition among specialty retailers has escalated, muting stock performance of Whole Foods (down 8%) and Sprouts (23% lower). In contrast, SpartanNash has advanced 73% on acquisitions and as its food distribution business has gained new accounts.

Ferrari's revenue growth almost came to a halt in 1Q, held back by euro strength, a trend that will continue through 2018. Despite the currency headwind, Ebitda increased 13% to 272 million euros -- [BLANK] by strong V12 sales up 23% -- and assisted by the ramp-up of the 812 Superfast, which also helped to drive Ebitda per vehicle close to 128,000 euros ($150,000). Ebit growth of 18% reflects lower depreciation, giving a 25.3% margin, a 370-bp improvement vs. 1Q17.

Morgan Stanley's preliminary $2.6 billion settlement with the Justice Department's RMBS task force may rise above $3 billion if the bank reaches a deal with New York's Attorney General, also a member of the group. Goldman Sachs may [BLANK] a similar task force settlement amount, based on its 2014 accord with FHFA being on par with Morgan Stanley's 2014 FHFA deal. Deutsche Bank's 2013 FHFA settlement was even higher, which may signal a higher DOJ settlement for it than the likely Goldman and Morgan Stanley deals.

The Drewry Hong Kong-Los Angeles container rate benchmark declined 9.6% to $1,875 per 40-foot container (FEU) in the week ended Sept. 24. The general increase of $600 per FEU from Sept. 1 [BLANK] to hold as slack capacity helped push rates lower for a third straight week. Rates fell below $2,000 per FEU for the first time in eight weeks and are down 0.6% compared with last year. Carriers may have to seek another general increase to drive rates higher.

Reckitt Benckiser won't panic buy, CEO Rakesh Kapoor said, speaking from the CAGE conference in London. He will [BLANK] "only when shareholders make money from this." He said the dividend payout ratio (60.3% in 2014) is the "right one at this time." The payout ratio is up 800 bps since 2011 and ranks fifth among peers. Debt reduction takes priority. With 1.5 billion pounds ($2.2 billion) of net debt, Kapoor places an aggressive short- to medium-term buyback program at the bottom of the list as a use for cash.

Two-thirds of investors expect OPEC and non-member nations to begin increasing oil output, based on our survey before the June 22 meeting. This [BLANK] the success of OPEC and non-OPEC intervention since January 2017, which has reduced global inventories, rebalanced the market and stabilized pricing.

Slower growth in emerging markets is likely to limit aircraft orders and lead to rising deferrals in 2017. Economic output in the BRIC nations is [BLANK] to rise 5.5%, an improvement over the [BLANK] 4.7% in 2016, though less than in most years since 2010. Slower growth likely means less buying as a number of airlines have multiples of current fleet on order. China's deceleration is most concerning as it has been a strong contributor to Boeing and Airbus orders and deliveries in the past decade.

The newest independent power producer, Talen, came out of the gate showing interest in acquiring more generation in the company's territories of Texas, the PJM capacity auction and New York-New England. CEO Paul Farr said on June 1 that Talen's balance sheet, plus proceeds from the regulator-required sale of about 1,400 megawatts, position Talen for portfolio growth, possibly [BLANK] from hybrid utilities. Fellow IPPs Dynegy and NRG have been active acquirers of merchant plants previously owned by hybrid utilities.

Ventas, HCP and Welltower, the three largest health-care REITs, each outperformed the peer group average in March. This [BLANK] a change for HCP and Welltower, which trail the average year-to-date. Exposure to skilled nursing remains a drag on health-care REITs. Care Capital Properties and Sabra Health Care REIT, which are focused on that subsector, were the two worst performers in the month. HCP, which suffers from exposure to skilled nursing operator HCR ManorCare, is the weakest year-to-date.

Health-care REITs are on pace for growth in funds from operations in 2019, at least by 2H, after years of declines due to net dispositions. Acquisitions or other investments are still key to driving growth, but dispositions have [BLANK], reducing dilution. Acquisitions made during 2018 will have an earnings impact in 2019.

As the earnings season has evolved, S&P 500 management commentary has shifted to focus on M&A and stockholder payouts. Near-term savings from U.S. tax overhaul is still expected to go to wages and capital spending, yet the hunt for deals and returns to shareholders are [BLANK] to show up in call transcripts.

Recent key timeline extensions in the biotech and pharmaceuticals industry include BioDelivery initiating the next late-stage trial of clonidine gel in painful diabetic neuropathy during 2H with enhanced patient selection vs. the previously targeted 1H. Ohr's Squalamine eye-drop Phase III start is also [BLANK]. Phase IIb readout of Trevena-Actavis's TRV027 in acute heart failure is extended to 1H16 from 4Q15, while Acadia delayed filing for FDA approval of pimavanserin to 2H15 from 1Q15.

While conventional wisdom states that China is now about half of the world's metal demand, a peculiar setup of China's closed currency system may be masking a tremendous amount of "fake" demand. While only time will tell, the use of metals as a manner to secure offshore dollar financing to take advantage of onshore Chinese yuan interest rates, which are much higher than in the West, may mean that true Chinese demand is far less than analysts and mining companies have [BLANK].

Fifth Third management said increasing competition from larger banks and nonbank lenders is driving it to scale back from certain products, damping loan growth. Management [BLANK] a combination of both rates and risk parameters as causes for concern. In certain commercial loan segments, management noted seeing competitors willing to offer more leverage and significantly lower pricing.

Restaurant industry two-year same-store sales rose 0.6% in May, reversing more than a year of declines. Traffic was negative for fast-food and casual dining chains for the 14th straight month, but [BLANK] to the best level since March 2016. Easier comparisons through the end of the year lend some hope that industry same-store sales will stabilize and return to low-single-digit growth in the second half of the year.

Congress and President Barack Obama may be open to skirting sequester without a grand bargain, boosting the 2016 U.S. defense budget. Overseas contingency funds, used for extraordinary events, could [BLANK] the base budget and allow Democrats and Republicans to appear strong on defense leading up to the 2016 elections without giving ground on core differences. Questions abound on using war funding to avoid sequester law, though it may be a politically expedient way to boost defense spending before the election.

Well-integrity testing and waste-storage tanks may be the most costly parts of the Bureau of Land Management's delayed fracking rule, accounting for almost 87% of the average $11,400 compliance cost per operation. Costs for producers will [BLANK] because most states already have some testing requirements and some companies already use waste-storage tanks. Companies that frack on federal land, mainly in the western U.S., could see added costs from the rule, including Continental Resources, Exxon Mobil and EOG.

With the largest U.S. base of cardholders and merchants, Chase may succeed with a nationwide digital-payments app, though it faces challenges. Chase Pay plans to [BLANK] market share by reducing merchants' payment-acceptance costs. Chase Pay runs on ChaseNet, a closed-loop Visa partnership that enables custom merchant-pricing and improved database marketing. Chase Pay may develop a rewards feature now that's its acquired the remaining technology assets of CurrentC, a failed major-merchant payments app.

The Stoxx 600 Europe Insurance Index staged a recovery from a five-month low, reached on July 7, following agreement between Greece and its creditors. The average forward P/E ratio for the industry rose to 11.8x, from 11x before the deal was [BLANK]. This multiple reached a one-year peak of 12.7x in April. The forward price-to-book ratio declined to 1.1x before rebounding to 1.2x. The industry's forecasts for future dividend growth helps explain why shares trade at a relatively high average yield of 4.5%.

Most branded-apparel companies met consensus in 2Q and managed to increase sales and margins, even as retailers aggressively competed through discounting and other promotions. Stock prices of high-priced apparel and accessories brands such as Michael Kors and Kate Spade declined amid investor concerns that 2H margins would be [BLANK]. Retailers' apparel inventories appear to be leaner than earlier in the year, which should reduce promotions and and improve margins.

Multi-property portfolios and Cotai Strip exposure will determine leadership among Macau's casino companies. While SJM still has the most casinos, its revenue lead faded over the last three years as Sands and Galaxy [BLANK] integrated resorts on the Cotai Strip. Galaxy and Melco Crown will open more properties this year, and Wynn Macau and MGM China should join the Cotai party with mega-resorts opening in 2016. SJM will probably be the last to open a Cotai location, in 2017.

The Regional Greenhouse Gas Initiative (RGGI) is set to further challenge coal power plant operators in particular, while providing more funds for renewables and energy-efficiency projects. The RGGI is a nine-state, cap-and-trade program that [BLANK] outside of President Donald Trump's direct influence. It has collected about $2.8 billion from operators since 2008 and recently finalized a plan to cut emissions to 30% below 2020 levels by 2030. Expansion to include Virginia and New Jersey may help lower firms' compliance costs.

Caterpillar's mining unit aftermarket sales were flat in the third quarter after a slight increase earlier in the year. During periods of slow economic growth, high-margin aftermarket sales help [BLANK] declines in equipment sales. Mining companies have used tactics to extend maintenance, Caterpillar says, such as using parked equipment for parts. Aftermarket sales should improve as mine output continues to rise. Several of the company's dealers and competitors have already cited an uptick in aftermarket sales.

Higher online competition and the hefty investments required to move online may spur more apparel stores with subscale digital operations to form partnerships with e-tailers and marketplaces, though losing control of image and customer data can be a concern. Online platforms with high market share are more likely to [BLANK] retailers, profiting from commissions and services such as marketing. Shoppers, particularly those who browse on mobile devices, tend to prefer the multi-brand platforms with wider assortments.

The rejection of a 2012 settlement of a merchant antitrust class-action against Visa and MasterCard opened the door to more claims against the companies. After a $7 billion settlement was [BLANK] on appeal, the case was restarted in the trial court. Class action and individual plaintiffs, including 7-Eleven, Target and others, will likely learn in 2Q whether they can file new complaints. The scuttled settlement opened the door for new claims that could increase the potential damages sought by merchants.

Post-1Q Earnings Outlook: Aramark's revenue momentum should stay within its 3-5% multiyear target range through fiscal 2H, driven by broad-based growth across all segments. Productivity is [BLANK], but margin expansion is unlikely before 2H due to the timing of reinvestments and new-account onboarding, which skew to 1H. Integration efforts are underway for Avendra and AmeriPride, which will be accretive to free cash flow in 2018 but dilutive to earnings.

Energy Future Holdings will likely escape paying $275 million to NextEra over the failed Oncor bid, despite NextEra's appeal of the bankruptcy court's decision rejecting the fee. Recoveries for unsecured creditors of EFH and its Energy Future Intermediate Holdings subsidiary may [BLANK] as a result.

For shale gas E&P outside North America, Shell projects the best prospects in Argentina and China, though challenges remain, including Chinese geological difficulties and Argentine currency restrictions. Shell also [BLANK] some shale potential in regions such as Tunisia and Turkey. Uncertainty persists as to the future of the oil major's Russian and Ukrainian operations, currently suspended. Peers including BP, Total and Statoil are also engaged in international shale exploration.

Like Harvey, Hurricane Irma's arrival in Florida is likely to crimp near-term homebuilding demand and delay deliveries scheduled for 2H into 2018. At the same time, labor costs are likely to [BLANK] as a depleted construction-labor force is further strained. This combination temporarily reduces earnings expectations. While the storm is expected to take direct aim at Miami, the industry's 11th-largest market, the repurcussions are likely to be widespread across the state.

Justice Department probes of Russia mirror trades and sanction breaches could add to the more than $800 million Deutsche Bank has paid in pacts with New York, the U.K. and the Fed. Deutsche faces forex probes by New York's financial regulator and private lawsuits that could [BLANK] more than $200 million. The bank is also being probed over ISDAfix, metals, SSA bonds and Treasuries, and sued over interest-rate swaps, Libor, Treasuries and SSA bonds, which collectively may cost hundreds of millions of dollars.

Health's access to the long-term care market through the purchase of Omnicare may help drive EPS gains. Long-term prescriptions have grown at a muted pace during the past few years, though an [BLANK] population, along with rising occupancy and construction of assisted-living units, supports future growth. Omnicare receives about 65% of sales from less-profitable government programs, though CVS Health may be able to better manage its Medicare Part D members that move in and out of long-term care units.

The European insurance industry is grappling with the implementation of the Solvency II regulatory capital regime, due to take effect from Jan. 1. Solvency II [BLANK] an economic-capital model to the valuation of both assets and liabilities, and sets out guidelines on disclosure and risk management. As the deadline approaches, more companies, such as Aviva, Legal & General and Prudential, may use the transitional measures already being widely used in Germany to smooth out the introduction of the regime.

Broadcasters may look to develop underutilized spectrum for new opportunities to better monetize their frequencies. ATSC 3.0, a next-generation, IP-based broadcast technology, would [BLANK] the efficiency of the broadcasters' spectrum vs. ATSC 1.0, the current standard. This may allow broadcasters to monetize their spectrum in new ways. However, any potential commercial implementation is a long-term goal with unproven business models. A required equipment upgrade may also keep adoption limited.

Both Goodyear's 7% bonds due in 2022, rated B1 by Moody's and B+ by S&P, and auto-supplier peer American Axle's similarly rated 6.625% notes due in 2022 trade wider than a regression of BB category rated peers. Goodyear aims to [BLANK] investment-grade ratings while American Axle targets 2x leverage. In contrast, Belden has laid out a leverage policy of 2.5x to 3.x on average and has 5.5% bonds due in 2022 that trade tighter than both Goodyear's and Axle's.

The EPS of companies in BI's life insurance peer group rose by a median 8% in 4Q, excluding Genworth, which posted a loss in both 4Q and 4Q15. Results improved vs. 5% growth in 4Q15, with insurers [BLANK] from favorable equity markets, expense control and capital management. The group's pretax margin rose 478 bps vs. 4Q15 to 15.9%, the best since 2Q15, despite a drag from lower portfolio yields, which fell 30 bps. The median consensus EPS change for the peer group is 14% for 1Q and 8% for 2017.

Eneres may fuel demand for Toshiba's lithium-ion batteries (LiB) in Japan by offering a new battery management service. Eneres is [BLANK] to install 10,000 units of Toshibas 10kW LiB that will help customers to cut electricity cost by reducing electricity demand at peak-time. Businesses in Japan may receive two-thirds of the total cost from the government when installing a LiB energy storage system. Other LiB manufacturers include LG Chem and Panasonic.

Venmo's volume has surged, but a consortium of the largest U.S. banks could begin to take market share with a new service just as PayPal seeks to extend Venmo to merchant payments. Chase, Bank of America and Wells Fargo [BLANK] a consortium in 2011 to offer real-time payments. While the service had $55 billion in 2016 volume due to the dominance of its partner banks, it can be difficult to set up and use. Venmo, which is easy-to-use, free and can be accessed via social media, has been embraced by millennials.

Commissioner Scott Gottlieb is aggressively pushing the FDA to speed the review of applications for generic versions of older, off-patent drugs that lack competition. The FDA is also looking to [BLANK] outcomes-based pricing discussions, update its policies for new digital tools, and crack down on youth e-cigarette use.

Nomura and Daiwa's shares underperformed most of the other Japanese brokers we track during April and in early May, as investors are concerned with their weakening retail business outlook. Yet the market could be [BLANK] a more positive view towards SBI and Kabu.com given optimism about rising online stock trades.

Linear Technology would receive $700 million from Analog Devices if the parties cannot close their merger by the agreed upon end date due to antitrust issues. As per the parties' July 26 agreement, the termination date is April 26, though it can be extended to Oct. 26 if the failure to [BLANK] is due to antitrust regulatory reviews. The fee is part of the agreement and would compensate Linear for disruptions and expenses incurred as a result of a lengthy antitrust review.

Amgen's requests for inter partes review of two of AbbVie's patents covering formulations of adalimumab are awaiting a decision from the U.S. patent office after AbbVie filed its response on Oct. 19. The agency will decide by mid-January whether to [BLANK] the challenged patents. Amgen argues that the patents claim combinations of adalimumab with known components for antibody formulations. If granted, the final decision on the validity of the patents could come as soon as late 2016 or early 2017.

Policy uncertainty has hindered distributed solar growth in some states that lead by capacity, including Arizona and Nevada. Arizona's policies have been in flux for years and regulators are working on [BLANK] net metering rates below the retail level. Growth flat-lined over about the last year. Year-over-year expansion slowed in Nevada after the regulator ended net metering in 2015. South Carolina, which began a new net metering policy in 2015, had a 650% increase in 4Q from the prior year.

Yue Yuen's athletic gear retailing business in China may help drive revenue to a 5.5% increase for 2016, according to consensus. At 26% of sales, the retailing unit sells brands such as Nike, Adidas and Li Ning, which had 1H sales growth from 16-46% as growing numbers of Chinese [BLANK] athletically involved. Yue Yuen's manufacturing business growth may accelerate beyond the 1.8% pace it set over the last 12 months if it can win additional orders from its global customers.

Workday's better-than-expected fiscal 1Q results highlight its leadership position in cloud human capital management applications. Increased adoption of its new financial management product and large-client wins in the past few months [BLANK] sales growth should remain strong in the coming quarters. Workday said its win rate against large vendors SAP and Oracle and midsize companies such as Ultimate Software and NetSuite remains high, which shows that it's still the competitor to beat.

China's GDP growth may slow next year, according to consensus expectations. In a Bear Case, that could [BLANK] on Macau's VIP gaming, which accounts for about 60% of total gaming revenue. The correlation between GDP growth and VIP baccarat growth has been 0.86 on a concurrent basis, and 0.87 when lagging VIP baccarat by one quarter.

As budgets recovered, states earmarked more general-budget funds for ailing transportation infrastructure. State transportation spending [BLANK] 4.4% in 2015 and 4.9% in 2014. This represents 59% total state spending in 2015, up from 56% in 2014 and 54% in 2013. Increasing education and health-care costs may limit such increases going forward. Medicaid is now 27.4% of state budgets vs. 21.7% in 2009, as costs increase. Additionally, K-12 programs cut during the recession are being resumed.

Telus spent more than its rivals in Canada's 2.5 GHz spectrum auction, given 2.5 GHz is well-suited to adding capacity to Telus's LTE network. Telus spent C$478.8 million ($398.9 million) on nationwide spectrum [BLANK] 1.3 billion MHz-Pops. This is on top of the C$2.6 billion Telus spent since 2014 to buy spectrum at auction to upgrade its network to compete more effectively with rivals. Bell (C$29 million) and Rogers (C$24.1 million) spent less due to spectrum ownership caps in the 2.5 GHz band.

The benefits of joining seeds and crop chemicals will remain unclear amid slow growth this year, yet pressure is on newly merged (DowDuPont, Nutrien) and merging (Bayer-Monsanto) producers to demonstrate the advantages. Cost cuts can support margins, but the case for growth from realigned portfolios is still [BLANK] to be made.

Medical device companies in the S&P 500 have avoided U.S. tax on $124 billion in accumulated foreign earnings, part of a $2 trillion total for S&P 500 companies that may help drive tax change proposals in Congress in 2015. If Republicans take full control, they may consider [BLANK] taxes on foreign earnings or a repatriation tax holiday. They may resist short-term limits on tax inversions while pushing for a broader tax code overhaul.

Major hotel markets in the Americas are seeing swings in revenue per available room, mostly due to currency volatility and tourist events. This [BLANK] Canada, Mexico and Brazil. STR's monthly statistics reflect the impact from changes in supply and demand. An increase in U.S. tourists is fueling to Mexico's revpar boom and Canada's improving performance. Brazil's Rio Olympics should boost demand, yet challenges such as a hotel glut, weak economic outlook and the Zika outbreak may damp the effect.

The FCC's 600 MHz spectrum auction, which may transfer 60 MHz of spectrum from broadcasters to wireless carriers, will provide a good blueprint for the auction of these same frequencies in Canada. Regulators in Canada have proposed [BLANK] a final plan for the country's 600 MHz auction after the U.S. one concludes. With U.S. proceeds expected to total an estimated $28.2 billion, a similar auction in Canada would be a significant event for both the Canadian carriers and the government.

Teen retailers Abercrombie & Fitch, Aeropostale and American Eagle lowered inventory levels during 2Q which may bolster the promotional environment in 2H, given there is little to no markdowns available for clearance, alleviating gross margin pain. Abercrombie said it will [BLANK] the chase program by employing fabric strategies to better match demand and prevent inventory overages and excessive markdowns. Chase represented 20% of the female assortment in 2Q.

In addition to the two lawsuits against Roxane, Jazz is defending Xyrem in a large number of other lawsuits and inter partes review patent challenges. Jazz is [BLANK] Allergan, Amneal, Ranbaxy, Par, Wockhardt and Lupin in a consolidated lawsuit. Jazz is also suing several generic-drug makers in individual lawsuits over its two method patents expiring 2033, which are likely to be consolidated. Jazz is also defending its Xyrem patents in 19 IPRs filed by generic makers at the U.S. patent office.

Kosmos has obtained a secondary listing on the London Stock Exchange (LSE) in efforts to diversify its investor base and increase its visibility. The listing may come at the expense of Tullow Oil, as Kosmos [BLANK] analogous operational exposure in Ghana but has a cleaner balance sheet and compelling near-term exploration in Mauritania-Senegal. The LSE was chosen given its robust liquidity and because investors' knowledge of -- and appetite for -- higher-risk exploration in frontier jurisdictions is sophisticated.

Bills such as S. 1656 and H.R. 2883 that would allow clean energy assets to qualify for master limited partnerships, or tax-exempt entities with publicly traded units, are unlikely to advance in 2016. While the measures have bipartisan support, there is little momentum in Congress to [BLANK] on the legislation, in part because demand for MLPs may be tepid. Some yieldcos, such as Atlantica Yield and TerraForm Global, that were incorporated to replicate some tax benefits of MLPs, have lost value over the last year.

Airfares are dropping as a U.S. market-share war rages, with profit growth threatened by rising fuel prices. The domestic market is [BLANK] for expansion, with the highest yields globally after years of capacity constraint. Strong domestic additions by U.S. carriers continue to pressure fares through 2016. Low-cost airlines lead the charge, with Southwest planning to expand 5-6% in 2016, JetBlue 8.5-10.5% and Spirit 20%, though the effects are felt by full-service carries, given they compete on common routes.

Large shopping-center REIT portfolios will start to shrink as landlords ramp up dispositions into 2018, and low cap rates keep acquisitions limited. This comes after shopping-center landlords [BLANK] their focus on redeveloping and remerchandising core assets, and as capital recycling hits a four-year low in 2017.

Near-term U.S. interest rate expectations mostly recovered from an initial drop after Britain's vote to exit the EU, yet, longer-term, implied short-term rates remain lower. Recently lowered Fed long-term expectations reinforce a lower-for-longer rates [BLANK], cutting bank revenue optimism. Investment banks' fixed-income trading revenue boost from rate uncertainty and foreign exchange volumes may fade, though credit trading may be aided by debt issuance and fund flows with expected lower longer-term interest rates.

Apartment REITs will be exposed for the remainder of 2014 and into 2015 to elevated construction levels that are depressing rent growth rates. In the strongest markets, such as New York and San Francisco, rent growth is [BLANK] to slow through 2015, even after a strong summer leasing season. Apartment REIT share prices have outperformed other REIT segments this year and are approaching consensus price targets, with analysts most bullish on bicoastal REITs.

Post-2Q Earnings Outlook: Box continues to show steady billings momentum, driven by high retention rates and increased sales at existing customers. Billings expanded 31% in fiscal 2Q, similar to the last quarter, while annual contract values (ACV) have been [BLANK] by growing order sizes. The company's expanding partnerships with large tech vendors such as Microsoft and IBM, coupled with compliance requirements such as GDPR in Europe, may continue to be a tailwind for boosting international sales.

American Realty Capital Properties is unlikely to succeed if it seeks dismissal of shareholder securities fraud lawsuits. The company's Oct. 29 disclosure of intentional accounting misconduct, and [BLANK] SEC and Justice Department probes, make dismissal less likely. Several suits filed against the company Oct. 30 will probably be consolidated, followed by dismissal bids by the end of 1Q. A ruling on dismissal may come by 3Q, and settlement may follow.

While income growth rose 4.1% in April from 4% in the prior month, after slowing down in the first quarter, consumer spending didn't follow. That may have been [BLANK] by faltering confidence. Personal income is key for card lenders because it drives consumer purchases and card-debt growth in the long term, since spending must be paid for with either current or future income. In mature card markets, spending correlates to economically cyclical income and card debt follows with a higher level of cyclically.

High-yield credit trading volume fell 7% in 3Q vs. the prior year, based on Finra Trace bond trading data. High-grade volume, a larger market, rose 10%, while the smaller convertible market [BLANK] 16%. Overall credit trading gained 4%, though wider spreads may weigh on 3Q results. Global high-yield corporates lost 4.6% as spreads retraced to levels approaching the 2012 European debt crisis. High grade was flat in 3Q. Volume is running 9% below a tough 2Q in the typically seasonally slower quarter.

Operating margins (including financial services) for North American automakers trail Asian and European competitors, with General Motors ending 2Q at 3.4%, behind Ford for the second straight quarter. Both Toyota and BMW's profitability [BLANK] 2Q above 10%, as high exposure to the well-performing U.S. luxury markets helped boost margins. This contrasts with U.S. carmakers' premium brands, which are sacrificing volume as they seek to command higher prices and strengthen brand reputations.

UBS's litigation risks in the U.S. include lawsuits and investigations that may cost more than $6.5 billion. Top-end risk in a U.S. RMBS probe may be $5 billion, though a $2.5 billion settlement [BLANK] more likely. A mortgage repurchase suit against UBS, which is settling, could cost between $543 million and $1.6 billion. Suits related to swaps and stock-lending platforms, forex, Libor and similar rates, silver, gold and U.S. Treasuries, along with possible probes related to FIFA, ISDAfix, and Treasuries may cost hundreds of millions of dollars in total. UBS is settling a forex suit for $141 million and an ISDAfix suit for $14 million. The bank has settled with some Libor plaintiffs for $18 million. The bank was fined $15 million by the CFTC in January in connection with manipulation of the metals market.

Solar inverter and power electronics suppliers contend with a multitude of competitive threats. These include [BLANK] technology, high competition among peers, the threat of low-cost Chinese supply and new entrants such as SunPower and Tesla. Leading global suppliers include SolarEdge, SMA Solar, Enphase and ABB.

Overseas buyers have bought a net $13.3 billion of Taiwanese stocks ytd, up from $1.5 billion a year earlier. The almost 9x surge probably [BLANK] growing optimism about local technology companies' sales amid economic recoveries in mature markets and upcoming new Apple products. The benchmark Taiex has jumped 9.2% ytd. Technology stocks make up 47% of the index by weight. South Korea has drawn $8.8 billion of inflows this year, while Japan has had an $11.5 billion outflow.

CenturyLink faces investor and subscriber lawsuits alleging it defrauded millions of customers and caused over $12 billion in damages, yet the company has a good shot at winning dismissals and settling for much less. CenturyLink may derail the subscribers' allegations of "cramming" -- or [BLANK] unauthorized charges to bills -- because of the language in users' contracts.

Alibaba aims to grow advertising sales by integrating users of its e-commerce sites and Youku, and by enhancing cross-platform promotion. Analysis of users' shopping and video viewing could help Alibaba [BLANK] advertising more precisely, and increase customer spending. Currently, Youku generates most of its revenue from advertising. It has also started to generate subscription revenue, leveraging younger users' willingness to pay for premium content.

Delta's revenue is likely to fall as fares suffer from intense competition. Domestic yields are [BLANK] as low-cost carriers strongly add capacity, with even business fliers benefiting. Revenue growth is unlikely without raising domestic fares, which may require broad-based capacity cuts. The drop in trans-Atlantic fares is likely to continue as exchange rates favor travel to Europe, though security concerns could limit demand. Asia fares struggle on excess capacity and Latin America from economic contraction.

VW's Audi and Tata's Land Rover face greater price competition from Volvo Cars after the latter cut prices 8% for its new, flagship XC90 SUV. This may [BLANK] sales and earnings at Volvo China's rivals. Volvo's move is aggressive since its sales surged in the final two months of 2015. The Geely-owned Swedish automaker plans to introduce a new S90 sedan at the end of this year, which will compete with mid-range luxury sedans such as BMW's 5 Series, Audi's A6L and Daimler's Mercedes E-Class.

The Stoxx 600 Europe Insurance Index underperformed the Stoxx 600 Europe by about 2.7% since the start of 2014, declining 1.58% compared with a 1.1% gain in the benchmark. This partly [BLANK] concern about continued low interest rates in Europe and U.K. pension reform. In July, shares in the insurance index fell on average 0.4%. That compared with a 1.72% decline in the wider index as tension in the Ukraine and the Middle East escalated and concern about Euro-zone inflation increased.

BT's TV subscription additions slowed in the last two quarters and fell behind BSkyB (including online NOW TV) and TalkTalk TV net adds. This suggests [BLANK] support from free-provision of Sports content to broadband customers. With its mobile launch going ahead, BT is positioned as a key convergence player in the U.K., giving its TV offer an increasingly important role. European operators strengthened their TV segment organically (KPN) and with acquisitions (Telefonica).

Congress is set to pass a $1 trillion 2015 spending bill between Dec. 11 and Dec. 13 that would fund contracts for top federal vendors such as Booz Allen Hamilton and Engility. The bill [BLANK] all federal agencies, though provides funding for Homeland Security only through Feb. 27, due to Republican concerns about President Barack Obama's immigration policy. Policies affecting banks, trucking and other industries are also included in the 1,603-page bill, H.R. 83.

American Campus is developing student-housing assets in markets that have low supply and high demand, with expected yields of 6.25-7%, which is key to its growth. The average age of on-campus student housing exceeds 50 years, [BLANK] universities to invest in modernization. Many are partnering with student housing experts such as American Campus, rather than undertaking the challenges on their own. American Campus is also developing off-campus housing that's purpose built for students and is within walking distance. American Campus' deal to provide student housing for the Disney College Program is expected to bring an estimated blended yield of 6.8% over a five-year phased development. It also validates American Campus as the premier developer of on-campus housing.

Polish lenders, including Millennium and PKO, have risen an average 30% this year, helping the MSCI EMEA financial index outperform the broader benchmark. The government's comments that it may drop plans to [BLANK] non-zloty mortgages have supported this. Turkish banks, up nearly 20%, were buoyed by robust 4Q earnings and a stabilization of the lira. VTB (down 10%) and Sberbank (down 6%) have been the biggest laggards as recent comments from President Donald Trump have tempered expectations of sanctions.

Heightened expectations of a Federal Reserve interest rate increase in the coming months are strengthening the dollar vs. global currencies. Central banks are [BLANK] their interest rates in a global currency war. The continued devaluation of foreign currencies against the greenback hurts the value of gold in dollar terms and conversely increases its worth in foreign currency terms.

Demand for digital products and infrastructure development will help global software spending climb at a rate of 6.5% through 2018, according to IDC. The U.S. will continue to [BLANK], with more than 47% of the market. Software spending in China will increase 10% annually during this period, yet won't exceed 3% of the global market. China has the second-highest level of global technology spending at $200 billion, but is just seventh in software spending at about $11 billion.

Global zinc slab production rose 7.7% through April to 4.47 million metric tons after gaining just 3.3% in 2014. Chinese output continues to drive global production with almost 2 million metric tons [BLANK] through April, a 14.5% increase. Attractive 2014 treatment charges motivated Chinese smelters to produce more metal, but their significant ramp-up has pushed the refined zinc market from a 2014 deficit into a 296,815 metric ton surplus. Consequently, treatment charges have increased in 2015.

The respite during natural gas shoulder season, the period between demand stages, has been especially dull in the Northeast as the lull from lower power demand and temperate weather has pressured near-term gas prices. Marcellus prices were hovering below 80 cents per MMBtu, while the New York hub, which [BLANK] to a new low of 41 cents earlier this month, vacillated in the 80-cent range most recently. This compares with prices in northern California of over $3, similar to Henry Hub benchmarks.

Fast growth at Instagram and price gains driven by the increasing ROI of its ads support Facebook's sales outlook, helping it to elude concerns about slowing growth in ad loads on the core site. Plans for 45-60% expense growth in 2018 are a potential headwind for margins, although the company has a history of [BLANK] expense growth guidance.

Japan's wealth-management business could have hit a ceiling on a limited shift from savings to investments by households, even after five years of BOJ easing. Japanese [BLANK] just 16% of $16.7 trillion of wealth in risk assets, such as equities and bonds. Their interest in overseas investments is also muted.

Hard-disk drive maker Western Digital Corp. faces slowing growth in its primary PC market and increasing competition from alternative storage technologies such as solid-state drives. To [BLANK] competitive, Western Digital has expanded its portfolio with enterprise and hybrid hard drives aimed at hyperscale consumers. Solid-state drives are faster alternatives in both markets and, as their prices drop, Western and rival Seagate aim to increase their capacity, defining consumers' view of what is the standard.

Quanta's (PWR +3.8%) 1Q earnings beat and uncharacteristically early guidance raise was driven primarily by electric transmission, though all of the utilities contractor's core markets appear to be behaving well. We see prospects [BLANK] by its leading position in the markets for electric transmission and distribution and energy pipelines. The company's emphasis on engineering services and project financing could spur market-share gains within these businesses.

Eli Lilly's dispute with generic-drug makers over the meaning of one of three Lilly patents covering the blood thinner Effient was scheduled to be argued at a claims-interpretation (Markman) hearing on June 17. The hearing was put on hold, likely because a motion to further consolidate cases is [BLANK]. The court is expected to reschedule the Markman hearing by the end of this year. The patent at issue covers methods of administering prasugrel and aspirin, and expires in 2023.

Tata Motors's consensus sales estimates have been in decline, and now indicate a 5.3% increase for the year ending March 2016. Revenue [BLANK] 5.5% in the April-to-June quarter on a China slowdown. That reverses a trend that yielded a 13% gain for the year ended March, and a 23% jump for the previous 12-months. The introduction of the Jaguar XE, a rival to BMW's 3 Series, Daimler's Benz C-Class and VW's Audi A4, may help stem the decline. Tata Motors gets 83% of revenue from its U.K. subsidiary, Jaguar Land Rover.

The EU tobacco industry's big fear is widespread introduction of plain packaging. It's usually flagged as a move to [BLANK] children wanting to smoke, though just 5% of young children do so. However, raising tobacco duty is a deterrent. In Australia, the only country currently with plain packs, tobacco duties were increased by 25% in 2013 and 2015 and smoking rates have fallen. With affordability an issue, consumers have gravitated toward mid-priced brands. Only the U.K. passed legislation to introduce plain packs.

AT&T's most significant court battle could affect data revenue, which contributed about 50% of 2014's total, if net-neutrality rules that allow Federal Communications Commission regulation of Internet service aren't reversed. AT&T is [BLANK] the Federal Trade Commission on its "throttling" practices to avoid paying $300 million or more. AT&T's plan to bid $9 billion in an FCC spectrum auction may be delayed pending a broadcaster suit. A second broadcaster suit is holding up FCC approval of the AT&T-DirecTV deal.

Further demand growth could push palladium's price above gold's in 4Q and 2019, we believe, while platinum prices are likely to remain vulnerable to China's slowing economy, potential dollar strength and a recovery in supply. Platinum and rhodium markets will likely be in surplus at the end of 2018, but palladium will [BLANK] in deficit, in our view. Yet there are signs of possible restocking, especially from China and automakers. Platinum slid 16% in 2018 through Dec. 6, as palladium rose 12% and rhodium recovered to rise 52% after lower prices and reduced stockpiles lured bargain hunters.

The most obvious impact of FCC rules will be the potential loss of set-top box rental fees. While no operator has publicly [BLANK] rental fees, Senators Markey and Blumenthal estimate rentals at about $20 billion, 10% of $200 billion in pay-TV industry revenue (2014). Time Warner Cable's equipment rental and installation charges were $1.43 billion in 2015, 14.5% of its video revenue. The percentage may be higher for Comcast, which has 59 million boxes and a mix of costlier, more advanced equipment.

Macau's casinos are likely to see a boost in gambling revenue through the Lunar New Year despite tough year-ago comparisons, with January's 36% increase affirming the return of VIPs from China and higher mass-market demand. The upcoming opening of the MGM Cotai resort is likely to [BLANK] Macau's draw, accelerating the influx of visitors.

Las Vegas casino spending recovered after the Great Recession, though market segments that depend most on international high-rollers have struggled. In 2016, Strip-area gaming revenue rose 2% for middle-market-focused slots, but [BLANK] 2% for popular table games, such as blackjack. For the high-end game of baccarat, win fell 6% because of weaker spending by customers from China and elsewhere in Asia. Baccarat players recently left five times more dollars at the table as win than other game patrons.

The Bear Case contends that continued high levels of sovereign debt and the weakness of the European economic recovery may force policymakers to keep interest rates low for a sustained period, harming European life insurer earnings. This [BLANK] a scenario where guarantees on historic policies are higher than the yields available on current assets. The Bear Case also contends that in search of higher yields, insurers may increase exposure to more volatile or less liquid assets.

The week of May 30-June 5 features the ASCO cancer conference with key data from Eli Lilly's abemaciclib and Immunomedics' IMMU-132 in breast cancer, and Genmab-Johnson & Johnson's Darzalex CASTOR trial in earlier-lines use in multiple myeloma. FDA action (PDUFA) date is due for Teva's SD-809 in chorea [BLANK] with Huntington's disease. Alkermes presents ALKS 5461 Phase III data in depression. The FDA will release briefing documents for the advisory panel on Teva's abuse-deterrent hydrocodone pain drug.

Finance and insurance employment, an indicator of office-using demand, has grown slowly after the 2008 financial crisis-related decline. Employment in the sector is [BLANK] about 1% growth annually, slower than total employment growth of 1.3%. Amid numerous banking job cuts and reorganizations, Manhattan office rent growth has stayed strong. Technology, advertising, media and IT tenants have replaced a number of financial or law firms that are cutting jobs or shifting operations to lower-cost areas.

Oshkosh and AM General have more at stake than their larger rival, Lockheed Martin, in the three-way fight for the Army's vehicle contract known as JLTV. The $27 billion award is likely the largest federal opportunity of the decade for the smaller companies, which exclusively [BLANK] ground vehicles, such as the Humvee. The competition is a chance for Lockheed to expand beyond its core aerospace business, though this wouldn't be its top program.

Equities revenue for the largest global investment bank peers may finish the year below 2015, based on 4Q indicators, even as comparisons ease further. Revenue [BLANK] 11% year-over-year in 3Q, after a 15% drop in 2Q and 20% decrease in 1Q, according to data from Coalition Analytics. Revenue is 16% lower year-to-date. A 27% decline in equities derivatives revenue is the biggest driver. Cash equities fell 19% and prime services 8%, with flat futures and options (F&O). Revenue rose 23% in 2010-15, or 4% a year.

President-elect Donald Trump's pledge to "dismantle the Dodd-Frank Act" and replace it with new policies that encourage economic growth is feeding hopes it could be a catalyst to spur pre-emptive banking moves to New York from London. If the banking environment [BLANK] less onerous, with a moratorium on new agency regulations and the potential for dilution of bail-in requirements (orderly liquidation, as per Title 2 of Dodd-Frank), domestic, euro zone, Swiss and Asian banks could look to increase U.S. headcount.

Investment bank trading revenue may be helped by volatility's rebound from historically low levels, though sustainability is the key question. Global growth remains the core business driver and expectations in this area are key to [BLANK]. Bank regulation worldwide is increasingly focused on systemically important banks, with evolving rules likely to raise funding and capital costs. Legal risk will extend for banks, though significant 2014 accruals may reduce the aggregate profit and capital drag in 2015.

Women's and girls' clothing make up the largest segment of the U.S. apparel market, comprising almost 60% of the total value. The category's sales in the U.S. may reach $175 billion in 2016, almost [BLANK] the $96 billion market for men's and boys' apparel, according to Bureau of Economic Analysis estimates. Children's and infants' clothing represent the smallest segment in the market at $19 billion, or 7% of the total.

China's demand for gold may be slowing. Consumer gold demand in the country fell 37% in 3Q from a year earlier, the World Gold Council said, [BLANK] down global demand to 929 metric tons, the lowest in almost five years. In 2013, India's gold import restrictions helped make China the top destination for the metal. Gold prices may stay capped if China's consumer demand fails to keep pace with the 2013 peak.

Exchange-traded funds focused on emerging market debt saw rare outflows in August amid rising geopolitical tensions surrounding North Korea saber rattling and terrorist attacks in Barcelona. These funds [BLANK] $339 million in net outflows over the two weeks ended Aug. 23, equivalent to 0.7% of AUM. Emerging debt ETFs remain among the most popular of fixed-income ETF assets, with $14.5 billion in inflows year-to-date or 31% of AUM, outpaced only by U.S. high grade corporate ETFs.

Rising fuel prices are pulling 3Q profit forecasts lower as airline competition keeps fares from increasing fast enough to compensate. Airline fuel costs were already [BLANK], with the average price of New York jet fuel $1.65 a gallon in 3Q17. The average for 3Q is $2.15, and will climb unless oil prices drop. Fuel makes up 20-30% of airline costs.

Nvidia and Samsung could resolve their ongoing patent spat by 3Q. The parties are scheduled to begin a second jury trial in Virginia [BLANK] Samsung's infringement claims, and they're expecting a final decision in Samsung's International Trade Commission case by May 5. Settlement could yield a patent cross-license and agreement to drop all pending litigation and patent challenges. Samsung may also be vying for the rights to manufacture Nvidia chips currently made by Taiwan Semiconductor.

An acceleration in U.S. retail sales since early October bodes well for momentum heading into the holidays and 4Q. As sales likely rose further over the Halloween weekend, retail sales for the month should [BLANK] higher, in our view. Sales through Oct. 26 rose 2%. Apparel sales outpaced total retail, up 2.8%, after being unchanged through mid-month, largely amid better traffic trends. Sales at family-apparel and children's clothing stores appeared healthy. Athletic and street-footwear stores gained 9.1%, while fashion-footwear retailers sales advanced 7.5%. First Data's figures are leading indicators for retail sales, taken directly from point of sale without estimates. The figures capture all noncash sales at retailers that use First Data processing services. First Data is the largest U.S. processor of credit-card data.

E*Trade may see heightened regulation if the company passes the $50 billion in assets threshold for systemically important financial institutions. In May, CFO Mike Pizzi said that the company [BLANK] to pause its growth - currently at $49 billion - to study the regulatory landscape. Regulatory efforts to increase the threshold failed in 2016. The Fed and some Democrats had voiced support for a $100 billion threshold, and the proposal may come again in 2017, especially if Donald Trump becomes president.

Written arguments have concluded on motions to dismiss lawsuits against Marcellus acreage lessees, such as Chesapeake and Anadarko, paving the way for a court decision likely in 1Q. Defendants [BLANK] the legal sufficiency of the complaints, including antitrust and racketeering allegations, and will likely pare a number of plaintiffs' claims. Neither party is expected to win this early skirmish outright, but partial wins could make settling the case more attractive.

Disciplined pricing and underwriting should enhance results in Hartford's flagship commercial unit, historically a leader in the small and middle market. Clinical and regulatory catalysts are the main binary events that alter biotech share prices. Valuation multiples of U.S. automakers have fallen faster than the broader market as solid -- albeit flat -- demand and a favorable shift toward trucks from cars in the domestic market has been overwhelmed by negative catalysts. Large pharma companies working on immuno-oncology targets appear focused on eight key targets as potential combinations with their PD-1/L1 drugs. Share prices for branded apparel and accessories companies have improved year-to-date, even as sales and margins are crimped by heightened competition, fewer tourists due to a stronger dollar and steep promotions. Vanguard's exchange-traded funds have cross-generational appeal, with the company's products making up at least half of the top ETF investments for baby boomers, Gen Xers and millennials holding TD Ameritrade accounts. Anheuser-Busch InBev NV has cleared all the major regulatory hurdles to acquiring SABMiller. Shareholder approval is all that's left, with management looking for this to be [BLANK] by Oct. 10. Universal's horror film "Ouija" is projected to take the top spot at the box office in its debut weekend, even though boxoffice.com lowered expectations by about 3% to $28 million. Our latest Equity Market Minute examines the growth vs. value trade styles in the U.S. as the performance of the former continues to dominate on stronger earnings expectations and a broad expansion in market valuation multiples this cycle. Growth stocks are expected to expand bottom-line earnings faster than value peers over the next 24 months, which [BLANK] a continuation in this trend unless a bearish valuation environment emerges.

A combination of rising inflation and slowing economic growth poses a headache for Brazilian policy makers. Inflation accelerated to 6.8% in September, above the central bank's upper target band, [BLANK] a 25 bp increase in the benchmark interest rate to 11.25%. With average bank lending rates already at 21%, any further increases may significantly depress credit demand. GDP growth forecasts for 2015 have been cut 100 bps in the past six months to 1.2%.

Great Plains Energy Inc. is one of the slowest-growing Midwest electric utilities, with most of its rate base in Missouri, where many utilities earn only a fraction of their authorized returns on equity due to a challenging regulatory environment. Wholesale-vehicle prices are deteriorating in an oversupplied used-car market, according to Black Book. Less expensive used vehicles may [BLANK] consumers if prices of new cars remain high. Licensing deal volumes in 2Q were in-line with the prior-year period, with more than 100 deals struck for the sixth successive quarter. Catalonia's unemployment rate is higher than other industrial regions in Spain, topping 20% in June versus the Madrid area at 19% percent and the Basque region at 16.1%. The narrowing gap in 4G population coverage among European mobile carriers will likely sap pricing power for those that have led in rollouts. South Korea's four biggest banks will come under less pressure to raise provisions, thanks to earlier restructurings and an improving economy. Given the significant asset writedowns in 4Q for many oil producers, the importance of earnings growth will be underscored through 2015, with the lowest-cost producers likely to emerge as the outperformers. Retail is at a watershed moment. Metals prices may benefit from a Donald Trump presidency, with silver in the middle sweet spot as a precious metal with industrial applications. Unlike widely held and stored gold, about 50% of silver supply disappears into industrial applications. Higher prices are likely necessary to incentivize the recycling of supply. The spread between office REIT dividend yields and the 10-year Treasury ended 2017 well below the elevated levels experienced during most of 2016. At 124 bps, the spread is basically in-line with early 2017 levels, after rising then [BLANK] during the year. Mizuho's unrealized gains rose 28% in the December quarter and may continue to increase if BOJ easing fuels stock and bond markets this year. ThyssenKrupp's MULTI elevator uses a rope-free, magnetic levitation system that reduces the footprint of the elevator shaft in building construction and drastically cut waiting times. MULTI is the result of several years of engineering effort, and the company has a 1998 patent [BLANK] on the technology. Yet the overall spending is less than 10 million euros, suggesting the barrier to replicate the technology may not be that high. Competitors have also been prioritizing R&D since 2017 mainly in the maintenance arena. Otis, Schindler, Kone, ThyssenKrupp and Mitsubishi are the top-five elevator and escalator manufacturers in the world by sales. Otis is the largest by sales, followed by Kone and Schindler, with annual sales of just over $10 billion.

Teva is fighting to protect its $3 billion Copaxone franchise in a consolidated lawsuit against generic-drug makers over their FDA applications to market a copy of the multiple sclerosis treatment's 40-milligram dosage, used three times a week. Antitrust review of AB InBev's proposed purchase of SABMiller is proceeding in multiple jurisdictions and seems to be on track. Safety equipment and creature comforts have caused vehicle weight gain that will require lighter materials to meet fuel economy goals of 2025. The PowerShares Active U.S. Real Estate Fund (PSR) is up 8.5% this month, leading all U.S.-focused real estate exchange-traded funds. The rising sales contribution from higher-margin luxury skincare items may cushion the profitability of Asian cosmetics companies from higher spending on marketing and new shops in 2018. Continued Investment in on-purpose propylene is projected by major technology providers, though falling oil prices may have trimmed the rate. The adoption of the coal levy in Germany may force RWE, Vattenfall, E.ON and EnBW to shut lignite and coal-fired power plants. Canadian Oil Sands' reported September production at the Syncrude project averaged 63,300 barrels a day after a process fire on Aug. 29. ADP's sales head-count growth should support bookings growth goals in fiscal 2018. Core payroll remains healthy, [BLANK] stable recurring revenue, with cloud-based solutions driving long-term growth. Increased market volatility forced clients to pause spending in 2Q, lengthening the sales cycle for FactSet's customer base. Big U.S. financial firms would face an immediate threat of being dismantled under a Bernie Sanders presidency. A ruling is likely in 2Q in an appeal by several pension funds of a 2015 dismissal of their lawsuit alleging several stock exchanges gave high-frequency traders unfair advantages. The competitive landscape for supermarkets such as Kroger, Whole Foods and Ahold has become crowded with new entrants in the past 10 years. A bill in Congress banning the FCC from regulating the Internet like a utility could affect Google, Netflix, Yahoo! and Amazon.com. Competition in renewable diesel is rising, with Neste Oil pressured by Eni's new facility, as well as Renewable Energy Group's acquisition of Dynamic Fuels and Valero's Diamond Green Diesel. A discrepancy between imports from Canada reported by the U.S. Census and exports to the U.S. reported by Statistics Canada seems to have been fixed in August. The world's largest packaged-food companies are expected by consensus to generate a median 11% increase in earnings per share in 2016, supported by stable costs, share buybacks and the integration of acquisitions. Dividends are estimated by consensus to rise a median 10% in 2016.

The U.K.'s decision to require greater corporate disclosure on outsourced labor policies and practices is intended to improve labor conditions in emerging markets by naming and shaming the offenders. The U.K. rule may lead to better working conditions in the supply chain of companies manufacturing in emerging markets.

Platinum's underperformance vs. palladium may be set to reverse, based on consensus. The use of blockchain technology for tracking and record-keeping continues to gain momentum across a wide range of industries, including food, manufacturing and health care. Salesforce's high premium for its proposed MuleSoft deal was probably driven by the growth expectations for the API market, given its disruptive effect on traditional middleware software and exposure to the cloud PaaS segment. Congress' FDA user-fee legislation calls for aggregate generic industry payments to increase 65% to $494 million annually from $299 million now. The biosimilar industry's fees come to a much smaller total but would also see a significant increase, more than [BLANK] from $20 million to $45 million in 2018. The House version, which passed on July 12, includes language aimed at prioritizing applications for generic competitors of older, off-patent drugs that have seen prices spike or are in short supply.

Molycorp will request court approval on Jan. 8 of the disclosure statement for its Oaktree-backed plan of reorganization and proposed bidding procedures. Strong European airline expansion is pressuring fares, hurting profit and will lead to higher pilot costs.
