A Norwegian failure or slowdown would unwind a large fleet and orders of Boeing 737s and Rolls-Royce powered 787s.

Weak traffic continues to plague the restaurant industry, as monthly data give little hope for a return to sales growth in 2H, even with easier comparisons. The impact of Hurricane Irma, [BLANK] to be 40 bps for September, pushed a modest same-store sales increase to a decline for the month.

Xcel's dividend increases over the past three years were 6-7% vs. a historical annual rate of less than 5%. Its forecast of 5-7% dividend growth over the next five years [BLANK] the 4-6% range it projects for earnings growth, and the gains will be driven in part by a higher dividend payout ratio. Xcel has historically maintained its dividend payout ratio at less than 60%, yet the 65% midpoint of its 60-70% targeted range is closer to its regulated peer average.

A constant focus of solar-energy technology spending is in pursuit of increasing product efficiency, while lowering costs. This trend is also driving innovation in home-energy management systems and integration with battery storage.

CMS's consolidated return on equity has exceeded 12% over several years, significantly above the 10% average for its regulated utility peers. The higher consolidated return on equity is partly a result of the legacy parent-level debt it took on in the early 2000s when CMS [BLANK] heavily in international operations, which it later sold. The company says that its utilities have consistently earned at or above the 10.3% authorized return on equity, which is under review as part of ongoing rate cases.

A 99.6% plunge since 2009 left an exchange-traded fund that bets on share volatility with about $1.2 billion, out of $6.7 billion in inflows. Returns for the iPath S&P 500 VIX Short-Term Futures ETN (VXX) were [BLANK] in two ways. Apartment transactions fell 27% to $16.3 billion in January from $22.5 billion in December, according to Real Capital Analytics data. Garden-style deal volume, 69% of all transactions, [BLANK] 3% from December to $11.3 billion. Mid- and high-rise volume declined 53% sequentially, yet was up 70% on the year to $5.1 billion. Cap rates fell 10 bps to 5.9% for garden-style properties, while remaining flat at 4.7% for mid- and high-rise deals. Overall apartment cap rates of 5.7% were at an all-time low.

Technology has the potential to obviate huge fines and cut operating costs or speed new-business acquisition for banks globally. New anti-terror and anti-money laundering rules will continue to heap pressure on banks' time and staff to fulfill know-your-customer checks and tick the [BLANK] numbers of regulatory boxes. BNP Paribas' record 2014 $9 billion fine, and multi-million dollar settlements at Standard Chartered and HSBC, detail the cost and severity of falling foul of sanction and money-laundering rules.

Celegne's quarterly gross margin grew to 95.1%, its highest in the past decade, driven by top-selling hematology drug Revlimid. The drug had strong international and U.S. growth, [BLANK] consensus by 3%. Sales of Pomalyst and Vidaza also beat consensus. Abraxane, Celgene's second-fastest growing drug, missed estimates by 9%. Forward P/Es for the public Class I rails have traded at an average 11.2% premium to the S&P 500 in the past five years. As the Bina Bawi field in Iraqi Kurdistan turns out to hold natural gas rather than oil, operator OMV decided to sell its 35% stake to partner Genel. Combining Bina Bawi's 4.9 trillion cubic feet of contingent resources with the 3.75 trillion cubic feet at Genel's nearby Miran field will [BLANK] the investment rationale for the required gas export pipelines for both fields. Cisco has until mid-March to file its initial responses in seven inter partes review petitions filed by Arista in 4Q. The Patent Trial and Appeal Board has already denied review on earlier Arista challenges that took aim at three of the of the patents.

Cornerstone's slowing growth in the fragmented human capital management market may increase pressure on the company to consider strategic options, including a sale or going private. Cornerstone is currently [BLANK] below the median valuation of cloud peers as the company's sales growth slows.

Citigroup's Dec. 5 comments on 4Q trading revenue point to a slight year-over-year decline vs. modest core growth signaled by JPMorgan and Bank of America the day prior. We expect Citi's more negative view [BLANK] its higher exposure to underperforming FICC. Rates and currencies momentum didn't carry over into 4Q, particularly in G10 rates, as Citi had anticipated. CFO John Gerpsach said equities continues to do well and growth will be aided by an easier comparison. Citi's view is a bit less optimistic than its mid-October expectations for modest growth, while JPMorgan and BofA were more stable. On net, we currently expect muted trading-revenue growth across global peers. Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley, Deutsche Bank, Credit Suisse and Citi earn relatively more from trading across the largest global investment bank peers.

While the jury is still out, preclinical models support the notion of combining a cancer vaccine and immuno-oncology (IO) therapies to induce more effective antitumor immune responses, with Bristol-Myers Squibb leading combination trials. An immunologically quiescent tumor (cold tumor) [BLANK] poorly to single-agent checkpoint inhibitors. Cancer vaccines need to induce effector immune-cell infiltration into the tumors, converting a cold tumor into an immunologically "hot" tumor, to enhance IO drugs like Opdivo.

Large semiconductor makers with diverse capabilities, such as Qualcomm and Intel, are exposed to sales increases as device makers favor chips with integrated feature sets, according to the Bull Case, even as costs rise on higher chip complexity. Smart, [BLANK] homes and expanding auto electronic content create opportunities for niche companies such as Nvidia and NXP. Improving demand for PC and for server chips from hyperscale consumers for data centers may stem sales declines caused by falling smartphone prices.

L-3's leverage, as measured under its bank-debt agreement, was 2.5x, less than the limit of 4x, it said during its 2Q earnings presentation. That may rise to 2.8x at year-end, based on the $3.9 billion of debt L-3 [BLANK] on its balance sheet, the midpoint of its full-year sales forecast range and targeted operating margin, depreciation and interest expense. Ebitda may be about $1.4 billion, a 31% cushion relative to the bank covenant.

Regulators should adopt a more lenient enforcement position on MiFID II, giving an informal grace period after Jan. 3. Meanwhile, as banks are keen to price competitively, regulators are going to be keeping a close eye on prices to [BLANK] they're not too low, because this could still constitute an inducement.

Despite drama in Washington, cycle-high valuations and an outlook that the Federal Reserve is likely to scale back its balance sheet, stocks climbed to new peaks this week. Following along, the CBOE Volatility Index (VIX) [BLANK] a new low for the cycle.

With few organic-growth opportunities, regional casinos rely on upgrades, M&A and rising employment to expand. Same-store win [BLANK] 1% in 2016, rose 1% in 2017, then ebbed moderately in 1Q and April, when state gaming results were dampened by the effects of a less favorable calendar. Cost cuts have buoyed Ebitda in a mature industry.

The $4.4 billion in projected political ad revenue for the 2016 presidential election could be threatened if Donald Trump secures the Republican nomination. Trump has [BLANK] on the media to convey his message, spending half as much in February as party rival Ted Cruz. As of Feb. 29, the most recent date for which data is available, Trump reported $1.3 million in his coffers, about $30 million less than Democrat Hillary Clinton. In comparison, Mitt Romney's campaign had $7.3 million at the end of February 2012.

Demand from China's construction equipment and commercial-vehicle boom may lift machine-tool sales in 2H. After an industry lull in 2016, China's machine-tool demand is rising as heavy machinery makers [BLANK] up spending to meet construction demand. There has been a recent shift upmarket and sales of higher-end products such as machining centers are rising. One reason is because manufacturers can win business orders by using higher-quality or foreign-branded machines.

The scale of Thai banks' lending recovery this year will be determined largely by the pace of public investment in infrastructure, as domestic demand remains tepid and economic expansion will be driven by external factors. Business loans continue to [BLANK] banks' balance sheets, followed by consumer lending.

Rising interest rates may slow the recent health-care REIT M&A boom, as REITs have used low-cost debt and equity capital to consolidate the mostly-fragmented industry. Health-care REITs have [BLANK] $7.9 billion of unsecured debt in 2015, locking in credit before rates rise. This year has had the most M&A deals since 2011, exceeding 2014's industry volume by $4.1 billion. Higher interest rates would raise borrowing costs, while the inverse correlation with stock prices may make equity financing less lucrative.

Automakers are looking for lighter materials such as high-strength steel and aluminum to reduce vehicle weights to meet stringent fuel-efficiency requirements, while maintaining safety. High-strength steel can be more attractive than aluminum because of lower costs, better availability of production facilities, and less time and money [BLANK] to rebuild carmakers' production lines. The U.S. has implemented Corporate Average Fuel Economy standards for vehicles. Europe and China have also announced efficiency targets.

Lessors' uncommitted orders are a likely source of narrow-body aircraft for Chinese airlines. Through 2020, Ascend [BLANK] over 1,000 unallocated single-aisle aircraft. Over 300 of these orders are from lessors in the region, not that those elsewhere would avoid the opportunity to place aircraft. Combined with about 1,500 unallocated orders in the airframers' backlog, the total could likely meet most if not all the Chinese airlines' needs over the next five years, even in optimistic scenarios.

The minimal increase in safety issues after the addition of immuno-oncology to chemotherapy justifies the combination's use if its efficacy vs. chemotherapy alone is as good as that seen in Merck's Keynote-021 trial. Fewer deaths and treatment discontinuations [BLANK] in the Keytruda combination arm, while treatment-related adverse events were similar. The Keytruda combination did see a higher number of grade 3-4 events. Early data from Roche's trial showed a good safety profile for Tecentriq plus chemotherapy.

Apartment construction has been rising since 2009 with both permits and starts in 2015 at or above pre-recession levels. Reis forecasts that apartment completions will [BLANK] 217,000 units in 2016, which would be 56% above the previous cyclical high of 139,000. New supply has been outstripped by demand, keeping occupancy rates elevated and driving accelerating rent growth in most markets. Reis forecasts that supply will outpace demand in 2016 in 29 of the 30 largest apartment markets.

The West Coast expansion of life-science companies may aid rents for traditional office owners, as the sector accounts for a portion of the new supply. Lab space typically [BLANK] higher ceilings and sophisticated water, air and electrical systems. This makes conversion to or from traditional office space difficult and costly. As buildings are developed in Mission Bay, San Francisco and Lake Union, Seattle, they limit the space available that traditional office tenants would otherwise seek.

Companies operating only domestically, along with smaller peers, may soon gain a competitive edge as tax advantages available to multinationals in the EU are about to end. These firms will also escape disclosure rules that [BLANK] to multinationals. Tax burdens on domestic companies are 30% higher and the EU estimates tax avoidance costs EU nations as much as $80 billion a year in lost revenue. Professional-services firms may also win more business as companies rapidly adjust tax strategy.

Elevated senior housing construction is concentrated in several markets, mostly in Texas. San Antonio and Houston have the most independent living construction, while Dallas also faces [BLANK] senior housing supply. Of the three large-capitalization health-care REITs, Texas makes up 12% of senior housing net operating income for HCP, 7% for Ventas and 4% for Health Care REIT. In a Bear Case, new assets will hurt occupancy and rents at existing facilities in these markets.

Helped, in part, by easier year-ago sales comparisons, children's apparel mid-month same-store sales rose 3.6%, according to First Data's non-cash point-of-sale data. Traffic [BLANK] 2.7% and ticket, or amount spent, was up 0.9%. The gain from Sept. 30-Oct. 17 was in contrast to last year's 5.9% mid-month drop. Same-store sales for the period were better than the overall retail's 1.7% gain. This bodes well for 3Q sales and margins at retailers such as Children's Place, Carters and Gymboree.

Procter & Gamble's 4Q organic sales were unchanged, trailing peers' 2% to 6% range. P&G, set to [BLANK] a category and brand refocus toward the end of 2016, reported fiscal 2015 adjusted EPS of $3.52, down 16% vs. the prior year. Currency cut 6% from FY15 reported sales and 9% from 4Q. CEO A.G. Lafley said forex will be challenging in fiscal 2016, denting sales by 4% to 5%. Scope to raise prices on its portfolio limits growth. A 3% price rise in 4Q reduced volume by the same amount.

Fox's domestic cable networks showed resilience, yet the tone overseas was somber. U.S. ads jumped 12% on high ratings at Fox News and FS1, while affiliate revenue is [BLANK] to get a 2H boost on renewals. In contrast, rupee demonetization hurt its Indian STAR cable networks, triggering a 6% drop in international ads. Broadcast momentum, which gained from the U.S. election and World Series, will continue through 2Q thanks to the Super Bowl. Lower theatrical revenue weighed on Film while lower expenses aided profit.

While hedge funds use ETFs to invest in, short and borrow stocks from, they have also become some of the loudest critics of the hot new investment vehicle as well as passive investing in general. This "frenemy" relationship comes as hedge funds struggle to [BLANK] in a market going increasingly passive.

Rules and regulations governing access to cloud-based data are critical for increased adoption of cloud services. While there's been widespread acceptance of cloud-based data storage, privacy and security concerns may [BLANK] further adoption, particularly with sensitive data such as tax information. Safeguarding data and limiting the government's access without proper authorization are necessary for increased adoption and critical for providers of cloud-based service such as Microsoft, Amazon, Google and IBM.

Medical device valuations remain below the 10-year average on a P/E basis vs. the S&P 500, even as consensus long-term EPS growth is rising. EPS growth is [BLANK] due to new product launches such as transcatheter heart valves from Edwards Lifesciences and Medtronic, as well as stronger demand for implantable defibrillators. While price declines remain a concern, an aging U.S. population and pending new therapies may sustain higher EPS growth.

General Electric's turnaround will speed up under new CEO Larry Culp vs. the 1-3 years in GE's current plan and should include cutting R&D and corporate costs that outpace peer averages to drive almost $2 billion in annual savings. Culp's decentralization of Danaher suggests cuts beyond that, while higher interest rates should [BLANK] pension pains.

Mondelez International's operating margin has been fairly stable at 10% of sales since the company split from Kraft Foods Group in 2012. The company is targeting an [BLANK] operating margin of 14% for 2015, excluding some costs from the divesture of its coffee business this year, up from 12% in 2014. The expected results would highlight its ability to streamline its supply chain and reduce overhead costs through zero-based budgeting.

Fast Retailing Co. will increasingly go head-to-head with H&M and Inditex's Zara as it expands abroad. Uniqlo, its flagship chain, [BLANK] on affordable clothing including the AIRism, Heattech and Ultra Light Down products. Its other brands include GU, Theory, Comptoir des Cotonniers, Princesse tam.tam and J Brand. Fast Retailing is opening outlets in Greater China, South Korea, Singapore, Malaysia, Thailand, Australia, Germany and the U.S. to offset the shrinking population in its home market of Japan.

Large-cap utilities are buying regulated assets and divesting merchant generation. PPL and Duke sold merchant plants to [BLANK] pure-play regulated entities. Hybrid Exelon bought Pepco to become more regulated. Electric utilities Duke, Southern and Dominion are acquiring faster-growing regulated natural gas distributors. A low cost of capital makes U.S. power assets targets of private equity and offshore buyers, as in the Fortis-ITC deal and Energy Capital's plan with Dynegy to buy Engie's power plants.

Growth of public clouds from Amazon, Facebook and Google is commoditizing technology hardware. This is amplified by data-center and public-cloud growth in [BLANK] markets. Many companies in these regions, particularly in Asia, use lower-cost, non-branded hardware made by vendors such as Quanta, Inventec and Sugon, relying less on HP, Dell, EMC or NetApp. This increases competition and damps pricing and margins. Branded companies are pushing into smaller, corporate clouds and enhancing services to maintain sales.

With exchanges owning assets outside the U.S., revenue growth at Intercontinental Exchange and CME probably was curtailed by a strong dollar in 4Q, after Nasdaq reported a 1% decline in 4Q earnings due to the impact of foreign exchange rates. The euro depreciated 4.2% vs. the dollar in 4Q, while the Swedish krona [BLANK] 7.6%. On an organic basis, excluding the foreign exchange impact, net revenue at Nasdaq rose 3%. The exchange rate move offset higher revenue in European equity derivatives and cash equities.

Vehicle miles traveled in the U.S. rose 0.7% in December, down from November's 1.1% and below the monthly average of 1.2% in 2017. Increases in road use were held down by elevated fuel costs in 2017 and may remain [BLANK] into 2018 as gas prices in January rose 8.5% from a year ago to the highest since 2014. The slowdown should provide auto insurers some relief from pressures on claim frequency. Still, economic growth typically leads to greater road use and may offset a portion of the effect from fuel costs.

Wells Fargo still faces several lawsuits and investigations related to various alleged misconduct and scandals even after its $1 billion settlement with the CFPB and OCC on April 20. Foreign-exchange and wealth-management probes could [BLANK] hundreds of millions of dollars. The bank also faces a CFPB probe for potentially improper freezing and closing of accounts. Probes related to the fake-account scandal may also result in more fines, and customer class-action claims could add to a proposed $142 million settlement.

All six public Class I railroads are expected to record EPS gains in 1Q, rising 20.9% on average, based on consensus. Canadian Pacific may gain the most at 51.9%, [BLANK] by easier comparisons and the continued realization of its management team's strategy. Consensus expects Kansas City Southern's EPS to gain the least at only 3.4%, due mainly to the deterioration of the Mexican peso and slower volume growth, especially in crude and energy-related segments such as metals and sand.

Molycorp will seek bankruptcy judge Christopher Sontchi's approval to borrow $135 million from secured lender Oaktree on July 20. Molycorp extracted some concessions from Oaktree since $21 million in interim financing was approved July 2, including Oaktree's agreement that $254 million in pre-petition debt wouldn't [BLANK] to debtor-in-possession status. The creditors committee may be able to gain further concessions, such as expanded parameters for its ability to challenge Oaktree's liens.

Perhaps foreshadowing challenges to the Interior Department's offshore oil well rule, compliance cost estimates from companies and a trade group range from 28 to 36 times higher than the agency's assessment. Exxon Mobil and Chevron also commented that the proposed rule's margin requirements may make it impossible to [BLANK] some wells, including into known reserves, resulting in stranded assets. Companies have requested tweaks in some technical standards and compliance timeline flexibility.

Asia's largest power utilities trade at an average forward price-to-book value of 1.18x, up 3% this year. The jump [BLANK] an 11% gain in the average share price and a 6% increase in one-year forward book value per share. The median P/B is now about 16% higher than the five-year average of 1.02x. The highest valuation in the group is 2.81x at CGN Power, driven by a rally in China's clean-energy segment. The lowest is Kepco's 0.45x, traditionally the group's laggard.

Del Frisco's cut its forecast range for earnings per share to 90 cents to 94 cents for the year, from 94 cents to 98 cents, citing delays in opening new restaurants, reduced sales expectations for the Chicago Double Eagle restaurant and a shift in its reporting period. The opening delays will result in a loss of about 19 operating weeks and may [BLANK] down restaurant-level Ebitda. Delayed municipal approvals also are limiting use of the location in Palm Beach, Florida.

Senior housing cap rates traditionally are tied to interest rates, but the prospect of oversupply in a number of markets is changing this trend. On a rolling 12-month basis, senior housing cap rates are up 40 bps since June 2015, while 10-Year Treasury yields have [BLANK] nearly 90 bps to a multiyear low. Oversupply in a number of southern markets is lowering occupancies and NOI gains, and appears to be driving pricing more than interest rates in the near term.

Ambac and JPMorgan have been pushed by the judge to settle the insurer's $768 million mortgage-bond lawsuit against units of the bank. Yet the parties may [BLANK] to wait for a ruling on JPMorgan's bid to toss fraud claims because the winner of the motion likely gains negotiating leverage. JPMorgan settled similar suits by bond insurers Assured and Syncora, making settlement likely in the Ambac case too. Based on the Syncora accord, this suit may have a settlement value exceeding $400 million.

United Rentals' stock price has correlated 68% to Ebitda per share since 2000, compared with a negative 49% correlation to free cash flow per share. The latter may be [BLANK] by the cyclical capital spending requirements in the rental equipment business. When sales and Ebitda are rising, the company raises its capital investment spending substantially, reducing free cash flow, and scales back as market conditions weaken.

Snap and MuleSoft could be harbingers for large tech IPOs in 2017 after a decline in average deal size and total IPO volume in 2016. More private unicorns may [BLANK] public markets to raise new rounds of funding amid improving business sentiment, coupled with less availability of private capital and venture capitalists deploying their capital on early-stage, not late-stage, companies. Companies with a recurring subscription model and a large customer base may be of keen interest.

Exchanges, principal trading firms and other market participants are waiting for the CFTC to respond to calls to split up a proposal on algorithmic trading. In recent comments, industry groups asked the agency to focus on risk controls and [BLANK] off provisions on source code and third-party algorithms. Concerns on how to measure the number of "AT persons," or those engaged in automatic trades, were also submitted. The CFTC will have to quickly decide which provisions to drop if it wants to finalize the rule in 2016.

Organic expansion has firmed up after a disappointing 2Q as passive investments in Canada posted the second-strongest monthly flows this year, with ETFs gaining in August. Mutual fund flows [BLANK] weak, despite positive signs in July. Mutual funds are trailing the 2% organic gains of 3Q17, suggesting little support for 3Q earnings.

Omnicom's 2017 organic sales growth outlook is cautious at 3-3.5% on political uncertainties. While the company should benefit from a host of account wins including McDonald's, Volkswagen and an expansion of its AT&T relationship, foreign exchange will remain a drag and may [BLANK] 1Q revenue by 1.25%. Sales also may be hurt by the disposition of lower-margin businesses as Omnicom prunes its portfolio. Yet Omnicom continues to focus on margins and expects to drive a 30-bp expansion to 14.1% in 2017.

FTR's Truck Loadings Index rose 1.9% to 130.8 in May from a year ago, the 55th straight monthly gain. Flatbed equipment led, rising 6.8%; while dry-van, which [BLANK] more than a third of total loads, increased just 1.7%. FTR expects the index to rise 2% this year, slightly outpacing consensus expectations of 1.9% U.S. GDP growth. The sluggish economy, looser truck capacity and persistently high inventory should continue to limit load growth into 2017.

Toshiba could seek Chinese buyers for its nuclear business, as China's 13th Five Year Plan intends to double nuclear power by 2020. A deal is likely to [BLANK] the U.S. operations given Westinghouse' agreements with Southern Company and Scana and the related liabilities. Toshiba could face problems in selling its nuclear business if there are flaws related to Westinghouse' AP1000 nuclear equipment design. China's capital flight controls may also be an obstacle to a deal.

The average price of Manhattan office transactions almost quadrupled to $814 a square foot in December since early 2010, according to Real Capital Analytics. Prior to 2015, nearby suburbs [BLANK] behind as investors, especially sovereign wealth funds, targeted urban assets as solid long-term investments even at high prices. In 2015, however, Long Island office values rose 45%, topping the Manhattan gain of 14%. Northern New Jersey trailed with a gain of just 5%, despite improving from recent years.

A stay has been lifted in a Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac shareholder lawsuit in Delaware, one of several legal challenges to an amendment of the 2008 U.S. bailout of the government-sponsored enterprises. The suit, filed in 2015, was temporarily stayed as the U.S. unsuccessfully tried to [BLANK] the various cases in a Washington, D.C., federal court. The lawsuits allege that the 2012 amendment, known as the "net-worth sweep," improperly diverts Fannie and Freddie profits to the U.S. Treasury.

Sales at children's apparel stores weakened in November, turning negative after three straight months of gains, according to First Data's non-cash point-of-sales figures. Comparable sales from Nov. 1-30 [BLANK] 1.8%. The decline was driven entirely by a 3.4% drop in transactions. Ticket, or amount spent, was up 1.7%. Higher ticket may have come from lean inventory and fewer discounts. Sales may be weak, but higher ticket may help 4Q margins at retailers such as Children's Place, Carter's and Gymboree.

The rising clout of millennials and female investors may boost emphasis on companies' sustainability performance given both demographics' stated concerns about such issues. Of all demographics, millennials lead in terms of interest in social impact [BLANK] (85%), and in follow-through of their concerns with 28% making such investments, based on a U.S. Trust survey of high net-worth investors. About 25% of baby boomers and men held similar views. Millennials may outgrow those sentiments as their parents have done.

Greenhill said entering this year that, barring another Brexit-like shock, announced European M&A should improve from a tough 2016. Management [BLANK] strong completed volume last year, which helped boost reported revenue despite weaker announcements. The lull may drag on fees early this year even as a pickup in deal announcements could increasingly support revenue. European announcements gained 12% year-over-year through Feb. 15. and would have more than doubled excluding a large 2016 transaction.

China's imports of iron ore and metallurgical coal, both used to make steel, have contracted this year and trail expectations. A slowdown in China's property market has led steel production to [BLANK] since the start of the year, the first drop in two decades. The slump may further damp global prices, already down 21% in 2015, given that China accounts for almost 73% of the global seaborne iron-ore trade and uses 19% of coking coal.

The large and expanding sweet and savory snacks market is concentrated, with PepsiCo's Frito-Lay division capturing almost 31% of global retail sales. After PepsiCo, the market is relatively fragmented, with no one entity [BLANK] above a 3% share. Kellogg, the second-largest competitor at 2.4%, has prioritized snacks as an important driver to its growth since it bought Pringles from Procter & Gamble in 2012. The U.S. has the highest per-capita snacks consumption, followed by Ireland and Netherlands.

A GAO study on "too-big-to-fail" is expected July 31 at a Senate Banking hearing. Senators Sherrod Brown and David Vitter [BLANK] the inquiry into government support of big banks and expect it to confirm the banks are able to borrow at below-market interest rates. They want this subsidy to end to allow community banks to better compete. Polling has Republicans winning the Senate, which would kill Brown and Vitter's effort, S. 798, to make banks to hold more capital.

Virtual and augmented reality growth may affect sales of companies in stages, as the technology is expected to go mainstream by 2020. Nvidia, AMD, Sony and HTC may [BLANK] visible sales effects in the near term on demand from gamers, while larger companies such as Facebook, Intel, Google and Microsoft gear up for longer-term growth. Apple and Snapchat may be potential entrants, likely in AR, as the iPhone giant seeks its next big product and Snapchat shows signs of interest by releasing its Spectacles camera glasses.

Fast-casual chains, including Chipotle and Panera, are the least robust Twitter users across restaurants, averaging about 42 tweets a month during the past year. They trail casual dining (46 tweets), pizza chains (63) and family dining (101), which are using the platform to [BLANK] with customers and create excitement around their brands as part of an overall social media strategy. Fast-food reigns with an average 415 tweets, followed by coffee at 361.

As a relatively new company with a limited portfolio of products, all of which are electric vehicles at a time when low gasoline prices are motivating drivers to larger vehicles, Tesla needs to tap into the demand dynamic of its largest markets. EV technology is expensive relative to comparable vehicles, though the company may [BLANK] buyers more willing to pay more if the vehicles are configured as SUVs. The existing Model S and forthcoming Model X SUV are too expensive to become high-volume contributors.

Sinopec results for 2015 were mixed, with cheap oil helping the refining & chemical units, while dragging down E&P to a loss. It [BLANK] its dividend payout to 56%, even as net income fell to 32.4 billion yuan ($5 billion). Sinopec expects capex this year to drop 10.6%, while oil production is projected to fall 5%. Gas output is set to rise 18%, but the November 2015 price cut may depress revenue. Sinopec has a stronger downstream presence than rival PetroChina, which may help it offset the drag from cheap oil.

The average 5.2% European telecom carrier consensus dividend yield is the highest among all industries within the Stoxx 600 Europe Index. This suggests investor concerns on cash flow generation continue to [BLANK] on industry valuations, amid extended capital spending for fiber rollouts and upgrades to 4G. Consolidation across Europe's mobile markets may help narrow the dividend yield gap to the wider market.

Japan, the world's largest LNG consumer, imported 30.7 million tons in the first four months of 2017, 5% more than a year ago. The nation's LNG imports surged after the Fukushima-related nuclear shutdown, [BLANK] at about 88 million tons a year in 2012-14 and fell to 83 million tons in 2016. Anti-nuclear sentiments may delay the pace of reactor restarts. Only Kyushu Electric's two Sendai units, Shikoku Electric's Ikata 3 and Kansai Electric's Takahama 4, with total capacity of 3.5 gigawatts are operating.

Agilent's updated view on fiscal 2016 will be closely watched after management acknowledged that its initial outlook provided with 4Q was conservative. This [BLANK] from its observation of a challenging macroeconomic environment, particularly in chemical and energy end-markets. Agilent's guidance for 2016 calls for 4.3% core sales growth, which excludes the impacts from the NMR business closing, M&A and currency. The prior long-range plan called for 5.5% core sales growth in 2015-17.

Some Australian retail landlords are enhancing their shopping malls, potentially allowing modest rental increases. Tenants' sales could remain resilient due to an increase in tourist spending and imposition of a 10% Goods and Services Tax on goods [BLANK] from overseas online retailers.

Truck tonnage extended a pattern of elevated month-to-month volatility with a 3.3% sequential gain in October after September's 1.9% decline. The Cass freight-shipment index has [BLANK] positive momentum since December, rising 2.9% in October.

Valeant's Bausch & Lomb business may fit Allergan's wish list for opthalmology products and is a natural target, given CEO Brent Saunders' familiarity with the business as former CEO. Allergan may also be able to [BLANK] up the asset at a decent premium due to Valeant's need to quickly generate cash flow to meet its debt repayment requirements. Bill Ackman, who recently joined Valeant's board, has said that the unit would be a good option for divestiture.

Biogen's BIIB037 is off to a good start proving it reverses amyloid plaque buildup in the brain and reduces cognitive decline. The benefit seen in the Phase IB study eclipses that seen with its predecessors, and so has [BLANK] investor optimism. To play devil's advocate, criticism of the data was also considered. Alzheimer's is widespread, affecting more than 5 million people in the U.S. alone, and available therapies offer little to modify disease progression.

When Royal Caribbean and Norwegian Cruise Line hosted 4Q earnings calls in February, they eased concerns about Zika's impact on bookings. The Centers for Disease Control [BLANK] areas in the Caribbean and South and Central America that reported virus transmission. According to the Cruise Lines International Association, the Caribbean accounts for 34% of industry deployment. Norwegian said during its call that Zika's effects had been "negligible" on its business. Royal Caribbean said it had seen no impact.

FedEx's purchase of TNT and its extensive European road express network should help the combined company gain market share. FedEx has [BLANK] TNT, UPS and DHL in Europe, where it has been methodically expanding organically and through small bolt-on acquisitions. About 63% of TNT's 6.7 billion euros in 2014 revenue was generated in Europe. Its largest segment, International Europe, accounted for 41% of revenue, followed by its Domestic (38%) and Asia/Middle East/Africa (14%) businesses.

Health insurers may join generic-drug makers and pharmacists in pushing the FDA to alter its proposed draft guidance calling for unique, four-letter suffixes to biosimilars' and biologics' core, nonproprietary drug names. Distinguishing original biologics from their biosimilar versions with these suffixes may [BLANK] commercial prospects for cheaper biosimilars vs. the original reference biologics. This may pressure insurers' operating margins; they prefer the cheapest alternatives for their enrollees.

Competition in India's lending market is likely to intensify as the government's $13 billion capital injection for state-run banks should help boost provisions for troubled loans. The public banks will probably push to [BLANK] greater market share in mortgages, as they carry less risk than corporate loans, which have driven a surge in bad debt.

Indications suggest that 2017 will be at best a flat spot and at worst an inflection point that will bring a decline in U.S. auto sales. The duration of the demand plateau and the depth of the decline will be [BLANK] by a dramatic shift in consumer preference for light trucks from cars, supporting profit generation even if unit sales decrease. Signs of peak demand have hindered the stock performance of mature automakers perceived to be ill-prepared to compete as technology advances alter the landscape.

The tax reforms adopted by the Spanish government reduce the corporate tax rate to 28% in 2015 from 30% the previous year, and to 25% thereafter. This [BLANK] the amount of tax paid by Spanish utilities, including Enagas, Endesa and Gas Natural, that generate the majority of revenue from operations in the country. The lower tax rate may be offset by new measures designed to limit the deductibility of some costs and restrict the use of net operating losses.

Consumers in Brazil should keep spending at a modest pace as inflation and interest rates are comfortably low. Unemployment is a mitigating factor, though it appears to have [BLANK] in 2Q17. Economic forecasts for GDP remain tepid, but point to a consumer-led recovery that should benefit branded-product makers and retailers.

Arista's challenges to eight Cisco networking patents with the U.S. Patent Office may help Arista avoid infringement liability and boost efforts to design around Cisco's proprietary technology. The reviews may [BLANK] clarity on what Cisco's patents cover and render portions of them unenforceable. Arista hasn't challenged all patents in the companies' lawsuits, suggesting the inter partes review petitions are targeting the technology Arista considers to be the most difficult to design around.

Bayer and Novo Nordisk have spent the least on drug R&D in absolute terms over the past three years, yet their positions on productivity contrast, with the latter's acute focus on diabetes paying dividends. Roche [BLANK] highest on R&D expenditure, driven by cancer, while Pfizer needs to extract greater value from its significant pipeline investment.

Data and analytics providers are most exposed to demand linked to the investment management industry, a category that accounted for 23% of the $25.8 billion market in 2013, according to Burton-Taylor. The segment, with 2.6% growth last year, is also [BLANK] faster than the broader market (1.1%). The commodities and energy segment has consistently expanded at a faster pace (9% growth in 2013), while equity sales and trading contracts.

There may be too much optimism about the prospects for heightened M&A in oil-levered plays driven by weakness in benchmark commodity prices. About $8.5 billion of unconventional oil and gas properties were acquired in the Bakken last year, when WTI benchmark prices [BLANK] about $93 a barrel and Henry Hub prices were $4.26 per million British thermal units. Although oil has since fallen by almost half, valuation multiples are mixed, suggesting either fewer deals will occur or multiples will retreat further.

North America-originated intermodal traffic increased 6.8% in the week ended June 17 (week 24) vs. 2016, based on AAR data. Canadian National volume (up 21%) continues to outmatch peers, [BLANK] by share gains and exclusive access to the Port of Prince Rupert. Rail capacity is expected to increase by 500,000 TEUs (20-foot equivalent units) at Rupert and by 600,000 TEUs at Vancouver, where CN has about 70% share. These two projects could add up to C$550 million in revenue through 2020.

Allergan remains the largest specialty pharmaceutical drugmaker by enterprise value and prescription volume from Symphony Health, following the 2015 Actavis-Allergan combination. Companies such as Shire, Valeant and Mallinckrodt have also [BLANK] their specialty presence through M&A. Shire, which has been focused on specialty assets, is almost 60% of the size of Allergan. Despite its enterprise value -- a distant No. 8 -- Endo's portfolio outpaces Mallinckrodt's on a volume basis.

Health-care REITs are the most interest-rate sensitive property sector, and their performance in 2017 and early 2018 has directly corresponded to moves in the 10-year Treasury yield. A 12-bp drop in the 10-year yield in March fueled a health-care REIT rally for the month, but couldn't completely [BLANK] the effect of a 35-bp increase year-to-date through 1Q.

China Tower may have to distribute considerably more than 50% of its profit as dividends to appeal to yield-seeking investors. Its initial public offering is [BLANK] at more than a 50% discount to the U.S. telco towers' average EV/Ebitda, consistent with Chinese telcos' discount to their U.S. counterparts. Yet that dividend yield may still fall short of those of leading Chinese telcos and their U.S. telco tower peers. Net profit will take time to recover from the impact of 2018's lease fee reduction, and free cash flow will pick up only as capital outlays decline. China Tower is mulling a dividend payout of at least 50% of net profit. Leading U.S. telco tower companies are structured as real estate investment trusts, and distribute at least 90% of their taxable income to shareholders.

REITs are about $100 billion underweighted by mutual funds vs. their benchmark weightings, based on a report by Cohen & Steers. With the new real estate industry classification that was [BLANK] on Aug. 31, separating REITs from the financial sector, fund managers may now be motivated to rotate allocations into REIT shares from financial securities. At 3% of the S&P 500, REITs are the ninth-largest sector, just below semiconductors (3.1%), and larger than biotech and insurance.

Heritage, Mylan, Sun and six other drugmakers are accused in consolidated proposed class-action lawsuits of conspiring to fix the prices of the antibiotic doxycycline (doxy) and/or digoxin, a heart medication. Purchasers of the drugs [BLANK] that sudden price hikes in 4Q12 were the result of illegal communications among the companies. Two Heritage executives who pled guilty in January to a doxy conspiracy have implicated other companies. A 40-state lawsuit over doxy pricing is also pending in Connecticut.

Alternating-current rigs fell by four, silicon-controlled rectifiers (SCR) rose by the same amount and mechanicals jumped by 15 to the highest level since August in the week ended Nov. 18, according to RigData. Most of the additions were verticals, as horizontals [BLANK]. High-specification rigs -- those with AC power types and 1,500-1,999 horsepower -- fell by one as utilization stayed at 44%. While 94% of active AC rigs and 84% of SCR rigs were drilling horizontal wells, 57% of mechanicals drilled verticals.

The aim of President Donald Trump and congressional Democrats to lower drug prices would have a limited impact on U.S. health-care costs, as prescription drugs comprised just 10.1% of national health-care spending in 2015, the most recent data show. Even a 10% cut in drug prices would [BLANK] to no more than a 1% reduction in health spending. About $162 billion was spent on drugs in Medicare Part B and D plans, more than half of which was for branded therapies, Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services data show.

The FDA review of Novo Nordisk's drug liraglutide for the treatment of obesity states that all trials met its guidelines. There were more gallbladder side effects in the liraglutide [BLANK] patients (2.3%) than placebo (0.9%). The FDA panel will need to decide on Sept. 11 if this is related to liraglutide or whether it can be explained as an issue often associated with weight loss. Gallbladder issues were not raised in the Belviq and Qsymia FDA reviews.

Asia's financial services are likely to see significant technology-led transformation in the next decade. Global tech giants will vie for greater presence in Asia's financial industry, potentially using India as a growth springboard into other [BLANK] markets. Banks in Southeast Asia and India should fight back by applying tech to transform their core operations and delivery models. Spending on cybersecurity is likely to grow exponentially.

Chinese insurers, with 10 trillion yuan ($1.6 trillion) of assets, only held 1.44% of them overseas last year, based on regulatory data cited by Shanghai Securities News. That means they can add at least $200 billion more before [BLANK] a 15% cap. Targets may include long-duration assets with stable returns, such as office blocks. By comparison, Taiwanese insurers hold 48% of assets overseas. Japan's ratio is 18%, as of October. Chinese insurers' total assets jumped 23% last year, up from 13% growth in 2013.

Shares of Nomura and Daiwa tapered gains in January after rallying in the wake of the November U.S. election. While the brokers [BLANK] revenue and earnings in most segments in fiscal 3Q, their average 37% price gains from Nov. 9 to Jan. 31 may have already accounted for these positives. That rally beat the Topix's 17% increase during the same period. A sustainable retail sales rebound may affect earnings, as would a solid performance by wholesale banking driven by bond trading.

Diesel fuel prices fell 9.4% on average in 3Q vs. the prior-year period. Despite [BLANK] sequentially in 11 of the quarter's 13 weeks, fuel prices actually rose 3.6% from 2Q. Fuel surcharges typically lag behind spot prices by 60 days. Given the minimal change from 2Q, the lag effect was negligible on rail profitability last quarter. CSX recorded a $1 million drag on 3Q profit from the surcharge lag, a $19 million swing from last year's $18 million boost to earnings.

China's telcos are likely to focus on sales and returns since government-mandated service-price reduction is mostly done, which may help stabilize average revenue per user. Most large chipmakers are trading at forward P/Es within typical ranges, but if 2018 and 2019 earnings should weaken, those optically high valuations may face downside, and high inventories amplify this risk in many cases. Boston Scientific has begun gaining ground in the $5.3 billion global implantable defibrillator market, adding 160 bps of share in 1Q, and may continue to outpace peers in 2017. Mobile gaming makes the graphics processing subsystem that much more critical for product differentiation. An aging population and growing economy are key drivers of senior housing demand, and while there is no stopping the former, the latter remains a question mark. Verizon's wireless-service revenue growth fell to 4.8% in 3Q from 5.9% in 2Q. Similar dynamics may [BLANK] AT&T. Enterprise spending on layer 2-3 switches is likely to remain a key driver of the total enterprise network equipment market, due to upgrades to higher port speeds in the campus market and continued data center investments. A bill giving Ebola vaccine and drug developers high-value vouchers may be signed into law as early as December. The growth of fixed-income exchange-traded funds has outpaced stock and commodity funds since 2010, reflecting inflows driven by demand for bond exposure with the convenience of ETFs. Funds focused on [BLANK] markets and U.S. high grade corporates have led asset growth among bond ETFs.

Earnings for gas-storage operators, such as Centrica, SSE and E.ON, depend on the spread between winter and summer gas prices. President Donald Trump's elevation of Republican FCC Commissioner Ajit Pai as the agency's permanent chairman will likely result in less regulation for cable, telecommunications and media companies. Apple may pay banks to run a person-to-person (P2P) payments service as it focuses on driving device sales. Fiat Chrysler's 4% volume increase in May resulted from 27% higher car sales and 2% fewer truck deliveries. The opposite dynamic has [BLANK] the company's recent results. Wynn Palace closed its profitability gap with rival Parisian Macao during its second full year of operation in Macau's Cotai region. The critical question for Deutsche Bank remains its earnings power, including the path it takes to improve overall profitability, amid a need to invest. Analog Devices may get U.S. antitrust clearance for its acquisition of Linear Technology on Oct. 19, but will still need approval from other jurisdictions before closing. Strong sales are likely to evade the Airbus A220 (C Series) as it targets the 100-140-seat market, a dead zone for airplanes. Asia's clean-energy investment picture will get even brighter in the coming months as capacity and financing trends align for a growth boost. Natural Grocers' shares are down 40% through Aug. 31, as the retailer combats new-store cannibalization and sales weakness. Auto sales in EU and European Free Trade Association countries were 7% higher through 1H after full-year gains in 2014-15, with last year's increase being the largest since 1991. Regulators are unlikely to take actions toward finalizing their proposal on executive compensation in 2H or 2018. The SEC, FDIC and FHFA have [BLANK] it from their short-term agenda. Micron's fiscal 3Q results and 4Q guidance are likely to be affected by key developments in DRAM and NAND memory markets. Emerging risks in the U.S. packaged-food industry that could compound growth challenges may prompt some companies to consider going private. Floating liquefied natural gas (FLNG) technology is designed to develop natural gas at sea, in areas where conventional offshore or subsea pipeline technology is not logistically or economically viable. Bard has earned the highest return on invested capital vs. its weighted average cost of capital among its large-cap peers in 2014, while Boston Scientific continues to earn less than its cost of capital. The prospects for global chocolate demand recovery may sour if packaged-chocolate makers raise prices this year, or keep shrinking bar sizes, to offset higher cocoa costs. The MSCI World Tobacco Index's outperformance of the MSCI World Index in the first half of 2015 is supporting the tobacco group's 23% premium valuation to the broader index, as measured by forward enterprise value-to-Ebitda multiples. The adoption of Netflix in Europe so far appears to be complementary to traditional pay TV subscriptions. December retail sales were likely mixed among the eight retailers reporting monthly sales. Costco, [BLANK] fuel, and L Brands are projected to lead, with consensus expecting mid-single-digit gains. Coming off of its most profitable year ever, Universal is poised for another strong showing in 2018, though it doesn't expect to surpass 2017 results. Luxury-goods brands are seeking opportunities beyond China's tier-1 and tier-2 cities. UnitedHealth is now well-positioned to get a remaining Medicare Advantage fraud lawsuit, and all $3 billion of potential liability, thrown out. The Justice Department opted to voluntarily dismiss, rather than [BLANK], the smaller of two similar suits against the health insurance company.

General Dynamics and Serco captured new revenue opportunities after winning spots on a $2.5 billion, eight-year Navy contract known as CANES. At 20.4x forward 12-month funds from operations, apartment REITs trade 10.9% above the total REIT FFO multiple of 18.4x. Casual-dining chains such as Cheesecake Factory and Bloomin' Brands are opting to use mobile-payment apps instead of tabletop tablets to speed up check payment, boost customer satisfaction and improve table turnover. If payment-protection claims continue at levels currently being received, with a sensitivity of about 250 million pounds per incremental 1,000, Lloyds could require an additional 500 million pound provision, more than manageable. Nomura and Royal Bank of Scotland are expected to have oral arguments by the end of 3Q in their appeal of a 2015 mortgage-bond trial verdict against them in a suit by Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac conservator FHFA. IBM's traditional IT outsourcing business will likely remain under pressure as a greater number of clients shift their infrastructure to the cloud and use more software in their data centers. Current account holdings and deposit facilities at the ECB grew more than 170 billion euros ($197 billion) in the three weeks after the ECB's second targeted LTRO in December, as banks deposited fresh cash. The American Institute of Architects forecasts nonresidential construction to rise 5.8% in 2016 and 5.6% in 2017, above the 5.3% growth recorded through June. Actelion's efforts outside of PAH include Zavesca and Valchlor, which drove 6% of sales in 2014. Part of Amgen's cost-containment program revamped its approach to manufacturing biologic drugs. Fifth Third, KeyCorp and SunTrust may have the greatest ability to boost earnings and profitability by driving commercial-bank efficiency gains, with ratios consistently above most BI-tracked regional bank peers in the past few years. Home Depot and Lowe's, whose 2Q sales rate weakened sequentially due to unseasonal weather, will likely see further deceleration in 3Q and 4Q, based on commentary from suppliers including Sherwin Williams, Masco and Whirlpool. Greek household disposable income fell almost 20% to $182 billion in the five years to 2013, IMF data show, significantly impairing customers' ability to service debt. Legislatures and regulators have grappled with the popularity of daily fantasy sports and high-profile operators DraftKings and FanDuel. Deposits accounted for 56% of Societe Generale's liabilities in 2Q, up from 49% in 2011, while the share of wholesale funding fell to 13% from 19%. As the Jan. 3, 2018 start date for MiFID II financial reform inches closer, investment companies are gradually gaining clarity on how the rules will apply in practice. Alcon, Bausch & Lomb, CooperVision and J&J may get a decision by 4Q on their joint bid to dismiss consolidated consumer antitrust suits challenging contact lens pricing practices. Branded drug list prices tracked by Symphony Health rose by a median 14.3% in 4Q from a year earlier in the U.S., where free drug pricing is allowed. The specialty nature of biotech drugs allows annual price increases to have a meaningful effect on profitability.

In a Bear Case for machinery, financial services and other industries, Republican party leaders could be convinced by election wins to wait until 2015 to consider renewing 55 tax breaks that expired in 2013. Intel's acquisition of Altera will likely require merger notification in the U.S., China and elsewhere given revenue and deal value, subjecting the deal to multiple antitrust waiting periods that could last over six months. While Altera's specialized chips are used adjacent to Intel CPUs for customized computing rather than as competitive substitutes, regulators may need time to [BLANK] the deal because industry relationships are complex, technology is changing rapidly and Intel has had past antitrust infractions.

North American rail revenue may have risen a median 4.3% in 4Q, with CSX the only carrier to record a decline in sales. Health insurers are pressing Congress to repeal the Obamacare-imposed excise tax on their industry, set to extract almost $150 billion over a 10-year period. Of the major biotech and pharma companies, Regeneron leads the pack in terms of total sales that may be exposed to the Medicare Part B pilot program, followed by Amgen and Roche. Kia's incentive costs in the U.S. may not fall as fast as its peers given its lower base and measures to retain market share in the slower-growing auto market. Global beauty and cosmetic brands could invest more in Asia to boost their sales, resulting in heightened competition for regional players such as Shiseido, Kao, Amorepacific and LG Household. Rising urbanization and incomes in populous Asian markets such as China, India and Indonesia should spur shoppers to [BLANK] more on skin-care and other cosmetics items. PetroChina, Sinopec and Cnooc should profit from the crude-price rally even as they need to pay a windfall tax in 2H. Bristol-Myers Squibb's 28.6% of sales spent on drug R&D was the highest among peers in 2014, followed by Eli Lilly at 27.9%. Rowan's drilling contract for the Gorilla III jackup, now working for EOG in Trinidad, will end early. Increased Mexican exports to the U.S., spurred by the peso's depreciation, may have a limited effect on banks' loan growth. Brexit will mean the U.K. ceases to be part of the European Atomic Energy Agency, which could result in border delays and raised barriers, causing radiopharmaceutical-drug-sales damage and limiting sales of imaging devices. A scenario that values AmEx's business segments in relation to peers suggests a forward P/E multiple of closer to 14x vs. the current 12x. Nexstar's and broadcasters' case against the FCC has a small but real chance to knock out local ownership limits, triggering rapid media consolidation. While the case mostly targets an FCC rule that keeps TV stations from selling ads, broadcasters also make a broader claim that all FCC media-ownership limits for local markets must die since the agency hasn't [BLANK] its rules as Congress required.
