Mutual funds and exchange-traded funds would have their derivative holdings restricted, and possibly forced to divest, under a 2015 SEC proposal the agency may dust off in 2019. Some alternative-strategy ETFs could be [BLANK]. Yet this remains a low priority, in our view, and probably not one the agency will act upon until 2H19.

As mine infrastructure is being built, careful attention needs to be paid to constantly changing variables such as width, depth, ore conditions, heat and water. Due to continuous mine transformation, the way the ore is mined needs to also [BLANK] congruently. Altering of mining methods contributes to delayed projects and significant costs. By combining known mine attributes, gathered through drilling and 3-D modeling, and statistical data, miners could better anticipate and quickly adjust.

Fertilizer prices are down 10-20% globally in 2016. While the drop made fertilizer more affordable for farmers in 1H, a 20% drop in corn prices since May has [BLANK] to the challenge. Compared with U.S. corn prices, nitrogen and potash have become more affordable than 15-year averages, while phosphates are at their average. Potash producers have curtailed and closed capacity, while markets await a belated spring deal announcement with China to set benchmark prices. Phosphate and nitrogen supply is less coordinated.

Pandora likely gained new leverage in negotiations with owners of pre-1972 sound recordings after Sirius's New York win. While courts in other states don't have to follow the New York ruling, it's likely to weigh on their analyses, [BLANK] it in Pandora's and Sirius's direction. Pandora may use its new leverage to drive a tougher bargain than in 2015, when it agreed to pay $90 million to record companies that own about 90% of all pre-1972 sound recordings. That deal expired at the end of 2016.

Nexstar and the National Association of Broadcasters face a delay in their challenge to the FCC's joint-sales-agreement rule after a U.S. appeals court in Washington on Nov. 24 canceled the Dec. 3 argument and moved the case to the Third Circuit. The Third Circuit should [BLANK] next steps within several weeks. The venue change was pushed by the FCC and by parties who want stricter ownership rules. Broadcasters, who want the FCC rules struck down, had urged the D.C. Circuit to decide the case itself.

The U.S. Patent Office will decide by June whether Eli Lilly's Alimta patent upheld on appeal is valid. The inter partes [BLANK] challenges create uncertainty for the patent, which absent an IPR challenge would have definitively kept generic versions off the market until May 2022. An adverse decision would affect the court ruling. The patent office has granted 11 IPRs in total, most recently three filed by Wockhardt. The office granted three Teva IPRs in October and combined these with two IPRs filed by Neptune.

Total's appeal of a lower court decision in Texas challenging FERC's authority to pursue certain fines against the company will likely get a hearing in 1Q over arguments that have been filed with the court. Total [BLANK] its final brief on Dec. 12, the last of the paper arguments the court will consider before making a decision. Arguments will then be scheduled. These types of appeals typically take about nine months from start to finish. The court process is running concurrently with the agency's.

Dong Energy, Vattenfall, E.ON, Innogy, Iberdrola and other power generators will boost combined installed capacity in Europe in 2017 and beyond as their new wind farms and solar plants offset coal- and nuclear-capacity shutdowns by companies such as Uniper, Drax and RWE. Renewable-power auctions in Germany, the Netherlands and the U.K., among others, will be the main drivers of renewable capacity additions, [BLANK] by onshore wind. Offshore wind and utility-scale solar will grow in importance.

Pressure on retailer margins is rising as the holiday season approaches. A tight labor market will make seasonal-worker hours more expensive and, at the same time, a highly price-competitive environment will [BLANK] retailers' ability to raise prices. Elevated transportation expenses will compound growing costs associated with expanding e-commerce sales.

Tom Harkin, retiring chairman of the U.S. Senate committee that deals with education, released a draft bill in June that's unfavorable to the for-profit education industry. The legislation [BLANK] risk-sharing and holds accountable low-performing schools and is a sweeping overhaul. Harkin began investigating for-profit schools in 2010 and the industry's shares have fallen 58% since then. A Republican-controlled Congress may be more favorable for the industry.

Major dry-van carriers' average length of haul inched up 0.3% in 1Q from a year earlier to 479 miles, gaining for an eighth consecutive quarter after 11 straight declines. The long-haul segment may have reached an inflection point in 2014 when rail service issues provided truckers an opportunity to [BLANK] back market share. Cheap fuel prices and looser truck capacity have made carriers more competitive against railroads in the long-haul segment. J.B. Hunt's length of haul increased 4% in 1Q in its Truck segment.

Beyond Celgene's five key trials to increase Revlimid's sales outside of multiple myeloma, there are other options that might help boost future contributions from lymphoma, and improve sentiment as data reads out. Early development efforts with promising new agents that are seeking to [BLANK] the immuno-modulatory effect of Revlimid, and a bull case for sales is one of these leads to a Darzalex-like scenario, with rapid development spurring practice change before 2020.

European industrials' direct sales exposure to Turkey is low, but the heightened crisis risk comes at a time of slowing European economic expansion. That could [BLANK] the sector's 5-6% organic sales growth seen this year. In particular, construction-exposed Schneider, Prysmian and Kone could post slower EMEA growth and risks to profit will increase if defaults soar.

Hurricane Nate's effect on Gulf Coast refiners and export lanes will muddy this week's EIA refined-product stock release. The end of driving season will [BLANK] U.S. gasoline demand, partly offset by more exports to Latin America, where demand has recovered from 2014's commodity-price slump. Analysts expect a 172,600-barrel draw in the week ended Oct. 6, vs. a 1.6 million-barrel build a week earlier. Most of the buildup in the past two weeks was in blending components as the East Coast switches to winter-grade gas.

Seaborne thermal coal producers likely welcome a supply outlook that does not include Galilee Basin projects coming to market as capacity additions would fall to 3 million metric tons by 2017 and then to zero by 2018. If the massive projects in the Galilee Basin that require more than $35 billion in capital outlays do not come to fruition, supply and demand fundamentals could begin to [BLANK] by the end of 2016.

Twitter is favored to win dismissal of a lawsuit alleging the company wrongly intercepted private messages. The key issue is likely to be whether a reasonable Twitter user would read the terms of service to [BLANK] Twitter's actions. Recent Google and Yahoo e-mail cases loom large. Twitter probably will say its terms, like Yahoo's, allow its conduct. Plaintiffs may say the terms, like Google's, don't fairly warn users. It's a close call, yet Twitter's terms likely are clear enough to end the case.

Sales and profit expansion for Hong Kong and Macau's retailers in 2H could trail 1H as the yuan weakens vs. the dollar-pegged currencies of the two cities. The increase in jewelry retailers' same-store sales may also [BLANK] as gold prices, which dropped to a 12-month low in August, more than offset the increase in buying volume by Chinese shoppers. Shops' profitability should rise, as savings persist from cuts over the past two years to renewed rents for street-level outlets. Hong Kong jewelry sales gained 23.5% in the first six months of 2018 vs. a 21.1% plunge two years earlier. Jewelry sales in Macau jumped 17.8% in the quarter ended March vs. an 18.3% slump during the same period in 2016.

Endo's prospects for winning dismissal of antitrust lawsuits over Opana ER are good, though it will likely have to wait until 2019 to file those key motions. Damages are unspecified yet could exceed $1.5 billion, based on drug buyers' claims of an alleged agreement between Endo and Impax to [BLANK] a generic version of the painkiller.

European telecom carrier Ebitda growth will likely stagnate next year as top-line growth remains modest while multi-year saving initiatives are reducing further opportunities to cut costs. A step-up in mobile competition due to a broader 4G network advance may also [BLANK] further gains as acquisition and retention costs pressure margins. Rising higher-margin fiber adoption for network owners and low churn benefits for carriers with high-convergence penetration will counter the 4G competition.

Featured research today: Changing consumer behavior means mall owners must be careful managing a tenant mix, store formats and anchors, and use technology to understand customers; After four years of declining profits, Allianz's asset-management businesses look [BLANK] to recover, with a full-year outlook for 2-2.6 billion euros operating profit; European shares trail global equities after a typical summer pause, and autumn pits seasonality and economic growth catalysts vs. currency, policy and valuation challenges.

Entergy had fought New York Governor Andrew Cuomo's bid to close the Indian Point nuclear plant for years, but low power prices after the Nov. 8 U.S. election may have decided the issue. Prices for 2022 in New York Zone G, where Indian Point [BLANK], fell over $3 a megawatt-hour from Nov. 8 to early January. That cost Entergy $50 million of Ebitda and put the plant in the red. Prices for 2019 held flat, suggesting that President Donald Trump's expected environmental reforms could reduce power margins over time.

Biotech and pharma events include Galmed's aramchol interim data from Phase IIb trial in nonalcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) patients. Gilead may be able to [BLANK] for accelerated FDA approval of simtuzumab with 96-week data from Phase IIb NASH trials, available in 4Q16, following a blinded interim futility analysis in 4Q15. Tobira expects cenicriviroc data from a pivotal Phase IIb trial in NASH patients. AstraZeneca will report Epanova/Farxiga Phase II data in diabetics with fatty liver disease.

Edison's returns on equity may improve with approved rate hikes of $209 million for 2016 and $272 million for 2017, and a pending 2018 general rate case filing requesting a $222 million revenue increase. The allowed regulatory ROE of 10.45% -- one of the highest in the U.S. -- is [BLANK] through 2017. That allowed ROE doesn't directly determine the financial ROE, yet it's a strong influence. Edison has one of the highest financial ROE among the regulated integrated peers due to asset expansion and rate increases.

Takeda's Millennium and multiple generic-drug makers are awaiting a trial decision -- likely in 2Q -- from the U.S. District Court in Delaware determining whether the generics stepped on Millennium's Velcade patent rights with their proposed copy-cat versions. A four-day bench trial was [BLANK] on Nov. 7, making the decision likely imminent. The decision will be appealable to the Federal Circuit, and could affect the three other lawsuits Millennium filed against Teva, Apotex and GlenMark over the same Velcade patent.

The Los Angeles Dodgers' network SportsNet LA was the second-most-expensive regional sports network after YES ($5.93) with a $4.33 monthly subscriber fee in 2015, according to SNL Kagan. DirecTV and other pay-TV operators have refused to [BLANK] SportsNet LA since its February 2014 launch due to high costs. The network may lose about $155 million in annual affiliate fees, assuming a distribution shortfall of 3 million subscribers. Time Warner Cable is paying $8.3 billion over 25 years to run SportsNet LA.

A long-term U.S. offshore wind plan indicates 86 gigawatts of installs is feasible by 2050 to encourage development of a domestic supply chain such as by Siemens, MHI-Vestas and GE-Alstom. A near-term target of 3 gigawatts by 2020 will still [BLANK] Europe and Asia, with 27 gigawatts possible for Europe by 2020. The 86-gigawatt target for offshore wind was identified during the Obama administration, and while it's unlikely to be pursued by President-elect Donald Trump, some new build may be driven by state goals.

The rehabilitation of Bank of Ireland (BOI) and Allied Irish Banks has driven return on equity for both lenders back toward double digits. Consensus [BLANK] for BOI to report a ROE of 10% this year, rising to 11.6% by 2017. Widening mortgage margins and falling deposit costs have been key to BOI's improved profitability, as cost-income ratios have returned to levels not seen since 2007. The lenders posted combined bad debt of 36.5 billion euros ($40 billion) in 2014, which remains key to the outlook.

Price and cost improvements that can boost 1H margins are the key to Nutrien's (NTR +1.2%) 1Q performance, in our view, though a slow start to U.S. planting will cloud underlying customer demand for the fertilizer company formed by the merger of PotashCorp and Agrium. Whether tight cash among farmers is [BLANK] retail product mix remains a key question, though a recent increase in crop prices may modestly improve customer sentiment.

Dow's business segments, recast in November 2014, highlight the diverse drivers of financial performance. Performance Plastics is the largest segment (47% of 2014 Ebitda) and has led earnings growth as margins [BLANK] 670 bps since 2012. Infrastructure Solutions margins and Ebitda were most stable in 2012-14. Agricultural Solutions faces the most unique demand drivers. These are seasonal and tied to crop prices, with crop chemicals and seed product launches adding growth.

The market capitalization of the top nine chaebol, large conglomerates that dominate South Korea's economy, is more than $700 billion, or about 60% of the value of the Kospi 200. Their size and influence have led to claims they are stifling competition, and their large cash reserves are [BLANK] as hindering investment and wage growth. Reform proposals have circulated since the Asian financial crisis. Chaebols' growing grip on the economy shows reformers have made little progress.

While U.S. online advertising is projected to rise about 18% in 2015, print advertising continues to erode. Ad spending on newspapers is expected to [BLANK] about 11% to $14 billion this year and by about 71% from 2005's $49 billion, according to Magna Global. Magazine advertising may also decline 10% in 2015, further accelerating the print medium's loss of share to digital advertising. Digital may account for about one-third of total ads in 2015.

A pickup in Tobacco industry M&A activity since 2013 was highlighted by Reynolds American's $27.6 billion purchase of Lorillard in June. Many recent deals have [BLANK] the developing electronic vaporizer industry, including Japan Tobacco's April acquisition of U.S. e-cigarette company Logic Technology for an undisclosed sum. British American Tobacco has a pending $10 billion deal to buy the remaining 25% of Brazilian tobacco company Souza Cruz it doesn't yet own.

An overall survival benefit, the secondary endpoint in Amgen's ASPIRE trial, may boost chances for EU regulatory success with Kyprolis. An interim analysis showed a trend for overall survival in patients [BLANK] with a Kyprolis-Revlimid and low-dose dexamethasone (dex) combo. Celgene's Revlimid plus dex improved overall survival in a Phase III trial. Kyprolis was granted accelerated FDA approval. Aspire data will be used to convert to full approval. The trial met its primary goal of improving progression-free survival (26.3 months vs. 17.6).

The North America Class 8 truck-order cancellation rate was 7.9% in June, down from May's 12.5%. For much of 2016, cancellations topped 10%, the level above which manufacturers typically cut production, yet they've been [BLANK]. Cancellations should remain at favorable levels as truck capacity tightens. Orders are running at replacement demand in 2017 after sliding 35% in 2016 and should accelerate seasonally later in the year. The robust PMI index, which truck orders track, supports higher purchases.

PNC's 3Q adjusted revenue may rise 1% year-over-year while EPS could increase 4%, based on consensus. The bank may [BLANK] no operating leverage in the quarter, though management said at a September conference that positive operating leverage is a goal, even without further rate hikes. Investors may seek updates and more concrete near-term targets on the bank's various revenue and expense initiatives introduced at the conference. Credit trends may also be watched, given the better provision outlook provided in 2Q.

In 2017, regulators around the globe could take action to try to stop Facebook from gaining access to some user data from WhatsApp. When Facebook paid $19 billion to [BLANK] WhatsApp in 2014, the companies promised no changes to WhatsApp's privacy policies. The August 2016 announcement that Facebook would seek limited WhatsApp user data was met with skepticism from U.S. stakeholders and European regulators.

Electric vehicles are still more expensive than gasoline models in China, even including subsidies of 30% to 60%. That has [BLANK] back sales as it takes buyers at least four years to recoup the extra cost through fuel savings. Low-end EVs, such as the Chery eQ, have the fastest paybacks because of lower battery costs. The mid-range BYD e6 has an eight-year payback.

A CSRA-led venture won a 10-year, $2.4 billion contract to provide complex IT services to the National Security Agency, which accounts for about 7% of the company's annual revenue. The company won the contract as part of a joint venture [BLANK] Eagle Alliance with Northrop Grumman, in which CSRA holds a 79% equity interest. CSRA has been the incumbent on the NSA IT services program, known as Greenway, since 2001. CSRA was reportedly head-to-head with General Dynamics in the competition.

Apple's lawsuit against Qualcomm seeks to improve device margins by reducing patent royalties. Apple is [BLANK] Qualcomm's licensing deals are anticompetitive and challenging how its patent fees are calculated. Companies making iPhones and other Apple devices license Qualcomm patents on technologies essential to 3G/Universal Mobile Telecommunications Services (UMTS) and 4G/LTE standards, and pass the cost on to Apple. The suit could serve as negotiating leverage for a direct licensing deal between the companies.

Convenience store chain operators including Casey's, Couche-Tard and 7-Eleven may have fewer short-term acquisition opportunities as favorable fuel margins make it less enticing for convenience store owners to sell. Lower fuel prices also [BLANK] to a higher number of gallons sold, and credit card fees drop as it becomes cheaper to fill up the gas tank. The resulting slightly higher cash flow may be enough to slow acquisition opportunities, particularly since only 37% of convenience stores are part of a chain.

The Drewry Hong Kong-Los Angeles container rate benchmark jumped 15.4% to $2,253 per 40-foot container (FEU) in the week ended Feb. 11. Rates were boosted by a general increase (GRI) of $600 per FEU on Feb. 9 aiming to [BLANK] on an expected pre-Lunar New Year increase in demand. Liners use GRIs as a revenue improvement measure to mitigate rate erosion and higher port and inland-related costs. Carriers of the Transpacific Stabilization Agreement are already planning for another GRI of $600 per FEU on March 9.

Broadcasters must now wait for stage 3 of the FCC's incentive spectrum auction, with stage 2 ending after one round. Prices remained unchanged, suggesting a national bidder may have [BLANK] the auction. The broadcasters will go through another stage of the reverse auction, where they will bid against each other to sell a smaller amount of spectrum at lower prices. Stage 3 of the forward auction should provide insight as to how much the remaining bidders are willing to drive up pricing as supply declines.

Global aluminum supply is likely to recover as the U.S. Treasury eases its stance on sanctions against Russian aluminum maker Rusal. Existing customers will be allowed to [BLANK] contracts and the divestment deadline has been extended to Nov. 12. Yet failure to meet the deadline could trigger renewed tightening of global aluminum supply.

Packaged food multinationals such as Nestle and PepsiCo, which have high sales exposure in Europe and the U.S., may see sales improve, given that GDP growth is improving there, while growth in Asia is slowing. Consensus projects 3% GDP growth in the U.S. in 2015, up from an [BLANK] 2.2% in 2014, and pan-Europe to improve to 1.6% in 2015 from 0.8% in 2014. Consensus projects Asia GDP to increase 6.1% in 2015, slowing from a projected 6.4% jump in 2014.

Iberdrola and other integrated utilities with high shares of earnings from renewables could be in a better position to maintain stable dividends than peers with exposure to commodity markets. Engie, which is sensitive to commodity prices because of its conventional generation, upstream exploration, LNG and gas supply and storage, [BLANK] its dividend for 2017-18 to far lower than analysts expected. Iberdrola, by comparison, plans to pay out 65-75% of net profit, which it expects to rise at 6% CAGR from 2016 to 2020.

Privacy complaints against Facebook, Instagram, WhatsApp and Google threaten massive damages and could disrupt revenue from personalized ads. The complaints are the first tests of the EU's new data-privacy rules, and how they're handled will [BLANK] insight into the severity of the regulation's impact on the platforms.

As ImmunoGen advances its own pipeline, questions will center on how to best optimize the dose of its antibody drug conjugates to prevent toxicities. The company will expand its R&D efforts for IMGN853 in ovarian and endometrial cancers, though must first select between dosing once every three weeks or once a week on a modified schedule to [BLANK] eye side effects. A new type of antibody drug conjugate, IMGN779 also will enter testing this year. Its different design may alleviate some unwanted delayed toxicities.

Even after tens of billions of dollars in RMBS settlements, including Goldman Sachs' $5.1 billion deal announced Jan. 14, several banks remain the subject of Justice Department RMBS task force probes and lawsuits that may result in multibillion-dollar accords. Barclays, Credit Suisse, Deutsche Bank, HSBC, RBS, UBS and Wells Fargo may [BLANK] with the task force in the next several months. Most deals are unlikely to approach amounts paid by BofA ($16.7 billion), JPMorgan ($13 billion) and Citigroup ($7 billion).

Some tech and manufacturing companies could face higher state and local taxes (SALT) due to the U.S. tax law's repatriation requirement and capital-expensing benefit. Repatriation might trigger levies in states such as California, which estimates it will [BLANK] $250 million due to the mandate. Apple, Google and Cisco may account for more than a third of that tab.

For-profit schools could face revenue cuts, enrollment threats and heightened regulatory scrutiny from a Hillary Clinton presidency. The Democrat wants to strengthen a regulation that [BLANK] for-profit programs from receiving federal aid if they fail to meet accountability standards. Clinton also wants to include Defense Department aid in the calculation of revenue from federal sources, currently capped at 90%. Clinton also wants agencies to more aggressively enforce laws prohibiting deceptive marketing.

Abbott Laboratories' revenue may have a very muted effect from an FDA letter warning doctors of a higher risk of target lesion failure vs. drug-eluting stents at two years, most notably in small vessels. The company has [BLANK] just 5% market share in Europe and 1% in the U.S. with the device, according to Millennium Research Group. Given the global drug-eluting stent market was $3.5 billion in 2016, Abbott may derive just $50 million of sales from Absorb (0.2% of its total revenue).

Amid a 6% increase in new vehicle volume in the U.S., Volkswagen brand unit sales have decreased 11% in 2014, given a product mix emphasizing mostly cars has failed to draw buyers. The Group's Audi and Porsche premium makes have [BLANK] the total market, selling 14% and 12% more units through September. BMW has also benefited from the attraction to luxury products with an 11% gain in U.S. vehicle sales. Jaguar is the only European luxury brand to post a U.S. volume decline in 2014.

The beverage peer group median one-year total return (including dividends) was 17% in the past 12 months, possibly reflecting consensus expectations for growth tied to product innovation and M&A. Monster Beverage's total return was 98% amid product releases and its new agreement with Coca-Cola that will [BLANK] Monster to reach wide global distribution. Anheuser-Busch InBev and Heineken total returns were more than 50%, supported by M&A in Asia and other developing markets.

Investment-bank revenue estimates may reflect expectations for global GDP to expand 3.7-3.8% in 2018-19 vs. 3.6% in 2017. Estimates generally [BLANK] in 1Q, similar to 2017, though Latin America, Canada and Russia were key exceptions. U.S. estimates climbed to 2.8% for 2018 from 2.6% at year-end, while euro zone estimates rose to 2.4% from 2.1%. The U.K.'s estimated growth of 1.5% and Switzerland's 2% forecast also increased, while China's 6.5% pace and Japan's 1.3% were about stable.

Retransmission fees, paid by distributors such as cable and satellite-TV providers to broadcast stations, may almost double to about $9.3 billion in 2020 from $4.9 billion in 2014, according to SNL Kagan. For pay-TV operators, these add to the already burdensome fees they [BLANK] to cable networks such as ESPN and CNN. CBS is targeting $2 billion in annual retransmission revenue by 2020 as it gets more aggressive in carriage negotiations with pay-TV operators and TV-station owners.

Commercial and industrial lending is a core U.S. bank product and less fragmented than commercial real estate, with bigger banks tending to serve larger customers. In 1Q, Bank of America (10.1%), Wells Fargo (8.3%) and JPMorgan (6.6%) [BLANK] market share of outstanding loans. BofA gained about 50 bps in 1Q and JPMorgan 30 bps, with Wells Fargo posting a more modest 10-bp increase. Each has also gained over the past several quarters, with share above year-end 2015. Wells Fargo reflects its GE asset purchase in 1Q16.

For liquefied natural gas project developers, bills being weighed by Congress won't help much to speed up permit approvals. Federal Energy Regulatory Commission applications for LNG plant siting and operations are slow and expensive, often [BLANK] tens of millions of dollars. For those reasons, fewer developers have applied to FERC. The Energy Department determines whether exports are in the public interest and hasn't yet rejected any export-permit applications.

Market speculation in April that Home Properties could be the next apartment REIT acquisition target following the Associated Estates deal likely contributed to the small premium buyout price. Lone Star Funds is [BLANK] only a 3.4% premium to the day prior to the deal announcement and a 9.2% premium from where it was prior to any reports of a takeover. This is well below the 17% and 65% premiums from the equivalent dates that Associated Estates garnered when it was bought by Brookfield Asset Management.

Office REITs exposed to East and West Coast cities traded at similar multiples at year-end. West Coast-focused Douglas Emmett and Kilroy [BLANK] at about 19-20x FFO, as did New York-heavy Empire State and Boston Properties. Multiples for SL Green and Paramount were lower. Both coastal markets have faced concern about slowing demand while continuing to see rents rise. Suburban office owners traded at lower multiples, except for Equity Commonwealth, which led all peers, at 30x FFO.

Better PC sales across the business and consumer segments, along with corporate cloud-driven server sales, may help hardware vendors such as Dell, Hewlett-Packard, Cisco and Lenovo, and component makers such as Seagate and Western Digital. Intel and Apple 3Q earnings reports [BLANK] that PC end markets may be improving. Demand seasonality in 4Q may also help as the holiday season and corporate budget flush typically adds to demand.

North American energy markets have proven to be more of a challenge than opportunity for railroads this year. Crude-by-rail, which has provided significant growth possibilities since 2010, is [BLANK] due to low oil prices and falling rig counts. Crude carload growth is expected to be flat this year, while frac sand volumes may drop 30% to 40%, according to PLG Consulting. Weak energy markets have spurred many railroads, including Canadian National and Canadian Pacific, to trim volume forecasts.

Pandora's case against pre-1972 recording owners threatens to raise royalty fees that already make its profits elusive. Although the plaintiff says Pandora's damages may [BLANK] $25 million, a better top-end estimate is $10 million to $15 million. In 2014, Pandora paid about $405 million to stream all post-1972 recordings in the U.S. The suit involves only oldies, likely about 5% of Pandora's catalog, and only those airing in California. The case could lead to suits in other states.

Merck, AbbVie and Bristol-Myers' new-drug portfolio growth is reliant on three blockbuster drugs at most, posing the issue of concentration risk. Keytruda is expected to [BLANK] two-thirds of Merck's portfolio sales in 2021 vs. 56% for Bristol-Myers' Opdivo. While both are approved, the extent of ongoing trials suggests potential clinical risks are material. AbbVie must report positive pivotal data for Rova-T in 2H, not only to justify the Stemcentrx deal, but to lower its reliance on Imbruvica.

Ameren's 2Q EPS growth was supported by the $92 million annual rate increase at the Missouri utility that was implemented April 1. The Missouri utility is Ameren's largest subsidiary, but capital spending is focused on expanding gas and electric infrastructure in Illinois, where the company [BLANK] higher returns on equity. The boost from increased Missouri electric rates will counter the negative impact of milder 2Q weather on power and gas sales.

RWE's decision to float a 10% stake in its renewable, grid and supply operations echoes a move nine years ago by EDF, which was followed by Iberdrola, EDP and Enel. Like those listings, this is [BLANK] to raise capital for future investment and take advantage of higher valuations for regulated-type assets compared with conventional power generation. EDF and the others bought back the units as the strategic advantage of the separate entities and valuations declined. This may suggest such a move will be temporary.

Regional strength in auto sales has remained a bright spot in the demand outlook for basic and specialty chemical producers. U.S. auto sales rose 9% from a year earlier in July, accelerating from 1% in June and [BLANK] a fifth-consecutive monthly increase. Asia-Pacific auto sales climbed 3%, aided by 5% growth in China. European new car registrations rose 4%, a 10th-consecutive monthly increase as Germany passenger car registrations jumped 7%.

Softwood lumber prices and earnings may have peaked for this housing cycle, and we expect 2019 prices to be down 10-15%. Prices should [BLANK] 2018 with an 11-12% gain, vs. our previous forecast of 15-17%, after an unprecedented correction from June-November amid slower single-family housing starts and incremental supply gains.

Creditors suing Caesars in New York federal court may seek to take advantage of a brief Caesars filed in support of its motion to appeal the district court's summary judgment ruling. The reply originally stated that not all of Caesars Entertainment Corp.'s guarantees were [BLANK] in the first of two transactions in 2014, which contradicted Caesars' statements in district court. Caesars is seeking to revise its reply brief, but Judge Shira Scheindlin may take notice of the potential admission.

The judge in a lawsuit by Fairholme and other Fannie and Freddie shareholders challenging a change to the GSEs' bailout may have further signaled a tilt toward plaintiffs. In a Sept. 30 order, the judge granted a shareholder motion to use discovery [BLANK] in the case in similar litigation. While that result wasn't surprising, the judge's refusal to wait for a response from the U.S. -- which opposed the motion -- may signal the court's unfavorable view of the government's arguments.

JPMorgan faces a $768 million fraud and breach of contract lawsuit by bond insurer Ambac related to four residential mortgage-backed securities issued by Bear Stearns units in 2005-07. Ambac seeks, among other things, to recoup money it paid or accrued in insurance claims after mortgage loans that [BLANK] the securities defaulted. JPMorgan is named as a defendant as Bear Stearns' successor due to JPMorgan's 2008 acquisition of the failing bank.

Health-care investors should expect presidential upstart Evan McMullin's policies to align with House Speaker Paul Ryan, who released a 37-page health-care plan in June. That plan focused on traditional Republican goals of repealing and replacing Obamacare, [BLANK] Medicare into a premium-support model and transitioning Medicaid into a block-grant program for the states. Republicans can keep blocking Democrat-favored actions aimed at high drug prices if they retain control of at least the House.

Lloyds Banking Group and Santander's high exposure to profitable standard-variable mortgages is likely to come under increased pressure from competition, challenger banks and net-interest margin pain within the U.K. mortgage industry. Fixed-rate mortgages could [BLANK] increasingly attractive to U.K. homeowners, as the return of inflation and Brexit uncertainties make variable products increasingly undesirable. The visibility provided by fixed-rate mortgages may become the preferred option for lenders and borrowers.

SAP's new cloud bookings in 2Q were 162% greater than last year, while constant currency revenue growth was 92% higher, driven by strong adoption of customer engagement, commerce and human capital management products. SAP said it's been [BLANK] deals in this area over Oracle, Salesforce.com and Workday. Competition in the cloud application space has intensified, as Oracle and SAP allocate more and more resources to challenge pure-play vendors such as Salesforce.com and Workday.

The pace of disruption to legacy business models by companies such as Uber, Airbnb and Netflix will accelerate with greater adoption of artificial intelligence. The first set of disruptions was driven by greater use of smartphones and cloud, and the next will likely be [BLANK] by AI. Cloud-based companies will be at the forefront of this change. The agility provided by cloud allows these companies to change their products and services much more quickly than legacy companies, hastening the pace of disruption.

Units of BNP Paribas are defending lawsuits and government probes in the U.S. related to alleged benchmark rigging. The bank is [BLANK] in a proposed class-action private antitrust suit related to Treasury securities and is settling similar suits related to foreign exchange and credit-default swaps. BNP has also disclosed investigations related to foreign exchange trading. The bank, as a top CLO arranger, may benefit from a suit challenging Dodd-Frank risk-retention rules for CLO managers.

Portola's Factor Xa inhibitor antidote met the primary end point of its Phase III study with Bristol-Myers and Pfizer's Eliquis with high statistical significance, removing some element of clinical risk in its other registrational trial as an antidote to Johnson & Johnson and Bayer's Xarelto. A Phase II study with Daiichi Sankyo's edoxaban is also under way, and due to [BLANK] by year-end. Portola has a commanding position in the Factor Xa inhibitor antidote market. Xarelto is the most successful drug in the Factor Xa class.

Children's apparel was the only category to see sales slow from mid-month levels. Comparable sales [BLANK] 2.9% between April 25 and March 31, according to First Data's non-cash point-of-sale data. That marks a decline from the 1.5% dip through mid-April. Traffic remained weak, dropping 7%. Ticket, or amount spent, was up less than mid-month levels, rising 4.3%. This suggests that more promotions were probably needed to drive sales. The category may still report positive 1Q sales, given February and March strength.

TransCanada's latest volley of legal challenges aren't likely to settle, as the company's requested relief is basically all-or-nothing, and the government isn't likely to reverse course during the Obama administration. The company has asked courts to find the president doesn't have certain powers under the Constitution or to [BLANK] $15 billion in damages. Neither of those positions invite negotiation. If the White House changes hands to a Republican, then the likelihood of settlement increases.

President Barack Obama's Feb. 2 budget requests a 12% year-over-year increase in Veterans Affairs Department spending in 2016, which would generate revenue growth for the VA's top contractors, McKesson and Lockheed Martin. Bipartisan backing of the VA, one of the biggest agency winners in the proposal, means Congress is likely to [BLANK] higher spending. Obama projects $3.2 billion-a-year in new spending in 2015, 2016 and 2017 for veterans to use non-VA hospitals. HealthNet and Triwest Healthcare manage that care.

Amazon.com's pending acquisition of Whole Foods and the potential impact of its involvement in marketing packaged-food products will be an important topic during 2Q company conference calls with investors. The transaction is likely to be a net negative for the U.S. packaged-food industry, as it may quickly reduce packaged-food producers' [BLANK] leverage with food retailers, particularly for those with brands that are not category leaders.

The rapid increase in unstructured data continues to aid adoption of NoSQL databases over traditional relational databases. Both large vendors such as Amazon and Google as well as pure-play companies including MongoDB and DataStax have offered their NoSQL database products on the cloud to [BLANK] their adoption for big-data-use cases. While nonrelational databases are about 15% the size of the $31 billion relational market, they're expected to expand 15% annually vs. 6% for relational databases, using IDC data.

UnitedHealth expects its medical-loss ratio to rise 120 bps in 2017, despite largely exiting public health exchanges. The health-insurer fee moratorium is the culprit for the increase, though the impact is more than [BLANK] by lower SG&A and a better tax rate. A continued mix shift to more government products could put medical-loss ratios at risk for diversified insurers, such as Aetna, Anthem and Cigna. The insurer fee would have caused Centene's ratio to increase, but it's benefiting from more commercial members.

Both the debt and equity markets have been receptive to health-care REITs that are active in expanding or spinning off skilled-nursing portfolios. REITs that [BLANK] more than 10,000 skilled-nursing beds have issued $6.9 billion of debt and announced $4.4 billion of equity offerings since 1Q15, though FFO multiples trail peers. Care Capital and Omega Healthcare, the two primarily skilled-nursing REITs, returned to the debt markets in July after a three-month lull, issuing $500 million and $700 million, respectively.

Sales at sports-apparel retailers such as Lululemon, Nike and Under Armour may have accelerated from mid-month levels, based on noncash point-of-sale data from First Data. Preliminary comparable sales, from April 30 to May 25, gained 3.9%, driven largely by a 3% increase in traffic, but still [BLANK] behind last year's mid-to-high single digit growth. Ticket, or amount spent, rose 90 bps. Fresh summer inventory and warmer weather may be behind the acceleration from mid-month levels.

Intensifying competition in Russia's mobile market since summer should slow growth in 2H, but we think a prolonged deceleration is unlikely. Carriers are focusing on [BLANK] customer value amid still-robust demand for service, which means offers for unlimited data may be temporary. We are more concerned about the structural limits on medium-term growth.

Hikma-Vectura's generic of Advair, which would also be AB-rated or therapeutically equivalent to the brand, isn't far behind Mylan, with an FDA assigned review date of May 10. The delay in Mylan's approval doesn't give Hikma the lead since Mylan was first to [BLANK]. Teva's AB-rated version may not be available until late 2017 or 2018, though other forms will launch in 2017. Sandoz hasn't given clear guidance on timelines, though it did file a citizen's petition with the FDA, which was denied.

Iron ore prices have fallen 23% ytd in China as investors await a massive stimulus from the government that has yet to appear. If the new Chinese government is more Hayek-leaning and less Keynesian (intervention), [BLANK] less stimulus, and a move toward more accountable state-owned enterprises, then little stimulus may be forthcoming. This could lead to even further price declines for construction metals such as iron ore.

Most oil-services companies have been reluctant to give guidance on North America past 2Q, though signs of a bottom in the market are quickly emerging. With the industry's sales and margins likely to be challenged through 3Q, investors may focus more on 2016, [BLANK] for revisions to earnings outlooks, E&P spending and rig and well counts. Oil prices still may remain the biggest driver of share performance.

Property and casualty insurers generate a large portion of revenue from the investment of premiums prior to paying claims. Premiums are mostly [BLANK] in fixed-income assets with an average credit rating of AA/Aa and duration close to four years. Changes in interest rates have a prolonged yet gradual effect on earnings. After falling to an average 2.57% in 2012, AA rated, 10-year corporate yields (measured weekly) averaged 3.05% in 2013, 3.15% in 2014 and 3.03% in 2015 (through November).

Boston Scientific's $450 million acquisition of transcatheter aortic valve maker Symetis is largely predicated on near-term success in Europe, given the company hasn't started a U.S. trial. Boston said it has no timeline for U.S. approval and is still [BLANK] forward with its own Lotus Edge in mid-2018. That means it could take until 2021 for an approval, depending on which Symetis valve it chooses. Boston may be signaling that this deal isn't about replacing Lotus, but truly is complementary.

Currency depreciation may be the biggest driver of AES's 2Q adjusted EPS, which may decline 35%, based on consensus. The June Brexit vote [BLANK] after AES reaffirmed its most recent forecast range for an 18% drop in adjusted EPS in 2016, which may be lowered. Profit may have also fallen at its U.S. subsidiaries, given low power prices and margins in the PJM and California markets, where many of its power generation assets are located.

Renewable jet fuel from vegetable oils or fats is being promoted by the biofuel industry as a way to cut airline carbon emissions. Support has come from oil companies and refiners including Neste Oil, which [BLANK] a renewable jet fuel. Total owns 21% of renewable fuel company Amyris, with Eni and Petrixis building new biorefineries. Airlines such as Gol Linhas and Air France have run flights on biofuel blends with Cathay Pacific taking a stake in Fulcrum Biofuels.

Big beverage makers' relatively low water use and geographic diversity minimize their potential cost exposure to water pricing that reflects scarcity, according to an analysis by the Natural Capital Declaration and German development agency GIZ. For companies including Anheuser-Busch InBev, Diageo and Nestle, paying the "total economic value" for water that [BLANK] its theoretical value would have minimal impact on their net debt/Ebitda ratios. Femsa is an exception due to its water-parched Mexico focus.

The FCC incentive spectrum auction, delayed until at least 2016 due to broadcaster lawsuits, will free up 600 MHz licenses. The FCC is seeking as much as 120 MHz, potentially [BLANK] carriers $54 billion. This may prove ambitious depending on how willing the broadcasters are to relinquish spectrum, though the $44.9 billion paid for 65 MHz of AWS-3 spectrum suggests demand remains strong. The FCC plans to limit Verizon and AT&T's bidding, while Sprint and T-Mobile may jointly bid with others.

Comcast may be preparing to top Disney's $52.4 billion offer for select Fox TV and studio assets. Comcast's prior $60 billion offer (equity price) was [BLANK] on antitrust grounds. The transaction would have represented a rich 13.5x forward multiple, potentially diluting Comcast's EPS. Disney expects the transaction would boost EPS in the second year, with a $10 billion stock buyback.

Gilead's pan-genotypic NS5A inhibitor GS-5816 improves upon ledipasvir, part of a combination with Sovaldi branded as Harvoni. Bristol-Myers Squibb's own NS5A, daclatasvir, works well with Sovaldi (NS5B targeted), though Gilead [BLANK] to move forward with its own combination. Ledipasvir may be slightly less potent than daclatasvir, though clinicians are unlikely to use Bristol-Myers's combination unless it is significantly cheaper. GS-5816 may block any inroads Bristol makes.

Long-haul loads (1,000 miles or more) fell 5.3% in February vs. a year earlier. This marks the 31st straight decline as shippers look to more economical and environmentally friendly alternatives to long-haul trucking, such as rail, and adapt to [BLANK] supply chains driven by e-commerce. Loads have shifted to shorter routes (500 miles or less) since 2012. Short-haul loads have increased 6.4% so far this year, compared with a decline of 4.9% for long-haul loads, and were up 3.4% in February year-over-year.

Consensus expectations for 2015 loan-loss provisions at Sberbank and VTB have jumped 25% in the past three months. With central bank deputy governor Mikhail Sukhov [BLANK] that bad debt in Russia may grow a further $15 billion this year, it could rise to 7% of total loans from 4.7% in 2014. This ratio more than doubled to 6.3% in 2009, when the economy shrank 7.8%. Consensus estimates for 2015 Russian GDP to fall 3.8 percentage points in three months to minus 4%, which may also compound bad debt pressures.

Activist involvement in industrials has generated significant positive stock returns, as actions have often included major changes in management and operations. Following Relational's investment and a CEO change, Illinois Tool Works embarked on a five-year Enterprise Strategy in 2012 which has [BLANK] almost 600 bps of margin increase over two years. Operating margins rose 300 bps at ITT. Gains have been more modest at Ingersoll-Rand. Internal programs are expected to reap higher margins.

The global router market is dependent on capital spending by telecom and cable companies worldwide, which account for about 75% of total router sales. This market [BLANK] 2% year-over-year in 2Q to $3.7 billion vs. 11.4% growth in 2Q15, according to IDC. The drop is due to a steep decline in spending among U.S. and Chinese telecoms, as these carriers work to preserve cash for spectrum purchases, acquisitions and debt reduction. Capital spending may remain subdued and weigh on router growth for the foreseeable future.

The nascence of electric vehicles makes their drivetrain components expensive for owners and means high-margin sales for suppliers. Global EV sales rose 55% in 2016, but to just 695,000 units, according to BNEF, and are [BLANK] to remain below 1 million in 2017. Slow adoption will keep component costs relatively high, while providing margin expansion for suppliers able to establish early share. High-margin parts include electric motors, advanced batteries and high-voltage wiring, and power distribution systems.

A strong yen in the fiscal year ending March 2017 could weigh on Honda's revenue growth. So far in the September quarter, the yen has [BLANK] against the dollar by almost 20% from a year ago. Japanese carmakers sell most of their vehicles outside the country, making their sales and earnings sensitive to currency fluctuations. A stronger yen diminishes the converted value of overseas sales and also damps exports. A weakening yen would move it higher.

Li & Fung may strain to grow its 2016 turnover by 3% as projected by consensus if trading, 96% of its revenue, falls again. Persistent economic and retail sales uncertainties facing its core U.S. and Europe customers this year may [BLANK] in lower volumes and turnover. Trading revenue, made up of costs of manufacture and delivery of goods sourced at free-on-board or landed duty-paid prices plus fees, likely fell last year after 1H's 2.5% drop on lower prices and weak currencies to the dollar.

General Electric and Safran are winning the battle for scale and share in the engine business, which bolsters profitability and cash flow, fostering investment for future programs. The market share of the geared turbofan built by United Technologies (UTX) and MTU is [BLANK] its predecessor, the V2500, as design challenges have some airlines on the fence.

Hurricane Matthew may dent hotel occupancy, or demand, for Miami and Orlando due to their location near the coast as residents evacuate inland and flights in and out of these destinations are canceled. While 4Q may be a seasonally slower travel period, this may [BLANK] on the quarter's revenue per available room in each city. The quarter already faces tougher annualized comparisons. Hotel demand in Tampa and in surrounding regional markets may get a boost as residents on the eastern coast move away from the storm.

Distillate stocks are expected to continue to be drawn down due to strong U.S. demand, refinery outages and gasoline-heavy yields. Gasoline demand has also been strong, but margins are more subdued due to the seasonal switch to winter-grade components, likely [BLANK] to another week of inventory builds.

Office CMBS issuance dropped 13% in September to $2.1 billion, down from $2.4 billion in August. Although September's total [BLANK] the three-year monthly average of $1.7 billion, office-backed CMBS in 2016 has generally been weak. Five of the last nine months' issuance has been well below this long-term average, and the sector is on pace for $18.4 billion in total issuance, below the last two years. CMBS issuance for all sectors is on pace for $142 billion, a decline from the last three years.

Paragon filed a new Chapter 11 plan on Feb. 7 after Bankruptcy Judge Christopher Sontchi denied confirmation of its plan to reinstate term loan lenders and swap bondholders' debt for $285 million in cash and 47% new equity. The new deal would give secured lenders, [BLANK] the term loans, $421 million in cash, $85 million in new debt and 58% of new equity. Unsecured bondholders would receive $50 million cash and 42% equity, a large reduction from their proposed recoveries under the rejected plan.

Antitrust review of pharmaceutical mergers can stretch to a year, though Teva appears poised for clearance to close its Allergan generic-drug deal in about eight months since its July signing. Concessions have been offered and the company stated in February that it's "working closely with four to five potential buyers in [BLANK] necessary assets." Teva's experience with the process allows for efficiency. It's 2008 acquisition of Barr took less than six months, even with 29 drugs divested.

Sluggish consumer spending combined with warmer-than-normal winter and heavy retail promotions pushed branded apparel companies' free cash flow yields to the highest levels since 2013. The continued shift toward athletic wear in recent years has pressured stock prices at more fashion-focused brands, [BLANK] FCF yields higher at companies such as Ralph Lauren (5.8%) and PVH (6.1%), the owner of Calvin Klein and Tommy Hilfiger brands. Yields are less than 1% at Columbia Sportswear and Hanesbrands.

Automakers' in-house financing units could challenge Chinese banks' grip on the local car-loan market following asset-backed securities reforms. The changes will let companies such as Dongfeng-Nissan Auto Finance and Volkswagen Finance use ABS to diversify risk and [BLANK] wholesale funding. That could help overcome restraints from capital bases that are dwarfed by state-controlled lenders'. The finance arms have just 20% of the market, according to KPMG.

Lock-industry peers Allegion, Assa Abloy and Dormakaba all achieve operating margins above 20% in the U.S., the largest non-residential construction market. Commercial and institutional customers, such as offices, [BLANK] malls and public buildings, are the strongest adopters of higher-margin electronic and access-control systems. The U.S. also confers greater economies of scale for lockmakers' hardware products, such as doors, on which high transport costs necessitate production close to the customer.

Daimler sold its 3.9% holding in electric-car maker Tesla in October, saying it doesn't need a financial stake to continue working together on projects such as the Mercedes B-Class Electric. That [BLANK] Toyota alone among automakers with a Tesla stake. Daimler is one of the few manufacturers actively pursuing fuel cells, an alternative to electric vehicles. Toyota has firmly backed fuel cells. The Tesla holding effectively gives it an option to license electric technology if fuel cells fizzle.

Electric vehicles stand to gain popularity in China thanks to stricter emissions standards and potential limits on new-vehicle registrations. China is home to 12 of the world's 30 most-congested cities, [BLANK] Chongqing, Chengdu and Shijiazhuang, according to the TomTom Traffic Index. The government could cap new-vehicle registrations to ease traffic congestion and curb air pollution in those cities. Connected-car technology may also help ease gridlock by promoting efficiency through improved travel planning.

Fox and Dish are likely to settle their dispute over Dish's Primetime Anytime and Dish Anywhere services by Jan. 15, before the case goes to trial. In an Oct. 9 order, the court said it would be unlikely to [BLANK] the case again, having given the parties months to reach an agreement before the contract was set to expire in 4Q. That may push the parties to settle soon. Dish resolved similar rows with CBS and ABC, in part because it limited ad-skipping on its Primetime Anytime service.

North America-originated intermodal traffic rose 5.4% in the week ended April 8 (week 14) vs. 2016, based on AAR data. Volume rose for all Class I peers, except KC Southern (down 1.6%), which is [BLANK] to gain a footing amid peso pressures and competition from truckers (down 2.8% this year). Union Pacific's intermodal carloads rose 5% this week, yet are the next worse after KC Southern this year (down 1.3%). UP management expects ocean-carrier challenges will continue to weigh on intermodal traffic in 2017.

Lynn Helms, director of North Dakota's Department of Mineral Resources (DMR), provided a roadmap for the Bakken's resurgence during May's Williston Basin Petroleum Conference. Between $55-$60 a barrel, operators would [BLANK] drilled but uncompleted wells (DUCs), and as oil prices move above $60 on a sustainable basis, drilling new wells would accelerate. Delays in completing the Dakota Access Pipeline have created uncertainty and hindered producer plans to ramp activity.

Banks with between $10 billion and $250 billion in assets may be able to return more capital, have easier stress testing and see other regulatory constraints lifted by regulators in 2018. The $50 billion threshold for systemically important financial institutions should be [BLANK] by 2Q. That may be a catalyst for bank growth, especially for those below $50 billion in assets. Regulators will also begin tweaking Dodd-Frank with additional changes to the qualitative stress test, compliance requirements and reporting in mind.

An appeal by Fairholme, Perry Capital and other Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac shareholders over the dismissal of their lawsuits challenging a 2012 change to the 2008 bailout of the GSEs may have about $160 billion at stake. That amount reflects a possible outcome if shareholders [BLANK] in retroactively returning the dividend rate back to 10% from the "net worth sweep" and recharacterizing excess payments as partial redemption of Treasury's shares.

Office REIT acquisition and disposition strategies can be dependent on interest rates, which dictate capital flows and asset values. If Treasury yields rise in 2016, capitalization rates may increase and office building values may [BLANK]. When capitalization rates rise, REITs often become buyers in cities such as New York and San Francisco, where purchases are currently considered too expensive by many REITs. Higher rates also raise REITs' cost of capital, so many have locked in debt before rates rise.

Shareholders and noteholders of American Realty Capital Properties (now VEREIT) have survived dismissal motions and seek class certification in securities fraud suits against the company after the 2014 disclosure of intentional accounting errors and subsequent departures of Chairman Nicholas Schorsch and others. Most of the suits are [BLANK] in New York federal court. The company is cooperating with Justice Department, SEC and state investigations. Former officers have been hit with criminal charges.

The German power market dominates the northeastern European market, which includes new EU states. Electricity prices are [BLANK] by coal-fired power plants accounting for about 50% of the total output. Germany's market is characterized by low fuel costs and excess capacities, which maintains power-price pressure in the region. Nuclear plants planned in Poland, the Czech Republic and Hungary, as well as the steady growth in renewables, may fill the supply gap as E.ON and RWE's German nuclear plants are phased out.

Postal carriers are looking to e-commerce growth to help offset a secular decline in mail and further diversify revenue sources. Mail volume in many developed countries has [BLANK] 10-40% over the past five years. Singapore Post and Bpost are actively balancing their revenue streams with acquisitions to further penetrate the supply chain and capitalize on e-commerce growth. Some postal carriers have also diversified into retail, banking and telecommunications to take advantage of their physical locations.

Investors that brought an antitrust suit against 16 banks in the global foreign exchange market may be emboldened by a $2 billion agreement reached with nine defendants that triggers extensive cooperation on their part, if it wins court approval. The remaining defendant banks have pending bids to [BLANK] the suit and may have good arguments. Neither Credit Suisse, Deutsche Bank nor Morgan Stanley have been fined by regulators and all deny taking part in a currency-rigging conspiracy.

Boston Scientific and Medtronic may gain implantable cardioverter defibrillator market share in 2015 due to new, smaller devices and quadripolar leads that cut side effects. Medtronic [BLANK] its quadripolar device in the U.S. in September, while Boston [BLANK] its devices in April. Medtronic also introduced the first MRI-safe device in Japan in 4Q, while Boston may gain market share with the industry's only subcutaneous ICD.

Roche's 2018-22 EPS growth rate risks being lowered, as Tecentriq's 2022 sales estimates were raised 30% despite the colon-cancer failure, weak lung data, U.S. bladder restrictions and second-line lung pressure in 2018. Roche's PE is at a historical low, yet is the highest-valued large-pharma on 2018-22 EPS growth of 2.9%, [BLANK] little room for error.

Vows by Democratic lawmakers to pass H.R. 870 via the appropriations process, where the bill would be tied to must-pass legislation, will most likely fail. Several [BLANK] and somewhat controversial bills have passed in prior years via the tactic. With Republicans in control of Congress and the Obama administration's desire for a "clean" budget, the idea will struggle to gain traction. H.R. 870's best chance is for Senator Chuck Grassley to endorse it in his Dec. 1 hearing, which will prove difficult.

Time is likely the biggest threat to a House-Senate deal that would limit the availability of EB-5 immigrant investor financing for high-end real estate developments. The proposal increasing investment and job creation requirements emerged on Dec. 4, a week before the authority for the underlying program is set to [BLANK]. Sen. Charles Schumer, a New York Democrat, and other EB-5 supporters are likely to push back on Congress' adoption of drastic reforms. A short-term extension absent reforms is likely.

After a dismal start, the summer box office has recovered with season-to-date receipts (as of Aug. 28) 1.1% above the same period last year. Receipts have [BLANK] from a 20% year-over-year decline in mid-June and 8% drop in mid-July. In general, franchises and sequels have struggled to find large audiences although some low-to-modest budget movies such as "Secret Life of Pets" and "Don't Breathe" topped expectations. Disney's "Finding Dory" has been the season's biggest film, with $480 million in sales.

Brazilian banks' outperformance in 3Q, following an average 22% increase in 1H for the country's four largest lenders, is likely to mean there will be little margin for error when results season kicks off on Oct. 26. Most recent central-bank data showed that lending [BLANK] year-over-year in August and weak credit demand is likely to remain a concern. Key for sentiment will be a reduction in non-performing loan inflows, though average new-loan rates above 30% continue to challenge borrowers' ability to repay.

Defense revenue from foreign clients represent 24% of total sales in 2015 for the five biggest U.S. contractors, from 16% in 2009. Sales to foreign military customers rose 10% in 2015, while those in the U.S. [BLANK] 2.4%. Backlogs indicate more growth is expected, as foreign customers bolster forces and capabilities. General Dynamics' international defense sales rose 11% in 2015 on IT demand, and new vehicle awards have aided its backlog. Lockheed expects overseas sales to be 25% of its total, from 21% currently.

Comcast's foray into wireless is cautious, with the company initially only going after existing customers. The move [BLANK] it to gauge demand and make calculated adjustments along the way. The company is keeping expectations low, citing a low-to-mid-single-digit penetration of its broadband base (1.2 million) as a reasonable first target. While the near-term goal is to lower churn and accelerate customers' bundle uptake, the long-term aspiration may be either building a network or buying someone else's.

Banks generally tightened commercial real estate credit in the July Fed Senior Loan Officer Survey, though the net number fell across loan types to the lowest in several quarters. Apartment lending showed the least net [BLANK] since October 2015. Banks have pulled back in the past year or so amid regulator concerns, reflected in CRE loan growth slowing to about 5% year-over-year in 2Q from closer to 10% in 2Q16. Banks on net reported eased lending standards again for larger and smaller customers in July.

Scor's 2Q results are likely to be held back by an accounting charge in the lower half of a $0-$350 million guided range related to U.S. tax reform and the Base Erosion and Anti Abuse Tax legislation. This has [BLANK] SCOR to restructure some of its operations. Scor's underlying performance should have remained strong after 2Q continued the 1Q trend of relatively benign catastrophe claims experience. In 1Q, Scor reported net income of 166 million euros, up 18.6%. The tax charge is expected to have limited impact on Scor's solvency ratio and no effect on the ability of the group to pay a progressive dividend.

Johnson & Johnson's new drug sales may rise at an annualized rate of 9% from 2014 to 2020, based on consensus, the lowest among peers. Olysio is the main drag, with consensus expecting $1.6 billion [BLANK] to drugs from AbbVie and Gilead from 2014 through 2015. Xarelto faces pressure from Bristol Myers' Eliquis, which has a best-in-class efficacy profile, while Medivation's Xtandi could hurt Zytiga. Norvartis' Cosentyx for psoriasis could hinder Stelara and biosimilar launches may curb autoimmune portfolio growth.

Supply-demand trends and pricing in both DRAM and NAND memory are likely to remain positive drivers for Micron sales in the near term. Micron's equity offering amid strong stock returns [BLANK] management taking tactical advantage of trends to shore up capital. Even as memory makers are extremely rational now, supply actions by Samsung and Toshiba in particular need to be closely watched, particularly in 2H18 and beyond. Chinese higher-end phones remain a key demand factor.

Hewlett-Packard and Computer Sciences are among those facing challenges in their IT infrastructure outsourcing businesses. This has been driven by an increase in cloud computing, more competition from offshore vendors, greater emphasis on software, price compression as chief information officers seek funding to [BLANK] in emerging technologies and the trend of smaller outsourcing contracts. These trends are likely to continue for the next few years, pressuring the industry and company revenue growth.

Chipmakers with greater industrial, Internet of Things (IoT) and automotive exposure should be better positioned in 2H, given sector strength illustrated by recent 2Q results. Customer demand has been strong and, [BLANK] with healthy inventories, sales momentum should continue into 3Q for companies including Texas Instruments, Microchip, Silicon Labs, Cypress and others.

Highway spending, two-thirds of transportation outlays, rose 6% in May, with gains across most categories. U.S. highway awards, which precede construction spending, fell 9%, which could [BLANK] in lower spending in 2019. With hopes of a federal infrastructure program shelved, outlays are likely to remain muted.

A majority of software vendors, including Microsoft, SAP and Oracle, are transitioning from a traditional license-based sales model to subscriptions. In this model, users pay a recurring fee rather than a large upfront payment and the software is generally [BLANK] via the cloud. This change increases insight into revenue but compresses margins in the short-term. The deferral of revenue to future quarters and the cost of investing in cloud infrastructure are the main reasons for margin compression.

Notwithstanding a loss in an early motion, the wastewater injection defendants still hold an edge in the overall case. The precedent supports the defendants' position that any link between wastewater injection and earthquake activity is insufficient to [BLANK] the injectors liable for earthquake damage in a courtroom. A finding for the plaintiffs on the issue of whether these companies can be held liable would create legal precedent, which is rare. The prior motion loss was expected.

Mitsubishi UFJ, Sumitomo Mitsui and Mizuho may report faster corporate loan growth this year and improved pricing as the weak yen will probably boost demand from exporters. Bank of Japan [BLANK] may also spur economic growth and investment gains for the megabanks. Risks include easing leading to inflation and higher staff salaries. The banks are seeking higher asset yields overseas.

As the U.S. premium has widened to the rest of the world, investors have turned to Europe for value. However, Europe as a whole now trades at a premium to its five-year average relative to world-developed markets [BLANK] the U.S., largely due to industrials and financials. In Developed Europe, just two sectors -- technology and health care -- offer discounts relative to the rest of the developed world on a volatility-adjusted basis and compared with five-year average forward price-to-earnings ratios.

E*Trade's organic revenue growth will likely be a focus on its 4Q call, the first full quarter since the company set a goal to boost the metric by two-three percentage points over 18-24 months. Trading may [BLANK] revenue as trade volume gains accelerated to 40% in November vs. about 18% growth since its September OptionsHouse acquisition. Total client-asset growth averaged just 0.3% in October and November vs. a 1% pace for the first 11 months of 2016. Net-interest income makes up about 60% of revenue.

Biotech and pharma events include Phase III data of Portola's anticoagulant betrixaban in acute medically ill patients and Tesaro's niraparib in ovarian cancer. Keryx [BLANK] Auryxia data for expanding to pre-dialysis chronic kidney disease. Ariad will reveal first data of a pivotal trial in non-small cell lung cancer. Array expects Phase III data of selumetinib in non-small cell lung cancer and a binimetinib/encorafenib combination in melanoma. Karyopharm awaits data from pivotal blood-cancer trials.

Apartment REIT transaction volume returned to historically normal levels in January, after December's $5.3 billion spike driven by the Mid-America acquisition of Post Properties.
