Should the Food and Drug Administration deem electronic cigarettes a tobacco product, the ban on characterizing flavors, excluding menthol, won't automatically extend to e-cigs. The FDA would need to [BLANK] a separate product standard. Several groups and the president's congressional allies want the FDA to ban e-cig flavors as part of a final "deeming rule," or in a separate action issued at the same time. The flavor ban wasn't part of the proposed rule. The final rule has been under review since October.

FTR's Trucking Conditions Index jumped 56% to 7.7 in June from May. The index has been positive for 39 consecutive months, [BLANK] favorable market conditions, yet is still down 10.5% this year and 43% below the January 2010 peak of 13.5. FTR expects the index to fall about 8% on average this year from 2014. While capacity should remain tight because of a driver shortage, and demand is still strong, disappointing economic growth is tempering truckers' expectations for 2H.

American Realty Capital Properties may name Glenn Rufrano as its new CEO, according to the Wall Street Journal. This will [BLANK] some of the uncertainty that has existed since ARCP's Chairman and CEO resigned in December and may please current investors due to Rufrano's past tenure as CEO of REITs New Plan Excel and Centro Properties. Yet, naming a new CEO will likely have minimal bearing on existing lawsuits, which are based on activities that occurred under previous leadership.

Domestic pricing power will be weak for U.S. airlines in 2018 as most continue to expand. We believe domestic U.S. capacity will increase by almost 5.5% as United and Southwest add about 5%, Alaska and JetBlue around 7.5%, Allegiant 11-15% and Spirit and Frontier [BLANK] 20%. Lower-cost carriers are focused on taking market share from full-service providers, while larger carriers such as United and Southwest appear ready to defend share.

A patient was admitted to a Texas hospital on Sept. 28 with a confirmed Ebola infection. The CDC is [BLANK] individuals who came into contact with the patient before his admission, as well as exposed health-care workers. The virus has an incubation period of two to 21 days. The effectiveness of the CDC's response and procedures will be tested within the next two weeks as new cases would be expected to emerge by then.

Pfizer's Ibrance and Novartis's Farydak were the only new 1Q chemical approvals for U.S. and EU large drugmakers. Ibrance [BLANK] accelerated approval in breast cancer, showing considerable survival benefit compared with letrozole, a current standard of care. The novel CDK-4/6 inhibitor is key to Pfizer's sales growth and could sell $4.2 billion in 2020, based on consensus. Farydak's win in multiple myeloma was against the vote of the panel, which was concerned about safety and potential survival-benefit discrepancies.

High-profile drugs for Alkermes and Mylan are set to test 2Q consensus, Symphony data show, while Valeant may need a nudge in price. Alkermes' Vivitrol flat-lined in June but is still on track to [BLANK] 2Q estimates. Collectively, key branded drugs for Valeant were a mixed bag, with ophthalmology growing a healthy 9%, gastrointestinal flat and dermatology down 8% sequentially. Jublia continues to weaken. Best-selling Xifaxan was flat. Regeneron-Sanofi's Dupixent launch looks impressive and may top estimates.

Nomura and Royal Bank of Scotland will be in court for oral arguments on Nov. 18 in their appeal of a 2015 residential mortgage-backed securities trial verdict against them in a lawsuit by the Federal Housing Finance Agency, conservator for Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac. Though appeal briefing [BLANK], the court on Oct. 25 asked for additional briefs on a right-to-jury argument. A ruling by the appeals court is likely in 1H. The banks' $806 million trial judgment payment was deferred pending the appeal.

VMware will continue to work with Hewlett-Packard, Lenovo and other companies following the Dell-EMC merger, according to VMware CEO Patrick Gelsinger. Similarly, Dell will not exclusively choose VMware for its hardware products and will [BLANK] its partnership with other software companies such as Microsoft and Red Hat. In the longer term, these lines may be redrawn. Hardware and software companies are increasingly becoming more open to competitive products driven by client demand and rising use of open source.

Medicare has proposed to increase dialysis reimbursement 0.8% in 2018, according to CMS, 10 bps faster than this year's pace as cuts instituted by the Affordable Care Act wane before completely lapsing in 2019. The increase is largely in-line with expectations from DaVita and Fresenius, and should modestly [BLANK] each company's revenue per dialysis treatment. Final rates are due at the end of October and have only been 10 bps higher than proposed rates since 2012, excluding a large reversal in 2014.

Vectrus, which began regular trading Sept. 29, joins pure-play government services companies Engility and SAIC in the hunt for federal contract dollars to offset declining war-related work. Since 2012, revenue has declined for Engility, SAIC, Exelis, L-3 and Leidos as the Iraq and Afghanistan wars have [BLANK] down. The unit that became Vectrus, spinning off from Exelis, won two recent $100 million-plus contracts unrelated to the war.

AstraZeneca could provide a much better earnings boost for Pfizer than Bristol-Myers Squibb, assuming a 30% premium for both, if it were to use cash from new debt and proceeds from a consumer-health sale. Political pressure will likely be [BLANK] on both sides of the Atlantic on either deal, making big cost savings very difficult.

Akorn's abbreviated new-drug application pipeline rivals larger generic-drug makers such as Endo, Aurobindo and Dr. Reddy's. The portfolio may be the seventh-largest, based on company filings [BLANK] the number of FDA applications at the end of 2016. This supports a consensus view that revenue growth may be double that of peers in 2017-20. Yet Akorn fell short on approvals expected by 1Q due to issues at a manufacturing site, making its target of 15-20 launches for the year key to proving its portfolio worth.

The DTN/Progressive Farmer Agribusiness Confidence Index remained negative in December, declining to 88.4 from 90.6 in August and 97.6 in December 2015. The current conditions index [BLANK] to 89.4 from 105.6, falling below the neutral reading of 100 for only the second time on record. Unlike farmers, suppliers remain pessimistic about the outlook, with the future index at 87.5 vs. 79.7 pre-harvest. Farm lending is still healthy for operating expenses, yet the sector's credit conditions have tightened.

Boston Scientific's Lotus transcatheter valve delay will reduce its organic revenue growth in 2018, but the company reiterated its 2020 margin outlook of 28%. Revenue growth for Medtronic and Edwards Lifesciences should improve as competition in Europe and the U.S. have been [BLANK] indefinitely.

Global automakers' enterprise value-to-forward Ebitda multiple is 5.2x, about 15% less than the three-year average and 48% below the MSCI World Index. Automakers' valuations tend to [BLANK] with geographic exposure, as a presence in faster-growing areas warrants relative premiums. Premiums can be seen in Asian multiples, especially Chinese companies where regional sales volume and growth has been high. The overall discount probably reflects the vehicle market's seasonal, slower-growing nature.

Cisco's second International Trade Commission patent case against Arista is scheduled to begin trial on Nov. 9. ITC staff attorneys will likely [BLANK] their position as to the validity and infringement of Cisco's asserted patents on the first day of the trial. The judge will issue an initial determination in April 2016, which is subject to review by August 2016. The staff positions were favorable to Cisco in its parallel ITC action, which went to trial in September 2015.

Swedish politicians have agreed to support nuclear and hydro generators as well as offshore wind farms. Generators' costs will be [BLANK] at the expense of higher household energy tariffs, with heavy industry spared. As four out of 10 reactors are to be decommissioned by 2020, Sweden wants to avoid the situation seen in the U.K., where spare power capacity is near lows. The new policy may help prevent or stem further closings amid low prices, but is unlikely to spur material nuclear and hydropower capacity additions.

The influence of severe acute respiratory syndrome influence on air travel amid the outbreak may provide an idea of Ebola's effect. SARS affected airline travel in the first half of 2003 and was centered on China when the World Health Organization issued a travel warning in April that was [BLANK] in early July of that year. SARS may have had the largest effect on Chinese airlines results, while other companies were more affected by the fighting in Iraq.

Average truckload spot rates per mile, including fuel surcharges, decreased 1.4% to $1.89 in the week ended Oct. 9, according to Internet Truckstop. All equipment types [BLANK], led by specialized (down 4.2% to $2.40) and temperature-controlled, which fell 3.6% to $1.92. Total spot rates were 15.7% lower vs. last year, driven by an estimated 48% drop in fuel surcharges. Spot rates excluding surcharges may have fallen 5.9%, which is far from Knight's expectation of a 3% to 5% contractual rate gain.

Middle East and Africa chocolate confectionery volume may grow the fastest among emerging markets, at almost 6% a year through 2018 vs. 5% in Asia and 4.5% in Latin America, Euromonitor data show. Western Europe, forecast to [BLANK] only 1%, is by far the world's largest region by demand. EU cocoa ingredients and chocolate confectioners are expanding to capitalize on emerging markets' booming demand. In 2014, Callebaut opened a plant in Chile and Nestle opened one in Egypt.

Mortgage banking income generally rose sequentially in 2Q with volumes across the largest banks, and may modestly rise in 3Q with smaller volume increases. Year-ago comparisons also [BLANK] in 2H. Lower production and mortgage repurchase expenses may further aid profit in 2H following staff cuts and large provisions taken during the past few years. Mortgage servicing profit may also be helped by lower costs with better credit, and servicing values may rise with rates.

O'Reilly quarterly results will continue to ease investors into the reality of weakness medium-term organic growth as demand remains lower after several years of strong new-vehicle sales and mild weather muting some winter purchases. The company will use 2H to show that the business is strong and that its current initiatives will [BLANK] results in 2018. A growth recovery in the cornerstone commercial business will be important after the DIY segment achieved the rare feat of outpacing it in 2Q.

The gap between consensus target prices and share prices reflects the market outlook for electrical peers. A higher differential could mean that risks from the slowdown in China, [BLANK] heavy-industry demand and dollar strength have already been factored in to share prices, with the recovery in Europe acting as a positive catalyst. Within the peer group, diversified European companies with U.S. exposure and those with strong order backlogs are the most optimistic, based on consensus targets.

After prolonged outages, EDF's French reactor availability rose to 89% vs. 77% a month ago. Yet Alpine's hydrologic deficit [BLANK] its highest since May 2011 and will persist through March, based on Markedskraft data. Alpine hydropower reserves remain below seasonal norms. German nuclear availability is also low amid refueling schedules and extended outages at EnBW's reactor. All of this may keep 1Q wholesale power prices elevated as lower hydropower output is replaced by higher-cost thermal generation.

Japan's hotel revenue per available room rose 2.3% in July, driven by a 3.8% room rate increase, cooling from last year's boom. Operators are raising room rates as visitors to the country [BLANK] 20% in July, led by a 27% surge in Chinese tourists, who make up one-third of arrivals. Occupancy in Tokyo and Osaka reached nearly 90%, suggesting a room shortage. Operators have raised rates in response, even as they are challenged by other lodging options such as guest houses and Airbnb.

Relative trucking demand, as measured by the Internet Truckstop's Market Demand Index, rose 0.8% to 17.9 in the week ended Nov. 28. Relative demand [BLANK] for a third straight week even though capacity loosened slightly. Available loads fell 32.1%, while truck availability dropped 31.2%, both declining in a week shortened due to the Thanksgiving holiday. Retailers will seek to maximize inventories leading up to the December holidays, so the index may rise in the coming weeks.

Bradesco reduced its loan growth guidance for 2014 to a range of 7% to 11%, down from 10% to 14% in 3Q, echoing peers Banrisul, Banco Pine and Banco ABC, who cut their forecasts in 2Q. The bank's outlook cited credit growth rates as ``risk-compatible,'' alluding to a shift among Brazilian banks toward safer [BLANK] lending. A by-product of this move may be lower net interest margins (NIM), with HSBC attributing its nine-month yoy decline in NIM partly to the changing composition of Brazilian loans.

The industry's second-largest orderbook ensures Cosco will stay as the world's third-biggest liner company for the foreseeable future. Having been replaced by Cosco, CMA CGM could either order more ships or seek mergers to [BLANK] its position. These are both difficult options, in our view. Challenges would stem from CMA CGM's large debt burden and getting anti-trust approvals.

IBM's patent lawsuit against Groupon seeks money damages and could resolve in a royalty-bearing license. IBM sued after private negotiations failed, alleging that Groupon's website and mobile applications infringe four company patents [BLANK] to technology in IBM's Prodigy services. The litigation could test the strength of the IBM patents-at-issue, affecting the company's ability to monetize the patents against others. IBM reported $117 million in 2015 licensing and royalty revenue, down 9.8% from 2014.

The SPDR S&P Oil & Gas Exploration & Production ETF (XOP) is up 22% this year, the most among larger-sized energy and oil ETFs, tracking crude oil's 21% surge. The ETF [BLANK] 7.4% in August as oil surged 13%. It was also among the best-performing oil-related ETFs in 2009, returning 40% as crude oil gained 78%. The fund has $1.6 billon in assets and an annual fee of 0.35%.

Truckmakers' production rates may be peaking as backlogs decline, orders slow and customers delay deliveries. Open 4Q build slots for North American heavy trucks [BLANK] at 31% in September, up from 24% a year ago. Build slots for 2016 are being scheduled earlier than normal as open slots filled faster for a third month, with 1Q 51% unfilled in September vs. 58% in September 2014 and 2Q's 69% unfilled (vs. 85% last year). The recent spike in order cancellations may put deliveries at risk.

The opening weekend is the most important period in a movie's theatrical run, typically accounting for 30% of its domestic box office. Sales usually [BLANK] significantly by the second weekend. Estimates for the opening weekend and the domestic run help gauge performance for both the industry and studios. Revenue during this time is critical because it helps determine the profitability of the film for its non-theatrical window.

China Telecom's sales growth may slow in 2Q as 4G matures and rivalry intensifies. Margins may expand thanks to lower infrastructure expenses amid less capital spending, and network [BLANK] with China Unicom. Canceled domestic long-distance and roaming charges won't affect China Telecom's financials until 4Q and will only touch a small percentage of sales later. An acceleration of 4G net additions with improved networks and market-share gains from China Mobile boosted sales growth in 1Q.

Advanced Silicon's case at the International Trade Commission pitting AMD patents against a slew of automotive and semiconductor companies could begin by Jan. 27. After a complaint is filed, the ITC has 30 days to [BLANK] whether to institute a full investigation of the alleged patent infringement. The ITC's decision is made after third parties are given the opportunity to comment on how a U.S. import ban on the accused products could affect the public interest. The ITC rarely denies institution.

Bristol-Myers Squibb's bid to have its Baraclude appeal reheard was denied, yet four dissenting judges would have granted a rehearing arguing that the original decision may be interpreted as changing precedent on obviousness. Although all the judges agreed on the law of obviousness as it should be [BLANK] to this case, the split centers on the way the lower court opinion could be read. Bristol-Myers has until late January to petition the Supreme Court, though the high court is unlikely to take up the case.

Supermarket operators such as Kroger, Delhaize and Roundy's may find some margin relief as the price gap to competitors such as Wal-Mart and Target abates. Grocers have [BLANK] operational efficiencies, selection and competitive pricing, building options for shoppers around convenience with loyalty rewards. This has reduced the appeal of driving to a supercenter for smaller-than-historical savings, hampering the ability of supercenters to steal traffic.

Qualcomm's revenue and EPS guidance for the near and intermediate term is contingent on what Apple is likely to pay. If Qualcomm only gets what Apple [BLANK] under an earlier agreement, royalty payments will likely revert to levels proportional to those before Sept. 30. Withholding all royalties would make it hard for Apple to show its willingness to license Qualcomm's patents on fair, reasonable and non-discriminatory terms in court.

Chinese internet giants Alibaba, Tencent and Baidu are aggressively acquiring businesses for long-term growth, with $24 billion spent last year, according to Beijing consultancy ITjuzi. The trend likely will continue as they search for growth areas to invest their cash which can [BLANK] their user bases. Their dominance will become stronger as new business segments mature and contribute to growth in the next 5-10 years.

Optimism about rising world demand for U.S. LNG persists, even amid lower oil prices and tighter competition, as two new projects move forward. Energy Transfer Equity is seeking Federal Energy Regulatory Commission approval to [BLANK] the Lake Charles export terminal, a 2.2 billion cubic-feet-a-day facility in Louisiana, expected be in service in 2Q19. BG Group will be the project's only customer. Sempra has requested a pre-filing review on a 1.4 bcfd LNG terminal in Port Arthur, Texas.

The share of service sales in China needs to increase for major elevator companies to see their margins recover. During the past five years, Asia-Pacific sales have [BLANK] on average, primarily from selling new equipment into China. Margins have narrowed by an average 180 basis points since 2010, because new equipment is less lucrative than service sales. Given the Chinese service market is competitive and fragmented, converting installed units to long-term service contracts may be harder than in other regions.

Hedge funds, insurance companies and non-bank financial firms may face more disclosure, leverage and liquidity requirements under a Hillary Clinton administation. In April, Clinton repeated her claim that the shadow banking industry needs further regulation, specifically [BLANK] insurers and hedge funds. Her plan calls for margin and collateral requirements for repurchase agreements, strengthening leverage and liquidity rules for broker-dealers and empowering the FSOC to address risk from non-traditional banking.

Changes in China's cotton market lowered global prices of the commodity, creating an opportunity for apparel makers to reduce costs and expand margins. Cotton remains the most commonly used raw material in the apparel industry and fluctuations in its price often [BLANK] merchandise margins. Chinese cotton prices have fallen since the government in 2014 enacted a subsidy to protect local growers, replacing a floor-price system set up in 2011.

While legislation making it more difficult for the Federal Trade Commission to block mergers, passed the House on March 23, it faces longer odds in the Senate. Many Democrats, including President Barack Obama, oppose it, which is an indication that Senate Democrats will [BLANK] the bill, H.R. 2745, from reaching the chamber floor. Tobacco, retail and other industries whose mergers are subject to review by the FTC could have an easier time getting deals approved if the bill becomes law.

Post-1Q Earnings Outlook: Suzuki's profit should rise as demand for mini-vehicles in Japan, also known as Kei cars, recovers and as new models boost sales and earnings from overseas, including Europe. The Japanese automaker should [BLANK] more robust earnings growth than rivals. The rebranding of dealerships in India boosted sales at its venture with Maruti. The carmaker's operating profit margin will probably widen as production exceeds retail sales, which cuts fixed per-unit costs of production and marketing.

Chinese power companies this year have bid for assets from Brazil (State Grid Corp. of China) to Pakistan (Shanghai Electric Power) with domestic M&A by China Resources Power and Huadian Fuxin. Longyuan Power has [BLANK] in Canada and is constructing a wind farm in South Africa while Shenhua Energy is building a coal-fired power plant in Indonesia. While all are looking for more, State Grid was blocked from buying a network in Australia for "national interest" reasons.

For Airbnb, safety, taxation and its impact on cities with housing shortages are some of the thornier issues it must confront before launching an IPO. The home-sharing service is trying to be collaborative with local governments, yet regulators, often [BLANK] by an entrenched and influential hotel industry, still create friction globally.

Sales for the week leading up to Halloween improved 0.6% over the same period last year. October monthly sales [BLANK] short of Redbook's 0.8% target due to weakness in the department store sector and a lack of consumer spending before year-end holiday promotions. Department store monthly sales slid 0.3%, 70 bps behind Redbook's expectation. Discounter sales rose 1% in the week ending Oct. 29, though food price deflation persists.

Digital advertising and e-commerce are likely to be among the earliest sectors to get a sales boost from their adoption of artificial intelligence technologies. Machine learning is likely to improve [BLANK] efforts for programmatic digital ads and purchase recommendations in e-commerce, which may support sales and improvements in ad ROI. Google CEO Sundar Pichai said in 2Q that AI-driven video recommendations on YouTube are already supporting increased user watch time on the site.

San Francisco apartment rent growth is expected to be but by almost half the next two years, slowing to 5.7% in 2017 from a high of 10.8% in 2015. Reis [BLANK] rent-growth deceleration to be far less pronounced on the East Coast, where year-over-year comparisons are easier. New West Coast supply is one of the primary drivers of converging rent gains. Apartment completions in San Francisco and Seattle are expected to reach the highest levels in at least a decade in 2016.

Europe is likely to stay a weak market for electrical power equipment suppliers in 2015 and beyond, which may encourage changes in strategy such as increased focus on renewables and power grid. European utilities are under pressure to cut unprofitable assets as over-capacity and high fuel costs [BLANK] earnings. Mechanisms such as capacity payments, lower gas prices or higher carbon prices could help ease this situation, though it's unlikely that any of these will occur in 2015.

Settlement may be on the horizon between Petrobras and investors suing the company, given that only a few months remain until their September trial. Class plaintiffs may be more amenable to negotiate after an appeals court [BLANK] Petrobras' petition for appeal, thereby jeopardizing their class status and the leverage it conveys. For Petrobras, the combination of institutional investors, which lend credibility and gravitas to the allegations, with class plaintiffs likely amps up the pressure to settle as well.

Liberty Global's operating cash flow-growth of 4.3% and free cash flow of $2 billion achieved full-year guidance. This [BLANK] significant acceleration in revenue-generating unit growth, robust controls on indirect costs and the boost from price hikes across the group. However, the slowdown in broadband net additions in the U.K., which leads in network expansion, following a second price increase in the year by November, highlights limits to pricing power.

Switzerland-based Nestle is the world's largest publicly owned packaged food company, generating $70.5 billion in food sales in 2014, up 0.6% from the prior year. The diverse product portfolio [BLANK] chocolate, baby food and pet food. Brazil-based JBS is the second-largest, with 2014 food sales of $51.3 billion, including beef, pork, lamb and chicken. Tyson ranks third, with 2014 food sales of $37.6 billion from a wide variety of meats.

European telecom carriers' prospects for growth in 2015 will be driven by their ability to monetize data demand and their readiness to compete in convergence offers. While competition will continue to be fierce in mobile, consolidation in Ireland, Austria and Germany may support [BLANK] power. Continued cost-cutting and reduced capital expenditure for some, as network deployments advance, will support cash generation. Deal activity will be driven by consolidation and convergence.

Samson Resources restructuring-support agreement is undergoing a revamp after continued low oil and gas prices, the CEO's announced resignation and challenges from unsecured creditors. Samson [BLANK] for bankruptcy on Sept. 16 with a pre-arranged restructuring agreement with second-lien lenders that would wipe out holders of $2.25 billion in unsecured notes, including Oaktree and Centerbridge. Equity sponsors KKR and Crestview that invested $4 billion in an LBO in 2011 would also be wiped out.

While further escalations remain a risk, trade tensions have already been weighing on recent factor performance, and a fair amount of risk aversion appears to be already baked in. Looking ahead to the earnings season, value's underperformance to growth will likely continue unless we see strong evidence that the growth differential between the two is [BLANK].

CenturyLink is defending itself against lawsuits alleging it defrauded millions of internet customers and caused $600 million-$12 billion in damages, a long shot for plaintiffs even at the low end of the range. Similar government suits on "cramming," or [BLANK] unauthorized, misleading or deceptive charges, have led to settlements of $68-$105 million. Also, CenturyLink has a good chance of thwarting the nine class-action suits likely to be combined. Fighting a Minnesota attorney-general lawsuit will be tougher.

A proposed Consumer Financial Protection Bureau rule to expand supervision of nonbank auto finance companies would affect 38 nonbanks that originate or refinance at least 10,000 auto loans a year. The plan gives the CFPB the authority to [BLANK] or lower that threshold in the final rule. A range of 5,000 to 50,000 originations a year is being considered. The lower threshold would subject 17 additional firms to CFPB supervision, or 93% of the market.

Consumer stocks in Chile, Colombia and Peru climbed in March, with Chilean companies outperforming their cross-border peers. Chile's consumer stocks gained 5.1% compared with Colombia's 1.5% and Peru's 1.6%, but only Peru's consumer stocks outperformed the local market, which [BLANK] 0.1%. Up 9.7%, Chile's Ipsa index was the best performer in March among major LatAm exchanges. The country's economy is gradually recovering, with favorable trends in private consumption, retail sales, inflation and interest rates.

Eli Lilly's Taltz achieved ASAS20 in up to 18% of patients with ankylosing spondylitis, after adjusting for placebo, with a similar response observed on the more stringent ASAS40 metric. While the benefit trails what was achieved in the MEASURE-1 and 2 trials by Novartis' rival IL-17 drug Cosentyx, patient baselines and trial design don't allow for a fair comparison because Lilly's COAST-W trial [BLANK] a harder-to-treat population. Comparing Taltz's overall result to sub-group data from the MEASURE-2 trial provides better context. Here, Cosentyx achieved a 25-26% placebo adjusted benefit on the two measures of disease response in TNF-nonresponders. Still, caveats apply; not only is the sub-group sample size small, but Novartis only recruited patients that had failed on one TNF-therapy compared with up to two for Lilly.

Medicare Advantage enrollment rose 9.8% in December from a year earlier and 0.4% month-over-month. Aetna (up 19.1%) and Humana (17.6% higher) added members at a rapid pace, though growth may taper in 2015 as group-membership gains [BLANK], based on forecasts. UnitedHealth's enrollment, which rose by just 0.7%, may accelerate in 2015 given the company's forecast of 8% growth. Cigna slowed additions in 2014 and also may seek to add members at an increased rate in 2015.

May's retail sales probably rose slightly, driven by strength at building materials and health and personal care stores. Department [BLANK] sales may be weak again, given high-single-digit declines seen in First Data's non-cash point of sale figures. Apparel store results could fare better, but may still decrease year-over-year. U.S. seasonally adjusted retail sales are expected to be unchanged in May from April's $474.9 billion. Excluding autos and gasoline, sales are estimated to rise 0.3%.

REITs' NOI growth in 2019 may be more affected by their ability to raise rents than occupancy. In recent years, REITs in many property sectors have defensively [BLANK] occupancy to protect against new supply, sacrificing rent gains in the process. REITs may be more able to raise rents in 2019, after most sectors, other than industrial, had limited pricing power in 2018.

Amazon Reload may further the company's efforts to capture grocery sales, only about one-third of which are paid for with credit cards, according to the 2016 U.S. Consumer Payment Study conducted by Total System Services. Reload pays 2% cash-back on funds loaded to an Amazon digital gift card using a [BLANK] checking account or debit card. The digital gift card can be used for purchases across Amazon.com platforms, including for groceries on AmazonFresh.

Railroads will keep equipping trains through 2016 with technology to prevent collisions and over-speed derailments. Congress [BLANK] the deadline for railroads to install Positive Train Control, or PTC, to December 2018 from 2015. CSX and Norfolk Southern estimate it will take them until December 2020 to complete installation. A multiyear U.S. road bill expected by December could provide $199 million to help equip trains with the $9 billion technology made by General Electric, Wabtec, Alstom and Siemens.

Auto insurance rates rose 4.7% in December vs. a year earlier and were up 0.3% sequentially, based on CPI data. The relative weight of auto insurance is modest, about 2.2% in the index, though annual gains have [BLANK] from 3.3% to 5.2% each month since 2012, well above overall inflation, even with stiff industry competition. Supporting industry margins, components of claims inflation are well below average rate gains. Auto repair costs increased 2.1% in December, while prices for auto parts fell 0.7%.

The U.S. total rig count rose for a sixth straight week. Oil at $50 a barrel [BLANK] enthusiasm about a rig recovery, but the rebound is at risk of faltering, given the recent pullback in prices and macroeconomic uncertainty. Labor and capital will continue to be near-term hurdles to growth. Operators want crude prices above $50 before altering capital budgets as many are still focused on living within cash flow. Visibility is clouded because closely held E&Ps account for more than 45% of the U.S. land rig count.

Loan-to-deposit ratios at U.S. banks have fallen 68 bps in 2017 through March 1, to 78.9%, based on Fed H.8 data. The ratio [BLANK] 42 bps vs. the prior week, but is down just 1 bp year-over-year. The ratio began rising in 2015 after drifting down since 2008. Loan growth that has approached the long-term average and a slowdown in deposit growth since 2Q14 have driven the increase. Deposit attrition is a risk to be monitored as rates rise. Low-cost core deposits cut funding costs and fuel bank revenue growth.

Newron-Zambon's safinamide is on the agenda for a possible oral hearing at this week's meeting of EU regulator CHMP, as an add-on therapy in early or mid- to late-stage Parkinson's disease. An oral hearing may [BLANK] to an opinion next month. If no hearing takes place, the CHMP may issue an opinion Nov. 20-21. Phase III data showed safinamide improved motor function and fluctuations when added to commonly prescribed drugs. AbbVie and Impax also have drugs under review aimed at reducing motor fluctuations.

China and the U.S. failed to reach an agreement about a pending solar-panel anti-dumping and countervailing duty investigation at November's Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation summit. Uncertainty about future duties caused by the dispute probably [BLANK] to a 40% slump in U.S. imports of Chinese panels in October, in dollar terms. That compared with 4% for all other countries. In total, U.S. imports fell 27%, including a 13% decline in prices.

The video game industry's key themes in 2H are likely to center on the growth of digital revenue and mobile gaming, the nascent yet rapidly expanding e-sports market and continued M&A. After six months of falling Chinese hardwood pulp prices, the discount to softwood pulp is more normalized. This [BLANK] prices, along with rising orders and mill downtime. The technical backdrop for broad commodities is quite favorable for 2018. A strong foundation is [BLANK] for further appreciation, with high potential to revisit key support levels of 2012-14. A consolidation year until recently, 2017 mean and median levels are now good support.
