Nexen has a 7% interest in Syncrude, a project that can process 350,000 barrels a day and also has had recent outages.

Capacity additions by Asian and Middle East carriers will likely hurt profits on long-haul routes into the Asia Pacific region in 2015. While the region boasts the fastest-growing economies in the world, strong expansion by Turkish Air, Chinese carriers such as Air China and China Southern, Middle East airlines such Emirates, Etihad and Qatar of the Middle East will [BLANK] yields. Lufthansa and Air France likely struggle most given their high cost of labor and strong unions.

Ross Stores 2016 operating income may grow by high-single digits again, based on consensus, as better merchandise margins offset higher wages and volatility in distribution, freight and buying expenses. New store growth remains a critical component of operating income growth because it [BLANK] sales gains. Risks to operating income growth may include a slowdown in comparable sales gains and increasing wages, notably in California, where the company operates more than half of its stores.

A 2012 Supreme Court decision ruled that Obamacare's expansion of Medicaid was optional for the states. The largest among the 20 states that have thus far [BLANK] not to expand Medicaid, Texas and Florida, are unlikely to do so in the near future, given both budget constraints and Republican opposition. President Barack Obama proposed giving holdout states three full years of 100% federal reimbursement no matter when they expand, though the Republican-led Congress isn't likely to advance the incentive this year.

Indicators from China illustrate an improving construction market, which bodes well for multi-industrial sales. Fixed-asset investment quickened in June, as the government eased lending requirements to [BLANK] the slowdown. Elevator orders, a leading indicator, rebounded in China in 2013. Government policy about green space could encourage elevator sales as apartments build higher. New laws requiring manufacturers to maintain their installed equipment may boost service sales.

Coming up in technology patent challenges, both Nvidia and Samsung have patent-owner responses due in IPR proceedings initiated by the other party. Samsung [BLANK] three responses, the latest of which is due Jan. 24. All three reviews concern patents at issue in Samsung's first International Trade Commission case against Nvidia. Nvidia must respond by Jan. 23 in a proceeding challenging a patent it is asserting against Samsung in its own ITC case, and in a federal court in Delaware.

After 2Q weather-adjusted retail electricity sales shrank at many big utilities, some executives are now talking more about reigniting earnings growth by spending billions of dollars on solar farms and M&A involving natural-gas midstream assets. Dominion, Southern Co. and Consolidated Edison are among the utilities investing in these areas, [BLANK] by strong balance sheets. Utilities may have a tough time spurring core earnings growth because regulators will be reluctant to grant annual rate increases above 2%.

An appeal by Fairholme, Perry Capital and other Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac shareholders over the dismissal of their lawsuits challenging a 2012 change to the bailout of the GSEs during the financial crisis may have about $169 billion at stake. That amount reflects a possible outcome if shareholders [BLANK] in retroactively returning the dividend rate back to 10% from the "net worth sweep" and recharacterizing excess payments as partial redemption of Treasury Department's shares.

After several years with weak products, AMD's refreshed CPUs and GPUs will likely gain share this year, but rivals Intel and Nvidia have substantial leads and cut prices or refreshed products even before AMD's performance-competitive chip launches. AMD's PC chips are increasing share, but servers [BLANK] the key opportunity in 2018. These will expand sales, yet sustained R&D leadership will be shown by higher-end segment sales growth, such as gaming and artificial intelligence, and margin gains.

Basic chemicals' discount vs. global equities started to widen in April, as volatile oil prices made margins more difficult to predict, while manufacturing data became less bullish. The median 2015 P/E for basic and diversified chemical producers fell 0.3x to 15.9x in April, [BLANK] a 0.1x increase for the MSCI World Index to 17.5x. Companies have suggested lower oil may boost demand later this year, though in the near-term it has driven chemicals prices lower, threatening 2Q margins for many.

Medical-loss ratios for managed-care companies were better than they appeared, if you exclude the incremental medical costs from leap day that averaged 80 bps. Cigna's MLR was best in class, as it was [BLANK] by Medicare Advantage growth. Excluding the leap day, Anthem's MLR rose the most (70 bps) for diversified companies, due to its government business becoming a larger portion of its mix. Most companies didn't change annual MLR expectations, while Molina and WellCare were exceptions.

A Citigroup unit, in its capacity as residential mortgage-backed securities trustee, faces lawsuits by Pimco and other mortgage-bond investors alleging more than $2 billion in trust losses. The bank is [BLANK] antitrust lawsuits proposed as class actions related to interest-rate swap trading platforms, Libor and U.S. Treasury securities. The bank also faces a tax-fraud lawsuit alleging it took improper deductions and failed to pay $800 million of levies in New York.

Recent timeline clarifications by biotech and pharma companies include Genfit initiating a Phase III trial in non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) by year-end. Gilead may be able to [BLANK] for accelerated FDA approval of simtuzumab with 96-week data, available in 4Q16, from Phase II trials in NASH. Esperion details Phase III trial design after receiving FDA meeting minutes. Pain Therapeutics-Durect's Remoxy FDA resubmission is planned for 1Q16. Shire targets SHP465 FDA refiling in 2Q17 in adult ADHD.

Global per-capita consumption of sugar-laden packaged foods, measured by the performance of confectionery products, has been stable since 2006, based on Euromonitor Passport data. The reading has been propped up by a 3% rise in the Asia-Pacific, [BLANK] by rising incomes and urbanization trends. This has been offset by declines in the more-developed consumer markets of North America (down 2%) and western Europe (down 0.2%), largely reflecting increasing aversion to sugary foods.

The U.S. wireless market is likely to remain highly competitive in 2016, due to pricing pressure from T-Mobile and Sprint, which is weighing on margins. The specter of cable companies [BLANK] the business also remains a threat. Canada is more mixed, with the benefit of spectrum auctions and wireline stabilization offset by a weak economy and the threat of new entrants. The introduction of wireless content services as a growth opportunity is an emerging theme among carriers in both regions.

China Mobile Ltd. will lose 4G-user market share to rivals China Telecom and China Unicom with the end of its 4G monopoly. China Telecom and Unicom [BLANK] their 4G licenses in February. China Mobile's year-over-year subscriber growth slowed to 3% in 3Q from 6% a year earlier as mobile market penetration reached 95% and as competition intensified. China Mobile's average revenue per user, ARPU, may stabilize as regulatory tariff-cutting tapers off, and since all three carriers' 4G package prices are similar.

Morgan Stanley's 2015 estimates are likely to decline after 3Q revenue missed consensus, reflecting weaker trading and a reversal of carried interest revenue in its Asia private equity business. Management said the key drivers of client activity are mixed in 4Q after JPMorgan [BLANK] Oct. 13 that analysts' 4Q trading estimates seemed high. Trading declines trailed peers after outperforming in the past few quarters, which may further damp optimism. Wealth management's pretax margin was within its target range.

Health-care holdings grew the most of any sector in 2Q, driven largely by an increase in share prices. Holdings grew to $3 trillion, [BLANK] a multiyear high set in 1Q. The trend was led by market-value increases of Johnson & Johnson, United Health, AbbVie, and Regeneron. All facets of health care were up in 2Q, led by double-digit increases in life sciences, managed care and specialty-generic pharmaceuticals. Trends have reversed for most in 3Q, however.

Caterpillar's Energy & Transportation sales by dealers fell 29% in November after dropping 27% in October, the sixth consecutive month that the decline accelerated. Energy sales fell 37% and may [BLANK] as backlog dwindles. Transportation sales plunged 58%. A year ago, sales were up 57% on substantial locomotive shipments ahead of Tier 4 emissions rules. Industrial sales slid 24% as spillover from the energy slump hurt demand. Power generation sales rose 1%, the second straight gain.

Building a pipeline of new customers is becoming harder for California's home-solar installers, as early adopters are exhausted, and intense marketing adds buyers' fatigue. California is the largest U.S. home solar-power market, yet growth has [BLANK] year-over-year. A shift toward customers buying systems outright instead of leasing them may have slowed expansion.

Merck, AbbVie-Johnson & Johnson and Kite Pharma are expected to get the most important FDA approvals in lymphoma in 2017. Merck's Keytruda may see FDA approval by March 15 in heavily [BLANK] Hodgkin lymphoma, competing with Bristol-Myers Squibb's billion-dollar Opdivo. AbbVie-J&J's Imbruvica may get label expansion into first-line treatment maintenance of mantle cell lymphoma in 2017 and into marginal-zone lymphoma by July 26. Kite Pharma could bring the first CAR-T therapy to the market -- KTE-C19 -- in 4Q.

Industry groups representing crude oil refiners are refocusing their opposition to U.S. Department of Transportation crude tank car regulations from their court challenge back to the agency. The scope of the dispute narrowed after Congress passed legislation and rendered most of the industry stakeholders' grievances moot, except for the costliest provision mandating installation of electronically [BLANK] pneumatic brakes. The suit is now on hold pending the agency's re-evaluation of the ECP brake requirements.

The refiling of a suit against U.S. Bank in state court by BlackRock and other mortgage-bond investors may signal what plaintiffs will do in similar cases against other mortgage-bond trustees if claims are dismissed in federal court. A U.S. judge threw out most of a suit [BLANK] $98 billion in losses against U.S. Bank in May for lack of jurisdiction. If Deutsche Bank and other trustees win dismissal of some federal claims on similar grounds, they may see suits resurface in state court.

Canada and Mexico together accounted for 17.7% of the North American heavy truck market in 2015, down from 19.2% in 2014 as U.S. demand surged, according to Ward's Automotive. Canada is larger than Mexico at 9.8% of North America, [BLANK] with 10.6% in 2014. In Canada, Daimler and Paccar are the market leaders with 38% and 25% share. Mexico's share of North American heavy truck sales declined to 7.9% from 8.5% in 2014. Paccar is the market leader in Mexico with 39%, followed by Daimler at 26%.

Land drillers' valuations historically have fallen with oil prices, as reduced rig counts and dayrates lower expectations for operating performance. Currently, all land drillers are trading below their trailing five-year EV/Ebitda multiples, even though U.S. oil and natural-gas production have moved down the cost curve and become less sensitive to [BLANK] energy prices.

Medicare Advantage enrollment rose 8.1% in April from a year earlier and 0.3% month-over-month. The rate of growth has [BLANK] in each of the past three months given Medicare Advantage membership additions within employer groups may be muted in 2015. Aetna (up 13.6%) and Humana (13% higher) both slowed the pace of growth, compared with March, while Anthem cut membership by 12%. Cigna (up 9.2%) and UnitedHealth (8.6% higher) increased membership at a higher pace in April.

The Italian government's creation of a 20 billion-euro ($21 billion) fund to bail out the nation's struggling banks, starting with Banca Monte dei Paschi, increases pressure on government finances and raises sovereign risk. Generali [BLANK] more Italian government bonds than any other insurer. The 70 billion euros of Italian sovereign debt in its portfolio amounts to 18% of its general-account assets. Unipol Group has the second-largest exposure at 39 billion euros, about 62% of overall investments.

Global brewers seeking to kick-start growth will likely look to make acquisitions in Asia's emerging markets over the next couple of years. The region is home to five of the 11 fastest-growing markets, based on [BLANK] absolute volume expansion through 2021. Consumers trading up to higher-margin premium offerings could also add to the area's appeal. Vietnam's plan to sell off majority stakes in state-owned Sabeco and Habeco could help speed up consolidation.

Overseas sales are significant for chemicals makers, typically making up more than 50% of revenue. But just three large U.K. chemicals companies [BLANK] a direct foreign-exchange impact from a potential Brexit vote. Croda, Victrex and Synthomer have market capitalizations of over 1 billion pounds ($1.47 billion) and significant non-U.K. sales. As most chemicals are priced in dollars, their earnings could get a boost if sterling depreciates. Changes in long-term consumption patterns would be the main EU-exit effect.

Historically high lease penetration in the U.S. has created affordability and demand for new vehicles in 2014. A dearth of [BLANK] in 2009 led to low supply and high prices for used cars through 2012. A return to normalized leasing since 2012 will translate into an increase of millions of pre-owned vehicles coming to market starting in 2015. Rising supply will drive down prices of pre-owned cars and shift the value dynamics as shoppers weigh whether to buy new or used.

Senior housing transaction volume by REITs rose to $4.5 billion in April, up more than nine-fold from March's $534 million. Senior housing acquisitions [BLANK] to $2.3 billion from $459 million in March. Transactions in April were dominated by the closing of the $2.2 billion merger between Omega Healthcare Investors and Aviv REIT, which added to both the acquisition and disposition totals. The merger makes Omega the largest public skilled nursing facility owner, with 759 properties.

Mitsubishi UFJ, Japan's largest listed bank by assets, boosted net revenue 16% in the fiscal first half ended September, outpacing Sumitomo Mitsui and Mizuho. The surge was [BLANK] by the consolidation of Bank of Ayudhya and a 25% jump in overseas loans. Net commissions also rose 8% because a stock and bond market rally helped boost trading and investment-banking fees. The bank will probably continue growing overseas loans because of the higher yields, while the continued Japan market rally this year may boost fees.

Barclays' purchase of Lehman Brothers' North American business in 2008 was plagued by wrangles over the real valuation of assets and liabilities and, therefore, the true net assets or capital backing the unit. A lawsuit seeking $11 billion in recoveries from Barclays was [BLANK] in favor of the British bank in early 2011. To avoid this problem in future, new Financial Stability Board rules stipulate that any material subsidiary must hold 75% to 90% of the minimum loss-absorbing capital required were it a resolution entity.

Lower-priced baby formula will probably make up a larger percentage of Biostime's infant-formula sales as it expands into China's lower-tier cities, where incomes trail behind those in Tier 1 and Tier 2 cities. Inner Mongolia Yili may also [BLANK] more demand for its cheaper products as it expands distribution in smaller cities to take advantage of China's urbanization push. Products priced below 300 yuan ($46) per 900 grams rose to 66.3% of Biostime's formula sales in 1H 2015 from 61.6% the year before.

Dell's multiple options to raise capital depend on its ultimate goal. These include a full company IPO and [BLANK] pieces or the whole of legacy businesses such as PCs, servers, storage or networking. Software segment sales could also raise cash.

North America gold-mine deals earned the highest price globally in 1Q, at $267.50 an ounce of gold equivalent in the ground. Kinross [BLANK] Bald Mountain and Round Mountain assets, including a 600-square-kilometer land packaging for prospecting, along Nevada's Carlin Trend, one of the most prolific regions in the U.S. The potential of long-life and low-cost operations, similar to other mines in the surrounding area, may justify the premium paid. The price on Asia-Pacifc assets was second-highest, at $199.04.

Auto insurance rates rose 8.3% in May, down from April's 9% and 8.9% in March, based on CPI data. Still, the rate gains [BLANK] 2018 are the highest since 2003, reflecting broad efforts among insurers to raise profitability following an acceleration of loss trends in 2015-16 and above-average catastrophe costs in 2017. As many insurers continue to seek rate adequacy, the industry is benefiting from more favorable claim frequency in 2018. This points to more moderate rate increases in future months and a strengthening in industry margins. Allstate, Berkshire Hathaway and Progressive are the top three publicly traded personal auto insurers and accounted for 31% of 2017's written premiums, according to AM Best. Other large multiline carriers, such as Travelers and Hartford, also have significant share.

Oracle's copyright clash with Google over Android may yield a multibillion-dollar damages award and threaten the unlicensed use of popular application-programming interfaces (APIs) among software developers. Oracle [BLANK] that Google expropriated a substantial portion of the code used in Java application-programming interfaces, including naming conventions and overall structure, to develop Android. Oracle seeks Google's Android profit and a prohibition on unlicensed use of Java APIs.

The FCC has reworked its set-top-box regulations that aim to let pay-TV subscribers stop leasing a box from their cable or satellite provider. The rules would let subscribers [BLANK] all programs on new platforms, using a free app from their cable or satellite company. The FCC will now let all content stay within the distributor's app, yet controversy still surrounds the FCC's desire to play a role in app licensing, to bar terms that undercut new platforms. Rules would take effect in two years.

The FDA is steadily accelerating the process of rolling out biosimilar guidance documents under commissioner Scott Gottlieb. The FDA's imperative received a boost when biosimilars were prominently [BLANK] in President Donald Trump's May drug-pricing blueprint.

While Lilly's basal insulin (BIL, peglispro) has shown superior blood sugar control in type 1 diabetics to Sanofi's Lantus, as well as lower night-time hypoglycemia, the good news stops here. Patients on BIL had higher rates of daytime hypoglycemia and [BLANK] blood lipids. Worst of all, liver enzymes were raised to levels that normally worry regulators. BIL's worse profile than Sanofi's Toujeo and Novo's Tresiba may now question the commercial potential of this drug even if approved.

Recently higher rates may add $600 million of net interest income for Bank of America in 1Q, the bank said in its 4Q regulatory filing, helping 2017 profitability. It [BLANK] that an instant parallel yield-curve shift of 100 bps may further boost core net interest income by $3.4 billion in the following year. That equals 9% of core 2016 net interest income and 4% of revenue. Bank of America's sensitivity may exceed that of largest U.S. bank peers. Most of the increase should go directly to profit.

June 11-17 features key Phase III data at the EHA hematology meeting by Alexion's ALXN1210 in treatment-naive PNH and Bluebird in beta-thalassemia (207), and interim data with plerixafor mobilization from Bluebird's Phase I 206 trial in sickle cell. Also [BLANK] are updates from Phase I or II trials of Global Blood (HOPE-KIDS 1), Bellicum (BP-004 interim survival), Epizyme (FL), Geron-Johnson & Johnson's imetelstat (IMerge MDS), MorphoSys' MOR202 and MOR208 combined with Zydelig (Cosmos), Karyopharm (Stomp MM), PD-L1 analyses of AbbVie-J&J's Imbruvica plus Bristol-Myers' Opdivo (LYM1002 NHL), Cellectis-Allogene-Servier's UCART19 (PALL/CALM ALL), Novartis' Kymriah (12-month Juliet DLBCL) and BioLineRx's BL-8040 (OS in AML).

If low gas prices persist, continued operation of unregulated power plants may be at risk. Entergy, which [BLANK] down its Vermont Yankee plant, says its unregulated, or merchant, nuclear plants contribute little profit, except for Indian Point. FitzPatrick in New York and Palisades in Michigan operate in regions of low power prices, and Entergy is reviewing FitzPatrick for possible shutdown. Pilgrim in Massachusetts benefits from New England gas and power congestion, though like the others, is hurt by low gas prices.

Clarity on capital rules should aid bank shareholder payouts in 2019-20, with costs still a critical profit lever amid revenue risks, in our view. U.S. global investment banks should further [BLANK] generally healthy capital payouts, but we expect UBS to keep its lead among global rivals in dividend payout and yield.

Apparel companies with sustainable cotton-use goals are turning away from organic in a sign that consumer demand may not justify the higher cost. Puma previously [BLANK] large apparel companies with 36% of its cotton organic in 2013 before slashing it to single digits. Last year it adopted a goal of 50% sustainable, but not organic, Better Cotton use by 2020. Puma's new goal lags behind companies including Adidas, Marks & Spencer, H&M and Nike, which all similarly have favored sustainable over organic.

Consensus 2016 EPS estimates for the five largest U.S. basic chemicals firms have been stable since midyear, even though valuations have fallen from 11.5x in June to 9.8x in October -- close to a three-year low. Companies have suggested volumes will rise, as new capacity [BLANK] into increased exports and lower oil prices boost consumer spending. Yet pressure on margins and weaker manufacturing demand, which drove Huntsman to cut forecasts in September, may surface as common themes in comments on 3Q earnings calls.

The SEC will likely file briefs by Sept. 26 setting forth its views in an appeal of a lawsuit by pension funds alleging Bats Global Markets, NYSE and other stock exchanges gave unfair advantages to high-frequency traders. The investors are [BLANK] the trial court's 2015 dismissal of the case. After arguments on Aug. 24, the appeals court asked the SEC to weigh in on jurisdiction and immunity. The parties will then have 14 days to respond. The additional briefing could push a ruling by the court to 1Q.

Caterpillar may have to pay billions of dollars for an IRS tax bill over its alleged failure to pay U.S. income taxes using an offshore tax structure. Caterpillar may have a tougher time than others [BLANK] the IRS if the dispute goes to court.

Adidas' ability to accelerate sales through digital platforms with minimal cannibalization and to speed up manufacturing initiatives will likely be the focus of its March 14 analyst day. Management recently [BLANK] its 2020 online sales target to 4 billion euros ($4.3 billion). Adidas generated about 1 billion euros online in 2016, implying 40% average growth for the next four years. This will make e-commerce about 15% of annual revenue, with margins higher than the company average.

G-III's operating profit is likely to shrink in fiscal 2017, as the expense of new product launches and higher shipping and rent costs weigh on its retail segment. Outerwear sales remained [BLANK] through 3Q. The company is expanding its department store presence with Tommy Hilfiger women's apparel and Karl Lagerfeld-branded accessories and footwear. Same-store retail sales at Wilsons and G.H. Bass have fallen during the year and have failed to cover increases in occupancy and personnel costs.

Murphy Oil's decision to shut down its Milford Haven refinery in Wales after failing to sell it shows how the U.K.'s more market-oriented policies are allowing capacity to be removed. Eastern European nations such as Croatia and Serbia, in contrast, are taking a more active role in protecting energy assets [BLANK] strategically important, even if they are unprofitable. A reduction in refinery capacity is likely to improve margins at EU refiners.

The average quoted premium for an annual comprehensive auto-insurance policy rose to 737 pounds ($916) in 3Q, according to the latest Confused.com auto insurance price index, in association with Towers Watson. That [BLANK] a quarterly rate increase of 3%, down from 6% last quarter, signifying a weakening in the U.K. auto pricing trend. As U.K. insurers need to raise rates to meet growing bodily-injury claims, Confused.com expects auto-insurance rates to continue to increase.

Procter & Gamble said continued price discounting in the value segment has reduced U.S. laundry sales. Both P&G and Church & Dwight [BLANK] the continued discounting trend, with coupons and promotions, on 2Q earnings calls. P&G leads the North American laundry market with a 54% share. Church is in second slot with 11%, though it led the value segment with a 54% share in 2013. Henkel had a 24% share last year and P&G just 9%.

The new uniform MBS coming in 2019 increases Freddie Mac and Fannie Mae's chances of exiting conservatorship next year, in our view, contrary to the prevailing notion that UMBS will prolong the status quo or increase the odds that the GSEs are wound down. In the process, the GSEs will [BLANK] their market dominance and Freddie will save $400 million a year.

If AbbVie decides to go with its own internal product ABT-494 instead of opting into Galapagos's filgotinib, the latter may find few companies interested in licensing the drug. This [BLANK] only those with a current rheumatoid arthritis business are the natural targets. Johnson & Johnson may be interested after it exited a deal on peficitinib with Astellas due to bad Phase II data. Pfizer, given filgotinib's strong data, could be interested if it sees a risk for Xeljanz from ABT-494 or Eli Lilly's baricitinib.

The 2014-15 flu season has been more severe than the prior year, though the number of cases dropped off in the first week of January. Flu incidents as a percentage of total outpatient visits have been [BLANK] in midwestern and southern states, the main operating areas of publicly traded hospital systems. The flu's prevalence in a given year has a direct impact on hospital outpatient visits, though flu-related visits typically carry lower revenue per adjusted admissions.

Shire's second chance to show that Actavis's generic version of its ulcerative colitis drug Lialda infringes its patent is an uphill battle after the Federal Circuit again reversed its early win on infringement. A win for Shire would [BLANK] competition from Actavis until June 2020. The lower court found Shire's patent was valid and only infringement will be reconsidered. Lialda brought Shire for $633 million in 2014, comprising 68% of its gastrointestinal-drug revenue and 11% of overall revenue.

If the Justice Department is successful in blocking the NCM-Screenvision deal, NCM will have to pay Screenvision $28.8 million, based on agreed conditions. The Justice Department has sued to block the transaction, [BLANK] it as creating a monopoly with an 88% market share for preshow services and cinema advertising in the U.S. The companies now face an uphill battle to close, having to either refute DOJ's market definitions or show that the benefits of the deal outweigh its detriments.

Excluding Aecom's latest restructuring plan, fiscal 2019 Ebitda is expected to rise 2%, despite backlog rising to an all-time high to 14% higher than the prior-year period. While the company has done a very good job of growing backlog, the fact that Ebit and [BLANK] Ebit have been equal only four times in the past 24 quarters, and that operating margin has declined over that period, makes us somewhat skeptical that Aecom has an optimal profile of units. The company has signaled it may exit more than 30 countries, which underscores our concerns, yet bond spreads assume that the company's ratings and outlooks will remain rock solid, despite the operating challenges and leveraged balance sheet.

Competitive video gaming, known as e-sports, is a nascent, rapidly growing part of the entertainment software market. Game software and hardware makers, advertisers and broadcasters are [BLANK] themselves for growth as viewership and revenue rise. For hardware and software makers, the biggest opportunity rests in selling more of their core products. New revenue sources such as advertising and sponsorship may grow faster, yet could be smaller than the $100 billion video-game market, according to NewZoo.

Celgene's $7.2 billion bid for Receptos, a 23% premium based on the 20-day share-price average, may be cheaper when the 90-day share price average is considered instead. Over the past five years, deals from $5 billion to $15 billion have [BLANK] a median 35% premium to the 20-day average. Receptos shares have climbed 70% this year on positive clinical data from the TOUCHSTONE trial, and on speculation over potential bids. Celgene's offer implies a 36% premium on the 90-day average vs. the 34% peer median.

Even if the U.K. were to exit the EU and sign a new trade deal, this doesn't mean that business regulations would be lighter. In many regards, the U.K. has a more liberalized economic approach than the rest of the EU, but it also often [BLANK] on regulations. One example is plain tobacco packaging, where the U.K. will implement the most stringent version of EU rules in May, even though this has led in part to the closure of two factories. It's unlikely the packaging rules would be reviewed if a Brexit occurred.

Retailer card lenders Synchrony and Alliance Data recently nudged loss forecasts up from record lows. General-purpose card lenders, which [BLANK] to have less subprime exposure, may follow. Loan growth has been rising and a U.S. jobless rate of less than 5% bolsters credit quality and growth. Card lender margins should remain wide with Fed interest-rate increases on hold, and should improve in initial stages of rate hikes. Longer term, electronic-payment gains may continue to offset uneven global consumer spending.

The pharmaceutical industry may have gotten the hint as list-price increases on branded medications have fallen to their lowest point since 2012, based on data from Symphony on the 200 top-selling drugs. Scrutiny on companies with aggressive pricing tactics have [BLANK] a burden on the industry, raising concern there could be payer, political and public pushback on list-price increases. Revenue could suffer if drugmakers aren't able to take a stronger stance on rebates to pharmacy benefit managers.

Salvatore Ferragamo expects an annual profit boost on tax deductions linked to the "patent box" benefit to extend to 2019. The portion of the exemption [BLANK] to 50% in 2017-19, from 40% in 2015-16. This could lower its tax rate rate to about 23% this year. The tax reduction might help ease midterm profitability pressure at Ferragamo, as a paring of products in the wholesale channel, markdowns and stock clearances dilute midterm margins. The company can apply for a renewal request from 2020.

The most noteworthy development from Celgene's analyst day was preliminary data for CC-122 in a type of lymphoma (diffuse large B-cell, or DLBCL) that has progressed beyond standard therapies. The event was [BLANK] to drum up interest in its drug-discovery engine and pipeline. Data categorizing the disease subtype (GCB and ABC) looked promising, especially in the context of data for Imbruvica in a similar setting. Even more interesting was the "gene classifier" data, which sliced the data in a less conventional way.

Disposing of power generation subsidiary, Edison Mission Energy, and the closing of its San Onofre nuclear plant, has enabled Edison International to focus solely on growth in California, which is better than most states. Regulatory support has [BLANK] for major utility capital expenditures on reliability, low-carbon and smart-grid spending. The other major California utility companies include PG&E, which has remaining liabilities from the San Bruno pipeline explosion, and Sempra, which is more diversified.

Sony's action thriller "The Equalizer" may take in $35 million when it opens Sept. 26, according to boxoffice.com and could draw a domestic total of $110 million. Focus' animation comedy "The Boxtrolls" [BLANK] the same day and could bring in $14 million in its opening weekend. This summer's results have been 17% lower so far this year compared with last, even with the strong showing by Marvel's "Guardians of the Galaxy" the first weekend of August.

Judge Benjamin Goldgar has pushed his ruling on the involuntary petition filed against Caesars Entertainment Operating Co. to May 18 from March 16. The [BLANK] decision will come more than a year after creditors Appaloosa, Oaktree and Tennenbaum filed the petition on Jan. 12, 2015. Goldgar's ruling may hinge on whether he examines debts paid and unpaid in the 30 days before the petition date, as proposed by the petitioning creditors, or looks back six months, as Caesars has suggested.

Electronic logging devices record truck drivers' hours and duty status, as well as provide fleet-management tools. These devices are connected to the engine to [BLANK] speed, location, distance traveled and some allow for communication with dispatchers. The ELD rules go into effect on Dec. 18, 2017 and could tighten trucking capacity by about 5% and pressure rates higher. Owner operators oppose the rule due to privacy concerns and reduced flexibility vs. manual log books, driving some to exit the business.

Convenient-care clinics may be the largest opportunity for payers to save costs, given routine health care may cost $100 a visit, compared with more than $600 at a hospital emergency room, according to Anthem. Retail pharmacies CVS Health and Walgreens [BLANK] the majority of the convenient-care market and can boost sales from increased store foot traffic. Hospitals can partner with these retail clinics to expand admissions. CVS Health is affiliated with 44 health systems nationwide.

Technology can be a long-term threat to freight forwarders. More online freight bookers are [BLANK] the market and connect shippers directly with freight forwarders and capacity carriers. Forwarders may use these systems to attract volume, yet margins will be squeezed as some charge 16% fees. Despite being a risk, digitization can also be an opportunity. A strong IT platform provides a competitive advantage and can make freight forwarders more efficient, control costs and improve customer service.

Global banks' 2Q equity fees and trading revenue should be supported by generally higher stock prices. Markets are up 3% so far in 2Q, as [BLANK] by the MSCI ACWI Index, after gaining 1.8% in 1Q. Major markets are mostly higher, as the S&P 500 rose 2.6% and the Nasdaq 4%. Europe's STOXX 600 is 2.4% higher, while Japan's Nikkei has gained 7%. The MSCI Emerging Market Index rose 3.6% with a 23.3% jump in China's Shanghai Exchange Index fueled by monetary policy optimism and a 5.5% gain in Brazil's Bovespa.

Australia & New Zealand Banking Group anticipates higher provisions in fiscal 1H than consensus projects. Narrowing margins, [BLANK] at its markets business, came despite 5% sequential growth in fiscal 1Q cash profit. These developments remain investor concerns, even as ANZ improved its 1Q domestic business performance through its retail and small-business segments. Earnings continue to carry outsize exposure to increasing volatility in overseas financial markets versus domestic rivals.

Biotech and pharma events in nonalcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) include Galmed's interim safety analysis of the Phase IIb trial in 1Q. Higher-dose data of Durect's Phase Ib trial in patients is [BLANK] in 4Q. Gilead may report the first data of GS-9674 (FXR agonist) in fatty liver disease patients soon and reveal its plan for combining agents that target different aspects of NASH by mid-2017. Allergan plans to start Phase III trials and get two-year data of the Phase IIb trial in mid-2017.

At the end of day two of the U.K. auction of 2.3 and 3.4 GHz spectrum, bidding reached 185 million pounds, a 164% increase over the reserve price. Excess demand across both bands [BLANK] high. Bidding for lots in the 2.3 GHz band reached 99 million pounds, 148% over the reserve price, while for the 3.4 GHz lots, bidding reached 86 million pounds, 185% over the reserve price. We see an upper bound of 800 million pounds for total proceeds from the auction.

China's refined copper production rose to 734,000 metric tons in October, beating the previous month's record of 715,000 tons, according to the National Bureau of Statistics. Rising imports of copper ore and concentrate and new capacity have [BLANK] Chinese output of refined copper. Three Chinese copper refineries with total capacity of 1.2 million tons were added to the global top 20 refineries by capacity, bringing the total number in China to nine.

The Bear Case for infrastructure software companies includes risks for operating system vendors such as Microsoft as the PC market stagnates. A more commoditized virtualization software market also represents a threat to pricing for those vendors, while emerging in-memory database technology may [BLANK] the traditional model that fueled much of Oracle's past success. Any impediments to access the fast-growing Chinese software market may also damp growth.

Variable annuity sales fell 5% in 1Q to $32.4 billion, the lowest level since 1Q10, according to Limra SRI, and 20% below their post-financial crisis peak reached in 2Q11. Customer caution may reflect higher fees and less attractive guarantees as life insurers [BLANK] terms to protect margins. Prudential Plc led the contraction, with sales falling 18% from 1Q14. Lincoln Financial reported a 9% decline and AIG sales fell 6%. Of the top 10 sellers, only TIAA-CREF and Aegon reported gains vs. 1Q14.

Settling certain claims from the 2010 Gulf of Mexico oil spill may cost BP $22.9 billion to $27.6 billion, compared with BP's projected $9.7 billion. BP has refrained from estimating business-economic-loss claims in its filings, and those claims may [BLANK] the most. As of April 1, these claims have the highest average cost at $161,177. Applying that to the 81,834 total unique claimants, or the 111,572 total claims, the total cost to BP for these types of claims could be $13.2 billion to $17.9 billion.

China's electricity output, a leading indicator for economy activity, dropped for the third straight month, to 444.64 billion kilowatt-hours, still 3.3% more than a year earlier. Crude steel production in China [BLANK] to an eight-month low, up 3.8% from the previous year. Waning domestic steel demand has dragged down the record production of May. China's steel industry is the nation's biggest electricity user, consuming more than 10%.

Axiata's shares fell 2.9% to underperform larger Indonesian rivals last month. Malaysian parent Axiata Group's plan to [BLANK] its 66% stake may have startled investors. Axiata is considering options to pare debt after Malaysia's regulator announced higher spectrum fees on Aug. 30. Telekomunikasi, Indonesia's largest telecom company, gained 4.5% on sustained strong growth in mobile data, broadband and IT services. Indosat was little-changed through the month.

Jawbone's patent-infringement actions against Fitbit and Flextronics in the International Trade Commission and in U.S. district court in Northern California threaten an import ban on Fitbit's wearable fitness-tracking products and could require Fitbit to pay Jawbone for alleged acts of infringement. Fitbit maintains Jawbone's claims have no merit and are only aimed at [BLANK] Fitbit's business. Jawbone filed its district court case a week before Fitbit's IPO and the ITC case a month later.

Online grocery has become the major driver of food-retail growth, despite elusive profitability. The models differ, with e-tailers adding warehouses and grocers [BLANK] store pickups. The U.K. and France are among the most developed markets. Competition in the U.S. is rising, as Wal-Mart bulks up its online operation and AmazonFresh adds collection points and opens in less-crowded Germany. In China, Alibaba Tmall and JD.com are expanding their grocery segments, given the attractive market size.

Ventas raised C$650 million ($574 million) in a September bond issuance at an average coupon of 3.4% to fund its purchase of Canadian assets from Holiday Retirement. Canadian investors eager for yield amid a decline in corporate bond issuance have [BLANK] to REITs, with Ventas setting Canadian records for largest inaugural REIT borrowing and largest unsecured REIT financing. Health Care REIT also owns assets in Canada, which could portend future bond issuance.

Southern's Aug. 31 decision on whether to complete the Vogtle project in Georgia will send a strong signal about whether any nuclear plants will be built in the U.S. in the foreseeable future. State regulators want Southern's Georgia Power to [BLANK] the half-done plant, at a cost of $6 billion. Many investors would rather Southern abandon the project and seek to recover its $5 billion investment to date. Abandonment-cost recovery is allowed by state law, but it needs regulatory approval.

Singapore homes remain affordable on historical metrics, and this should be a key factor driving buyer demand in the coming year. Price growth is [BLANK] steam since the residential market's lull in 2016, and should continue due to strong sentiment from domestic buyers.

Charter's bout over its power to operate in New York likely won't end with the company exiting the Empire State. A state regulator says Charter [BLANK] to extend its system as required. Charter has a strong defense, yet it likely won't jeopardize its right to operate in New York, worth about $19 billion. All signs, including a Nov. 23 extension, point to a settlement.

Investment banks' market-making and trading revenue may be poised for an uptick as the Volcker Rule is set for tweaks by federal regulators in 2018. Proprietary trading is unlikely to [BLANK], but regulators will focus on broadening the market making exemption as well as allowing more usage of Tier 1 capital to invest in hedge and private funds. Loosening compliance may be a first step. More material changes could take most of 2018 to cook. Congress is unlikely to repeal the rule, but smaller measures are possible.

Corporate buyers seeking to reduce costs have used virtualization and cloud computing to consolidate hardware purchases, reducing vendor profit margins. This is aided by growth of hyperscale data centers, expected to [BLANK] 40% of x86 server units by 2018 from 23% in 2013, purchased directly from lower-margin Asian original design manufacturers instead of brands such as Dell and Hewlett Packard Enterprise. Asian customers' preference for low-priced Asian sellers, such as Lenovo, may further drag on margins.

Mylan's 20 milligram per milliliter generic of Teva's multiple sclerosis drug Copaxone is held up with the FDA, though may offer limited opportunity, given Teva's resilience in the face of Glatopa, the first Copaxone generic launched by Sandoz and Momenta. Teva's 40 mg/mL version [BLANK] 73% of the Copaxone market, even with generic competition. The larger opportunity may lie in a 40 mg/mL copy. Sandoz, Mylan and Amneal are seeking approval for this thrice-weekly version.

Discover is rapidly increasing card loans but its growth rate has flattened at about 10% recently. While its loan-loss rate continued to rise in April, the pace slowed sharply vs. the surge of 2017, which may [BLANK] well for credit costs. Still, its fast loan gains, while aiding revenue, create pressure to build reserves.

Intra-Asia and intra-Europe container trade routes' dependence on small-sized ships increases their vulnerability to disruptions from IMO 2020 emission regulations. Though costs will increase most on Asia-U.S. and Asia-Europe routes as they employ larger ships, regional trade is most at risk as it's [BLANK] by older fleets with poor vessel economics.

Environmental activism from non-governmental organizations forms a principal 'above-ground' risk for operations in the ecologically-sensitive Barents Sea. This is seen in a lawsuit from Greenpeace and others brought Oct. 18 against the Norwegian government for allowing Barents Sea activity, [BLANK] a violation of the COP21 Paris agreement and Norway's constitution. In uncharted legal territory, the suit signals a new tactic for NGOs' shifting campaigns, though immediate impact to drilling plans appears unlikely.

The market's liberalization and long-term auctions may turn Iberdrola into a major electricity supplier in Mexico. The company plans to [BLANK] to acquire up to 9.5% of power being sold at the third long-term capacity auction in the country, with results due in November. For the first time, private companies will be allowed to buy electricity via long-term deals. This will allow Iberdrola, currently active in Mexican power generation, to challenge state-owned utility CFE in supplying electricity to customers.

FSOC's process for designating nonbank SIFIs, and potentially billions in associated capital requirements, are at issue in MetLife's lawsuit, currently on appeal, contesting its nonbank systemically important financial institution status. MetLife [BLANK] the "too-big-to-fail" label's costs weren't considered prior to the designation and include hundreds of millions of dollars in annual costs and potentially billions in associated capital requirements. The government's appeal is on hold until July.

Inflation should boost EU food processors' results, eliminating damaging promotional activity. Yet it takes time to [BLANK] complex-taste and nutritious food innovations for retailers, capable of driving both price and volume to restore organic sales growth to the historic norm of about 5%. Retailers' adoption of everyday low prices will deliver cost-saving opportunities for food makers to be reinvested, spurring volume. Pricing remains pressured by increased discount-retailer presence and changing shopping habits.

China, the world's largest producer and buyer of gold, is seeking to expand its influence in the global market by trying to become a price setter, with its own yuan fix. China is expected to [BLANK] a gold-pricing auction in the next few months. Because China is a closed currency system, there is uncertainty about whether the fix will be globally accepted. The Shanghai Gold Exchange is in talks with U.S.-based Comex and the Hong Kong exchange on cross-listing of gold contracts.

Improved utilization at Mazda's new plants and sales of higher-value crossover vehicles should help the company achieve a targeted operating margin of more than 7% by March 2019. The Mexico plant now [BLANK] more models, including the Mazda 3, Mazda 2 and a compact car for Toyota. A Thai facility has also started producing engines and transmission components. The ratio of overseas production is now about 40%. Localization can help automakers better manage foreign exchange exposure and keep margins stable.

United Technologies' bid for Rockwell Collins, and Boeing's recent announcement of plans to create its own avionics platform, is further evidence that M&A will continue to be a route for aerospace suppliers to contend with increasing OEM price and competitive pressures. Supplier consolidation should continue to [BLANK] up steam, given signs of a nearing cycle peak, as plane makers wring costs from the supply chain with a focus on execution and profitability, and with Boeing's concerted push into the aftermarket.

Akorn could fetch more than $40 a share in a takeover bid, given multiples paid in recent deals and the increasing rarity of generic-injectable drugmakers. The median Ebitda multiples from specialty-generic drugmakers was 14x, [BLANK] $42 a share for Akorn. Those with generic-injectable capabilities have fetched 21.8x Ebitda on average, suggesting Akorn may be worth much more. Akorn, though, has a lot of baggage that could weigh on the premium, such as litigation risks, ophthalmic exposure and ephedrine erosion.

Japan's population may decline by 250,000 a year on average over the next three years, according to the U.S. Census Bureau. The proportion [BLANK] 65 or more may also rise to 28.3% in 2018 from 26.4%. Bears contend this shift will weigh on auto sales, particularly as the market is already saturated. The country has had about 450 vehicles for every 1,000 people for 10 years.

Cisco is unlikely to relent in its lawsuits targeting Arista's network-switch products and related software, removing any settlement possibility in the near term. Cisco continues to pursue ITC cases aimed at [BLANK] Arista's sales and securing monetary damages for patent and copyright infringement. The companies are involved in numerous legal actions spanning the ITC, U.S. district court, the Federal Circuit appeals court and proceedings before the U.S. patent office challenging Cisco's patents.

Near-term biotech and pharmaceutical industry events include Phase II data of Amgen-Cytokinetics-Servier's oral omecamtiv mecarbil in chronic heart failure, and XenoPort's XP23829 for psoriasis and its potential in multiple sclerosis. Galena will [BLANK] more mature data of GALE-301 in ovarian and endometrial cancers, as will Endocyte for vintafolide in lung cancer. Conatus awaits Phase II data in patients with liver cirrhosis and portal hypertension. Click on the image to open the full calendar.

Basic chemicals companies have long pursued more-stable earnings (and improved valuations) by acquiring smaller specialty producers. Such deals are likely in 2015, with financing ample, industrial growth modest and feedstock volatility for basic chemicals [BLANK]. Weaker industrial growth in China and Europe are threatening many basic chemicals chains with oversupply. Plunging oil prices have increased margin volatility for basic chemicals. Both raise the importance of specialty niches.

Natural gas benchmarks remain below $2.70 per MMBtu, levels seen prior to the start of winter withdrawal season. Yet January and February [BLANK] key for winter heating demand and prices. Stockpiles fell by 182 billion cubic feet for the week ending Dec. 15, above expectations of a 171 bcf draw. Heating degree days, a proxy for demand, rose over 50% from the previous week, while output was more subdued. Storage sits 2.4% below the five-year average of 3.53 tcf and is 5% below last year.

Slow connection speeds vex subscribers so much that 37% of the 50% respondents in an Ovum survey who said they may change wireless providers cited the plodding access. That's an issue for Europe, which [BLANK] developed counterparts in 4G service. Mobile operators with high convergent (bundled fixed-mobile services) penetration, and those with 4G leads, may contend with lower churn pressure, suggesting the disruptive small operators with little spectrum may struggle to expand market share.

Declining demand for platinum and a lower supply deficit amid slower draw-downs of above-ground stock could weigh on the metals' price recovery. There will be a deficit of about 170,000 ounces in 2016 and 100,000 in 2017, based on the World Platinum Investment Council and SFA (Oxford) [BLANK] out Nov. 22. Total 2016 supply will be 7.9 million ounces, as a 3% drop in mining supply counters a 9% recycling increase vs. 2015. Demand may fall 3% to 8 million ounces on a downturn in autocatalyst and jewelry segments.

Benefiting from strong demand and tighter supply from continued OPEC oil-production cuts, Asian LPG margin has expanded $5 a barrel in the past four weeks, extending a climb above its five-year seasonal high. Demand remains robust in India as the government accelerates plans to [BLANK] fuel oil and kerosene by offering 50 million free LPG connections to poor households by the end of 2018. Chinese demand growth averaged a strong 21.5% in May to June.

Office REITs with a large New York presence have been sellers in the market in 2016, while investing elsewhere. Asset prices remain elevated and REITs are using Manhattan properties to [BLANK] portfolio transformations and deleveraging efforts. SL Green, which was the most active office REIT buying in New York in 2015, sold $500 million of assets in 1Q and will close the $2 billion sale of 388-390 Greenwich St. to Citigroup in 2Q. Also, Mack-Cali sold 125 Broad St. , its only Manhattan property.

The European Commission's new set of proposals for connectivity builds on existing targets, aiming to achieve a minimum 100 mbps connectivity for all EU households by 2025. The previous agenda [BLANK] for a minimum 30 mbps coverage for all and a minimum 100 mbps for half of the households by 2020. The commission also envisages fiber-to-the-premises connection to key institutions and 5G coverage commitment for at least one major city in each EU Member State by 2020.

Relative spot trucking demand in North America, measured by Internet Truckstop's Market Demand Index, fell 18.8% to 16.0 in the week ended June 12 after jumping 25.7% the previous week on seasonal strength. The trucking market was less tight as truck availability increased 10.5%, [BLANK] the 10% drop in available loads. The Northeast and Mountain regions were the weakest. Truckers and shippers were less efficient during the week as load turnaround times rose 3.4% and truck turnaround increased 5%.

Resolute's horizontal wells in Reeves County, Texas, produced more oil in their first nine months than any other operator in the county. Wells constructed by Resolute in the county in the past 18 months took less than four months to [BLANK] 100,000 barrels of oil, while average oil wells in the county took 10 months. The strong performance likely stems from quality rock and intense completion designs, with proppant concentrations averaging 1,677 pounds per lateral foot on Wolfcamp A wells.

Humana may report one of the strongest quarters among managed care companies as consensus expects 34% EPS growth in 3Q. Humana increased its 2016 EPS outlook 3% in July since Medicare Advantage claims were lower than [BLANK]. Company guidance for its medical loss ratio implies 340 bps of improvement in 2H for the retail segment (90% of costs). The exchanges are a wild card as Humana took a charge in 2Q, expecting a $337 million loss for 2016, but the company acknowledged losses may worsen.

Amgen's decision to end its partnership with AstraZeneca on the psoriasis drug brodalumab due to potentially raised risks of suicides may have negative connotations for Novartis's Cosentyx and Eli Lilly's ixekizumab. Even though Cosentyx has already been [BLANK] and such risks haven't been seen in its trials to date, Amgen's decision may raise some concern among physicians. That's unlikely to be lost on the Johnson & Johnson sales force pushing psoriasis drug Stelara, which hasn't had suicide-related issues.

Although Carnival hasn't provided yield guidance for next year, post-June advance bookings for 1H17 point to much higher prices, with less inventory to sell, than a year earlier. Carnival's 3Q sales were slightly above consensus, as constant-currency revenue yield gains [BLANK] the high end of June guidance and non-fuel unit costs rose more slowly than expected due to expense timing. Management reiterated its outlook for 2016, when net yield is seen to rise 3.5% and non-fuel unit cruise costs 1.5%.

Several U.S. states support offshore wind projects from developers including Orsted and Avangrid, which could open opportunities for suppliers such as Siemens Gamesa and MHI-Vestas. U.S. tariffs on some Chinese imports will mostly skip the onshore wind sector, while levies on steel that will probably [BLANK] into 2019 add to pricing pressure for turbine makers.

After stalling in the Gulf of Mexico, Tropical Storm Hermine is expected to reach hurricane status before making landfall along the Florida panhandle, based on National Hurricane Center projections. Meteorological site Weather Underground compared Hermine's path, which would be Florida's first hurricane in over 10 years, with that of Hurricane Agnes, which [BLANK] $3 billion (1972 dollars) in damage. The storm paths and size differ, but a similar northern trek by Hermine may lead to a broad swath of losses.

Near-term biotech and pharmaceutical industry events include Phase II data of Amgen-Cytokinetics-Servier's oral omecamtiv mecarbil in chronic heart failure and XenoPort's XP23829 for psoriasis and its potential in multiple sclerosis. Galena will [BLANK] more mature data of GALE-301 in ovarian and endometrial cancers, as will Endocyte for vintafolide in lung cancer. Conatus awaits Phase II data in patients with liver cirrhosis and portal hypertension. Click on the image to open the full calendar.

There were 12 major LNG receiving terminals in China as of April, with a total capacity of about 40 million tons a year. All are [BLANK] by the country's three oil majors: PetroChina, Sinopec, and Cnooc Group. Seven terminals, about 60% of capacity, are operated by Cnooc. All three companies, which are state controlled, plan to expand receiving capacity. Private companies such as ENN and Guanghui Energy are keen to enter the market.

Sirius XM is defending a victory in a potential class-action lawsuit led by Flo & Eddie, owners of songs by the Turtles. The lower court said Sirius didn't unlawfully air old recordings in Florida by not [BLANK] a license to the songs. Federal law gives copyright protection only to later recordings, and the court said the pre-1972 songs weren't protected by state law. A reversal could mean Sirius would owe about $26 million, a reduced amount after record companies settled the issue.

Fairholme, Perry Capital and Arrowood Indemnity are likely to appeal the Sept. 30 dismissal of their Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac claims against the U.S. Possible bases for appeal include the judge's failure to consider the background of the Sweep Amendment, which diverted profits to the Treasury, and his interpretation of HERA, the statute that empowers the FHFA. An appeal is due by early December and likely to be [BLANK] by the end of 2015, though petitions to the Supreme Court could follow.

Morgan Stanley, RBS and 10 other banks have until Jan. 20 to file motions to dismiss amended antitrust lawsuits by buy-side investors and swap-execution facility plaintiffs. The suits [BLANK] the banks conspired to deter development of exchange-like interest-rate swap trading platforms. Plaintiffs will then have until Feb. 17 to oppose the motions, and the banks will finish the briefing on March 17. Oral arguments are expected after that. Plaintiffs filed amended claims on Dec. 9.

Remarks from Fed Governor Jerome Powell suggest regulators will revisit the Volcker Rule's proprietary trading restrictions with the idea of making it easier for banks to hedge and make markets. To do so, regulators should [BLANK] the rule's market-making exemption, including the definition of reasonably expected near-term demand of customers, or RENTD. Loosening the exemption could boost trading volumes. Changing the exemption probably won't happen until after a thorough review, which could take a year or more.

European insurers (SXIP index) have outperformed euro area banks (SX7E index) by 83% since mid-2011, the onset of the sovereign crisis. This is partly attributable to the cost of higher bank capital requirements, as the common equity Tier 1 ratio has [BLANK] to 11.45% (3Q) from less than 9% for the euro zone's largest 11 lenders. QE may further boost unrealized gains on sovereign bonds owned by insurers and banks, while continuing to challenge German and Austrian insurer profitability as yields fall below guarantees.

Deutsche Bank's 3Q legal costs may rise as it aims to join U.S. peers in putting the worst behind it in coming months. The bank's litigation costs [BLANK] in 2Q, similar to the aggregate U.S. trend, even as total costs rose across the largest European peers. Deutsche may be making progress toward a settlement with the Department of Justice, as reported by Manager Magazin on Sept. 9. Goldman Sachs' cost decline -- accounting for the largest share of U.S. peers' drop in 1H vs. 2015 -- was driven by its DOJ settlement.

Bank of America and Wells Fargo are asking the U.S. Supreme Court to rule that the city of Miami has no standing to sue them under the Fair Housing Act for alleged discriminatory mortgage lending that the city says hurt it economically. The suits are among more than a dozen of similar suits by cities [BLANK] Los Angeles and Chicago against banks such as Citigroup, HSBC and JPMorgan. The cities allege the banks lent to minorities on unfavorable terms, which lowered property values and tax revenue.

Apartment REITs have $9.1 billion of development projects underway, down from a high of $10.3 billion in 2Q15, but still more than 4x the 2011 cyclical bottom. The [BLANK] funding obligation for these projects is $4 billion. The drop in development pipelines from the 2Q15 peak is due to more projects being completed than started and those deals could lift the earnings contribution. Development yields remain above acquisition cap rates, as well as apartment REITs' cost of capital.

Boeing profit and margins will rise in 4Q on deliveries of about 30 more 737s, its highest-margin airplane. The surge in 737 deliveries likely won't compensate for [BLANK] revenue on 11 fewer 777 deliveries. Margins are better, as the 777 is the second-most-profitable airplane. Global Services will assist as profitability recovers in 4Q.

Johnson & Johnson faces an estimated 700 state-court lawsuits by consumers who claim they developed mesothelioma from talc-based products. Two California trials [BLANK] in mistrials in 3Q and 4Q. A trial in New Jersey may also be a close call, given a victim was allegedly exposed to alternative contaminants.

Increasing iron-ore supply along with falling China crude steel production and demand may put intense pressure on iron-ore prices for the next three years. Chinese crude steel production is down 2.1% this year, and [BLANK] 3% in September. Steel demand in China, the world's largest user, fell a staggering 8.3% in September, and declined in 20 of the past 21 months. As the export market gets saturated with new iron-ore supply from Australia and Brazil, China's mills may begin to close, lessening the need for iron ore.

Spectrum aggregators, such as NRJ TV and Michael Dell's OTA Broadcasting, have been on a station-spectrum buying spree as they prepare to cash in at the 2015 broadcast auction. Spectrum M&A [BLANK] $420 million from 2011 through September 2014, according to SNL Kagan. The value paid averaged $3.48 per TV home and 25 cents per MHz-Pop in the period. NRJ TV was the most active buyer, spending $234 million. Full-power stations and Class A stations each accounted for 50% of deals.

Boeing probably won't launch an appeal of the U.S. International Trade Commission's unfavorable ruling in its trade case against Bombardier. An appeal attempt is especially unlikely if Boeing seeks to [BLANK] Canada's fighter-jet business.

Consensus projects the 10-year Treasury yield will rise 90 bps to 3.1% by year-end 2015, while swap forwards imply a more muted 30-bp increase to 2.5%. Rising rates could increase office property cap rates, thereby [BLANK] property values. This coincides with higher debt costs, given that investors require higher returns when capital costs grow. Lastly, office REIT share prices have historically traded lower amid rising rates, albeit less than other major REIT property sectors.

Qualcomm's legal battle with Apple was initially thought unlikely to impact licensing sales and EPS in 2017. This view has changed, because Apple may lower payments to contract manufacturer Hon Hai/Foxconn, which would then withhold [BLANK] due to Qualcomm. Continued underpayments would breach Hon Hai's Qualcomm license and complicate its non-Apple revenue. The payments will likely continue at a much lower rate and this may also prompt Qualcomm-Hon Hai litigation for patent infringement and breach of contract.

Chinese solar wafer and ingot producer Comtec began production at its new 300 megawatt plant in Malaysia in June and announced plans to double the size of this facility in 2015. A key driver for this growth is to produce equipment outside China to [BLANK] trade dispute risks. Malaysia is growing as a base for solar equipment makers, with First Solar, Panasonic, Hanwha Q Cells and a joint venture between SunPower and AU Optronics all active in the country.

Sands China's casino revenue stabilized in 2Q as mass-market gaming bottomed out. The segment rose in June from a year earlier for the first time since 2014, and growth momentum may [BLANK] after the Sept. 13 debut of Parisian, a French-themed resort on Macau's Cotai Strip. The company's focus on its mainstream business and cost savings also helped widen Ebitda margins. Sands' cluster of resorts at the heart of Cotai should help increase cost savings, as well as labor and gaming-table efficiency in 2016.

Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac's accord with banks to define the behavior that resulted in billions of dollars in fines may encourage lenders to loosen mortgage restrictions, which over time may help fuel a broader housing recovery. FHFA Director Mel Watt provided guidelines as to what outcomes could [BLANK] banks at risk of having to repurchase bad loans. A greater understanding of risk may enable banks to reduce the credit overlays that have limited the pool of would-be homebuyers.

Increased Airbus and Boeing production, permissive financing markets and lower fuel prices should keep the supply of aircraft strong, stoking airline competition. While interest rates are rising, which increases the cost of airplane ownership, heavy competition in the leasing business is [BLANK] rates low, making it a preferred funding source in 2019.

Jawbone's patent-infringement actions against Fitbit and Flextronics in the International Trade Commission and in U.S. district court in Northern California threaten an import ban on Fitbit's wearable fitness-tracking products and could require Fitbit to pay Jawbone for alleged acts of infringement. Fitbit maintains Jawbone's claims have no merit and are only aimed at [BLANK] Fitbit's business. Jawbone filed its district court case a week before Fitbit's IPO and filed the ITC case a month later.

The transition to cloud services from legacy IT will create uneven growth opportunities in the IT services industry. Companies that have sizable consulting and application development practices should grow at a faster pace [BLANK] with those that have greater exposure to legacy IT outsourcing work over the next decade. Longer-term, the industry needs to create a stream of services to offset the decline of support revenue under a cloud model, making the segment more dependent on software and less on head count.

The conditions are ripe for a recovery in Europe's infrastructure industry: low interest rates, increasing alternative sources of liquidity and the ambition of several governments to kickstart infrastructure developments to boost job creation and economic growth. Yet there remains a shortfall between funds available, infrastructure projects and assets to [BLANK] them, though investor appetite is clearly growing. Nevertheless, Europe remains a global infrastructure giant whose potential remains to be exploited.

A House Republican plan would shift the Comprehensive Capital Analysis and Review (CCAR) program to a two-year cycle from an annual schedule, reducing opportunities for the Federal Reserve to object to planned dividends and buybacks and cutting associated regulatory costs. Currently, the Fed can [BLANK] capital returns for banks whose capital falls below minimum levels or are too ambitious during the Fed's annual stress tests.

Avista Capital Partners and Advent International agreed to acquire Kremers Urban, UCB's U.S. specialty-generic-drug business, for $1.53 billion on Nov. 7. Golden Gate Capital [BLANK] the acquisition of Dow Chemical's Angus unit for $1.22 billion on Nov. 12. Dow has been under pressure from activist investor Third Point to improve shareholder returns.

A key takeaway from the 2017 Consumer Analyst Group of New York (CAGNY) conference was the extent to which slow sales growth across the consumer products sector weighed on the need to contain costs to sustain profit. Companies including General Mills, Kellogg, Coca-Cola and Procter & Gamble [BLANK] the intense pressure on sales to prioritize product innovation and re-examine their supply-chain efficiency, among other things. Renewed sector M&A activity was also a frequently addressed topic.

Net-metering policies are under review in 2016 in several states where the rooftop solar market has been expanding largely due to existing net-metering programs. Regulators or lawmakers in some of the largest states by net-metered solar photovoltaic capacity, [BLANK] Arizona, may tweak rates or capacity caps. Reducing the rates that solar owners are paid for excess electricity sold to the grid or tacking on new fees could lower new project demand for residential solar developers.

AbbVie is expected to file a lawsuit against Amgen ahead of the FDA's projected date for approving Amgen's biosimilar version of adalimumab of Sept. 25. As most costs are paid in rubles, dollar dominance within oil operators' revenue will largely offset the decline in crude. Russian companies with large dollar debts will report significant debt revaluation, though this will not affect cash flow.

Australia's housing market could be peaking as the nation's regulator has imposed more curbs on mortgage lending. To [BLANK] with the new rules, lenders toughened loan criteria for investors in favor of buyers who will actually live in the homes. Mortgage rates may slowly rise as banks have been facing funding pressure and new bank levies on liabilities. Home-price increases led to falling affordability in cities such as Sydney and Melbourne, limiting demand for mortgages.

J&J-Genmab's daratumumab has cemented its role in combination with Velcade and dexamethasone in patients with relapsed/refractory multiple myeloma who are naive or sensitive to a proteome inhibitor -- an important spot since Celgene's Revlimid is moving frontline and is used in maintenance, making patients refractory at progression. The Phase III Castor trial of Darzalex, which showed a hazard ratio of 0.39, is practice [BLANK], according to a discussant at ASCO.

Russia banks' funding strategies in 2015 are likely to be a key focus during 4Q results. Lenders' loan books rose by $18 billion more than their deposit base in the first 11 months of 2014, [BLANK] the funding gap between loans and deposits by 20%, to $90 billion. This shortfall has been covered by central bank borrowings, which rose 50% last year to $100 billion in November, almost 10% of the industry's liabilities. Growing reliance on central bank funding is an area of concern.

The software-as-a-service industry may have near-term margin pressure due to a number of issues. Discounts offered by legacy vendors, which are vying for greater market share, may [BLANK] both legacy and pure-play companies. Pure-play vendors have outpaced their legacy counterparts over the past decade, but are now facing rising competition. In addition to the legacy vendors' increased spending on marketing and infrastructure, the subscription model defers revenue to future periods, all of which affect margins.

Cloudera has the potential to leverage a partnership with Intel to improve performance in processing large volumes of unstructured data on its platform. Intel is one of the largest Cloudera holders at 20% of outstanding shares, which should help [BLANK] confidence to Cloudera's business. As Cloudera pivots to the cloud and expands in artificial intelligence, predictive analytics and machine learning, its partnership with Intel will help differentiate its offering from competitors.

China's slowing construction sector is dragging down a range of metals. Construction of new homes has [BLANK] 16% year-to-date, and offices are down 11.8%. New business construction is down 7.2%. The two-year construction decline has affected each metal differently, but all are lower. Nickel was hit the worst given it had the highest inventories. The movement of metals from bonded warehouse stocks where financing deals proliferated, to the LME, has also helped send nickel to financial-crisis lows.

Google, Samsung and other Android device makers finally won their bid to litigate the patent cases brought by Rockstar, the patent troll partly owned by Apple and Microsoft. An appeals court sided with Google and ordered the Texas judge to stay all cases in the patent troll-friendly court [BLANK] the resolution of Google's case in California. This is a clear procedural win for Google, which has been focused on moving the cases to California since the filings last October.

Construction Confidence improved by 390 bps in September to minus 12, its best reading in 2016. Slow and steady gains in Europe's construction outlook have raised optimism in the key market, where chemical companies [BLANK] better demand in 2Q. Of large economies, Germany, the U.K. and Italy have improved the most this year. Among the most construction-linked chemicals are vinyl resins, coatings and packages of polymer or adhesive technologies for insulation and weatherproofing.

Plaintiff Appaloosa Management faces lower hurdles in the early stages of its merits case against SunEdison than the hedge fund did when it unsuccessfully sought to block a component of the clean energy giant's now-canceled deal to acquire Vivint Solar. The bar to [BLANK] a dismissal bid by SunEdison and TerraForm Power is lower than the threshold for a preliminary injunction. Appaloosa has already engaged in discovery on a Nov. 20 board reshuffle, an aspect of the deal the court found troubling.

With demand growth close to zero, U.S. utilities will look to strategic moves, building distribution and transmission networks and utility-scale solar to boost 2016 earnings. Their strong balance sheets, low interest rates and an appetite for renewable tax credits, could [BLANK] acquisitions of companies and assets that could boost earnings. Yieldcos were supposed to help, but have lost value as financing vehicles. Some smaller companies will likely sell to deep-pocketed buyers, especially from overseas.

Inverters are typically a commoditized part of a solar installation, yet a wave of innovation is disrupting the market. The key function of inverters is to [BLANK] solar energy into a current suitable for grid use. The introduction of power electronics and microinverters adds system control and optimizes generation, with home-energy storage and related energy-management systems becoming increasingly prevalent. Competition has accelerated product cost cuts, with new U.S. and Chinese entrants possibly disruptive.

A subsidiary of Parker Drilling providing labor to two of Exxon Mobil's Pacific OCS rigs lost a court case potentially worth millions to Parker in back-pay that will change the labor cost structure moving forward. A key decision on whether the new interpretation is [BLANK] retroactively or prospectively is expected in 2H.

Compliance with the General Data Protection Regulation is tough. Yet financial-services companies also need to navigate the new Network and Information Security Directive and the Recast Payment Services Directive (PSD2), which can [BLANK] conflicts. The U.K., meanwhile, isn't likely to deviate after Brexit.

The growth in video streaming, data and application use, as well as the growth in Internet-connected devices, may prompt subscribers to upgrade to higher-capacity wireless and wireline data plans. Carriers with tiered plans are in a position to [BLANK] these customers to higher-priced tiers. This may translate to increasing average revenue per user, which may help offset the pressure on revenue growth as net phone subscriber and legacy access line additions slow.

A wireless tower is essentially vertical real estate that's owned and managed by a tower operator. Carriers [BLANK] tower space to site their antennas, radios, base stations and cabling. Besides the tower, operators such as American Tower, Crown Castle International and SBA Communications also own or lease the land beneath the tower and often install generators for backup power. Tower leases include annual rent escalators and are often adjusted when carriers add or adjust equipment on the site.

Hong Kong net gold exports to China declined 21.3% sequentially in April to an eight-month low of 46.6 metric tons. The inbound shipments decline 22.1% from a year earlier, ending the year-to-date imports down 26% as Chinese buyers have been [BLANK] by robust equity markets. Shanghai Composite Index has surged 37.3% in the same time, reaching its highest level since 2007. Average gold prices edged down 1.6% in April and remained flat during the first four months, which has further discouraged buying.

Seven lawsuits over Caesars' asset moves and guarantee releases are pending at four courts in three states. All are stayed voluntarily and all will likely be extinguished if Caesars' new reorganization plan is [BLANK] on Jan. 17. UMB Bank (first lien trustee), Frederick Barton Danner (unsecured noteholder), Wilmington Trust (unsecured trustee), BOKF (second lien trustee), WSFS (second lien trustee and the plaintiff in the Delaware suit) and Trilogy (unsecured noteholder) have settled with Caesars.

Awards may come in the first quarter in two major federal contract competitions with a combined potential value of $1.6 billion. Accenture, Nelnet and Great Lakes Higher Education may learn the winners in a $1.1 billion Education Department deal for [BLANK] student-aid college loans and grants. A $500 million contract for Afghanistan life-support services also may be awarded.

Snap's addressable market of advertisers is likely focused on reaching millennials, who are increasingly shifting away from TV, forcing as much as $60 billion in ad spending to chase them. Snap's full-screen and video-centric ad units may [BLANK] to brand marketers, with retail, travel and entertainment particularly exposed to millennial wallets.

The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) will not decide 2014 renewable fuel standard mandates this year, instead announcing biofuel targets for 2014, 2015 and 2016 next year. Biofuel producers are relieved that proposed cuts are not [BLANK], yet continued uncertainty is affecting new investment. The American Fuel and Petrochemical Manufacturers Association has filed a notice of intent to sue the EPA over the lack of 2014 regulations.
