Santander Chile's ROTE targets may be challenging to manage amid macro headwinds, given Chile's economy isn't yet on a path to recovery. Revenue growth is likely to [BLANK] as asset repricing kicks in after 100-bp rate cuts. While provisions could rise, imminent cost-cutting efforts may possibly offset that.

The 1.6% average dividend yield for building materials companies is almost in line with the 1.7% average yield on 10-year euro-zone government bonds year-to-date. The last time the two traded on a par was in 2009, when the pair [BLANK] about 4%. This divergence may relate to falling euro-zone bond yields as the ECB's quantitative easing package begins and runs to 2016. Consensus points to a median 2.2% dividend yield in 2016 from 2015 earnings.

Growing levels of flood risk suggest an urgent need to increase insured coverage and adhere to strict market pricing. Climate change [BLANK] to raise the average cost of flood damage significantly, while boosting the frequency of catastrophic events. The Natural Resources Defense Council estimates floodplains will expand 50% by midcentury. They could possibly double in highly populated East and Gulf coast regions, where most NFIP subsidized policies reside, further raising their cost.

Air-freight rates in May fell back to record lows, negating gains over the previous two months. Rates will likely [BLANK] depressed till July following a seasonal decline. The Drewry East-West Air freight index at 79.1 was down 1.6% from April. The average air-freight rate of $2.57 a kilogram was 11% lower than a year earlier and 21% less than the five-year average. Freight rates have been pressured by weak demand and rising belly-hold cargo capacity, tied to increased passenger volume.

An Exelis unit being spun off as Vectrus has won two U.S. military contracts held by other companies since August. The potential incremental revenue may [BLANK] declining war-related contract dollars. The unit won a contract Sept. 17 worth up to $80 million in 2015 for base services in Turkey and Spain. Vinnell Brown & Root is the incumbent. The unit beat Lockheed Martin for another $103 million-a-year deal in August. Lockheed is challenging its loss.

Teva and its newly acquired Actavis unit will rely heavily on new launches to offset generic volume declines. Prescription volume in the U.S. has been [BLANK] fast since the beginning of 2013. Teva's base business is the primary cause, with the most recent 3Q tally showing Teva's franchise down 17% year over year and Actavis' down 6%. Combined, the unit is down 13%. New launches are needed to pick up the slack in volume, though given timing, there might not be a significant turnaround until 2018.

Retail sales of Class 8 trucks rose 20.1% in March from a year ago, after a 24.6% gain in February, as tight capacity and high freight demand continue to drive growth. Sales [BLANK] strong, at a three-month annualized rate of 275,340 units, above replacement demand. Even with an inventory gain of 28% vs. a year-ago, the heavy truck inventory-to-sales ratio fell to 2.3 months. It still is slightly above the target range of 1.5 to 2 months. Further inventory increases could spur a slowdown in build rates.

Athenahealth's Network Services division, created in 2016, is coordinating several initiatives to increase platform users, which may create a connected health-care network similar to that formed by Uber in transportation. The company is in the early stages of [BLANK] common collaboration tools for network users, including a global appointment calendar that would function similar to OpenTable. Network gains may indirectly increase sales in the near term, but its main focus now is attracting users to the platform.

The U.S. Justice Department plans to begin accepting bids this month for contracts to run five prisons under its Criminal Alien Requirement 16 and 17 competitions. The facilities together will house about 10,000 inmates, with the contracts [BLANK] at $2 billion over 10 years. Awards will likely come in 2016, and the selected contractors are scheduled to begin work in the first half of 2017, according to the Bureau of Prisons. Potential protests may delay that timeline.

NiSource's earnings growth and earned return on equity may fall now that it's a pure-play utility. The spinoff of Columbia Pipeline Group in early July contrasts with other utilities' announcements of new pipeline investments, which [BLANK] higher Federal Energy Regulatory Commission-authorized returns on equity than the average of 10% for Nisource's utility rate base. NiSource's earnings growth may almost exclusively depend on rate case outcomes and automatic mechanisms to recover gas distribution investments.

AstraZeneca's acalabrutinib showed a 96% overall response rate in previously untreated chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) patients in a Phase I/II trial, according to an ASCO abstract, which bests AbbVie's Imbruvica. No cases of atrial fibrillation were [BLANK]. This is a limiting side effect for Imbruvica, seen in 6% of patients in Resonate-2. Acalabrutinib must show complete responses to effectively compete with Imbruvica. Thus far, 86% of patients had a partial response.

The Asian LPG margin has risen $7.3 a barrel in the past seven weeks, rising above its five-year seasonal high, benefiting from tighter supply due to increased OPEC compliance to oil-production cuts. Indian demand remains robust as the government accelerates plans to [BLANK] fuel oil and kerosene by offering 50 million free LPG connections to poor households by end-2018. Chinese demand slowed to 2.1% in July, after averaging 21.5% in May to June.

Global flooring demand may rise 7.2% annually to $325 billion by 2018, according to the Freedonia Group. In volume terms, demand is expected to [BLANK] 4.5% annually. North America is expected to generate the highest growth rate at 5.6%, followed by the Asia-Pacific region at 5.2%, "other" at 4% and western Europe at 2%. Nonresilient flooring, which accounts for 59% of the global market, is forecast to grow 4.8%, followed by resilient flooring (13% of market) at 4.2% and carpets and rugs (27% of market) at 4%.

Norwegian Cruise's reliance on U.S. guests crimped its outlook in Europe. Management [BLANK] 34 cents of its 2016 EPS-guidance cut to lower sales expectations, of which 70% was due to weak North America-passenger demand for Mediterranean cruises. A 28% rise in 3Q-Caribbean capacity also tempered its outlook. For 2016, management lowered midpoint-guidance for EPS by 35 cents and yield-growth 2.25 percentage points. 2Q revenue missed consensus by 3%, yet EPS, buoyed by cost savings, beat by 2%.

The APHINITY trial of Roche's breast-cancer drug Perjeta, due in 4Q or the following quarter, is crucial to achieving 2020 consensus sales of about $4 billion, with the positive trial for NEOSPHERE providing hope. The GOYA trial's failure to show Gazyva beat Rituxan in aggressive cancer after the surprise success of GALLIUM in less-aggressive NHL, with data due at ASH, [BLANK] further upside to the potential of combination trials. The November SITC conference provides a platform for early stage immuno-oncology data.

The settlement of a U.S. Department of Justice lawsuit seeking to block Anthem's acquisition of Cigna appears unlikely. Resolving the antitrust issues [BLANK] by the DOJ at trial could be a challenge. Among other things, the DOJ alleged harm to a national accounts market of four competitors, which could be tough to "fix" with divestitures. In addition, the fact that Anthem, called "slow to innovate," is absorbing Cigna, characterized as an innovator, compounds the problem of finding an appropriate remedy.

SunPower is offering its high-efficiency solar modules in new deals with retail power providers to accelerate its presence in the home solar market. The company has agreements with TXU Energy for Texas and ConEdison Solutions and Dominion Energy Solutions [BLANK] New York State and New Jersey. The deals heighten competition with home solar companies in those states and builds SunPower's equipment demand alongside its existing dealership network, as it leverages power company customer relationships.

Astra's success with its immuno-oncology drug Imfinzi, particularly its Pacific trial win in lung cancer, makes it even more of an attractive target to Pfizer than in 2014. The weaker pound vs. the dollar post-Brexit, undiminished tax savings and the fact that, even not taking account of the tax-inversion potential, it [BLANK] the best EPS accretion for Pfizer, makes it even more compelling. Yet, there are antitrust issues on at least two fronts: Pfizer's Bevancio and ertugliflozin.

The bottom for thermal and coking coal remains elusive as prices head for the fifth straight year of declines. Though seaborne coking coal prices are at their lowest levels in more than a decade and producers have exercised supply restraint, it hasn't been enough to support prices, as demand has [BLANK] even more. The same can be said for thermal coal. Prices are likely to stay under pressure as seaborne demand falls in 2015 for the first time in more than a decade.

Singapore investors may get a new opportunity to invest in U.S. property via a Canadian insurance company, showing the global nature of commercial real estate that continues to inflate U.S. asset values. Canadian insurer Manulife plans to [BLANK] some U.S. property assets as a REIT in Singapore, according to the Wall Street Journal. Few of the 89 Singapore-listed real estate developers and REITs own U.S. assets, with Global Logistic Properties the biggest exception.

The amount of natural gas used to fuel power plants in Mexico has almost doubled in the past decade, but a simmering trade fight with the U.S. has the potential to disrupt the trend. Natural gas, which can be freely traded between Mexico and the U.S., could get hit by retaliatory tariffs or taxes if House Republicans' proposed 20% border-adjusted tax is [BLANK]. President Donald Trump's plan to renegotiate the North American Free Trade Agreement could also affect U.S. energy exports.

Aggressive pricing from energy-storage suppliers in the National Grid's U.K. tender round may encourage additional procurements, while also increasing price pressure on battery manufacturers. The accepted tenders for 201 megawatts of battery-energy storage [BLANK] from 7-11.97 pounds ($9.27-$15.86) per megawatt of response per hour. The lowest accepted tenders came from EDF Energy Renewables, Vattenfall and Low Carbon, undercutting more established battery energy-storage providers, such as AES.

Post-2Q Earnings Outlook: Tesaro's much-anticipated launch of Zejula, the third PARP drug to be introduced in the U.S., is off to a remarkable start thanks to its broad label. Zejula beat estimates, but also [BLANK] a dominant position vs. rivals Rubraca (Clovis) and Lynparza (AstraZeneca). July trends point to further growth, making estimates obsolete. Zejula's ramp-up ahead of potential label expansions of its PARP rivals will be key, as that has the potential to level the field.

Fixed-income ETF flows reflect lower interest-rate risk appetite, as long-duration funds saw outflows equivalent to 1.4% of assets under management for the four weeks ended Oct. 18 vs. inflows of 3.1% of AUM for ultra-short term funds, 1.2% of AUM for short term funds and 1.9% for intermediate term. The 10-year benchmark U.S. Treasury yield has risen over 25 bps since the Federal Reserve's Sept. 7 announc ement that it will start [BLANK] its balance sheet in 4Q.

Gamesa is working to retain a market-leading position of 54% of the installed turbines in Mexico's small but high-growth wind power market in the face of rising competition from Vestas and Nordex. The country's two auction rounds for wind energy in 2016 [BLANK] about 1.44 gigawatts of new capacity. The auction process may begin to add price and margin pressure for developers and manufacturers with the first round at an average auction bid of $55.32 per megawatt hour, with the second at $35.85.

While the positive stimulus of lowering interest rates inside China would normally be a giant plus for metal demand, one must take into account how lower interest rates, and a weaker dollar value of the yuan, may curb demand for the financial carry trade. These deals have led to a large amount of metal [BLANK] up to facilitate an arbitrage of low western interest rates with high internal Chinese rates. Metals are used as collateral to make the trade work, a move that has artificially inflated demand.

Employers in the steel, automotive and rail industries are among those pushing Congress to pass legislation repealing Obamacare's tax on high-cost health insurance plans. This so-called Cadillac Tax, which goes into effect in 2018, [BLANK] a 40% tax on plans' values in excess of $10,200 for individuals and $27,500 for families. The tax doesn't target specific industries, though those with unionized workforces that have negotiated generous benefit packages may be affected disproportionately.

EQT's 2015 output may rise 23% even with lower well development capital and fewer wells being drilled. That's because EQT seeks to maximize operational efficiencies and improve well economics by [BLANK] wells with longer laterals from multi-well pads. The volume from its drilling program will be prolific in 2015 even with 44% fewer wells drilled. The shorter-cycle drilling environment in Appalachia suggests an acceleration of activity is possible if benchmark commodity prices recover sooner, promoting more volume.

Increased oil drilling in North America is driving growth in crude transported by rail. Pipelines do not have the capacity currently to handle the [BLANK] production. Rails carry crude oil to and from destinations pipelines cannot reach, and can transport crude two to three times faster than pipelines. Railroads may lose market share due to regulatory pressures, thinner Brent-WTI spreads and as pipelines, which are cheaper, expand their reach and capacity.

Boeing threw in the towel on returning 747 production to one a month, taking an $800 million charge on the program along with $800 million to expense two of the 787 test aircraft and $400 million for boom development for the KC-46 tanker. The admission that 747 won't [BLANK] to one a month production is more evidence of little demand for four engine aircraft. Boeing has long awaited a turnaround in the cargo market to improve demand while for passenger use the airplane competes with Airbus' A380.

Slowing 2015 economic growth in the developing world and Europe could lead to more delivery deferrals for airframers and engine makers. The developing markets, including the Asia-Pacific region and Latin America, [BLANK] 38% of the industry's total backlog. Europe accounts for 25%. Traffic growth will moderate if GDP slows, which is expected for China, Brazil, Russia and the eurozone. Boeing, Airbus and the engine makers are particularly exposed, given the concentration of Asian backlogs.

Fortum's power hedging policy indicates that the company may have a positive outlook for the recovery in wholesale electricity prices in the Nordic region in the next two years. At the end of 2014, the company sold forward only half of its power output for 2015, [BLANK] with 67% historically and 10% of its 2016 production, which is four times lower than the average in the past five years. Generators sell forward their future production to hedge risks and maximize profit using their market views.

Chimeric antigen receptor T-cell (CAR-T) therapy may have a place in solid tumors with approaches in the works by Juno and Intrexon. The therapy has been limited to blood cancers -- notably those [BLANK] to CD19. Solid tumors lack a good target that's limited to the tumor alone so that eliminating it can cause side effects in normal cells. These new second-generation approaches allow for fine control of the system so that T-cells can also be turned off quickly or activated just near the tumor.

The proposed acquisition of Booker by Tesco that's under review by the U.K.'s antitrust regulator is likely to be approved, though a number of concessions may be needed before a decision is issued. The merger [BLANK] the U.K.'s largest food retailer and a leading food wholesaler in a deal with both vertical and horizontal overlaps. These are likely resolvable with divestitures. Tesco and Booker on January 27 agreed to a 3.7 billion-pound acquisition that the parties expect to close in late 4Q or 1Q18.

Elevated asset values in Manhattan have kept REITs on the sidelines, though private buyers remain. REITs [BLANK] just 14% of Manhattan office acquisitions in 2015, according to Real Capital Analytics data, trailing international (36%) and institutional investors (30%). The disparity is even more stark in 2016, with no office REITs among the 30 largest buyers of New York office properties, while private buyers have remained active and asset values are still elevated.

The yen is down 3.5% to 124 vs the dollar so far this year, extending last year's 12% plunge as Japan tolerates currency weakness to pull the nation out of a deflationary spiral. Lingering depreciation would [BLANK] forex gains on overseas assets at Mitsubishi UFJ, Sumitomo Mitsui and Mizuho. Japan's three largest banks had an average 33% of total loans overseas in the last fiscal year. Consensus median estimates indicate the yen will depreciate to 126 vs the dollar in 2016. The most bearish projection is 138.

Trucking companies, in addition to competing with each other, must fight for market share with the other modes of freight transportation: air, rail, pipeline and water. Shippers must make tradeoffs between costs, reliability, transit times, accessibility, capability, flexibility and security when [BLANK] a mode of transportation. Including the 4.1% share of less-than-truckload carriers, trucks account for almost three quarters of the U.S. domestic transportation market.

People's United's 2016 EPS guidance remained unchanged as a negative revision to net interest income was offset by lower costs. The [BLANK] acquisition of investment manager Gerstein Fisher may be modestly accretive to 2017 earnings with annual revenue of over $17 million, the company said. The bank's 2Q results beat estimates on lower-than-expected expenses. It generated positive core operating leverage, with core revenue up 4% vs. a 2% increase in core expenses, improving its efficiency ratio.

Advances in car technology, such as automatic braking systems, has led to a significant reduction in fatality rates in the past decade. A 2015 study by the European Commission [BLANK] a 66% drop in the number of fatalities and a crash reduction rate of 27% since 1991. As technology advances and car safety improves accident and claims numbers are expected to decline further. This is evident from a study by KPMG which estimates an 80% decline in average accident frequency per vehicle by 2040.

The decline of crude oil prices hasn't weakened projected U.S. refiner spreads, according to EIA estimates. The [BLANK] volatility of oil prices will likely increase the price uncertainty. Refinery margins may recover from weakness in late December, improving in the summer as product prices recover. Refiners may also have improvement from retail margins, which tend to rise when pump prices are lower, because not all price cuts are passed on to consumers.

Square is available to merchants in the U.K., where it won't enjoy the first-mover advantage it had in the U.S. Still, the U.K. is the logical place to start European expansion, given its high rate of card use and because almost 3 million businesses don't accept cards. Square faces off against similar services, such as PayPal Here, SumUp and iZettle -- recently acquired by PayPal -- and [BLANK] a much lower merchant rate of 1.75% of sales in the U.K., vs. 2.75% in the U.S. Only about 4% of Square's 2017 revenue was earned outside the U.S. It came from Canada, Japan and Australia, a market the company entered in 2015. Square remains focused on tapping the estimated 20 million U.S. businesses that don't accept cards, though it noted that international expansion is a key 2018 priority.

The market capitalization of the top nine chaebol, large conglomerates that dominate South Korea's economy, is more than $600 billion, or about three-fifths of the value of the Kospi 200. Their size and influence have led to claims they are stifling competition, and their large cash reserves are [BLANK] as hindering investment and wage growth. Reform proposals have circulated since the Asian financial crisis. Chaebols' growing grip on the economy shows reformers have made little progress.

Most global investment banks reported FICC results well above expectations, though equities were mostly in-line, down 11% from the prior-year period. Low volatility pressure on the equities derivatives business was a key reason for weakness, [BLANK] volume lower, even as prices rise. Further evidence of the slump may come with the earnings results of BNP Paribas (July 31) and Societe Generale (Aug. 1). Each is relatively more weighted toward derivatives than cash equities.

Macau has only 7,400 unemployed people and a 1.9% jobless rate, even with last year's downturn. This is a challenge for casino operators, as they have tens of thousands of positions to [BLANK] with new resort openings. Key posts, including table dealers and management must be held by Macanese. Galaxy and Wynn have employee share programs to acquire and retain labor, while other operators offer bonus programs and wage increases. These costs can weigh on profit margins, especially while revenue is weak.

Henkel and Procter & Gamble increased their share of the U.S. laundry-care market in the four-week period ended July 31, according to IRI data. Their closest rival, Church & Dwight, [BLANK] share. While Henkel had the biggest expansion from the year-ago period, its share (7%) is still far behind the leader, P&G, which has 61.7%. Consolidation in the category should spur innovation, growth and share upheaval. Post completion of Henkel's pending purchase of Sun Products, the group will overtake Church's No. 2 ranking.

American Airlines' record coupon and firming aircraft values are signs of strong investor demand for aircraft-backed bonds and could spur other airlines to issue. American issued a 3.7% senior tranche and 4.38% junior tranche, the lowest fixed-rate coupon financing in over a decade, to [BLANK] Boeing 777-300s and Airbus A321s and A319s. Oriel Valuations indicates 777 values are strong, while A321 and A319 values are firming.

A Senate bill aiming to increase pharmaceutical competition by boosting incentives and speeding up the approval of new generic drugs has a favorable legislative environment. The bill, S. 2615, is consistent with Republicans' interest in lowering regulatory hurdles and Democrats' desire to [BLANK] rising drug prices. The Senate committee on health issues is in the process of assembling its version of the House-passed 21st Century Cures bill. This new measure could be added to a final version.

Helicopter orders and service revenue will likely fall through 2017 as energy capital spending sinks amid low oil and gas prices. Declines may [BLANK] on stable, albeit lower, energy prices. Deferrals, cancellations and depressed order flows are likely due to stored helicopters. Some are likely to be re-purposed, though costs to refit the interior can make it prohibitively expensive. Manufacturers will attempt to blunt the effects through other markets, such as military, corporate and para-public.

Surging sales of medium and heavy trucks in India may continue on its new emission standard adoption and possible tax reform. The Bharat IV emission standard will [BLANK] out in 10 Indian states in April, and nationwide in April 2017. Truck buyers may rush to purchase the cheaper, State III-compliant models ahead of that. The new goods and services tax that may take effect in April will let manufacturers consolidate production, boosting truck demand. Sales of medium and heavy trucks in India climbed 37% in January.

Almost half of the 30 members of the S&P Utilities Index are expected to raise dividends during the first quarter, based on consensus. Such changes usually are made at or around the time companies [BLANK] quarterly earnings and give profit forecasts. CenterPoint, Northeast Utilities, NextEra, CMS, Dominion and Sempra are projected to boost payouts the most. Solid earnings and cash flow growth, along with sales of risky assets, are boosting dividend-paying capacity.

Gasoline crack spreads remain high as strong demand encourages U.S. refinery utilization in the summer driving season. Inventories are 1% above the five-year average, yet below seasonal norms when [BLANK] to account for higher demand. Gasoline output remains robust, assisted by crack spreads over $29 a barrel, slightly off the year's highs. Stockpiles may have risen by 717,000 barrels in the week ended July 17 vs. an increase of 3.3 million a year earlier. That would be the fifth build in six weeks.

Strong industry support for Microsoft and Facebook's challenges to a gag-order law bolsters the odds the measure is struck down. Federal and local law enforcement officials are increasingly using the law to [BLANK] cloud customer data without alerting the users whose data is being searched. That raises constitutional concerns, and the onus will be on the government to provide compelling reasons for the gag orders. The lack of safeguards to prevent abuses of the law makes that a difficult burden to meet.

Drugs from Gilead, Amgen and Sanofi were among the top-selling medicines in Medicare's Part D program, according to the most recent U.S. government data. Democratic presidential nominee Hillary Clinton wants to give the government authority to [BLANK] Part D prices directly, highlighting a potential risk to drugmakers' margins. Notably, the 2014 data reflects the first year of Gilead's hepatitis C franchise. Two AstraZeneca drugs on the list have faced or will soon face patent expirations: Nexium and Crestor.

Telefonica decided to abandon the planned IPO of Telxius, as purchase orders received were below its minimum expectations. At the low end of the original IPO pricing range, Telefonica was aiming to raise 1.1 billion euros ($1.2 billion) for a 36% stake, [BLANK] fees. Lower figures likely wouldn't have been enough to significantly cut Telefonica's net debt, 52.6 billion euros as of 1H, or 3.2x Oibda. Telefonica may opt to sell Telxius assets piecemeal and accelerate plans for other listings, including O2 U.K.

Activist Bill Ackman, the largest private shareholder in Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, jumped into the legal fray over the agencies, challenging the terms of the 2008 U.S. bailout as unfair to investors. The lawsuit is likely to bring volatility to the shares, [BLANK] trading opportunities for Ackman and other investors as more than a dozen legal cases are litigated in coming years. Herbalife stock has gyrated since Ackman began betting against that company in 2012.

Software-as-a-service products form the largest segment of the public cloud market, generating about $51 billion in revenue in 2015, according to IDC. Lower costs, revenue stability and faster speed-to-market are driving spending on SaaS, which IDC expects to [BLANK] annually by 16% to $92 billion by 2019. The market is comprised of both pure-play cloud vendors and larger software companies that are transitioning from legacy on-premise products to a cloud-delivery model.

Slowing apparel sales have forced many apparel retailers to increase their presence in adjacent categories like home, jewelry, shoes, beauty and more. Dillard's low penetration in home, 4% of sales, vs. rivals at more than 10% [BLANK] it more vulnerable to a slowdown and consumer fickleness in apparel. Sales in the home and furniture category have been mixed for Dillard's. In the latest quarter, 3Q, sales were stronger in home and furniture after having been weak in the two prior quarters.

A U.S. Bancorp unit is fighting two lawsuits by a group of mortgage-bond investors, including BlackRock and Pimco, which allege the bank failed in its duties as bond trustee. The bulk of claims are in state court after the 2015 dismissal of most of the suit in federal court, which is now [BLANK] in narrowed form. In total, the suits allege more than $100 billion in trust losses, making them the largest of several suits by these investors against mortgage-bond trustees.

Return on common equity for BI-tracked payment processors may start to rise after being stable to down in the last year. Prior to that, ROE had [BLANK] since 2013. ROE at Global Payments and Total System has yet to reflect expected synergies from recent M&A. Vantiv's ROE has risen following its 2009 IPO, but is below 3Q highs. Debt-to-total capital has risen from deals weighing on total capital returns, though cost of capital is below the return on tangible capital.

Global hedge funds, real estate investment trusts, private equity and venture capital could have easier access to Europe's $17 trillion asset-management market by the fourth quarter. The European Commission may give foreign alternative investment managers the equivalent of a passport, [BLANK] them to freely market non-European Economic Area funds inside the 31-member bloc and offer EEA funds outside the region. Managers would have to comply with only one regime instead of a myriad of local rules.

Severe weather in the U.S. caused an estimated $475 million of economic losses in July, based on catastrophe data from Aon Benfield. High winds, tornadoes and hail were the primary cause of damage, which largely [BLANK] the Southeast and Midwest. Preliminary estimates of insured losses were about $325 million. Catastrophe costs for July fell short of a year earlier, when similar types of storms generated losses well over $500 million and included an unusual tornado in the greater Boston area.

Tencent successfully shifted its dominance to mobile from PC with WeChat, China's largest social-networking platform of 806 million monthly active users. It [BLANK] to take market share in China's online ads market. Tencent capitalizes on WeChat's high user engagement through ads on its official accounts and news feeds on WeChat moments, which remains under monetized. Tencent also seeks new advertisers by leveraging its e-commerce investment in JD.com and its fast-growing online payments.

More U.S. rig count declines may be in store as contracts end and aren't renewed due to depleted E&P capital spending budgets. Rig counts outside the major oil and gas plays led the weakness, falling four in the week [BLANK] Nov. 6 after shedding nine the previous week. Oil-targeted rig-count declines were led by the Eagle Ford, which dropped three rigs, while the total gas-directed count rose one. Despite the Permian's three-rig gain, the play is the largest source of rig losses to date.

Latin American 2Q yields were slightly higher even as business travel fell on the World Cup and strong capacity additions, including Delta adding 20%. American and United pricing power [BLANK] as their fuel prices rose only slightly. Delta yields fell although pricing power was flat on lower fuel prices yoy. American warned of coming yield weakness on 3Q World Cup effects and less Venezuela flying, which was highly demanded on a currency arbitrage scheme.

Health Net is most exposed among managed care companies to TRICARE, with 4% of its 2013 revenue from the Defense Department program. Humana [BLANK] 1% of its revenue from TRICARE. UnitedHealth is the largest of the three incumbents by overall revenue and is likely the least exposed. The next round of TRICARE contracts may be 50% larger than the current ones, making them a more significant potential driver of revenue for managed care companies. Only two companies may win deals.

Despite a recent cold snap boosting short-term demand, forecasts for milder U.S. temperatures later this month, along with record-high production, may continue to deter higher benchmark prices. Drawdowns from storage are [BLANK] at 80 billion cubic feet in the week ended Feb. 5, half the year-earlier level of 160 billion, based on consensus. Stockpiles remain robust, at 22% above the five-year average. If prices stay depressed, volume declines may be realized as E&Ps cut capital spending.

Demand for 10-year Treasuries during the quarterly refunding auctions has trended lower over the past several years as represented by falling bid-cover ratios. Less dramatic down-trends in demand have also [BLANK] at other 10-year and 30-year Treasury auctions. Bid-cover for shorter-maturity securities haven't demonstrated any meaningful trend, remaining volatile within a range over the past several years.

Kuka's bid to dominate the Chinese robotics market will face rising competition from the likes of ABB and local rivals. It [BLANK] to team with Midea to boost its capacity by 100,000 robots a year and reach 1 billion euros of sales in China. ABB plans similar capacity additions by 2020, adding to its $6 billion in existing sales there.

Bears contend that crude-by-rail growth may be hampered by regulatory and environmental concerns. Higher fuel prices and [BLANK] growth in China may also hurt railroad earnings. Railroads are susceptible to cold temperatures, severe weather and accidents, all of which can affect networks, reducing productivity and earnings as operating costs rise. These events are unpredictable and may decrease rail profitability.

The NCAA basketball tournament, which starts March 15, is one of the largest, most watched sports events in the U.S. Ad sales topped $1.19 billion in 2015, just short of the NFL as the second-most lucrative post-season sports event. The tournament provides an opportunity for athletic brands to gain exposure and showcase products, through the sponsorship of [BLANK] teams. Nike continues to lead the sponsored universities in this year's tournament, though it's lost some share to Under Armour and Adidas.

Calculated spreads along the U.S. ethylene chain are heading downward, as feedstock costs surge and ethylene prices plunge. Long-term averages suggest they have further to fall, as new capacity comes [BLANK] at both upstream (ethylene) and downstream (polyethylene, other derivatives) levels of the supply chain.

Nvidia could be on the hook for up to $45 million in Samsung's Virginia patent-infringement case targeting Nvidia's graphics processors. Samsung filed the case after first being [BLANK] by Nvidia following failed licensing negotiations. A judgment could weigh heavily in settlement discussions and offset royalty payments that Nvidia planned to receive from Samsung. Samsung claims Nvidia infringes three patents: two related to integrated circuit manufacturing and one on SDRAM (memory) chips.

The new economic plan in Turkey, due Sept. 20, must provide a credible strategy to rein in inflation and the surge in loan rates for European banks to maintain their material exposures to the embattled country. BBVA's chairman reiterated the lender's commitment to Turkey after the central bank raised the repo rate, though this could [BLANK] to be shortlived if Erdogan's saber-rattling continues. UniCredit may need to write down the carrying value (currently 2.5 billion euros) of its Turkish participation by up to 40%, we estimate. Turkey's credit rating was cut on Aug. 17 by S&P (to B+, four notches below investment grade) and Moody's (to Ba3, three notches below investment grade). S&P forecasts a recession in Turkey next year, and expects inflation to peak at 22% near term.

One insight about Free Press' forthcoming request to stay the FCC's order reinstating the UHF discount may come when the D.C. Circuit sets a briefing schedule. That order may come soon after the stay petition is filed, and it may [BLANK] the judges likely to act on the stay. While there's no guarantee the scheduling judges will ultimately rule, they often do. Bush-appointee Thomas Griffith and Obama-appointees Sri Srinivasan and Nina Pillard have acted on motions during May, making them the leading contenders here.

Rising milk costs are reversing last year's deflation and may pressure margins of dairy goods makers as growth remains sluggish in Europe and North America on a lack of substantial innovation in brands that appeal to shoppers. Baby milk makers that took advantage of lower costs to innovate, boost efficiency and [BLANK] via deals may find it easier to pass on higher prices. New regulations in China add volatility, but the transition to a local model could help Nestle and Danone's trusted baby milk premium-brands.

Tax reform is stealing the limelight in an otherwise solid start to S&P 500 earnings-reporting season. Charges litter the landscape, and [BLANK] commentary is focused on future tax savings. EPS growth estimates are finally moving closer to projections in our model, now that companies can provide insight on tax accounting. So far, companies have been a bit elusive about their plans for the windfall, though investment and payments to employees seem generally preferred over distributions.

Drugmakers were largely spared criticism in the Oct. 28 Republican presidential debate. Chris Christie, New Jersey's governor, explicitly rebuked the concept of what he [BLANK] "Hillary Clinton's price controls" on the pharmaceutical industry. Fellow candidate Dr. Ben Carson turned the drug-pricing question into a call for fewer regulations. These stances differ from those of Democratic candidates Clinton and Bernie Sanders, a senator. Both have called for more government involvement in setting drug prices.

Manufacturers of solar cells that rely on third-party wafer suppliers may face gross margin pressures in 3Q after raw material polysilicon and wafer prices rose. Planned maintenance of polysilicon capacity has curbed output, with wafer producers also reducing supply as production lines are [BLANK] to use diamond wire saws.

Tidal Lagoon Swansea Bay is proposing to build a 320 megawatt tidal lagoon power plant, with an overall budget of 1 billion pounds ($1.6 billion) to cover construction and grid connection. The project may [BLANK] as the world's first purpose-built tidal energy lagoon and will provide renewable energy for up to 14 hours per day. The project is currently in a developmental stage, with construction possibly starting in 2015 and grid connection by 2018.

Strong performance from companies such as Nvidia offset Asia demand-driven issues and weakness in PC and smartphone markets for the logic chipmaker peer group in 1H. Mobile chipmakers Qualcomm and MediaTek are grappling with [BLANK] smartphone growth, particularly as emerging-market demand wanes. Those with greater data-center and non-Asia-related exposure may fare better than peers with heavy PC or China exposure in 2H. The Philadelphia Semiconductor Index rose 5%, outpaced by 10% gains for logic chipmakers.

Rapid market-share gains have fueled Xiaomi's growth in the last two years, making it the world's fifth-largest smartphone maker, based on 2015 IDC data. Xiaomi's success hinges on its ability to [BLANK] low-cost, feature-rich phones, as well as its online-only sales model, flash-sales marketing campaign and frequent changes to its custom Android skin, MIUI. Xiaomi may gain further share from rivals, including Apple and Samsung, as it enters more markets such as India and adds products.

Major media companies and internet-video platforms, as well as gaming-specific sites such as Twitch and Activision's MLG, are set to spar for increasing e-sports advertising revenue. Advertising and media rights revenue will remain major growth drivers for the e-sports market, as the audience [BLANK] worldwide.

After a mainly encouraging start to the European TMT 3Q earnings season, with the exception of advertising group WPP, Telefonica (Oct. 31) and BT (Nov. 1) are among those [BLANK] this week. We expect Telefonica to show steady revenue growth, leaving the prospect of a guidance upgrade likely, while BT will probably report another quarter of sales and profit squeeze, with attention shifting toward strategy execution under incoming-CEO Philip Jansen. Meanwhile, we think Eutelsat (Oct. 30) may finally show underlying revenue growth, Swisscom's (Nov. 1) fundamentals are unlikely to have deviated much from prior trends, and Safaricom (Nov. 2) should have sustained dominance in Kenyan telecom and mobile money.

Broadcasters have started disclosing their proceeds from the Federal Communications Commission's spectrum incentive auction. The use of proceeds may be [BLANK] on earnings calls and could be tied in with discussion on M&A. To date, Fox ($350 million), Tribune ($190 million), Gray ($91 million), Sinclair ($313 million) and EW Scripps ($0) have announced their expected gross proceeds. Each broadcaster has said that their participation in the auction will not materially affect their business operations.

ConocoPhillips is suing Petroleos de Venezuela SA, or PDVSA, to stop the state-owned company from selling its Citgo affiliate or further burdening it with debt. The effort comes as Conoco [BLANK] arbitration cases against Venezuela in various venues over nationalization of assets in the country during Hugo Chavez's time in power. Conoco isn't likely to capitalize on any arbitration award without enforcing it on Venezuela-owned assets in the U.S., where Citgo is Venezuela's only material holding.

North American producers continue to report elevated 4Q margins, though falling resin prices may challenge further growth. While companies [BLANK] strong volumes, U.S. spot high-density polyethylene prices have fallen 18% since November. Such drops historically follow lower oil and are followed by contract prices. U.S. HDPE cash margins narrowed for four consecutive months to $1,250 a metric ton in January, based on Nexant models. Customer inventory destocking affected 4Q, which may continue into 1Q.

Platinum prices have fallen 14% in less than three months, compared with a 6% drop in gold, helping to push the gold-platinum ratio to an 18-month high. The ratio almost [BLANK] 1 for the first time since April 2013. Historically, an ounce of platinum has been worth more than an ounce of gold, with the exception of a few months in the early 1990s and from late 2011 to early 2013. Investor confidence in platinum may have waned as prices fell and strikes across South Africa were settled.

Shopping center REIT rental spreads on new leases have been 15% to 20% in four of the past five quarters. High occupancy rates and little new supply provide few options for retailers, and [BLANK] rents are in many cases well below market. Those trends are likely to continue in 3Q with occupancy rates at seven-year highs. As a result, shopping center REITs have consistently increased same-store net operating income in the 3% to 4% range, fueling earnings growth.

Family apparel stores rose 9.1% in mid-January, their best sales jump in at least 2 and 1/2 years, according to First Data's non-cash point-of-sale data. Traffic [BLANK] 9.9%, likely due to weak comparisons to 2013 when traffic and sales both fell more than 5.7%. That was when the "polar vortex" cold weather snap affected about 200 million U.S. residents and led to many store closures. The mid-January gains come after a strong November and December that led most apparel retailers to raise 4Q sales expectations.

AIA's 15-year deal with Bangkok Bank -- Thailand's largest lender -- will give it access to a sprawling potential client base as it seeks to extend its dominance in the country's insurance market. Bangkok Bank will sell AIA's long-term products exclusively, [BLANK] the insurer to fend off rivals such as FWD and Southeast Life. AIA is Thailand's largest life insurer by annual premium equivalent.

Autos may be viewed as the next consumer product to lead semiconductor growth amid slowing smartphone and PC markets. Yet even with a technological innovation pace that's similar to that of PCs and smartphones, design cycles are significantly longer and widespread adoption may not [BLANK] until 2020. Still, auto semiconductor sales are expected to expand 9% annually through 2019, 3x the broader market, to comprise 12% of chip sales. Content expansion is driving growth, with auto shipments expected to rise just 2%.

CenterPoint may provide an update on potential plans to spin off its stake in Enable Midstream on the 2Q earnings call. The company invested in midstream assets to boost growth, but now [BLANK] faster earnings expansion at its gas and electric utilities, given the slowdown in the midstream sector due to low commodity prices. Consensus forecasts a 6% increase in adjusted EPS. CenterPoint's equity earnings from Enable likely rose in 2Q, given Enable's distributable cash flow increased 4% to $144 million.

The Guyana-Suriname Basin could present a huge opportunity for offshore drillers in the coming years if massive oil fields continue being discovered. Building on the success of their Liza-1 and Liza-2 wells, Exxon [BLANK] the Skipjack-1 well (recently spud 24 miles to the north) may be even bigger. The Liza-2 is estimated to hold 800 million to 1.4 billion barrels of oil equivalent (BOE). For perspective, BP's Thunder Horse field, one of the largest in the Gulf of Mexico, holds 1 billion BOE.

Electronics will lose its OLED TV set market share to Chinese and Japanese rivals, as panel supply from the Korean company's 38%-owned LG Display rises. The world's sole producer of OLED TV panels aims to [BLANK] its capacity by 1.8x to 60,000 sheets a month this year to reap the benefits of scale. LG's shipment share will likely fall from about 85% in 2016, as Sony and Panasonic sell more OLED TV sets. In China, Skyworth is using OLED products to promote its brand image at the expense of margin.

India's oil-product demand growth is losing steam as a sharp rupee depreciation and strong oil price makes domestic fuel prices expensive. A high taxation policy -- one of the highest globally, while benefiting the national exchequer with windfall gains, is [BLANK] demand growth for gasoline and diesel. We expect demand expectations by the IEA to be significantly downgraded for 2018 as current estimates are unrealistic. Over a longer term, demand should rise an average 208,000 barrels a day (208 kbd) annually between 2018-23 -- 14% higher than its previous five year average and 16% more than China's 178 kbd growth over the same period.

Hospital patients may have sought more elective procedures that generate higher revenue in 4Q as health-plan deductibles were exhausted, curtailing out-of-pocket expenses. HCA's revenue per [BLANK] admission may exceed peers' because of its investment in more profitable services, such as transcatheter aortic valve replacement. Community Health and LifePoint underperformed earlier in the year, as demand for higher-revenue procedures lagged behind in rural markets.

Russia's submarine buildup and increased presence in the Mediterranean Sea and North Atlantic, along with elevated threats from China, North Korea and Iran, will likely help preserve budget dollars for U.S. Navy submarine programs. The Navy is expected to procure Virginia-class subs well into the 2030s, which are key to [BLANK] the threats, given their stealth technology and Tomahawk missile capacity. Production stands at two a year, though could be accelerated to meet new, higher fleet goals.

Puerto Rico and the board overseeing its debt restructuring proceedings may be able to win dismissal of Assured's and Financial Guaranty Insurance's court challenge of Puerto Rico's revised fiscal plan. Motions to [BLANK] are due on July 20 and briefing will conclude on Sept. 7. The bond insurers have guaranteed a combined $4.5 billion of bonds issued by the commonwealth and its instrumentalities.

Volkswagen awaits an initial hearing in front of U.S. District Judge Charles R. Breyer, who was appointed Dec. 8 to handle the consolidated cases by the Judicial Panel on Multi-District Litigation. This likely sets the stage for processing cases to be consolidated into the court and [BLANK] potential lead players on the plaintiffs' side. Breyer has as much experience as any other U.S. jurist in handling large-scale consolidated cases such as this, meaning he'll likely set an aggressive schedule.

Relative stability in metals prices should bode well for industrials' performance, particularly machinery and electrical equipment, relative to the broader S&P 500. So far this year, prices for industrial metals have [BLANK] those for energy. This divergence in the commodity complex has aided relative performance for industrials stocks. Over the long run, the sector's stock prices show a stronger correlation to metals prices than to those for energy.

Medical-device manufacturers scored a win against the Obamacare 2.3% excise tax with Congress' enactment of a two-year moratorium on the tax in 2016-17. However, that delay lessened the near-term pressure on Congress to [BLANK] the tax entirely before the elections. Repeal, or at least an extension of the moratorium, could be part of Republican efforts to replace many Obamacare provisions. The budget-reconciliation measure Congress passed -- and then-President Barack Obama vetoed -- in 2016 had such a provision.

Earnings growth at South Korea's banks could cease as North Korea's threats intensify geopolitical tensions. The banks [BLANK] mounting funding and asset-quality risks as brinkmanship and diplomatic saber-rattling undermine South Korea's economic outlook.

About $30 billion in capital that banks pledge to the Federal Reserve may be returned under a bill proposed April 21. Banks are [BLANK] to pledge 6% of their capital and surplus in exchange for stock in the U.S. central bank. H.R. 5027 would allow 5.5% to be returned to banks for their use, including investment, though still subject to call. The bill is a response to a 2015 action that cut the dividend banks earn on Fed stock. The bill is unlikely to move anytime soon, but could pass during the lame-duck session.

Delays and cost overruns have plagued previous programs, indicating risk to the 80 to 100 planned orders for the new LRS-B plane. Original B-2 plans [BLANK] 132 aircraft, yet just 21 were built as procurement costs ballooned to $1.2 billion apiece. President Carter's administration ordered 250 B-1s, though President Reagan reduced the order to 100. The U.S. has cut 400 F-35 orders, an indication of risk to plans to build about 2,500 of the planes.

At a time when first-line lung-cancer treatment is believed soon to be dominated by combinations, the purpose of AstraZeneca's newly-initiated Pearl trial, testing durvalumab as a single agent vs. chemotherapy, is unclear. The paramount Mystic trial, which had progression-free and overall survival as secondary endpoints for durvalumab alone vs. chemo, has now been [BLANK] with both as primary endpoints. By not having a durvalumab-plus-chemo arm in any of its trials, AstraZeneca's strategy is puzzling and worrying.

Marvell's response to Innovatio's patent-infringement complaint is due Nov. 13. The response was initially due at the end of September, though both sides [BLANK] to extend the deadline. The parties requested the extension after attending an Oct. 14 settlement conference that could help resolve their dispute. Innovatio sued Marvell for patent infringement in March and amended its complaint in August after Marvell challenged the sufficiency of Innovatio's initial allegations.

TalkTalk's focus on stabilizing the business, following a cyberattack last year, will require more spending on customer retention. This will likely [BLANK] its competitive threat to other operators. With management aiming to reduce marketing spending this year, the potential for taking market share is reduced while rivals BT and Sky boost marketing ahead of the soccer season and in the back-to-school period. TalkTalk has so far failed to stem declines with pay-TV net losses at 123,000 customers in fiscal 1Q.

Electrical equipment makers such as ABB and Schneider, with short- and long-cycle businesses exposed to heavy oil and gas, metals and mining industries, will target regional and end-user markets offering growth in 2016 after a weak 2015. Revenue strength from consumer, construction and automotive industries is expected to [BLANK], though high-voltage segment demand remains elusive. Firming European economies should be a bright spot vs. weakness in China, while dollar appreciation may curb North-American exports.

Biofuel producers may not get the demand boost they had sought from the Environmental Protection Agency's Renewable Fuel Standard. The EPA on May 29 [BLANK] to cut the 2015 biofuel target to 16.3 billion gallons, or 20.5% below the statutory level specified by Congress. The proposed 2016 target of 17.4 billion gallons is 21.8% below the congressionally mandated level. Despite lower targets, retailers may still need to increase sales of gasoline blends that contain more than 10% ethanol.

China hopes inventory controls and mid- to long-term coal-procurement contracts will stabilize coal prices. A strong coal price rally this year is likely to [BLANK] in losses for power plants. More price controls could follow in 2018, and industry consolidation may be encouraged to help implement the policies.

Prudential Financial is poised to shed its "too-big-to-fail" label and Federal Reserve oversight soon, providing EPS tailwinds through cost-savings and less onerous capital requirements. The Financial Stability Oversight Council under President Donald Trump is actively reducing the number of firms designated "SIFIs" and [BLANK] final timing for Prudential's de-designation review.

NetSuite's standalone growth prospects are weakening, meaning there's risk in terminating its deal with Oracle. Yet large shareholders such as T. Rowe Price said the offer of $109 a share is too low and won't [BLANK] the deal at this price. While NetSuite is still gaining market share in the cloud Enterprise Risk Management segment, its sales growth will likely taper amid its niche focus on midsized customers and increased competition from SAP and Oracle if it doesn't end up getting acquired by the company.

JinkoSolar's commissioning of a new 120-megawatt solar module plant in South Africa, its first outside of China, may indicate a rising trend for Chinese solar producers setting up production operations globally. The plant will [BLANK] the high-growth local South African market and comply with domestic manufacturing content rules. Production outside of China may also allow modules to be produced for the U.S. market and avoid newly imposed import tariffs.

JPMorgan, Bank of America and Citigroup are consistently the top three underwriters of U.S. corporate issues in recent years, aiding similar global rankings. Lower issuance has [BLANK] fees in 2018, a trend likely to extend in 3Q for the trio. JPMorgan and Citi are relatively stronger than BofA in the EMEA region, where HSBC and Barclays tend to lead.

Turkish banks' 4Q earnings may be dominated by discussion of rising bad debt and moderating loan growth. Bad debt increased by a quarter in the first eleven months of 2014 and [BLANK] $16.8 billion in November. Volume growth has almost halved to 18% year over year, lifting the bad debt ratio by 35 bps to 3.1%. This is the highest in four years. Halkbank lowered its 2014 earnings target by as much as 15% after increased provisioning needs in 3Q amid growing bad debt.

Spot prices for polysilicon, the key raw material for silicon solar panels, have risen throughout 2H as maintenance and upgrades take plants offline. Increased environmental inspections of plants in China also [BLANK] the supply of metallurgical silicon, a key precursor to polysilicon. Demand is rising for high-efficiency panels that require increased purity silicon, which is in limited supply within China. This demand may result in higher customer prepayments for producers of high-quality polysilicon.

Health insurers are pressing Congress to repeal the Obamacare-imposed excise tax on their industry, set to extract almost $150 billion over a 10-year period. However, a moratorium on the tax ends on Dec. 31, and Republicans were unable to pass legislation [BLANK] key ACA provisions ahead of a Sept. 30 budget deadline.

Higher commodity and freight costs aren't likely to abate for the rest of 2018, so we feel Dr Pepper Snapple's (DPS +0.8%) overall operating performance will continue to be weighed down. Despite a 6% net sales increase in its 1Q, the company's diluted EPS [BLANK] 8% because of these higher manufacturing expenses, along with promotional support. Dr Pepper Snapple expects to merge with Keurig Green Mountain by the end of 2Q, which will create a leading North American beverage company and a potentially more formidable competitor to segment leaders Coca-Cola and PepsiCo.

Intense rivalry and slowing economic growth are challenges for Asian airlines and could place Airbus and Boeing's backlogs at risk. GDP growth forecasts for China and Malaysia have been cut, while they've been [BLANK] higher for Japan, which is a bigger part of Boeing's backlog. AirAsia, a growing low-cost airline group in Southeast Asia, deferred A320s and A330s in 2014 as profit evaporated, raising risks to Airbus production rates. AirAsia makes up 8% of the A320 backlog and AirAsia X is 23% of the A330 backlog.

The net position of nickel speculators relative to LME market resumed its decline in the week ended Oct. 10 as growing stockpiles outshone positive U.S. economic data. Money managers have seen less positives for nickel, and [BLANK] their positions since the Sept. 8 peak. Since then the market has discounted the possibility of an immediate Philippine nickel ore export ban and LME stockpiles have swelled, up 11%. China continues to produce nickel pig iron and keep the market oversupplied.

Alliant's consolidated return on equity has exceeded 10.7% in recent years, more than 100 basis points above the average for U.S. utility peers, boosted by Wisconsin and FERC authorized ROEs above 10%. The company's Iowa utility also gets incentive authorized ROEs above 10% for some projects, [BLANK] the Marshalltown gas-fired plant under construction. FERC cuts to Midwest transmission ROEs may not have much impact on Alliant's consolidated ROE since transmission only contributes a small share of earnings.

The majority of DuPont's Nutrition & Biosciences segment sales are to customers in non-cyclical end markets. Revenue growth could continue to [BLANK] in the low- to mid-single-digit range in coming quarters, driven by modest price and volume gains. The more than $30 billion global market for nutrition and health ingredients could expand 3-7% over the next few years. More than 20% of the Nutrition & Biosciences segment represents faster growing higher-margin enzymes and biomaterials. Revenue growth for pharma, a smaller portion of sales, could top 10%, with margins above the segment average. Lower-margin, slower-growing soy-protein and sweetener product lines comprise less than 15% of revenue.

Scrutiny will grow in the coming months of companies' employee pension liabilities and, in some cases, widening deficits as rates in the U.K and internationally fall to new lows. Policymakers and regulators may [BLANK] how the issue can best be alleviated for corporates, given the likelihood of this situation lasting for many quarters. Royal Bank of Scotland took advantage of its FY15 kitchen-sinking operation to address its pensions deficit which, it expects, could result in some capital relief.

High demand from retailers seeking flagship locations and stores in Class-A malls are boosting leasing spreads and retail sales per square foot at top mall REITs. General Growth is seeing a number of retailers developing new store concepts, [BLANK] in stores left vacant after recent bankruptcies. L Brands and fast-fashion retailers are signing leases for larger spaces in Simon malls, replacing older stores with lower sales. Macerich is leasing more spaces to fast casual restaurants, notably Chipotle and Teavana.

The Sainsbury-Asda deal may raise antitrust concerns in 463 local areas, but the number of stores the parties may need to divest to appease regulators won't derail the deal, in our view. The U.K. regulator on Sept. 27 [BLANK] its preliminary findings about horizontal overlaps. Yet vertical concerns may complicate the path for approval.

Retail REIT occupancies rose to a record 95.4% in 4Q, well above the 89.8% national average reported by Reis. To maintain retailer demand, REITs [BLANK] to own locations that generate the highest tenant sales. As retailers focus on their most profitable stores and flagship locations, REITs are therefore able to quickly fill vacancies at higher rents, even if some retailers close stores. Mall REITs with strong tenant sales tend to operate at above-average occupancy vs. those with lower sales.

Mitsubishi Electric is armed with a war chest of funds for acquisitions as its cash balance widens the gap versus its debt obligations. Acquisitions may help the company accelerate its overseas expansion plans and [BLANK] its geographic revenue exposure. Potential overseas targets may become cheaper in terms of acquisition cost as the yen strengthens against global currencies. Investment opportunities in the U.K. may arise with sterling depreciation further reducing the price tag.

Biotech and pharma events include Vanda's Hetlioz Phase II jet-lag data in 4Q. AveXis will provide clarity in early January on the potential to file for accelerated approval with Phase I [BLANK] in spinal muscular atrophy type I after an FDA meeting in late 4Q and a similar update for Europe in 1H. Onconova's rigosertib Phase III trial in myelodysplastic syndromes has an interim analysis by early 2018. Anthera's Sollpura Phase III Result trial in exocrine pancreatic insufficiency will have final data in 1Q.

San Antonio and Houston were the two weakest senior-housing markets in 4Q, according to NIC. Properties in the Southwest region, which [BLANK] Dallas, had a 150-bp decline in occupancy from the prior year, with San Antonio down about 500 bps. Construction in the region surpassed 8.3% of existing inventory, well above the 5.5% ratio for the entire U.S. With oil-related employment concerns already reducing regional demand, current construction levels should further lower Southwest senior housing occupancy in 2016.

The "netback" per barrel, or revenue minus production costs, is only a margin calculation. Also called an operating netback or field netback, it takes into account production taxes and [BLANK] gains and losses, too. A higher netback implies a more profitable, efficient operation. Analysis of other metrics are needed to construct a more complete mosaic, such as reserve replacement cost, recycle ratio and asset intensity metrics.

Morgan Stanley, Goldman Sachs and Credit Suisse earn more from equities trading and from overall trading than global peers. Morgan Stanley's trading business is more equity [BLANK] than most global peers, except UBS. Credit Suisse and Goldman Sachs are more balanced. Morgan Stanley earned 24% of revenue from equities vs. a peer median 9% and 36% from overall trading in 2015. Equities trading has grown as portion of Morgan Stanley, Goldman and Credit Suisse's revenue by three to four percentage points from 2014.

Oral arguments are likely to take place by end-3Q in the appeal of AIG shareholders' lawsuit challenging the insurer's bailout terms. The government filed its final brief on May 18 after Hank Greenberg's Starr International [BLANK] to U.S. arguments in March. Both Starr and the U.S. are appealing the trial verdict. Starr argues the trial court erred in denying damages. The U.S. opposes those contentions and wants the liability ruling reversed. A ruling may come by year-end or early 2017.

Investors claim Braskem may be liable for as much as $31 million in ADR losses incurred after a March 11, 2015, news report implicated the company in Petrobras' bribery scandal. Likely due to the ADRs' quick price recovery, plaintiffs haven't sought to [BLANK] the class period. This may change if new details emerge from Brazil's investigation or Braskem's dealings with U.S. authorities. Following SEC subpoenas, the company has begun talks with the SEC and Justice Department on settlement of the graft allegations.

No new pyramid scheme allegations have been levied in the courts against Herbalife since April. Government investigations [BLANK]. The company may settle a suit brought by disgruntled sales representatives last year, and continues to face a securities class action by shareholders. The definition of a pyramid scheme is when income in a multilevel marketing plan is primarily derived from recruiting new sales team members, not from selling retail products.

As the media landscape continues to evolve, with digital platforms becoming increasingly prominent, live TV remains a critical part of the ecosystem, thanks mostly to sports programming. However, we believe live TV will continue to lose share to [BLANK] services as the content wars unfold.

Evaluating Biogen as part of Allergan's M&A due diligence may have merit, given the potential portfolio synergy with central nervous system (CNS) diseases. Allergan's [BLANK] CNS drugs don't overlap with Biogen's leading multiple sclerosis franchise, nor its pipeline of Alzheimer's agents. In fact, it would be complementary, though the Alzheimer's drugs carry significant clinical risks. Allergan will need to be comfortable with these risks, which may be more than other alternatives.

Appaloosa and Elliott Management asked a New York court to dismiss, or at least pause, an action brought against them by casino giant Caesars while a lawsuit they filed proceeds in Delaware. Caesars had sought a declaratory judgment against second-lien holders [BLANK] that certain asset transfers, such as data on rewards members, are legal. Caesars will respond, and a judge will rule after the motion is fully argued. Caesars moved to dismiss the Delaware claim on Sept. 23.

Costs for smart-meter rollout, designed to digitalize the grid, will continue to put upward pressure on household power prices in the U.K. Recent price hikes have been blamed on smart meters by major energy suppliers such as British Gas, Scottish Power, EON and SSE, which all raised their prices, citing rising costs for installing smart meters in millions of homes, alongside rising wholesale power and gas prices. As a result, the U.K. supplier cost index [BLANK] about 8% in the last six months. Historically, other government policies, such as carbon emission-reduction schemes, have also been associated with price hikes. The U.K. aims to install smart meters fitted in more than 30 million households and businesses by 2020.

Teva may miss out on $900 million of 2016 Ebitda due to a delay in completing the Allergan Generics deal, which had been expected to close in 1Q and has since been delayed until June. Due to the large number of abbreviated new drug applications in the respective portfolios, FTC and FDA review is taking longer than [BLANK]. Teva predicted that the Allergan Generics unit would contribute about $2.7 billion in Ebitda in 2016 with a 1Q closing. Without synergies, the combo may have $26 billion in pro forma revenue.

As Aldi expands rapidly across the U.S. and Lidl opens its first stores, grocery operators are working to understand the economic model of these hard-discount retailers. Kroger's small Ruler chain is an ongoing test to see if the company can [BLANK] return on invested capital objectives with this format. Currently, there are about 38 Ruler locations. If successful, it may be a weapon in Kroger's arsenal to expand in existing and adjacent markets and compete with other hard-discount operators.

The iShares Broad USD High Yield Corporate Debt ETF (USHY) could hurt bond managers who are used to easily outperforming passive ETFs, which tend to hold only the most liquid constituents. USHY is much broader than HYG, holding twice the amount of issues and issuers, which has helped it (and its index prior to [BLANK]) outperform a majority of active high-yield funds.

Futures positions indicate gold, silver and bond prices will increase, unlike the dollar. Metals and some ratios, notably in gold vs. silver, are [BLANK] for what would typically be considered crisis levels, leaning too far on the risk-off pendulum, in our view. The amount of silver per ounce of gold has surpassed the peak from the Lehman-bankruptcy era. Adding fuel to potential mean reversion, CME-traded gold and silver futures are the most net-short as a percentage of open interest since 2006. They're also quasi dollar longs. Greenback weakness should turn silver into a metals-recovery leader. Contrarily, net positions in Treasury-coupon futures are also the shortest ever on the expectation of increasing yields, the opposite of what occurred in the financial crisis.

Some U.S. nuclear and coal power plants owned by utilities such as NRG, FirstEnergy, Dynegy and Entergy might get short-lived revenue boosts from new federal policy from President Donald Trump's Energy Department, but long-term solutions appear elusive. Congress may attempt to [BLANK] the development of advanced nuclear-power technology. Wholesale-market rule changes from FERC could be prioritized in 2019, but proposing and finalizing a rule can take a year or more. Nuclear power has already received billions of dollars from U.S. states and has a better chance of securing more policy support.

Long-running declines in voice and low-bandwidth data revenue and competition with cable companies will persist in 2018 for incumbent wireline carriers such as CenturyLink, Frontier and Windstream. While high-speed data continues to grow, the declines will make it difficult to [BLANK] free cash flow.

Valero has an excellent liquidity position that provides significant protection against a severe industry downturn or other financial shock. Strong operating cash flow of $4.6 billion for the 12 months ended March 31 enable the company to [BLANK] a solid cash balance of $4.7 billion. With no bonds coming due until February 2020, and cash on hand that covers debt maturities for the next 15 years, liquidity will depend on management's discretionary use of cash.

The average cash cost of a new copper mine is currently $1.41 a pound, well below the $2.55 price of the metal. Due to this large differential, copper miners may boost production by about 14% by 2020 from the [BLANK] 2016 total. Most of that additional copper likely won't reach the market before 2018. The potential restart of mines that were taken offline when prices were close to $2 a pound may add even more to global supply.

Dollar General 's operating margin likely stays pressured from higher wages and a growing consumable mix that puts pressure on gross margin. Better-aligned inventory, down 1% on a per-store basis, at the end of 2Q is [BLANK]. Still, sales must improve at higher-margin categories such as apparel and home to help boost gross margin. Rising traffic on its value proposition, coupled with expanded consumable assortments, are key to achieving a low-single-digit same-store-sales gain.

Unit volume for advanced auto batteries for hybrids, plug-ins and electric vehicles is expected to increase 26% globally in 2017, based on just-auto.com estimates, ramping up acceptance as automakers move away from diesel engines. While just-auto expects diesel engine demand will decline in western Europe through 2030, advanced batteries are [BLANK] by historically low oil prices. The largest gains globally are forecast for 2020-25, including 93% worldwide growth and 115% in western Europe.

The complaint that according to reports Qatar has lodged at the WTO, arguing that the Saudi-led embargo of June 2016 violates WTO obligations, will probably evolve into a trade dispute. That could last at least one year, but parties would likely try to [BLANK] a non-judicial settlement beforehand. This initial request would simply open formal consultations with Saudi Arabia, Bahrain and the United Arab Emirates. If talks are unsuccessful, Qatar could move to the litigation phase by the start of 4Q at the earliest.

NBC's cable network ratings rose 0.2% in 3Q, as MSNBC's gains offset USA Network's losses, according to Nielsen. USA Network's viewership [BLANK] 7% due in part to a 35% ratings plunge for the TV show "Mr. Robot," despite receiving overwhelmingly positive reviews. MSNBC continues to benefit from the election cycle, with a 107% gain. NBC Sports Network ratings soared 105% thanks to the Olympics and Nascar. Syfy fell 31% as TV show "Z Nation" viewership slumped 30%. E! rose 3% and Bravo gained 4%.

The U.S. rig count rose by nine to 1,927 in the week ended Oct. 24, according to Baker Hughes. Oil-targeted rigs rose by five after [BLANK] a 19-rig slide the prior week. Rigs targeting gas rose by four and even with their two-week increase of 12 rigs, they're still down 11.2% this year. Drilling may slow if oil prices continue to decline and exploration and production companies are forced to cut capital spending to boost free cash flow.

Worker accident rates may indicate relative operational risk for gold miners. Companies with high accident rates may [BLANK] more down-time and risk fines and lawsuits, in addition to potential for other major incidents such as spills. New Gold and Kinross report the lowest lost time incident rates (LTIR), and no fatalities for three years. Newcrest and Newmont report low LTIR and below-median fatality rates. Harmony, Sibanye Gold and AngloGold lag behind, with LTIR x4-5 the peer median.

Astec, Granite Construction, Vulcan Materials, Caterpillar and other engineering firms and equipment makers would likely see no increase in federal funding for transportation projects without a long-term deal in Congress to pay for highways. Congress is considering a tax on U.S. companies' foreign earnings, among other options, to [BLANK] highways for the next six years. Absent a deal, firms may not get long-term funding certainty. Road-industry revenue comes from government highway and transit funding.

A flurry of potential managed-care M&A may prompt customer turnover at pharmacy benefits managers. A hypothetical purchase of Humana, which operates its own benefits manager, by Aetna could [BLANK] CVS Health to lose Aetna as a client. Cigna may use Humana's benefits manager services, rather than UnitedHealth's OptumRx, if it were the purchaser. A potential acquisition of Cigna by Anthem, which uses Express Scripts as its benefits manager, may allow Express Scripts to add Cigna's members.

Though not under direct Federal Reserve oversight, First Republic's asset size subjects it to some U.S. big-bank rules. The bank could dodge stress-test and living-will requirements if Congress raises the asset threshold [BLANK] tougher oversight. First Republic may also see regulatory burdens reduced if Congress eases some Dodd-Frank rules. Expected retirement-advice rules could impact the bank's investment-advisory business and the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau is working on overdraft fee rules.

SunPower has the highest-efficiency silicon solar panels in mass production, with its X-Series modules boasting a conversion rate of 21.5%, driving higher power output than competing panels. This lead is under increasing pressure as competitors [BLANK] an expanding residential solar segment. SolarCity is testing a module at 22%, with production expected in mid-2017. The use of passivated emitter rear cell (PERC) technology is boosting competitor panel efficiency to about 18.5% from 16-17%.

While the pact between pharmacy-benefit manager Express Scripts to exclusively reimburse AbbVie's hepatitis C drugs threw biotech stocks into declines at the end of 2014, such an agreement had been likely since August. Express Scripts' 2015 drug exclusion list, which was [BLANK] early in the month, suggested it would modify which hepatitis C agents to reimburse as drugs are approved and prices become known. The extent to which AbbVie pledged to reduce the net price of Viekira Pak to secure the arrangement isn't clear.

Automakers in China may extend incentives to offset a 2.5 percentage point increase in the sales tax for small passenger vehicles. This will likely [BLANK] into car companies' earnings this year. China raised the tax to 7.5% this year, from 5% in 2016. Wholesale car retail surged about 25% in 2H last year as buyers were expecting the tax to be fully restored to 10% after it was cut in October 2015. This probably shifted significant sales from this year into 2016.

Belle, Daphne and C.banner, China's major retailers of fashion shoes, are struggling to revive sales growth as a weak economy encourages shoppers to seek bargains online and at cheaper stores. Belle and Daphne [BLANK] their sharpest declines in same-store sales during their latest fiscal quarter, falling 16% and 15.9%, respectively. An increase in sales of Nike and Adidas in China may offset further declines in Belle's fashion-shoe sales to support consensus estimates for flat revenue this year.

Sandoz's Zarxio is sold in the U.S. at a 15% discount to the gross price of the Amgen's Neupogen, far below the 45% at which biosimilar copies of Merck's Remicade have launched in Europe. Both Novartis's Sandoz and Amgen will [BLANK] further discounts and rebates to payers, making the net price much lower. It's unclear whether Sandoz is offering bigger rebates than Amgen.

Poland's central bank restarted the monetary easing cycle by lowering interest rates by 50 bps to a record low of 2% on Oct. 8, driven by the growing concern about deflation and mounting pressure on GDP expansion. This reduction follows the rate-cut cycle in November 2012 to July 2013 that [BLANK] 225 bps. The nation's banks will most likely need to readjust their business strategies to mitigate the pressure on their net interest margins.

E.ON's aggressive power hedging will likely protect it against further declines in wholesale power prices until 2017. At the end of the first quarter, E.ON [BLANK] forward all of its power output in central Europe for 2015-16 at 50 euros ($56) per megawatt hour and 38 euros/MWh. These levels exceed the closing wholesale price of 34 euro/MWh for 2015 and 32 euro/MWh for 2016. Steag is less well-protected. Steag sold forward 70% of 2016 and 30% of 2017 power vs. E.ON's 100% for 2016 and 60% to 70% for 2017.

If OPEC's tentative agreement to curtail output is confirmed at the Nov. 30 meeting, near-term downside to the gold-oil-price ratio may ensue. Conversely, uncertainty about how the cut will be enforced, and non-member production commitments, [BLANK] longer-term gold-oil ratio support. The ratio was at 25x as of Nov. 25, down from a 2016 peak of 47.6x on Feb. 11. OPEC is attempting to address systemic oversupply resulting from Iran's return to pre-sanction production, amid resilient Russian and Saudi Arabian output.

Intense telecom and streaming competition, along with hurricanes may curb Comcast's subscriber metrics. The company [BLANK] 100,000-150,000 video subscriber losses but still projects a gain in customer relationships thanks to broadband investments (DOCSIS 3.1) and 55% of its customers on X1.
