Also, Comcast has also acquired 200,000 wireless customers. NBC faces a difficult quarter in film with domestic box office slipping 41%. Broadcast will also be hurt by tough Olympics comparisons.

CGRPs for migraine may cost upward of $14,000 a year, based on historical therapy prices, 7x that of Botox. The current migraine market is [BLANK] by triptans, which on average cost $14,000 if patients have 10 migraine headaches a month. Botox costs $2,000 a year, according to Allergan CEO Brent Saunders. However, the drug failed in episodic migraines, meaning CGRPs could command a hefty premium. Taking the maximum daily dose of triptans pushes the average cost to $40,000 a year.

Major hotel markets in the Americas are seeing swings in revenue per available room, mostly due to currency volatility and tourist events. This [BLANK] Canada, Mexico and Brazil. STR's monthly statistics reflect the impact from changes in supply and demand. An increase in U.S. tourists is fueling Mexico's revpar boom and Canada's improving performance. Brazil's Rio Olympics led to a short-term demand jump, yet challenges such as a hotel glut, weak economic outlook and the Zika outbreak may damp the effect.

Chinese gas utilities face shrinking profit margins due to lower oil prices and slowing property-market development. Average [BLANK] 12-month Ebit margin for the top-five gas utilities dropped to 16% in 2015 from 18% in 2013. Companies focused on gas for vehicles had the biggest declines, as low oil prices discouraged vehicle owners from converting to natural gas. A slower property market reduced growth for pipeline connections and utilities' income from this high-margin segment.

Post-3Q Earnings Outlook: The outlook for loan-loss reversals is key to Itau's 2018, with a pro forma decline in the coverage ratio back to 1Q14 pre-recession levels (178%), driven entirely by reserve releases, implying a boost to pretax profit of 10 billion reais. A lower cost of risk is crucial, given greater margin pressure, with rates falling to near-record lows and still-weak loan demand [BLANK] NII growth. Strong demand for investment products should continue to drive low- to mid-single-digit fee growth.

Fixed-income ETFs that employ smart beta strategies or active management are coming to market at a record pace as issuers bet on wider adoption, despite disappointing results so far. Almost 90% of the $635 billion in fixed-income ETF assets are still held in products [BLANK] market-value-weighted indexes.

Lockheed has the potential to add hundreds more F-35 orders in the coming years as aging fleets and global hostilities accelerate international sales campaigns. The company is steadily [BLANK] F-35 costs and profitability, and a stronger foreign order book could bring lofty production and margin expectations closer to reality.

The bond portfolio of the European life insurers has shown a decline in its credit quality in the past three years, mainly driven by downgrades for certain bonds and a strategic shift into lower-rated assets in a search for higher yields. Insurers may [BLANK] willing to seek higher yields in non-standard structures, such as direct lending or private placements if interest rates remain low. Insurers with BBB rated bonds or below may face challenges to maintain low capital requirements under Solvency II rules.

China's hotel occupancy rates are improving, driven by rising demand which is also mitigating a supply glut. The pickup in domestic and international tourists is driving hotel revpar growth in smaller cities while South Korea's tourism boom remains [BLANK] on China's ban on tour groups venturing there. These patterns may change as Chinese travelers venture further abroad, and more frequently. STR's monthly Asia hotel data tracks recoveries in India and China, and the impact of Chinese tourists.

Eli Lilly and Pfizer, with new drugs contributing less than 5% to 1Q sales, could nevertheless achieve annualized growth of 39% through 2020. Pfizer's gains could be driven by the breast cancer drug Ibrance, whose sales may further be [BLANK] by its potential use in combination with Merck's Keytruda and Novartis' Mekinist. Eli Lilly's growth hinges on the lung cancer drug Cyramza, which could face pressure from Bristol-Myers' Opdivo, and securing favorable access for its recent launches in diabetes.

The potential for more flexible trucking hours-of-service rules in the electronic logging device era doesn't deter our view of a prolonged truckload rate cycle. While changes could add productivity enhancements, [BLANK] a major economic shock, we believe the current state of robust freight demand and limited driver availability will continue to keep capacity tight through 2019.

Additional selling of merchandise directly to consumers should continue to drive apparel brands' margin expansion in 2015. Sales generated at company-owned stores and online often [BLANK] substantially better gross margins than the traditional wholesale channels, mainly due to the higher prices paid by consumers. Direct-to-consumer sales at VF, the owner of the North Face and Vans among others, expanded more than 100 bps every quarter in 2014, contributing to margin improvement.

Iowa's importance in selecting the president has helped to protect the Renewable Fuel Standard despite bipartisan interest in reducing the EPA program's requirements. Because of agriculture's importance in Iowa, candidates from both parties have [BLANK] to support biofuels in hopes of winning over farmers. Yet Ted Cruz's victory in Iowa's Republican caucus on Feb. 1 suggests the influence of the RFS may be waning. Cruz and an expanding bipartisan group of lawmakers support legislation to reform the program.

Sales performance for major U.S. packaged-food categories was similar to historical averages during the four weeks ended Dec. 31, all-channel IRI data show. Categories that [BLANK] better include those that benefit from an increasing preference for snacking, such as spices and seasonings and salty snacks.

Duluth's focus on increasing revenue and brand awareness through the expansion of its physical retail presence brings near-term challenges for its e-commerce growth and profitability. The uncertainty about its ability to re-accelerate sales without deeper promotions [BLANK] concerns about its earnings outlook.

The 340B program, which allows safety-net hospitals to obtain discounts of as much as 50% on medicines given on an outpatient basis, has become increasingly contentious. 340B sales [BLANK] $16 billion in 2016. The Republican-led Congress is revisiting the 340B statute, while the Trump administration is scaling back Obama-era rules and dramatically cutting hospitals' 340B reimbursement.

Takeda's Millennium is awaiting a trial decision in its lawsuit against generic-drug makers Sandoz, Intas, Actavis, Apotex, Acord and Teva over proposed copies of Millennium's myeloma drug Velcade. The lawsuit centers on a patent covering the bortezomib mannitol ester, Velcade's active ingredient, [BLANK] in January 2022. Velcade is also covered by a compound patent that expires in 2017 that the generics don't contest. Velcade brought Takeda $946 million in 2014, or 5% of its revenue.

Kansas City Southern took the express track to investment-grade status, moving to low BBB ratings in 2013 from a single B in 2010. The company remains committed to [BLANK] its investment-grade rating, prioritizing higher capital spending and shareholder rewards over balance-sheet strengthening. Striking a balance between shareholder rewards and investing for growth when allocating capital may help the company build upon the improvement it saw to its credit profile in 3Q.

St Barbara made the grade as the best-performing mid-tier gold producer in BI's peer group during the past 12 months. This follows CEO Bob Vassie resolving its Gold Ridge mine issues in the Solomon islands, which [BLANK] its shares skyrocketing. Evolution Mining, a gold miner with copper as a byproduct, and low cash costs due to a weaker Australian dollar vs. the U.S. dollar, was the second-best performer. Eldorado Gold's had poor cash flow and higher costs led to its worst performer status.

Buyers of Kobe Steel products hit by revelations of falsified quality data may turn to U.S. and European rivals, including Constellium and Norsk Hydro. The global aluminum market won't be [BLANK] as Japan is a small share.

Auto suppliers with high exposure to the U.S. are experiencing elevated, though flattening, demand and increasing in-vehicle content, which drives revenue. The combination of large volume and increased content of safety and technology components will [BLANK] revenue and margins. Suppliers will accelerate the development of high-tech parts as autonomous-driving features become a priority for automakers. U.S. new-vehicle unit sales rose 0.4% to an all-time high in 2016, surpassing 2015's record.

Washington's partisan divide threatens sustained increases in U.S. defense spending, which would limit revenue and profit growth at contractors such as Lockheed Martin, Boeing, Raytheon, Northrop Grumman, General Dynamics, BAE Systems and Huntington Ingalls. The president's base defense budget of $574 billion requires [BLANK] or repealing sequester, while the House and Senate want to spend more. Democrats, increasingly strident after the Obamacare vote, want more social spending that Republicans will resist.

Average daily rates measure revenue per occupied room. Higher ADRs [BLANK] profitability more than occupancy gains because there is no relative rise in variable costs. Rates vary based on guest profile, seasonality, brand, competition and location. Emerging markets such as China and India have lower ADRs due to oversupply and a higher proportion of cheaper hotels. The U.S. and U.K. have higher, stable rates because of a balanced mix of corporate and leisure guests.

T-Mobile was charged with excessive billing for third-party services by the FCC and the FTC, which sets up the potential for all carriers to face millions of dollars in reimbursements for these charges. There are three likely FCC suit scenarios for T-Mobile in terms of how it could [BLANK] out, though the carrier is seeking to dismiss the suit. AT&T, Sprint and Verizon may also face large reimbursements as the industry scrambles to reform its practices.

Senior gold producers posted EPS declines of 29% on average in 3Q, following cost cuts designed to keep pace with falling gold prices, which are down 3.6% vs. the prior-year period. Consensus had [BLANK] a decrease of 27%. Silver producers reported a 6% EPS decline vs. estimates of 33%, following a 8.1% drop in the price of silver. Companies continued to focus on cost-cutting during earnings reports, as a reaction to falling stock prices that have trailed metals in the past few years.

The Federal Trade Commission and Justice Department screen proposed M&A to prevent deals that are likely to create, enhance or facilitate the exercise of market power. Jointly [BLANK] "horizontal merger guidelines" (HMG) set out the analytical process both agencies use to undertake the assessment. The HMG describe the methods and economic tools used to assess M&A and factors that may justify clearing a deal. They are meant to assist the business community by increasing the transparency of the agencies' process.

Giving shoppers value via promotions or price cuts hurts retailer margins, but deals are vital to woo shoppers. Sales at discounters Ross Stores and the Marmaxx unit of TJX rose 3% in 3Q, while broader apparel retailers [BLANK]. More than 40% of respondents to a Kantar Retail survey of 4,046 people in December said "getting a good deal" or "spending as little money as possible" was most important when shopping. Under 30% of respondents reported feeling better about their jobs, finances or wealth.

China's plan to combine its banking and insurance regulators will help plug the gaps between the two watchdogs, paring risk yet limiting revenue growth. It's also [BLANK] bank shareholding rules to limit business intervention from secondary-market investors. Foreign banks may gain market share after rules on wealth products and funding for these lenders were also eased.

Six of the nine apartment REITs raised their 2014 earnings outlook following 2Q results due to strong seasonal renter demand. Apartment REIT 2Q [BLANK] funds from operations per share rose 0.7% yoy, led by Essex Property Trust and Equity Residential which benefited from strength in Northern California and Seattle. Washington, D.C., is the only major market in which apartment REITs operate that had yoy revenue declines, due to excess supply.

President Donald Trump and his administration have called for a revival of the Glass-Steagall Act, a law that separated investment and commercial banking. In January, Treasury Secretary Steve Mnuchin said that while the administration doesn't want to bring back the 1933 law, it [BLANK] a "21st century" version. But Republicans plan to roll back Dodd-Frank, which means the odds of Glass-Steagall legislation passing are slim in 2017. In the longer term, regulators could impose their own version of Glass-Steagall.

Issuers and investors are likely to gain more clarity in 4Q over how EU regulators will encourage greater convergence in covered bond markets. Regulators have launched a market study arising out of its 1Q consultation and public hearing, shortly after which it [BLANK] it would seek to build on and export best practices from countries with strong covered bond markets such as Germany. The European Commission may issue voluntary-led measures or publish formal proposals to regulate covered bond markets directly.

French retail sales don't seem to have been calamitous in November, though several sectors were weak. The end-of-month protests [BLANK] to hurt confidence and to some degree revenue going into December. Spending should peak late, with Christmas on a Tuesday, leaving room for last-minute food purchases after the fourth December weekend.

Deloitte's 2016 holiday forecast of 3.6%-4% growth may be optimistic, given recent retailer sales trends and waning consumer sentiment. Holiday sales likely come at the expense of large incumbents, [BLANK] Bed Bath & Beyond, Macy's and Pier 1 Imports, as smaller, more nimble retailers take advantage of shoppers' interest in differentiated assortments and experiences. E-commerce may swell at a strong 17%-19% to nearly $100 billion, which will further pressure traditional retailers as sales shift to Amazon.com.

Hospital operators may see significant near-term disruption as President Donald Trump, HHS Secretary Alex Azar and CMS head Seema Verma try to focus the U.S. health-policy debate on increased price transparency in 2019. Senate Republicans struggled to [BLANK] key Obamacare provisions and convert Medicaid into a per-capita cap program during 2017. Another attempt is unlikely now that Democrats will have a majority in the House of Representatives, but a Dec. 14 U.S. District Court judge declaring the ACA unconstitutional could, pending appeal, send Congress back to the drawing board. Such plans risk increasing the number of uninsured Americans in the near term during a transition period, thus pressuring hospital operators' profit margins.

Office transaction cap rates rose from record lows as volume shrank in February, according to Real Capital Analytics. Urban office deals [BLANK] 5.4%, up 30 bps from January's level, which was the lowest since at least 2000. Urban office deal volume was down 38% from January and 25% year-over-year. Suburban offices also traded at lower prices during the month, with cap rates rising 20 bps to 7.1%. It was the first time suburban deals traded above 7% since February 2016.

Low farm commodity prices may trigger some revenue protection policy payments, though harvest yields may be sufficient to allow insurers and reinsurers to earn modest profits. U.S. crop conditions through the third week of August were largely favorable, with 72% of the corn crop judged to be in good or excellent condition, [BLANK] with a five-year average of 56% for the same period. The comparable number for soybean was 71%, vs. a 57% five-year average.

Vectrus is likely to keep a federal contract that may make up 8% of its annual revenue after a protest by losing bidder Lockheed Martin failed Dec. 11. Vectrus in August [BLANK] the $517 million deal for Army Corps of Engineers technology services over incumbent Lockheed. Vectrus's 2014 revenue guidance is $1.15 billion to $1.2 billion. The prior contract was less than 1% of Lockheed revenue. Protests are pending on another recent Vectrus award, a $411 million Greenland military base services deal.

The treatment of multiple myeloma, the second most common blood cancer, has seen one revolution already with the introduction of Velcade (a proteasome inhibitor) and Revlimid (an immunomodulator) significantly raising survival rates. Drug sales in this disease category were $9.4 billion in 2015, and are [BLANK] by consensus to grow to $20.2 billion in 2020. Sales drivers are Revlimid's use in newly-diagnosed patients and the new antibody therapies Darzalex and Empliciti, both approved in 4Q15.

Post-2Q Earnings Outlook: Clean Harbors' results were solid, though perhaps a bit disappointing in light of improving cyclical trends. Ebitda [BLANK] 9% year-over-year, slightly below 1Q's growth rate, though still consistent with 2017 guidance (which was affirmed). The Ebitda gain was powered by increased disposal volume in Technical Services and signs of a rebound in energy-market activity, particularly in the U.S. Safety-Kleen continues to grow, though margins were dampened by challenges at two re-refineries.

The long road to bank-system rehabilitation will see important roles played by bondholders and strategic investors, potentially including the Qatari Investment Authority, the European Stability Mechanism, private equity and hedge funds and some of Italy's own, larger financial institutions. In a similar fashion to restructuring lenders, including RBS, Deutsche Bank and Credit Suisse, investors will have to [BLANK] several years before Italian banks begin to approach normalized levels of profitability.

Japan Display's sales rose 120% in the quarter ended in June driven by continued LCD demand from Apple along with rising shipments of higher-resolution displays to Chinese smartphone makers. Screens with in-cell touch technology likely aided sales growth, accounting for more than 70% of units [BLANK] to Asian customers. Sales of such screens helped sales in Korean peer LG Display's mobile segment rise 7% sequentially in the same period.

China Holdings is focusing on cost savings and increasing its mass-market business ahead of its Cotai property opening in 2H. Revenue reached an inflection point in 3Q16, but [BLANK] the trajectory hinges on MGM's ability to increase its mass-market gambling revenue. MGM Cotai should offer more mainstream appeal, given its added hotel, dining, retail and entertainment outlets, boosting revenue and profit growth. It continues to focus on cost savings to widen Ebitda margins.

Macy's, J.C. Penney, Kohl's and other U.S. department store sales may have recovered after a slowdown in October, according to First Data's non-cash point-of-sale data. Sales growth [BLANK] to 2.1% in mid-November vs. an 80-bp drop last month. The pickup was driven by a 3.2% increase in transactions, yet the average amount spent fell 1%. This implies that price cuts may have led to more sales. The bulk of November sales are still to come as holiday shopping begins.

Building materials companies are trading in three tiers on a price-to-earnings basis. Those at the highest premium, with ratios above 20x, [BLANK] Vulcan Materials, Cementos Argos, UltraTech Cement and Martin Marietta. Multiples in the 15x-20x range include Sika, LafargeHolcim, Cemex and CRH. The lowest, at below 15x, include Dangote, HeidelbergCement and Saint-Gobain. Weaker growth in Africa is affecting Dangote, while HeidelbergCement and Saint-Gobain are mired in doubt around M&A.

Vertex's Kalydeco label expansion to cystic fibrosis with R117H mutation may get EU regulator CHMP's opinion April 23-24, after the company was asked for more information in February. The CHMP issued first questions in October, when it [BLANK] if subgroup analysis is appropriate. The FDA approved it for patients ages 6 and older. The Phase III trial didn't meet the primary goal, yet showed more benefit in those 18 and older. AbbVie-Galapagos's GLPG1837, which acts similarly, will have Phase I data in 3Q.

Quality Care Properties, Care Capital Properties and Omega Healthcare Investors, which are the only REITs focused 100% on skilled nursing, were the worst performers in the peer group in 2016 through Nov. 15. Shares of each [BLANK] by at least 14%. The skilled-nursing business is facing challenges from its exposure to government reimbursement and changes in the way operators are paid. These risks do not transfer to asset classes such as senior housing and medical office buildings.

China could use public-private partnerships to accelerate the deployment of electric-vehicle charging stations, which would probably cut costs for the government and help boost EV sales. Similar ventures [BLANK] automakers are common in developed markets, such as a recent tie-up between Nissan and Hydro-Quebec in Canada.

Momentum in 3Q box office sales may be unsustainable, ending with about $2.3 billion in box-office gross receipts, down about 10% lower vs. last year. Receipts were up 1% through Aug. 5, but the summer slate was mostly front-loaded with blockbusters, [BLANK] a somewhat underwhelming lineup for the rest of the season.

The number of life science technology M&A deals is likely to surpass last year's total on a dearth of bolt-on acquisitions. The industry posted its second-largest year since the financial crisis in total purchases in 2015, when deals [BLANK] almost $15 billion in market value were completed. Only about $7 billion in acquisitions occurred in 1H, dominated by Thermo's $4 billion purchase of FEI. Yet the industry has undertaken 19 deals to date vs. 26 for all of the prior year.

A late-2018 decline in REIT shares is pricing in the risk of an economic slowdown in 2019. REITs had [BLANK] supportive ground with the 10-year Treasury yield at or slightly above 3%, but a slowing economy would hurt real estate demand. If the economy holds up, REIT shares should be supported by the lower 10-year yield, which is 50 bps below its peak.

A higher percentage of shorter-term loans positively correlates with banks' interest-rate sensitivity. Canadian banks are [BLANK] higher domestic and U.S. policy rates, while longer-term rates remain relatively low. Among BI-tracked Canadian banks, National Bank of Canada and Scotiabank have the largest proportion of short-term loans. RBC, Bank of Montreal and Toronto-Dominion, which have higher leverage to U.S. rates, average about 19% of loans with maturities under 12 months.

Fintech firms may see stricter cybersecurity regulation and resilience-testing than more-established financial players. The volume of data they [BLANK] via new digital infrastructure is about three times more vulnerable to attack than other sectors, according to the European Commission. Regulators are considering imposing further rules on top of the burdens that the Network Information Security Directive will bring starting May 9, 2018, which include a potentially unlimited fine for breach.

India aims to raise annual coal production to 1.5 billion tons while halting imports of the fuel by 2020. To [BLANK] this, the government announced in late February the opening up of the coal sector to private investment. This would likely improve the country's overall mining efficiency and power supply.

Dominion Resources Inc.'s planned $6 billion purchase of Questar adds to the gas build-out that it sees as a driver of faster growth than the core electric utility, and allows it to stay mostly in low-risk regulated businesses. Over 50% of Dominion's Ebitda is in slow-growth electric, while the Virginia service territory [BLANK] a solid operational and regulatory base. The utility's master limited partnership, Dominion Midstream, has outperformed peers due to a strong pipeline of drop-down, or transferred assets.

Toyota and Honda combine to occupy seven of the top 10 spots on the list of highest miles-per-gallon vehicles of all time, with five of those cars 2014 model year offerings. The 2014 Prius, Prius c, Lexus CT 200h and Honda Accord get more than 70 mpg (unadjusted, laboratory-tested, [BLANK] city and highway), and trail only the 2000 Honda Insight as the best of all-time. The two General Motors vehicles on the list sold in 1986 and 1994 and weighed less than 2,000 pounds.
